headline: Luck vs. Skill: Seeking the Secret of Your Success
text: THERE may be no topic that more reliably divides liberals and conservatives than the relationship between success and luck. Many conservatives celebrate market success as an almost inevitable consequence of talent and effort. Liberals, by contrast, like to remind us that even talented people who work hard sometimes fall on hard times through no fault of their own.

headline: Wanting to Kill
text: I REMEMBER the phone call from my mother distinctly. It came in February of 1980. I was 19, a high school dropout working as a tool-and-die apprentice, living in my hometown of Bridgeport, Conn.

headline: Mr. Negative vs. Mr. Complacent
text: DURING the dog days of last summer’s debt ceiling negotiations, with Washington gridlocked and the president’s approval ratings slumping, a narrative coalesced among disappointed liberals. President Obama was failing, they decided, because he was too moderate, too reasonable and too conciliatory. He didn’t have the ideological confidence required to actually fight for liberalism, or the brazenness required to really tear the Republicans apart.

headline: Two Central Banks and the Sound of Silence
text: WHEN is no news big news? When central bankers, confronted by a crisis in this post-Lehman world, convene and take no action.

headline: Get It Right on Gas

headline: Finding the Price of Fairness
text: KENNETH R. FEINBERG, who styles himself as “a lawyer and mediator in one,” has made a career of handling hot potatoes and moving them from politicians’ plates to his own. At moments of national disaster, he has embraced the trying task of applying mere money to sustain and comfort the survivors and to bind the wounds of the afflicted.

headline: At Last, a Medal for Guatemala
text: LONDON — History was made in the 20-kilometer racewalk Saturday: Guatemala finally won a medal.

headline: At the Right Intersection
text: I’M a fifth-generation Texan, named after my grandfather, Bert. But I didn’t know my real name until kindergarten. My family used to call me Bertito, which means Little Bert in Spanish. Then they shortened it to Tito, so when the teacher called the roll and said Bert, I didn’t know she meant me.

headline: The Remains of a Home for the Mentally Ill

text: FROM a very young age I remember dancing around our family living room in Montebello, Calif., to the music of Harry Belafonte and Miriam Makeba, inspired by my parents’ love of world arts and culture.

headline: Massachusetts Takes On Health Costs
text: Give Massachusetts credit for setting audacious health care goals. It took the lead in guaranteeing near-universal health insurance coverage for its residents, providing a template for the federal reforms to follow.

headline: Too Many Prisoners
text: The Justice Department in its recent annual report on federal sentencing issues wisely acknowledged that public safety can be maximized without maximizing prison spending. As it noted, the growing federal prison population, now more than 218,000 inmates, and a prison budget of almost $6.2 billion are “incompatible with a balanced crime policy and are unsustainable.”

headline: Letters: When Tax Rates Touched the Sky
text: To the Editor:

headline: Working While Sick
text: More than 40 million American workers get no paid sick leave. They have to work when ill or take unpaid sick days, which can lead to financial hardship, or, worse, dismissal. The best way to address this workplace and public health problem is with a national law requiring businesses to provide paid sick leave — a normal benefit for workers in at least 145 countries.

headline: Feeling Right, Finally
text: BOSTON — Justin Morneau batted cleanup here Thursday for the Minnesota Twins. He had two hits off a left-hander, including an opposite-field double, and the Twins’ pitchers shut out the Boston Red Sox. It was something like a perfect day, once routine, now precious.

headline: At London Games, This Is Fútbol
text: It looked like any other fútbol game — thousands of chanting fans packed into a picturesque stadium. The constant roar of the crowd provided the soundtrack for a show, taking place below on the perfect green grass. When the camera panned the field, however, ponytails were in abundance (and, no, it was not Zlatan Ibrahimovic, Philippe Mexes, Martin Caceres and Ronaldinho kicking around).

headline: Pictures of the Day From London | August 4, 2012

headline: Mariners’ Hernandez Stifles Yankees in Shutout
text: Felix Hernandez raised his arms and kissed the italicized names tattooed on each of his wrists — the left one for his son, Jeremy; the right one for his daughter, Mia. He first pitched in the Bronx as a 21-year-old in 2007, before the tattoos, but the posture and pose of a dominating performance have since become familiar.

headline: Raising a Future Olympian? What Are the Odds?
text: LEEDS, England — Like any parent watching the Olympics, I have often wondered if I might someday see my child wearing the national colors while standing on a medal podium. When my wife informed me the other day that our 2-year-old daughter had climbed out of her crib for the first time — sticking the landing as well, it seems — my curiosity was piqued even further.

headline: Challenging Batters and Physics Experts Alike
text: On April 29, 2011, in the first inning against the Toronto Blue Jays, the Yankees right-hander Freddy Garcia threw a low split-finger fastball to Juan Rivera that struck him out swinging.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 5
text: The latest unemployment report offered a mixed bag on the economy with stronger than expected job growth combined with a small uptick in the jobless rate. Lawmakers from both parties will stop by the Sunday shows at the beginning of a five-week Congressional vacation to discuss the long list of unresolved issues and what the economic numbers mean for the presidential campaign.

headline: For Umenyiora, Contentment at Last
text: ALBANY — They laughed at Jerry Reese when he drafted Osi Umenyiora in 2003. Who was Umenyiora, the news media wondered, and why was he selected in the second round — 56th over all out of tiny Troy State?

headline: Round One in Sprints to Jamaica; Briton Takes 10,000
text: LONDON — Heading into the Olympics, America’s top sprinters were determined to break the Jamaican stranglehold on the 100 meters. Jamaica’s women swept the event four years ago, and the United States had won only one medal in the women’s 100 in the last three Olympics. Usain Bolt personifies his country’s dominance as the world’s fastest man.

headline: Before Sprints at Olympic Track, Sitting Down at the Table

headline: Single-Minded
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Sometimes, when you’re just starting out in life, or when things aren’t quite working out the way you wished, you have to be grateful for what you have. Even if it’s just one thing.

headline: From Darkness of Munich Olympics, Moments of Clarity
text: Our family trip to Cleveland for Monday night’s Indians game would ordinarily prompt a historical detour, perhaps to the site of League Park, where the Bill Wambsganss-era Indians played. Instead, I can stomach only a David Berger tour now.

headline: From the 902nd Pick to the Major Leagues
text: SAN DIEGO — The quick ascension of Josh Edgin will continue with yet another unlikely upswing.

headline: Primer: Rousseff and Brazil’s Dark Past
text: Simon Romero, the New York Times bureau chief in Brazil, previews his article on Dilma Rousseff, Brazil’s president and a former guerrilla, and how the country is dealing with its past.

headline: Less Practice Equals More Medals for U.S. Diving Team
text: LONDON — Who knew the best way to end a medal drought was to focus on winning them two at a time?

headline: Rangers Resist Pressure to Trade Top Prospects
text: His division rival had just traded for the best pitcher on the trade market, but Jon Daniels, the general manager of the Texas Rangers, went ahead with a question-and-answer session with fans last weekend. Instead of criticism, though, he found support. One fan, who said he spoke for all the rest, thanked Daniels for not selling the farm.

headline: Aug. 4: Likely No New Blue States in November
text: Saturday was a light day for polling, with only the national tracking polls and a South Dakota poll out; our forecast was essentially unchanged.

headline: Speedster’s Late Arrival to the Tigers
text: When Quintin Berry showed up at Detroit Tigers spring training this year, playing for his fifth organization in three years, Alex Avila knew who he was. Berry had never played in the majors, and had only four career games above Class AA. But he had made an impression at that level.

headline: Michael Phelps Wins 22nd Olympic Medal
text: On Saturday, Michael Phelps collected his 22nd medal, and 18th gold, in his racing finale, the United States men’s 4 x 100 medley relay.

headline: Man Suspected of Faking His Death Has Returned to New York, Officials Say
text: Officials investigating the disappearance of a Long Island man who seemed to try to fake his own death last week said on Saturday that he had returned to New York, but that they had not decided whether to charge him with a crime.

headline: Financing a Race
text: Where the roughly $400 million spent by the Obama campaign and the Democratic National Committee since the beginning of last year has gone:

headline: Record Spending by Obama’s Camp Shrinks Coffers
text: President Obama has spent more campaign cash more quickly than any incumbent in recent history, betting that heavy early investments in personnel, field offices and a high-tech campaign infrastructure will propel him to victory in November.

headline: U.S. Women Set Mark in Medley Relay
text: LONDON — It was going to take a lot of bling to deflect attention from the brilliance of Michael Phelps, who won his sixth medal and fourth gold of the London Games on Saturday in his fourth and final Olympics. His United States teammates on the women’s 4x100-meter medley relay had the credentials to pull it off. Missy Franklin, Rebecca Soni, Dana Vollmer and Allison Schmitt took a combined five individual golds and two silvers into the final, and they left London Aquatics Centre for the last time with a world record and a relay gold.

headline: Making a Pitch to the Tea Party in Indiana
text: EVANSVILLE, Ind. — When Mitt Romney campaigned last week at one stop in Colorado, a key swing state whose governor and senators are Democrats, he sought to sell himself with a simple message: He is a deal maker, someone who can work with Democrats and reach across the aisle, as he did when he was the governor of Massachusetts.

headline: Furyk Clings to One-Shot Lead at Firestone
text: AKRON, Ohio — Jim Furyk had the worst of his three rounds at the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational on Saturday, yet he enters the final round with the lead — barely.

headline: Florence Waren, Jewish Dancer Who Resisted Nazis, Dies at 95
text: Even in the depths of war in occupied France, Florence Waren and Frederic Apcar — or “Florence et Frederic,” as they were billed — dazzled Paris, he in tails, she in jeweled gowns with flowers in her hair, the two of them gliding and swirling across the stage as one of the most famous ballroom-dance teams in Europe.

headline: Mars Mission’s Fate Rests on Landing
text: PASADENA, Calif. — The future of NASA’s exploration of Mars now comes down to a struggle between gravity and a half-million lines of computer code.

headline: A Record Day for Swimming
text: Michael Phelps wins his 22nd medal and the American women’s team sets a world record in the medley relay.

headline: Mary Louise Rasmuson, Who Led Women’s Army Corps, Dies at 101
text: Mary Louise Rasmuson, who joined the Women’s Army Corps when it was formed during World War II, rose to be its director under two presidents and later found a new life as a civic leader and philanthropist in the young state of Alaska, died on Monday at her home in Anchorage. She was 101.

headline: History on the Track
text: Oscar Pistorius becomes the first double-amputee runner to compete in the Games, highlighting a busy day on the track.

headline: Replacing Water Meters to Cut Costs Across Texas
text: ROUND ROCK, Tex. — Early one recent morning, Buddy Franklin and a team of utility workers descended on the Rock Hollow neighborhood in this Austin suburb. They went from house to house with one mission: to install new electronic water meters that change how the city records, and bills for, water use.

text: The majority of Texas students do not leave public schools prepared for college.

headline: Uzbek Group Says Drone Killed Leader
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A major Uzbek militant group closely allied with Al Qaeda announced Saturday that its leader had been killed in an American drone strike in Pakistan’s tribal belt, along the Afghan border.

headline: Leader’s Torture in the ’70s Stirs Ghosts in Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Her nom de guerre was Estela. Part of a shadowy urban guerrilla group at the time of her capture in 1970, she spent three years behind bars, where interrogators repeatedly tortured her with electric shocks to her feet and ears, and forced her into the pau de arara, or parrot’s perch, in which victims are suspended upside down naked, from a stick, with bound wrists and ankles.

headline: Fairs, Like Crops, Are Drooping With the Heat
text: CEDARBURG, Wis. — The cheese curds were sizzling in vats of oil, the cartoon-colored carnival rides were spinning, and the tractors, ready to pull something heavy, were revving. Yet all was not right last week at the Ozaukee County Fair, age 153.

headline: Parsing Numbers to Choose Best Ever
text: There are numbers in chess that have special significance. One of them is 2,851: the highest rating of all time, which Garry Kasparov, the former world champion, earned twice, in July 1999 and January 2000.

headline: Calhoun Breaks His Hip
text: Coach Jim Calhoun, who has led the Connecticut men’s team to three N.C.A.A. titles, broke his hip in a bicycle accident and had surgery at the UConn Health Center in Farmington. Calhoun, 70, slipped on sand while riding near his beach home in Madison, Conn., falling off the bike. This is the latest health complication for Calhoun, who has outlasted three bouts with cancer, missed games because of back problems last year and broke five ribs while riding his bike in 2009. The fall forced Calhoun to miss a charity game on Saturday night that featured many of his former players.

headline: Sigh of Relief for the Jets
text: Santonio Holmes had an injury scare, but X-rays on his chest came back negative, alleviating the Jets’ fears that he fractured a rib during a scrimmage in Cortland, N.Y. It was a rare dose of good news for a receiving corps that has lost several members over the last week — Jeremy Kerley and Chaz Schilens among them — to groin or hamstring pulls.

headline: A Call to Investigate Russian Governor’s Comments
text: MOSCOW — A member of a Kremlin-sponsored civic chamber will ask state prosecutors to investigate racially tinged statements made by the governor of the Krasnodar region, a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin, to see if the remarks violate Russian law on incitement of ethnic hatred.

headline: Mets Walk, Over and Over, to a Victory
text: SAN DIEGO — The Mets were productively passive Saturday night, drawing 10 walks as they strolled to a 6-2 win over the San Diego Padres. Mike Baxter epitomized the approach and set a franchise record for a nine-inning game with five walks. Vince Coleman had five for the Mets during a 16-inning game in 1992. The last major league player to have five in a nine-inning game was Ryan Howard of the Philadelphia Phillies in 2006.

headline: 15-Year-Old Ledecky Spoiled Britain’s Party
text: LONDON − Watching the Olympic women’s 800-meter freestyle final, Bob Bowman had a feeling of déjà vu. In the water, a 15-year-old from Maryland was turning an Olympic debut into a coming-out party.

headline: 48 Captives Are Iran ‘Thugs,’ Say Rebels in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A group of Syrian rebels took responsibility on Sunday for the kidnapping of 48 Iranians in Damascus a day earlier, but the rebels insisted that their captives were members of Iran’s elite Revolutionary Guards, not religious pilgrims as Iran’s official news agency had reported.

headline: With Live Streaming and New Technology, BBC Tries to Be Everywhere at the Olympics
text: While some American television viewers are grumbling about the retro feel to NBC’s London Olympics coverage, with tape-delayed broadcasts of the opening ceremony and other events, audiences in Britain are getting a more contemporary — even futuristic — TV Games.

headline: Media Firm's Olympic Moment to Come After Medals Are Awarded
text: ROME — As the world’s best athletes compete for a spot on the podium at the Olympic Games in London, one Italian is focused on a 10-minute event that will take place once all the medal-giving is over and done with.

headline: Curtis Martin: ‘I’m Going to Bare My Soul’

headline: 2,000 Arrested in China in Counterfeit Drug Crackdown
text: SHANGHAI — Chinese government authorities have detained nearly 2,000 people as part of a nationwide crackdown on the sale of fake or counterfeit drugs and health care products, according to a report on Sunday from Xinhua, the official news agency.

headline: ‘Mini Minis’ Help Keep Field Events on Track
text: LONDON – Tottling to and fro along the right-hand side of the javelin green at Olympic Stadium here are three newcomers to the track: adorable miniature Mini Coopers.

headline: Murray Beats Federer for the Gold in Straight Sets
text: A breakthrough Olympics for the British has perhaps its greatest breakthrough of all. After four losses in Grand Slam finals, Andy Murray broke through for the biggest title of his career, winning Olympic gold with a stunning 6-2, 6-1, 6-4 rout of his rival Roger Federer.

headline: Student Contest Winner | Aurora and the Gun Control Debate

We love watching you interact with The New York Times.

headline: Ethiopian Sets Olympic Record in Women’s Marathon
text: LONDON — On the narrow streets of Sunday’s women’s Olympic marathon, Tiki Gelana of Ethiopia reached for her water bottle and collided with another runner just beyond the halfway point. She fell to the ground and scraped her right elbow. She got up and was bumped again.

headline: Eagles Coach’s Son, 29, Dies at Training Camp
text: Garrett Reid, the oldest son of Philadelphia Eagles Coach Andy Reid, was found dead Sunday morning in his dormitory room at the team’s training site in Bethlehem, Pa., after a troubled life that included a struggle with drug use and prison stints.

headline: Dueling Campaign Ads for a Weekend Off the Trail
text: Both Mitt Romney and President Obama are off the campaign trail today, but their campaigns are not resting. Both sides released new ads this weekend that took up some fresh themes, with the Romney campaign seizing on the unemployment figures released Friday and the Obama team making an appeal to female voters.

headline: Disruptions: At Its Trial, Apple Spills Some Secrets

headline: From Film to Broadway, but Changes in Schedule
text: Two new musicals bound for Broadway next spring are taking unexpected detours. “Diner,” based on the hit film of the same title, is postponing a San Francisco run that had been scheduled for October and November, while “Honeymoon in Vegas,” also based on a popular movie, has canceled performances planned for late this year in Toronto.

headline: At Site of Heartbreak, Murray Overwhelms Federer for Gold
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Andy Murray has yet to win Wimbledon, but he has now won a big one at Wimbledon.

headline: A New Comedy Podcast Network From Splitsider
text: The heavy-hitters in the rapidly growing comedy podcast universe are mostly located on the West Coast. Marc Maron’s “WTF” and Scott Aukerman’s “Comedy Bang! Bang!” are both based in Los Angeles, as are the major podcast networks like Earwolf, Nerdist and Maximum Fun. But this geographic imbalance might start to change with the announcement, scheduled for Monday, that Splitsider, the popular New York comedy site under the umbrella of The Awl Web family, is starting its own podcast network.

headline: ‘Total Recall’ Remake Struggles at Box Office
text: Add “Total Recall” to the list of remakes that go thud. Sony, betting in part on advancements in visual effects and fond memories of the 1990 original, spent at least $200 million to make and market a new version starring Colin Farrell in the role Arnold Schwarzenegger made famous. But moviegoers weren’t feeling it: “Total Recall” took in about $26 million at North American theaters over the weekend, a distant second behind “The Dark Knight Rises,” which was No. 1 for the third weekend in a row, with about $36.4 million in ticket sales ($354.6 million total over three weeks).

headline: Move Over, Max Decugis: Williamses Win Doubles

text: Andy Murray beat Roger Federer in straight sets to win gold in men’s singles. Murray has yet to win a Grand Slam singles title, but winning gold in his own country surely qualifies as a major victory.

headline: From Chaplin to Groucho to T. S. Eliot
text: According to the captivating new book “Hello Goodbye Hello” Alexander Woollcott, the writer and Algonquin Circle wit, loved to play a game called Strange Bedfellows. One of his biggest coups took place at a Cap d’Antibes villa in the summer of 1928 when he succeeded in bringing together Harpo Marx and George Bernard Shaw (“corned beef and roses,” as he called them) at lunch. The two hit it off, and later that week Harpo drove Shaw to Cannes, where a friend of Shaw’s cast them as extras in a movie; a scene featuring them playing billiards, alas, would be left on the cutting-room floor.

headline: Candidates React to Shooting at Sikh Temple
text: President Obama and Mitt Romney released statements Sunday afternoon on the shooting at the Sikh temple in Wisconsin. In his statement, the president said:

headline: Pollsters Struggle to Pin Down the Right (Cell) Number
text: As they gauge voter sentiment in this tight presidential race, pollsters face a big challenge: more and more voters hang up on them.

headline: Loneliness and Love on the Moor
text: The ghost of theater styles past hovers over “Brontë: A Portrait of Charlotte,” a one-woman show starring Maxine Linehan. Written by William Luce for Julie Harris, “Brontë” is one of those “spend an evening with a great writer” plays whose mini-vogue seems to have come and gone. (The Luce-Harris “Belle of Amherst” might have been the peak of the trend.)

headline: Garcia Skirts Trouble Just Enough to Beat the Mariners
text: On a tepid, cloudy night in Seattle in August 1999, Freddy Garcia struck out 12 Detroit Tigers as part of a shutout, setting the Seattle Mariners’ rookie record. That night, Ken Griffey Jr. hit two home runs.

headline: If This Dancer’s Amigas Could See Her Now
text: The 1966 musical (and 1969 movie) “Sweet Charity” gets a Latin makeover in the director Julio Agustin’s production at the New Haarlem Arts Theater, and it’s called for. The original could use some salsa. With its picaresque and coincidence-filled narrative; somewhat flighty title character (a lovelorn floozy, if not a prostitute, with a heart of gold); and principal setting (a dime-dance joint, already an anachronism in mid-’60s New York), the musical, originally staged by Bob Fosse, is itself a watered-down version of Fellini’s “Nights of Cabiria,” which actually did concern a prostitute and gritty issues like physical and emotional abuse and an existential take on religion. “Sweet Charity” was never one of Fosse’s more provocative shows, and Neil Simon’s quip-packed book seems sitcom-ready in retrospect.

headline: Many Tales Witnessed Many Ways
text: Never underestimate the power of serendipity; any chance encounter can have profound repercussions. Take, for example, the composer Phil Kline, who discovered “Indeterminacy,” a seminal two-LP set by John Cage, while working as a college-radio D.J. during his time at Columbia University.

headline: In Fastest Field Ever, the World’s Fastest Man Proves It Again
text: LONDON — Four years later, still no one can catch Usain Bolt.

headline: Esther Kartiganer, a Force as a ‘60 Minutes’ Producer, Dies at 74
text: Esther Kartiganer, who as senior producer in charge of vetting content on CBS’s “60 Minutes” became entangled in a controversy over a program that raised questions about President George W. Bush’s military service during the Vietnam War, died on Wednesday in Aspen, Colo. She was 74.

headline: Sailing Into a Summer Night on the Wings of Beauty
text: “I’ve been watching you,” David Harrell yelled at the people assembled in Hearst Plaza on Saturday night for Lincoln Center Out of Doors. “I think you’re beautiful,” he said, and then, “I thought this was going to be strange,” and: “This has really moved me. It’s really changed me.”

headline: Vivid Harmonies in the Dappled Shade
text: Charles Ives represents the newer end of the compositional spectrum on many programs. But as the cellist Kevin McFarland said before the JACK Quartet’s performance of the second movement of Ives’s String Quartet No. 2 on Saturday afternoon, “It’s still kind of an early piece for us.”

headline: Richards-Ross Breaks American Drought In the Women’s 400
text: LONDON — Sanya Richards-Ross earned a long-coveted gold medal in the women’s 400 meters Sunday, becoming the first woman from the United States to win the event since 1984.

headline: Scenes From Shooting at Sikh Temple in Wisconsin
text: Last Updated, 9:30 p.m. A gunman walked into a Sikh temple in suburban Milwaukee on Sunday and killed six worshipers preparing for a morning service, in what is being described as an act of “domestic terrorism,” law enforcement officials said. The gunman was also killed.

headline: NBC’s Coverage in London Is Becoming a Rating Success With a Shot at a Profit
text: Critics of NBC’s coverage of the London Olympics have voiced sometimes brutal commentary on Twitter using the hashtag #NBCFail, but with one week left in its comprehensive, multiple-platform coverage, NBC’s own take is that its programming is a success.

headline: A Commando Mission for Millionaires
text: “Soldiers of Fortune,” an execrable action thriller plopped into a few local theaters without screenings for critics, is one abortive military mission. For the cast, shooting the movie (in Ukraine) may have been a working vacation, but for viewers, watching it is an excruciating sentence of hard labor.

headline: Study Questions Risk of S.E.C. Revolving Door
text: WASHINGTON — The revolving door has long been the focus of government watchdogs here, a symbolic portal that business executives and lawyers pass through on their way to government posts and back again to the private sector. There, the thinking goes, they use their influence with former colleagues to reap benefits for themselves and their companies.

headline: A Quick Visit From a Busy Conductor
text: In her revitalization of the Mostly Mozart Festival over the last decade, Jane Moss, the artistic director of Lincoln Center, has shown an uncanny knack for catching conductors on the rise: not least, the festival’s current music director, Louis Langrée.

headline: In Battle Between Longtime Rivals, More Than One Gold Is in Offing
text: LONDON — Just 2 points stood between Lee Chong Wei and gold in the men’s badminton finals — and not just the modest amount of precious metal in the Olympics’ most coveted prize. He was also on the verge of winning a bar of gold worth more than $600,000.

headline: A Hall Full of Memory Rocks Out Once More
text: PORT CHESTER, N.Y. — Forty years ago, in its heyday, the Capitol Theater here was known as a rock stage with great acoustics, a crumbling space where the Grateful Dead, Janis Joplin, Santana and Pink Floyd played memorable concerts. So when Peter Shapiro, a founder of the Brooklyn Bowl, took over the theater last year and announced plans to reopen it as a concert hall next month, he had a heavy reputation to live up to.

headline: MTV Sets Date for ‘Jersey Shore’
text: To those who thought “Jersey Shore” would not or could not survive for three full years, MTV is proving otherwise. The network has set a premiere date for the sixth season of this much-mocked but also much-watched reality show and has ordered a second season of the spinoff “Snooki and JWoww,” which features these two “Jersey Shore” cast members living elsewhere in New Jersey.

headline: A Stormy Lollapalooza Sends Fans Scurrying
text: A severe thunderstorm in Chicago forced organizers of the Lollapalooza music festival to suspend all activities and evacuate an estimated 100,000 people from Grant Park for more than two hours on Saturday afternoon, The Associated Press reported. A handful of acts had their sets cut short when concert officials announced that the park would be evacuated because the National Weather Service had issued a severe thunderstorm warning. Concertgoers took shelter in neighboring bars and restaurants and in three underground parking garages that were designated evacuation centers for the sold-out event. The gates reopened a few hours later, and a curfew was extended to accommodate the night’s scheduled headliners, which included the Red Hot Chili Peppers,  Frank Ocean and Franz Ferdinand.

headline: General Way Things Are Going
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Have you been following the 2012 LONDON Olympics? Lynn Lempel has, and she offers us a nice beginning to our solving week by salting her grid with six of the sports you will find in the competition.

headline: Anything But Human
text: Wherever I turn, the popular media, scientists and even fellow philosophers are telling me that I’m a machine or a beast. My ethics can be illuminated by the behavior of termites. My brain is a sloppy computer with a flicker of consciousness and the illusion of free will. I’m anything but human.

headline: World Youth Teams Championships Finals
text: TAICANG, China — At the 14th World Youth Teams Championships here the three 80-board finals ended on Saturday.

headline: A Decadent Reminder of Russia Before Putin
text: MOSCOW — If there was one place in Moscow that embodied the gold rush mentality of expatriates in the troubled Yeltsin era, it was the Hungry Duck, a dive bar that until it was shut down by the city in 1999 brought together profiteers, thugs with crew cuts, drifting students, émigré castaways and Russian women hoping to meet foreign men.

headline: One Man Multitasking, Guvnor
text: The actor James Corden arrived in New York this spring not exactly a household name and cast in the lead of a comedy some people feared might be too British to succeed on Broadway. He promptly won the Tony for best actor and a passel of other awards, putting that doubt to rest. Now, as his run in “One Man, Two Guvnors” enters its last weeks, he has become a case study in multitasking, juggling the opportunities that have come out of his sudden success here.

headline: Latino Show for a New Generation
text: “East WillyB,” a Brooklyn-based Web series, is taking on issues facing a growing Latino population.

headline: Networks Struggle to Appeal to Hispanics
text: Sofia Vergara is probably the most recognizable Hispanic actress working in English-language television. She is one of the stars of “Modern Family,” among the highest-rated scripted shows on network television, and she has parlayed her celebrity into commercials for brands like Pepsi and Cover Girl.

headline: Guided by Lucky Magazine, Shopping Will Soon Require Less Clicking
text: Before women go to the mall, they go to the shopping bible Lucky. Now the magazine wants to save them the price of gas.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Why I Decided Against a Career in Journalism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lending to Students
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Mets’ Loss, Harvey Learns From Mistakes
text: SAN DIEGO — Matt Harvey, a young pitcher with the mien and aura of an honor student, received the next lesson on his major league syllabus: how to fail.

headline: Training Those Who Guide Young Minds
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Does the ‘Free Exercise’ of Religion Mean?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Day 3 of Track and Field
text: Scenes from Sunday’s track and field events at the London Games, featuring a gold medal run by Usain Bolt in the men’s 100 meters.

headline: Martin E. Segal, Titan of the Arts in New York City, Dies at 96
text: Martin E. Segal, whose puckish warmth and old-fashioned ways belied his power and influence as one of the city’s leading cultural figures, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 96.

headline: Gunmen Kill 15 and Steal Vehicle in Attack on Egypt Base
text: CAIRO — Masked gunmen opened fire on an Egyptian Army checkpoint in the northern Sinai Peninsula on Sunday, killing 15 soldiers who were preparing to break their Ramadan fast. The gunmen then seized at least one armored vehicle and headed toward Israel, apparently in an attempt to storm the border, witnesses and officials said.

headline: Aggregators Help Radio Reach Online Audiences
text: For the radio industry, there may be no better symbol for the challenges of adapting to the digital age than two candy-colored mobile apps.

headline: A Common Refrain as Harlem Loses Its Bowling Alley
text: As groups of cheering children sought to knock down pins at Harlem Lanes on Friday morning, Joey Hill and Marsha Kindell had a different objective: get rid of mounds of documents.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include consumer credit for June (Tuesday); second-quarter productivity (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the trade deficit for June and wholesale trade inventories for June (Thursday); and import prices for July (Friday).

headline: Optimism in Greece After Talks With Lenders
text: ATHENS — Envoys of Greece’s international creditors on Sunday wrapped up a review of the country’s progress in meeting the terms of its second bailout and said they would return in September for a final assessment that will determine whether further money would be released and a potentially disastrous default averted.

headline: Competitive Armchair Olympics: Olympic Record
text: Click to begin the race.

headline: Women Finally Get Their Chance to Be Contenders in Olympic Boxing
text: LONDON — For much of the match, the North Korean boxer seemed intent on wrapping her arms around her Russian opponent as if her strategy were to dance cheek to cheek. Occasionally, they traded blows, and the Russian slightly got the better of that. She won the bout, 12-9.

headline: The Clinton Tax Challenge for Republicans
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Security Start-Ups Catch Fancy of Investors
text: MENLO PARK, Calif. — The question is no longer who have hackers hit. It is who has not been hit.

headline: Criticism Grows as Check-Cashing Stores Expand in Poorer Areas
text: Behind bulletproof glass, a smiling teller at a RiteCheck store in the South Bronx waited patiently for customers to hand over their checks. For every $100 cashed, she collected a $1.91 service fee.

headline: With 10th-Place Finish, a Lifter Earns a Victory Over the Pain
text: LONDON — It was not Holley Mangold’s best day. First, she tore her uniform. Then she tore a tendon. And then there was the not insignificant matter of lifting a few hundred pounds over her head again and again.

headline: Who Is Jamaica?
text: Kingston, Jamaica

headline: To Increase Learning Time, Some Schools Add Days to Academic Year
text: PHOENIX — It was the last Sunday in July, and Bethany and Garvin Phillips were pulling price tags off brand-new backpacks and stuffing them with binders and pencils.

headline: Terms of Service
text: In the first of a new series on private languages, we offer a selection of secret codes used in the dining rooms and kitchens of some of New York’s finest restaurants.

headline: Women at War
text: On Aug. 29, 1862, during the Second Battle of Bull Run, Union soldiers could see a young woman helping the wounded seek shelter under a rock ledge, while taking fire herself. At Petersburg in June 1864, Sgt. Frederick O. Talbot, of the First Maine Heavy Artillery, found himself standing beside this same woman as she beckoned soldiers to the frontline breastwork to be treated. He was told that the men of the Fifth Michigan Infantry would have anyone’s “life in a minute” for saying “any harm of her.”

headline: A Torrent of Toys, From Lunchables
text: MARKETERS used to entice children with cheap plastic trinkets in boxes of Cracker Jack or cereal. The Lunchables brand is raising the stakes considerably.

headline: In California, County Jails Face Bigger Load
text: FRESNO, Calif. — Standing on the footsteps of the Fresno County Jail, where he had just been released one recent afternoon, Juan Diaz rated the food inside a 2. The state prison at Coalinga, where he served three years on a weapons conviction, earned a 10.

headline: Fatal Shootings of 2 Brooklyn Shopkeepers Unnerve Fellow Merchants
text: The recent killings of two shopkeepers in south Brooklyn bore eerie similarities, though their deaths occurred nearly four weeks apart. Both were shot in the head or neck with what the police said were .22-caliber guns. Both were Egyptian immigrants around retirement age. And both sold their wares at addresses that contained the same numbers: two 7s, a 1 and an 8.

headline: After Phelps, More Prodigies
text: LONDON — Nine months after the Beijing Games, Michael Phelps was in the weight room at Loyola College in Maryland when a photograph of Brett Favre flashed on a nearby television as part of an ESPN report that Favre was considering coming out of retirement a second time.

headline: Terms of Service
text: Ever wondered how restaurant staff members communicate with one another? Or why some diners have curious letters appended to their reservations?

headline: Aug. 5: State Polls, National Polls, and Likely Voters
text: Good news for polling junkies: pollsters seem to be picking up their pace a bit, and we’re finally starting to see some state polls released on the weekends. On Sunday, there were two state polls out, each of which were a bit strange.

headline: Seeking Economic Lift, Not Just Laughs, in Tie to Comedy
text: JAMESTOWN, N.Y. — For those caught up in the Olympic spirit, there was the traditional grape-stomping competition. Or perhaps the test of chocolate-wrapping skills, even if some of the competitors just could not resist sticking a few candies from the fast-moving conveyor belt inside their blouses.

headline: In Kansas, Conservatives Vilify Fellow Republicans
text: TOPEKA, Kan. — In eight years in the Kansas Legislature, State Senator Dick Kelsey said, he never voted for a tax increase and frequently supported spending cuts. As an evangelical pastor, a staunch opponent of abortion and an acknowledged leader in the fight to elect conservative lawmakers, he has been endorsed by Kansans for Life and the National Rifle Association.

headline: Zillow and Other Sites Broaden Their Mission to Include Businesses
text: SEATTLE — For the first few years of its existence, the only thing Zillow cared about was getting people to come to its real estate Web site to snoop on the market value of neighbors’ homes and other properties. Over 34 million visitors a month now do so.

headline: In Basketball, a Different and More Literal Globetrotter
text: LONDON — The traveling basketball coach, now on gig No. 12 and in country No. 3, looked across the scorer’s table as “The Star-Spangled Banner” played Sunday. He recognized the faces of the opposition, all American, all familiar.

headline: Militias Eager to Oust Islamists in Mali
text: The recruits have almost no weapons, little military instruction and not much more than the hard ground to sleep on.

headline: A Détente Before the Election
text: Does voter fraud sometimes happen in the United States? You bet.  But we are dealing with this relatively small problem in an irrational and partisan way.

headline: Lottery Numbers
At Governors Island Reunion, Childhood Bonds Endure
text: Before Governors Island became the scene of artist-inspired miniature golf and food festivals, before it sprouted bike rentals, hammocks and Mark di Suvero sculptures, before it evolved into a cool weekend getaway for overheated New Yorkers, it was home.

headline: Fearing an Impasse in Congress, Industry Cuts Spending
text: A rising number of manufacturers are canceling new investments and putting off new hires because they fear paralysis in Washington will force hundreds of billions in tax increases and budget cuts in January, undermining economic growth in the coming months.

headline: Jamestown Loves Lucy
text: Lucy’s hometown celebrates her life and career

headline: The Leak Police
text: In the months leading up to the invasion of Iraq in 2003, this newspaper famously published a number of stories regurgitating the Bush administration hype about Saddam Hussein’s supposed arsenal of mass destruction. A few journalists elsewhere — notably Jonathan Landay and Warren Strobel, then of the Knight Ridder newspapers — dug deeper, discovered contrary intelligence, and challenged the official line. Later, The Times also published some excellent work on how an administration eager to justify its decision to go to war cherry-picked the intelligence to make its case.

headline: Carrots and Sticks for School Systems
text: Education Secretary Arne Duncan has been pushing the states to create rigorous teacher evaluation systems that not only judge teachers by how well their students perform but also — when the results are in — reward good teachers while easing chronic low performers out of the system. More than half the states have agreed to adopt new evaluation systems in exchange for competitive grants from the federal Race to the Top program or greater flexibility under the No Child Left Behind law.

headline: As Libor Fault-Finding Grows, It Is Now Every Bank for Itself
text: Major banks, which often band together when facing government scrutiny, are now turning on one another as an international investigation into the manipulation of interest rates gains momentum.

headline: In Britain’s Little Jamaica, Rejoicing Over a Speedster
text: LONDON — The  Electric Brixton might have been a colonial outpost. At this cavernous nightclub nine or so miles southwest of Olympic Stadium, there were no Union Jacks, no cries for Team GB, but the closest thing to a hometown crowd a man can get 4,700 miles from home.

headline: Republicans Fail a Security Test
text: Senate Republicans regularly promote themselves as the true custodians of national security. This claim seemed particularly hollow last week when they helped block a new measure aimed at protecting America’s vulnerable computer networks from attack by, among others, potentially hostile foreign governments.

headline: When the Sweeper Comes
text: There is a line of cars double-parked on West 12th Street. It is Monday morning, 9:30 or so. In each car, a driver waits, some reading, some making calls, some drumming their fingers on the steering wheel. The opposite curb is empty. It is a quiet block, but the air is full of expectation.

headline: Outside Cash in Missouri Race Could Be a National Model
text: WASHINGTON — Missouri’s long, divisive Republican Senate primary draws to a close Tuesday, but after all the intraparty fireworks, it is the incumbent Democrat, Senator Claire McCaskill, who remains in deep trouble.

headline: Times Photographer Is Arrested on Assignment
text: A freelance photographer for The New York Times was arrested on Saturday night while on assignment with two reporters who were conducting street interviews in the Bronx.

headline: DNA and the Fourth Amendment
text: Earlier this year, Maryland’s highest court held that collection of DNA samples from people arrested but not yet convicted violated the Fourth Amendment’s prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures. Last week, Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. stayed that ruling while the Supreme Court decides whether to hear Maryland’s appeal of the state court decision. The Supreme Court should take up this case, but there was no good reason for the chief justice to allow the police to continue collecting DNA while the case is on appeal.

headline: Afghan President Moves to Reassure Allies After Security Ministers Are Dismissed
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai moved quickly on Sunday to confirm Parliament’s decision to dismiss two senior security ministers the day before, but he reassured the Western allies that he would avoid a vacuum in the two ministries charged with fighting the war and organizing the transition to Afghan control.

headline: A Big Decision, With Its Timing Carefully Planned
text: Barring a total surprise, the next big thing in the 2012 presidential race will be Mitt Romney’s choice of a running mate.

headline: Writer Defends His Handling of Interview With Assad
text: Even when his country was not convulsed by war, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria rarely gave televised interviews to foreigners. His session with Barbara Walters in December was a public relations disaster. So it seemed surprising a few weeks ago when Mr. Assad granted another Westerner a face-to-face chat on camera.

headline: It’s Bradley Left Standing as Furyk Tumbles on 18
text: AKRON, Ohio — Jim Furyk entered Sunday’s final round of the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational with a one-stroke lead, hoping to overcome some lingering disappointment from his final-round collapse at the United States Open in June.

headline: Saying Mali ‘Is Our Country,’ Militias Train to Oust Islamists
text: MOPTI, Mali — Hundreds of young men are stuffed into makeshift training camps near this provincial capital, arising at 4 a.m. for physical exercises and simulated hand-to-hand combat in preparation for the day when they can free their north Mali homeland from the radical Islamists whose harsh rule has driven tens of thousands of frightened, desperate civilians to flee the country.

headline: Should the U.S. Seek More Tech Manufacturing?
text: What should the United States do to encourage high-tech manufacturing, or are those jobs not worth it pursuing?

headline: Enjoying the Games, Despite What May Be Behind the Curtain
text: I wasn’t surprised that Charles Yesalis had been intently watching the London Olympics. The surprise is that Yesalis is actually enjoying the Games.

headline: One Race, Every Medalist Ever
text: Usain Bolt’s 9.63 set an Olympic record in the 100. So how far ahead of every Olympic medalist is he?

headline: Jets Linebacker Looks to Add to His Game
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Aaron Maybin finds inspiration in conventional sources, like his two favorite books, “The Alchemist” and “The Secret,” but also by gazing at the ceiling in his bedroom at his New Jersey apartment.

headline: NASA’s Curiosity Rover Successfully Lands on Mars
text: At 1:31 a.m. Eastern time on Monday, NASA’s Mars Curiosity rover completed its eight-and-a-half-month journey from Earth and landed on the surface of Mars. The Times is reporting the news as it unfolds directly from NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, and covering events and reaction from people tuning in around the globe.

headline: Warren Winkelstein Jr., Medical Sleuth, Dies at 90
text: Dr. Warren Winkelstein Jr., a physician and researcher whose groundbreaking studies connected unprotected sex between men to AIDS, smoking to cervical cancer and air pollution to chronic lung disease, died July 22 at his home in Point Richmond, Calif. He was 90.

headline: Corrections: August 6, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: P.G.A. Championship Will Be Latest War by the Shore
text: In the spring of 1990, there was a news conference for the Ryder Cup, which was coming one year later to the inconspicuous, windswept South Carolina barrier island known as Kiawah. The man charged with turning an oceanside tract of swamp and shrub into a dauntingly beautiful championship golf course was asked where he planned to put the huge galleries expected for the event.

headline: Styled to a T | Diane Kruger
text: Hide and Seek. Head-to-toe leather and suede for day — as shown by the likes of Calvin Klein, Bally and Derek Lam — is this season’s second skin.

headline: Word of the Day | symbiosis
text: symbiosis •\ˌsim-be-ˈo-səs, -ˌbi-\• noun

headline: Day 11: What to Watch For
text: Here are some of the events, teams and athletes to watch on Monday at the London Games. (All times Eastern.)

headline: A Coming-Out Party in Hanoi
text: HONG KONG — It wasn’t much of a parade, as these things go. More like a noisy bike ride with some balloons. But the gathering of about 100 gay Vietnamese in Hanoi on Sunday was still a proud declaration of sorts, a kind of political coming-out in the socially conservative country.

headline: Embracing Sheldon Adelson
text: There are two things that set Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign apart: his caution and his secretiveness.

headline: Gunman Kills 6 in Wisconsin Gurdwara
text: Sikh religious leaders had gathered in the lobby of the sprawling Sikh temple in suburban Milwaukee, and lunch was being prepared as congregants were arriving for Sunday services, Steven Yaccino, Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora wrote in The New York Times. Instead of worshipers, though, an armed man stepped through the door and started firing, killing six people.

headline: FindTheBest: A Comparison Engine Tries to Build a Business
text: Kevin O’Connor recalls that he was met with mostly skepticism when he made the rounds of potential venture investors a few years ago. He wanted to build an online comparison engine, but not one for a single product or service like travel or restaurants. He wanted to cover hundreds of topics and products, from lawyers to nursing homes, smartphones to dog breeds.

headline: Novartis and Penn Unite on New Anticancer Path
text: The drugmaker Novartis and the University of Pennsylvania announced a research and licensing agreement early Monday that aims to bring to market a new approach to fighting cancer that has shown promising results in early trials.

headline: Rover Curiosity Lands on Mars
text: A NASA rover, Curiosity, landed on Mars on Monday.

headline: Ending Blackouts, One Solar Lamp at a Time
text: The blackouts in northern and eastern India last week helped highlight a basic fact of life in the country: many people here do not have access to reliable electricity. The humor newspaper, The Onion, perhaps summed it up best with this headline: “300 Million Without Electricity in India After Restoration of Power Grid.”

headline: News Quiz | August 6, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Curiosity Rover Lands Safely on Mars
text: PASADENA, Calif. — In a flawless, triumphant technological tour de force, a plutonium-powered rover the size of a small car was lowered at the end of 25-foot-long cables from a hovering rocket stage onto Mars early on Monday morning.

headline: Saving a Parking Spot in Comfort
text: Dear Diary:

headline: First Indian Woman in Olympic Discus Throw Finals
text: “With the throw of a discus, Krishna Poonia of India made history on Saturday night,” Mary Pilon wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Prime Minister’s Defection in the Dark Jolts Syrians
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The defection of Syria’s prime minister, Riyad Farid Hijab, began like so many others: with coded conversations and furtive planning. He began discussing the idea of fleeing, an aide said, as soon as President Bashar al-Assad strong-armed him into taking the job in June. In recent days, he worked to get his extended family out. Then, early Monday, the prime minister slipped out of Damascus under cover of darkness with his wife and four children, scrambling through the desert as a fugitive.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 6, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the special London 2012 section.

headline: In the Olympics’ Shadow, a Tale of Two Cities
text: Both crime-ridden and trendy, Hackney is one of the host boroughs for the Olympic Games in London.

headline: What We’re Watching on Day 11
text: The U.S. women's soccer team meets its longtime regional rival Canada in the semifinals and the marquee track events continue with the men's 400-meter. Victor Mather has the latest from London.

headline: Jets, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit resumes his previews of all 32 teams with a look at the A.F.C. East this week. First up are the Jets.

headline: Counselor’s Calendar | August Checklist for Rising Seniors
text: In March, The Choice introduced a series called Counselor’s Calendar, to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

headline: Measuring Mooching
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Gunman Attacks Sikh Temple in Wisconsin, Killing Six
text: WHERE did a gunman open fire on Sunday morning?

headline: Thigh-Popping Success on a Bike Lies in the Quads
text: LONDON — The picture of the Olympics so far, an image that swept across the Internet and introduced the sports world to the term “quad-off,” might be one featuring two cyclists in their underwear with shorts around their ankles, their thunderous thighs prominently displayed.

headline: Farmers Fight Nuclear Plant in Bid to Save Land
text: Badlu Ram tugged against the tattered strips of the white gauze that bound his hands and legs to the hospital bed in the town of Fatehabad. “Please free me,” he pleaded. On July 13, Mr. Ram had attempted suicide by consuming pesticide. “It was my duty … it was my duty,” he repeated.

headline: What We’re Watching: Soccer Gold Goes Through Canada

headline: My Son, Lost and Found
text: My son, who is 12, loves living in Manhattan. He thinks our neighborhood is great. One day last year he told me he never wanted to leave Chelsea. He could live here the rest of his life, he said. I told him he was very lucky to feel this way, but he was going to have to get his own apartment.

headline: Israeli Defense Chief Says Egypt Attack a ‘Wake-Up Call’
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, said on Monday that a terrorist attack that killed 15 Egyptian soldiers on Sunday night should serve as “a wake-up call” to the new Egyptian president about the growing danger in the Sinai Peninsula and the border between the two nations.

headline: For Many Sikhs, Wisconsin Attack Has Troubling Echoes
text: For Sikhs in the United States, India and elsewhere, the killing of six people at a gurudwara, or Sikh temple, in Wisconsin on Sunday afternoon has brought grief and sorrow but also concern that the rampage might be the latest example of a hate crime against Sikhs on American soil in the decade since the 9/11 attacks.

headline: U.S. Fight Against E.U. Airline Emissions Plan Heats Up
text: A meeting of 17 non-European nations hosted by the U.S. State and Transportation departments in Washington last week ended with assurances that the participants were working toward curbing their emissions from aviation.

headline: As Knight Capital Gains a Lifeline, It Loses Market-Making Duties
text: The Knight Capital Group confirmed on Monday that it had struck a $400 million rescue deal with a group of investors, staving off collapse after a recent trading mishap, even as the New York Stock Exchange temporarily revoked the firm’s market-making responsibilities.

headline: Daily Report: Consumer Sites Broaden Mission to Include Businesses
text: The clear line between Internet companies that cater to consumers and those that serve businesses is beginning to blur, reports Nick Wingfield on Monday in The New York Times. Sites like Zillow, LinkedIn, Groupon and GrubHub — consumer services that help people find homes, advertise their talents, find daily deals and order takeout food — are among the companies seeking to burrow more deeply into the operations of businesses in their respective markets.

headline: Not Cool, Britannia: Plans Are Dropped to Honor Homes of Some Great Britons
text: During his career with the Monty Python comedy troupe, Graham Chapman was set upon by the Spanish Inquisition (which nobody expected), pitted in combat against the fearsome Black Knight and crucified in a musical number, accomplishments for which he surely deserves some recognition. Instead, Mr. Chapman, who died in 1989, is one of several noteworthy Britons and people who lived in Britain whose names have been dropped from a list to have their homes distinguished by ceremonial markers because of budget cuts at the organization that grants them.

headline: Signs in China Point to Meeting on Transition
text: BEIJING — At least five senior Communist Party officials have arrived at the beachside resort of Beidaihe, including Xi Jinping, the man expected to be the next leader of China, setting the stage for what some analysts expect to be the climactic negotiations over the coming once-a-decade power transition.

headline: Monday Reading: August Checklist for Rising High School Seniors
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Vote of Confidence
text: “I kept asking myself, ‘Is that really my skirt?’ ” Mimi Plange recalls of the time she saw Michelle Obama wearing a periwinkle gabardine skirt from her spring collection during an appearance on “The View” in May. “And it was. And it looked great. And I felt really, really blessed.” In her fifth season, the 34-year-old Plange, who was born in Ghana and grew up in California, has joined the ranks of White House-approved designers, including Thakoon Panichgul, Jason Wu and Carly Cushnie and Michelle Ochs of Cushnie et Ochs, with clothes that have obvious first-lady appeal: they are romantic (corseted organza dresses in an hourglass silhouette, top left, $2,900; Esti’s, 718-645-2600), mature (Victorian silk blouses with velvet trim) and practical (lots of A-line skirts). “I am catering to every woman’s body from a female perspective,” Plange says. “It’s not about me or what I want to wear; it’s about wearable, real fantasy for real women.” And although Plange admits that she had never really watched “The View” — “I’m still not sure what the episode was all about because I couldn’t pay attention,” she says — she’s now a fan of the show and its star guest for life.

headline: Romney’s Fund-Raising Outpaces Obama’s Again in July
text: The fund-raising machine behind Mitt Romney and the Republican Party once again bested President Obama’s effort last month, raising $25 million more in July than the president and his Democratic allies did.

headline: Best Buy Founder Offers $8.8 Billion to Buy Out Company
text: Richard Schulze, the founder of Best Buy, offered to buy the electronics retailer on Monday in a deal that would value it as much as $8.8 billion.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Sticking the Mars Landing, and TV’s Latino Woes
text: While incredible feats were being accomplished in London, another example of human excellence was occurring millions of miles away: the Curiosity rover landed in a 96-mile-wide crater on Mars at 1:32 a.m. Eastern time. The Mars mission’s final stage was a thriller — the rover, the size of a small car, was lowered at the end of 25-foot-long cables from a hovering rocket stage, Kenneth Chang writes. One wit on Twitter noted that the 14-minute time delay for images from Mars to reach Earth was nothing compared to the hours of delay from NBC in showing Usain Bolt’s Olympic-record-setting dash in the 100-meter race.

headline: A Proclamation of Innocence for a Prisoner Who Never Gave Up
text: Sometimes it turns out that people do tell the truth about themselves. Sorry if that qualifying “sometimes” sounds cynical. But when you meet someone in prison who says she did not commit the murder that earned her a sentence of 25 years to life, you have reason to take her claims with a shaker of salt.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Epicurious: Stop yanking back the husks on that greenmarket corn; whether you keep it or throw it back in the pile, it’s ruined. (As one farmer asks, do you break your eggs before you buy them?) Instead, follow this simple tip for finding the best ears: Feel the outside. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Going Underground: Behind the Scenes of Our Second Avenue Subway Cover Shoot
text: For this week’s cover article, the photographer Richard Barnes went deep into the bowels of New York City to capture the otherworldly atmosphere of the Second Avenue Subway construction. I accompanied Barnes on one of his descents into the construction zone, and later conducted this Q. and A. with him.

headline: Slovenia Leads Games in Medals Per Capita
text: LONDON — Once again, the United States, China and, to a lesser degree, Russia, are battling to become the nation with the biggest haul of Olympic medals. That is no surprise: their teams have the best resources – training facilities and so on – to produce athletes like Michael Phelps and a raft of Michael Jordan-like badminton and table tennis players.

headline: Splitsville for Team Anna?
text: Anna Hazare, the anti-corruption crusader, may be organizing a political party, but he has no plans to join it. Nor to be a candidate for office. Nor to continue the work of Team Anna.

headline: The Shame of Putin’s Courts
text: MOSCOW — Of all the bad feelings one can have about one’s own country, shame is the most painful. Righteous outrage motivates one to act; sadness breeds solidarity; even fear can bring people together. But shame not only makes you want to jump out of your skin, it also means you have already effectively jumped out of the skin that is your country.

headline: Philippines Moves Forward With Bill to Improve Contraceptive Access
text: MANILA — Despite opposition from the powerful Roman Catholic Church, a bill that would mandate sex education in schools and subsidize contraceptives moved ahead on Monday after being stalled in the Philippine Congress for 14 years.

headline: Middle East Journal: I’ll Stick With Our Model (as Long as I Can)
text: This is my last post on my trip to the Middle East. It’s going to be a while before I see any return on my investment, but the cost has not been outrageous. The trip cost about $4,100, including the two Gold Key fees. I’ll be reimbursed for about half of that by the State of Pennsylvania. We are in the process of putting together printed materials, and I’m mulling another trip in the fall to present them.

headline: Video of News Conference About Shooting at Sikh Temple in Wisconsin

Our colleagues Steven Yaccino, Jennifer Preston and Marc Santora are following the investigation.

headline: Swept Off Her Feet
text: When is a shoe not just a shoe? Why, when it’s a love object, a fetish or an alternate dream of self, of course. Shoes, like handbags, have grown in cultural stature over the last few decades, sending out coded and not so coded messages about the women who wear them: I am sexy, chic, kooky; I can walk without falling down in four-inch heels; I can afford to spend gobs of money on elusive brands and esoteric leathers. Manhattan department stores have, in the last few years, enlarged their shoe departments, in recognition of their allure and “recession-proof” sales potential, in many cases taking away space from what was once the main event — the clothes themselves.

headline: Why Your Family Should Talk About Money More Often
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

He is gay.

headline: Persistence Is Key to Treating Sexual Pain
text: Millions of women experience vaginal discomfort, and sometimes crippling pain, for a variety of reasons, most often a loss of estrogen. The resulting vaginal dryness and atrophy can make sexual intercourse, a pelvic exam, urinating, or even sitting, walking or cycling a painful nightmare.

headline: S.E.C. Gets Encouragement, but Needs Something More

That is pretty much what a federal jury told the Securities and Exchange Commission when it urged the government to continue to pursue financial fraud cases involving Wall Street while finding the agency had not proven that a former Citigroup banker, Brian H. Stoker, had violated securities laws.

headline: A Provençal Reunion, With Vegetables at the Center of the Plate
text: Last month I had a reunion in Provence with friends who discovered this magical region of France with me more than 30 years ago. It was a true southern French vacation – we relaxed, we went to the market, we cooked. Market stalls were piled high with summer squash, tomatoes and eggplant, green beans — both regular ones and the flat ones that we call romano beans and that my Provençal market labeled cocos — onions of all kinds, braids of plump pink garlic, and leeks. Even the supermarket produce sections were inspiring. We bought short-grain rice from the Camargue, southwest of our area of Provence, for our risottos, and a local wheat berry called petit épeautre for chewy pilafs and grain salads. We ate peaches, apricots, amazing strawberries and melons for dessert and for breakfast.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Courtney Force and Erica Enders Produce History at the Dragstrip
text: Having lost twice in final-round eliminator races this summer, Courtney Force, a rookie in the National Hot Rod Association’s Funny Car division and the daughter of the driver-owner John Force, was poised for a breakthrough entering the Nationals event at Pacific Raceways, in Kent, Wash., on Sunday.

headline: Age Claims a Community of Women
text: At the foot of a long drive leading to the Franciscan Retreat Center in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., the “Welcome and Parking” sign is misleading. The convent closed in 2011, when its original population of 100 nuns had dwindled to 35, the youngest past age 60, most in their 80s and 90s, and a few past their 100th birthdays.

headline: Peeling, Seeding and Grating Tomatoes
text: Tomato season is finally here, and to celebrate, this week’s column is all about tomato salads. With tomatoes this good, it’s a shame to cook them, especially at the beginning of the season before any of us have a chance to tire of the sweet fruit.

headline: As Greece Rounds Up Migrants, Official Says ‘Invasion’ Imperils National Stability
text: ATHENS — A vast police operation here aimed at identifying illegal immigrants found that, of 6,000 people detained over the weekend, 1,400 did not have proper documentation, leading the minister of public order to say that Greece was suffering an “unprecedented invasion” that was threatening the stability of the debt-racked nation.

headline: A Stubborn Racial Disparity in Who Calls the Upper East Side Home
text: Bernard Walker had just been promoted when word began circulating at his church that there was an apartment available on 86th Street and First Avenue. The tall, beige building with neat rows of balconies did not excite his wife at first, but when she saw the apartment and its walk-in closet, he said, she was sold. That was about 45 years ago, and they have been there ever since.

headline: Wisconsin Shooter Identified as Army Vet
text: The suspect in the shooting rampage that left six people dead and three wounded at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin has been identified as Wade Michael Page, law enforcement officials announced on Monday.

text: LONDON — Britain won the gold medal in team show jumping on Monday afternoon, narrowly defeating the Netherlands in a rare jump-off.

headline: Comparing Credit Cards’ Auto Rental Insurance
text: Many credit card companies offer accident insurance when the cards are used to pay for a rental car. But details of coverage vary depending on the network behind the card, a report from CardHub.com finds.

headline: John C. McGinley Joins ‘Glengarry Glen Ross’ Revival on Broadway
text: The high-testosterone crucible of David Mamet’s “Glengarry Glen Ross” continues to add to its roster of prominent possessors of Y chromosomes for a coming Broadway revival. John C. McGinley, who played the acid-tongued Dr. Perry Cox on the NBC comedy “Scrubs” and the tough-as-nails Sergeant O’Neill in Oliver Stone’s Vietnam War drama, “Platoon,” will play the embittered real estate salesman Dave Moss in the “Glengarry” revival, its producers said on Monday.

headline: U.S.-Mexico Preview, Part 1: The A Team
text: One year ago this week, in his first game as United States national team coach, Jurgen Klinsmann’s squad eked out a 1-1 draw against Mexico at Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia. On that night the team started poorly but seemed to draw strength from its optimistic, charismatic leader. Trailing at the half, it clawed back and got a result. All things considered, it was a good showing for both coach and team.

headline: American Ballet Theater Announces Apprentice Program
text: Developing young dancers will be a new focus at American Ballet Theater. The company has announced the creation of a program for six dancers to work as apprentice members of Ballet Theater’s corps de ballet, Kevin McKenzie, the artistic director, said on Monday. The selected dancers will train under Kate Lydon, ABT Studio Company’s artistic associate, and Clinton Luckett, ABT’s Ballet master, for 10 weeks beginning in September, and they will then advance to apprentice level with American Ballet Theater during the company’s performances of “The Nutcracker” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. According to the announcement, training will provide full immersion into the ballets in ABT’s repertory, including tutorials in ballet story lines, history, style and mime. In addition, dancers will attend seminars in hair and makeup and company etiquette in preparation for entering the main company. The dancers will be selected first from among the students at the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School, second from among Summer Intensive students and by audition. Their apprenticeship will continue throughout ABT’s performance season ending July 2013.

headline: 3 Ads Warn About Budget Cuts for Children’s Programs
text: A new campaign created by the Minneapolis office of Fallon Worldwide for the Children’s Defense Fund, the advocacy group, uses social media to explain the long-term costs of cutting government-financed initiatives for children.

headline: Sparing Sewers All That Restaurant Grease
text: Every hour of every day, plants across the United States treat the waste that flows through the nation’s sewers. The process is energy-intensive. Wastewater treatment plants often consume more electricity than any other service a city provides — sometimes even as much as 30 to 40 percent of its overall energy consumption, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: ‘Reckless and Slanderous’
text: I won’t defend Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, who—presumably because he’s not up for reelection—claimed last week that Mitt Romney won’t release his tax returns because he hasn’t paid taxes in ten years. His source: An unnamed Bain insider. That’s improbable and I agree with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell that it’s “beneath the dignity” of Mr. Reid’s office to spread rumors. (If it turns out Mr. Reid is correct, I’ll be the first to apologize.)

headline: Del Toro Shoes Offer a Flash for Fall
text: Fall often signals dark colors and luxe fabrics. But for Del Toro, the Miami-based footwear brand best known for its velvet slippers, it means toying with the idea of reflection. The brand is introducing a limited-edition line of sneakers and wingtips made from 3M reflective material, a high-visibility fabric that could be illuminated by headlights (or in many cases, by street-style photographers).

headline: The Twigs Speak to Him
text: Xavier Dumont’s furniture pieces look as if tree limbs fell to the ground and settled into graceful but utilitarian shapes. Mr. Dumont, a French sculptor, created the one-of-a-kind twig-inspired benches and easels now on display at Anthropologie’s gallery at Rockefeller Center. He opened his own design studio in 2005 in Paris, where he lives.

headline: The Ego in ‘Raising Successful Children’
text: Madeline Levine’s opinion column “Raising Successful Children” tops the most e-mailed list on The New York Times this morning. On the one hand, that’s with good reason. I read part of it out loud to my husband last night:

headline: Gibson Guitar To Pay $300,000 in Penalties and Lose Seized Tropical Hardwood
text: The Justice Department has closed its criminal investigation against the Gibson Guitar Company after the company agreed to a series of steps, including payment of $300,000 in penalties and forfeiture of seized rosewood and ebony shipments from India and ebony from Madagascar with an estimated value of more than $419,000.* [3:12 p.m. | Updated | The company may be able to get the Indian wood back, under the terms of the complicated agreement. ]

headline: The Arctic Drilling Countdown
text: After several weeks of delays linked to mechanical problems and persistent sea ice, Shell is completing its final preparations for drilling in the Arctic Ocean, company officials said Monday. The company hopes over the next several days to demonstrate to regulators that its oil spill containment equipment is ready and to receive clearance from the Environmental Protection Agency to operate its drill ships without running afoul of air pollution laws.

headline: Science Times Podcast
text: The science of cheese; the buzz about yeast; and a painful subject for older women.

headline: Bill Blass Fires Designer. Again.
text: Jeffrey Monteiro and the rest of the women’s design team at Bill Blass were dismissed last week in the latest blow to a brand that has had more than its share of them in the last decade. Since Mr. Blass retired in 1999, the struggling company has tried five different women’s designers (or six if you count that season in 2003 when the public relations director was ghost-designing a collection behind the scenes), but has been unable to recapture a high-end customer for its women’s wear.

headline: Skewering Seattle’s Microsoft Elite
text: The free-range hilarity of “Where’d You Go, Bernadette” begins with Bee Branch’s report card from Galer Street School in Seattle, “a place where compassion, academics and global connectitude join together to create civic-minded citizens of a sustainable and diverse planet.” This school gives three grades: S for “Surpasses Excellence,” A for “Achieves Excellence” and W for “Working Towards Excellence.” So every kid is some kind of excellent. But Bee is a straight-S student all the way.

headline: Duke Acquires Papers of Abraham Joshua Heschel
text: Duke University has acquired the papers of Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel, the influential scholar, writer and theologian, the university announced Monday. The collection has never before been available to scholars and includes manuscripts, correspondence, publications, documents and photographs over a 50-year period.

headline: Peru: Antibodies Seen in Amazon Dwellers Suggest That Rabies May Be Survivable

headline: Rubik’s Cube Twists Back Into Limelight

headline: Rubik Resurgence

headline: A Slowdown in Growth, an Increase in Income Inequality
text: The income stagnation of the last decade stems, in the simplest terms, from two factors: a slowdown in economic growth and a rise in inequality, which has concentrated the economy’s modest gains among a small share of the population. In this post, I want to look at both factors in a bit more detail.

headline: At the End of Life, Talk Helps Bridge a Racial Divide

headline: The Get | 3.1 Phillip Lim’s Vendetta Mini Cross-Body

Earning its name from the classic “V for Vendetta,” Lim’s new Vendetta cross-body bag packs a powerful one-two punch: a compact shape and an extra-long strap, making it ideal for quickly slinging over the shoulder (and keeping your superwoman hands free). “I like the idea of it being worn in many different ways, as a messenger during the day and as a clutch at night,” Lim says. The Vendetta comes in classic brown, black and a most coveted color-blocked version. “The basis of the bag comes from structured vintage satchels,” Lim adds. “We played with the idea of color blocking to modernize it and changed the proportion a little, too.” WHAM!

In this video, Ms. Vega follows the production of the online series “East WillyB,” that one of its creators, Julia Ahumada Grob, says can be seen as a “Latino ‘Cheers’ set in gentrifying Brooklyn.” A Kickstarter campaign has come up with $50,000 in financing for new episodes.

headline: Between the Devil and the Deep Blue Sea
text: There’s some sadness in the story of the S.S. United States, which for a time in the 1950s and 1960s was the fastest and most advanced ocean liner ever built. It was the lifelong project of William Francis Gibbs, America’s preeminent naval architect, a self-taught engineer who, among his many other achievements, was instrumental in transforming a German liner captured during World War I into the Leviathan, the pride of America’s postwar passenger fleet. Then, during World War II, he pioneered a revolutionary process to construct the so-called Liberty Ships, which became symbols of America’s industrial might. All along, Gibbs nursed plans to build a revolutionary superliner. But his designs, hatched in his parents’ Philadelphia attic as early 1916, were not realized until 1952. Ten years after its christening, his transatlantic ship would prowl the icy North Atlantic as a kind of floating anachronism, jet planes having turned its record three-day, 10-hour crossing time into a sorry joke. Such is the sweep of “A Man and His Ship” (Simon & Schuster, $30) an absorbing, transporting new history by Steven Ujifusa, which coincides with a show about the S.S. United States now on view at the Forbes Gallery (through Oct. 20).
