headline: Sharon Osbourne Repeats Threat to Quit NBC Show
text: Sharon Osbourne, below, has repeated her threat to leave the hit NBC summer series “America’s Got Talent,” though the network continues to treat her comments as less-than-official positioning for the future. Ms. Osbourne told The New York Post that she was quitting the show over a dispute involving her son, Jack, who was in discussions to appear in another NBC reality competition, “Stars Earn Stripes,” before he was found to have multiple sclerosis earlier this year. The show involves strenuous physical activity and requires that contestants pass a physical exam. An NBC spokeswoman said there had never been a contract with Jack Osbourne for “Stars Earn Stripes.” Ms. Osbourne told The Post there had been an oral commitment for him to take part in the show. The network is taking no public position about Ms. Osbourne’s future participation on “America’s Got Talent,” except to restate that she has a contract with the show, one she renegotiated last year.

headline: Prayer in Missouri

headline: A Governor’s Gift to Nature
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has joined the honor role of governors and conservation groups that have stepped forward at critical moments to protect large parts of the Adirondacks from commercial development. On Sunday, Mr. Cuomo announced that the State of New York had bought 69,000 acres of timberland from the Nature Conservancy, including stretches of the upper Hudson River watershed. The purchase is the largest single addition in more than a century to the state’s “forever wild” forest preserve and will be open to hunting, fishing and recreational use but not to homebuilding and logging.

headline: Verlander Dominates the Yankees While Nova Proves Ineffective Again
text: DETROIT — On April 20, after a decent performance against the Boston Red Sox, Ivan Nova noted that if asked, he would say he is the best pitcher in the world, a comment meant to express self-confidence more than a critical assessment of his talent. Nova is certainly not the best in the world, especially after another dismal outing Monday. But a strong case could be made for the man who beat him.

headline: Chavela Vargas, Mexican Ranchera Singer, Dies at 93
text: MEXICO CITY — Chavela Vargas, whose tender yet fierce interpretations of Mexico’s classic ranchera songs made her a star in Latin America and Spain, died on Sunday in Cuernavaca, Mexico. She was 93.

headline: Celebrities Turn Out for Obama Fund-Raising Event
text: President Obama finished an evening of fund-raising at a star-studded event at the Connecticut home of the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein on Monday night, and even offered his personal review of the latest Batman movie.

headline: Tales and Drinks Don’t Stop at the Rick’s Café of the Hamptons
text: SAG HARBOR, N.Y. — A lot of the talk at the American Hotel is about the American Hotel.

headline: Zambia: Chinese Supervisor Dies During Protest at Mine
text: Workers striking at a Chinese-owned coal mine killed a Chinese supervisor when they hit him with a coal trolley, officials of the mine workers’ union said Monday. Employees at the Collum Coal Mine staged a protest over the weekend, demanding that their pay be raised to match Zambia’s new minimum wage for laborers of about $230 a month, which was announced last month. China has invested heavily in Zambia, a major producer of copper, coal and other minerals. Chinese companies in Zambia have long been accused of mistreating and underpaying their workers, and violence has broken out at the Collum mine during labor disputes in the past. President Michael Sata was elected last year on a largely anti-China platform, but has softened his position since taking office.

headline: Russia: Suicide Bombers Strike at Military Unit in Chechnya
text: Suicide attacks against a military vehicle left four people dead and wounded three on Monday on the outskirts of Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, in Russia’s volatile North Caucasus region. A spokesman for the Russian Interior Ministry said two suicide bombers ambushed an armored military van near a police checkpoint outside of the city. The dual explosions killed three members of a military unit and wounded three others. A fourth body, presumed to be that of one of the bombers, was also found at the scene. The bombing is the first suicide attack in Grozny in nearly a year. Moscow has been battling separatists in Chechnya since the 1990s, but a leader backed by the Kremlin has cracked down on the insurgency.

headline: For U.S. Volleyball Leader, Victories on Court and Off
text: LONDON — The stew of cultures served up by the Olympics is comfort food for Donald Suxho, the starting setter for the United States Olympic men’s volleyball team who immigrated from Albania in the 1990s and met his Ukrainian-born wife in 2005 while playing professionally in Greece.

headline: A Struggling Voting Bloc
text: Because single women have fared the worst among women during the economic downturn, some of their votes could be up for grabs as the message of a better economy becomes more appealing.

headline: Weymouth Journal: British Victory Spurs Sausage Sales
text: Periodically throughout the Olympics, The New York Times will check in with Dennis Spurr, owner of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, England, a pretty town on the coast where the sailing events are taking place. Spurr’s sausage business was targeted by the Olympic branding authorities in 2007 after he put up a sign featuring the Olympic five-ring logo fashioned out of sausage links. He took it down on their demands but replaced it with a sign featuring five squares made out of sausage links.

headline: Joy and Therapy in Making Confetti
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — With great satisfaction, Margaret Carver dumped a few bags of old tax returns and bank statements into a plastic trash container here in front of the Central Square post office. Then Bob Luce, a driver for DataShredder, pushed the container into the metal arms of his mobile shredding truck.

headline: Robert Hughes, Art Critic Whose Writing Was Elegant and Contentious, Dies at 74
text: Robert Hughes, the eloquent, combative art critic and historian who lived with operatic flair and wrote with a sense of authority that owed more to Zola or Ruskin than to his own century, died on Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 74 and had lived for many years in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

headline: In Weak Economy, an Opening to Court Votes of Single Women

She lost the considerable savings she had tucked away after selling her business in 2002, and struggled to find work as a business consultant, recently moving in with a friend in the suburbs who does not charge her rent.

headline: Being Sikh in America
text: On Sunday, my wife and I were having a quiet brunch with friends at home in Pennsylvania when the phone started ringing. First my parents called from their home in Maryland. Then a cousin called from India. “Have you seen what’s on CNN? There’s been a shooting at a gurdwara in Wisconsin…” I felt a familiar emptiness. I had felt the same way after the morning of September 11, 2001.

headline: Is Michigan State Really Better Than Yale?
text: During the M.B.A. gold rush of the past three decades, the Yale School of Management accomplished the unthinkable. As the number of prospective business-school candidates shot up to more than 750,000 a year and tuition payments cleared $100,000, Harvard, Stanford, the University of Chicago and other schools hired star faculty members, built gleaming buildings, established themselves as global brands and brought in tens (and sometimes hundreds) of millions in profits to their universities each year. Meanwhile, Yale somehow lost money.

headline: Miami Dolphins, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview

Since the day he bought this team for $1.1 billion, the owner Stephen Ross has made no secret about his desire to turn the Dolphins into an entertainment darling. No gimmick is too kitschy for Ross – anything to combat the empty orange seats that have become ubiquitous at (Whatever the latest sponsor’s name is) Stadium. Scoff if you want, but in the maddeningly apathetic South Beach sports community, kitschy gimmicks are part of doing business.

headline: The Secret of Neuromarketing: Go for the Pain
text: We all like to think we make buying decisions on a rational level, but neuroscientists tell us otherwise. While marketers have known this instinctively, brain mappers have shown that the smallest part of the brain, the amygdala, lights up like a Christmas tree when confronted with fight-or-flight or in this case buy-or-fly situations.

headline: The Drumbeat of Ramadan
text: ISTANBUL — It is the holy month of Ramadan and, just before twilight, my Istanbul neighborhood fills with an intoxicating smell from the two wood-fire oven bakeries feverishly producing loaf after crusty loaf of seasonal bread. There’s a bustle of last-minute shopping and of people rushing to get home. When the sun finally goes down and the call to prayer comes, the streets are eerily silent except for the clink of cutlery from open apartment windows as families sit down to break the fast.

headline: Near Injection Wells, Many Quakes Go Unfelt
text: A series of small earthquakes made Halloween of 2008 an unusually scary one for people in the Dallas-Fort Worth area. While it has long been theorized that underground injections of fluids from oil and gas development operations could decrease friction and cause faults to slip, the quakes occurred in an area where people weren’t accustomed to tremors, renewing calls for research into the geological consequences of the booming natural gas industry in Texas.

headline: 10 Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Cosmo
text: When I asked my friends about Cosmopolitan to prepare for my recent article in The Times Magazine, some said they wouldn’t be caught dead with a copy outside a doctor’s office or an airplane. But it turns out that reading Cosmo on an airplane — which I’m doing right now — is way, way more intense than reading it at home, because when you’re poring over an article about putting a [whatever] in or around your [whatever], and touching his [whatever] in [whatever method], while trying to lean over the magazine in such a way that hides the almost-naked people in the photographs … I don’t know. It was much easier at home!

headline: London Live: Follow Tuesday’s Action at the Olympics
text: The track and field action kicked off on Tuesday and started with a crash: Liu Xiang of China tumbling out of the heats of the 110-meter hurdles, taking the 2004 gold medalist out of the competition and flashing back to his similar flameout in Beijing. The women’s hurdles provided legitimate excitement, with Sally Pearson of Australia just holding off American Dawn Harper, the 2008 gold medalist, by .02 seconds. Kellie Wells of the United States finished third and Lolo Jones was fourth.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Sikh Temple Shooter’s Hate-Filled Music, and the Apple-Google Chill
text: Wade M. Page, an Army veteran and rock singer who killed six people and wounded three others when he opened fire on Sunday in a Sikh temple in Oak Creek, Wis., was among hundreds of people tracked by the Southern Poverty Law Center for his ties to the white supremacist movement and his role as the leader of a white-power band called End Apathy, Erica Goode and Serge F. Kovaleski report. In an interview posted on the Web site of the record company Label56 (and since taken down), Mr. Page mentioned going to Hammerfest, an annual white-supremacist festival; he also said he played in various neo-Nazi bands, including Blue Eyed Devils, whose song “White Victory” includes the lines: “Now I’ll fight for my race and nation/Sieg Heil!”

headline: Life Term for Gunman After Guilty Plea in Tucson Killings
text: TUCSON — Jared L. Loughner pleaded guilty on Tuesday to killing six people and wounding 13 others last year during a meet-and-greet event here held by Gabrielle Giffords, then a member of the House of Representatives and the primary target of his rampage. The plea brought a sudden resolution to a case that seemed threatened by the fragility of Mr. Loughner’s mental state.

headline: Models, Models, Everywhere

headline: The New Black
text: For years the London-based designer Markus Lupfer and the British retailer Asos.com have made cool and quirky clothes for women — at very different price points (Lupfer, high; Asos, low). Now they’ve gone into business together and are meeting in the middle, offering a 10-piece, all leather, kaleidoscope-patterned collection for the Asos Black label (available in October). “I love the cutout skater dress,” Lupfer says. “It is so cute and fun.” Along the lines of Lupfer’s own ready-to-wear brand — which features glitter-bombed cocktail dresses and loudmouthed graphic tops — Asos Black includes tailored track pants, boxy shell tops, hot-shorts and pencil skirts, as well as pouchettes and utilitarian heels to complete the look. The collaboration hits what Lupfer calls the “nonintimidating” (read: cost-effective) side of high fashion, which is probably why he can comfortably add, “The girls in my office want it all.”

headline: Elizabeth’s Braised Leeks With Parmesan
text: My friend Elizabeth tells me that even people who think they don’t like leeks like this dish. The leeks are braised in wine and water or stock until soft and golden, then topped with Parmesan and run under a broiler, so you get a crunchy layer on top of soft cooked leeks. One of the tricks here is to discard the outer layers that become papery when you cook them, so that the whole leek will be soft and easy to cut through.

headline: Rafalca Does Not Advance in Olympic Dressage
text: LONDON — As he rode into the ring on his horse, Rafalca, the equestrian Jan Ebeling blew a kiss to a few women in the stands he calls the three amigos: his wife, Amy Ebeling; Beth Meyer; and Ann Romney, whose husband, Mitt, is the presumptive presidential candidate for the Republican Party.

headline: New York Comedy Festival Unveils 2012 Lineup
text: Kevin Hart, Bill Maher, Robin Williams and Aziz Ansari are among the funnymen who will be featured at this year’s New York Comedy Festival, its organizers announced on Tuesday. The five-day festival, which is produced by Carolines on Broadway in association with Comedy Central, will kick off its ninth year on Nov. 7, beginning with a Next Big Thing event at the Paley Center for Media and an interview with Ricky Gervais, in conversation with John Hodgman, at Town Hall.

headline: The Daily Shoe | YSL
text: In honor of Bergdorf Goodman’s 111th anniversary, T’s Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the store’s famous shoe salon. Today’s pick: A gold-toed flat from YSL.

headline: American’s Bag Delivery Lets You Skip the Carousel
text: First there were fees for checked bags. Then for carry-ons. Now, American Airlines is adding a fee, but this time it’s for a perk that had not been previously included in the price of a ticket: baggage delivery to the address of a passenger’s choosing.

headline: The Affordable Care Act Rebate Checks Are in the Mail: Now What?
text: Some small businesses were among the most strident opponents of the Affordable Care Act, but by Wednesday, many of these businesses will have received checks totaling $321 million from their health insurance providers, courtesy of the health care overhaul that became law in 2010. The checks are rebates from insurers that did not spend at least 80 percent of the premiums they collected from small group plans on either actual health care expenses or improving the quality of health care, a provision known as the medical loss ratio rule.

headline: Iran Warns U.S. on Fate of Hostages in Syria
text: TEHRAN — Iran said Tuesday that it was holding the United States responsible for the fate of a group of Iranians held by Syrian rebels, as the highest-ranking Iranian official to visit Syria since the antigovernment uprising began there arrived in Damascus to show support for President Bashar al-Assad and attempt to secure the release of the hostages.

headline: The Daily Shoe | YSL
text: In honor of Bergdorf Goodman’s 111th anniversary, T’s Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the store’s famous shoe salon. Today’s pick: A gold-toed flat from YSL.

headline: Russian Booster Rocket Fails to Deliver Satellites
text: MOSCOW — A Russian booster rocket carrying two telecommunications satellites malfunctioned during a launching early Tuesday, failing to deliver the satellites into their proper orbit and rendering them useless and unsalvageable.

headline: Corporate Fraud Cases Often Spare Individuals
text: WASHINGTON — Pharmaceutical companies, military contractors, banks and other corporations are on track to pay as much as $8 billion this year to resolve charges of defrauding the government, analysts say — a record sum and more than twice the amount assessed last year by the Justice Department.

headline: Marvin Hamlisch in Song
text: Videos from some of the films and musicals featuring the composer’s music.

headline: Jessica Hecht and Judith Light to Star in New Richard Greenberg Play
text: Jessica Hecht and Judith Light, who won a Tony Award this year for her performance in “Other Desert Cities,” will star next spring in the world premiere of Richard Greenberg’s new play, “The Assembled Parties,” the Manhattan Theater Club said on Tuesday.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: August 9
text: A fresh crop of leather dresses better suited to real life; the oversize glossy street-culture magazine Sneeze can be found in conspicuously located street boxes; and Jade Lai, the owner of the hip downtown boutique Creatures of Comfort, discusses her picks for fall.

headline: U.S. Coach Keeps Talking, and His Team Keeps Winning
text: LONDON — The United States women’s basketball team battered another overmatched opponent Tuesday. Afterward, Geno Auriemma talked the way only Geno Auriemma can.

headline: Perfectly Captivating Amid All Their Imperfections
text: MANCHESTER, England

headline: Jamaica’s Blake Faces 200 With a Nudge From Bolt
text: LONDON – Yohan Blake is young and fast, but if he leaves the London Olympics without a gold medal in the individual sprints, it will be his own fault. He’s the one who woke up the sleeping giant.

headline: Christie, Rubio and Ryan
text: An addendum to Bill Kristol and Stephen Hayes’s Weekly Standard case that Mitt Romney should choose either Marco Rubio or Paul Ryan as his running mate raises the possibility that Romney might still be considering Chris Christie:

headline: Pfizer Settles U.S. Charges of Bribing Doctors Abroad
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Tuesday that it had reached a $45 million settlement with Pfizer to resolve charges that subsidiaries of Pfizer and Wyeth, which it acquired in 2009, bribed overseas doctors and other health care workers to increase sales of their drugs.

headline: Pregnant, Depressed and Surprised
text: A pregnancy (especially a first pregnancy) is in so many ways a rabbit hole.

headline: British Brothers Are Again Atop an Increasingly Popular Sport
text: LONDON — To win a medal at the men’s Olympic triathlon Tuesday, it took a band of brothers, not all of them related. Alistair Brownlee, the prohibitive favorite, delivered Britain its 19th gold medal of these Games with an 11-second victory over Javier Gómez of Spain. Brownlee’s younger brother, Jonathan, was 31 seconds back, in third.

headline: Scenes in Tableau: Drama Strategies to Use With Any Day’s Times (Part 2)
text: This week is Drama Week on The Learning Network, and we’ve teamed with David Kener, a teacher and former executive director of the American Place Theater Literature to Life Program, to bring you different strategies daily for using theater techniques in classes across the curriculum.

headline: Historical Society Exhibit to Focus on World War II and New York City
text: Helping to fill the seemingly endless appetite for information about World War II, the New-York Historical Society is planning a major exhibition on the conflict’s effect on the homefront this fall.

headline: ‘NBC Nightly News’ Adds Three Million Viewers From Olympics
text: Nothing has helped the recently flagging fortunes of NBC News like the injection of large audiences after coverage of the Olympics on the network this summer.

headline: Nicoletta
text: Inside the chef Michael White’s new pizzeria in the East Village.

headline: On Our Radar: Manila as Waterworld
text: Deadly torrential rains worsened by a tropical storm submerge over half of the Philippine capital. The storm is now headed for Zhejiang Province in China, where more than 250,000 people have been evacuated ahead of its anticipated landfall late Wednesday. [Reuters]

headline: Broadway Shows’ Closings Are Good for Business
text: Three Broadway productions saw expected upticks at the box office last week given that their runs were coming to an end, two newcomers showed mixed results and big-ticket shows that have been dominant for months mostly held steady, according to the weekly grosses and other data released by the productions.

headline: Alongside Rudolph’s Ilk, Yoiking in Lapland
text: Nils-Heikki Paltto is far from the only reindeer herder who hates wolverines, loves the solitude of tracking his herd on snowmobile during the dim Arctic winter, and knows how to yoik, a form of singing that falls somewhere between a chant and a yodel. Yoiking is the unique tradition of his Sami people, the indigenous group that populates (minimally) the northern stretches of Norway, Sweden and Finland that we call Lapland.

headline: The Quotable Robert Hughes
text: It often seemed as if Robert Hughes, the critic and historian who died Monday at 74, never wrote a bad sentence. And he wrote many hundreds of thousands of them in a wildly industrious career that stretched over almost a half-century, in books, in the pages of Time magazine and in almost any publication that asked him. Here is a highly subjective selection of some of his best:

headline: N.H.T.S.A. to Pedestrians: The Streets Are Getting Meaner
text: On Monday, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration issued an advisory to pedestrians after statistics showed pedestrian fatalities rose by 4 percent in 2010 relative to their levels in 2009. The statistics represented the most recent fatality data available to the federal government as reported by individual states. N.H.T.S.A. expects to release final numbers for 2011 later this year.

headline: An Empire Stretches Its Dough
text: IN an earlier, more primitive era, chefs with an entrepreneurial urge believed that success began with a delicious product. If you cooked something that enough people wanted to eat, you could build an empire that might one day span the country. First, though, you needed 11 secret herbs and spices. You needed special sauce. You needed Hot Doughnuts Now.

headline: Congressional Primaries in Missouri and Michigan Among Those to Watch
text: Nope, sorry. The Congressional primaries are not over yet.

headline: One on One: Steve Mann, Wearable Computing Pioneer
text: Steve Mann is considered by many to be the world’s first cyborg. He has been using wearable computers that assist his vision since the 1970s. Now he wears a display screen over his right eye and is connected to a computer and the Internet. In this edited interview, he discusses “mediated reality”; the coming wearable-computing wars among Apple, Google and RIM; and the brain-computer interface.

headline: An Outsize ‘Ring’ on a Living-Room Scale
text: I have seen segments of the Metropolitan Opera’s latest production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle, directed by Robert Lepage, from various perspectives in addition to performances in the house: “Das Rheingold” projected onto large screens in Times Square (in a deluge) and in an HD screening at a movie theater in Ellsworth, Me.; “Die Walküre” in HD at a theater in Manhattan. Soon I will be able to view it in the intimacy of my living room, and you will too, on eight DVDS or five Blu-ray discs, to be released by Deutsche Grammophon on Sept. 11.

headline: Pictures of the Day From London | August 7, 2012
text: The 12th day of the London Olympics.

headline: So Where do Guys Eat, After All?
text: Guy food. What is it? Well, it’s manly, see. Turns out there are guy-food categories: steakhouses, barbecue joints, seafood shacks, brew pubs, taco stands, pizza parlors, burger spots, sandwich places and “adventurous eating.” And now Men’s Health magazine has announced the nine finalists, one in each of those categories, for its “2012 Manliest Restaurants in America” competition.

headline: Leader, but Never the Winner
text: LONDON — The capacity crowd at the Olympic Velodrome on Tuesday roars in anticipation. Six highly trained and fit cyclists set off on a race for gold.

headline: Returning to Campaign Trail, Romney Presses Welfare Attack
text: ELK GROVE VILLAGE, Ill. — Mitt Romney returned to the campaign trail on Tuesday to press a theme that his campaign had hit earlier in the day  with a new advertisement, accusing President Obama of gutting the work requirement at the heart of the federal welfare program, a message designed to peel away middle-class votes from the president.

headline: Indigestion for ‘les Riches’ in a Plan for Higher Taxes
text: PARIS — The call to Vincent Grandil’s Paris law firm began like many others that have rolled in recently. On the line was the well-paid chief executive of one of France’s most profitable companies, and he was feeling nervous.

headline: For One Kenyan Olympian, Throwing Beats Running
text: LONDON — Kenya has sent 44 track and field athletes to the London Games. Forty-three are runners who aspire to win gold medals from 800 meters to the marathon. The other is Julius Yego, javelin thrower.

headline: In ‘Squawk Box’ Case, a Delicate Line for Prosecutors
text: An appeals court ruling that reversed the convictions of six brokers and traders for misusing brokerage firm “squawk boxes” was a setback for the Justice Department.

headline: Flooding Worsens in the Philippines
text: Thousands fled the capital, Manila, on Tuesday as flooding spread, leaving some residents stranded on their roofs awaiting rescue.

headline: Lugar Urges U.S. and Russia to Team Up to Rid Syria of Chemical Weapons
text: MOSCOW — Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican who has been a leading proponent of joint efforts by the United States and Russia to reduce their arsenals of nuclear and chemical weapons, urged on Tuesday that the two countries team up to eliminate the stockpile of chemical weapons in Syria.

headline: With Block Lifted, Paris to Cut Vehicle Traffic Along the Seine
text: PARIS — A dream project of the Socialist mayor of Paris to reduce car traffic along the banks of the Seine has been unblocked by France’s new Socialist government.

headline: Luxury Living in Old Temple of the 5 and Dime
text: The Woolworth Building’s neo-Gothic tower, one of New York City’s most recognizable landmarks, is about to be turned into luxury condominiums, a transformation that would be second only to placing penthouses atop the Chrysler Building or the Empire State Building.

headline: Competitive Armchair Olympics: Easy Rider
text: Click.

headline: Philip Marlowe Set to Return in Novel by John Banville
text: Philip Marlowe is making another comeback. Henry Holt & Company said on Tuesday that Raymond Chandler’s creation, one of the world’s most famous private eyes, will star in a novel written by John Banville to be published in 2013.

headline: Vain Glorious | The Seaweed Secret
text: Who: Repêchage Beauty From the Sea.

headline: Capturing the Winter Songs of Rare Whales
text: Between Greenland and the northern island of Spitsbergen, Norway, in the blackness of the Arctic winter, a group of rare whales sing in ghostly screeches and drawn-out creaks, eerie whistles and hollow screams, day in, day out, in the ice-laden water.

headline: How ‘Mildred Pierce’ Explains the World
text: The four most overrated things in life, Christopher Hitchens once said, are “Champagne, lobsters, anal sex and picnics.” This remark was repeated at his memorial service this past April in New York City. The next speaker was the British comic Stephen Fry, who is out and proud. “Well,” he commented, “three out of four isn’t bad.”

headline: On Its Centenary, Celebrating a Ride That Advanced Physics
text: BAD SAAROW-PIESKOW, Germany — Precisely where Victor Hess, his electroscopes and his hot-air balloon touched down is a mystery.

headline: What Influences Consumers to Buy or Rent Their Homes
text: Even the deepest housing crisis since the Great Depression wasn’t enough to dampen Americans’ desire to own their homes.

headline: British Brothers Dominate Triathlon
text: Alistair Brownlee was first and his brother Jonny finished third, giving Britain its first medals in the event.

headline: Six-Second Goalkeeper Rule Proves Baffling to Many
text: The critical, controversial call that helped the United States women’s soccer team score the tying goal in its overtime victory over Canada may not have been wrong, but that does not mean it was right, either.

headline: TimesCast Politics | August 7, 2012
text: Republicans say Obama 'gutted' welfare. | The push for a female debate moderator. | Parts of the Republican coalition look for trouble. | Romney's new 'protective pool.'

headline: The Sport of Olympic Pin Collecting
text: Pin trading at the Olympics is a sport in itself, and anyone can qualify. The Times’s Ken Belson went to the Olympic park with 10 New York Times pins to see what he could acquire.

headline: Sipping on a Sunset, Italy in Mind
text: JUST as the culinary cognoscenti press us into embracing certain food trends (“You will eat pork belly! Love cupcakes now! Hate cupcakes now!”) so, too, do they dictate our drinks.

headline: The Caucus Click: A Hug for Caray
text: Mitt Romney gave a hug to Dutchie Caray, wife of the Chicago Cubs announcer Harry Caray at a campaign event at Harry Caray’s restaurant in Chicago.

headline: Painted Black, Nissan NV200 Taxi Is Poised for London Duty
text: The Nissan NV200 van, the same model chosen to be New York’s Taxi of Tomorrow, was announced on Monday for service in London.

headline: Marvin Hamlisch, the Pro’s Pro
text: 3:52 p.m. | Updated How fitting that Marvin Hamlisch, a one-time rehearsal pianist for countless singers and dancers, should have created the vamp of all Broadway musical vamps for “A Chorus Line.” That vamp, set to words by Edward Kleban as the song “One,” is the thematic thread and engine of a show whose score would not have cohered without it. This motif, so elemental that it seems to have existed forever, is the catapult behind everything else in the show.

headline: Calling Jack Horner
text: Greenmarkets normally win plaudits for selling produce that’s locally grown and often organic, but they also sell items that are simply not available anywhere else.

headline: Marvin Hamlisch, Whose Notes Struck Gold, Dies at 68
text: Marvin Hamlisch, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer who imbued his movie and Broadway scores with pizazz and panache and often found his songs in the upper reaches of the pop charts, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 68 and lived in New York.

headline: Weight Training May Lower Diabetes Risk
text: Doctors routinely recommend regular aerobic exercise to reduce the risk of Type 2 diabetes. But for those who prefer resistance training to running on a treadmill, a new study shows that weight training can protect against diabetes as well.

headline: Federal Judge Grudgingly Approves Morgan Stanley Price-Fixing Case
text: Over objections from consumer groups and New York officials, a federal judge on Tuesday approved a $4.8 million settlement between the Justice Department and Morgan Stanley over accusations of price fixing in the electricity market.

headline: A Kitchen Rainbow
text: Bialetti, an Italian cookware company, introduced its five-quart oval pasta pot more than 10 years ago. I loved its shape, which neatly accommodated a pound or two of long pasta like spaghetti, and its colanderlike lid, which locked in place for easy draining. I even put up with the color, metallic blue. Now Bialetti has introduced an array of hues: red, charcoal gray, purple, turquoise and orange. Meanwhile, I have discovered some uses besides preparing pasta: It will hold six ears of corn on the cob, and is ideal for steaming or boiling two 1 ¼-pound lobsters.

headline: Filipinos Turn to Twitter as a Lifeline After Severe Flooding
text: The worst flooding since 2009 has swamped major streets in Manila and nine provincial areas around the city, as rescue workers used rafts and boats to try to rescue people trapped on rooftops or in buildings. As my colleague Floyd Whaley writes, more than 50 people have been killed and at least 250,000 have been evacuated in the last week in the flooding, which was set off by a series of storms and monsoon rains

headline: Thick Crust or Thin: What’s Your Slice?
text: This week Pete Wells reviews Nicoletta, the East Village pizzeria where the chef Michael White had hoped, he said, to conjure the Wisconsin pizza of his youth, a pie with a crust that’s not too thick or too thin, cut into squares. What he is serving instead has a crust that, while not deep-dish, approaches that heft, sliced into the usual triangles.

headline: Sunglasses From Oliver Peoples and Parabellum
text: Oliver Peoples has paired up with Parabellum, the leather goods company, for a limited line of two unisex sunglasses, resulting in a curious intersection of rugged and polish.

headline: Top Two Finishers in Beijing Trade Places
text: LONDON — As Australia’s Sally Pearson sailed over hurdle after hurdle Tuesday, a crowd of 80,000 at Olympic Stadium erupted in a roar, but she said she could not hear a thing.

headline: A Sikh Temple’s Century
text: THE Stockton Gurdwara in California — the first Sikh temple in the United States — is celebrating its 100th anniversary this year. Immigrants from Punjab, India, purchased the lot on Grant Street in early 1912.

headline: Get Comfy With Your Sofa Before It’s Delivered
The Folly of Attacking Outsourcing
text: The middle class, I’m sure you’ve heard, is under threat by cheap foreign labor. We must be having an election soon. President Obama’s assault on Mitt Romney for sending jobs overseas draws from a playbook used repeatedly by politicians of the right and left over the last two decades.

headline: George Romney’s Extra, Extra-Value Meals
text: On the campaign trail, Mitt Romney rarely tells detailed personal stories from his life, an omission that has left some voters grasping for a flesh-and-blood narrative to latch onto.

headline: Come See Our Play. But Watch the Movie First.
text: They’re somewhat rare, but theater prequels and sequels are out there. There are two prequels actually running now on Broadway: “Wicked,” an origin story about the witches from “The Wizard of Oz,” and “Peter and the Starcatcher,” about the life of a young Peter Pan.

headline: A Note to My Readers
text: In a recent blog post, I used an inappropriate phrase to refer to the late VP of PR for Chick-fil-A. My choice of words did not rise to either my own standards or to The Times’s, and the phrase has been removed from the post. I regret this lapse.

headline: Obama Signs Law Requiring Him to Detail Budget Cuts
text: President Obama agreed on Tuesday to tell Congress within a month just how he would make nearly $1 trillion in automatic spending cuts scheduled to take effect starting at the beginning of 2013.

headline: TimesCast Politics: A New Republican Charge on Welfare Change
text: Charles Dharapak/Associated Press

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Zip It
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Is Manchester United’s Ferguson the Ultimate Insider?
text: “Real fans,” as Manchester United Manager Alex Ferguson put it, should not be concerned over the Glazer family’s debt-laden ownership of soccer’s most valuable team.

headline: Buoyed by ‘Avengers,’ Disney Profit Surges 24 Percent
text: LOS ANGELES — The success of the film “Marvel’s The Avengers” and the “Cars”-related expansion of a theme park powered the Walt Disney Company to a 24 percent increase in quarterly profit, well ahead of expectations, the company reported Tuesday.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: These Little Piggies

headline: Cake Shop Avoids Closing Down
text: After months of financial uncertainty, the indie-rock club Cake Shop has collected enough money through a novel Internet fund-raising site to avoid closing down, one of the owners, Nick Bodor, said on Tuesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Egypt, the Philippines and India.

headline: Karmazin Tones Down Language on Sirius Takeover
text: Is the boardroom drama at Sirius XM Radio cooling down?

headline: Changing Seasons
text: The view from the property where the author rented a cabin in the Maine woods and installed a game camera on a tree there last October.

headline: In $440 Million Trading Error, Upside of Wall St. Failures
text: The near implosion of the Knight Capital Group on an accidental $440 million trading loss may make many feel that Wall Street firms are on automatic self-destruct with the timer set to go off fairly soon.

headline: Anna Piaggi, Fashion Editor With a Keen Eye for Trends, Dies at 81
text: ANNA PIAGGI, an oracular Italian fashion editor known for an endless array of eye-popping, wildly colorful outfits of the most peculiar combinations, ranging from vintage Patou to thermal mountain rescue coats to a uniform vest from late-period McDonald’s, died Tuesday at her home in Milan. She was 81.

headline: Competitive Armchair Olympics: Beach Boys
text: Click.

headline: Obama to Make Three-Day Campaign Swing Through Iowa
text: At a time when he usually races from state to state seeking votes, President Obama has decided to invest much of next week in a single place, Iowa, the one where it all began for him.

headline: Black Keys, Foo Fighters and Neil Young to Headline Benefit Concert in Central Park
text: The Black Keys, Foo Fighters and Neil Young and Crazy Horse will be on the bill for a charity concert in Central Park next month intended to motivate people to do something to alleviate extreme poverty around the world, organizers announced on Tuesday.

headline: A Beginner’s Guide to Olympic Pin Collecting
text: LONDON – For Olympic athletes, glory comes wrapped in gold, silver and bronze. For some of the rest of us, it comes in the form of an enamel pin.

headline: Footnotes
text: The Public Theater said that its production of “Into the Woods” at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park would run through Sept. 1, a week longer than originally scheduled. The Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical began previews on July 24 and officially opens Thursday. ... In other fairy tale news, “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella,” already announced for Broadway with Laura Osnes as Cinderella and Santino Fontana as the Prince, has a theater and an opening date. The musical will start previews at the Broadway Theater on Jan. 21 with an official opening night of Feb. 21, according to a release.

headline: Highlighting Contrasts and Not Holding Back
text: When the Chamber Orchestra of Europe took its first steps into the spotlight, it left a mixed impression. This was an ensemble of young musicians, mostly alumni of the European Union Youth Orchestra, who wanted to continue working together as a professional group, and you wanted to root for them. They gave you plenty to work with: on their early recordings and tours the playing was energetic and trim, but it could also be cautious and prim, as if only the most finely polished performances were acceptable.

headline: Our Extinction, via the Internet
text: The future according to Tom Hanks: post-apocalyptic, with electricity rationed and rebels communicating via antique radios. The future according to the “CSI” creator Anthony Zuiker: tenuous, with the world about to fall victim to a vast online fraud.

headline: Gutting Welfare
text: In 2005, 29 Republican Governors requested more flexibility in implementing welfare work requirements. They asked Congress for “increased waiver authority, allowable work activities, availability of partial work credit” in order to “effectively serve low-income” Americans according to their states’ needs. One of these governors was, as the mayor of London once put it, a guy called Mitt Romney.

headline: Gulping the Heady, Thin Air of Creativity
text: VAIL, Colo. — Even on a rainy evening here, the walk from the center of this town to the Gerald R. Ford Amphitheater, where most performances of the Vail International Dance Festival take place, is a thrill for the senses: you pass through pine trees beside a rushing mountain stream amid the Rockies. And after several performances, the walk home features a sky full of unusually bright stars.

headline: The Family Breakfast
text: As a mother, I daydream about the ideal family dinner, a sort of mini-Thanksgiving with a Norman Rockwell haze to it. I love the idea of a family seated around the table, talking over the events of the day, learning table manners, conversational skills and good nutritional habits.

headline: Woman Prepares to Officiate and Make N.F.L. History
text: Shannon Eastin, who was overruled by her mother when she wanted to play youth football, will make it to the N.F.L. on Thursday night. Eastin will become the first woman to officiate an N.F.L. game when the San Diego Chargers host the Green Bay Packers in a preseason game.

headline: Lots of Sand at P.G.A., but No Bunkers
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — There are more than 30 acres of waste area at the Ocean Course, host to this week’s P.G.A. Championship, and although much of those areas is made of sand, none of it will be considered a bunker.

headline: TimesCast Politics
text: Jodi Kantor reports on the push for a female debate moderator.

headline: Defending Champs Advance to an All-U.S. Final
text: LONDON — Misty May-Treanor and Kerri Walsh Jennings reasserted their dominance in women’s beach volleyball Tuesday, defeating China in two sets in their semifinal match. They will face their United States teammates, April Ross and Jennifer Kessy, for the gold medal Wednesday.

headline: Twin Prostitutes, Growing Old Plying Their Trade in Amsterdam
text: When Martine Fokkens bustles into the small grocery store early in “Meet the Fokkens,” a 2011 documentary portrait of identical twin prostitutes, she calls out a cheery hello to the man behind the counter. She has a purple hat and orange scarf framing her plump white face and a Chihuahua tucked under an arm, and what she needs, she announces, is a box of condoms. She was 69 when the movie was shot and still plying her trade from one of the picture windows in Amsterdam’s red-light district. Two years earlier her sister, Louise, had hung up her own riding crop because, as the second twin explains in this insistently upbeat movie, “I couldn’t get one leg over the other.”

headline: Craigslist’s Challenger Could Be an App, or Several
text: A few days ago an incoming alert caught my eye. Someone had posted a public message through Highlight, an iPhone app that shows people who else is nearby whom they might want to meet.

headline: Cuomo to Attend Only Last  Day of Democratic National Convention
text: Despite his growing stature within the Democratic Party, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is skipping most of the Democratic National Convention next month because, he said, he is too busy with his day job in New York.

headline: Artistry Fades as Gymnasts Push Boundaries
text: The American gymnast Aly Raisman won an Olympic gold medal in the floor exercise Tuesday with a score of 15.6, well above the silver medalist Catalina Ponor’s 15.2 (a huge margin in the fractional point differences of gymnastics) and the bronze medalist Aliya Mustafina’s14.9. The difference in the scores reflects the difficulty of these women’s routines.

headline: An Irish Revolutionary Checks Out the Sights 90 Years After His Death
text: The other day, Richard Teahan was strolling down Fifth Avenue with Michael Collins under his arm when a woman covered fully by a burqa approached him near 65th Street and asked for directions to the Port Authority Bus Terminal.

headline: Lifting 545 Pounds Over His Head for Olympic Gold
text: The Iranian weight lifter Behdad Salimikordasiabi won gold with a 545-pound lift. Mark Cannella, a former United States coach, explains how he did it.

headline: Take Part in Live Op-Ed Video Discussions
text: This year at the Republican and Democratic conventions, we will be training our eyes and ears as far outside the bubble as we can. In a series of four live videos, New York Times Op-Ed columnists, including Frank Bruni and Gail Collins, will be talking to you and, we hope, with you about four key issues in the campaign. Since Campaign Stops began on Nov. 6 last year, you have contributed more than 60,000 comments. Now we’re giving you another chance to speak up.

headline: Wealthy in France May Pay More
text: How much higher taxes might be in France under a proposed law.

headline: Woods Keeps Things Light, Even Amid Dark Clouds
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — Tiger Woods was speaking, but the boom of thunder overhead would not let him be heard. Then he was trying to listen, but the drumbeat of rain pounding on the roof would not let him hear.

headline: Philanthropist Wants to Be Rid of His Last $1.5 Billion
text: Across from a television set with the obsolete girth of a model bought 20 years ago, beneath the grandchildren’s crayon artwork taped to the wall, to the left of an abandoned hula hoop, Charles F. Feeney sits in an armchair and explains how he will get rid of his last $1.5 billion, give or take, by 2016.

headline: "Understands"
text: A new ad from Priorities USA, a "super PAC" supporting President Obama, attacked Mitt Romney for the closing of a factory by Bain Capital.

headline: Another Jets Dust-Up Is One Too Many for Ryan
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — On a crisp, cloudless morning, midway through the Jets’ second straight contentious practice, Rex Ryan finally showed Tuesday that he actually has a boiling point, abruptly stopping a drill and angrily ordering the Jets to line up.

headline: Risking Life, Limb and Dignity With Stupid Human Tricks

headline: With Eight More Hits, Jeter Will Join Aaron

When he looked around, he found one of the game’s greatest players standing there. It was Hank Aaron, who said he had long been looking forward to meeting Jeter, who was then only 25 but already had two World Series championships.

headline: Stony Brook and Albany to Join Colonial Athletic Association in Football
text: The Colonial Athletic Association will add Stony Brook and Albany to its football-only membership beginning in 2013, the league announced Tuesday.

text: Twitter officials have complied with a court order to turn over account information to help New York police investigators identify who threatened to carry out an attack like the Colorado movie theater shooting at a Broadway theater where Mike Tyson is appearing in a one-man show, the police said Tuesday.

headline: Egypt’s Sinai Problem
text: Update: On Wednesday, after this editorial was published, Egypt was reported to have launched its first airstrikes in decades in the Sinai Peninsula, deploying attack helicopters to strike at gunmen after the shootings of 16 Egyptian soldiers on Sunday. Few details are known, but it appeared to be a retaliatory action to defend Egypt against an upsurge in attacks by militants. The strikes will add to tensions between the new government of President Mohamed Morsi, an Islamist, and the largely secular Egyptian army.

headline: Fraud in Special Education

headline: Iranian Easily Lifts Spirits of His Country

headline: Heavy Burden on Athletes Takes Joy Away From China’s Olympic Success
text: BEIJING — When Liu Xiang, China’s track and field superstar, crashed to the ground at the London Olympic Games on Tuesday after stumbling over the first hurdle in his 110-meter men’s hurdles heat, an announcer on the state broadcaster openly wept and subway riders thronging platform television screens gasped in horror.

headline: After Shooting, Searching for Clues in the Music of Hate
text: As a teenager, Wade M. Page, the 40-year-old gunman who killed six people and wounded three others at the Wisconsin Sikh Temple on Sunday, developed a passion for music. His stepmother, Laura Page, 67, recalled that he worshiped the guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan.

headline: Aug. 7: North Carolina Isn’t Central to Electoral Math
text: There were two polls out in Colorado on Tuesday showing apparently contradictory results. One survey, from Rasmussen Reports, had an exact tie there. Another, from Public Policy Polling, put President Obama ahead by six points, or by four points with Gary Johnson, a Libertarian, included in the survey. (In cases where pollsters ask questions both with and without Mr. Johnson on the ballot, we simply average the numbers, so our forecast model treats the poll as showing a five-point lead for Mr. Obama.)

headline: In Syria, Potential Threat to Government Air Power Emerges
text: For the first time since the conflict in Syria began last year, an activist opposed to President Bashar al-Assad has publicly presented possible evidence that the antigovernment forces have obtained a heat-seeking, shoulder-fired anti-aircraft missile.

headline: Tennessee: Mosque Is Expected To Open This Week
text: A new mosque that has faced arson, vandalism and a court battle has passed inspection and will be allowed to open by Friday, in time for the final week of Ramadan, its leaders said Tuesday. The State Fire Marshal’s Office said it had issued a temporary certificate of occupancy for 30 days to the Islamic Center of Murfreesboro. For two years, the center’s expansion has faced legal challenges and threats of violence. Vandals painted “not welcome” on construction signs at the mosque and set fire to construction equipment. A Texas man was indicted in June on charges that he left messages threatening to detonate a bomb at the center on Sept. 11. In May, a county judge ruled that the construction plans had not received sufficient comment from the public and that an occupancy permit could not be granted. Federal prosecutors filed a discrimination lawsuit, and a federal judge ruled in the mosque’s favor last month.

headline: Instead of Industrial Giants, Brooklyn Has Niche Factories
text: The hulking five-story brick factory, complete with an emblematic smokestack, once braided rope for New York’s shipbuilding industry and employed hundreds of blue-collar workers.

headline: Brazil Gains Business and Influence as It Offers Aid and Loans in Africa
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — In Mozambique, Brazil’s government is opening a plant making antiretroviral drugs to fight the AIDS epidemic. Brazil is lending $150 million to Kenya to build roads and ease congestion in the capital, Nairobi. And in Angola, a rising oil power, a new security agreement seeks to expand the training of Angolan military personnel in Brazil.

headline: In Slip, Romney Refers to ‘Sheik Temple’ Tragedy

text: Under the terms of a deal brokered by his defense team and the prosecution, Jared L. Loughner will spend the rest of his life in prison, and be spared a possible death sentence.

headline: In Russia, Madonna Defends a Band’s Anti-Putin Stunt
text: MOSCOW — Madonna, the pop megastar known for her own less-than-pious adaptation of religious symbols and settings, used a sold-out concert here on Tuesday night to voice support for the three women from a feminist punk band who are being tried on hooliganism charges for staging an anti-Putin stunt on the altar of Moscow’s main Russian Orthodox cathedral.

headline: Pearson Takes Gold in Hurdles
text: Sally Pearson of Australia won the gold in the 100-meter hurdles. Dawn Harper of the United States took the silver.

headline: Chavez Helping Yanks, but They’re Struggling

headline: Romney Presses Obama on Work in Welfare Law
text: ELK GROVE VILLAGE, Ill. — Mitt Romney accused President Obama on Tuesday of gutting one of the signature bipartisan accomplishments of the recent political era: the overhaul of welfare policy.

headline: Echoes of Syria’s War in the Golan Heights

headline: Burkina Faso Official Goes to Islamist-Held Northern Mali in Effort to Avert War
text: DAKAR, Senegal — A rare diplomatic opening inside Islamist-held northern Mali was tried on Tuesday by the foreign minister of neighboring Burkina Faso — an attempt to avert a war that some Western officials say is now nearly inevitable.

headline: Obama Is an Avid Reader, and Critic, of the News
text: WASHINGTON — A few months after President Obama’s $787 billion economic stimulus package passed, he began to notice news reports, but not about the jobs the bill might create or how much of the country’s infrastructure it would repair. Instead, the articles focused on traffic jams.

headline: Accusations Against Bank on Iran Deals Surprised U.S. Regulators, Too
text: Top executives at Standard Chartered said they were surprised when New York’s banking regulator accused them on Monday of scheming with the Iranian government to launder billions of dollars to potentially support terrorist activities.

headline: Yes, It’s a Sport, and Russia’s Sinister Dolls Win
text: LONDON — One team wore bathing suits decorated with a picture of what appeared to be an owl dressed in a tuxedo. Another began its routine with the athletes lying, inert, by the side of the pool. And in an homage to the Mexican artist Frida Kahlo, a third team, the synchronized swimming duet from Italy, tried to imagine how it might look to descend into madness while performing intricate leg maneuvers upside down in an Olympic swimming pool.

headline: Security Questions Are Raised by Break-In at a Nuclear Site
text: WASHINGTON — An 82-year-old nun and two fellow pacifists who penetrated the defenses of one of the nation’s most important nuclear weapons facilities last week are due in federal court in Knoxville, Tenn., on Thursday to face charges of trespassing and spray-painting antiwar slogans on a building that houses nuclear bomb fuel. But the incident has also put the Department of Energy’s security system on trial.

headline: Mark O’Donnell, ‘Hairspray’ Writer, Dies at 58
text: Mark O’Donnell, who won a Tony Award in 2003 as co-author of the book for the Broadway musical “Hairspray” and was nominated for another in 2008 for “Cry-Baby,” died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 58.

headline: Kremlin Critic Debugs Office. Tweets About It.

headline: Germany: Criticism Over Man Suspected as Bin Laden Guard
text: German security officials are coming under fire for allowing a Tunisian man they believe may have served as a bodyguard to Osama bin Laden in 2000 to live in western Germany for years, despite being considered a “dangerous jihadist” who they say is spreading extremist views. German authorities insist they have done everything legally possible to curtail the activities of the man, identified only as Sami A., in accordance with privacy laws. He has been under observation since 2004 and is restricted to the city of Bochum, where he lives with his German wife and three children and must check in daily with the police, Birgit Axler, a spokeswoman for the Interior Ministry in North Rhine-Westphalia said Tuesday. Reuters quoted German authorities saying they have had trouble deporting him because of his marriage to a German.

Growing numbers of elite athletes are turning to these natural beverages to provide what they hope will be a legal performance benefit.

headline: Sir Bernard Lovell Dies at 98; a Radio Telescope Bears His Name
text: Sir Bernard Lovell, a pioneer in radar and radio telescopes from the days when the technology helped save Britain in World War II until the beginning of the space age, died Monday at his home in Swettenham Village, England. He was 98.

headline: Fact-Checking Is Not Enough
text: The speaker is a Midwestern Everyman: White, balding, deep in middle age, with hollows around his eyes. He sits at a kitchen table, nursing a cup of coffee, talking about what happened after Bain Capital closed down his steel plant in 2001. He lost his job; his family lost its health insurance. His wife felt lousy but didn’t go to the doctor, to spare the family worry and expense. When she finally ended up in the hospital, the diagnosis was cancer. She had 22 days to live.

headline: A Conversation With: Former Lok Sabha Speaker Somnath Chatterjee
text: Somnath Chatterjee was the speaker of the Lok Sabha, India’s lower house of Parliament, from 2004 to 2009. A widely admired parliamentarian from West Bengal, Mr. Chatterjee had joined the Communist Party of India (Marxist) in 1968. In 2008, he was expelled from the party for refusing to step down as speaker during a no-confidence vote against the government on the issue of the India-U.S. civilian nuclear deal.

headline: Britain Gives Nuclear a 2nd Chance

If things go according to the plans of EDF Energy, the British subsidiary of the French state-owned utility EDF, this verdant hillside overlooking the Bristol Channel in southwest England will be the site of two gigantic nuclear power stations — the first to be built in Britain since the mid-1990s.

headline: Rebels Pull Back as Syrian Military Continues Moving In on Aleppo

headline: What’s So Bad About a Boy Who Wants to Wear a Dress?
text: The night before Susan and Rob allowed their son to go to preschool in a dress, they sent an e-mail to parents of his classmates. Alex, they wrote, “has been gender-fluid for as long as we can remember, and at the moment he is equally passionate about and identified with soccer players and princesses, superheroes and ballerinas (not to mention lava and unicorns, dinosaurs and glitter rainbows).” They explained that Alex had recently become inconsolable about his parents’ ban on wearing dresses beyond dress-up time. After consulting their pediatrician, a psychologist and parents of other gender-nonconforming children, they concluded that “the important thing was to teach him not to be ashamed of who he feels he is.” Thus, the purple-pink-and-yellow-striped dress he would be wearing that next morning. For good measure, their e-mail included a link to information on gender-variant children.

headline: Watching a Spectacular Public Meltdown With Just a Hint of Jealousy

headline: A Pattern of Dolphins
text: Scott Baker, associate director of the Marine Mammal Institute at Oregon State University, writes from Samoa, where he studies the formation of local communities among dolphins, and their genetic isolation from one another.

headline: Conversion Ratings
text: KARACHI — With more than 90 cash-strapped channels competing for the attention of 40 million viewers daily, it’s not surprising that Pakistan’s independent media producers resort to sensationalism to boost ratings. During the holy Muslim month of Ramadan, channel owners and advertisers try to cash in on religious sentiment by hiring celebrities to host ever more elaborate, though only marginally religious, shows.

headline: Still Together, in Separate Beds
text: The chance to watch Meryl Streep or Tommy Lee Jones is often all the encouragement the otherwise reluctant moviegoer needs to risk the kitsch pleasures of “Mamma Mia!”and the familiar genre beats of “Men in Black 3.” The new film “Hope Springs” holds out the delectable promise of watching them work on screen together for the first time, and in a story about a longtime marriage that’s gone dry. It’s a subject that’s as unusual in mainstream American cinema as the sight of major stars letting it all hang out on camera, wrinkles and possibly dignity included, though perhaps not for long, given the movie industry’s growing interest in the country’s aging population.

headline: Feasting After Fasts in the Streets of Old Delhi
text: During this holy month of Ramadan (or Ramzan, as it is called in India), when the sun sets, Old Delhi awakens to a slew of delectable aromas and crowded markets as excited Muslim families break their fast with a feast known as iftar. A majority of the families prepare traditional delicacies in their homes and head out to the Jama Masjid, the principal mosque of the area, to eat in its gigantic courtyard. Many others throng the narrow lanes to feast after their fast.

headline: Blockbusters Yield to Magic
text: WHEN “Jaws” landed in June 1975, it thrilled so many moviegoers week after hot sticky week that within months it had made box office history. As the critic Tom Shone put it in his book “Blockbuster,” “That’s what America did in the summer of 1975: It watched ‘Jaws.’ ” These days, though, Americans are rarely unified by one must-see movie for long, even when school’s out. When “Marvel’s The Avengers” opened in May, it topped the box office for three weeks until it was toppled by “Men in Black 3,” which held the top spot for two, until it was bested by “Snow White and the Huntsman,” which held on for one. And so it goes as each studio behemoth is bumped by the next in what has become a faster cycle of planned obsolescence.

headline: Was It Hard, Our Year in the Woods? Yes and No.
text: When our nearest neighbors in Maine (two miles away) saw us for the first time after the winter, they said, “Oh, you’re still here.” I wasn’t sure if it was a statement or a question, but I was sure that many doubted our ability to cope with the shift from a suburban New Jersey life to an off-the-grid cabin in the woods of Maine for a year.

headline: British Central Bank Cuts Growth Forecast
text: LONDON — The Bank of England lowered its growth forecast on Wednesday, predicting an even slower exit from recession than foreseen just three months earlier, but its governor, Mervyn A. King, ruled out an imminent cut in interest rates or other quick moves to stimulate the economy.

headline: Don’t Shun a Gift Horse, Even if It’s Singing
text: LONDON

headline: Taliban Gun Locker: The Frankengun of Wardak Province
text: Almost no matter the place or the year, whenever analysts and arms researchers scrutinize infantry weapons circulating through a conflict, they encounter predictable finds. Time and again, the same items turn up: AK assault rifles, PK machine guns, RPG-7 shoulder-fired anti-armor weapons, and, depending on the region, a smattering of M-16 variants, Fabrique Nationale and Heckler & Koch weapons, and bolt-action or lever-action rifles from yesteryear. There are oddities, including homemade jobs. Often there are also stray vestigial arms from previous wars in the same region or from particular arms transfers to a government on the same soil. But most of these are outliers. Usually a researcher can write up a list of likely candidates, then check them off while working the beat.

headline: Carlyle Swings to a Loss in 2nd Quarter
text: The Carlyle Group swung to a loss in its second quarter, the firm said on Wednesday, as it struggled to show growth in its core private equity investments.

headline: China Draws In an A-List Hollywood Director
text: BEIJING — James Cameron, director of the global hit films “Titanic” and “Avatar,” said Wednesday he was setting up shop in the Chinese city of Tianjin to bring his cutting-edge 3-D technologies and production services to a high-technology industrial park aimed at aiding China’s booming moviemaking industry.

headline: What Syria Looks Like From Tehran

headline: After Baby, a Gold?
text: Qualifying for the women’s Olympic high jump final begins on Thursday morning. In this year’s competition, at least three of the medal contenders have given birth in the last year or two, including the gold medal favorite, Anna Chicherova of Russia, and the American Olympic trials champion Chaunté Lowe. And that does not include the defending Olympic champion, Tia Hellebaut of Belgium, who is in the midst of a second comeback to the sport after having had two children since she won the gold medal four years ago.

headline: London Live: Follow Wednesday’s Action at the Olympics

She led at the end of the turn and held off a challenge from Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce of Jamaica, the 100-meter champion. Carmelita Jeter of the United States finished third.

If you want to keep icons out of sight but still open them quickly, you can create your own keyboard shortcuts to open specific programs on the PC.

headline: On Our Radar: N.R.C. Puts Off Licensing Decisions
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission suspends final decisions on licenses for power plants pending a court-ordered reassessment of the issue of storing spent nuclear fuel. headline: That Newark Airport Greeter Sure Can Project
text: If the woman answering international travelers’ questions as they arrive at Newark Liberty International Airport’s Terminal B seems a little repetitive, she should be forgiven. She is an airport virtual assistant, otherwise known as AVA, a hologram-like display that was installed there late last month as part of a six-month trial run. La Guardia and Kennedy Airports were scheduled to get trial avatars of their own last week.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Obama on the News Media, and Madonna Speaks Out in Russia
text: Barack Obama has more than a spectator’s interest in how the news media does its job, Amy Chozick notes as she describes the president’s typical news diet. Press coverage helped propel him to the national stage when he was a state legislator, and three and a half years into his presidential term he sees news coverage as frustrating his ambitions to change the tone of political debate. His most persistent complaint is what he calls the news media’s belief in a “false balance,” in which two opposing sides are given equal weight regardless of the facts. (A note of caution from Tom Rosenstiel, director of the Project for Excellence in Journalism: “I think we’ve learned through history to beware of presidents playing press critic. They’re not press critics — they’re people trying to advance a political agenda.”)

headline: India’s Boxing Hero Mary Kom Settles for Bronze
text: Mary Kom’s gold medal quest ended on Wednesday when she lost in the semifinals of the Olympic women’s flyweight boxing competition to Britain’s Nicola Adams, the second-ranked fighter in the world.

headline: TimesTalks: Women of the Summer Games
text: For the first time, the United States has sent more women than men to compete on its Olympic teams in London, reflecting the evolution of women’s participation in the modern Games. The TimesTalks series hosted a panel discussion on Wednesday with Olympic athletes past and present about participating in the Games, how they have prepared and what they have discovered.

headline: U.S. Decathlon Favorite Wastes No Time in Taking the Lead
text: LONDON — At times, the decathlon is best described as the world championship of standing around. Run the 100 meters, then wait through three other heats. Move to the long jump, then wait for your three attempts. On to the shot-put. More waiting. Then an afternoon break, two more events at night, and then do it all again in five new events tomorrow.

headline: Ancient Energy Boost, Brewed From Toasted Leaves and Bark
text: Long ago, at a pre-Columbian ritual center across the Mississippi River from present-day St. Louis, the home of Budweiser, people were heartily imbibing a caffeinated tealike beverage commonly known as “black drink.” The chemical residues found in their porous, unglazed ceramic mugs tell the tale.

headline: The Best Time to Buy and Sell College Textbooks
text: It’s that time of year again, when students across the country get ready to spend serious money on college textbooks. But to get the best deals — on both buying books for the upcoming semester and selling your old texts — it may be worth paying closer attention to when you shop and sell.

text: Apple on Wednesday said that it had temporarily disabled the ability for customers to reset their AppleID passwords by contacting customer service over the phone, after a hacker used this technique to break in to a technology journalist’s account over the weekend.

headline: Visa and MasterCard Settle Lawsuit, but Merchants Aren’t Celebrating
text: It has been called the largest private antitrust settlement in history, but the tentative $7.3 billion deal made last month between credit card companies and merchants may do little for Andy Charles, the owner of Haven’s Candies, which accepts credit cards at its three stores in the Portland, Me., area.

headline: FAQ: Frequent Airline Questions
text: THERE are some things one invariably wonders when waiting for a plane to take off. Is the air vent above my head blowing someone’s flu into my face? If I neglect to turn off my cellphone, will I really endanger the plane? If I knock back a cocktail at 30,000 feet, will it knock me out? Plagued by these and other aviation questions at the height of the summer vacation season, I called government officials and medical doctors for answers. Here’s what the experts had to say about five common travel bugaboos.

headline: Breaking It Down: A Soccer Match for the Ages
text: Ali Krieger is a defender for the United States women’s national soccer team and plays for FFC Frankfurt. Because of an injury, she is not playing for the team in the 2012 Games. She was an alternate on the 2008 United States Olympic team and started for the Americans in last summer’s World Cup. She has been writing for the 2012 London Olympics blog, and this is her third post.

headline: Will the Credit Card Settlement Help Merchants?
text: The Times has published an article exploring the dissatisfaction brewing among some retailer advocates with a recently proposed settlement to a lawsuit that pitted merchants against Visa, MasterCard and the leading banks. Among the grievances: for the first time, merchants would gain the right to charge customers more for paying with a credit card — unless they accept American Express cards. As the article explains, American Express, which is not party to the settlement, has rules that can make it difficult or impossible for merchants to institute surcharges.

headline: For the Very Old, a Surprise in Blood Pressure Readings
text: It’s such a routine thing: A nurse wraps the cuff around your elderly relative’s arm, squeezes the bulb, listens with a stethoscope and says: “120 over 60. Very good.” Smiles all around (this was my 89-year-old father’s latest reading), because everyone knows that high blood pressure is a risky proposition.

headline: Investigators Seek Clues in Gunman’s Last Weeks Before Temple Murders
text: MILWAUKEE — Around the middle of June, Wade M. Page split with his girlfriend, moving out of the home they shared in South Milwaukee. In mid-July, he suddenly stopped showing up to his job as a machine operator. About two weeks later, he bought a 9-millimeter handgun, testing it by firing 50 rounds at a target in the gun shop’s basement.

headline: Liberty’s Spinoff of Starz Was Firmly Denied Only a Month Ago

headline: Twin Reports Stoke Cautious Optimism for Rebound in the Housing Market
text: WASHINGTON — In the latest sign that the worst might be over for the battered American housing market, the two government-controlled mortgage finance giants, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, this week reported some of their best quarterly results since the real estate collapse.

headline: Too Conservative, or Just Extremely Conservative?
text: Ahead of Tuesday’s G.O.P. primary in Missouri, Senator Claire McCaskill and her Democratic supporters spent around $2 million on ads describing one candidate, Representative Todd Akin, as too conservative for the state. Ms. McCaskill’s hope was that Missouri Republicans would think “too conservative, sounds good!” and support Mr. Akin—in her estimation a relatively weak challenger. That strategy seems to have worked: Mr. Akin won last night’s race with 36 percent of the vote.

headline: New York Kids’ Stories
text: At a moment when crowded public schools, escalating rents, competitive hyperparenting and a flagging economy may drive wavering New York parents out to the suburbs, three newly published and gloriously illustrated books for city offspring could persuade them to stay put.

headline: Natural Selection’s Evolution: Rebecca Stott Talks About ‘Darwin’s Ghosts’
text: Soon after he published “On the Origin of Species,” Charles Darwin was accused of neglecting to mention the thinkers who had helped to shape evolutionary theory before him. He scrambled to put together a list of predecessors that would be added to future editions of his book. In “Darwin’s Ghosts,” Rebecca Stott tells the story of those predecessors’ work, from the empirical research of Aristotle to the studies of Alfred Russel Wallace, who was piecing together the science around the same time as Darwin. In The New York Times Book Review, Hugh Raffles called the book an “absorbing account” with a narrative that “flows easily across continents and centuries.” In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Stott discussed the roots of her interest in Darwin, the reasons Wallace played second fiddle without complaint and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: New Fossils Indicate Early Branching of Human Family Tree
text: Fossil by fossil, scientists over the last 40 years have suspected that their models for the more immediate human family tree — the single trunk, straight as a Ponderosa pine, up from Homo habilis to Homo erectus to Homo sapiens — were oversimplified. The day for that serious revision may be at hand.

headline: Reader Photos: America’s Record Drought

headline: Diabetes and the Obesity Paradox
text: Type 2 diabetes, a condition widely thought of as a disease of the overweight and sedentary, also develops in people who aren’t overweight. And it may be deadlier in these normal-weight people, a new study shows.

headline: Reversing Course,  Los Angeles Art Museum Will Look for Chief Curator
text: The Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, stung by criticism of its leadership, has reversed course and decided to conduct a search for a chief curator, after initially saying that it would leave the position unfilled.

headline: In a Starving Nation, Luxury for a Few
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean news media, which scrutinizes every photo of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, zeroed in this week on one particular photo released by the North’s state-run news agency on Tuesday. It shows Mr. Kim watching an art performance by soldiers during a military visit, the first reported in the North Korean media since he fired the top army leader, Vice Marshal Ri Yong-ho, on July 15.

headline: ‘Golden Boy’ Cast Features Tony Shalhoub, Yvonne Strahovski and Danny Burstein
text: Seth Numrich will play the lead character in Bartlett Sher’s coming production of Clifford Odets’s “Golden Boy” for Lincoln Center Theater, alongside an ensemble cast including Yvonne Strahovski, Tony Shalhoub, Danny Burstein and Dagmara Dominczyk among several others, press representatives for the theater company said on Wednesday.

headline: The Sound of Hate
text: THE shooting rampage on Sunday that killed six people and wounded three others at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin exposed the continued dangers of white power extremism in our midst. The shooter, Wade M. Page, was affiliated with a range of neo-Nazi skinhead groups, and during the last decade, he played in several prominent bands in the white power music scene.

headline: Giants’ Thomas Says A.C.L. Is Not Torn
text: ALBANY — Giants cornerback Terrell Thomas said Wednesday that despite an injury scare last Sunday, there was no tear in his right anterior cruciate ligament and he could possibly return to the practice field by as early as the opening week of the season.

headline: U.S.-Mexico Preview, Part 2: The North American Solution
text: The first of three articles explored what Jurgen’s Klinsmann’s A team might look like for the Aug. 15 friendly between the United States and Mexico. For this piece we will speculate on who would receive consideration if Klinsmann opted to choose a B team of North America-based players.

headline: Poll Finds Tight Senate Races in Virginia and Wisconsin
text: A new poll finds tight races for Senate seats in the presidential swing states of Virginia and Wisconsin.

headline: Taxing Olympic Medalists
text: If I get a bonus for good performance, it’s taxed. If you get a bonus for good performance, it’s taxed. Heck, when Lloyd Blankfein gets a bonus for good performance (or bad performance!), even he pays taxes on it.

headline: Coaching the Kayakers on 2 Wheels
text: WINDSOR, England — As she prepared for a race Wednesday, Krisztina Fazekas of Hungary got into her kayak with her three teammates. Her husband and coach, Rami Zur, hopped onto a bicycle a few feet away. Then the couple embarked on a classic Olympic canoe-kayak tradition.

headline: In Iowa, Romney Leaves a Stance on Wind Power Unsaid
text: DES MOINES — Seeking support in the swing state of Iowa, Mitt Romney on Wednesday called for developing a laundry list of energy resources that included wind power, but he pointedly did not mention that he opposes a tax credit for the wind industry that the state’s Republican leadership strongly favors.

headline: Rick Ross Scores a Fourth No. 1 Album
text: This week on the pop charts the Miami rapper Rick Ross scored his fourth No. 1 album with “God Forgives, I Don’t” (Maybach/Def Jam), and Phillip Phillips, this year’s “American Idol” winner, topped the digital songs chart with his single “Home,” thanks to its being used by NBC as a theme song for the women’s gymnastics competition at the Olympics.

headline: Adelson Libel Lawsuit Seeks $60 Million
text: Sheldon G. Adelson, the billionaire casino owner who has emerged as one of the country’s biggest Republican donors, filed a $60 million libel lawsuit in federal court on Wednesday against a Democratic group that Mr. Adelson said had falsely accused him of condoning prostitution in his Macau casino properties.
