headline: A Guy’s Perfect Closet, Only Bigger
text: OH, the dreaded middle ground. That space between casual and tailored is the worst, really. It leaves men floundering. Not the ones who care about notched lapels or three-button jackets that roll to two and who follow Tumblrs about men who don’t ever wear socks. They’re fine, if irritating. But for men aiming for the respectable mean, the ones who understand that theoretically they can do better but have no idea how, looking crisp is a perpetual struggle.

headline: A Store With Shelves Full of Crime Faces Its Demise
text: “Endings, man, they weren’t as easy as they looked.”

headline: Debate in Germany Over ‘Dangerous Jihadist’
text: BERLIN — Revelations that a Tunisian man who is considered a “dangerous jihadist” and may have served as a bodyguard to Osama bin Laden in 2000 has been living for years in a western German city have ignited a debate over the difficulties faced by the German authorities in trying to curtail the activities of potential Islamic extremists.

headline: A Rebel’s Cause: Fortifying the Fashion Flock
text: HE was at the Frieze Art Fair in New York, bear-hugging Johan Lindeberg, yakking with a chef from Fat Radish and exchanging grins with gallerists.

headline: In London, Censure of an Elite Bank Draws Harrumphs
text: LONDON — In this summer of revelations about bad behavior by British financial institutions, bashing the banks has been London’s other Olympic sport.

headline: Respectful of History, U.S. Boxer Has a Shot to Make Some
text: LONDON — Her rope-a-dope tactics and enthusiastic embrace of her talents call to mind Muhammad Ali, who as Cassius Clay was a 1960 Olympic gold medalist. But Claressa Shields, the teenager left to shoulder the gold medal expectations of the United States in a sport it once ruled with iron fists, exhibited an even longer reach into history, describing Sugar Ray Robinson as her inspiration.

headline: If Rematch Means Shootout, U.S. Is Ready
text: LONDON — One year after the Women’s World Cup final, so much is the same for Japan and the United States. They have the same stars. They have the same expectations. They are the two best teams, despite what the FIFA rankings say.

headline: A Critical Design Change for a Bag to Carry Your Tech Stuff
text: A few months back, I wrote about what tech stuff I own — and what I carry it in. I noted that I had a Timbuk2 messenger bag. It’s a Transportation Security Administration-approved model that unzips to open like a butterfly’s wings, so that the laptop compartment can lie flat for airport scanning.

headline: Marketing Time in a Bottle Pays Off
text: THE beauty industry, long promising to stop or at least stave off time, is finding a way to market it. Over the last year or so, store shelves have become packed with so-called time-release products, which promise staggered benefits the longer they sink in.

headline: The Breadbasket of the Union
text: The summer of 1862 saw the Civil War’s two fronts as a mirror image. In the West, Federal troops had harnessed long stretches of the Cumberland, Tennessee and Mississippi Rivers to drive deep into the Confederacy. Fort Henry, Fort Donelson, Nashville and Memphis had all fallen, leaving Union forces largely in control of Kentucky, middle and western Tennessee, northern Mississippi and northern Alabama.

headline: Near Miss for Kibbutz in Path of Sinai Incursion
text: KEREM SHALOM, Israel — The members of the tiny kibbutz here on Israel’s troubled border with Egypt and the Gaza Strip were just finishing a light supper in their dining hall on Sunday evening when text messages warned them to take cover.

headline: Mourinho Has Eyes on U.S.

headline: Chamberlain Works to Be Displayed at Plaza of Seagram Building
text: The plaza of the Seagram Building, which has been the stage for a procession of supersized contemporary art installations over the last few years, is about to sprout a forest of tinfoil tentacles. Or at least a bunch of towering, sinuous things that appear to be made of foil, created by the sculptor John Chamberlain, who died in 2011.

headline: Us Weekly, for a Lot Fewer of Us
text: AS the textbook-thick September issues of fashion magazines begin clogging mailboxes and newsstands this week, there will be some new faces competing for your attention, especially if you are part of that vastly underserved population known as rich people.

headline: What Cornfields Show, Data Now Confirm: July Set Mark as U.S.’s Hottest Month
text: It may come as little surprise to the nation’s corn farmers or resort operators, but the official statistics are in: July was the hottest month in the lower 48 states since the government began keeping temperature records in 1895.

headline: Asked & Answered | Susie Breuer
text: “I love being behind the scenes,” Susie Breuer insists. “The spotlight isn’t a comfortable place for me.” But after 20 years of quietly working in fashion production for industry magnates like Tommy Hilfiger, Karl Lagerfeld and, currently, Calvin Klein, Breuer is finally getting a center-stage moment with the recent release of her first book, “Blue Is the New Black: the 10 Step Guide to Developing and Producing a Fashion Collection” (BIS Publishers, $45). Dispensing insider tips and personal anecdotes from years in the business, Breuer offers a thorough look at the somewhat arcane journey to building a collection, from conception to high street or catwalk, and the interplay among the many individuals who contribute along the way.

headline: Kindler, Former Pfizer Chief, Joins Lux Capital
text: Jeffrey B. Kindler, who retired as Pfizer‘s chairman and chief executive at the end of 2011, has joined Lux Capital as a venture partner, the firm announced on Wednesday.

headline: Yankees Slide, but Are They in Danger?
text: We interrupt the Olympics to present a possible news alert. The Yankees, losers of 12 of their last 18 games, might, sort of, be in a little bit of trouble. But probably not.

headline: Subsidies for a Global Warming Gas
text: More than 40 percent all carbon credits issued by the United Nations have been awarded to 19 plants for destroying HFC-23, a global warming gas.

headline: McIlroy Gives Himself a Passing Grade, But Wants to Improve It

There’s little doubt that hoisting the Wanamaker Trophy on Sunday at the season’s final major would lift his grade near the top of the class.

headline: Long-Lost Le Mans Corvette, Found at Last?
text: Chip Miller, a noted collector of Chevrolet Corvettes who died in 2004 at age 61, spent much of his later life searching for a Corvette fielded by Briggs Cunningham — the driver, automotive manufacturer, yachtsman and race-team privateer — at Le Mans in 1960. Though he was unsuccessful in his search, before his death Miller passed along a valuable clue he had kept closely guarded.

headline: Pole-Vaulter Bends but Doesn’t Break
text: LONDON — Steve Hooker of Australia is the defending Olympic pole vault champion, but he has had a problem with the yips that would bring sympathy from any golfer.

headline: Scene City: Liza Minnelli and Alan Cumming Bring Cabaret to Fire Island
text: A night of cabaret in Cherry Grove with the one and only.

headline: Fire Island’s Got Talent
text: THE Ice Palace nightclub in Cherry Grove on Fire Island is not a place ordinarily associated with great theater. On Friday night, Alan Cumming was there at an underwear party, dancing around in a jock strap and doing something with a gummy bear that cannot be described in this newspaper.

headline: Stone Links: The Drone Wars
text: A new chapter in the ongoing debate about the morality of drones opened last week, with a profile in The Guardian of the philosopher Bradley Strawser. Strawser’s perspective on just war theory and the ethics of drones, which was also featured in a recent news analysis in the Sunday Review, is all the more interesting because, as a professor at the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School, he is employed by an institution which is uniquely positioned to act on his views.

headline: U.F.O. Home
text: Roberto Sanchez Rivera built his home in Puerto Rico to look like a spaceship, with lights and audio effects.

headline: The Flat
text: AROUND midnight on a sweltering Friday, the Flat was no place to cool off. In the swarmed bar, young women danced with condensation-slick bottles of Dos Equis held aloft. Heems, a rapper from the group Das Racist, slouched on a zebra-print bench under a portrait of an old woman.

headline: Norbert Leo Butz Will Join Katie Holmes in ‘Dead Accounts’
text: This fall on Broadway, Norbert Leo Butz will play the ne’er-do-well brother of Katie Holmes’s character, whose return to their childhood Ohio home sets off the action in Theresa Rebeck’s “Dead Accounts,” representatives for the play announced on Wednesday. “Dead Accounts” will begin previews at the Music Box Theater on Nov. 3, with a scheduled opening on Nov. 28.

headline: Teenagers’ Petition on Female Moderators Draws Support
text: Quick, name the last woman who moderated a presidential debate. If you are having trouble, there is a reason: No woman has done the job in 20 years, since Carole Simpson in 1992.

headline: The U.S. Bounces Back, and Over
text: LONDON — The three Americans who won gold medals in Olympic Stadium on Wednesday were competing in different ways. Aries Merritt had to clear 10 hurdles. Brittney Reese had to leave the takeoff board at full speed before treading on the Plasticine strip that marks a foul. Allyson Felix had to sprint the curve and find something new within herself and her famously smooth stride.

headline: New Google Tools to Make the Search Engine More All-Knowing
text: When Google imagines the future of Web search, it sees a search engine that understands human meaning and not just words, that can have a spoken conversation with computer users and that gives users results not just from the Web but also from their personal lives.

headline: A Grounded Flying Saucer in Puerto Rico
text: On a hill overlooking a highway, the colored lights of what appears to be a flying saucer are visible. A closer examination reveals a spaceship-inspired house.

headline: Money, Mentoring and a Claim on the Payoff
text: If you believe someone has a great future as an entrepreneur, maybe you should own a piece of it.

headline: Destination | Makepeace Island
text: Makepeace Island, Richard Branson’s island in Australia, is a 10-minute ride on a private launch from Noosa, on Queensland’s Sunshine Coast. The name is reason enough for any couple (quibbling or not, let’s make peace!) to visit, plus the island is heart shaped — though not quite as much as it appears to be on its namesake Web site — a forgivably cheeky exaggeration.

headline: Close Encounters of the Romantic Kind
text: JUANA DIAZ, P.R.

headline: Police Return to Cellar Tied to Patz Suspect
text: A police evidence unit brought out several large paper bags on Wednesday from the basement in SoHo where the man charged in the Etan Patz case says he killed the boy who disappeared in 1979.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Democratic Republic of Congo and Manila.

headline: What’s Next in the Standard Chartered Case
text: The  order issued to Standard Chartered by Benjamin M. Lawsky, the superintendent of the New York State Department of Financial Services, creates a problem for the federal government in its own investigations of the bank. Mr. Lawsky accused the bank of operating “as a rogue institution” in its dealings with Iranian customers in violation of federal law, and seeks to revoke its license to do business in New York.

headline: The Starbucks-Square Deal: Visionary or Risky?
text: The mobile wallet just became more hip with the news that Starbucks has teamed up with Square, the mobile payment start-up. Beginning this fall, you’ll be able to pay for a cup of joe at Starbucks by showing a Square barcode on your smartphone to a cashier.

headline: A Sneakers-Only Runway
text: WANT to rub shoulders with a high-powered fashion editor? How about a designer? Arguably the best place these days isn’t the Top of the Standard hotel or even Amy Sacco’s new boîte, No. 8, but a nondescript slab of a building at 27th Street and Eighth Avenue, a neighbor to Chelsea housing projects and a Gristede’s grocery store, and the home of the misleadingly titled Midtown Tennis Club. (It’s not in Midtown, and membership isn’t required to play there.)

headline: Felix Wins Gold
text: Allyson Felix of the United States won the women’s 200 meters at the London Games in 21.88 seconds on Wednesday, upgrading her previous two Olympic silver medals to gold.

headline: A Flock of Keyboards, Gathered in the Round
text: When people refer to piano quartets or piano trios, they generally mean a piano and some other stuff — a violin and a cello, say. But the new ensemble Grand Band is a piano sextet in the purest sense: six pianos, and only six pianos.

headline: Weymouth Journal: Beer in Sausage, Rather Than Beer and Sausage
text: Periodically throughout the Olympics we will check in with Dennis Spurr, owner of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, a pretty town on the English coast where the sailing events are taking place. Mr. Spurr’s sausage business was a target of the Olympic branding authorities in 2007 after he put up a sign featuring the Olympic five-ring logo fashioned out of sausage links. He took it down on their demands, but replaced it with a sign featuring five squares made out of sausage links.

headline: All the Trimmings Are the Main Course
text: A YEAR before Paula Cheng graduated from Parsons the New School for Design with an M.F.A. in fashion design in May, she won a contest organized by the Metropolitan Museum of Art to create designs inspired by the Alexander McQueen exhibition at the museum. Ms. Cheng focused not on bumster pants nor showstopper gowns, but on black platform-heeled shoes and sandals with winged tiers of fur that have already been pictured on Italian Vogue’s Web site.

headline: And the Olympic Gold for Whining Goes to ...
text: LONDON — For the handful of countries sitting at the top of the medal count, the Olympics have been a source of joy and a cause for celebration.

headline: R. Peter Straus, Radio Pioneer, Dies at 89
text: R. Peter Straus, who took over WMCA in New York in the late 1950s and turned it into one of the nation’s most innovative radio stations, broadcasting what are regarded as the first radio editorials and political endorsements and helping to popularize rock ’n’ roll, died on Monday at his home in Midtown Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: An E-Mail Service With Lots of Smarts
text: “Coming soon, from the creator of the Macarena!”... “New, from the founders of Myspace!”... “He has the same agent as Steven Seagal!”

headline: On Fridays, Partying Starts Early
text: NICOLE WASILEWICZ, 27, stood poolside at the Thompson LES hotel, toenails Day-Glo orange, bikini peeping out from beneath a tank top, clutching a frozen cocktail that she probably could not afford.

headline: Grounded? Thank Mom and Dad
text: Why didn’t anyone tell me that grounding my child would be this hard?

headline: Making Facebook Less Infantile
text: BRANDY CASWELL, 28, turns to Facebook to keep up with her friends. But in the last year or so, she found that her newsfeed was being overrun with baby photos, documenting everything from nap times to diaper changes.

headline: Brown Questions Role of Warren’s Daughter in Voter Registration Effort
text: BOSTON – Senator Scott P. Brown on Wednesday accused Elizabeth Warren’s daughter of using her position on the board of a nonpartisan organization in service of her mother’s Senate campaign.

headline: Clinical Trial Is Favorable for a Prenatal Gene Test
text: A new method of prenatal testing that can detect more genetic problems in a fetus than ever before could be headed toward wider use after encouraging results from a clinical trial, researchers said.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: The Riot Girls’ Style
text: It has been a shock to see the bravely smiling faces of three girls from the Russian punk collective Pussy Riot locked in a glass cage in a Moscow courtroom these past two weeks. Ordinarily they are dressed in shots of clashing colors, their faces hidden behind bright balaclavas. Stripped of their costumes and dressed in plain clothes (graphic tee, button-down shirt, day dress), they are unrecognizable. Hearing their names and seeing Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, 22, Maria Alyokhina, 24, and Yekaterina Samutsevich, 29, exposed and vulnerable on national television seems only to emphasize the band’s slogan: “We Are All Pussy Riot.” After all, if women who look like Tolokonnikova, Alyokhina and Samutsevich are Pussy Riot, why can’t I be, too?

headline: In a Factory’s Shadow, Fears About Health
text: NATHKUVA, India — By issuing carbon credits to companies for reducing emissions in the developing world, the United Nations aimed to inject cash into poor communities supporting the growth of sustainable industry. But in this remote village adjacent to Gujarat Fluorochemicals Limited’s coolant gas plant, environmental groups and residents have been at loggerheads with the company over pollution since it opened in 1989.

headline: The Agents Who Fooled the Nazis About D-Day
text: Ben Macintyre is the reigning champ when it comes to attention-grabbing World War II spy stories that are stranger than fiction. Each of his two most recent books, “Agent Zigzag” and “Operation Mincemeat,” has been suspensefully written and studded with exotic details. And each has been narrowly particular. “Agent Zigzag” focused on Eddie Chapman, the onetime thief who turned his duplicity toward deceiving Germany on behalf of the Allied war effort. The more amazing “Operation Mincemeat” outlined the elaborate use of a floating corpse to spread disinformation.

headline: Kitty Cam Shows Not All Cats Are Killers
text: No owner would likely deny that cats are creatures with personality. Some spend all day stalking squirrels, some spend all day snoozing in the sun. Some like to cuddle, and some are loners.

headline: Homes for $400,000
text: Properties in Virginia, Oregon and Nebraska.

headline: What You Get for ... $400,000
text: RICHMOND, VA.

headline: Scott Recalls Els’s Show of Support at British Open
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — Ernie Els, who won last month’s British Open when Adam Scott bogeyed the final four holes, played nine practice holes with Scott on Wednesday at the Ocean Course.

headline: Hewlett-Packard’s Deal-Making Missteps
text: Hewlett-Packard has no problem spending money on deals.

headline: House Hunting in ... Germany
text: CONTEMPORARY FOUR-BEDROOM HOUSE IN BAD TÖLZ, BAVARIA

headline: In Germany, a Modern Bavarian House in the Foothills of the Alps
text: This four-bedroom home is outside the spa town of Bad Tölz in Bavaria. It’s on the market for $2.42 million (1.980 million euros.)

headline: Romney Aide Touts Health Care Overhaul
text: A principal message-maker of the Romney campaign drew criticism from conservative circles on Wednesday by suggesting that if a laid-off steel worker in an anti-Romney ad had lived in Massachusetts, he would have had health insurance and his wife might still be alive.

headline: Angry Romans Occupy Ludlow Street
text: The new production of “Coriolanus,” Shakespeare’s drama about an election that pits disdainful elites against the 99 percent, would seem to be a perfect fit for both our time and the inherently populist theater series to which it belongs, Shakespeare in the Park(ing) Lot. (Yes, this Elizabethan tragedy is performed gratis on the pavement of a functioning municipal parking lot, amid cars, trucks and pedestrians ferrying home Chinese takeout.)

headline: Johnny’s First Phone: A Guide for Parents
text: Wendy Sue Swanson, a pediatrician in Seattle, knows that a 9-month-old baby can perform some basic acts of imitation. You might expect smiling, blinking and some other facial expressions and gestures. But you know what she’s seeing a lot of?

headline: Uncertainty of Operatic Proportions
text: “The new normal?” Speight Jenkins, the general director of the Seattle Opera, repeated the question I had just asked him over the telephone. He paused for a moment.

headline: Suburban Taxpayers Vote to Support Detroit Museum
text: The Detroit Institute of Arts was saved from devastating budget cuts Tuesday night after voters in three Michigan counties agreed to institute a property tax increase earmarked specifically for the museum.

headline: Editor Fired Following Harassment Accusation
text: CONWAY, Ark. — The gathering, Marc Smirnoff said, was intended as a morale-boosting retreat for his staff at The Oxford American magazine, a July 4 overnight party at a mountain cabin that would fuel the creative intellect.

headline: They ‘Tessellate,’ and Dabble in Both the Sinister and the Naughty
text: At the stroke of midnight on Tuesday night Alt-J was at Glasslands Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, playing “Handmade,” the secret track from “An Awesome Wave,” its new full-length debut. A simmering hymn of one-way infatuation, it boiled down to a duologue between Joe Newman, the band’s frontman, and Gus Unger-Hamilton, its keyboardist. “Legions upon legions of craftsmen handmade my feelings,” they harmonized with studied imprecision, before reaching a moony refrain: “For yoooouuu.”

headline: With School Gym as Olympic Stadium, Autistic Students Chase Goals
text: In London, thousands gathered on Wednesday to watch as two Jamaican track stars, Usain Bolt and Johan Blake, limbered up for the 200-meter sprint. At the Rebecca School for developmentally disabled children in Manhattan, however, Sam Wilkinson had eyes for only one race: the one between his team, East Side Story, and its rival, the Subway Stars.

headline: A Puzzle of a Carpet to Add or Subtract
text: For home dwellers who stress over finding the perfect size and shape for an area rug, the Dutch design company Droog has an answer: All in One, a reconfigurable wool carpet made from 14 different pieces covering about 388 square feet. “If you have a big room, you can use them all together as one piece,” said Renny Ramakers, director of Droog. Or you can split them up for different rooms.

headline: Cool Pieces for Hot August Dinners
text: Dinosaur Designs may not have anticipated a blistering hot summer, but it had the wisdom to introduce a collection called Sorbet that coincides with it. The handmade resin pieces include soy sauce dishes, gelato spoons (right), vases and salad servers, in refreshing hues that are layered to look sculptural.

headline: Romney Makes a Surprise Stop at a New Jersey Wedding
text: Mitt Romney’s arrival at a New Jersey fund-raiser on Wednesday capped a breakneck drive along New Jersey’s highways followed by a surreal pursuit by an Orthodox Jewish wedding party, according to a reporter on the trip.

headline: Classic Seating in a New Wardrobe
text: Midcentury furniture classics reimagined: that’s the angle behind the designer Madeline Weinrib’s treatment of a score of notable pieces, which she upholstered in her signature prints. Displayed from Saturday to Sept. 3 at Sebastian & Barquet’s Southampton gallery, the collection includes Vladimir Kagan’s Erica chaise in lavender jacquard ($18,500), Osvaldo Borsani’s P32 lounge chair in dove-gray striped ikat on the back and dove-gray ikat on the front ($7,000) and a three-seat sofa by Ico and Luisa Parisi in brown-striped ikat (above, $45,000). “I wanted to pay tribute to the original designs,” Ms. Weinrib said, “while simultaneously introducing them to the viewer in a way they’ve never experienced the pieces before.” The exhibition is open Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., 67 Jobs Lane, Southampton, N.Y.; information: (631) 283-0456 or sebastianbarquet.com.

headline: Like a Sprinter, Bursts of Power
text: A reporter sprinkled cocoa powder onto light gray carpet, then ground in cheese-flavored tortilla chips with her heel. She picked up the new Dyson DC44 Digital Slim cordless vacuum cleaner with its sapphire-blue good looks. Would it inhale the mess?

headline: Sales at Lekker Home, J. Pocker and Others
text: Lekker Home is taking 30 percent off some Ethnicraft furniture pieces, through Aug. 13 (a two-door Oak Stonecut TV cabinet, originally $2,800, is $1,960); (617) 542-6464, lekkerhome.com.

headline: How the French Get Connected
text: Unlike many in his profession, Mathieu Lehanneur, 38, is not driven by the desire to create the next great chair, but he would like to improve the world around him.

headline: Rembering Ballesteros, the Competitor Who Never Quit
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — As the lone returning competitor from the 1991 Ryder Cup match at Kiawah Island Resort’s Ocean Course to play here this week in the P.G.A. Championship, José María Olazábal couldn’t help but reminisce. Olazábal paired with Seve Ballesteros to form “the Spanish Armada,” one of the most formidable teams in Ryder Cup history. In 1991, they went 3-0-1 in their four matches together.

headline: Time Wasters, Pointless but Fun
text: Times have changed since the best way to pass an idle 10 minutes was Nokia’s famous Snake, or whatever flavor of game was built into your old, dumb cellphone. These basic games were simple entertainment and they were fun — to an extent. But with smartphones, we have thousands of app-enabled ways to pass the time waiting in line at the post office or even when struck with insomnia.

headline: Obama Says Romney Would Take Women Back to 1950s on Health Care
text: 1:02 a.m. | Updated  An updated version of this blog post appears here.

headline: Second World Mind Sports Games in France
text: LILLE, France — Play in the Second World Mind Sports Games will begin here Friday and end on Aug. 23. Five games are represented: bridge, checkers, chess, Chinese chess and go.

headline: Steinbeck Family Outraged That Texas Judge Cited ‘Of Mice and Men’ in Execution Ruling
text: Marvin Wilson, a mentally retarded man with an I.Q. of 61, was executed by the state of Texas on Tuesday night, after the Supreme Court refused to accept the argument that the killing violated the constitutional ban on “cruel and unusual punishments.”

headline: For Women at the Olympics, the Spotlight Can Be Harsh
text: The American sprinter Lolo Jones may have been speaking for a number of female Olympic athletes on the “Today” show Wednesday morning when she tearfully deplored criticism she had received in American media related to her physical appearance.

headline: Surviving the Heat
text: July was the hottest month on record in the United States. People around the country looked for creative ways to beat the heat.

headline: Ideas to Make You Shiver
text: A FEW weeks ago, I made the most embarrassing fashion faux pas of my life: I wore shorts to a wedding.

headline: 5 Things You Could Be Doing If You Were at the Essex County Fair Instead of Reading This Blog Post
text: In last Sunday’s magazine, we published Ben Stechschulte’s photographs of drivers in the Essex County Fair’s demolition derby competition in upstate New York.

headline: A Colorful Getaway
text: A founder of Fab.com decorates a house that embodies the spirit of the Web site.

headline: Bringing His Work Home
text: SPARROWBUSH, N.Y.

headline: Flower Riot
text: Summer’s bright dahlias on display.

headline: Yankees Tinker With Lineup, but It’s Not Panic
text: DETROIT — A day after Eric Chavez declared that there was a high level of concern among the Yankees over their poor play, Manager Joe Girardi changed his lineup.

headline: Dahlias Springing Up, Just Like Mom’s
text: BALTIMORE

headline: U.S., Too, Wants to Bolster Investment in a Continent’s Economic Promise
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton landed in South Africa this week, she brought along a hefty delegation of executives from some of America’s leading companies — Boeing, Walmart, FedEx, G.E. — and a message: America is ready to invest in Africa.

headline: Children’s Work Spaces
text: Campion Platt searches for a work space that allows a child to spread out.

headline: Work Spaces for Children
text: THIS time of year, children often begin to despair over the end of summer and the looming school year. For many parents, mid-August signals the start of school-supply shopping season and perhaps a time to rethink their child’s work space.

headline: Farewell to the Subway Olympics That Never Were
text: With the London Olympics approaching its end, City Room traveled this week to sites in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens that would have been utterly transformed had New York City won its bid for the 2012 Games. Neither idle nor abandoned, these waterfront areas today are home to new parks and recreational areas, light industry and heavy construction. But they are also raw-edged works in progress, where whole swathes of land stand behind chain-link fences topped in razor wire. They present a very different scene than those described by the captions in the slide show, which are quoted from the official 2004 Olympic bid package.

headline: Dissolving Scotland’s Old Firm
text: GLASGOW — Imagine if the Republican Party filed for bankruptcy only weeks before Election Day. Or if Apple went broke at Christmas. Or if the Letterman show was canceled ahead of sweeps week.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Our prewar apartment has the original plumbing fixtures and fittings in the bathroom. Do they add vintage appeal or should they be replaced?

headline: Aug. 8: Colorado and Virginia Flip Places in Forecast
text: Mitt Romney got one of his better polls in a long while on Wednesday. The poll, in Colorado, was one of three state surveys conducted by The New York Times in conjunction with Quinnipiac University and CBS News. It gave Mr. Romney a five-point lead there, with 50 percent of the vote, to President Obama’s 45 percent.

headline: Dabbing the Brow of Cowpoke or C.E.O.
text: YOU can’t help but wonder if the late Richard Carlson of San Francisco would have chosen “Don’t Sweat the Small Stuff” as the title of his motivational best seller if he had lived on the East Coast instead of the West. Surely the only self-help advice for this cruel summer in New York is “Oh, Just Go Ahead and Sweat Everything.”

headline: Powerful Indian Financial Exchange Trades Accusations With Economist
text: MUMBAI, India — It is the business version of “he said, she said.”

headline: Pros Line Up to Debate Use of Long Putters
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — There was grumbling about the legitimacy of the long putter when it first appeared on the professional tours decades ago. But as time passed, it remained mostly on the fringe in elite golf, with no player winning a major championship using one. Traditional shorter putters reigned, and that kept the grousing to a minimum.

headline: Editorial Page Promotion at The Times
text: Terry Tang, whose 15-year career at The New York Times has included stints on the metropolitan, business and editorial desks and also involved building its online presence, has been named deputy editorial page editor.

headline: Heightened Scrutiny for Horses at Travers Stakes
text: New York authorities have ordered that all horses racing in the Travers Stakes on Aug. 25 be placed under 24-hour surveillance, and their trainers will have to document each medical treatment a horse receives in the 72 hours before the race.

headline: Board Finds What Marred Test of a 787
text: The National Transportation Safety Board said on Wednesday that a fan shaft fractured inside a General Electric jet engine on a Boeing 787 Dreamliner during a test run late last month, causing it to eject hot shards of metal.

headline: Tough Choices Coming for Ryder Cup Captains
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — The European Ryder Cup captain José María Olazábal gathered his potential troops for dinner and said it would be the last chance for all of them to be under one roof before the team convened in September. The 39th edition of the biennial competition begins Sept. 28 at Medinah Country Club outside Chicago, and Olazábal expressed confidence that his team was rounding into shape.

headline: City Council Berates Elections Board and Voices Concern Over Future Voting
text: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, said that when she and her fiancée showed up to vote last fall, their ballots were disqualified because of a mistake by a poll worker.

headline: A Candidate Whose Ads Are Never Off the Air
text: HONOLULU — Channel 110 is a choice spot on Hawaii’s digital cable dial, coming right after Fox News and right before CNN Headline News. These days, it is the home of LL12, a station that will soon devote every minute of every day to one topic: Linda Lingle, a Republican running for the United States Senate.

headline: Send Bittman Packing
text: Mark Bittman is going somewhere to write about something food related. Help decide his destination.

headline: A Gold Medal Winner Returns to His Day Job
text: TORONTO — Andy Murray had all of one day in London to bask in the glory of his Olympic gold medal, which included a national stamp of approval released Monday by the British Royal Mail system. By Tuesday, Murray was being delivered first class across the Atlantic to North America, back on the trail of the Grand Slam title he still hasn’t won.

headline: Anti-D.W.I. Technology
text: To the Editor:

headline: Massachusetts Health Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: A New Life for a Piano
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Bicyclist Runs Into Ethics and the Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: Defining Happiness
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Mad Dash in the Subway
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Victim in Sikh Temple Shooting, a Life of Separation
text: NEW DELHI — When his chance came to go to America, Ranjit Singh promised his wife and three young children they would not be separated for too long. He was taking a position at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin and hoped his family might join him there. Until they did, he would send back money. He would call.

headline: Congressman’s Report of Trip Is at Issue
text: When Representative Michael G. Grimm, a first-term Staten Island Republican, went on a fact-finding trip abroad last year, he widely publicized his first stop, Israel, sending off a stream of messages about his activities there via Twitter. But he was largely silent about his second stop, Cyprus.

headline: Nuns, at Juncture, Meet to Weigh Their Reply to the Vatican
text: ST. LOUIS — With their leaders saying that they stand at a historic crossroads, more than 900 Roman Catholic nuns have gathered here for a four-day meeting to decide how to respond to a biting Vatican assessment that cast them as disobedient dissenters and ordered three American bishops to overhaul the nuns’ organization, the Leadership Conference of Women Religious.

headline: A Print Focus Returns in Lane Bryant Campaign
text: LANE BRYANT, the women’s plus-size fashion retailer, is introducing a $10 million advertising and marketing campaign to make its clothing and lingerie more relevant to current and prospective customers.

headline: Google Goes Back to the Drawing Board for Nexus Q
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In June, Google engineers took to the stage in front of thousands of cheering software developers to introduce the Nexus Q, a black ball meant to stream video and music. It was Google’s first try at building its own hardware — in the United States, no less — and Google called it “a third wave of consumer electronics.”

headline: U.S. and Gulf Allies Pursue a Missile Shield Against Iranian Attack
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and its Arab allies are knitting together a regional missile defense system across the Persian Gulf to protect cities, oil refineries, pipelines and military bases from an Iranian attack, according to government officials and public documents.

headline: The Court at the Olympics
text: Many people are celebrating the achievements of American women at the London Olympics, where women exceed men in the number of athletes on the United States team and have walked away with an impressive number of gold medals. And many have noted the connection between the women’s historic success and the 40th anniversary of Title IX, which President Richard M. Nixon signed into law on June 23, 1972.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 25
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: At La Guardia, a Smiling Helper Materializes, Digitally
text: La Guardia Airport’s newest employee, a young woman named Marie, made quite an impression during her first day on the job Wednesday. Airport managers smiled as they watched the blue-eyed, 6-foot-tall blonde with apple-red cheeks stand in front of new arrivals and pleasantly explain where they could find the baggage claim and the taxi stands. Her bosses did not even mind when she twiddled her thumbs and rolled her eyes when no one was around.

headline: With Rates Low, Banks Increase Mortgage Profit
text: Interest rates on mortgages and refinancing are at record lows, giving borrowers plenty to celebrate. But the bigger winners are the banks making the loans.

headline: Christie Seeks to Weaken Oversight of Halfway Houses
text: Gov. Chris Christie’s administration came under heavy criticism from legislators last month at hearings on New Jersey’s privately run halfway houses, which handle thousands of inmates each year. On Wednesday, Mr. Christie fired back, saying he would significantly weaken a measure approved by the legislators to increase their oversight of the system.

headline: North Korea: Is That a Dior, Comrade?
text: In a country that still has trouble feeding all its people, Ri Sol-ju, the wife of the country’s young leader, was pictured this week with what appears to be a luxury many North Korean women have probably never heard of, much less owned: a Christian Dior handbag. If it is not a knockoff, the bag’s going price in Seoul is the equivalent of $1,600, about 16 times the monthly wage of some of North Korea’s best-paid workers. The family of Ms. Ri’s husband, Kim Jong-un, has long been said to live in style. A former Russian presidential envoy who traveled with his father on a private train in 2001 reported that it was stocked with cases of French wine and that live lobsters were delivered. But it has been unusual for Pyongyang’s elite to show wealth so publicly. In a recent speech to party leaders, Mr. Kim lovingly remembered how his father insisted on wearing a threadbare gray parka to remind himself of the famine of the 1990s.

headline: All-American Ending for Beach Volleyball Team
text: LONDON — Misty May-Treanor said she wanted Wednesday night’s gold medal match to be the best of her and her American beach volleyball teammate Kerri Walsh Jennings’s lives. And by most accounts, it was.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Hear, All Ye People;  Hearken, O Earth (Part 1)
text: This is the first installment in a two-part series.

headline: China: Typhoon Leads to Evacuation
text: A typhoon struck the eastern coast of China on Wednesday, landing near Shanghai and creating torrential rain and powerful winds that knocked out power and forced the evacuation of more than a million people. There were no reports of deaths, but many businesses were closed and Shanghai’s two major airports delayed or canceled hundreds of flights. Shanghai’s ports, among the world’s busiest by container volume, were also closed Wednesday, according to Reuters. Local governments in the region were on high alert following flooding in Beijing in late July that caused the deaths of at least 77 people and led to a public outcry over the city’s poor preparedness.

headline: Publishing Losses Hurt Results at News Corp.
text: A write-down on News Corporation’s underperforming publishing unit contributed to the company’s loss of $1.6 billion, or 64 cents a share, in the quarter that ended June 30.

headline: A Brooklyn Block in Bloom
text: There are purple petunias, pink begonias and magenta New Guinea impatiens in front of Maureen Facey and Marian Facey-Boone’s home on Lincoln Road in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn.

headline: Another New York Transplant, Ted Hope, to Lead San Francisco Film Society
text: Yet another leading light in the New York independent film world, Ted Hope, has been named to a position that has been held by two prominent New Yorkers: the executive directorship the San Francisco Film Society.

headline: Urged to Shoot, Durant Obliges as U.S. Ousts Australia
text: LONDON — The point guards bother Kevin Durant the most. They find him in meetings, on buses, in hallways of hotels. Shoot the ball, they tell him. Shoot. The. Ball.

headline: Mexico: Attack Kills Four in Acapulco
text: Gunmen burst into a house in Acapulco late Tuesday night, killing four people — including a pregnant woman and a 3-year-old girl — and wounding one person, Mexican authorities said. The attack appeared to be the work of organized criminals, according to an official from the state prosecutor’s office. “Acapulco has become a place with high rates of drug consumption,” said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Amid President Felipe Calderón’s crackdown against drug gangs, Acapulco, formerly a popular tourist destination for Americans, saw a drastic increase in homicides in 2010 and 2011.

headline: Americans Win Gold and Silver in Beach Volleyball
text: Misty May-Treanor and Kerri Walsh Jennings defeated their fellow Americans in the final.

headline: The Wacky Primary Voters
text: Missouri Republicans have just nominated a Senate candidate who appears to believe that the government’s college student loan program is the equivalent of Stage 3 cancer. Actually, he said “the Stage 3 cancer of socialism,” which is perhaps not the exact same thing. But I believe you get the idea.

headline: How to End the Chaos in Syria
text: Syria is descending toward civil war, if it is not already embroiled in one. What can be done to stop this, or at least limit it?

headline: Mr. Romney Hits Bottom on Welfare
text: Mitt Romney’s campaign has hit new depths of truth-twisting with its accusation that President Obama plans to “gut welfare reform” by ending federal work requirements. The claim is blatantly false, but it says a great deal about Mr. Romney’s increasingly desperate desire to define the president as something he is not.

headline: News From Our Neighboring Planet
text: Mars never gets old. Every time we get a new look at the planet we see it in higher resolution. The earliest images shot from a dedicated spacecraft, taken by Mariner 4 in July 1965, look more like images from an abdominal ultrasound than photographs of a planet.

headline: Heat Exhaustion in a Texas Prison
text: For much of the summer of 2008, temperatures in Beeville, Tex., soared above 90 degrees. For almost two weeks, the heat index was 130 degrees or higher, in what scientists consider the “extreme danger” range, when the risk of heat stroke is imminent.

headline: Obama AWOL in Syria
text: ASPEN, Colo.

headline: Stop-and-Frisk in New York City
text: The New York City Police Department is trumpeting a decrease of about one-third in the number of citizens detained under its increasingly unpopular stop-and-frisk program. The news comes as a relief, since New Yorkers, nearly all of whom were innocent of any crime, were stopped nearly 700,000 times last year.

headline: Errant Code? It’s Not Just a Bug
text: San Francisco

headline: Mixing It Up With the Charmer, the Flight Attendant and the Pundette
text: Any evening of theater that includes pieces by Paul Rudnick and Neil LaBute is pretty close to a sure thing. But when neither play — fine though both are — is the best work on the program, that’s unexpected.

headline: Quarrelsome, Motley Crew: Flirting, Insulting, Drinking
text: IN “BULLET FOR ADOLF,” WHICH OPENED ON WEDNESDAY NIGHT AT NEW WORLD STAGES ... WHAT’S THAT? Oh, was I shouting? I’m sorry. It’s just that I’ve seen this new play, and it’s performed at such a high decibel level that it’s hard to hear yourself think over even the recollection of it.

headline: It’s a Small Whirl After All
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Interesting-looking grid, isn’t it? I guessed what it was right away, but the pleasure in doing Joe Krozel’s puzzle was in seeing exactly how he was going to pull off a pictorial representation of the completed TIC TAC TOE grid.

headline: Opposing Sides Preview Strategies in Kidnapping Trial
text: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Some 50 members of an Amish-Mennonite sect filled half the federal district courtroom here Wednesday, arriving from several states to support Kenneth L. Miller, a pastor accused of abetting international parental kidnapping in a case involving same-sex marriage, conservative Christianity and a bitter custody battle.

headline: In Laundering Case, a Lax Banking Law Obscured Money Flow
text: The list of global banks that have been accused in recent years of laundering foreign transactions totaling billions of dollars has been growing — Credit Suisse, Lloyds, Barclays, ING, HSBC — and now Standard Chartered.

headline: Chicago Delay Fuels Concern About New York Bike Sharing
text: An ambitious bike-share program, trumpeted as a transformational initiative by a powerful big-city mayor, has been pushed back to the spring.

headline: Fatal Attack Shows Plan to Unsettle Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three NATO soldiers and an Afghan civilian were killed Wednesday in a suicide attack in the middle of the provincial capital of Kunar Province in eastern Afghanistan.

headline: A Glimpse Into the Garden’s Future
text: Madison Square Garden opened its doors to the news media Wednesday for a tour of the second part of a three-part renovation of the arena. The event was led by Hank Ratner, president and chief executive of Madison Square Garden Company.

headline: An Open-Water Test for Swimmers
text: The 10-kilometer marathon open-water swim is perhaps the most arduous swimming event at the London Olympics, and it takes a special athlete to undertake its challenges.

headline: Punk Band’s Moscow Trial Offers Platform for Orthodox Protesters
text: MOSCOW — With the gold domes of the Cathedral of Christ the Savior glittering just across the Moscow River, members of three Russian Orthodox groups that espouse a fervent blend of nationalism and religiosity set fire on Wednesday to a poster of the feminist punk band Pussy Riot and also put a match to a poster of the pop star Madonna.

headline: Piecing Together a Regional Missile Defense
text: The United States has been negotiating billions of dollars in weapons deals with individual Persian Gulf countries to protect against a potential attack from Iran.

headline: Plots Are Tied to Shadow War of Israel and Iran
text: BERLIN — A magnetic bomb detonated on a diplomatic car in New Delhi. The police uncovered a cache of explosives at a golf course in the Kenyan city of Mombasa. Five Israeli tourists and a Bulgarian bus driver were killed in an attack outside the airport in the Black Sea coastal city of Burgas.

headline: For Lefty Relievers, a Danger of Overuse
text: As the Mets’ Tim Byrdak continues to weigh his options after learning Monday that he tore the anterior capsule in his pitching shoulder, he has uncovered certain realities about his field of work. Namely, there are inherent risks associated with being his team’s sole reliable left-handed reliever.

headline: In Clamor for Roles at Convention, More Are Out Than In
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Newt Gingrich hoped to get a coveted speaking slot at the Republican National Convention. Instead the Romney campaign will have him teach a series of workshops they have nicknamed Newt University.

headline: Photo Replay: U.S. Men Advance
text: The United States men’s basketball team reached the Olympic semifinals with a 119-86 rout of Australia on Wednesday.

headline: Corrections: August 9, 2012
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: The Welfare Gambit
text: I smell desperation.

headline: Roy S. Bryce-Laporte, Who Led Black Studies at Yale, Dies at 78
text: Roy S. Bryce-Laporte, a sociologist who led one of the nation’s first African-American studies departments, at Yale University, and did research that advanced understanding of blacks who came to the United States voluntarily rather than as slaves, died on July 31 in Sykesville, Md. He was 78.

headline: Voter Portraits: Zoey Kotzambasis
text: Like many of her young Republican peers, Zoey Kotzambasis supports abortion rights and same-sex marriage. Those liberal-to-moderate social views, she believes, will change the face of the G.O.P.

headline: Mourning Wisconsin Shooting Victims, in New York
text: Amritpal Singh of Queens, right, and others held up images of the victims, including an injured police officer, of the recent shooting at a Sikh temple in Oak Creek, Wis., as they took part in a vigil Wednesday in Union Square Park.

headline: Young in G.O.P. Erase the Lines on Social Issues
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Matt Hoagland, the county leader of a group of young North Carolina Republicans, is busy trying to ramp up enthusiasm for Mitt Romney at the grass-roots level. So there are a few things he avoids mentioning to prospective young voters he wants to woo, including the hot-button topics like abortion and same-sex marriage, which have dominated campaigns past.

headline: Dr. William C. Reeves, Who Sought Cause of Fatigue Syndrome, Dies at 69
text: Dr. William C. Reeves, an epidemiologist who fought his own federal agency to obtain money to study chronic fatigue syndrome and then infuriated patients with the ailment by suggesting that it was linked to psychological problems rather than a virus, died on Aug. 3 at his home in Atlanta. He was 69.

headline: Dr. James West, a Pioneer in Addiction Study and Care, Dies at 98
text: James W. West, a surgeon whose struggles with alcohol led him to develop treatments for addiction and eventually to become medical director of the Betty Ford Center, died on July 24 at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 98.

headline: Breast Cancer Group Changes Leaders
text: Nancy G. Brinker, the founder of Susan G. Komen for the Cure, will leave her post as chief executive, and its president will resign, the group announced on Wednesday in the most significant leadership shake-up to follow its short-lived attempt to cut financing for breast cancer services provided by Planned Parenthood.

headline: This Time, Sloppy Play Doesn’t Sink Yankees
text: DETROIT — A day after Eric Chavez said there was a high level of concern over the Yankees’ recent poor play, the team came perilously close to blowing a sizable lead in what could have seemed like a catastrophic loss.

headline: Rebuking Critics of Leaks, Top Counterterrorism Adviser Seeks a Little Room
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s top counterterrorism adviser bluntly rejected on Wednesday charges from Mitt Romney and other Republicans that the White House has leaked classified information for political purposes, calling the claims “specious and unfounded.”

headline: Day 14: What to Watch For
text: Here are some of the events, teams and athletes to watch on Thursday at the London Games. (All times Eastern.)

headline: Life, Interrupted: Medical Bills, Insurance and Uncertainty
text: Like a lot of other young people, I never thought about health insurance until I got sick. I was 22, and my adult life was just beginning. But less than a year after walking across the stage at my college graduation, I received an unexpected diagnosis — acute myeloid leukemia — and with it came a flurry of consultations, tests and appointments. From early on, my doctors told me I would need chemotherapy and a bone marrow transplant.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Peculiar Heartbeat
text: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a 31-year-old woman with heart palpitations that leave her dizzy and short of breath?

text: expropriate •\ek-ˈspro-pre-ˌat\• verb

headline: Down-Ballot Races Provide Much of Season’s Election Theater
text: WASHINGTON — Santa Claus is quite possibly coming to town. And really, that’s not even the weirdest thing that has happened so far in the 2012 Congressional election cycle as House and Senate primaries move into the final stages.

headline: California: Company Faces 2nd Suit Over Visas
text: A new whistle-blower lawsuit has been filed against Infosys, the giant Indian outsourcing company, by a man who says he was harassed into quitting after he reported visa fraud by managers there. Satya Dev Tripuraneni, an American who worked for Infosys for five years in California, says the company billed fraudulently for workers brought from India on short-term visitor visas and also evaded taxes. After he reported his concerns, he was threatened and demoted, Mr. Tripuraneni claims in the lawsuit filed in federal court for the Northern District of California. Danielle D’Angelo, an Infosys spokeswoman, said the company had started an internal investigation of the claims. A trial in the case of Jay Palmer, another whistle-blower who reported suspected visa fraud at Infosys, begins Aug. 20 in Montgomery, Ala.

headline: Real Madrid’s Mourinho Sees a Future Coaching in the U.S.
text: José Mourinho of Real Madrid said he would be interested in coaching in the United States in the future, although not as the national coach. “The quality of the game is good,” he said in New York. “They have a positive approach to the game, they want to win, want to play well, want to express good qualities. Step by step it is coming, and one day I want to give a little bit of a help.” More at nytimes.com/goal.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,059 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Police Sergeant Shot in the Leg in Queens
text: A New York City police sergeant was shot in the leg while pursuing a suspect on Wednesday night on a street in Queens, the police said. Authorities said that the sergeant was expected to survive.

headline: Previewing Japan-U.S. Soccer Final
text: Can the United States avenge its 2011 World Cup defeat to Japan in Thursday's Olympic Women's soccer final? Sam Borden joins Victor Mather to break down the matchup.

headline: Groups’ Campaign Spending Scrutinized in New York
text: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York is escalating his inquiry into the fastest-growing but darkest corner of the campaign world, requesting in recent weeks tax returns and other financial documents from dozens of tax-exempt groups that are among the biggest spenders in this year’s election, people with knowledge of the requests said.

headline: Should Britain Return to Nuclear Power?
text: HINKLEY POINT, England — For my latest Green Column I visited Hinkley Point in southwest England where Britain’s first nuclear plants in nearly 20 years may be built. Britain is worried about running out of power capacity. Many of the country’s coal-fired and nuclear plants are aging and are scheduled to be retired in the next few years.

headline: Lost Boys of the Line of Control
text: Up in the mountains, a hushed stillness has descended on Dalaunja, the last village bordering the Line of Control, which divides Kashmir between India and Pakistan.

headline: A Week of Ghosts: Japan’s Annual Grieving
text: HONG KONG — There may come a time when these memorials will cease, when they are unneeded, untoward, unwanted. But not yet.

headline: Obama Assails Romney on Women’s Health Care
text: DENVER — President Obama made one of his strongest pitches to date for the women’s vote, which is crucial to his re-election, telling a mostly female crowd of 4,000 here on Wednesday that Republicans led by Mitt Romney would take them back to the era of the 1950s.

headline: Internet Gambling and More Casinos Threaten Shakopee Tribe
text: After 25 years of booming profits, the tribal casino business has suddenly gone flat. The growth of commercial casinos and online gambling is raising financial concerns for one of the richest tribes.

headline: In House Race, Watchdogs Question Family Finances
text: BOSTON — Representative John F. Tierney, the Massachusetts Democrat who is seeking his ninth term in the House, is facing new questions over the illegal offshore gambling business once run by two of his brothers-in-law, just a few months before an election pits him against the most viable opponent of his career.

headline: News Quiz | August 9, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: $1 Million Each Year for All, as Long as Tribe’s Luck Holds
text: SHAKOPEE MDEWAKANTON INDIAN RESERVATION, Minn. — A generation ago, the Shakopee Mdewakanton tribe lived in a motley collection of beat-up trailer homes, melting snow for bath water when wells froze over because they lacked indoor plumbing. Three-quarters of tribal members received government food supplements.

headline: For Victim in Sikh Temple Shooting, a Life of Separation
text: “When his chance came to go to America, Ranjit Singh promised his wife and three young children they would not be separated for too long,” Jim Yardley and Sruthi Gottipati wrote in The New York Times. “He was taking a position at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin and hoped his family might join him there.”

headline: Growth Flagging in China, Government Data Show
text: HONG KONG — Hopes dimmed for an imminent pickup in China, the world’s growth engine, as a batch of disappointing economic data released Thursday showed industrial production and retail sales falling well short of expectations in July.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 9, 2012
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Why Can’t the Bronx Be More Like Brooklyn?”

headline: The Secret to Solar Power
text: Most mornings, Danny Kennedy hops on a bike with orange saddlebags and rides half an hour from his home to Oakland’s Jack London Square. He makes for quite a picture cruising down Telegraph Avenue, decked out as he often is in an orange helmet, orange jacket and orange leather Adidas shoes. When he arrives at his office, he often makes his rounds on an orange indoor bike. (He’s not joking around with the orange thing.) Though Kennedy was once a young environmental activist documenting the horrors of the oil and mining industries, he’s now a 41-year-old company man. The orange that he wears daily — which extends even to the checks on his shirts, and which drives his wife crazy — is the brand color for his rapidly growing residential solar company, Sungevity, whose revenues grew by a factor of eight in 2010 and doubled again in 2011, and whose employees have grown to 260 from 3 since the company’s inception five years ago.

headline: A Bipartisan Proposal for More Equity in Big Banks
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: A Child’s Life Changes and a Story Begins
text: Nearly three years ago, Alex Masi took a photograph of a little girl in Bhopal, India. Lens published the picture in May of 2011, shortly after it received the Photographers Giving Back Award — a sum of $5,000 that went directly to the child, Poonam Jatev, and her family.

headline: What We're Watching on Day 14
text: The U.S. women's soccer team will play Japan with a gold medal on the line and Usain Bolt looks to win his second gold medal in the 200-meters.

headline: Three Key States, Split Evenly
text: WHEN were poll results from three key battleground states concerning the upcoming presidential election released?

headline: A Conversation With: Author Nilanjana Roy
text: In her first novel, “The Wildings,” the literary critic and journalist Nilanjana Roy has imagined a world where the animal kingdom is a vast, interlinked network of species that communicate with each other and follows an inviolate, ancient code of conduct. Humans are known as “Bigfeet” and are just puzzling, oafish creatures that form the backdrop.

headline: War of Words and Arms Amid Assault in Syrian City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian rebels in embattled Aleppo tried to maintain morale on Thursday by highlighting small gains in the midst of a withdrawal from the most contested area of the city, as government forces fired on their positions with jets, helicopters, artillery and tanks.

headline: New England Patriots, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit completes his analysis of the A.F.C. East with a look at the Patriots. Earlier this week, he assessed the Jets, the Bills and the Dolphins.

headline: Fast-Paced Trial in China Murder Leaves Shadows
text: HEFEI, China — Worried that a longtime friend and business associate might harm her only child, Gu Kailai lured him to a rented villa in southwest China, plied him with alcohol until he could take no more and then, when he began to vomit and requested a drink of water, poured a poisonous concoction into his mouth.

headline: Summer of No Discontent
text: TEL AVIV — Last summer was the summer of tents and hope. This summer is the summer of no free lunches and tough economic measures. Last summer, a surprisingly vigorous social justice movement sent hundreds of thousands of Israelis to the town square. This summer, its dregs are attracting meager participation.

text: (function($){var data = chameleonData;var ticker = new NYTD.NYTMM.NewsTicker($('#nytmm_embed_223'), data);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

headline: Go Ahead, Send Me Packing
text: The (Times) Magazine’s food and drink issue will appear on Oct. 14, and the editors (of which I’m one) have agreed that I should travel somewhere and write about the food. That, in itself, is not that unusual of an idea, but maybe this is: we’ve decided to solicit your input to determine where I’ll go.

headline: Go Fish
text: I used to say that I never invented a dish in my life, but now that would be disingenuous. I know I’m not creative in the same sense that a talented chef is, but I also know that my experience has taken me from a place where I would slavishly follow recipes to one where I rarely look at them. Now almost every meal begins with a fantasy. I then buy what looks as if it has the potential to fulfill that fantasy — or simply open the refrigerator and see what’s already there. At that point I improvise on an already established theme from I guess what you’d call my repertoire. In this regard, cooking is like music, but easier: the basic skills are not difficult to attain, and the creativity comes not in reinventing them but in imagining new ways in which to combine them.

headline: Punch-Drunk Love
text: On a good day, the train ride from New York to Burlington, Vt., takes about nine hours. (Train? As I’ve confessed before, I’m one of those hopeless nondriving New Yorkers. Besides, I love trains. Usually.) But an unseasonably hot Wednesday in late May was not a good day. Forty minutes out of Penn Station, the engine broke down. Off went the lights and the air-conditioning. A “rescue engine” was on its way, but after half an hour slipped by without any sign of deliverance, I began to despair. Then we changed trains. Again. And again.

headline: The Problem With Performance Reviews
text: Performance reviews are standard protocol in corporate America. The objective seems to be for the company to give formal and direct feedback to employees, who are assumed to understand that the reviews represent an opportunity to get a status check (like a report card) that can help them improve their performance and in the end further their careers.

headline: Uttarakhand Floods Kill Dozens and Displace Hundreds
text: Even as much of India is struggling with a weak monsoon, the Himalayan state of Uttarakhand is facing a very different emergency, as heavy rains and flash flooding have swept away homes, stranded villagers on high ground and left at least 28 people dead.

headline: French Fury as Sarkozy Intervenes on Syria
text: LONDON — He’s back! Just three months after being put out of office by the French electorate, Nicolas Sarkozy has sparked a political firestorm by criticizing his successor’s Syria policy.

headline: Special Education Reform Brings City More In Line With National Trend
text: New York City is revamping how it teaches many of its special-needs students, who have learning disabilities or moderate behavioral problems. Although the national trend has been to mix more of these students into mainstream classrooms, the city has stuck to an old model of keeping special ed students separate. Until now.

headline: An Uncertain Phase for Nuclear Power Licenses
text: In a rare action, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has acceded to a petition filed by anti-nuclear groups that it halt some licensing activities until the agency can sort out its troubled policy on nuclear waste. The groups, two dozen of them, are sounding triumphant, as if they have brought the industry to its knees.

headline: Journey to Antarctica
text: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agency’s human spaceflight program.

headline: Pistorius to Run in Relay Final After Team’s Crash and Appeal
text: LONDON — Oscar Pistorius bounced on his carbon-fiber blades in the sun at the start-finish line Thursday, waiting for his turn to run in the 4x400-meter relay. But the handoff never came.

headline: An Architect’s Vision: Bare Elegance in China
text: Hangzhou, China

headline: The Two Halves of a Neighborhood’s Soul, Bared for All to See
text: Spike Lee’s messy, meandering, bluntly polemical “Red Hook Summer” has one crucial ingredient: a raw vitality. This celebration of African-American resilience in a struggling New York neighborhood envisions two cultures coexisting uneasily in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn. It is on the side of hope.

headline: Powerful Indian Financial Exchange Trades Accusations With Economist
text: One of India’s fastest-growing financial exchanges “is suing a prominent economist claiming defamation,” Vikas Bajaj  wrote in The New York Times. But Ajay Shah, the economist, says “the Multi Commodity Exchange of India is just using legal means to quiet a critic.”

headline: The 2012 Cycle: Attack, Feign Outrage, Repeat
text: The Democratic outrage machine is in full lather.

headline: Opinion Report: Humane Confinement
text: From the editorial page

headline: Ouya Game Console Ends Kickstarter Campaign With $8.5 Million
text: The Ouya, an inexpensive gaming console that runs on Android, is the latest experimental hardware project to take the Web by storm. It raised more than $8.5 million through Kickstarter, the crowd-funding Web site, in a campaign that ended early Thursday.

headline: London Live: Follow Thursday’s Action at the Olympics
text: Usain Bolt of Jamaica became the first man to defend his title in the Olympic 200 meters, holding off a challenge from Jamaican teammate Yohan Blake down the final straightaway to win in 19.32 seconds. Bolt has now completed his second straight 100-200 double. Jamaica swept the medals with Warren Weir finishing third.

headline: National Oilwell Varco to Buy Robbins & Myers for $2.5 Billion
text: National Oilwell Varco agreed on Thursday to buy Robbins & Myers, a maker of oil well drilling equipment, for about $2.5 billion, as deal-making in the energy sector continues unabated.

headline: Daily Report: A Stumble for Google With Media Player
text: Google’s Nexus Q, a black ball meant to stream video and music, is the company’s first try at building its own hardware — in the United States, no less. But as Claire Cain Miller reports on Thursday in The New York Times, Google’s indefinite postponement of Nexus Q shipments last week indicates the challenges it faces as it tries to move into two new areas: hardware and social technology.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: At Last, Political Ads 24/7; and a Firing at Oxford American
text: With the influx of outside spending on campaign ads this year in many states, it can seem as if TV is wall-to-wall political advertising, but in Hawaii, Adam Nagourney reports, the Republican candidate for United States Senate is turning that vision into reality. Linda Lingle, a former two-term governor, pays $2,500 a week for channel 110 on the digital cable dial for LL12, where she airs speeches, her own ads and endorsements and video issue papers in 10 of the languages spoke on the islands. The channel, while a relatively high number, is ensconced between CNN Headline News and Fox News, so presumably gets a few politically interested channel surfers.

headline: A Familiar Tale of Trump and Real Estate, This Time in Scotland
text: With so many famous people calling New York home, it is not surprising that some of them catch the attention of documentary makers. Indeed, one of our better-known citizens is the main figure in a film that opened in Manhattan a few days ago. He happens not to be one of our more beloved citizens: Donald J. Trump.

headline: Funeral Services Planned for Marvin Hamlisch
text: The life of Marvin Hamlisch, the highly decorated composer of “A Chorus Line” and “The Way We Were,” among many other works, will be commemorated at visitations and a funeral service, his press representatives said on Thursday. Public visitations will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, in Manhattan, on Sunday between 2 p.m. and 5 p.m., and between 7 p.m. and 9 p.m., and on Monday during those same hours. The funeral, which is also open to the public, will be held on Tuesday 11 a.m. at Temple Emanu-El at 65th Street and 5th Avenue in Manhattan.

headline: When the Choice Is Jobs or the Environment
text: For the past couple of decades, economic common sense and fears about climate change have coincided. Relying on fossil fuels was a mistake, both because we were running out of them and because of the impact of greenhouse gases on the environment.

headline: Printing From Your iPhone, at a Price
text: Seldom do plug-and-play devices live up to the name. It’s usually more like, plug, fail, reread instructions, curse, hold for tech assistance, fail, curse more, Google until you find an answer, play, try to soothe frazzled nerves.

headline: All the President’s Media
text: BUENOS AIRES — Last week, Argentina’s small but active Twitter scene became transfixed with more than three dozen messages sent out by Juan Cruz Sanz, a young journalist at Clarín, the country’s largest circulation daily. Sanz’s short missives recounted how high-level officials pressured C5N — a cable TV news station recently bought by an executive close to the government — to renege on an offer to hire him as a panelist on a late-night program. The spokesman of President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner and her chief of cabinet allegedly made calls to C5N managers. (A manager at the channel later denied the allegations, also on Twitter.)

headline: In a Factory’s Shadow, Fears About Health
text: “By issuing carbon credits to companies for reducing emissions in the developing world, the United Nations aimed to inject cash into poor communities supporting the growth of sustainable industry,” Elisabeth Rosenthal wrote in The New York Times. But in the remote village of Nathkuva adjacent to Gujarat Fluorochemicals Limited’s coolant gas plant, “environmental groups and residents have been at loggerheads with the company over pollution since it opened in 1989.”

headline: Thursday Reading: The Financial Problems of Parents of Olympians

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Jezebel: New Coke, Coke Zero and Diet Coke Plus have all been consigned to the recycling bin of history. But 30 years after its birth, regular old Diet Coke remains “the world’s liquid crack of choice.” Why? One theory holds that its mix of low-calorie cred and suspect chemicals allows conscientious people an acceptable way to be bad. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Wall Street Journal Editorial Praises Ryan for No. 2 Spot
text: The Wall Street Journal editorial page, a leading forum of conservative thought, had high praise Thursday for Representative Paul D.Ryan as Mitt Romney’s possible running mate, citing his determination to curb entitlement spending. The editorial said that Mr. Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, had taken on entitlement spending “against the advice of every Beltway bed-wetter” concerned about the implications of such a cause.

headline: The Power of Images: California Maps Greenhouse Gases
text: One of the most significant political problems facing campaigns against air pollution these days is this: by and large, you can’t see it. You can track its molecules, watch emergency room admissions go up and down as it waxes and wanes and estimate the number of lives shortened by it. But none of that provides the jolt of, say, a picture of a tornado’s path or a river on fire.

headline: Monkees, Despite Death of Davy Jones, Say They Will Go on Tour
text: The three surviving members of the Monkees say they will go on tour in November, minus the charismatic Davy Jones, who died in February.  Michael Nesmith, Micky Dolenz and Peter Tork announced that they would start a 12-date American tour in Escondido, Calif., on Nov. 8, hitting several major markets before wrapping up with a concert in New York on Dec. 2.

headline: The Troubled Life of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board
text: Back in 2003, the national commission on the Sept. 11 attacks advised that as the country bulked up its defenses against terrorism, the watchers themselves would require watching. Congress heeded the warning and created the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board in 2004 to make certain more aggressive intelligence collection did not unduly infringe on Americans’ rights.

But now the novel, widely considered one of the greatest works of the 20th century, has suffered perhaps its gravest indignity yet: being insulted by Paulo Coelho.

headline: A Funereal Presence Swoops In to Roost and Caw
text: The installations of Janet Cardiff and George Bures Miller have always had a poltergeist quality; they disrupt space while being more or less invisible. Using ambisonic recording technology they engulf listeners in a constantly shifting three-dimensional field — a complete soundscape, as the artists call it. Submitting to one of these works is a deeply uncanny experience, even when the sounds are derived from glorious 16th-century choral music (as in their 2001 masterwork, “The Forty Part Motet”).

headline: On Borrowing Digital Books From the Library

headline: On Our Radar: An Agent Orange Cleanup
text: The United States and Vietnam begin a cleanup operation to rid a former army air base in Da Nang of the toxic residue of Agent Orange, a defoliant that was stored there by American forces during the Vietnam War. The United States Army sprayed millions of gallons of the chemical on vegetation to destroy enemy cover, a practice that has been linked to ills like diabetes, cancer and birth defects. Washington has not admitted liability for health problems caused by the herbicide. [Voice of America]

headline: More Noir Than Chardonnay

headline: Search Engines Log the Fearsome Journeys of War Families
text: A wife just found out her husband is going to war. Her husband stands in a doorway. She backs down a hallway away from the news of a deployment that keeps coming closer. She locks herself in a room, sits in front of a computer, and types into a search engine the phrase “husband off to Afghanistan soon.” She knows Afghanistan is not a word but a place. It is a country made of mountains, men, and machine guns where her husband will go to war and live or die. But she is searching for more.

headline: Crepes du Nord Heads for the Malls

As in his other restaurants, he will emphasize sustainable and organic foods, with some ingredients grown on his upstate farm.

headline: The Two Civil Wars
text: Josiah Williams was 23 years old when he saw his Uncle Whit’s head blown apart at the Battle of Cedar Mountain, which took place in north central Virginia on Aug. 9, 1862. But even his account as witness wasn’t enough to convince his parents, back in Indiana, of Whit’s death. They simply refused to believe him and, without a body to bring back, he had no more proof to offer.

headline: ‘Bring It On’ and ‘Closer Than Ever’ Extend Runs
text: Gimme an E! Gimme an X! Gimme … Well let’s cut to the chase: The Broadway production of “Bring It On: The Musical” will continue through Jan. 20 at the St. James Theater, the show’s producers announced on Thursday. It had been scheduled to close on Oct. 7.

headline: Raymond Harding, 77, Dies; Liberal Party Power Broker

headline: Bourne, Under New Management
text: Just before “The Bourne Legacy” gets its game on, the franchise’s new face, played by Jeremy Renner, comes out of the Alaskan wilderness to take refuge in a cabin. There he meets another of his kind, a superspy with a scowl and enough artillery to invade a small country. By the time they’ve grudgingly warmed up to each other an unmanned drone is blasting everything to bits. It’s an effectively blunt opener for a series that from its start has tracked a different military drone, this one a man fighting to recover first his identity and then his humanity. That you may not remember the name of Mr. Renner’s agent, Aaron Cross, after all the dust finally settles, suggests that the fight goes on.

headline: Hagerty: Pebble Beach Auctions Could Gross a Record $215 Million
text: Collectible vehicles worth $205 million to $215 million will be coming to auction Aug. 15-19 at five events held in conjunction with the Pebble Beach Concours d’Elegance, according to an estimate released Wednesday by the Hagerty Price Guide.

That’s the premise of the new television drama “The Americans,” which will star Keri Russell, Matthew Rhys and Noah Emmerich, and which FX said on Thursday it had ordered  for next year.

headline: Obama Draws Contrast With Romney on Wind Energy Tax Credit
text: PUEBLO, Colo. – Speaking not far from a wind turbine manufacturing plant here on the hot plains, President Obama on Thursday contrasted his support for keeping alive an expiring tax credit for wind energy producers with the opposition of Mitt Romney to that subsidy and others for clean energy alternatives to oil.

headline: Tokyo Rises Early for Women’s Gold Medal Game
text: TOKYO — Soccer fans were napping to prepare for what the local news media were calling the battle of the century, the women’s Olympic gold medal match Thursday between Japan and the United States, which was scheduled to kick off at a ghastly 3:45 a.m. here. “It’s national sleepiness day!” says Miki, who tweets at @Mikilin999.

headline: Iran, Excluded From Other Meetings on Syria, Hosts Its Own
text: TEHRAN — Shut out of diplomatic meetings on the Syria conflict, Iran convened emergency consultations of its own on Thursday, with participants from nearly 30 countries, including Russia and China, discussing ways to reach a solution. It was the first such gathering since the special representative Kofi Annan resigned as a United Nations and Arab League mediator last week.
