headline: 4 Decades on, U.S. Starts Cleanup of Agent Orange in Vietnam
text: DA NANG, Vietnam — In the tropical climate of central Vietnam, weeds and shrubs seem to grow everywhere — except here.

headline: How to Make Your Lost Phone Findable
text: Last week, I lost my iPhone on a train. I used Apple’s Find My iPhone feature to track it to a house in suburban Maryland, and the local police were able to return it to me. Because I’d tweeted about these developments, the quest for the phone became, much to my surprise, an Internet-wide, minute-by-minute real-life thriller. (You can read the whole story here.)

headline: Barclays Names a New Chairman
text: LONDON — Barclays, whose top management was toppled amid an interest rate manipulation scandal, on Thursday turned to a former Bank of England official to be its next chairman.

headline: When Only a Shack Will Do
text: A SEAFOOD shack should be a little tumbledown, possibly decrepit, with insufficient parking and oil-stained cartons of fried mollusks dispensed brusquely through a window. You should eat at a picnic table, salt wind whipping your hair into your mouth, or take your haul down a poison-ivy-laced path to the beach, fending off stalker gulls. There should be a sunset that lasts half the night, and nowhere else you need to be.

headline: Robert Zemeckis Movie ‘Flight,’ With Denzel Washington, Will Close New York Film Festival
text: There’s no official word yet on which movie will be showing when the New York Film Festival takes off this year, but its organizers know how they’ll bring the festival in for a landing: “Flight,” a new thriller directed by Robert Zemeckis and starring Denzel Washington, will make its world premiere as the closing-night selection on Oct. 14, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Thursday.

The following are selected quotes from the book, “Winning a Lawsuit in the U.S.,” published by Guangming Daily publishing house in February 1998.

headline: 36 Hours in Montpellier, France
text: NOSTRADAMUS, a former resident of France’s eighth-largest metropolis, might have put it this way: “The lord of multicolored pants / Will conjure two iron serpents / And a bald builder shall erect / A mighty blue monolith.” It would be an apt prediction of the splashy new projects appearing in this Mediterranean city, which has recruited titans of fashion and architecture to inject some style and modernity. Christian Lacroix, celebrated for his radiant clothing lines, has decorated two recently unveiled tram lines, while the superstar architect Jean Nouvel devised the plans for the enormous new monolithic (and very blue) city hall. Throw in a forthcoming futuristic municipal archives building from the architect Zaha Hadid, and this university center and night-life hotbed may be France’s most forward-looking city.

headline: A Tour of Montpellier, France
text: Christian Lacroix and Jean Nouvel provide star-powered optical pop to this city by the sea.

headline: The Spanish Campaign
text: Alongside the presidential campaign we all know—centered at the moment on a debate between “Romney Hood” and “Obamaloney”—the candidates are waging a shadow war in Spanish, more closely focused on the issues politicians assume are particularly important to Latino voters. The newest foray is a dishonest Spanish-language ad running in Nevada, which attacks President Obama for breaking a campaign promise to pass immigration reform, and for deporting too many illegal immigrants.

headline: How Not to Write to Your Child at Camp
text: This is the season when rural mail carriers’ backs start breaking from the additional weight destined for the summer camps along their route. In my capacity as the Mail Lady of Beam Camp in Strafford, N.H., I see the impact these letters have on their intended recipients. Some bring joy. Others … well, some of the mail circumstances force me to deliver makes me feel fortunate that my job prevents me from subjecting the two campers I spawned to the same blunders, well meaning though they may be.

headline: In the Soup, A Dash of Biodiversity
text: A warm, brothy bowl of fibrous shark fin cartilage may not appeal to many palates, but every culture has its delicacies. Think of crunchy fried tarantulas in Cambodia, or a plate of garlicky snails in France.

headline: Returning to Her Trail of Tears
text: IN 1995, after her mother’s death and her own divorce, Cheryl Strayed decided to hike the mountainous Pacific Crest Trail, which runs from the Mojave Desert through California and Oregon to Washington State, alone. Oh, and she had no experience in distance hiking.

headline: After a Jog 35 Years Ago, He’s Still Running in Circles
text: At 11 a.m. on Sunday two things will happen: in London, around 100 of the world’s fastest men will launch themselves onto the 26.2-mile Olympic marathon course, dashing from Buckingham Palace to the Tower of London in front of hundreds of thousands of excited spectators.

headline: Soaring Ointment Prices Are a Dermatologic Mystery
text: They are the staples of most dermatology practices: generic creams and ointments that treat everything from skin rashes to athlete’s foot to scabies. Many doctors prescribe the drugs without a second thought. But increasingly, some dermatologists say, patients are complaining about a recent, mysterious and rapid rise in price.

text: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service’s financial problems worsened in the spring. The agency reported a $5.2 billion net loss on Thursday for the quarter that ended June 30.

text: This year, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg continued to work after breaking two ribs during one of the Supreme Court’s busiest months, and just a few weeks before the court released its landmark decision on President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Follow the Bouncing Beau
text: For two years, our son dated a man he loved. (We never cared for him.) Enter our daughter, who met this boyfriend at our summer home. The two of them went off together — and not innocently. Sparks flew. They are now a couple, leaving our son brokenhearted. And we are in the awkward position of having this man in our home as our daughter’s partner. Our son thinks we should not allow it. Is there any etiquette for a mess like this? Patty, Pelham, N.Y.

headline: Bookshelf
text: “The Global Tree Project” (Damiani, $40) shows off Shinji Turner-Yamamoto’s enchanting site-specific installations, including the birch trees he suspended in the nave of an abandoned 19th-century chapel in Cincinnati. Davy Rothbart falls in love instantly, often with the wrong people, which explains the title of his achingly funny essay collection: “My Heart Is an Idiot” (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, $25). From a 300-year-old silk Limoges bridal purse to a Céline tote, Judith Clark’s “Handbags” (Yale University Press, $50) assembles standout pieces from the Simone Handbag Museum, which opened last month in Seoul, South Korea.

headline: Sad News Like a Warm Hug Goodbye
text: WHEN friends and colleagues heard that my father had died in an unexpected drowning — on Father’s Day, no less — they couldn’t believe I was at work the next day, that I went swimming in the morning, that I was not at home weeping.

headline: Another Jolt to Global Food Prices
text: For anyone doubting the importance of American agriculture to world markets, the latest price report from the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization will be revealing. The agency reported on Thursday that its food price index jumped by 6 percent in July. That was largely because of rising grain prices, with the drought in the United States and its expected impact on the corn harvest being the biggest factor. The cereals component of the index jumped 17 percent.

headline: The Elements of Grooving
text: “IT’S not about the move, it’s the groove,” Val Ho, a k a Ms. Vee, said to her hip-hop class at the Broadway Dance Center in Manhattan. I tried to take this advice to heart as I warmed up alongside nine fellow students on a recent afternoon. Most of them were women in their 20s with dance backgrounds and perfect posture.

text: U.S. Olympic coach Drew Johansen reveals some secrets behind the 10-meter platform dive.

text: While Weekend Miser is soaking up the rays along the beaches of North Carolina (you think he’d pay Hamptons prices?), he has passed the baton — or rather forwarded several e-mails — to us about all kinds of affordable cultural goings-on around New York.

headline: Best Buy Suffers for Lack of a Plan
text: Confronted with an extraordinary situation, the board of Best Buy, the large electronics retailer, did what good corporate governance practices required. It fired the chief executive.

headline: ‘Elf’ Will Return to Broadway for the Holidays

text: Donna Murphy sings “Children Will Listen” in the Shakespeare in the Park production of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine’s musical.

headline: N.H.L. Negotiations Take a Tense Turn
text: Talks between the N.H.L. and the players association turned sour Thursday, with N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman saying that a “wide gap” divides the two sides and that the owners will not proceed with the 2012-13 season if no new collective bargaining agreement is in place when the current one expires on Sept. 15.

headline: United States Wins Women’s Soccer Gold
text: LONDON — Megan Rapinoe cried. Hope Solo danced. Christie Rampone leapt into the air, jumping into the arms of Abby Wambach as Wembley stadium erupted around them. For all the elaborate celebrations the United States women’s soccer team displayed over the course of the Olympics, the most memorable one was unrehearsed.

headline: Former Goldman Programmer Is Arrested Again
text: The legal odyssey of a former Goldman Sachs programmer, Sergey Aleynikov, took a surprising turn on Thursday when the Manhattan district attorney charged him with state crimes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Syria, the Philippines, India and Afghanistan.

headline: Fame, That Sleazy Siren
text: Stomach-turning, sick-making, rancid, repugnant, repellent, squalid, odious, fetid, disgusting — there is a thesaurus full of terms to describe the contents of Bruce Wagner’s willfully offensive new novel, “Dead Stars.” Photos of dead babies; paparazzi in search of crotch shots of child celebrities; Internet posts celebrating an actor’s getting cancer; violent, graphic group sex; parents pimping out their children — one repulsive scene follows another in these pages, drowning the reader in a more- than-600-page-deep cesspool.

headline: Jackson Pollock’s Hamptons
text: Images from the artist’s studio in the East Hampton hamlet of Springs.

headline: Meandering Just This Side of the Hamptons
text: I HAVE never been a fan of the Hamptons. Sure, the pristine beaches and sloping waves are a welcome respite from the Manhattan summer scorch that can melt the soles of your flip flops. But by the time midsummer rolls around on the eastern end of Long Island, a hint of desperation seems to settle in among the summer habitués who know that the days of sunset clambakes and lazy afternoons at Georgica Beach are coming to an end.

headline: Wheelies: The Undercut Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Eaton Wins Gold Medal in Decathlon
text: LONDON — By the time Ashton Eaton finished, after he dashed and hurdled and jumped and vaulted, after he completed 10 grueling events in two very long days, he struggled to stand up straight. He paused at the final finish line and bent over, hands on knees, gasping for breath.

headline: Obama Campaign Tries to Distance Itself From Widely Criticized ‘Super PAC’ Ad
text: President Obama’s top advisers have spent the last 36 hours trying to put distance between their candidate and a “super PAC” ad that lays the blame for the death of a cancer victim at Mitt Romney’s feet.

headline: Kiss Babies, Dodge Scandal, Praise the Lord
text: “The Campaign” is a comedy about a North Carolina Congressional election. Since it stars Will Ferrell and Zach Galifianakis as rival candidates — you probably know this if you own a television — the movie is obviously not a realistic depiction of the American electoral process. But its relationship to the reality of contemporary politics is nonetheless interesting to consider. Too soft and silly to be satire, too upbeat to be a cautionary tale, the film (directed by Jay Roach) is a fun-house fable that both exaggerates and understates the absurdities of our democracy in this contentious election year.

headline: Bolt Wins 200 Meters
text: Usain Bolt of Jamaica edged his teammate Yohan Blake to win the gold medal at the London Games.

headline: Come Let Us Adore Him
text: The baby’s feet must smell sweet to the rapt old king who kneels and cups them to his face like flowers. One of three sages and seekers, he’s come a long way to find this child, who sits upright, grave and alert, on his mother’s lap, though he’s only 2 weeks old.

headline: In the Orbit of Sancerre
text: EVERYBODY knows Sancerre. That’s a problem among some in the wine avant-garde, for whom familiarity breeds contempt. I have heard Sancerre sneered at as a sort of comfort food, signaling timidity in a cliquish world that sizes up personality and status by choice of beverage.

headline: Wisconsin Is Sued Over Dogs in Wolf Hunts
text: The wildlife agency in Wisconsin, the only state that allows people to use dogs while hunting wolves, faces a lawsuit contending that it is permitting state-sanctioned animal fighting.

headline: Sisters of Summer | Haim
text: The Los Angeles sisters Alana, Este and Danielle Haim, of the girl group Haim, started their musical careers in a band with their parents. “We did covers of KEarth 101 songs, bands like the Eagles, Billy Joel and Santana,” explains Danielle, 23, the middle sister. It wasn’t until years later — Aug. 7, 2007, to be exact — that Danielle, her younger sister, Alana, now 20, and her older sister, Este, now 26, played their first show sans their parents. After taking a break to finish high school (Alana), finish college (Este) and tour with Jenny Lewis and Julian Casablancas (Danielle), the girls of Haim are now releasing demos, and their summer anthem “Forever” landed them on tour with Mumford & Sons. Here are Haim’s picks for their favorite jams of the season:

headline: Varied, Colorful Elements, United in Performance
text: There seem to be odd little pockets of convergence in the musical cosmos. One involves the pianist Garrick Ohlsson, the composer Luciano Berio and Beethoven’s “Emperor” Concerto. The last time I heard Mr. Ohlsson play the “Emperor” was with the Philadelphia Orchestra in 1993, in a program with “Epiphanies,” a major work by Berio: a concert that because of a cancellation ended up also being conducted by Berio.

headline: Pronks for the Memory: Rendering Luxury
text: WASHINGTON — Still-life painting bloomed as never before in the Netherlands in the 17th century, and among its most vibrant and coveted blossoms were those of Willem van Aelst (1627-83). He is the subject of “Elegance and Refinement: The Still-Life Paintings of Willem van Aelst,” a small, intense exhibition of 28 paintings at the National Gallery of Art here.

headline: The Rewards of Patience
text: IN the darkest days of the housing crisis, paralysis was the word of the day. Even in the rarefied world of high-end New York real estate, developers and buyers alike had to put their dreams on hold, at least for a while.

headline: The First Goal in the U.S. Victory in the Women’s Olympic Soccer Final
text: The U.S. women’s soccer team scored the first of its two goals in the eighth minute of its gold-medal-winning match against Japan.

headline: Even in Death a Choreographer Is Mixing Art and Technology
text: Throughout his life Merce Cunningham came up with new ways to blend art and technology. He changed the way we think about space and time onstage, he explored dance on film before just about anyone else, and long before James Cameron and Hollywood made motion-capture cool, he was using three-dimensional computer animation to choreograph. Now, three years after his death in 2009, Cunningham is again at the vanguard. On Friday the Aperture Foundation is to introduce its first interactive application for the iPad, “Merce Cunningham: 65 Years.”

headline: The Market Is Speaking. It Says $95 Million.
text: IT’S as if 50 Central Park South had laid down a challenge to 15 Central Park West and any other building that believes its apartments can command sky-high prices.

headline: Comedy Listings for Aug. 10-16
text: Comedy

headline: A Universe Like Ours, Only Weirder
text: Not all filmmakers create complete and resonant fantasy worlds, rife with strange, sometimes frightening beings as well as mysterious movement, emotional suspense and uncanny detail. Fewer still are honored with extensive museum retrospectives that do these worlds full immersive justice, allowing devotees and neophytes alike to grasp the essence of their achievement and its evolution, strengths and weaknesses all.

headline: 3 Guests, 48 Hours, Constant Agita
text: At the opening of her photography show, Marion, the high-strung heroine of “2 Days in New York,” has an awkward encounter with a critic. Frustrated by his poker face and his noncommittal responses, and stressed out by everything else going on in her life (about which more shortly), Marion launches into an unhinged, obscene tirade at the poor man. Later in the film a karmically empowered pigeon drops an airborne excretory insult on him. Since Marion is played by the director of the film, Julie Delpy, I will take this as a warning.

headline: Movie Listings for Aug. 10-16
text: Movies

headline: Pop Listings for Aug. 10-16
text: Pop

headline: Jazz Listings for Aug. 10-16
text: Jazz

headline: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Aug. 10-16
text: Classical

headline: Romney’s Bus Tour Gets Some Unwanted Company
text: Mitt Romney is about to get some unwanted company on his upcoming bus tour across several swing states.

headline: The Hamptons Without the Hubris
text: How to take the roads less traveled to a different Hamptons, far from the manicured landscapes, mansions and beach crowds.

headline: Romney’s Running Mate? Some Say Wikipedia Holds the Answer
text: Who could be Mitt Romney’s choice for vice-presidential nominee?

headline: U.S. and Gulf Allies Pursue a Missile Shield Against Iranian Attack
text: Thom Shanker reports in today’s paper about an effort to knit together a “regional missile defense system across the Persian Gulf to protect cities, oil refineries, pipelines and military bases from an Iranian attack.” The shield is meant to be a pointed message to Tehran.

headline: The Quay Brothers at MoMA
text: A new exhibition explores the puppet-centered universes created by the experimental animators known as the Quay Brothers.

headline: Even in Car-Buying Behavior, New Yorkers Are Exceptional
text: As a New Orleans-style funeral march for a 1982 Honda Civic illustrated last weekend, New Yorkers share at times perplexing relationships with their automobiles. It only follows, then, that buying behaviors of the city’s residents would be somewhat out of step with those of buyers outside the five boroughs and its suburbs.

headline: Dance Listings for Aug. 10-16
text: Dance

headline: Closing Fees Ease Up
text: FOR some people, a major hurdle to homeownership is the closing costs that come on top of the required down payment. There are fees for everything from title searches to deed recordings, and if you happen to be buying in New York or New Jersey, you’ll find some of the highest costs in the country.

headline: A Naturalist’s Notes on London; Bettie Page Photos
text: PHILADELPHIA — Scholars have spent months poring through scribbles on a 1739 history of London that recently arrived at the Library Company, a research center here founded in 1731. The book belonged to Peter Collinson, a British cloth merchant and naturalist who was a close friend of Benjamin Franklin’s and a major importer of American plants.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Aug. 10-16
text: Art

headline: A Pin-Up Archive Unveiled
text: A cache of vintage stills by the octogenarian photographer Bunny Yeager is going on sale, including many photos of the pin-up queen Bettie Page.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 10-16
text: ‘PRESERVATION DETECTIVES’

headline: Spare Times for Aug. 10-16
text: Around Town

headline: Restored River a Boon to Yonkers
text: IN large part as a result of the ongoing city-and-state-funded effort to “daylight” the Saw Mill River, developers in Yonkers have been able to forge ahead on various real estate projects relatively unaffected by the economic malaise thwarting new construction elsewhere.

headline: Beachfront, With Cessna Parking
text: WHEN a 37-acre tract in Montauk landed on the market at $18 million two weeks ago, it may have lent the term “sky-high real estate” another layer of meaning. The land in question is the home of the local airport, a privately held property with a 3,200-foot runway, a taxiway, six hangars, and a small terminal with two restrooms and two showers.

headline: A Giveaway to Feel Good
text: Trojan took a promotion for its vibrators to Chelsea.

headline: Trapped in a Jungle and a State of Mind
text: Marcel Proust opened “Swann’s Way,” in 1913, with reflections that occurred at the edge of sleep. Almost 20 years earlier Joseph Conrad had kicked off his first novel, “Almayer’s Folly,” with a rude awakening from a daydream. Both writers have inspired the Belgian filmmaker Chantal Akerman to make free adaptations: “La Captive,” her sensual, mesmerizing 2000 film (based on Proust’s “Prisonnière”) and now “Almayer’s Folly” (“La Folie Almayer”), a tropical study in helpless intransigence, from Conrad’s often overlooked debut.

headline: Rare Matinee, and an Even Rarer Mets Home Win
text: As the Mets walked back to their clubhouse at Citi Field on Thursday, a day of work complete, they heard a rather unfamiliar noise: cheers.

headline: Manchester United Prices I.P.O. at $14 a Share
text: 9:52 p.m. | Updated

headline: For Taller Sand Castles, the Secret Is Less Water
text: A group of physicists say they have figured out how to build taller, thinner sand castles: by mixing 99 parts sand with only 1 part water.

headline: Islamists in North Mali Amputate Man’s Hand
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Islamists who control northern Mali have publicly amputated the hand of a man they accused of robbery, continuing an increasingly harsh application of what the vast region’s new masters consider sacred law.

headline: ‘Best Of’ Lists for the Lifestyle Crowd
text: Edgewater

headline: The Victims of the Shooting in Wisconsin
text: Six people were killed when a gunman opened fire at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin. Learn more about the victims.

headline: In Real Estate Deal, Romney Made His Loss a Couple’s Gain
text: MISSOURI CITY, Tex. — Look closely and it is there, sandwiched between Goldman Sachs Hedge Fund Partners II and D3 Family Bulldog Fund: the mortgage on Timothy and Betty Stamps’s modest home on Gentle Bend Drive here.

headline: First Recession, Then Crime and Fear
text: DUBLIN — A woman’s cries for help pierced the sunny afternoon, alerting me that something was wrong — though what wasn’t immediately clear. This was Blackrock, after all, a posh Dublin suburb of tended lawns and expensive houses sheltered behind stone walls lining narrow lanes. But Marie was lying on a sidewalk where seconds earlier, a man had sprayed mace in her eyes, shoved her into a spiky hedge and grabbed her purse, she said, crying in shock.

headline: Q&A
text: Helping a Relative Rent an Apartment

headline: To Save Water, Limiting Summer Soakings to Two-Minute Bursts
text: It was hot out on Thursday at the Glendale Playground in Queens, but the weather did not deter Nazar Nemy, 9, and two friends from doing some heavy lifting on the way to the playground’s overhead sprinklers.

headline: No Need to Get Your Top Hat Wet
text: THE big iron and glass marquee is not just shelter, it’s like white tie and tails. Step under one, and the sunlight falling through the glass makes you stand taller, live higher, dance better. Very few have survived, but each one is a treat nearly unique to New York City.

headline: Hard to Have Dreams if Mom’s a Nightmare
text: If the aimless characters in “Goats” didn’t feel so uncomfortably lifelike, it would be tempting to heap scorn on this wispy screen adaptation of Mark Jude Poirier’s 2001 novel, directed by Christopher Neil from a screenplay by Mr. Poirier. The story is narrated by a 15-year-old named Ellis Whitman (Graham Phillips), a latter-day Holden Caulfield, without the quirks and the pathos, who lives with his nightmarish mother, Wendy (Vera Farmiga), on the outskirts of Tucson.

headline: Suspect Sought in Shooting of Police Sergeant
text: The New York City police on Thursday released the name and a photo of the man being sought in the shooting of a sergeant during a pursuit in Queens.

headline: French President Shuts Down Roma Camps and Seeks Relocation for Roma
text: PARIS — Despite criticism from Roma support groups and leftist politicians, President François Hollande’s Socialist government, following a policy adopted by his predecessor, Nicolas Sarkozy, is dismantling illegal travelers’ camps and rounding up Roma from Eastern Europe for repatriation.

headline: Yahoo’s Chief Reviews Plan for Alibaba Proceeds
text: Marissa Mayer, Yahoo’s newly minted chief executive, is reworking the company’s playbook and nothing seems off limits.

headline: For U.S. College Applicants, Extra Activities Are Encouraged
text: Students interested in attending an American university should know that admissions officers will base their decisions on more than just good grades and high test scores. They want to know how a student might enhance the university just by being there. A good indicator is an examination of personal interests, often illustrated by extracurricular activities.

headline: Not Quite ‘Swan Lake,’ but Surprisingly Close
text: If you’re not a horse person, dressage is an odd event indeed. Horse and rider carry out carefully choreographed movements, often to music, in a formal manner, with their performance evaluated on tiny points of precision, line, apparent ease of execution and musicality. Then again, if you’re not a dance person, you could say almost exactly the same thing about ballet — a strange ritual involving carefully choreographed movements, often to music, in a formal manner, with performance evaluated on tiny points of precision, apparent ease of execution and musicality.

headline: Amgen, Citing Weak Results, Halts Study of a Cancer Drug
text: Amgen is halting a late-stage clinical trial of an experimental drug for pancreatic cancer after an outside monitoring panel concluded that the drug was unlikely to improve the survival of patients with an advanced form of the disease.

headline: Health Insurer Refunds May Stall in Employers’ Hands
text: It was the great health insurance giveback: $1.1 billion in premiums returned to policyholders under the Affordable Care Act. But while many people who buy their own insurance found a check in the mail last week, millions insured through employers are still wondering what is happening with the money.

headline: In a City Known for Its Shoes, Water Up to Its Knees
text: MARIKINA, the Philippines — Marikina is famed for its cobblers, whose handmade shoes are a source of local pride. Its Shoe Museum is home to a pair of shoes from each president of the Philippines, including 800 of the more than 3,000 pairs in the collection of Imelda R. Marcos. A barge in the Marikina River sports statues of two giant shoes, and what the city fathers claim is the world’s largest functional shoe — more than 15 feet long — is on display in a local mall.

headline: Girardi Loses His Cool, but Yankees Win the Game
text: DETROIT — Frustrations boiled over in dramatic fashion Thursday as Yankees Manager Joe Girardi — veins bulging in his neck, and arms gyrating over his head — screamed and stomped and threw his hat, gesturing emphatically to the crowd as he stormed off the field.

headline: A ‘Painting Marathon’ at Beach Volleyball
text: LONDON — Pop music blared as women in bikinis danced around in celebration and drunken fans continued chanting. But Peter Spens was focused on his selection of brush, color and perspective.

headline: For a Zealous Cop and a Gang of Two-Bit Thieves, Crime Does Not Pay
text: In the late ’60s and early ’70s, on television and at the movies, the streets were full of complicated cops: big-city detectives whose confusion, frustration and unorthodox methods reflected a general crisis of authority in the societies they served. Popeye Doyle, Dirty Harry Callahan and Frank Serpico (at least as imagined by Al Pacino and Sidney Lumet) made common existential cause with small-screen counterparts like Kojak and Columbo. Max, the sad, obsessive Parisian flic at the heart of Claude Sautet’s “Max et les Ferrailleurs,” is an especially memorable addition to this international brotherhood of disaffected policemen, even if his contributions have, until now, been largely forgotten.

headline: Political Disagreement, Revisited
text: I was delighted by both the number and the quality of responses to my post last week about political disagreement.  Here I’ll try to rethink the issue in light of the many good ideas put forward by readers.  (And apologies to all those whose excellent comments I haven’t been able to mention here.)

headline: Big-Hitting Woodland Looks Comfortable on Ocean Course
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — Gary Woodland, one of the PGA Tour’s longest hitters, used his length to his advantage and posted 5-under 67 in the first round of the P.G.A. Championship. That score put him in a four-way tie for second place, one shot behind Carl Pettersson.

headline: Russia: Activist Fined Under New Law
text: A Moscow court on Thursday ordered a political opposition leader to pay a $380 fine for organizing an unsanctioned demonstration. It is one of the first punishments to be levied under a tough law adopted in June to clamp down on street protests. The activist, Eduard Limonov, who organized a protest without a permit in July to support the freedom of assembly, had faced the possibility of an even larger fine under the new guidelines. Mr. Limonov said he already owed nearly $17,000 from previous verdicts. “I earn less and less every day,” he said. “So I will not pay the $380 just like I did not pay the $16,880.”

headline: Mexico: Drug Suspect Extradited to U.S.
text: Sandra Ávila Beltrán, who is accused of being a drug trafficker and is known as the Queen of the Pacific, was extradited to the United States on Thursday to face cocaine-smuggling charges filed in a United States District Court in Florida. In 2007, Ms. Ávila’s arrest in Mexico City on charges stemming from the 2001 seizure of nine tons of cocaine from a boat in the Mexican port of Manzanillo caused a stir because she was the first woman to be charged as the leader of an international drug-smuggling operation. She was acquitted of the Mexican charges at the end of 2010 and had been fighting extradition.

headline: Little Camaraderie, Plenty of Crashes at BMX Races
text: LONDON — Given the carnage on display Thursday, it is safe to assume that whoever designed the BMX racetrack really dislikes BMX racers. Or has no regard for their safety. Or kind of enjoys watching them crash.

headline: Deal Making in Hong Kong, Distracted by Debauchery
text: Dry as new bank notes and doggedly uncinematic, Simon Yin’s “$upercapitalist” approaches the seamy side of international finance with a story as stale as the subprime meltdown.

headline: Britain: Judge Is Picked to Lead Inquest Into Death of Former K.G.B. Officer
text: Judicial authorities said Thursday that they had taken the unusual step of appointing a senior judge to hold a long-planned inquest into the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer poisoned in London in 2006 with a rare radioactive isotope, polonium 210. The case soured relations between Britain and Russia, and the new development may put at risk recent improvements. At British inquests, judges replace coroners only in the most high-profile cases, like the inquiry into the death of Princess Diana. The hearings to be overseen by the judge, Sir Robert Owen, could provide the first opportunity in the case for witnesses to testify under oath. A procedural hearing is to be held next month. British prosecutors have accused another former K.G.B. officer, Andrei K. Lugovoi, of Mr. Litvinenko’s poisoning — a charge he denies — and are seeking his extradition, which Russia has refused. Mr. Litvinenko, who fled Russia in 2000, had secured British citizenship shortly before he died, and he accused Russia’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin, of responsibility for his poisoning.

headline: Faster, Higher, Stronger: Day of Golden Drama
text: LONDON — The world’s fastest man and the world’s greatest half-miler ran past the finish line and into the history books. Wembley, the iconic stadium, bulged with 80,203 fans for women’s soccer as the United States found redemption against Japan. Ireland won its first gold medal in 16 years as women’s boxing crowned its inaugural Olympic champions. And a friendly debate ensued about exactly who was the world’s greatest athlete.

headline: Among Readers in Polyglot New York, 50 Shades of Best Sellers
text: The Chinese immigrants in Flushing, Queens, devour books with titles like “Romantic Flower” and “The Heart With a Million Knots.” The Russian women in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, clamor for a diet guide advocating plenty of meat. In Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a bookseller cannot keep a tell-all by the wife of an adored Polish politician on the shelves.

headline: If Guns Do Not Kill, Tax the Bullets
text: In 1993, a United States senator with one of the great political brains of 20th-century America, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, said that we ought to forget gun control as a way to stanch criminal violence. It was hopeless, Senator Moynihan pointed out: even if the sale of new guns was totally forbidden, there were already enough guns in homes and private hands to last the country for 200 years.

headline: Reflections on the Holocaust and a Survivor Who Defied Nazis
text: Barely 60 minutes long, the Holocaust documentary “The Lion of Judah” feels less like a feature film than a well-executed school project pulling together certain required elements: travel footage, reaction interviews, archival background and licks of music. The director Matt Mindell divides time between reporting on his tour of the Warsaw Ghetto and camps (Majdanek, Auschwitz, Terezin) with a group, and ceding the stage to an 81-year-old survivor, Leo Zisman, who recounts to visitors his experiences facing down Nazis.

headline: Theodor Herzl, a Life From Journalism to Zionism
text: Bland is a word you probably don’t associate with either the history of Zionism or Theodor Herzl. But the documentary “It Is No Dream: The Life of Theodor Herzl,” directed by Richard Trank, manages to be almost boldly dull. A production of Moriah Films, a division of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, “It Is No Dream” satisfies neither as a movie nor as a history lesson.

headline: Daly, Still Fan Favorite, Is in Hunt in the P.G.A.
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — John Daly is 46 now, with a face that is growing leathery and a sluggish gait slowed all the more by the slightest limp. His shoulders sag, he has had lap-band surgery and he seems mildly embarrassed — and like something from another era — when he steps aside, turning his back to light a cigarette.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | The Runcible Spoon
text: Every weekend, the Runcible Spoon in Nyack, N.Y., turns into a buzzing social hub for New York City’s amateur cyclists.

headline: National Polls Show Clear Advantage for Obama Among Independents
text: In the all-important struggle for independent voters, President Obama is opening some daylight over his Republican rival.

headline: Guns, Butter and Then Some
text: Back in the administration of W., we looked for the weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. That was the wrong place; they’re here at home. Normally the W.M.D. I write about is the Standard American Diet (yes: SAD); occasionally I talk about food safety, or climate change, or related topics. But no matter what you look at, the basic problem remains so-called leadership that cannot stand up to big ag, big food, big energy, Wall Street …or the N.R.A.

headline: DeAndre McCullough, Drug Dealer Who Inspired ‘The Corner,’ Dies at 35
text: DeAndre McCullough, whose experiences as a 15-year-old drug dealer in Baltimore inspired the writer David Simon and the former police officer Edward Burns to feature him in the book “The Corner: A Year in the Life of an Inner City Neighborhood,” which became an Emmy-winning mini-series on HBO, was found dead on Aug. 1 in Woodlawn, Md. He was 35.

headline: In the Shadow of Assad’s Bombs
text: Saraqib, Syria

headline: Mr. King’s English-Only Bill
text: Bills that seek to make English the official language of the United States never go anywhere, but there’s at least one proposed in every Congressional session, invariably put forth by Republicans to appeal to nostalgia for a mythical past. The latest is sponsored by Representative Steve King of Iowa, one of the most ardent restrictionists in Washington, whose other hard-line bills included one to build an electrified border fence (which he designed and once demonstrated on the floor of the House).

headline: For Football Fans, the Focus Is on Monday
text: ESPN on Monday will introduce a new multimedia advertising campaign for its marquee program, “Monday Night Football.”

headline: Rights for Domestic Workers
text: The California Legislature is considering a bill to extend basic labor rights to domestic workers: the nannies, cooks, baby sitters and other caregivers whose labor allows households to function smoothly, thus contributing to the larger economy. Domestic workers toil long hours for low pay, but have long been excluded from many of the fundamental protections most other workers enjoy under federal labor law.

headline: At Hearing, Customers Complain of Unfair and Inaccurate Water Bills
text: A woman from Queens said her quarterly water bill jumped by more than $500. A small-business owner said his bill for the quarter rose to $10,000 from about $1,000.

headline: Where Cyclists Fuel Up on Carbs
text: MEMBERS of this particular brunch crowd do not exactly meet at noon for mimosas and omelets.

headline: Riling Up the ‘Shrewd, Wild Boys’
text: Today we would consider Edmund Keyser, who kept a saloon in Philadelphia during the 1860s, a compulsive gambler. But at the time he was known as a “sporting man.” Keyser enjoyed all of the era’s brutal entertainments. He bet on bare-knuckle boxing. He bet on rat-baiting. He played the horses. And come October of each election year, he would scrawl “busy canvassing” in his meticulous wager book and entertain himself hustling for the Democratic Party.

headline: Sudan and South Sudan Make Progress
text: Sudan and South Sudan ended a dangerous stalemate when they finally reached an agreement on oil pipeline fees last week. The elements of the deal should be carried out as quickly as possible given the severe financial stress on both nations.

headline: Accuracy in Criminal Background Checks
text: For far too long, the federal government has neglected its responsibility for regulating the companies that provide criminal background checks used by 9 in 10 companies to screen job applicants. The damage done to job seekers by flawed and unreliable data — a common problem with such services — can be devastating.

headline: Hear, All Ye People; Hearken, O Earth (Part 2)
text: This is the second installment in a two-part series.

headline: Male Couples Face Pressure to Fill Cradles
text: WASHINGTON — When the jubilant couple were wed in June, they exchanged personalized vows and titanium rings, cheered the heartfelt toasts and danced themselves breathless. Then, as the evening was winding down, unexpected questions started popping up.

headline: Interview: Martin E. Segal
text: An interview with Martin E. Segal conducted by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: Striking a Blow for Ireland
text: BRAY, Ireland — For the Irish, Katie Taylor is more than a great athlete sprung from the native soil; people speak of her as if she has sprung from themselves, for she seems everyone’s sister, their daughter, their friend. She is the epitome of the strong-willed Irish lass. She has known what she wants out of life: a gold medal in boxing. And she has gone for it.

headline: Romney’s Side Course of Culture
text: When Mitt Romney asserted last week that “culture does matter,” he settled into a pose that was more triumphalist than anthropologist. Romney had begun by asserting that culture explained the difference in G.D.P. between Israel and the Palestinian Authority, but soon he was claiming that culture also made the United States “the greatest economic power in the history of the earth.”  His attempt to define American culture settled in on vague attributes like “patriotism,” “family orientation,” “honor and oath” and “freedom,” a list that seemed cribbed from Ron Swanson’s Pyramid of Greatness.

headline: What Should Be Eliminated From the Olympics?
text: The case for paring down the Games: no more tennis, a lot less swimming, no mismanaged boxing, and an end to sailing.

headline: How to Make Congress Do Its Job: No Budget, No Pay
text: To the Editor:

headline: AIDS in Uganda: Prevention Is Better Than Treatment
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fighting Web Piracy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Victims of Military Hazing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Times Photographer’s Arrest
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Campaign to Digitize Your Wallet Is Intensifying
text: This week, Starbucks joined forces with Square, a technology start-up that lets you pay for things with a smartphone. Coming from a company whose cafes seem to be on every corner, that’s a powerful endorsement. Does that mean your phone will soon replace your wallet?

headline: New Patterns in the Urban Fabric
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
Regulator Shines a Spotlight on a Bank, and on Himself
text: On the evening before Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York’s top banking regulator, issued highly charged money laundering claims against a British bank, he spoke with the Manhattan district attorney.

headline: Merging Spirituality and Clinical Psychology at Columbia
text: The psychology graduate student ran a wooden stick across the edge of a Tibetan Buddhist singing bowl on Tuesday and asked the five homeless young men sitting in front of him to listen to the undulating sound, and to raise their hands when they could no longer hear it. One by one hands went up, until well after the sound had seemed to dissipate.

headline: Weaving a Grandmother’s Wisdom Into a Meditative Piece
text: In 2001 Erin Leddy lived with her grandmother Sarah Braveman and recorded some 20 hours of interviews about the older woman’s life, philosophy and physical deterioration. In “My Mind Is Like an Open Meadow,” her hourlong solo piece, Ms. Leddy replays and interacts with the remixed audio, which streams from speakers on and around the stage.

headline: A Witch, a Wish and Fairy Tale Agony
text: The fairy tale forest of “Into the Woods” has suddenly grown a lot thicker. This 1987 musical by Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine, which stirs up the shadows of classic bedtime stories, was never what you’d call uncrowded. But Timothy Sheader’s overreaching revival, which opened on Thursday night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, has added a whole new bramble of interpretive undergrowth.

headline: Provider of Punch at Brunch

headline: Crime Wave Engulfs Syria as Its Cities Reel From War

But in the background, many Syrians describe something else that has them cowering with fear: a wave of lawlessness not unlike the crime wave Iraq experienced during the conflict there.

headline: Obama Drawing Big Crowds, but Not Like in ’08

headline: Ruggiero Ricci Dies at 94; Prodigy Whose Violin Mastery Grew
text: Ruggiero Ricci, a virtuoso violinist who first awed audiences at age 10 with his mastery of Mendelssohn and later remade himself into a mature musician whose range reached from the 19th-century acrobatics of Paganini’s Caprices to premiere performances of contemporary works, died on Sunday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 94.

headline: The Search for Energy Takes a Turn Underwater
text: EASTPORT, Me. — The fearsome tides that sweep out from the easternmost shores of the United States have for more than 80 years teased engineers and presidents like Franklin D. Roosevelt, who have dreamed of harnessing their force to make electricity.

headline: Ben Heineman, Multifaceted Businessman, Dies at 98
text: Ben W. Heineman, a lawyer and corporate leader who took over railroads, created one of the nation’s first conglomerates and became a close confidant and adviser to President Lyndon B. Johnson, died on Sunday in Waukesha, Wis. He was 98.

headline: Komen’s Leadership Changes Are Met With Skepticism
text: Leadership changes at the Susan G. Komen Foundation for the Cure  six months after an online uproar over a decision to cut funds for breast cancer screenings at Planned Parenthood was greeted with skepticism on Thursday among breast cancer advocates and longtime former supporters.

headline: Fourth Time Brings Title for United States
text: LONDON — Thrice before, gold medals were awarded in women’s water polo, and each time the United States team was on the podium but not atop it. The bridesmaid routine was wearing thinner than a wedding veil for Brenda Villa and Heather Petri, the two holdovers from the inaugural Olympic squad from 2000.

headline: After Deadly Shooting at Sikh Temple, Neighbors Turn Out to Work for Tolerance
text: OAK CREEK, Wis. — After the sadness and shock, members of Wisconsin’s insular Sikh community found themselves confronting scenes they never would have expected. There were outpourings of support, including a gathering of hundreds of people of different faiths and skin colors, some holding candles, others wearing white head scarves, in a gesture of solidarity with this predominantly Indian religion.

His wrenching story of 23 days without a court hearing became the plot of Dave Eggers’s book “Zeitoun,” and turned him into a New Orleans hero.

headline: C.D.C. Reports Sudden Rise in Mild Cases of Swine Flu
text: The number of people reported to have swine flu has risen sharply in the last week, federal health officials said Thursday, but they are not calling the increase a pandemic because there is no evidence of transmission between humans. So far, all the reported cases have been relatively mild, and have passed to humans through direct contact with pigs.

headline: Hyderabad’s Charm Found in Ramadan Delights

And the month of Ramadan is ideal for discovering the city’s most indulgent dishes.

headline: The Secrets of Hissing Trees
text: Three years ago, a researcher collecting tree core samples in Connecticut was startled to see one of the trees begin to hiss and spit. Even more surprising, he found that the leaking gas could be set on fire.

headline: Daily Report: The Campaign for Mobile Payments Intensifies

headline: 10 Animated GIFs From London 2012
text: London 2012 has been talked about as being the most social of Olympics. Hundreds of athletes are on Twitter, as are our reporters. But animated GIFs are also having their moment at these Games. Once the social pariah of bad Web site design, they have seen a resurgence over the last few years, becoming trendy, much like the way hipsters made facial hair fashionable. And like those full beards and handlebar mustaches, they have a tendency to be rather ugly. But best yet, they can’t be beat for being silly and novel. The Washington Post has a nice summary of them. The Atlantic has been king among Olympics animated GIF guides. And Storify has this post on the animated GIFs of London 2012.

headline: South Korean’s Visit to Disputed Islets Angers Japan

headline: Aug. 12 — 18
text: LONGTIME admirers of the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright HORTON FOOTE, who died in 2009, probably feel they know Harrison, Tex., almost as well as they know their own hometowns. headline: Trying to Be Stars, Like the ‘Jersey Boys’ They Portrayed
text: STRUTTING across the stage in red silk jackets, the quartet belted out vintage tunes like “Breaking Up Is Hard to Do,” “Sherry” and “Happy Together.” Two middle-aged women giggled, then shouted, “Those are Temptations moves!” Sidling up to the microphone, rolling their hands, the singers had the air of the Rat Pack, Motown and a nightclub act rolled into one. Between numbers they recounted favorite memories from the past few years, like singing “Oh What a Night” with Dick Clark in Times Square on New Year’s Eve.

headline: Are You Worth More Dead Than Alive?
text: ‘Do you see lights?” Ruben Robles asked his brother, Mark, in 2007. Bright, star-shaped and white, they flashed before Ruben’s eyes while he was driving, shopping at Costco, feeding the cats. Mark didn’t see anything, so Robles went to a doctor, who thought that the visions might be stress-induced. Robles ran a collection agency in Los Angeles, and the hours were long, the debtors argumentative. Several weeks later, Ruben began suffering seizures. He went to see another doctor, and this one ordered an M.R.I., which revealed a ghostly white orb on his left frontal lobe. The diagnosis was brain cancer. Only 36 years old, Ruben was told that he might not live to see his 38th birthday.

headline: The New Net Worth

headline: Last Bites
text: On Friday afternoons, my father-in-law, Howard Jack Malach, would leave work early and drive across town to Grodzinski, a kosher bakery, before it closed for Shabbat, all for the sake of the babka. Yes, there were closer bakeries with their own babkas in this corner of Toronto’s Jewish suburbs, but to Howard, Grodzinski’s babka was king — a dense, perfectly moist loaf with veins of dark, sugary chocolate. At home, Howard would set it on the counter (where his wife, Fran, would inevitably tear a chunk off), slicing the loaf for the kids at the end of dinner. The next morning, he’d reheat the leftovers until the chocolate melted, then dunk sticky slices into his coffee.

headline: If the Sikh Temple Had Been a Mosque

The fact that the Democratic candidate had been a prominent and visible member of a Protestant church in Chicago for years somehow mattered not at all. The Obama campaign even created a Web site wholly devoted to answering conspiracy theories and smears.

headline: Laid Off More Than Once, and Seeking a Career

headline: Children’s Apps That Inject a Little Learning Into Vacation

headline: The Get | Asprey’s Wiltshire Clutch
text: The London designer Katie Hillier virtually eats, breathes and sleeps accessories working at the helm of her fine jewelry line, Hillier, and as a consultant for Marc by Marc Jacobs and Victoria Beckham. Most recently she’s designed a 10-piece collection of handbags in collaboration with the British heritage brand Asprey (prices starting at $1,200). “I didn’t want to reinvent the wheel,” says Hillier, who studied up on Asprey classics like the Belgravia Darcy bag and the Mayfair clutch before putting pen to paper on the designs. “There are so many wonderful Asprey bags that are just perfect as they are,” she explains. So instead of updating or reinterpreting those, Hillier turned to archival gentlemen’s document holders for inspiration. Warm, sybaritic shades of sapphire, hazel and shiny licorice make the bags feel especially luxurious and modern. “For the palette I was very inspired by a walk through the woods in autumn,” Hillier says. A standout: this accordion clutch in bramble crocodile, part of the Wiltshire group that also features shoulder bags in skins like ostrich and python.

headline: Memorial Service for Victims of the Sikh Temple Shooting
text: Last Updated, 7:53 p.m. Thousands of mourners from around the world crowded into a gymnasium at Oak Creek High School in Oak Creek, Wis. to attend a wake and a memorial service for the six worshipers who were shot and killed on Sunday at the Sikh Temple of Wisconsin in suburban Milwaukee.

headline: Blackmail Cited as Motive in a Killing That Shook China

text: Janmashtami, which marks the birth of Lord Krishna, celebrated in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh.

headline: After a Part in Poe’s ‘Raven,’ the Dust of Obscurity
text: One hundred and sixty-eight bleak Decembers ago or thereabouts, Edgar Allan Poe sat before a fireplace in a farmhouse on a high bluff on what would someday be called the Upper West Side, composing a poem.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: '2 Days in New York'
text: Julie Delpy, the director of "2 Days in New York," narrates a scene from her film.

headline: Swift Rescue in U.S. Provides Lessons for Europe
text: Lee Sachs, chief executive of Alliance Partners, is former counselor to the secretary of the Treasury and was head of the financial crisis response team in the Obama administration.

headline: Live: Spain Defeats Russia to Advance to Basketball Final
text: The first time around, Spain’s men’s basketball team didn’t take Russia as seriously as it should have in the London Olympics. Russia won, 77-74, in group play.

headline: David Rakoff, 47, Comic Essayist, Dies
text: David Rakoff, a prizewinning humorist whose mordant, neurotic essays examined everything from his surreal stint portraying Sigmund Freud in a Christmastime shop window display to his all-too-real battles with cancer, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 47.

headline: How to Tune Out the Euro Crisis
text: Each year, I retire to our Russian dacha for as many days as we can manage, to savor the quiet, soak up the sun and the simpler life, albeit one complicated by a lack of running water, occasional power outages and a wide variety of insects ready to inflict irritation. As I write in my latest column, the dacha is much more than a place; it is a mindset, and a keepstone, “our” spot on this Earth where very little changes each year, where the constancy of Russia bats back its equally eternal uncertainties.

headline: Hopes Spring Eternal
text: Americans have a curiously limited vision of France. We may be wild about Chanel sunglasses, Vuitton handbags, Champagne or Paris in the spring, but when it comes to the kinds of contemporary French culture that can’t be bought in a duty-free shop, most of us draw a blank. Luckily, this veil of benign ignorance is being lifted as publishers in the United States introduce American readers to a new generation of hugely gifted French writers who are reworking the boundaries of fiction, memoir and history (Emmanuel Carrère, Laurent Binet, the American-born Jonathan Littell) or of high art and snuff lit (Michel Houelle­becq). Among the recent crop of writers just reaching the top of their game, Marie NDiaye, born in 1967 and now living in Berlin, is pre-eminent.

headline: Starbucks Gets the Square
text: Square Chief Executive, Jack Dorsey and Starbucks Chief Executive Howard Schultz come together to bring Square's innovative payment system across the country and put the customer first.

headline: Unhappy All the Time
text: In 1999, the British novelist Rachel Cusk gave birth to a daughter and then, 15 months later, to a second one. Like women writers all over the planet, she realized motherhood was material. So she wrote a book, “A Life’s Work: On Becoming a Mother,” which came out in Britain in 2001, when her younger daughter was a year old.

headline: Bring It On
text: Fiction has not been kind to cheerleaders. Maybe this has something to do with the fact that future writers are more likely to be found scowling on the bleachers than doing back handsprings across the gymnasium floor. But now Megan Abbott has put her spirit fingers to the task of writing the Great American Cheerleader Novel, and — stop scowling — it’s spectacular.

headline: A Rugged Speaker for the Outdoors
text: In the world of portable speakers, simplicity is a big selling point. Their design has been streamlined by adding rechargeable internal batteries and removing cables in favor of streaming Bluetooth technology.

headline: This Old House
text: The problem is not that Dale Peck can’t write. Far from it. The problem is that Dale Peck can’t stop writing.

headline: A Campaign Staff Awaits the Unnamed No. 2
text: BOSTON — They say they have no idea whom they will be working for, but just as soon as Mitt Romney announces a running mate, 10 full-time staff members are ready to jump in to work for the No. 2.

headline: Reversal of Fortunes
text: Each of these books illuminates one particular economic story very well, but fails to see the larger and more complex picture.

headline: Streams of Consciousness
text: Around 1806, Britain’s most popular board game was introduced to the United States. Called the Mansion of Happiness, it — like the New Game of Human Life, a somewhat less thrilling predecessor — was based on the idea that life is a voyage in which travelers are buffeted between vice and virtue. In 1843 an American edition was issued. It quickly caught on, selling 4,000 copies in 10 months. The “mansion” in question was a heavenly one, the final destination for the pious. (“Be virtuous then and forward press, / To gain the seat of happiness,” the rules read.)

headline: Trading Places
text: Ever since the surge in crime that began in the 1960s, cosmopolitan Americans have been on a quest for urbanity, looking for a metropolitan culture that had been lost to social breakdown. They sought safety in the suburbs or in urban enclaves, but they were forced to give up the civic spaces, parks, boulevards and bustling street life that had made cities so stimulating in the past. Alan Ehrenhalt’s 1995 book, “The Lost City: Discovering the Forgotten Virtues of Community in the Chicago of the 1950s,” subtly evaluated all that had been forsaken.

headline: I Mean It
text: Things weren’t going well for sincerity even before Hallmark strip-mined it down to muck. Lionel Trilling pronounced it dead some 40 years ago. Snark and irony have long had more cultural cachet. Among its many pitfalls is that the more you seek or proclaim it, the less sincere you seem. (Only politicians have yet to get the message.) Another small problem: if people truly did say what was in their hearts on a regular basis, marriages would rupture, friendships would founder and no one would ever sit through a faculty meeting again.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: THE UNINVITED GUESTS  By Sadie Jones.  Harper/HarperCollins, $24.99.

headline: Lost in the Killing Fields
text: When a 7-year-old Cambodian girl named Raami first sets eyes on a member of the Khmer Rouge, clad in black pajamas and sandals made from rubber tires, she pretends he is a tevoda, an angel. “You must be Dark One!” she greets him, and pouts when he won’t join her game. She is shocked to learn that this shabby apparition is a revolutionary soldier, come to order the immediate evacuation of her family to the countryside, along with all the other residents of Phnom Penh. “This is a Khmer Rouge?” she thinks. “Where was the many-named larger-than-life deity I’d expected?”

headline: App for the Ancients
text: In her 2010 memoir, “The Butterfly Mosque,” G. Willow Wilson told the story of her conversion to Islam, charting her transformation from child of atheist parents to Boston University-­educated undergraduate to faithful Muslim with an Egyptian husband and an apartment in Cairo. Wilson wrote of the contrast between East and West, and of feeling compelled to keep her religious beliefs secret. “In the West,” she observed, “anything that must be hidden is suspect; availability and honesty are interlinked. This clashes irreconcilably with Islam, . . . where the things that are most precious, most perfect and most holy are always hidden: the Kaaba, the faces of prophets and angels, a woman’s body, Heaven.”

headline: The Witness
text: The Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs approached Claude Lanzmann in 1973 and suggested that, with Israel’s backing, he make a documentary film about the murder of the European Jews. Lanzmann was and is a French journalist, and his qualifications for undertaking such a project were obvious at a glance. He had spent many years producing copy for the glossy French magazine Elle and, then again, for mass-­readership newspapers. He sat on the editorial committee of Jean-Paul Sartre’s magazine Les Temps Modernes. He was handy with a film camera. Also, he had displayed an acute sympathy for the plight of the Israelis — a less-than-­universal trait even in those days.

headline: Crime and Punishment
text: In recent years, America has succumbed to a peculiar form of Shariah-phobia. According to this narrative, covert jihadis are working to usurp the law of the land and replace it with Islamic rule. A caliphate will rise on the ashes of the Constitution, Americans will be forced to pray in mosques and judges will mete out stonings and amputations. “Stealth jihadis use political, cultural, societal, religious, intellectual tools; violent jihadis use violence,” Newt Gingrich told the American Enterprise Institute in July 2010. “But in fact they’re both engaged in jihad, and they’re both seeking to impose the same end state, which is to replace Western civilization with a radical imposition of Shariah.” During the Republican presidential primaries, every candidate weighed in on the Shariah threat. In November 2010, Oklahoma voters approved a constitutional amendment banning the use of Islamic law in court. A federal appeals court blocked the amendment, but more than two dozen other states have considered legislation to restrict judges from consulting foreign and religious laws.

headline: N.B.A.’s New Market Begins to Take Shape
text: The N.B.A.’s collective bargaining agreement is a fascinating case study in subtlety and a masterwork of delayed repercussion. On the surface, the agreement has had little effect on the N.B.A. since its introduction last year. Players are still receiving lucrative multiyear contracts and owners have shown little restraint in offering similar deals to even the lesser tier of players. Yet the entire market for players has rotated, quietly altering its dynamic. The more things change, after all, the more they superficially appear to stay the same.

headline: A Very Bad Year
text: Out of a clear blue sky, amid a wave of terrorist bombings, a commercial airship crashes among the skyscrapers of the financial district, burning victims alive at their desks. But this catastrophe was not the work of Al Qaeda. It happened on July 21, 1919, when a stray spark ignited the 10,000 cubic feet of hydrogen in the Goodyear blimp Wingfoot Express as it floated above Chicago’s crowded Loop. With Twitteresque speed, sportswriters at Comiskey Park watching the Yankees play the soon-to-be-Black Sox began to telegraph the news across the country, even before the Wingfoot exploded through the skylight of the Illinois Trust and Savings Bank, killing more than a dozen people.

headline: Dead Again
text: Two decades ago, the Book Review ran an essay, “The End of Books,” in which the novelist Robert Coover questioned whether print could survive the age of “video transmissions, cellular phones, fax machines, computer networks, and in particular out in the humming digitalized precincts of avant-garde computer hackers, cyberpunks and hyperspace freaks.” Was the book as “dead as God”?

headline: It’s Alive!
text: By now, we’ve all heard the warnings: Humanity is under siege. Ever-encroaching communications technologies are replacing intimate connections. We prefer the companionship of Siri — the iPhone 4S’s temperamental personal assistant — to real-life interaction, and walk around with buds lodged in our ears, touchpads attached to our fingers and (soon, some say) neural chips embedded in our brains. In this cyborgian age, inanimate things take on a life of their own, endowed with properties that once upon a time distinguished people from things. They pulse with vitality, their beeps echo our touch and they feel melded to our bodies. The very nature of what it means to be human may be changing before our eyes.

headline: Up Front
text: In 1973, when Ron Powers was a 31-year-old columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times, he became the first TV critic to win a Pulitzer Prize. (Television had been pervasive for 25 years or so, which isn’t bad by Pulitzer standards; no car critic landed a prize until 2004.) Powers soon moved out of the newspaper world into broadcasting, where he won two Emmys (one local and one national), and then into books, where he has twice topped the New York Times best-seller list (for “True Compass,” written with Ted Kennedy, and “Flags of Our Fathers,” with James Bradley).

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: WHY DOES THE WORLD EXIST? AN EXISTENTIAL DETECTIVE STORY,  by Jim Holt. (Liveright/Norton, $27.95.) An elegant and witty writer converses with philosophers and cosmologists who ponder the question of why there is something rather than nothing.

headline: Genetic Study Finds Bullfrog Trade is Prime Pathway For Devastating Amphibian Fungus
text: A University of Michigan genetic analysis has found that the global trade in bullfrogs is a prime conduit for the chytrid fungus, which has been devastating amphibian populations around the world. The paper is being published in the journal Molecular Ecology [link is subscription only].

headline: Paperback Row
text: BLUEPRINTS FOR BUILDING BETTER GIRLS,  by Elissa Schappell. (Simon & Schuster, $15.) As in Schappell’s first book, “Use Me” (2000), these linked stories concern witty, caustic women operating in a post-1960s, post-Friedan cultural landscape. From reckless teenagers to rueful middle-aged mothers, Schappell agilely explores their vulnerabilities and the shifts in perspective that come with age and experience.

headline: Ironman Will Proceed After Hudson River Is Declared Safe
text: The Hudson River has been declared safe for swimmers, and the Ironman United States Championships will go on as scheduled Saturday.

headline: Tunisian Overcomes Illness to Win Open Water Event
text: LONDON — The afternoon before the men’s Olympic 10K open water event, Oussama Mellouli of Tunisia was undecided about being in it. He had a medal from the London Games, the bronze he earned Saturday night in the 1,500-meter freestyle, the longest pool event. In the days after that race, Mellouli came down with flulike symptoms.

headline: Growing Up Coltrane
text: In Sunday’s magazine, Zachary Woolfe profiles Ravi Coltrane, the jazz saxophonist, who has just released his first album for Blue Note Records, ‘‘Spirit Fiction.’’

headline: Romney at New Hampshire Debate
text: Mitt Romney responds to a question at the January 8, 2012 New Hampshire debate.

headline: Men’s Basketball Semifinals Preview: U.S. vs. Argentina
text: With a spot in the gold medal game at stake, here is a look at how Argentina and the United States are faring and where their semifinal matchup might be decided:
