text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Extremely Close Up at the Olympics
text: Jed Jacobsohn is on assignment for The New York Times, covering the Olympics in London. They are his seventh Olympics, beginning in 1996 in Atlanta. On Tuesday, he spoke from London with James Estrin. The interview has been edited.

headline: Fareed Zakaria Is Suspended After Admitting Plagiarism
text: The Indian-born American journalist Fareed Zakaria apologized on Friday for plagiarizing parts of a column on gun control in the Aug. 20 issue of Time magazine, Christine Haughney reported on the New York Times blog Media Decoder.

headline: The Weekend Word: Drought
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: What We're Watching on Day 16
text: Today we consider the unfamiliar horse. Victor Mather fills us in on this and some Olympic sports you may not know much about, including the modern pentathlon and race walking.

headline: Once Again Great, Britain Braces for an Olympics Hangover
text: LONDON — We Brits have been living an uncharacteristic two weeks of national euphoria over our glorious Olympic Games and now we’re shedding a collective tear that the party is almost over.

headline: What We’re Watching: An Unfamiliar Horse, of Course
text: (function($){var data = chameleonData;var ticker = new NYTD.NYTMM.NewsTicker($('#nytmm_embed_447'), data);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir:  A woman delivered a child in a taxi after being turned away by a gynecologist at a government hospital in the Ganderbal district of Kashmir, Kashmir Live reported. State officials will investigate this apparent case of medical negligence, the newspaper wrote.

headline: Mitt Romney Names Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin as His Running Mate
text: Mr. Romney, the Republican candidate for president, announced his selection of Mr. Ryan via his vice presidential app on Saturday morning.

headline: Romney Chooses Ryan, Pushing Fiscal Issues to the Forefront
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney introduced Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin as his running mate on Saturday at a spirited rally in Norfolk, Va., bringing to his side one of the party’s young conservative leaders in a move that altered the contours of the campaign and sharpened the choice facing the voters in November.

headline: Milestones: Paul Ryan
text: Paul Ryan, a rising star in the Republican Party and a favorite among conservatives who view him as deeply committed to their fiscal principles, has spent nearly his entire career in Washington.

headline: Live Updates: Romney Chooses Paul Ryan as Running Mate
text: Mitt Romney introduced Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin as his running mate Saturday morning in Norfolk, Va., the beginning of their bus tour through battleground states. The Times is providing live updates and analysis.

headline: Risky Ryan
text: Until this morning, Mitt Romney was running a campaign of extreme caution, in which he seemed intent on making it as hard as possible for voters—and Democrats—to pin down how he would really govern, which tough choices he’d be prepared to make.

headline: Mitt Romney on Hunting in 2007
text: Mitt Romney responded to a question about hunting while campaigning in April of 2007.

headline: Paul Ryan on His Family and Wisconsin
text: Paul Ryan discusses his upbringing and his family ties to Wisconsin.

headline: A Closer Look at the Ryan Budget
text: Mitt Romney’s new running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan, has proposed huge changes in entitlement programs like Medicare and Medicaid, which insure more than 100 million people and account for more than one-fifth of the federal budget.

headline: Mexico Wins Soccer Gold Medal
text: Two goals from striker Oribe Peralta fired Mexico to a 2-1 win over tournament favorite Brazil in the men’s soccer gold medal game at Wembley on Saturday. The game was barely 30 seconds old when Peralta seized a hasty pass from Rafael da Silva, ran into the penalty area and shot past Gabriel.

headline: TimesCast Politics | Romney Picks Ryan
text: A look at the new vice-presidential candidate. | Romney and Ryan as close friends. | A few things you might not know about Mr. Ryan.

headline: Rolling Out Ryan
text: A vice presidential nominee’s rollout can be as important as the nominee himself, and I was struck in particular by something I heard on CNN just minutes before Paul Ryan stepped to the microphone on the U.S.S. Wisconsin to give his speech this morning.

headline: Romney Announces Running Mate
text: Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney tapped Rep. Paul Ryan of Wisconsin as his vice presidential running mate on Saturday.

headline: For Women’s Leagues, Strike 1. Strike 2. Strike 3?
text: One league started after the United States won the 1999 Women’s World Cup. Another began play months after the American team won the Olympic gold medal at the 2008 Beijing Games. Neither league — Women’s United Soccer Association or Women’s Professional Soccer — survived past three seasons. Now, in the afterglow of another United States triumph, in London on Thursday, the focus is back on the prospects for the long-term survival of top-level women’s league.

headline: For U.S. Volleyball, No Shortage of Stars
text: The United States women’s volleyball team have spiked themselves into the gold medal match against Brazil after defeating South Korea in Thursday night’s match.

headline: Wed and Tortured at 13, Afghan Girl Finds Rare Justice
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — When she refused to prostitute herself or have sex with the man she was forced to marry when she was about 13, officials said, Sahar Gul’s in-laws tortured her and threw her into a dirty, windowless cellar for months until the police discovered her lying in hay and animal dung.

headline: Medals That Were Won Not in Pentathlon or 100 Meters, but in Iambic Pentameter
text: The torrent of sports poetry inspired by the London Olympics continues unabated: NPR even hosted Poetry Games, in which listeners voted on a selection of verse with an athletic theme by celebrated poets from various countries. But few people today recall that poetry, just like the 100 meters, was an official Olympic competition from 1912 to 1948. Sadly, the names of the medal winners are not listed on the International Olympic Committee’s rosters. And many of the winning poems in the so-called Pentathlon of the Muses — which had to be “inspired by the idea of sport” — have mysteriously vanished as well, perhaps, as critics have suggested, because of their dubious literary quality.

headline: Offensive Coach Gives Defense a Lift
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — The Jets needed a safety, and not merely any safety. They were, of course, looking for a safety who could blanket opposing receivers and wallop them when they caught the ball, but they really were seeking a maestro, someone who could run the secondary.

headline: Redirecting Fresh Water Raises Fears for Farmers
text: COURTLAND, Calif. — On the last Sunday of July, this small town in the Sacramento River’s delta takes a pause from the peak of the pear harvest season by holding its annual pear fair. A pear run, a pear parade, a pear pie eating contest and a pear fair queen are as much a part of life’s rhythm here as the pruning, picking and packing of pears.

headline: Reds Prospect Speeds Up the Stolen Bases Ladder
text: In May, when the Cincinnati Reds prospect Billy Hamilton was starting his mission to steal as many bases as possible, Hamilton said the single-season major league record of 130, set by Rickey Henderson in 1982, was “always breakable.”

headline: Elevating Ryan, and His Budget Details
text: WASHINGTON — To date, Mitt Romney has been criticized for a lack of detail behind his promise to reduce the nation’s rising debt through sweeping spending cuts and tax changes, but he has also been politically insulated by it.

headline: A Sudden Star Works to Keep Things Grounded
text: ALBANY — As Victor Cruz walked off the practice field last week, ahead of him, a chorus rose up the path toward the locker room like a swelling wave. Fans cried their adoration not with catcalls or screeches but through a monophonic purr.

headline: At Root of Italy Library’s Plunder, a Tale of Entrenched Practices
text: NAPLES, Italy — For months now, the alarm has been resounding throughout the insular and competitive world of antiquarian books: beware of volumes bearing the stamp of the storied Girolamini Library in Naples. They could be hot.

headline: Why Paul Ryan?
text: I did not think that Mitt Romney would choose the Wisconsin congressman Paul Ryan as his running mate. Nor did I think that Romney should pick Ryan as his number two. But now that he’s done so, let’s consider what might have made the presumptive Republican nominee choose the way he did.

headline: A Designer’s Dream, a Golfer’s Nightmare
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — For more than four decades, the golf course architect Pete Dye has been giving professionals nightmares, heartburn and high anxiety. To some he is a mad scientist. To play a Dye course, they say, is to break into a cold sweat, feel their knees wobble and heart skip a beat. But the 86-year-old Dye has also earned their respect.

headline: China Asserts Sea Claim With Politics and Ships
text: HAIKOU, China — China does not want to control all of the South China Sea, says Wu Shicun, the president of a government-sponsored research institute here devoted to that strategic waterway, whose seabed is believed to be rich in oil and natural gas. It wants only 80 percent.

headline: At the Games, a Whole Lot of Hugs
text: Emotions at the Olympics run from the highest highs to lowest lows, as seen in these photos of athletes celebrating, consoling and supporting each other in the most human of ways — the hug. Throughout the Olympics there have been thousands of them. Here are 26 of our favorites.

headline: Rallying Dodgers, One Cap at a Time
text: LOS ANGELES — From the floor-to-ceiling windows of his wood-paneled owner’s suite, behind the left-field foul pole at Dodger Stadium, Magic Johnson sees his past and his future. When he arrived in this city in 1979, the Dodgers ruled the sports scene. He wants it to be so again.

headline: Variety: A Rowdy Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — What a visual this quote invokes! I love the phrase “the Woodstock of antiquity.”

headline: U.S. and Turkey to Tighten Coordination on Syria
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey and the United States agreed Saturday to accelerate preparations for the possible fall of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, creating a formal bilateral team to manage helping the opposition, providing aid to fleeing refugees and planning for worst-case outcomes that include a chemical weapons attack.

headline: Setting Record, and Setting Record Straight
text: LONDON — Far from the London Games, in the eastern German town of Jena, Marlies Gohr watched television Friday as the United States broke one of track and field’s oldest and most suspect records in the women’s 4x100-meter relay.

headline: Ambiguity in Health Law Could Make Family Coverage Too Costly for Many
text: WASHINGTON — The new health care law is known as the Affordable Care Act. But Democrats in Congress and advocates for low-income people say coverage may be unaffordable for millions of Americans because of a cramped reading of the law by the administration and by the Internal Revenue Service in particular.

headline: The Triumph That Inspired Kenyan Runners to Be Great
text: In the fall of 1968, I was a college freshman on a football scholarship at Morgan State in Baltimore; Kevin Thompson was a sixth grader living in Harlem. Despite our age difference, we each remember the Mexico City Olympics and the polarizing, often bloody events leading to them.

headline: Mexico Has Its Moment in Upset Over Brazil
text: LONDON — On one side of the field the Brazilian soccer prodigy Neymar fell in despair. On the other, the Mexican defender Diego Reyes dropped to the ground with glee. One was despondent that he could not be part of making history; the other was floored that he had.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: A Risky Rationale Behind Romney’s Choice of Ryan
text: When is it rational to take a big risk?

headline: Prosecution Rests in Kidnapping Trial of Pastor
text: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Prosecutors rested their case on Friday against an Amish-Mennonite pastor accused of abetting an international parental kidnapping, after three days of testimony suggesting that others had also conspired to help a born-again Christian mother spirit her daughter abroad.

headline: Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan
text: The speeches from Norfolk, Virginia.

headline: Mr. Ryan’s Cramped Vision
text: Mitt Romney’s safe and squishy campaign just took on a much harder edge. A candidate of no details — I’ll cut the budget but no need to explain just how — has named a vice-presidential running mate, Paul Ryan, whose vision is filled with endless columns of minus signs. Voters will now be able to see with painful clarity just what the Republican Party has in store for them.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Daring to Tell the Truth
text: Would voters reward or punish honesty in politics?

headline: Coalition Soldiers Killed Were Shot in Company of Afghans
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Six of the eight American, British and coalition service members killed since Thursday in southern Afghanistan were shot in the company of their Afghan allies, officials of the NATO-led coalition here said Saturday.

headline: ‘Al’ and ‘Joe’ Lead the Spam Squad
text: 8:25 a.m. Received an urgent e-mail from Al Gore with an unsettling subject line: “Disaster.” Turns out the former vice president wanted to tell me that the Republican Party had been “hijacked by an extremist fringe,” and I should send “$3 or more” a.s.a.p. Now, I’m a fan of the former vice president and, considering some of the blather I’ve heard recently from the Tea Party, it didn’t surprise me to learn that the G.O.P. had been hijacked. But I’m beginning to worry that it’s the Democrats who are now controlled by an extremist fringe — of e-mail writers. These are some of the genuine campaign e-mails I received over just two days recently:

headline: Trade Relations With Russia
text: Congress was supposed to pass a bill to improve trade relations with Russia before it left town for summer recess. That did not happen, and American companies that do business in Russia, or want to, may find themselves at a disadvantage with foreign competitors once Russia joins the World Trade Organization on Aug. 22.

headline: In Romney’s Image
text: Ann Romney said that Mitt Romney would pick a candidate who shared her husband’s values. Take a look at how Mr. Romney and his running mate, Paul D. Ryan, match up.

headline: De Facto Life Without Parole
text: Last week, an appeals court in Florida overturned a 60-year sentence for a young defendant who shot someone when he was almost 17 years old and was convicted of attempted murder, armed robbery and armed burglary. He would not have been released from prison until he was 76, exceeding his life expectancy according to National Vital Statistics Reports. The court found his sentence was unconstitutional. On the same day, a Florida state trial judge, without any hesitation, sentenced another defendant to 100 years for crimes he committed as a juvenile.

headline: One-of-a-Kind Stats for Angels’ Rookie
text: Mike Trout turned 21 on Tuesday, and naturally, he celebrated by hitting a home run. It gave Trout, the Los Angeles Angels’ incomparable rookie, 20 homers for the season. He hit his 21st on Friday, and he entered Saturday with a .345 average and 36 stolen bases, leading the American League in both categories.

headline: A Tax Plan That Defies the Rules of Math
text: IN May of 2000, when George W. Bush was running for president on a platform of extravagant tax cuts for all, his campaign did something that would be considered remarkable today: it submitted his tax plan to the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation, to see how much all those tax cuts would cost the Treasury.

headline: For U.S. Women, Medals and a Moment to Celebrate Title IX
text: LONDON – At a news conference Saturday, Ashton Eaton, the Olympic decathlon champion, sat next to fellow United States gold medalists Brenda Villa, Kayla Harrison and Missy Franklin. A question was posed to all the athletes, and a chivalrous Eaton said, “Ladies first.”

headline: The Long, Dry History of the West
text: Long before the current drought or the continuing conversation about  global warming, before the Dust Bowl, the climate in large portions of the American West was far drier than modern humans have become accustomed to.

headline: 30 Seconds With Ryan Howard
text: First baseman Ryan Howard returned to the Philadelphia Phillies last month after recovering from a torn Achilles’ tendon. He sustained the injury in making the final out of last year’s National League division series loss to the St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: In Olympic Park, a Deluge From Our Sponsors
text: LONDON

headline: Hundred-Year Forecast: Drought
text: BY many measurements, this summer’s drought is one for the record books. But so was last year’s drought in the South Central states. And it has been only a decade since an extreme five-year drought hit the American West. Widespread annual droughts, once a rare calamity, have become more frequent and are set to become the “new normal.”

headline: How to Get Doping Out of Sports
text: Denver

headline: German Austerity’s Lutheran Core
text: IF there’s one nationality the rest of the world thinks it readily and totally understands, it is the Germans. Combine their deep involvement with Nazism and anti-Semitism and, voilà! — 2,000 years of gripping, complex history vanishes.

headline: Trust: Ill-Advised in a Digital Age
text: Las Vegas

headline: A Social Conservative, Too
text: Paul Ryan’s conservatism is almost always described in terms of his approach to budgetary matters and his desire to cut federal spending significantly. And that has been the focus of the discussion about him today.

headline: They Know They Are Being Watched?
text: Gail Albert Halaban began looking into other people’s windows six years ago, soon after moving to New York. She was living across the street from a 24-hour flower shop, waking up at all hours with a newborn baby, and the shop was the most reliable show in town. Then, when the store changed owners and hours, she said, she needed something else to watch.

headline: Victoria Nuland
text: Ambassador Victoria Nuland is a career diplomat and foreign policy adviser who has served under such political opposites as Dick Cheney and Hillary Rodham Clinton. Currently, she is the spokeswoman for the State Department.

headline: Meet the Beatles, Again
text: “DO the Beatles have any other playlists besides ‘Sgt. Pepper’s’?”

headline: In Defense of Single Motherhood
text: IN a season of ardent partisan clashing, Americans seem united in at least one shared idea: Single mothers are bad. A Pew Research Center poll on family structures reports that nearly 7 in 10 Americans think single mothers are a “bad thing for society.”

headline: Exploding the Myths About Vietnam
text: AS the war in Afghanistan drags on with no definitive victory in sight for the United States and American troops begin to withdraw, comparisons to the Vietnam War are once again in the air, 50 years after both Washington and Hanoi decided to beef up their forces in South Vietnam. “Just take a run through the essential Vietnam War checklist,” wrote Tom Engelhardt in Mother Jones magazine, noting “there’s ‘quagmire’ ” and “the idea of winning ‘hearts and minds’ ” as well as “bomb-able, or in our era drone-able, ‘sanctuaries’ across the border” and even “a one-man version of My Lai.” Although these analogies are particularly attractive to critics — who see America’s battle in Afghanistan as even more futile than Vietnam and advocate a quick exit — they are deeply flawed.

headline: Rules Delayed, Governing Denied
text: It has been 19 months since President Obama signed into law the Food Safety Modernization Act, the first overhaul of the Food and Drug Administration’s food safety laws since the 1930s. But if you think the food supply has become markedly safer since then, think again.

headline: Digging Below the Bottom Line
text: Q: How do New York Times reporters and editors translate corporations’ quarterly earnings into easy-to-understand articles?

headline: Weather Vain
text: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

headline: For Men, Sport’s Stigma Dampens Appeal
text: LONDON — Around and around they went, gracefully shimmying and passing balls, hoops and batons to and fro. The crowd roared as the rhythmic gymnasts, five to a team or competing as individuals, made their way through elaborately choreographed routines. They seemed to have it all: gallons of product in their hair, makeup caked on their smiling faces, and uniforms adorned with enough reflective matter to make a Vegas showgirl blush.

headline: The Soul of the Olympics
text: IT’S easy to be cynical about the Olympics: about the runaway commercialism; about the jingoism that so many countries bring to the games; about NBC. Definitely about NBC. Its breathless degree of fake suspense during prime time broadcasts has been a silly mockery of our wired ways, and too many on-the-spot interviews with athletes redefined dippy. How do you feel? Jubilant if you’ve medaled, crushed if you haven’t and really, really tired. Fill in the blanks.

headline: Old Love
text: YEARS ago, when I was a callow 39, I had lunch with a college friend whose intellectual authority over me was considerable; we lunched together often, at least once a month. On that particular occasion I put to him a question that embarrassed me: what if one is deeply in love with a young woman — which was my case — and with age her beauty fades. Will her attraction fatally diminish? Might it be displaced by a sort of repulsion? For instance, when her skin withers and wrinkles, will I still want to kiss the crook of her arms, those arms that I so admire, and, if gallantry pushes me to do so, will I have to avert my eyes?

headline: Indians Fade Away in A.L. Central
text: When Travis Hafner signed a $57 million contract extension in 2007, he had just turned 30 and was on his way to his fourth season in a row with at least 100 runs batted in. The Cleveland Indians, who were on their way to a division title, had Hafner locked up through 2012.

headline: Likability Index
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Romney’s Mormon Story
text: THERE’S an interesting dilemma facing the filmmakers who are presumably hard at work, in some well-hidden editing room, on the biographical movie that will play just before Mitt Romney accepts his party’s nomination: What should the movie say about Romney’s Mormonism?

headline: The Anxious Idiot
text: There are things we can do to break the powerful habit of negative and catastrophic thinking. So why don’t we always do them?

headline: Chronicling the Business of the Games
text: LONDON — As spectators crowded into Lord’s, the famous cricket ground, for an Olympic archery competition one recent morning, two people received a special greeting.

headline: In a Land of Pears, a Debate Over Pipelines
text: A $14 billion project would run giant pipelines under the Sacramento River delta, delivering water to corporate farms and areas of Central and Southern California.

headline: For Canadian Trainer, Hall of Fame Honors and Big Worries About Future
text: Roger Attfield loves horses. He fell for them as a boy growing up in England, where he became an accomplished show jumping rider and steeplechase jockey.

headline: In Contention, Scott Prefers to Look Forward
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — Adam Scott isn’t dwelling on his failure at the British Open last month. Through two rounds, he was tied for seventh place at the P.G.A. Championship and was well positioned to make a weekend charge for the Wanamaker trophy.

headline: Paul Ryan: A Reading List
text: With the news Saturday, there will be tons of coverage of Representative Paul D. Ryan, but I thought it was also worth collecting some of the detailed articles that have been written about Mr. Ryan over the past few years. We welcome other suggestions in the comments section.

headline: Before the Meeting Adjourns, Tell Me What You’ll Do Next
text: This interview with  Bill Flemming, president of Skanska USA Building Inc., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Breaking a Buck, Maybe, but Not Taxpayers’ Backs
text: MARK Aug. 29 on your calendar. It’s the day all of us could end up on the hook for a big future bailout.

headline: Farah Wins 5,000 to Give Home Team Another Title
text: LONDON — Mo Farah of Britain ran toward the line in the 5,000 meters, a slow start becoming a burning finish at 3.1 miles. His eyes were wide, and his mouth was open, and 80,000 people howled him on toward his second gold medal.

headline: A Mutual Fund Master, Too Worried to Rest
text: VANGUARD, the penny-pinching mutual fund company founded by John C. Bogle, has become a colossus. Its index funds — once derided for not even trying to beat the market — are now the industry standard.

headline: For a Fortnight, a Stiff Upper Lip Curls Into a Smile
text: SHEFFIELD, England — All day, people line up here at an unexceptional corner of a town plaza called Barker’s Pool, sometimes a dozen or more at a time, waiting to have a photograph taken with a mailbox. This is not just any mailbox, of course. It is a mailbox that has been given a coat of gold paint.

headline: Deadly Quakes Strike in Iran
text: TEHRAN — At least 250 people were killed Saturday when two powerful earthquakes struck several towns near the Iranian city of Tabriz, state-run Press TV reported, quoting government officials. Khalil Saei, the director of the crisis management headquarters in East Azarbaijan Province, confirmed the death toll and estimated that over 2,000 were injured.

headline: How Big Data Became So Big
text: THIS has been the crossover year for Big Data — as a concept, as a term and, yes, as a marketing tool. Big Data has sprung from the confines of technology circles into the mainstream.

headline: Sometimes, There’s a Happy Ending for All
text: IF all you learned about the service economy in the United States is what you read in this column, you’d think this country was managed and staffed exclusively by nincompoops and dummies. This is not the case. Certainly, the Haggler’s e-mail skews heavily to tales of transactions gone wrong, but remember, this column is basically one large complaint box.

headline: Two Prisms for Looking at China’s Problems
text: CHINA is confronting some serious economic problems, and how Beijing does — or doesn’t — respond to them could bend the course of the global economy.

headline: Wembley F.C., So Near and Yet So Far
text: LONDON – The bus driver will know, we thought, so my companion tapped on his window in the parking lot.

headline: After Sinai Attack, U.S. and Egypt Step Up Talks on Security
text: WASHINGTON — In the wake of the attack that killed 16 Egyptian soldiers near the border with Israel last Sunday, the United States and Egypt are negotiating a package of assistance to address what administration officials described as a worsening security vacuum in the Sinai Peninsula.

headline: A Market Rebound That’s Defying Old Rules
text: AT first blush, it may look as if stocks are following a similar pattern to that of the last two years: the market sinks in the spring, then bounces back in the summer amid signs that the economy is getting past a rough patch.

headline: Between Outbursts, Rockies Manager Stays Positive
text: When Colorado Rockies Manager Jim Tracy burst onto the field in Los Angeles last Monday to argue a reversed call, a seasoned observer knew what would come next. Vin Scully, the Hall of Fame Dodgers broadcaster, was about to narrate a tirade as only he could.

headline: Galt / Gekko 2012
text: Paul Ryan for VP — or, as Romney said in the press conference, “the next president of the United States”. I did say Galt/Gekko, not Gekko/Galt.

headline: The Caucus Click: A New Stage for the New Ticket
text: Mitt Romney and Paul D. Ryan made an impromptu stage out of wooden boxes at a campaign event on Saturday in Ashland, Va.

headline: Bolt’s Last Run Results in World Record and Third Gold
text: LONDON — After an unforgettable performance in the 4x100-meter relay, Usain Bolt of Jamaica wanted a souvenir with which to remember his second Olympics. His grip tightened around his object of choice: not a trinket featuring the London Games’ omnipresent one-eyed mascots, but the baton he had received from his training mate, Yohan Blake, and carried across the finish line in world-record time moments earlier.

headline: Top Two Winning Nations Can’t Help Being Rivals
text: It is, for now, a muted Olympic rivalry. China and the United States have been jostling for the top spot on the medal ladder for three Summer Games now, and yet the tussle remains more statistical than emotional.

headline: Paul Ryan’s G.O.P. Budget Proposal
text: Details of the 2013 House Budget Committee proposal under Paul Ryan.

headline: Paul Ryan and Previous Paths to the Vice Presidency
text: How Paul Ryan’s career compares with the country’s most recent vice presidents.

headline: Brazil Keeps Celebrating as Gold Eludes U.S. Again
text: LONDON — At the end of the Olympic volleyball final, for the second Summer Games in a row, the United States women found themselves in second place on the medals stand watching the Brazilian team wildly celebrate its victory.

headline: What Europe Thinks of Paul Ryan
text: LONDON — Bold but risky, cautious but clever. The European press was mulling what it thought on Saturday of Mitt Romney’s choice of Paul D. Ryan as his Republican vice-presidential running mate.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 12
text: The decision is in: Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin is Mitt Romney’s running mate.

headline: With Nova in Form, Yanks Beat Toronto, Lose Sabathia and Add Lowe
text: TORONTO — Just as one Yankees starter, who was seemingly lost, was rediscovered on Saturday, a more important one disappeared.

headline: The Trail to the Top
text: I WAS the fourth of five children, raised in San Jose, Calif., with a stay-at-home mother and a father who was an operations manager for Lockheed’s missile systems division. My dad earned his master’s degree while working full time when we were little. He was my first role model when it came to working hard.

headline: After Medal Haul, Phelps Plans to Work on His Golf Game
text: After 22 Olympic medals, 18 of them gold, Michael Phelps has a new goal: improve his golf game. And after providing NBC’s Olympic broadcasts with high ratings for his races, Phelps will get help from the Golf Channel, a part of the NBC Sports Group, as the latest celebrity to appear on the swing coach Hank Haney’s “Haney Project.”

headline: Yankees Put Sabathia on Disabled List With Elbow Soreness
text: TORONTO — The Yankees placed C.C. Sabathia on the disabled list Saturday because of recurring soreness in his left elbow, Manager Joe Girardi said.

headline: U.S. Women Run Away With 5th Straight Gold
text: LONDON — The most dominant team in basketball, men’s or women’s, college or professional, domestic or international, won another gold medal Saturday. It felt like 2008 all over again. Or 2004. Or 2000. Or 1996.

headline: Obama Signs Law Exempting Many Appointees From Senate Approval
text: A backlog that has left many government agencies without presidential appointees for months at a time may ease a bit because President Obama signed legislation on Friday exempting scores of government positions from Senate confirmation.

headline: On Pittsburgh and the Peace Sign
text: WHEN it comes to cities that fuel the creative fire, Pittsburgh isn’t usually the first to spring to mind. But don’t tell Kyle Abraham. This dancer and choreographer has been mining that town for material his entire career. Born there into the hip-hop culture of the late 1970s, Mr. Abraham, 34, mixes that influence with classical music and movement training. In 2010 he caught the eye of the dance world with “The Radio Show,” which was inspired by a Pittsburgh station and earned him a Bessie Award. It dealt with race and identity, issues he’s explored throughout his work. Then came “Live! The Realest MC,” loosely based on the story of Pinocchio and an autobiographical look at coming out in a hip-hop world.

headline: The Meaning of It
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — IT took me a while, but I think I’ve finally gotten over my “What have you done for me since the October, 2011, puzzle contest, Patrick Berry?” thing. Today’s Sunday puzzle is the kind of jokey, strong, wordplay-filled grid I like to see from him. And clean. This is no stunt grid, but even when he makes a showy puzzle, Mr. Berry can be counted on to fill his puzzle well.

headline: Martin Fleischmann, Seeker of Cold Fusion, Dies at 85
text: Martin Fleischmann made the greatest discovery since fire: replicating the furnace of the sun at room temperature in a jar of water, essentially solving the world’s energy needs forever.

headline: Jean Merrill, a Writer of Children’s Underdog Tales, Dies at 89
text: Jean Merrill, a children’s author best known for her 1964 book, “The Pushcart War,” about street peddlers in New York who use (nonlethal) guerrilla tactics and savvy publicity maneuvers to fight back when unbridled Big Business threatens to banish their pushcarts from the streets — a book, in other words, that Mother Jones or Saul Alinsky might have produced had they been writers of whimsical allegories — died on Aug. 2 at her home in Randolph, Vt. She was 89.

headline: The Power of Music, Tapped in a Cubicle
text: Editors’ note: Here’s one of our favorite stories from the archives, now being featured in our Smarter Living collection.

headline: Mexico Tops Brazil for Gold Medal
text: Mexico scored less than 30 seconds in during a 2-1 victory for the country’s first Olympic title in men’s soccer.

headline: Three Players Suspended for Conspiring to Cheat
text: Nearly two years after an investigation began into cheating accusations involving three top French players, the World Chess Federation has ruled that they are guilty and has temporarily barred them from chess.

headline: In Romney and Ryan, a Pair Who Don’t Mind Their Differences
text: NORFOLK, Va. — For their debut as the Republican ticket, Mitt Romney and Paul D. Ryan descended single file from the rear of the battleship Wisconsin to the soaring soundtrack of the film “Air Force One,” waving to a crowd of about 2,500 that had been handed small American flags.

headline: Massacre on the Nueces
text: Just after midnight on Aug. 10, 1862, nearly 100 dismounted Confederate cavalry and state militia crept across the dry Texas Hill Country toward a campsite on the banks of the clear Nueces River, where 65 men slept, with just two on watch. Suddenly the dark silence was shattered by Confederate gunfire. Before sunset, those who had not escaped were dead or captured — and the captured were quickly executed.

headline: Gold for Bolt, Farah and the U.S. Women
text: The Jamaicans won the 4x100-meter relay, and host Britain added another gold of its own on the track.

headline: Two Months to Assess Santana’s Future
text: Johan Santana’s start Saturday, his first since missing three weeks with a sprained right ankle, was a welcomed return for the struggling Mets, who have seen their season fizzle after a promising first half.

headline: Racial Profiling Rife at Airport, U.S. Officers Say
text: BOSTON — More than 30 federal officers in an airport program intended to spot telltale mannerisms of potential terrorists say the operation has become a magnet for racial profiling, targeting not only Middle Easterners but also blacks, Hispanics and other minorities.

headline: Aug. 11: Will Ryan Pick Move the Polls?
text: We’ll be hitting few different topics in this polling update, most of them related to Mitt Romney’s selection of Representative Paul D. Ryan as his running mate.

headline: Three Players Move Up at the P.G.A.
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — Before the rain came on Saturday, three players stormed into contention on moving day.

headline: Nurturing Champions, With Family at His Side
text: LONDON — The family Krzyzewski gathered at an Italian restaurant late last week, all 16 of them, as the end to another Olympic basketball tournament drew near. Children crawled under the table. Food spilled. Babies cried.

headline: American Upsets Chinese and Tops Local Favorite in Diving
text: LONDON — Chinese divers had won six of the seven gold medals awarded at the London Games going into the conclusion of the diving program Saturday night. They were expected to win their seventh in that final event, the men’s 10-meter platform. Two Chinese divers, Qiu Bo and Lin Yue, were ranked first and second after the preliminaries and again after the semifinals.

headline: Athlete Dies Competing in Swim Leg of Triathlon
text: An athlete competing in New York City’s first Ironman triathlon died Saturday morning during the 2.4-mile swim in the Hudson River, the first stage in the grueling 140-mile race, according to the police.

headline: Police Fatally Shoot Knife-Wielding Man in Times Square
text: When the tourists and shoppers thronging Times Square on Saturday afternoon first saw the police officers, guns drawn, confronting a knife-wielding man, many thought they had stumbled onto a movie set.

headline: Scenes From the Modern Pentathlon
text: Fence, swim, ride, shoot, run. Simple.

headline: South Korean Denied Medal Over Politics
text: LONDON — A South Korean soccer player was barred from receiving his bronze medal at the London Olympics on Saturday for displaying a sign with a political message after a victory over Japan in the third-place game.

headline: Shadows Over Ironman, but a Spirit of Carrying On
text: The death of a swimmer and a water contamination scare cast a shadow over the Ironman U.S. Championship on Saturday, but organizers and participants professed that they were upbeat about the race’s debut.

headline: Ryan Pick Gives Obama Chance to Change Subject
text: The selection of Representative Paul D. Ryan as the Republican vice-presidential candidate provides President Obama with something he has been eagerly looking for — a bigger target.

headline: Running Mate Is an Upbeat Budget Cutter, Eager to Joust With Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Paul D. Ryan, the 42-year-old Republican named on Saturday as Mitt Romney’s vice-presidential running mate, is idolized by young conservatives in the House, who see him as a role model and a polished spokesman for their vision of America.

headline: In Modern Pentathlon, a Day of Madness
text: LONDON — While the rest of London was still sleeping on Saturday morning, 36 men got up, put on their white fencing uniforms and headed to the Copper Box, their first step in an important daylong quest to win one of the more bizarre and grueling Olympic events.

headline: Meditations from the Dad in the Minivan
text: Dan Zevin, author of “Dan Gets a Minivan: Life at the Intersection of Dude and Dad” and “The Day I Turned Uncool,” may be a humorist, but like the dads profiled in the Sunday Styles piece “Just Wait Until Your Mother Gets Home,” he has also been a full-time father, squeezing in a sentence or two during nap time. Now, when the babysitter doesn’t show, or the school calls to turn in the child with a fever he dropped off moments before, he’s the guy who takes the fall. His musings on fatherhood, in appropriately short, new-parent appropriate bursts, follow.

headline: McIlroy and Singh Share Lead as Heavy Rain Stops Play
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — If you build a golf course on the ocean, there is always the chance a storm will roll in from the sea. And throughout the week at the 2012 P.G.A. Championship, thunderstorms have been in the forecast every day for the Ocean Course on Kiawah Island. But the rain has been infrequent, with little impact on play — until Saturday.

headline: Looking to Mexico for an Alternative to Abortion Clinics
text: MCALLEN — In this Roman Catholic stronghold, where abortion is deeply stigmatized, reproductive health providers tell stories of women going to pharmacies across the border in Mexico, in search of a drug they hope will terminate unwanted pregnancies.

headline: Knee Injury Sidelines Jets Safety
text: Safety Eric Smith, an integral member of the Jets’ secondary and a valuable contributor on special teams, could miss the rest of the preseason after spraining the medial collateral ligament in his left knee while covering a punt during the team’s 17-6 loss to Cincinnati on Friday night. The extent of Smith’s injury has not been announced by the team, but a football official with knowledge of his magnetic resonance imaging results confirmed it. Smith could return for the Sept. 9 season opener against Buffalo. ¶ The police in Davie, Fla., said that Dolphins receiver Chad Johnson had been arrested on a domestic violence charge, accused of head-butting his newlywed wife during an argument in front of their home. Johnson’s wife, Evelyn Lozada, is on the reality show “Basketball Wives.” Johnson changed his last name back from Ochocinco after his wedding to Lozada. (AP)

headline: Police Shoot Man in Midtown, and Tourists Reach for Cameras
text: The typical afternoon furor in Times Square became something more menacing on Saturday as throngs of police officers drew their weapons and pursued a man with a large knife down Seventh Avenue and then shot him to death.

headline: A Dire Dance for a Harlem Cultural Center
text: Stomping and twisting, homeless mothers and children and young professionals were all part of the mix at the Dwyer Cultural Center in Harlem one recent Saturday, as they tried to master the intricacies of swing dancing. But scenes like this have been few and far between lately. The Dwyer, which since opening three years ago has attracted 75,000 visitors to visual art exhibitions, readings, writers’ workshops, children’s educational programs and music and theater performances — all free or low-cost — has run into major financial problems.

headline: In Ill Doctor, a Surprise Reflection of Who Picks Assisted Suicide
text: SEATTLE — Dr. Richard Wesley has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the incurable disease that lays waste to muscles while leaving the mind intact. He lives with the knowledge that an untimely death is chasing him down, but takes solace in knowing that he can decide exactly when, where and how he will die.

headline: In Hard Times, Schools Zero In on Employees
text: When Texas lawmakers took up the issue of how to make fewer dollars stretch further in public schools during the 2011 legislative session, “efficiency” was a commonly uttered word.

headline: In a G.O.P.-Dominated State, Democrats Wait for Their Opening
text: Being a Democrat in a Texas election is like being the fastest sprinter outside of Jamaica or the best beach volleyball team outside of the United States. Unless something odd happens, your medal will be silver or bronze.

headline: What the Star Chefs Love in Houston’s Chinatown
text: Mention Chinatown to Texans, and many will think first of New York or San Francisco, where traditional Chinese street signs, bumpy durian fruits and bamboo baskets filled with dumplings have inspired countless Instagrams. While the Chinatowns in those cities have long been tourist destinations, a similar corridor in Houston receives less recognition, even from local residents, a surprising fact considering that Houston’s New Chinatown is large (almost six square miles) and centered on a busy stretch of Bellaire Boulevard. “Many people have lived in Houston all of their lives and have never been here,” said Christy Chang, who gives weekly tours of the area with her company, Asian Heritage Discovery.

headline: About as Bad as It Gets for Santana in His Return
text: The much-anticipated return of Johan Santana began with the expectation that three weeks on the disabled list with a sprained ankle had helped rest his fatigued left arm.

headline: How Campaign Outwitted the 24-Hour News Cycle
text: DULLES, Va. — The escape plan was carefully choreographed. On Friday, after a day of work, Representative Paul D. Ryan pretended to turn in for the night, walking through the front door of his home in Janesville, Wis.

headline: Romney Team Hints at More Openness on Ryan’s Tax Records

Ryan had produced tax returns for a greater number of years than Mr. Romney has in his run for the White House.

headline: What We're Watching on Day 17
text: While there are still some big events on Sunday, it's also time to reflect on the London 2012 Olympics. Members of The Times staff select their favorite athletes and stories of the Summer Games.

headline: London 2012: A Gold Medal, or An Also-Ran?
text: There were drugs, of course there were — a slew of positive tests and expulsions, in weight lifting and race walking, in gymnastics and judo.

headline: Cleveland Browns, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: It’s Year 14 of the Cleveland Browns’ rebuilding project. Or Year 3 of their third or fourth rebuilding project – however you want to look at it (averting your gaze would be understandable). The Browns finished 4-12 last season, the third straight year, and ninth time since their reinstatement in 1999, that they have lost at least 11 games. They did it primarily with bad offense (13.6 points per game, ranked third worst), though their defense was nowhere near as good as its No. 5 scoring ranking suggested.

headline: Silver and Bronze Are Not Equal
text: Watching the Olympics over the past two weeks, I noticed something odd about the heights of the podiums during the awards ceremonies. While the podium on which the gold medal winner stands is — as expected — the highest, the heights of the silver and bronze podiums are the same.

headline: How Not to Be a Helicopter Parent: Volunteer
text: Years ago, when one of my children was partying too much in high school, and college applications were looming, I quit my job teaching at a university and began working full time at home. In truth, I had been teaching college students on and off for 25 years, and I was at the end of my pedagogical rope. But I also convinced myself that staying home to badger my child 24/7 would improve his chances in life.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Open magazine ran an Independence Day special on “Radical Indians” this week. Particularly interesting is a dissection of the work of Arundhati Roy, the writer and activist, whom the magazine labels “the Queen of Exaggeration.”

headline: A Young Ugandan Surprises the Field and Himself
text: LONDON — The East Africans were heavily favored to win the Olympic marathon Sunday, but they happened to be Kenyans and Ethiopians, not a Ugandan named Stephen Kiprotich.

headline: Highlights and Analysis From the Men’s Basketball Title Game

headline: Government Agencies Targeting Yoga Studios, Some Owners Say
text: Three years ago, yoga studios in New York waged a spirited and successful campaign to fend off a proposed state government regulation that some studios said would have led to their demise.

headline: 200 Rescued in Iran After Quakes; Death Toll Rises to 300
text: TEHRAN — Iranian relief workers saved more than 200 people from the rubble of dozens of villages destroyed when two powerful earthquakes struck Saturday in a wide area north of the city of Tabriz, an Iranian official said Sunday.

headline: Racial Profiling Charges Renew Questions About Counterterrorism Program
text: My Washington bureau colleagues Mike Schmidt and Eric Lichtblau wrote a revealing story Sunday on the accusations by more than 30 Transportation Security Administration officers at Boston’s Logan International Airport that a program intended to detect terrorists has instead degenerated into racial and ethnic profiling.

headline: Romney and Ryan to Give First Joint TV Interview on CBS
text: 1:32 p.m. | Updated For their first joint television interview, Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan have picked the most popular news program on American television: CBS’s “60 Minutes.”

headline: Syrian Jets Pound Rebel Positions as Opposition Presses for No-Fly Zone
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian jets fired on areas in and around Aleppo again on Sunday, continuing an escalation of force that has led activists and rebels to demand that foreign forces establish a no-fly zone to counter the government’s air superiority.

headline: Chesney and McGraw: A Country Night in New Jersey
text: More than 56,000 people packed into MetLife Stadium on Saturday to hear Kenny Chesney and Tim McGraw perform back-to-back concerts, one of the largest country music events ever in the New York City metropolitan area.

headline: In Upheaval for Egypt, Morsi Forces Out Military Chiefs
text: CAIRO — President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt forced the retirement on Sunday of his powerful defense minister, the army chief of staff and other senior generals, moving more aggressively than ever before to reclaim political power that the military had seized since the fall of Hosni Mubarak last year.

headline: ‘The Bourne Legacy’ Leads Weekend Box Office
text: “The Bourne Legacy” managed to sell an estimated $40.3 million in tickets at North American movie theaters over the weekend, a No. 1 opening that was solid if not spectacular. “Legacy,” featuring Jeremy Renner, cost Universal Pictures and a financing partner at least $125 million to produce and tens of millions more to market.

headline: James and U.S. Replenish Gold in Treasure Chest
text: LONDON — The Americans stood together on the highest platform, in the same place everyone but Spain figured they would stand Sunday afternoon. An official hung gold medals around their necks, and in that moment, the favorites, a collection of basketball millionaires, reverted to childhood.

text: The United States defeated Spain, 107-100, for the Olympic gold medal in men’s basketball.

He lost so much range of motion, he said, that he could not touch his left shoulder with the fingers on his left hand.

headline: Big-Data Investing Gets Its Own Supergroup
text: Big Data is getting a council of wise men. With money.

headline: Mozart Festival Theme Takes Flight, From Lobby to Stage
text: It is hard to attend Mostly Mozart Festival concerts these days without getting birds on the brain. Birds and bird song are a pervasive element of this year’s festival, which is exploring the “avian theme inside and outside the concert hall,” as Lincoln Center’s artistic director, Jane Moss, explains in a program note.

headline: Digital Diary: How GIFs Became the Perfect Medium for the Olympics
text: This year’s Olympic Games have been the most compelling I can remember watching: the elaborate blinged-out accessories worn by Ryan Lochte, the staggering physical feats of Usain Bolt, Gabby Douglas’s heartwarming win.

headline: Tough Love in a Tough Job Market
text: “Get to Work,” an eight-episode reality series that begins Monday on the Sundance Channel, sounds from the title as if it might help the mainstream unemployed — the middle-income victim of downsizing, the blue-collar laborer whose factory has closed — find employment. It won’t.

headline: Yanks’ Rally Falls Short as Hughes Loses Grip
text: TORONTO — At the moment that virtually every pitch is thrown by every pitcher at every level of baseball, the throwing hand pronates. When the hand releases the ball, the thumb tends to twist underneath the hand in a circular motion, followed by the index and middle fingers.

headline: A Royal Power Player Who Sprints to the Throne
text: No character in Shakespeare is as hungry for power as Richard III. And it’s hard to think of an actor with a naturally hungrier look than Ron Cephas Jones, the tall, beanpole-thin, snakelike actor who portrays the title character in the production of “Richard III” from the Public Theater’s new Mobile Shakespeare Unit. This scaled-down staging has been presented at prisons, homeless shelters and other sites in underserved neighborhoods before returning to the company’s home base on Astor Place.

headline: Pick a Topic, Any Topic. He Did.
text: In the final essay of this hodge-podgy collection, Nicholson Baker — best known for his microscopically detailed accounts of daily life, his love of the minute, the specific, the Seinfeld-ian small — notes that he’d like to write a book for children and adults called “The Way the World Works,” a book that would explain “everything about history, beauty, wickedness, invention, the meaning of life,” the “whole unseemly, bulging ball of wax.”

headline: Both Sides Focus on the Republican Ticket’s New Face
text: WAUKESHA, Wis. — Democrats moved aggressively on Sunday to wrap Mitt Romney in the politically charged details of budget-cutting proposals championed by his new running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan, as Mr. Romney sought to capitalize on conservative enthusiasm for his choice without having to defend every element of Mr. Ryan’s positions.

headline: Stars and Athletes Tread a New Stage, One With Live Ammo
text: The thanking of our troops is a fine gesture, but one easily exploited by anybody looking for an applause line or a few more votes or, perhaps, improved television ratings.

headline: The New Boss, Not the Same as the Old Boss
text: Let’s say your highly successful television show is ending because the star is moving on, and you want to create a new show that will suck in as many of the old viewers as possible. What do you do?

headline: James Naughton, Newsman and Puckish Inspiration, Dies at 73
text: James M. Naughton, a prank-loving White House and national correspondent for The New York Times during the Nixon, Ford and Carter administrations and later a senior editor at The Philadelphia Inquirer for almost two decades, died on Saturday at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He would have been 74 on Monday.

headline: Fighting Their Way Up Art World Ladder
text: Meet Liz, an aspiring pop socialite in the Olivia Palermo mold, haughty enough to disdain the commoners around her but vain enough to crave their attention. Her father is an art collector, and at least partly because of that, she’s been able to secure an internship at Eli Klein Fine Art, a SoHo gallery. That’s where she’ll work — but not very hard — on “Gallery Girls,” the Bravo reality series that has its premiere on Monday and that is rooted in the belief that there is privilege, and there is bootstrapping, and ne’er the twain shall meet.

headline: Footnote
text: Carolina Performing Arts at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, is set to announce a new concluding program for its performance season, “The Rite of Spring at 100,” to be presented by the Martha Graham Dance Company. Titled “Myth & Transformation,” the two-night program will feature Graham’s interpretation of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring”; the world premiere of a work choreographed by Nacho Duato with music by Arvo Pärt; and performances by the guest artist Wendy Whelan, a principal dancer for the New York City Ballet. The program is scheduled for April 26 and 27.

headline: Beneath the Dappled Light, There’s Safety and Charm in Numbers
text: In perhaps the most famous aria in all of Handel’s operas, “Ombra mai fu,” King Xerxes of Persia states that no shade was ever so dear as that of his beloved plane tree. Though I’ve observed plane trees all my life and have known that aria for decades, only on Saturday did Handel’s sublime melody come to mind — when I spent over two hours in the shade of plane trees in Battery Park, watching the opening event of the 31st annual Downtown Dance Festival. The charm of those trees’ shade on a warm afternoon, the ravishing way they filtered the brightness of the light, and the dappled look of the leaves from beneath: all brought back Xerxes’ words as set to music by Handel.

headline: The Veil of Opulence
text: As the selection of Paul Ryan shows, the schism between the Obama and Romney doctrines of fairness is wide. But only one of them offers the moral clarity needed to guide policy.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS The data will include retail sales for July, the producer price index for July and business inventories for June (Tuesday); the Consumer Price Index for July and industrial production for July (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, housing starts for July, and the Philadelphia Fed index for August (Thursday); and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for August and leading economic indicators for July (Friday).

headline: Occupy Wall Street Inspires a Show
text: In commemoration of the one-year anniversary of the Occupy Wall Street movement, the Civilians theater company will assemble an evening of performance material inspired by more than 150 interviews with activists associated with the Occupy movement that have been conducted over the last year. A cabaret, called “Let Me Ascertain You: Occupy #S17,” is to feature monologues and songs created by Civilians artists from their interviews. It will run for one night, Sept. 17, at Joe’s Pub at the Public Theater.

headline: A Memoir to Come From Billy Crystal
text: The comedian Billy Crystal has reached an agreement with Henry Holt & Company to publish a memoir covering over four decades of his life and featuring his thoughts on growing older, The Associated Press reported. Financial terms for the book were not disclosed, but it was reported that the deal could be worth about $4 million. Mr. Crystal, who will turn 65 next year, also hopes the book will translate to the stage in a similar fashion to his previous memoir, “700 Sundays,” which was adapted into a one-man play in 2004 and won a Tony Award in 2005 for Special Theatrical Event.

headline: Obama Says He Fundamentally Disagrees With Ryan’s Vision for the Country
text: CHICAGO — President Obama addressed his rival’s vice-presidential choice for the first time on Sunday, calling Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin a nice guy whose leadership would be a national disaster.

headline: Stride’s New Flavor of Chewing Gum: Red Herring
text: ON Aug. 1, a billboard appeared in the SoHo neighborhood of Manhattan displaying only a date, “08.13.12,” and clues seemed to point to Apple.

headline: ‘Ultra’ Brands End Dispute Over Their Name
text: At nightclubs and festivals around the world, dance music is all about good times. But behind the scenes of this increasingly lucrative and competitive sector of the music business lie the same kinds of disputes over trademarks and exploitation rights that plague any industry.

headline: Second World Mind Sports Games in France
text: LILLE, France — After Sunday’s play at the Second World Mind Sports Games here, the qualifying stage was just over half completed.

headline: Exploring the Bounds of Propriety
text: Administrivial Vacation Alert! I’ll be on vacation this week, but during the meanwhile you will be in the very capable hands of Tom Gaffney, fellow puzzlehead. I’ll be back for the Tuesday, Aug. 21 post, and look for this blog to be outfitted in a “Deb Amlen Went on Vacation and All This Blog Got Was a Lousy T-Shirt” t-shirt upon my return. Have a great week, and keep on solving!

headline: Documentary Exploring Obama’s Political Roots
text: Dinesh D’Souza — the author of the best seller “The Roots of Obama’s Rage” and a former American Enterprise Institute fellow — is not a fan of President Obama. The strident documentary “2016: Obama’s America” (co-directed with John Sullivan) builds on Mr. D’Souza’s 2010 cover article for Forbes, which asserts that Mr. Obama pursues his father’s left-leaning, “anticolonial” ideals. Here they are presented as flaws consistent with the senior Obama’s multiple relationships, alcoholism and fatal auto accident in 1982.

headline: Wanted, Dead or Alive: Used Books
text: ARCHER CITY, Tex. — Larry McMurtry, the famed author of “Lonesome Dove” and dozens of other books, was walking slowly along State Highway 79 on Friday morning toward this town’s only major intersection. Down the block, more than 150 collectors and dealers were queuing up to bid on 300,000 used books — about two-thirds of the stock of Booked Up, the four-building literary mecca that Mr. McMurtry started here in 1988.

headline: The Beginning of Back to Normal
text: Periodically throughout the Olympics, we checked in with Dennis Spurr, the owner of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, a pretty town on the English coast where the sailing events took place. Spurr’s sausage business was a target of the Olympic branding authorities in 2007 after he put up a sign featuring the Olympic five-ring logo done in sausage links. He took it down on their demands, but replaced it with a sign featuring five squares made of sausage links.

text: NEW CANAAN, Conn. — It was full-service retail politics on Thursday for Christopher Shays at the New Canaan Metro-North train station.

headline: Argentina’s New Literary Tradition: Pensions for Aging Writers
text: BUENOS AIRES — It is not enough for this city to boast cavernous bookstores that stay open past midnight, broad avenues once roamed by literary giants like Jorge Luis Borges, cafes serving copious amounts of beef and red wine, or even a bizarre neo-Gothic skyscraper, the Palacio Barolo, inspired by Dante’s “Divine Comedy.”

headline: Cruz Cringes at Replacement Officials
text: ALBANY — Add Victor Cruz to the growing number of N.F.L. players who are concerned about the league’s replacement officials.

headline: Paul Ryan, Black Panther?
text: Did Paul Ryan quote a famous 1960s Black Panther Party slogan in his speech on Saturday announcing his candidacy for vice president on the Republican ticket?

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Dale Olson, Top Hollywood Publicist, Dies at 78
text: Dale Olson, a top Hollywood publicist who protected the public images of a throng of stars, including Clint Eastwood, Steven Spielberg, Shirley MacLaine, Gene Kelly and Joan Crawford, and who helped persuade Rock Hudson to announce that he had AIDS, died on Aug. 9 in Burbank, Calif. He was 78.

headline: The Last Book Sale
text: Larry McMurtry auctioned some 300,000 used books from his bookstores in Archer City, Tex.

headline: A Bird Magazine’s Final Chirps in Print
text: For three decades, fans of Bird Talk magazine have dutifully collected issues for their articles and centerfolds. But the September issue is the last that will appear in print, leaving disappointed subscribers with BirdChannel.com, the magazine’s related site, as the only way to read the publication’s information on all types of birds — from love birds to macaws and cockatoos.

headline: MundoFox to Enter the Latino TV Market
text: LOS ANGELES — The correspondents were on camera and on location in Mexico City, Washington and Los Angeles. Rolando Nichols, the lead anchor, listened intently to the receiver in his ear as he stood in front of the bright red walls of the news studio.

headline: Wondering How Far Magazines Must Fall
text: Making a weekly newsmagazine has always been a tough racket. It takes a big staff working on punishing deadlines to aggregate the flurry of news, put some learned topspin on it and package it for readers. But that job now belongs to the Web and takes place in real time, not a week later.

headline: Israeli Minister Asks Nations to Say Iran Talks Have Failed
text: JERUSALEM — Amid intensifying Israeli news reports saying that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is close to ordering a military strike against Iran’s nuclear program, his deputy foreign minister called Sunday for an international declaration that the diplomatic effort to halt Tehran’s enrichment of uranium is dead.

headline: Slither, Flutter and Glow: Lure of Nocturnal Creatures
text: Mike Feller directed his headlamp toward a fallen log. A dot of green beamed back, the telltale eyeshine. It was coming from a fishing spider, an arachnid known for its multiple eyes, considerable girth (two inches in diameter) and speed of movement.

headline: Woman Becomes First Openly Gay General
text: WASHINGTON — An Army officer being promoted to brigadier general openly acknowledged her homosexuality on Friday by having her wife pin her star to her uniform, thus becoming the first openly gay officer of flag rank in the United States military.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Liberal Fan Club
text: There is one point on which Democratic strategists and the hard right are united: they fervidly support Mitt Romney’s decision to choose Paul Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, as his vice-presidential running mate.

headline: Britain Takes a Final Bow
text: LONDON — With a gaudy three-hour farewell that mashed up theater, acrobatics, fashion and a few generations of musical idols, London extinguished the Olympic torch Sunday night, capping two weeks of athletic achievements with a jukebox collection of songs and a marathon display of endearingly wacky stagecraft.

headline: In ’12 Race, Mayor Seeks Immigration Discussion
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wants the presidential candidates to talk more about immigration policy. So on Tuesday, he will be visiting the cities where their campaigns have headquarters, pressing them on the issue.

headline: NBC Banks on Olympics as Springboard for New Shows
text: The Olympics have cast a spell over NBC for the last two weeks, bestowing the gift of flight on a network long stuck in ratings mud. But like Wile E. Coyote suddenly discovering his jet pack has run out of fuel, a vertiginous plunge looms.

headline: Will Paul Ryan Make a Difference in the U.S. Election?
text: WASHINGTON — The selection of Paul Ryan, chairman of the U.S. House of Representative’s Budget Committee as Mitt Romney’s running mate has excited Republican activists, but it’s hard to find a successful role model for the seven-term congressman’s quest to become vice president.

headline: Key Officials Under Karzai Are Criticized
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The chief of Afghanistan’s antigraft commission has called for the country’s finance minister to step aside while he is being investigated in connection with corruption allegations, even as the minister appealed to his Western backers for support.

headline: Tutoring Not Required Under a Federal Waiver
text: The city says certain struggling schools no longer have to use their federal money to pay for tutoring services offered free to students, now that New York has won a waiver from the No Child Left Behind law. The change has left school communities wondering what extra support will be available in the new school year.

headline: Hollywood Eager to Feed China’s Appetite for 3-D
text: BEIJING — Zheng Huan and Tang Xiaomei, infrequent moviegoers from rural Jiangxi in southeast China, saw their first 3-D film last week while visiting the capital.

headline: You Had to Be There
text: On London’s Olympic stage, athletes, fans and volunteers created a memorable experience. Four New York Times reporters reflect on their impressions covering their first Olympics.

headline: Astros Begin Again, Starting With Youth and Hope
text: HOUSTON — The Mules of Central Missouri State won one game at the 1974 N.C.A.A. Division II College World Series. A tall, right-handed sophomore with a fastball, a curveball and a knuckle-change fired a 2-0 shutout against Ohio Northern, striking out 11 in a row at one point. He went undefeated as a junior but stretched a tendon in his shoulder as a senior and never pitched again.

headline: Some in California Skirt a Ban on Foie Gras
text: SACRAMENTO — Seemingly an afterthought, the last appetizer listed on the menu at Restaurant Thir13en is a brioche that, at $21, may sound overpriced even if it is “house made” and comes with strawberry rhubarb purée and a bacon chip. Accompanying it, though, are “complimentary seared foie gras and foie panna cotta.”

headline: Climbing the Rankings, and Hoping to Follow in His Brother’s Footsteps
text: MASON, Ohio — Though he is still a long distance from where he wants to be, Christian Harrison is moving quickly through the familiar footsteps that have gone before him.

headline: Final Event of the Games Concludes With a Roar
text: LONDON — By the time Narumi Kurosu entered the ring for the final meters of her run in the women’s pentathlon Sunday, her native Japan, as well as Cuba, Britain, Kazakhstan, Lithuania, Russia, Uganda and the United States, had already struck Olympic gold.

headline: Libor Case Energizes a Wall Street Watchdog
text: Months after he arrived in Washington in 2009, Gary Gensler knew he had a big case.

headline: The One Housing Solution Left: Mass Mortgage Refinancing
text: MORE than four million Americans have lost their homes since the housing bubble began bursting six years ago. An additional 3.5 million homeowners are in the foreclosure process or are so delinquent on payments that they will be soon. With 13.5 million homeowners underwater — they owe more than their home is now worth — the odds are high that many millions more will lose their homes.

headline: For Ryan and Obama, More Than the Usual Rivalry
text: When President Obama was first elected, aides say, he saw Representative Paul D. Ryan, another ambitious Midwestern policy wonk, as someone he could possibly work with to reverse the building federal debt.

headline: Problems Riddle Moves to Collect Credit Card Debt
text: The same problems that plagued the foreclosure process — and prompted a multibillion-dollar settlement with big banks — are now emerging in the debt collection practices of credit card companies.

headline: Korea Policing the Net. Twist? It’s South Korea.
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A government critic who called the president a curse word on his Twitter account found it blocked. An activist whose Twitter posting likened officials to pirates for approving a controversial naval base was   accused by the navy of criminal defamation. And a judge who wrote that the president (“His Highness”) was out to “screw” Internet users who challenged his authority was fired in what was widely seen as retaliation.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Philip Marlowe, Peerless Detective, Returns for an Encore
text: In his spare time, Philip Marlowe plays chess with the dead, working out problems from a book of historic games as though a living chess player might let him down. He reads the society page when he has “run out of things to dislike.” He is a softhearted cynic, yet truer to the spirit of the law than any lawman.

headline: Again Backing Santana, a Met Reaffirms His Painful Decision
text: As Johan Santana delivered the first few pitches of his start against the Atlanta Braves on Saturday night, the Mets’ Mike Baxter momentarily felt an eerie familiarity and smiled to himself.

headline: McIlroy Dominates Another Major
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — The birth of a champion, and maybe golf’s next dominant player, was dispiriting, humiliating defeat. Put Rory McIlroy back in the woods of the 10th hole at the 2011 Masters as he whacked his ball from tree to tree, a boy lost in the forest on his way to a mortifying fall from the summit of the leader board.

headline: Free Speech at Military Funerals
text: President Obama signed a new law last week that broadens federal limits on protests at military funerals for members or former members of the Armed Forces. The changes cover services held in private places as well as military cemeteries.

headline: The Romney-Ryan Plan for America
text: Less than 24 hours after Mitt Romney chose Paul Ryan as his running mate on Saturday, his campaign was already trying to distance itself from Mr. Ryan’s politically toxic budget plan. His budget is not ours, the campaign said; Mr. Romney “will be putting together his own plan for cutting the deficit and putting the budget on a path to balance.”

headline: The Romney Package
text: BRACE yourself for weeks of chatter about Mitt Romney’s running mate. Vice presidents matter, as we have been spookily reminded by the recent re-emergence of Dick Cheney on our TV screens. And Paul Ryan matters more than most. (See below.)

headline: In the Name of the Future, Rio Is Destroying Its Past
text: Rio de Janeiro

headline: Paul Ryan’s Journey
text: Some of the milestones in Representative Paul D. Ryan’s life and career.

headline: Is the Threat From Hate Groups Overlooked?
text: Has the government's focus on Muslim terrorists made us neglect the threat from white hate groups? Should law enforcement pay more attention to them?

headline: Closing Time
text: An eclectic mix of British performers took the stage as the Olympics drew to an end.

headline: Robert Gould Shaw’s Gruesome Task
text: On Aug. 11, 1862, Robert Gould Shaw arrived in the Virginia town of Culpeper on a grim errand: the young lieutenant was there to accompany the remains of five fellow officers on the first leg of a final journey home to Boston. Before the bullet-ridden corpses were packed for shipment, Shaw carefully clipped a lock of hair from the lifeless head of one body. He repeated the somber act on the others, and put the locks away for safekeeping. He planned to present the keepsakes to mourning friends as a memento mori.

headline: Effort to Cut Milan Traffic Halted as Court Favors Garage
text: MILAN — It would seem to go without saying that a measure aimed at reducing traffic in the center of a city would hurt the business of a parking garage there. It would not even seem to be a matter of dispute, much less a court case.

headline: Lost Weekends Define Woods’s Drought in Major Tournaments
text: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — Tiger Woods buried his face in a white towel, then threw the towel at his bag with undisguised contempt. His tee shot at the par-5 seventh hole had landed in gnarly rough, and going for the green appeared out of the question.

headline: Traffic Jams Aggravate Around the World
text: Milan has entered a legal battle over traffic control. But gridlock is a global problem. Here is a collection of curated videos showing snarls, backups and standstills around the world.

headline: Giants’ Kid Gloves Come Off for Developing Cornerback
text: ALBANY — The second-year Giants cornerback Prince Amukamara sometimes wears dazzling white football gloves, shiny and sleek, as if his hands were dipped in ivory.

headline: Museum Defends Antiquities Collecting
text: Over the last five years, the Cleveland Museum of Art has been at work on one of the largest building programs of any art institution in the country, a $350 million project that has been unveiled in sleek new stages and will be completed by 2013, adding 35,000 more square feet of gallery space.

headline: At Queens Bakery, the Art of Translating a Planet’s Worth of Sweet Confections
text: The vanilla in the extract sold at Pattycakes, a cake-supply store in Queens, originates in Madagascar, but it is when the tiny bottles leave the shop that the spice truly becomes multinational.

headline: On Jackson Heights Sidewalks, a Treat’s Messy Aftermath
text: On a stroll through the busy streets of Jackson Heights, Queens, Sahadev Poudel kept gesturing at the ground with disgust. He stopped on the sidewalks in front of sari boutiques and Indian grocery stores, pointing out stains that looked like dried blood.

headline: As Ryan Looks to Focus on Economy, Spotlight Shines on His Other Views
text: WASHINGTON — Though best known as an architect of conservative fiscal policy, Representative Paul D. Ryan has also been an ardent, unwavering foe of abortion rights, has tried to cut off federal money for family planning, has opposed same-sex marriage and has championed the rights of gun owners.

headline: Helping Couples Facing Illness
text: WISH UPON A WEDDING, a nonprofit organization that provides free weddings for couples in which one partner is terminally ill (or both), was started in 2010 by Liz Guthrie, a former wedding planner who is now the organization’s executive director.

headline: Kerley Back Practicing After Hamstring Injury
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Two days after watching the Jets’ first preseason game on a television in the receivers’ meeting room at the team’s training camp, the injured second-year wide receiver Jeremy Kerley returned to the field Sunday and took one small step forward.

headline: Japanese Economy Signaling a Slowdown
text: TOKYO — Japan’s economic growth slowed to an annual rate of just 1.4 percent in the second quarter, the government said Monday, as cooling global demand weighed on the nation’s exports, while domestic demand, which had helped Japan outperform other Group of 7 industrialized countries this year, appeared to lose steam.

headline: Em nome do futuro, Rio está destruindo o passado
text: This is the Portugese-language translation of a New York Times Op-Ed. If you cannot view the Portugese, you might need to adjust the settings on your Web browser or on your computer’s operating system
