headline: A Clause That Could Salvage the Winter Classic
text: The N.H.L. can cancel the Jan. 1 Winter Classic at 115,000-seat Michigan Stadium as late as Jan. 1, the day of the game, because of a work stoppage “arising from the lack of a collective bargaining agreement,” the contract between the league and the University of Michigan shows.

headline: U.S. Men’s Basketball Team Wins Gold
text: The United States defeated Spain, 107-100, for the Olympic gold medal in men’s basketball.

headline: Niese Provides Steadying Hand, but Mets Keep Him on His Toes
text: Jon Niese is in his third full season with the Mets, and so far this year, it has been hard to say whether he has taken a full step forward in his progression or arrived at a bit of a plateau.

headline: Study Links Healthier Weight in Children With Strict Laws on School Snacks
text: Adolescents in states with strict laws regulating the sale of snacks and sugary drinks in public schools gained less weight over a three-year period than those living in states with no such laws, a new study has found.

headline: A Host of Ills When Iron’s Out of Balance
text: Iron, an essential nutrient, has long been the nation’s most common nutritional deficiency. In decades past, many parents worried that children who were picky eaters would develop iron-deficiency anemia. My mother boiled meat I refused to eat and fed me the concentrated broth in hopes I’d get some of its iron.

headline: Trouser Press
text: I think I probably gasped when I saw pantsuits — real jacket-and-trouser looks — follow one after the other down the fall runway of the usually girly Miu Miu line.

headline: Word of the Day | primogeniture
text: primogeniture •\pri-mo-ˈje-nə-ˌchu̇r, -chər, -ˌtyu̇r, -ˌtu̇r\• noun

headline: The Week in Politics Pictures: Aug 5-Aug 12
text: A look back at the week in politics.

headline: The Long Run
text: Articles in this series are exploring the lives and careers of the candidates for president and vice president in 2012.

headline: Motorola Set for Big Cuts as Google Reinvents It
text: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Motorola Mobility, the ailing cellphone maker that Google bought in May, told employees Sunday that it would lay off 20 percent of its work force and close a third of its 94 offices worldwide.

headline: Tea Party Hopes to Gain Larger Stage in Election With Romney’s Pick
text: For two years, Tea Party lawmakers in the House have been the stubborn barbarians at the gate, strong-arming their often reluctant Republican colleagues by refusing to compromise on spending, taxes, debt or social policy.

headline: Should Great White Sharks Remain Protected?
text: HONG KONG — It has been a month since the shark took Ben Linden.

headline: For Ryan’s First Solo Outing as Candidate, a Soapbox Appearance at the Iowa State Fair
text: DES MOINES — Representative Paul D. Ryan is going solo, and for his first outing alone as the Republican vice-presidential candidate he has chosen a particularly exposed high-wire appearance: a political soapbox at the Iowa State Fair.

headline: Conservative Star’s Small-Town Roots
text: JANESVILLE, Wis. — Representative Paul D. Ryan’s childhood home here was not overtly partisan. His parents were enthusiastic supporters of Representative Les Aspin, a Democrat, yet adored President Ronald Reagan from their glimpses of him on the evening news. But the death of his father when Mr. Ryan was only 16 punctured his life of math tests and bike riding, and in that fissure, the seeds of his worldview were planted.

headline: Bangalore Couples Turn to Cops for Counseling
text: As the three stars with a red-and-blue ribbon on his shoulder strap will tell you, M.L. Purushotham is a police inspector. But here’s his unofficial job description: redeemer of relationships and savior of marriages.

headline: News Quiz | August 13, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Conversation With: Social Scientist Anandi Mani
text: Anandi Mani, an associate professor at the University of Warwick in Britain, is one of the authors of a study on women’s political representation and its effect on crime in India. As the government reserves for women a third of all seats in local government institutions like the village council, the researchers sought to find out whether having female political leaders at the local level would have a positive effect on women. Instead, they found that the reported number of crimes against women rose. Ms. Mani explained in an e-mail interview with India Ink why that’s not bad news.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 13, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article “Another Landmark for Jeter.”

headline: Sustainable Innovation, Part I
text: Sustainable consumer products can be put into two broad categories.

headline: Picturing the Remnants of Anti-Chinese Violence
text: Many people try to pay homage to historic sites by preserving or taking stock of whatever remains. Tim Greyhavens, a photojournalist from Seattle, wants to highlight a slice of history by challenging his audience to fill in the blanks.

headline: The Ryan Role
text: Links added

headline: Ugandan Copters, en Route to Battle Shabab, Disappear Over Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — At least two Ugandan military helicopters, crucial assets in a push against militants in Somalia, have vanished over Kenya, officials in Nairobi said on Monday.

headline: Cincinnati Bengals, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: Temper any optimism you might have for the Cincinnati Bengals with a healthy sprinkle of caution. Yes, this is a relatively young team coming off a surprising postseason appearance. But we’ve seen this before. In 2005 the Bengals made the postseason only to lose in the wild-card round and then finish 8-8, 7-9 and 4-11-1 the next three years. In 2009, they surprisingly broke through with another wild-card appearance, only to lose that game and 12 more the following season. The Bengals have not had back-to-back playoff seasons in 30 years. They have not won a playoff game in 22 years — the N.F.L.’s longest current drought.

headline: I.B.M. Adds an African Lab to Its Growing Global Research Network
text: I.B.M. is opening a research center in Nairobi, adding an African lab to its global network.

headline: It’s the Accounting, Stupid
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

text: WHO is Paul Ryan?WHO chose him to join his campaign?

headline: What Are Paul Ryan’s Chances of Becoming President?
text: On Saturday when introducing his new running mate, Mitt Romney initially referred to Paul D. Ryan as the “next president of the United States.”

headline: This Week in Small Business: The Van Indicator
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Peltz Takes Seat on Ingersoll-Rand Board
text: The activist investor Nelson Peltz is joining the board of Ingersoll-Rand, heading off a potential proxy fight.

headline: The Good, the Bad and the Unforgettable
text: LONDON — Danny Boyle and the British started this Olympics off in unconventional fashion : a “Chariots of Fire” spoof; an ode to the National Health Service; geese and sheep on the same infield where Olympians would eventually throw javelins and discuses.

headline: Protesters In Hong Kong Ordered Out Of HSBC Site
text: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong judge on Monday gave a dwindling band of Occupy Hong Kong protesters two weeks to vacate the space below HSBC’s Asian headquarters, accepting a petition by the bank.

headline: Swiss Bank Julius Baer to Buy Bank of America Unit
text: LONDON — The Swiss bank Julius Baer agreed on Monday to buy the private banking operations outside the United States of Bank of America Merrill Lynch, in a deal that will increase the European firm’s assets under management by 40 percent.

headline: Defending a Sanctuary With Paint and Song
text: The cove yawns like a Cheshire cat’s ear-to-ear grin, inviting local inhabitants and tourists to stroll along a mile-long sandy beach. Considered by many to be the Caribbean’s finest, Flamenco Beach lies on Culebra, a tiny speck of land off Puerto Rico’s east coast that boasts a striking range of biodiversity. The human population of 1,800 is outnumbered by multitudes of migratory birds, sea turtles and marine life, including critically endangered leatherback and hawksbill sea turtles.

headline: An Antarctic State of Mind
text: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agency’s human spaceflight program.

headline: Premier of Australia Backs Plan on Refugees
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Julia Gillard of Australia endorsed a set of sweeping changes to immigration policy on Monday that would increase the number of refugees the country accepts by nearly half while reopening remote offshore detention centers that have been criticized by human rights groups as inhumane and ineffective.

headline: Syrian Rebels Claim First Jet Downing, in Possible Shift for War
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian rebels said Monday that they had shot down a Syrian fighter jet for the first time, raising new questions about the opposition’s military capabilities, and whether Syria’s control of the skies might be threatened.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Ruth Padawer on Parenting Boys Who Dress Up As Girls
text: Ruth Padawer, who teaches at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, wrote this week’s cover article on boys who like to dress up as girls. Her last article for the magazine was on reducing a pregnancy with twins to a single fetus.

headline: Consumer Reports Receives $2 Million Grant for Food Safety Study
text: Consumer Reports, the product-testing magazine, has received a $2 million grant from The Pew Charitable Trusts to engage in an ambitious two-year study of the safety of meat, poultry and other food items.

text: From the editorial page

headline: North Korea Reported to Be Pursuing Industrial Project With China
text: SEOUL, South Korea — An influential official from North Korea left for China on Monday to discuss building joint industrial complexes on their borders, the North’s state-run Korean Central News Agency reported.

headline: As Bird Talk Flies Off, a Question: What Magazine Do You Miss Most?
text: Monday brought news of the end of Bird Talk magazine. Adding to the indignity, subscribers were being sent copies of Dog Fancy in its place, Christine Haughney reports. (Sending copies of Cat Fancy with a smiling feline on the cover would be the cruelest cut of all, we suppose.)

headline: Monday Reading: Is Your Family Ready for a Volunteer Trip?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Daily Report: Google Unveils Plans for Motorola
text: Motorola Mobility, the ailing cellphone maker that Google bought in May, told employees Sunday that it would lay off 20 percent of its work force and close a third of its 94 offices worldwide, Claire Cain Miller reports in Monday’s New York Times.

text: Dear Diary:

headline: Elusive FinSpy Spyware Pops Up in 10 Countries
text: It is one of the more elusive commercial cyberespionage tools available. It is marketed as a way for governments to spy on criminals. And for over a year, virus hunters unsuccessfully tried to track it down. Now it is popping up across the globe, from Qatar to an Amazon server in the United States.

headline: Insane Clown Posse Says It’s Investigating F.B.I. Gang Report
text: The Detroit hip-hop duo Insane Clown Posse used the platform of its annual Gathering of the Juggalos festival to announce that it was pursuing an investigation into why its fans were classified as a gang in a report published by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline: Greek Economy Shrank 6.2% in Second Quarter
text: The Greek economy continues to contract rapidly, official data showed on Monday, a painful reminder of how Greece, the weakest member of the euro zone, was chasing a moving target in trying to meet its bailout obligations.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Decanter: The pendulum has swung away from overtly oaky wines as winemakers adopt a more refined approach to using barrels, Andrew Jefford reports. — Eric Asimov

headline: The Stalin in Putin
text: Thirteen members of the Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee were killed in Moscow 60 years ago this past Sunday. This tragedy is sometimes referred to as “Stalin’s last execution.” Surely other people were put to death before the tyrant died in March 1953, but it was the last of the show trials to have been completed. The date has also often been referred to in the West as The Night of the Murdered Poets, based on the erroneous assumption that all of those killed wrote verse. In fact, the men were intellectuals from different fields.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Lobbying Romney to Pick Ryan, and Seeking an Olympic Afterglow
text: Mitt Romney’s selection of Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin over the weekend to be his running mate is being credited with shoring up Mr. Romney’s conservative bona fides — something his campaign would have known because conservative publications had been telling him through editorials that he should pick Mr. Ryan to shore up his conservative bona fides. The Weekly Standard and The Wall Street Journal both wrote editorials promoting Mr. Ryan for the Republican ticket: The Journal’s editorial on Thursday (Why Not Paul Ryan?) and The Weekly Standard’s editorial dated Monday but online earlier (Go for the Gold, Mitt!). Perhaps this is the reason, Michael Barbaro writes, that Mr. Romney’s camp was eager to announce the day he made the decision, Aug. 1: “Mr. Romney is sensitive to the perception that he acts at the behest of the party’s right wing. Now, he is making the case that he had settled on Mr. Ryan well before a chorus of conservatives told him to.”

headline: India’s Olympic Program Under Spotlight Again
text: Six medals. That is all that India – the world’s second most populous country – managed to win at the London Olympics. While six is a record, it is still a pitiful showing for a country with ambitions to become a great power.

headline: Being Sikh in America
text: DELHI — From 1988 to 1993 I was a graduate student at New York University. Like many nonobservant Sikhs, I did not wear a turban, but I did keep a beard. When I would travel to small-town America, my appearance sometimes gave rise to a barely concealed hostility, occasionally even a comment or two.

headline: Olympic Politics: What Does It Mean for Boris?
text: Big sport can sometimes get tangled up with big politics, and the just-ended Olympic Games in London — the subject of my latest column — was no exception.

headline: Stately Homes of a Five-and-Dime Store Founder
text: Crescent Beach Road in Glen Cove, on Long Island, is a pleasant suburban stretch, all pitched roofs and tidy green lawns. On a leisurely drive, it might look like a million other serene spots around the country, until suddenly, something very different emerged from around the bend: a towering marble archway about 15 feet high, which appears at the side of the road like a gateway to another era, fallen from the sky.

headline: Lars von Trier Seeks Film Submissions for User-Generated Project
text: While he prepares for his next act of cinematic provocation, the Danish director Lars von Trier is inviting audiences to engage in their own acts of button-pushing filmmaking as part of a user-generated project that seeks reinterpretations of well-known works by Paul Gauguin, August Strindberg and Albert Speer, among others.

headline: Street Style: Chambray Shirts
text: The best of readers’ looks for the week of Aug. 6.

headline: On Our Radar: Paul Ryan’s Environmental Record
text: The announcement of Mitt Romney’s choice of running mate elicits a round of critiques of Paul Ryan’s environmental record. [The Huffington Post]

headline: Business Day Live | August 13, 2012
text: As it seeks to reinvent Motorola, Google cuts jobs. | Britain cleans up and tallies its tab after the Olympics.

headline: Gender Split for Debate Moderators
text: The moderating duties for the four presidential and vice-presidential debates this year will be evenly split between male and female journalists for the first time, the Commission on Presidential Debates said Monday, nearly two months before debate season begins.

headline: Glow With the Flow
text: First there was the raw food movement. Then came macrobiotics, followed by the all-mighty juice cleanse. The latest detox craze isn’t something you can ingest, but it has plenty of people drinking the proverbial Kool-Aid. A cardiovascular procedure called External Counter Pulsation therapy, cleared by the F.D.A. in 1987 for the treatment of angina, claims to stimulate and clear collaterals (small blood vessels) to bypass narrow or clogged arteries. During the procedure, a patient’s legs are strapped to an adjustable bed using pressurized cuffs hooked up to a heart monitor. The cuffs inflate and deflate in sync with the heartbeat, pumping blood upward, so it can oxygenate more rapidly and distribute with greater ease. Now rebranded as Pure Flow Pulsation at New York’s PureFlow, E.C.P. is being offered, under the guidance of the cardiologist Dr. Samir Shah, as a multipurpose remedy for everything from fatigue to weight gain. (Andrew Barile, PureFlow’s co-founder, says that a 45-minute session is the aerobic equivalent of a seven-and-a-half-mile walk.) Some New Yorkers are swearing by it. “At first I wasn’t convinced, but by the third session I noticed that, for the first time in 20 years, I was able to enjoy a full night’s sleep without interruption,” says Celeste Fierro, a restaurant and nightclub consultant. Her tolerance for alcohol is lower, too. “I used to be able to drink a bottle of wine at dinner, and now I can only take a glass.” And for the Tom Ford stylist Sabrina Baldieri, the results are outwardly apparent, too. “I have more control over my weight,” she says. “It also gives me immediate relief from jet lag and an overall glow.”

headline: Climate Insight From a Magical Mountain Range
text: As many people know, human civilization arose during a particularly stable period in the history of the earth – the Holocene, encompassing the 12,000 years since the end of the last ice age. It may have been no accident that civilization burst forth during an era when ice had retreated from some of the most favorable land and when climate, sea level and other conditions had settled down after the turbulence of the ice age.

headline: Romney/Ryan: The Real Target

It is not about satisfying the conservative base, which was motivated anyway by Obama-hatred; it is not about refocusing on the issues, because R&R are both determined to avoid providing any of the crucial specifics about their plans. It is — as Jonathan Chait also seems to understand — about exploiting the gullibility and vanity of the news media, in much the same way that George W. Bush did in 2000.

headline: Could Ryan Tip Wisconsin Toward Romney?

headline: What Paul Ryan Doesn’t Offer
text: Anyone who’s picked up a newspaper or turned on a TV news program in the last 48 hours knows by now that Paul Ryan, Mitt Romney’s running mate, is best known as the very conservative author of a very conservative budget plan, which would cut $6 trillion from federal spending over the next 10 years. Anyone who’s ventured below the fold probably also knows that he’s a social conservative: He opposes same-sex marriage and has said that he’s “as pro-life as a person gets,” which seems accurate since he’s the co-sponsor of a bill that would grant fetuses “all the legal and constitutional attributes and privileges of personhood.”

headline: The Sound of New York’s Skaters
text: “None of us can skateboard. We just don’t have the coordination, I guess,” says Michael Ian Cummings, the lead singer for a band called, of all things, Skaters. “The name just reminds me of my youth and the way I felt listening to music and hanging out with my friends running around the city being a hooligan.” The self-invented, devil-may-care attitude that’s characterized both skate culture and the irreverent sound of so many New York bands (the Ramones and Suicide come to mind) has had a big influence on Skaters, who released their debut EP, “Schemers,” for free on the Web earlier this year. A rose-colored, wistful affection for the city is shared by the group’s three members — Cummings, Noah Rubin (drums) and Joshua Hubbard (guitar) — and can be heard loud and clear in songs like “Good Weird Woman,” with its subway-station-sounding saxophone, and “Are We Just Doomed?” a bittersweet account of leaving home and hardly sleeping, something any New York band worth its salt knows intimately. “I couldn’t imagine making or listening to this music in any other environment,” Cummings says. And even without the skateboards or skills, Skaters do look the part. Dressed in the British men’s-wear label Folk, as they were for their T photo shoot, there’s no covering up their romantically ragged edges.

Why risk it?

headline: Deck Chairs That Crossed the Atlantic
text: In 2009, Tamra Gallant, a Vancouver-based entrepreneur with a background in woodworking, visited Great Britain and saw deck chairs in parks and on beaches that she wished could be readily found in North America. She founded Gallant & Jones with Gwyneth Jones, a textile designer, and began producing similar chairs in white oak and organic cotton fabrics. “We made them ourselves at first because we’re perfectionists,” Ms. Jones said. Naturally protected from water damage and rot, the oak frame has a coating of ultraviolet-resistant oil for further safekeeping. The sling and pillow fabrics are easily removable for cleaning and storage. Available through Lin Morris starting at $280, lin-morris.com.

headline: A Tutoring Company in Search of a Tag Line
text: For the last couple of months, Alexandra Mayzler, a member of the She Owns It business group, has struggled to come up with a new tag line for her company, Thinking Caps Tutoring. Thinking Caps, which she started in her college dorm room, has outgrown its current tag, “Students teaching students.” Settling on something new that both sounds good and differentiates the company has been so difficult that she wonders how she ever came up with the first one.

headline: Dad! That’s Not How Mom Does It!
text: A few years ago reality television was approaching its social-experiment phase, with new series that appeared to have been cooked up in university psychology seminars. In 2006, there was “Black. White.,” in which two families — one white, one black — switched races for several weeks with the aid of makeup and some credulous supporting cast members. The next year came “Kid Nation,” which unleashed a group of rugrats onto a spit of land in New Mexico and watched them attempt to build a new society, all while flirting with the fine print of child labor laws.

headline: Not the Death, but the Details
text: When John Banville inaugurated his pseudonymous series of Benjamin Black books in 2007 with “Christine Falls,” this esteemed author seemed to have taken an iffy turn. The Banville name would be reserved for literary fiction (like “The Sea,” winner of the Man Booker Prize); Benjamin Black would swim in the supposedly shallower waters of the whodunit. The Black books were said to be much more casually and quickly written than the serious ones. Mr. Banville would have no trouble keeping his august reputation and his day job.

To hear him tell it, little, if anything, should distinguish the two.

headline: ‘Bring It On’ Starts Modestly at Sis-Boom-Box Office
text: The only new Broadway musical of the summer, “Bring It On,” grossed $472,810 in its first full week after opening on Aug. 1, a modest showing at the box office that was still promising enough for the producers to announce a three-month extension of performances. “Bring It On,” inspired by the 2000 movie about a high school cheerleading rivalry, took in only 39 percent of its maximum possible gross last week – in part because many choice seats were not on sale at three performances. Those tickets instead went complimentary to late-coming critics and other members of the media.

headline: NBC Says Nearly 220 Million Watched the Olympics
text: NBC announced on Monday that its coverage of the London Olympics was the most watched entertainment or sporting event ever on American television.

headline: Finding Their Way to Concert Halls: Blackbirds, Sea Gulls and Chickens
text: The most famous bird in Mozart lore is the starling he bought with some silver coins in 1784 and buried, with much part-serious solemnity, three years later. He transcribed its song in his notebook along with the price he paid for it — 34 kreutzer — and the melody, which he may well have taught it, closely resembles the carefree opening theme of his Piano Concerto No. 17.

headline: Romney, Mormonism and Money

My argument runs counter to some of the arguments in Adam Gopnik’s tour d’horizon of Mormonism in a recent issue of the New Yorker, and particularly this passage:

It is the latest in a series of mass pardons set to coincide with national holidays in the isolated former Soviet republic. Turkmen state media reported on Monday that 44 foreigners would be among those pardoned.

headline: Slowly, Dickey Approaches Rare Feat

headline: Palestinian Seeks Diplomatic Allies
text: Hanan Ashrawi, a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization’s executive committee, asked diplomats from two dozen countries on Monday to support the Palestinian Authority’s renewed bid for observer-state status at the United Nations, calling it “a test of the whole rule of law.” Speaking in East Jerusalem to envoys from countries in Europe, Latin America, Asia and the Middle East, Ms. Ashrawi asked them not only to vote for the future United Nations resolution on observer-state status, possibly this fall, but to provide the Palestinian Authority with a financial “safety net” when, she predicted, “Americans decide to cut off aid” because of the bid. The Palestinians’ plan is to petition the United Nations General Assembly, where passage is all but assured. That would give the Palestinians access to organizations like the International Criminal Court, where they hope to pursue claims against Israel on matters like settlements.

headline: Let the Real Debate Begin
text: Mitt Romney’s choice of Paul Ryan to be his running mate is — do I dare say this? — good news for lots of people. Conservative Republicans will mobilize around a deeply conservative Tea Party hero, who will help ease their essential discomfort with their presumptive presidential nominee. Democrats will try to make political hay over the shrink-the-government budget proposals that Ryan, a congressman from Wisconsin, has rolled out in the House, starting with his plan to “save” Medicare by essentially creating a voucher program that would inevitably cause seniors to pay for more of their own health care.

headline: Quinn Seeks to Expand City Program Benefiting Companies Owned by Minorities and Women
text: Responding to longstanding appeals from civil rights groups, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, plans to introduce a bill that would significantly expand New York City’s efforts to direct contracts to companies owned by women and minorities.

headline: Free Speech, Even if Hateful

headline: Where Do Sentences Come From?
text: Sift the debris of a young writer’s education, and you find dreadful things — strictures, prohibitions, dos, don’ts, an unnatural and nearly neurotic obsession with style, argument and transition. Yet in that debris you find no traces of a fundamental question: where do sentences come from? This is a philosophical question, as valuable in the asking as in the answering. But it’s a practical question, too. Think about it long enough, and you begin to realize that many, if not most, of the things we believe about writing are false.

headline: WikiLeaks Stirs Global Fears on Antiterrorist Software
text: WASHINGTON — A new release of stolen corporate e-mails by WikiLeaks has set off a flurry of concern and speculation around the world about a counterterrorist software program called TrapWire, which analyzes images from surveillance cameras and other data to try to identify terrorists planning attacks.

headline: Israel and Iran
text: Israeli leaders are again talking about possible military action against Iran. This is, at best, mischievous and, at worst, irresponsible, especially when diplomacy has time to run.

headline: Systematic Office Sabotage, With a Smile

headline: Summer Hideaways
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — The epitaph that Thomas Jefferson wrote for himself lists precisely three accomplishments: that he authored the Declaration of Independence and the Virginia Statute of Religious Freedom and that he founded the University of Virginia. (Not one to pad a résumé, Jefferson refrained from mentioning, you know, his presidency.) If you knew this, you probably had no trouble filling in 46 Across, which referred to the establishment of UVA. It’s just one of many clues in today’s Ian Livengood-constructed puzzle that seems perfectly suited for mid-August: tossed in alongside vacation destinations in the theme, there are a couple of nagging reminders of school.

headline: 3 Dead, Including Gunman, in Shooting Near Texas A&M
text: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — A gunman opened fire on police officers near the Texas A&M University campus shortly after noon on Monday, killing at least two people, including a local constable, and wounding four others, the police said. The gunman, who was shot by officers, died after he was taken into custody.

headline: Repair New York City’s Housing Issues
text: More than 650,000 people live in housing that is controlled or subsidized by the New York City Housing Authority. Too many have to wait for months for needed repairs to leaking plumbing and other problems. In an estimated 10,000 apartments, repairs are not scheduled until 2014. This is clearly unacceptable.

headline: Mexico: Suspect Linked to Veracruz Killings, Officials Say
text: The Mexican Navy announced Monday that a man suspected of being a member of a drug gang had been captured while carrying the identification cards of a recently slain newspaper employee in the state of Veracruz. The authorities link the suspect, Juan Carlos Hernández Pulido, whom they captured Friday, to the killing of the newspaper employee, Irasema Becerra. Her dismembered remains were found in May along with those of three photojournalists. Six journalists have been killed in Mexico so far this year; five of them in Veracruz. None of the crimes have been solved yet.

In the late summer stretch from now into September, this topic is bound to heat up as Michelle Obama and Ann Romney make their own campaign stops — though 2012 is no 2008 when it comes to up-ending age-old paradigms for women in politics.

headline: No Longer Stagnating, Euro Zone Contracts

headline: Baltimore Ravens, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: There are 27 seconds left in the A.F.C championship game. The visiting Baltimore Ravens trail the New England Patriots by 3. It’s second-and-1. Quarterback Joe Flacco is dropping back to pass. He has completed five of his last seven throws on what’s turning out to be a brilliant 56-yard drive. Flacco calmly pump-fakes and then slings a laser between two defenders in the front corner of the end zone. The ball lands in the hands of wide receiver Lee Evans. It’s an incredible throw – the type of throw that exhibits why the Ravens took Flacco in the first round, the type of throw that makes fans forget about Flacco’s middling 57.6 percent accuracy in the  regular season or his four-year reputation as the young quarterback who isn’t ready to push a great Ravens club over the top.

headline: Blaming Obama for George W. Bush’s Policies

headline: The One Task I Can’t Seem to Delegate
text: The other day, three yearly license plate renewal stickers arrived in the mail for three of my company vehicles. This meant someone would have to put the stickers on and replace the registration card in each of the cars. Normally, that someone would be me. While I have become quite adept at delegating almost everything else, the combination of vehicles and stickers has long been a surprising source of grief, education and humor for me. I have given speeches about my failures to manage this process.

Go to georgialouise.co.uk; (212) 388-0800.

headline: A Polymer to Protect Phones From Impact
text: The super-shock-absorbent material called non-Newtonian polymer inspires a lot of don’t-try-this-at-home stunts, like getting whacked in the head with a shovel through a layer of the stuff.

headline: Hard Truth for Author: Publisher Pulls ‘The Jefferson Lies’
text: Last month the History News Network voted David Barton’s book “The Jefferson Lies” the “least credible history book in print.” Now the book’s publisher, Thomas Nelson, has decided to stop publishing and distributing it.

headline: Daily Report: Google Buys Frommer’s, in Continuing Effort to Produce Original Content
text: Google made another foray into producing original content when it announced on Monday its plans to buy the Frommer’s brand of travel guides from John Wiley & Sons to augment its local and travel search results, reports Claire Cain Miller on Tuesday in The New York Times.

headline: A Not Insubstantial Pageant
text: LONDON — In the end, nothing went terribly wrong, and more went right than anyone could have anticipated. If this sounds like faint praise, it isn’t. For seven years, the Olympics have been bearing down on London filling it with anxiety and an anticipation that were scarcely articulated — at least until the Olympic torch landed on this island and all along the length and breadth of the country, often in driving rain, people lined the streets to watch it go past.

headline: Cleaning a River That Was Given Up for Dead
text: In 1984, when the Environmental Protection Agency put the old Diamond Alkali factory in Newark on its list of the most heavily polluted places in the country, the agency was not thinking about the Passaic River, which runs right in front of the plant.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Mediaite: Meet Paul Ryan: running mate, Congressional leader, fiscal watchdog — and former driver of the Oscar Meyer Wienermobile. Specializing in turkey bacon and Lunchables. (Via Grist.) — Patrick Farrell

headline: Getting It Right
text: We’re quick enough at City Room to pounce on errors made in the public sphere. We should be equally prompt in acknowledging when problems are solved.

headline: Tech and Financials Slump, Thwarting a Market Rally
text: Stocks were mixed in light trading on Tuesday, with the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index falling for a second day, as a slump in technology and financial shares reversed an earlier rally that followed a report of better-than-expected retail sales.

headline: A Wide Receiver’s New Reality
text: Perhaps we should thank Chad Johnson for officially welcoming us to football season. Because the N.F.L. cannot really begin until some nonsense involving a past-his-prime receiver reminds us there is no I in team, but there is in “oh geez, not another reality show.” This is possibly now in the N.F.L. rule book. So, Johnson merely stepped up to perform his duty as past-his-prime receiver with the celebrity ego gone off the rails. That he got arrested on domestic violence charges against the woman he just married on reality TV and well, you have the proper absurdity points for a full-fledged fiasco.

headline: On Our Radar: A Colossal Burmese Python
text: University of Florida researchers dissect the largest Burmese python ever found in the state, measuring 17 feet, 7 inches and weighing 164 pounds. The snake, an invasive species, was carrying 87 eggs, highlighting the challenge of controlling a population estimated to have grown to tens of thousands of snakes in South Florida. [Ocala.com]

headline: Afghan Attacks Kill Dozens in Deadliest Day for Civilians This Year
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Bombings and shootings took the lives of at least 43 Afghans on Tuesday in the deadliest day for civilians this year as insurgents struck while people were preparing for the Muslim holiday that ends the month of Ramadan.

headline: Business Day Live | Vending Machine Tech
text: The vending machine business gets a technology makeover.

headline: Business Day Live | August 14, 2012
text: Weighing the costs of ever-faster stock trades. | Strong currency accelerates Canada’s decline as an automaker. | For a financial rule designed to protect taxpayers, legislative limbo.

headline: Timely | Camera Sly
text: Aïda Ruilova’s compact, psychologically charged videos, which have been shown everywhere from the Venice Biennale to a Jumbotron in Times Square, don’t so much draw you in as snare you in a relentless loop with no hope of climax or resolution. Her latest, a collaboration with the director Abel Ferrara, begins with a conversation about Pier Paolo Pasolini’s death and veers into a wholly tangential discourse on love, hustlers, desire, drugs, conspiracy, film scripts and the actress Zoë Lund. It will be shown at the New Museum in New York this fall and at Kayne Griffin Corcoran in Los Angeles next spring. And then there is Ruilova’s continuing collaboration with her husband, the artist Raymond Pettibon. “Having a baby is the ultimate ready-made,” she says of their infant son. “We make videos with him every day.”

headline: Will Indian Women Ever Have the Freedom Not to Marry?
text: Behind the Bollywood dream of the Great Indian Wedding, complete with white horse and brass bands, the reality for many Indian women is stark: there isn’t much alternative to marriage. Does it have to be this way for the next generation? How long can tradition be used to justify marrying off women before they’re old enough to make good choices — or to pressure women into marriage, because being single is not a culturally acceptable choice?

headline: Shining a Light on Obama
text: This photograph from The Associated Press is creating a fair amount of chatter this morning, and is naturally prompting some caption-writing contests. No, it is not doctored, and it captured President Obama speaking at Bayliss Park in Council Bluffs, Iowa, on Monday.

headline: Guggenheim Announces ‘Works & Process’ Performance Season
text: The Royal Danish Ballet, the director Robert Lepage and an expert on the neuroscience of taste will be featured in the fall season of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum’s Works & Process series, which begins Sept. 9. The performances, aimed at giving audiences insight into the creative process, will take place in the museum’s Peter B. Lewis Theater. Most events will also be livestreamed.

headline: The Art of Reef Conservation
text: What’s not to like about the work of Jason deCaires Taylor? The 37-year-old sculptor, raised in England, Spain and Malaysia, has found a way to blend a love of diving and coral reefs with his art — which he crafts on dry land and then lowers into the seas, where, he says, it diverts divers who might otherwise spend too much time poking at fragile reefs. The sculptures themselves, with time, end up as homes for corals, sponges and other marine life.

headline: Throughout the City, a New Generation of Street Signs
text: This message is addressed to New Yorkers who were more surprised to see a street sign with uppercase and lowercase letters than they were to learn that an intersection in Harlem had been named for Judge Bruce McM. Wright:

headline: Estadio Azteca: Into the Lion’s Den
text: On Wednesday, when the United States plays Mexico in a friendly in Mexico City, the Americans will try to earn their first victory on the home soil of their greatest rival: they are 0-23-1 in Mexico since the first game in 1937, a 7-2 drubbing. To win, they will need to beat Mexico in the Estadio Azteca, one of the most famed stadiums in the world: a 105,000-seat caldron perched at an elevation of 7,200 feet.

headline: Wheelies: The Driverless Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Frank Ocean Cancels European Performances
text: Frank Ocean has abruptly canceled his European tour, including several festival appearances and a series of high-profile concerts with Coldplay. Mr. Ocean, an R&B singer who drew international attention when he revealed last month that his first true love was with a man, did not give a reason for his decision.

headline: Should Candidates Talk About Climate Change?
text: 1:16 p.m. | Updates below | Anthony Leiserowitz, the director of the Yale Project on Climate Change Communication, just sent the note below about a new analysis of climate attitudes. I’m posting it here as part of a continuing effort to point to notable news and analysis out there in the firehose flood  of information:

headline: Hand-Turned Rolling Pins Banish Lumps and Bumps
text: Though the job of fashioning the dough for fresh fruit pies, tarts, cobblers and such can be improvised with a wine bottle, it really calls for a well-made rolling pin that’s sleek and balanced. Vermont Rolling Pins are hand turned, in eight styles, including a hefty classic Shaker model (top); a simple column; a lighter, sharply tapered French style (center) that is a dream to use for delicate pastry; and several finished with handsome carved finials and handles. They can be ordered in a choice of woods, including cherry, maple and walnut. The Shaker, French and column styles also come in child’s versions (bottom).

headline: Image of the Day: August 14
text: Boxer Mary Kom received a warm welcome on her return home.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | Punk Rockers, Scientists, Cheerleaders and Activists
text: Updated | Aug. 18, 2012

headline: Good Enough to Make Farm-Stand Peaches Blush
text: Farm stands are piled high with the perfect argument for not buying most supermarket peaches. So why even consider the organic fruit from Frog Hollow Farm in Brentwood, Calif.? Because the farm ships its big, handsome peaches unblemished and ready to savor, dripping with rich juice. Unlike many farm-stand peaches, these have their skins brushed to be less fuzzy. And they include unusual varieties. Cal Reds, weighing 6 to 7 ounces each, are ready now. The skin deepens to burgundy, and within, the golden, fairly firm, satiny flesh is sweet but trimmed with tartness. They are excellent to halve and grill, to slice atop a tart or to serve plain with a glass of prosecco. The Cal Reds will be finished in about 10 days, but the harvest continues into mid-September with giant Summersets and juicy Autumn Flames.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: It’s About the Boomers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Keeping the Lobster but Losing the Gluten
text: Gluten-free with no compromise describes the new version of lobster mac and cheese from Hancock Gourmet Lobster in Cundy’s Harbor, Me. Gluten-free? Really? The macaroni is a quinoa pasta, its lush mascarpone cream sauce is thickened with a little gluten-free flour, and the breadcrumb topping is made from corn, rice and grated cheese. The serving is liberally studded with chunks of lobster.

headline: Israel Names New Home Front Minister
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Tuesday named an old army friend from a rival political party as his new home front minister, amid growing concern here about preparedness for the response to a potential attack on Iran this fall.

headline: Rainbow Trout Baked in Foil With Tomatoes, Garlic and Thyme
text: My friend Christine always makes salmon prepared this way when I arrive at her home in Provence after my long trip from California. It’s a great dish to make when you don’t know exactly when guests are going to arrive, as everything can be prepared in advance and the fish can be baked at the last minute. I’ve adapted Christine’s salmon recipe to rainbow trout, which are farmed in a sustainable way and less expensive than wild salmon.

headline: A Giant Hospital Chain Is Blazing a Profit Trail
text: During the Great Recession, when many hospitals across the country were nearly brought to their knees by growing numbers of uninsured patients, one hospital system not only survived — it thrived.

headline: The Making of Rear Admiral Farragut
text: “Yesterday I hoisted my flag at the main, and the whole fleet cheered, which I returned with a most dignified salute,” wrote David Glasgow Farragut, commander of the Union’s Western Gulf Blockading Squadron, to his family on Aug. 12, 1862. “I called all hands, and read the act of Congress complimentary of their achievements. I got under way, and stood down the river, leaving a general order to be read to the fleet. I stopped at the forts, to let the men see what they had done to deserve the resolutions.”

headline: Rare Otto Frank Archive to Be Auctioned in New York
text: An archive of documents and artifacts relating to Otto Frank, the father of Anne Frank, will be auctioned off on Nov. 5 at Doyle New York, the auction house has announced.

headline: ‘Insufficient’ Evidence for Routine Hearing Tests, Experts Say
text: Hearing tests are cheap and effective. There are no known health harms. And they can identify older adults with compromised hearing who might benefit from using a hearing aid.

headline: Science Minister Vilasrao Deshmukh Dies at 67
text: Vilasrao Deshmukh, the minister for science and technology and a former Maharashtra chief minister, died of multiple organ failure in Chennai on Tuesday afternoon. Mr. Deshmukh, 67, had been suffering from liver cancer over the past six months.

headline: Fall Poetry Festival Lineups Announced
text: Poetry may make nothing happen, as W. H. Auden once wrote. But in October it will bring an unusual number of poets and poetry mavens to the greater New York area. The United States poet laureate Natasha Trethewey, the Pulitzer Prize winner C. K. Williams, the former New Jersey poet laureate Amiri Baraka and dozens of others will gather in Newark on Oct. 11-14 for the 14th Geraldine R. Dodge Poetry Festival, a biennial event that bills itself as North America’s largest poetry event. And Oct. 18-20, the American Academy of Poets will present its sixth annual Poets Forum, which will feature readings and discussions on issues like poetry and social media (the subject of a lecture by Jorie Graham), and poetry-themed walking tours of Harlem, the West Village, the Museum of Modern Art and SoHo.

headline: Cincinnati Is Federer’s Kind of Town
text: MASON, Ohio — “You know why we like Stan Wawrinka here?” a fan said as he watched Wawrinka, the Swiss professional player, play a first-round match at the Western & Southern Open in Cincinnati last year.

headline: New Woodward Book Due in September
text: The fall books season just got a little more crowded. Bob Woodward’s 17th book, “The Price of Politics,” will be published on Sept. 11, his publisher said on Tuesday, in the splashy, embargoed style that has been a trademark of a Woodward release.

headline: ‘Undisguised Blackmail’
text: If there is any chance of a diplomatic solution on Iran’s nuclear program – admittedly a long shot – the major powers have to stand united on sanctions, incentives and negotiating strategy. The United States and its partners (Britain, France, Germany, Russia and China) have managed that pretty well since President Obama took office, despite what Mitt Romney  might say on the campaign trail. But the Russians are getting anxious.

headline: Before Dropping Algebra, Fix Math Education
text: In an opinion article in response to a recent New York Times essay, a parent writes: "Before dropping algebra in favor of more ‘useful’ mathematics, we would do well to first examine how we deliver and assess the most fundamental aspects of math education."

headline: Trying to Deposit Checks With My New iPhone
text: Bank of America has (finally) begun offering a check deposit feature on its mobile banking app for smartphones and tablets. The addition gave me the push I needed to try mobile banking on my new iPhone. So I tested it, with varying results.

headline: A Historical Benchmark for Religion and Race
text: With the choice of Paul D. Ryan to be the Republican vice- presidential nominee, not one person in a group of top political jobs — the presidential and vice-presidential nominees of both parties, the Supreme Court justices, the speaker of the House or the Senate majority leader — is a white Protestant. That group instead comprises nine Catholics (six justices, Mr. Ryan, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Speaker John A. Boehner), three Jews (on the court), two Mormons (Mitt Romney and Senator Harry Reid) and one African-American Protestant (President Obama). For much of American history, white Protestants dominated the top rungs of American government.

headline: Increasing Limits, and Safety, for Teenage Drivers
text: How much does it matter that “Youth Driving Laws Limit Even the Double Date”?

headline: At NBC, the Thrill Is Gone Along With the Audience
text: NBC got its first taste of the difference between the Olympics and anything else it can offer in prime time: its audience Monday night dropped about 25 million from the network’s Olympic highs.

headline: Unimpressed by Micron’s Offer, Elpida Bondholders Offer Alternative
text: Bondholders of Elpida Memory, the Japanese chip maker, are not giving up without a fight.

headline: Taylor Swift Announces New Album
text: Taylor Swift, one of the biggest-selling pop stars in recent years, said on Monday that she would release her fourth studio album on Oct. 22. The album, “Red,” will have 16 songs, including the title track, she told fans during a nighttime Web chat event filmed in her living room in Nashville.

headline: HCA’s Growing Profit
text: Since 2006, when HCA was taken private in a leveraged buyout, profits at its acute-care hospitals have soared. Total margin, a measure of financial performance, has remained far higher at HCA hospitals than at other similar institutions.

headline: In Monterey, Dressing Up a Bugatti for a Dress-Down Affair
text: Jean Bugatti incorporated a good deal of advanced engineering into the Type 64 Coupe, the last Bugatti produced by a member of the Franco-Italian clan. But only three Type 64s were built before Bugatti’s death in a testing accident in 1939. The grieving family never completed chassis No. 64002, and it remained without a body for 73 years.

headline: Amid Insider Trading Inquiry, Tiger Asia Calls It Quits
text: Tiger Asia, a spinoff of Tiger Management, the hedge fund founded by Julian Robertson, told investors in a letter that the fund would be returning their money in the coming weeks as a result of a “prolonged legal situation.”

headline: The Daily Shoe | Tod’s
text: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon in honor of the store’s 111th anniversary. Today’s pick: Tod’s classic driving shoe in ultra-soft snakeskin. $925.

headline: OrderAhead Wants to Offer Takeout for Everything, on Your Phone
text: Ever call your favorite restaurant to order lunch, then wait an excruciating amount of time in line to pay and pick up your meal — only to get home and realize the restaurant gave you tuna salad instead of tuna niçoise?

headline: U.S. Airlines Set Records For Punctuality, Baggage
text: The 15 largest domestic airlines have set records for on-time performance, for the fewest long tarmac delays and for the lowest rates of canceled flights and mishandled baggage during the first six months of this year.

headline: Primaries to Watch in Florida and Wisconsin
text: Voters head to the polls in four states Tuesday to winnow their picks for the House and Senate, and the addition of Representative Paul D. Ryan to the Republican ticket has the potential to add a new dynamic to some of the races.

headline: Read All About It: Brooklyn Is Hip
text: Brooklyn’s days as an unsophisticated and unfashionable urban backwater? Over.

headline: ‘Stars Earn Stripes': Respect for Troops, or Fake Soldier Games?
text: Well, they came, they geared up, they zip-lined and they gushed about getting a taste of the military life. In a two-hour premiere last night, “Stars Earn Stripes” paired eight stars with experts including a former Navy Seal, a member of the Army’s Delta Force and a SWAT commander.

headline: Pulling Together Real Stracciatella
text: PERHAPS love was in the air. I was on my honeymoon in Italy, after all. But when I took my first bite of just-made stracciatella, thin strands of fresh mozzarella soaked in heavy cream, I knew I had found another true love.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Tod’s
text: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon. Today’s pick: Tod’s classic driving shoe in ultrasoft snakeskin.

headline: Bloomberg Urges Campaigns to Discuss Immigration Reform
text: 9:50 p.m. | Updated  BOSTON — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined Rupert Murdoch, the chief of the News Corp. media company, in Boston on Tuesday night, appearing in the same city as Mitt Romney’s campaign headquarters to make an economic argument for immigration reform and call for a more substantial discussion of the issue in the presidential campaign.

headline: A Park’s Starring Role in a Yearly Ritual
text: “Into the woods, each time you go,/There’s more to learn of what you know.” It was hard not to be reminded of those Sondheim lyrics last week when I went to Central Park, which is as close as many New Yorkers get to the woods, for the latest Shakespeare in the Park production. Dodging bikers and runners, walking up the gentle slope and through one of the wooden pathways to arrive at the Delacorte Theater, I was reminded of my first visit years ago.

headline: Can a Banker Think Like an Entrepreneur?
text: In a just-published New York Times article, I write about Jolyne Caruso, a Wall Street veteran who founded the Alberleen Group, a company that applies the incubator concept — ubiquitous in the world of tech start-ups — to investment banking. The Alberleen Group provides seasoned investment bankers with the infrastructure and working capital to start their own firms. In exchange, it takes a revenue share.

headline: The Dolphin Lover’s Conundrum
text: People who express the greatest concern about protecting Florida’s wild dolphins are often the same ones who break laws about feeding, petting or swimming with the charismatic species, according to a new study commissioned by the National Marine Fisheries Service. And the report suggests that dolphin harassment is on the rise.

headline: Profile in Style | Hannelore Knuts
text: Perhaps the worst thing you could call Hannelore Knuts  is a model-turned-fill-in-the-blank. Fortunately, the title doesn’t really apply. After 14 years in the business, the 34-year-old Belgian is still modeling — and does five hours of boxing workouts a week to keep it that way. She is also taking photographs: she shot her first campaign, for the French men’s brand Arnys. She acts: she’s in the first feature by her boyfriend, the artist Nicolas Provost, and she will play David Bowie in a Radio Soulwax video. She designs bags for Delvaux and just put the finishing touches on a bike for Marniek Kint, which she describes as having a slightly off-white frame, a fluorescent pink brake cable, classic racing handlebars and a hot pink basket. “Yep! The perfect man race bike for women,” she says. And not least, this fall she will appear on the Belgian version of “Dancing With the Stars.” So what do you call Knuts? Busy comes to mind.

headline: British Bank in $340 Million Settlement for Laundering
text: Standard Chartered, the British bank, has agreed to pay New York’s top banking regulator $340 million to settle claims that it laundered hundreds of billions of dollars in tainted money for Iran and lied to regulators.

headline: Biden Warns Romney Policies Would Put Crowd ‘Back in Chains’
text: 9:43 p.m. | Updated Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. created a stir Tuesday at a campaign speech in Virginia when he told the crowd that Mitt Romney’s policies would enable the banking and financial sectors to “put you all back in chains.”

headline: Police in Rome Seize Marijuana Farm Operating in Tunnel
text: ROME — The police have discovered and seized a sprawling marijuana farm in a tunnel in the capital built during the era of Mussolini. The crop had an estimated street value of $3.7 million.

headline: Mounting Injuries Trouble Giants; Are Beds to Blame?
text: ALBANY – Injuries are starting to pile up for the Giants just as the end of  training camp nears. On Tuesday, the team listed four defensive linemen with injuries: Marvin Austin (back), Chris Canty (knee), Martin Parker (back) and Shaun Rogers (leg).

headline: The Gifts She Gave
text: WHEN aspiring young food writers ask how I learned the trade — Was culinary school the first step? A journalism degree? Apprenticeship in a three-star kitchen in France? — I brace myself to disappoint them. I didn’t do any of those (extremely practical and admirable) things.

headline: Memories of a Friend, Sidekick and Foil
text: I TOLD Helen that I thought the manuscript was really good. In fact, it was the type of cookbook that I thought I would have written someday, and I was slightly jealous of it.

headline: In the Ordinary, Silicon Valley Is Finding the Next Big Thing
text: Square’s tie-up with Starbucks may be this year’s most important venture capital deal.

headline: Instead of a Bedtime Story, a Lullaby From Miles Davis
text: Make no mistake: Rain Pryor, the star of the autobiographical solo show “Fried Chicken and Latkes,” is not just defined by her father, the comedian Richard Pryor. She most definitely is her own woman. But she sure does one hell of an impersonation of her dad.

headline: Your Favorite Julia Child Recipes
text: Since it’s sold more than 2 million copies since 1961, you’d assume a lot of cooks have used “Mastering the Art of French Cooking” by Julia Child, who would have turned 100 on Wednesday. (She died in 2004.) But I found plenty of Julia Child fans who confessed under pressure that they had made only her coq au vin or boeuf bourguignon — and a lot of those people had made the dish just once.

headline: Court to Hear Google’s Challenge to Class-Action Lawsuit on Book Scanning
text: In May, the Authors Guild celebrated a decision in the long-running case over Google’s book-scanning project when a federal judge granted its authors class-action status.

headline: Despite Mixed Reviews, Producers Eyeing ‘Woods’ Move to Broadway
text: Theater producers are pursuing a possible Broadway transfer of the Central Park staging of “Into the Woods” in spite of several negative reviews last week that would usually put a damper on such plans.

headline: Tigers Stuck in Neutral
text: Things seemed so perfect in spring training for the Detroit Tigers. The team, on paper, had it all: ace pitchers in Justin Verlander and Doug Fister, a can’t-miss closer in Jose Valverde, a slugger in Miguel Cabrera and an off-season, big-money acquisition in Prince Fielder.

headline: The Apollo to Present ‘Ask Your Mama!’
text: “Ask Your Mama!” — the multimedia musical show based on the poetry of Langston Hughes — will be presented for one night at the Apollo Theater next spring, the theater announced on Tuesday.

text: The Ryan pick and the race for Congress. | Will Wisconsin flip? | Iowa fairgoers weigh in. | Chris Christie to keynote convention.

headline: Chelsea Clinton Does Not Rule Out Run for Office
text: Could another Clinton presidency be on the horizon? We’ll just have to wait and see — Chelsea Clinton, for one, is not ruling out a run someday for elected office.

headline: Nuclear Regulator Ticks Off Her Wish List
text: The new chairwoman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Tuesday that she had asked the agency’s staff to look into the likely effects of climate change on nuclear power reactors.

headline: Syrians Try to Balance Desires of Life With the Demands of a Growing War
text: ALEPPO, Syria — They can be seen clinging to their parents in war-damaged dwellings across Syria, and heard crying out in response to the gunfire and artillery that boom at all hours of the day and night.

headline: Raspberry Jam, Only Better
text: FOR years, homemade raspberry jam was the hands-down favorite in my house. The alchemy of sugar, berries and lemon juice makes a perfect fruity spread.

headline: TimesCast Politics: The Ryan Pick and the Race for Congress
text: The Ryan pick and the race for Congress. | Will Wisconsin flip? | Iowa fairgoers weigh in. | Chris Christie to keynote convention.

headline: So Soon, Another Sweathog Is Gone
text: First Robert Hegyes. Now, alas, Ron Palillo has left the classroom, dead of a heart attack at 63.

headline: New Ad Attacks Obama on Medicare
text: Mitt Romney‘s campaign signaled that it intended to fight rather than run from Democratic attacks over Republican Medicare policies, unveiling a new ad that stresses that President Obama cut $700 billion from the program.

headline: Medicare Confusion
text: An unnamed Republican operative told Politico this week that if Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan “win the battle to define Medicare” they will win the election, but “if they lose it, then they lose big in the fall.” Whether that’s accurate or not, the Romney campaign doesn’t seem to have figured out its Medicare messaging.

headline: Edible Selby | Live Stream
text: Ole-Martin Hansen moved from Norway to London 10 years ago to study sound art, but he soon found a very different calling: smoking salmon, the Norwegian way. At his North London shop, Hansen & Lydersen, he recreated his grandfather’s special smoking chamber in a 1950s boiler room, where he flavors fresh salmon from Denmark’s Faroe Islands with beechwood and juniper, and uses small fans to blow air on the fish. “The salmon needs to move,” he explains. After curing the fish with salt from Guérande, France, Hansen sends it to some of London’s finest restaurants and markets. Lest there be any doubt about his dedication to the fish, Hansen adds that the chamber is equipped with a piano, on which he plays them Edvard Grieg’s “In the Hall of the Mountain King.”

headline: Excerpt: 'Blind Date'
text: Andrea Lynn Green, left, and Hallie Foote in one of the one-act plays in "Harrison, TX: Three Plays by Horton Foote."

headline: Note to Self: Double-Check Those Electric Bills
text: Are you one of those people who pay monthly electric and gas charges without closely looking at the bills? (You know who you are.)

headline: Spike Lee’s Red Hook
text: Spike Lee, the director behind “Red Hook Summer,” discusses some of the Brooklyn locations where he shot his latest film.

headline: ‘Mirror Fasts’ Help Take the Focus Off Yourself
text: NARCISSUS had only a pool of water in which to gaze, but we see our reflections at almost every turn. In bathroom mirrors, shop windows, sliding subway doors, brass elevator banks and even in the screens of smartphones: no matter where you go, there you are. Mindful of what happened to Narcissus (it wasn’t good), some people are trying to abstain from looking at their reflections for a day, a week, a month or even a year.

headline: Wells Fargo Settles Mortgage-Crisis Case for $6.5 Million
text: Wells Fargo on Tuesday settled accusations that it sold troubled mortgage investments without fully researching the products or disclosing the risks to customers.

headline: Building a Turkish Empire, One Friend at a Time
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 14
text: A view of the day in sports, including an athletic competition for disabled soldiers in Diyagama, Sri Lanka, and Olympians returning to their home countries as sports heroes.

headline: ‘Smash’ Schedule Prompts Jeremy Jordan To Depart ‘Newsies’ on Sept. 4
text: Will the hit Broadway musical “Newsies” continue to flourish without its breakout star, Jeremy Jordan? Disney Theatrical Productions will soon find out. Disney executives said on Tuesday that Mr. Jordan, who has become an audience favorite as the brooding New York City newsboy Jack Kelly, would give his final performance on Sept. 4 so he can concentrate on his new leading role in the NBC series “Smash.” Disney also announced that a 22-year-old unknown, Corey Cott, who graduated from Carnegie Mellon University in May and joined the “Newsies” company last month, would take over the role of Jack on Sept. 5.

headline: Ryan Begins to Sync His Schedule With Romney’s
text: LAKEWOOD, Colo. — Representative Paul D. Ryan’s days on the campaign trail include public rallies like two on his schedule for Tuesday, one here in a Denver suburb and another in Las Vegas.

headline: Utility’s Role in Convention Tests Obama
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — When Charlotte first emerged as the top contender to host the Democratic convention, its lead cheerleader was James E. Rogers, the outspoken chief executive of the hometown utility, Duke Energy. He promised to be a public face and a private fund-raiser for the effort.

headline: Manhattan Prosecutor to Centralize Efforts Against Cybercrime
text: Many criminals in the city are becoming more sophisticated, like using high-tech tools for identity theft and other forms of computer crimes. The city’s response?

headline: The Dirt on Clean | Laundering Fashion’s Most Elaborate Creations
text: Though “Downton Abbey” is currently between seasons — Season 3, which will take the fictional Crawley family into the Jazz Age, will have its debut next month in Britain but not until January on this side of the Atlantic — its sumptuous costumes remain firmly planted in our imaginations; for many, they’re reason enough to tune in. So while watching the the Balmain fall 2012 collection unfurl it was easy to embroider a line between the elaborate, mosaic-style beading that the designer Olivier Rousteing dreamed up and the exquisitely embellished clothes worn by Lady Mary and company. The obvious parallels, of course, lie in the richness of the workmanship. But there are less evident similarities between the “Downton” costumes and Rousteing’s clothes, as well as those of Erdem Moralioglu, who embroidered lace onto rubber; Marios Schwab, who layered sequined gowns with chiffon; and Gucci, where the designer Frida Giannini sent out a cocktail dress dripping with coq feathers. These creations (and many others, every season) beg the inevitable question: How are they to be cleaned? Once these individual testaments to the skills of seamstresses, embroiderers, featherers and beaders have been worn, perspired in and spilled on, what’s the wearer to do?

headline: Lawmaker Literally Can’t Wait to Leave Congress
text: So much for a long goodbye.

headline: A Fiery Introduction for Romney in Ohio Coal Country
text: BEALLSVILLE, Ohio — A Senate candidate, introducing Mitt Romney at a rally here on Tuesday, railed against “radical organizations” like the Sierra Club and the League of Conservation Voters, and he said he had a message for those, like President Obama, who stood in the way of the coal industry: “Over our dead bodies.”

headline: For Shark Week, the Volkswagen Beetle Sheds Its Shell
text: Had it been Hyundai with its discontinued Tiburon sports car, which took its name from the Spanish word for shark, the promotional materials would have practically written themselves.

headline: Koufax’s Roundball Once Trumped His Fastball
text: Sandy Koufax’s sports odyssey took him from a muscular, leaping center for the Lafayette High School basketball team in Brooklyn to left-handed bonus baby for the Brooklyn Dodgers to the Hall of Fame as one of the most dynamic pitchers in baseball history.

headline: Biang!

headline: In an Endless Loop of Noodles
text: IF you are one of those people who believes that ingredients should always be treated with respect, by all means stay away from Biang!, an excitable name for a frequently exciting new restaurant in Flushing, Queens.

headline: David Boudia: An Olympic Silhouette in Gold
text: On Saturday night in London, David Boudia won a surprise gold in the men’s 10-meter platform. According to The Times, it’s the first gold for the United States in diving since Laura Wilkinson in 2000 and the first for the men since Mark Lenzi won the 3-meter springboard in 1992.

headline: ‘Dear Pussycat': Editors Remember Helen Gurley Brown
text: The influence of Helen Gurley Brown, who died on Monday at age 90, extended widely across the culture, and deeply within the world of magazines. What follows are remembrances from women who worked with Ms. Brown: Lesley Jane Seymour, Bonnie Fuller, Jill Herzig, Cathleen P. Black, Kate White and Donna Kalajian Lagani.

headline: Subway Fire Near Dekalb Station in Brooklyn Causes Delays
text: Update, 6:45 p.m. | A fire in the subway tunnel north of the Dekalb Avenue station in Brooklyn is wreaking late-afternoon havoc on lettered train lines, causing an ever-changing series of delays and reroutings, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said.

headline: Times Co. Names Mark Thompson Chief Executive
text: The New York Times Company has named Mark Thompson, the departing director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation, as its new president and chief executive.

headline: In Fragmented Brazilian Forest, Few Species Survive
text: The Atlantic Forest in Brazil, which runs along the country’s southeastern shore near Rio de Janeiro, has been fragmented by centuries of human habitation. While the rain forest originally spanned over half a million square miles – an area comparable to the size of South Africa – almost 90 percent of it is now gone. Fields, roads, and cities have taken the place of trees.

headline: Sect Pastor Is Convicted of Assisting in Abduction
text: After only four hours of deliberation, a federal jury in Burlington, Vt., found an Amish-Mennonite pastor guilty of abetting international parental kidnapping in a widely publicized case involving a same-sex union and religious opponents of homosexuality.

headline: Obama Returns to Iowa in Bid to Reignite the Fervor
text: OSKALOOSA, Iowa — This prairie state is the place where his unlikely bid for presidency began. But now it is 2012, and the big question for President Obama is whether, four years after that historic run, Iowa can do for him what it did in 2008.

headline: Your Olympic Keepsakes

headline: Negative Ad, a First for Akin, Goes Up in the Missouri Senate Race
text: After an ad released by the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee criticized his positions on Social Security and Medicare, Representative Todd Akin is responding with an ad of his own that calls the attacks leveled on behalf of his opponent, Senator Claire McCaskill, “misleading, deceptive, false.”

text: Facial mists aren’t new (think of the famous Evian can), but several refreshing skin-care sprays have been recently introduced, all promising to moisturize. They’re a logical seasonal replacement to heavy serums, and many come in carry-on non-aerosol bottles.

text: A small-town couple, Jim and Cindy (Joel Edgerton and Jennifer Garner), grieving over their inability to conceive, write the attributes of their dream child on scraps of paper that they bury in a box in the garden. That night, during a violent storm, a dirt-covered, leaf-sprouting creature claws its way out of the soil and into Jim and Cindy’s house.

headline: Giants Lose Rogers for Season

headline: A Composer Focuses on a Small Group of Colleagues at Tanglewood
text: LENOX, Mass. — Here’s what makes the Tanglewood Music Center’s Festival of Contemporary Music such an enlivening summer oasis most years: As soon as you think you’ve mapped the festival’s stylistic leanings, you run into music that overturns your expectations.

headline: An Incessant Birdcall, Then Peaceful Fishing
text: No composer has transcribed bird song with more dedication than Messiaen, an ornithological sampling artist whose obsession manifested itself in myriad colorful works evoking birdcalls. But other composers certainly indulged in the occasional bird-song transcription, including Dvorak. He included the call of the scarlet tanager, which he heard while hiking in the Iowa countryside in 1893, in his String Quartet No. 12 (“American”).

headline: For Obama and Romney, a To-Do List for Travelers
text: Mitt Romney and President Obama are pounding the campaign trail, courting swing voters by talking about so-called issues like “jobs,” “the budget” and “health care.” Anyone notice anything missing here? Like a nod toward the issues that matter to that all-important, nonpartisan voting bloc, the American budget traveler?

headline: Data Storage Could Expand Reach of Surveillance
text: A wave of worry about a software program called TrapWire, designed to detect terrorists casing possible targets, appears to be unjustified, as I wrote in Tuesday’s Times.

headline: 11 Found Slain, Including Ranger, at Park in Kazakhstan
text: MOSCOW — A forest ranger and 10 other people were found stabbed to death this week in a national park in Kazakhstan about 24 miles from the country’s largest city, Almaty, and not far from the border with Kyrgyzstan, Interior Ministry officials said on Tuesday.

A mash-up of the two genres, Top Chef: The Cruise, will feature hosts of the popular reality competition show, Tom Colicchio and Gail Simmons, and former “cheftestants” along with 2,000 passengers. Tickets for the five-day cruise on Celebrity Constellation, departing from Miami in April 2013 and making stops in Key West, Fla., and Cozumel, Mexico, go on sale Aug. 16.

headline: Old Queens Burial Ground Is Declared a Landmark
text: A Queens cemetery dating back to the 18th century was declared a landmark by the city on Tuesday: Brinckerhoff Cemetery in Fresh Meadows, a private burial ground that was used from 1730 to 1872. There are no gravestones or markers still visible on the site, located along 182nd Street, but according to a survey, there had been 77 gravestones and markers there.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,070 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Getting Schooled With Jumaane Williams
text: City Councilman Jumaane Williams stands out in a crowd. It’s not just his long dreadlocks. It’s the rocking, jerking motion of his body that is the result of Tourette's syndrome. Mr. Williams doesn't usually refer to his disability, but he is frank about some of his challenges, especially when meeting young people in his Brooklyn district.

headline: In Mexico-U.S. Rivalry, the Edge Heads South
text: The United States has been playing Mexico in soccer since 1934 but has yet to win a game on Mexican soil. The Americans’ overall record there is 0-23-1, with Game No. 25 set for Wednesday night, when a United States team with many novices and hopefuls will take on Mexico’s national team at Estadio Azteca in Mexico City.

headline: Nine Straight Days of 110 or More: That’s Hot, Even for Phoenix
text: PHOENIX — Hot is a relative term for people used to the scorching summer weather in this city built on land better suited for cactus than lawns. But nine straight days of excessive heat seem to have stretched even the most elastic tolerance levels to their limits.

headline: China: Self-Immolations Continue
text: Two young Tibetan men set themselves on fire on Monday in a Tibetan region of western China to protest Chinese rule, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group in London, and Radio Free Asia, a news organization financed by the United States government. The men, who were identified as Lungtok and Tashi, self-immolated in the town of Ngaba, known in Chinese as Aba. Free Tibet identified both as former monks of Kirti Monastery, while Radio Free Asia said Lungtok was a monk and Tashi was believed to be a layperson. Forty-eight Tibetans have self-immolated since March 2011. The condition of the two men was unclear on Tuesday, though Free Tibet reported that Lungtok is believed to have died.

headline: Mexico: Criminal Leader Found Dead
text: The leader of a criminal syndicate operating in the volatile region of Chéran, in the state of Michoacán, was found slain on Tuesday, according to the state attorney’s office. A military patrol found the leader, Mauricio Cuitláhuac Hernández, near a burning van in the town of Santa María Urapicho. Residents of Cherán have been struggling to drive out armed illegal loggers who they say have destroyed their forests and tormented their families under the protection of cartel henchmen for months. The government deployed 600 police officers to Michoacán this week. No suspects have been named in the killing.

headline: Given Opportunity, and Competition, McKnight Gets Serious
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Joe McKnight said with a smile that he felt great and was looking forward to the season because he could be put in several positions to make the most of his many talents. Then he practically screeched to a halt, changing directions.
