text: The dripping canyons of New York City’s ever expanding network of train and subway tunnels would seem to be a far cry from the euro zone’s continuing financial debacle.

headline: Ron Palillo Dies at 63; Played Horshack on TV
text: Ron Palillo, who portrayed the goofy high school underachiever Arnold Horshack in the hit 1970s sitcom “Welcome Back, Kotter” with such definitive oddballness that he had trouble for years afterward finding work as an actor, died on Tuesday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 63.

headline: U.S. Vows to Speed Aid to Iran Earthquake Victims
text: The Obama administration said Tuesday that it would expedite applications to help Iran’s earthquake victims. Prospective donors have expressed worry and confusion over whether such charitable aid runs afoul of the extensive American sanctions imposed on the country because of its disputed nuclear program.

headline: Importing Russia’s Top Gun
text: IZHEVSK, Russia — The nickname of this town, home of the factory that makes Kalashnikov rifles, is the “Armory of Russia.” Over the years, it has armed a good number of other countries, too, as the lathes and presses of the Izhevsk Machine Works clanged around the clock to forge AK-47s and similar guns for insurgents and armies around the world.

headline: From Izhmash, With Love
text: American hunters and gun enthusiasts are snapping up tens of thousands of the civilian versions of AK-style weapons.

headline: Mine Plan Puts Two Kentucky Fixtures on Collision Course
text: UTICA, Ky. — The signs begin around Girl Scout Road, yellow placards dotting yards and affixed to trees along Route 231 here. “No Coal Trucks” they say, or, more to the point, “Stop Strip Mining.” Some have a phone number for a clutch of residents in this small town, a dozen miles outside Owensboro, who aim to do just that.

headline: The Little Restaurant That (I Wish) Could
text: There is a tiny restaurant in the garment district that I keep rooting for. It’s like a dear but troubled friend who has issues. It’s 38th Street Restaurant and Bakery, also known as Ming Du, a simple, steam-table Chinese place where neighborhood workers get tasty food cheap.

headline: Unprosecuted Hate Crimes
text: Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. told the Senate in 2009 that “we have a significant hate crimes problem in this country.” The recent murders at the Sikh temple in Wisconsin have raised this issue in the public consciousness.

headline: Mr. Bloomberg’s Immigration Road Trip
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg took his pro-immigration views on the road on Tuesday to public forums in Chicago and Boston, where he urged President Obama and Mitt Romney to make immigration a central issue in the presidential campaign.

headline: Uncertainty Surrounds Next Year’s Ironman
text: New York City’s first Ironman may be its last.

headline: Major Investor in the Apthorp Cedes Its Day-to-Day Control
text: The Apthorp apartment building has long been one of New York City’s most famous structures, a heavy limestone behemoth built by the Astors in 1908, once home to Nora Ephron and Al Pacino. In recent years, however, it has developed a decidedly less glamorous reputation as one of the city’s most troubled condominium conversions.

headline: Overt Discrimination in Ohio
text: Update: On Wednesday afternoon, Jon Husted, the Ohio Secretary of State, announced that all Ohio counties would follow a uniform early-voting policy. The policy would extend early-voting hours to 7 p.m. on weekdays during the last two weeks before the election, though all early voting is banned during the final three days of the campaign.

headline: Aug. 14: The Fog of Polling — and Ryan’s ‘Bounce’ So Far
text: As I noted on Saturday, past vice-presidential announcements have typically been greeted with a small “bounce” in the polls. Harry J. Enten, at The Guardian, has run the numbers on this for vice-presidential announcements dating back to 1984. He finds a net gain of four percentage points in the polls — and a mean of six — for the party that just named its new running mate.

headline: Police Sought Cellphones for Video of Times Square Shooting
text: Dozens of bystanders grabbed their cellphones and hit the record button as a knife-wielding man skipped backward through Times Square on Saturday. Some witnesses, holding their cellphones above their heads to capture the action, ran alongside police officers as they pursued the man down Seventh Avenue with guns drawn.

headline: Rainbow Room, Shut by a Feud, Has a Fading Wish
text: It was probably the most cinematically perfect space in New York. It had that stylishly streamlined modern look — elegant crystal chandeliers here, a revolving dance floor there, long velvety draperies beyond. And it had those magical views that made the Empire State Building and the Chrysler Building seem small enough to reach out and touch.

headline: Tall Tale: Origin of the Pesky Pole Feeds Red Sox Lore
text: The truth is, no one really knows exactly how — or why — the right-field foul pole in Fenway Park came to be known as the Pesky Pole. The truth, too, is that no one was really giving the subject that much thought until Johnny Pesky died on Monday at age 92 after seven decades with the Boston Red Sox as a player, manager, coach, broadcaster and beloved baseball ambassador.

headline: New Jersey Fines Halfway Houses $45,000 Over Escapes
text: The Christie administration said on Tuesday that it had issued $45,000 in fines against New Jersey halfway houses from which nine inmates escaped in recent months, the harshest penalties ever brought against the troubled network of private operators.

headline: Lottery Numbers
House Chairman Survives Florida Primary
text: Representative John L. Mica of Florida fought off Representative Sandy Adams on Tuesday in a closely watched Republican primary election that pitted two incumbents against each other in an important swing state.

headline: Heartfelt Singing and Screeching, Amplified
text: Two hours into karaoke night, there was still no karaoke to be heard at Joe’s Place in the Bronx.

headline: Ecuador: President Denies Decision to Grant WikiLeaks Founder Asylum
text: The president of Ecuador, Rafael Correa, denied on Tuesday a report on the Web site of The Guardian that he had decided to grant asylum to the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, who is holed up in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London. “There is still no decision,” Mr. Correa said in a post on Twitter. Mr. Assange took refuge in the embassy in June, seeking to avoid extradition to Sweden, where he is wanted for questioning on allegations of sexual molestation and rape by two women.

headline: Battle Lines on Care
text: Candidates and outside groups have started to inject the Medicare issue into advertising for House and Senate races.

headline: Obama-Ryan Battle Intensifies Over Medicare Savings
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Paul D. Ryan’s budget blueprint assumes the same amount of Medicare savings as President Obama’s health care law, even though Mitt Romney and Mr. Ryan have said those cuts would be devastating to millions of older Americans on Medicare.

headline: L.I.R.R. Worker Pleads Guilty in Pension Fraud Scheme
text: A former worker for the Long Island Rail Road pleaded guilty on Tuesday to conspiracy and perjury charges, admitting that he had schemed to steal from a federal pension agency by pretending to be disabled and then lied to a grand jury.

headline: Focus Turns to N.F.L.’s Replacement Officials
text: Separated by a few plane flights and a tense negotiating chasm, the N.F.L. and its locked-out officials watched the first full slate of preseason games over the weekend. Their assessments of the debut of replacement officials were as contrasting as black and white stripes.

headline: Mother’s Precautions Finally Fail, 2 Blocks From Home
text: Paula Shaw-Leary had every reason to believe that the seven children she raised in Harlem were finally clear of the street violence that had worried her for years.

headline: Urban League Football Classic to Be Played at Yankee Stadium
text: In 1973, George Steinbrenner made a business decision — he bought the Yankees — and a charitable decision. He chose to underwrite the struggling New York Urban League Football Classic.

headline: Grandmas Grow Gold in Swaziland
text: PIGGS PEAK, Swaziland — After her daughters died, Khathazile took in her 11 orphaned grandchildren without hesitation. It is what a gogo, or grandmother, does in a country where the world’s highest H.I.V. infection rate has left a sea of motherless children.

headline: Giants Defensive Tackle Out for Season With a Clot
text: ALBANY — The Giants almost escaped training camp without a major injury. That changed Tuesday, the last day of camp here, when the team discovered defensive tackle Shaun Rogers had a blood clot in his calf that would keep him out for the season.

headline: Fewer Government Resources
text: The United States collects the same amount of taxes as it did 45 years ago, leaving less money for services.

headline: Union’s First Proposal Offers Concessions
text: The N.H.L. Players’ Association made a surprising initial proposal to league owners Tuesday in negotiations toward a new collective bargaining agreement, offering significant salary concessions combined with a reformed revenue-sharing plan.

headline: Where Small Talk Has Epic Meanings
text: For Mrs. Robert Henry, good conversation is sacred, something to put your faith in, along with God and country. A fanatically gracious small-town matron, Mrs. Henry (Dolores to her friends) proselytizes tirelessly for this religion in the opening entry of “Harrison, TX,” an evening of three short, piquant plays by Horton Foote at 59E59 Theaters. And shame on those who dare dismiss her as just a flibbertigibbet.

text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE —

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Executive From CBS Will Lead Big East Conference
text: Imagine Mike Aresco’s enthusiasm Tuesday when he was named the commissioner of the Big East, a conference that is essentially a television free agent in a landscape of expanding media, in which networks have trampled over one another bidding for college sports.

headline: William N. Wallace, Former Times Reporter, Dies at 88
text: William N. Wallace, a former sports reporter for The New York Times and one of the first to cover professional football beyond following the local team, died on Saturday in Norwalk, Conn. He was 88.

headline: When Cruelty Is Cute
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Japan: Cabinet Member Visits Tokyo War Shrine
text: A Japanese cabinet member visited a Tokyo war shrine on Wednesday for the first time in three years, a move that could add to already heated exchanges with neighboring South Korea over history. The visit by Jin Matsubara, the National Public Safety Commission chairman, was the first by a cabinet member to the Yasukuni Shrine since the Democratic Party came to power in 2009 with vows to build closer ties with Asia. Mr. Matsubara, an outspoken conservative, told Kyodo News that he visited the shrine to Japan’s war dead as a private citizen, ignoring a request from Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda not to go. The visit comes as Tokyo and Seoul have clashed over compensation for World War II-era sex slaves and over disputed islands.

headline: An Ex-Wrestling Executive Wins a G.O.P. Primary
text: Linda E. McMahon, a former wrestling executive, easily captured Connecticut’s Republican Senate primary on Tuesday night, clinching a second chance to run for a position she failed to win two years ago.

headline: After Battling Delays, Pettitte Hopes to Return Quickly, but Not Too Quickly
text: An X-ray on Andy Pettitte’s broken left ankle Monday showed it had improved, but not enough to allow Pettitte to begin pitching from a mound.

headline: Enlisting From Afar for the Love of Israel
text: LOD, Israel — Three days into Josh Warhit’s first-ever visit to Israel, as a 16-year-old on a summer tour, war broke out in Lebanon, which transformed the group’s itinerary — and his life plan. On Tuesday, with talk rampant about the possibility of an imminent Israeli attack on Iran, Mr. Warhit became a citizen of Israel to enlist in its army.

headline: Why Moderates Should Like Paul Ryan
text: Paul Ryan is not a moderate, not a centrist, and certainly not a perfectly neutral non-ideological number-crunching budget wonk. He is a conservative whose fiscal blueprints and budgets are drawn up with conservative goals uppermost in mind. He’s a Reaganite pro-life hawkish supply-sider who wants limited government and the lowest possible tax burden. Out of all the running mates available, Mitt Romney chose one of the most explicitly ideological options.

headline: Kuroda Dominates as Yankees Defeat Rangers Again
text: The Yankees’ catchers have about 10 key words they use to communicate with the Japanese pitcher Hiroki Kuroda when he is on the mound. They are basic phrases of pitching — relax, keep the ball down, attack the strike zone.

headline: Two-Way Jabs on Medicare Recast Races for Congress
text: WASHINGTON — In one tight Florida House race, a hastily assembled TV commercial to begin airing Wednesday takes aim at a top target of Democrats, highlighting his votes “to end Medicare as we know it.”

headline: Penn State Warned by Accreditation Panel
text: Pennsylvania State University has been warned that its accreditation is in jeopardy unless it corrects conditions that contributed to sexual abuse of children by a former assistant football coach, Jerry Sandusky.

headline: Scoreless Duel, and Then It’s Over for the Mets
text: CINCINNATI — Again and again, four times in all, Cincinnati Reds hitters belted baseballs that arced toward the outfield seats, only to watch them thump off the padded walls.

headline: Parking Rules
text: On Wednesday, because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Romney Delivers a Harsh Rebuke of Obama at Final Stop on Bus Tour
text: 11:14 a.m. | Updated In a CBS interview on Wednesday, Mitt Romney continued his harsh rebuke of the Obama administration, charging that President Obama is running a campaign of “enmity and jealousy and anger and this is not in my view what the American people want to see.”

headline: Ryan Meets Casino Mogul and Major G.O.P. Donor
text: LAS VEGAS — Four days after his announcement as Mitt Romney’s running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan was not in Florida talking Medicare with elderly voters or in drought-ridden Iowa talking about a farm bill. He traveled to the Venetian hotel here for a meeting hosted by Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire casino mogul who has pledged to spend as much as $100 million this year to defeat President Obama.

headline: The Making of the Indian National Flag
text: The tricolor flag, made from hand-spun and handwoven cotton, is produced by a small manufacturing unit in the southern Indian state of Karnataka.

headline: Strategies for Hot-Weather Exercise
text: Is it possible to stay cool while exercising in the heat?

headline: Word of the Day | pessimism
text: pessimism •\ˈpe-sə-ˌmi-zəm also ˈpe-zə-\• noun

headline: Al Freeman Jr., Actor Prominent in Civil Rights Era, Dies at 78
text: Al Freeman Jr., a star among a generation of black actors that emerged during the civil rights era, who made his mark in both drama and race relations with his portraits of some of the movement’s most forbidding personalities — angry young men in the 1960s plays of James Baldwin and LeRoi Jones, Malcolm X in a television drama, and the black separatist Elijah Muhammad in Spike Lee’s 1992 movie “Malcolm X” — died on Aug. 9 in Washington. He was 78.

headline: Pinterest Rolls Out Android and iPad Apps
text: Pinterest, the social networking service where people “pin” content from around the Web on a virtual board, said on Tuesday that it was releasing versions of its mobile app for Android devices and the iPad.

headline: Gunman in Texas Wrote of ‘Inspirational’ Snipers and of Buying a Gun
text: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — On his Facebook page, Thomas Caffall posted a list of “inspirational people.” One was Carlos Hathcock, one of the most famous snipers in the United States Marine Corps who recorded 93 confirmed kills during the Vietnam War. Another was Vasily Zaytsev, a Russian sniper during World War II who was known for his skills with the Mosin-Nagant rifle.

headline: Thompson Wins G.O.P. Senate Race in Wisconsin
text: WAUKESHA, Wis. — In the final week of his primary campaign, Tommy G. Thompson, the 70-year-old former governor of Wisconsin, performed 50 push-ups for a local newspaper editorial board to prove he was spry enough for the Senate post he is seeking. He has barnstormed the state for months, visiting with voters and raking in high-profile endorsements for a candidacy that, once presumed dominant, had increasingly felt the encroachment of younger challengers for the Republican nomination.

headline: Heading for the Exits in China
text: HONG KONG — Charlie Custer, a filmmaker and blogger, is back in the United States. Left China. Couldn’t take it any more. Bad air. Unsafe food. And there was a nasty-scary spat with a government journalist.

headline: News Quiz | August 15, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Syrian Conflict Crosses Border Into Lebanon in Abductions
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Spillover from the Syrian conflict hit Lebanon in a frightening new way on Wednesday with the abduction of more than 30 Syrians inside Lebanese territory, which their captors called revenge for the kidnapping of a relative inside Syria.

headline: Reversal on Immigration Policy in Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The lower house of Australia’s Parliament passed sweeping changes in immigration policy on Wednesday that are meant to deter asylum seekers who try to reach the country by the thousands each year on rickety, overcrowded ships and boats.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 15, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “A Financial Plan for the Truly Fed Up.”

headline: Finding Mars in Familiar Places
text: The rover Curiosity survived its famed “seven minutes of terror” and has touched down on the surface of Mars, and the world cheered.

headline: The Mind of a Flip-Flopper
text: Forget for a minute everything you know about politics. Barack Obama now openly supports gay marriage. Mitt Romney now opposes roughly the same kind of health care reform he fought for as governor of Massachusetts. What if they weren’t two politicians calculating how to win an election but instead just two guys who changed their minds? They didn’t “flip-flop”; they experienced, as social scientists say, an attitude change, the way any of us do when we become a vegetarian or befriend a neighbor we used to hate or even just choose to buy a new brand of toothpaste.

headline: The Birthplace of Obama the Politician
text: Scenes from Roseland, the Chicago neighborhood that a young Barack Obama hoped to one day fix.

headline: What Does Obama Really Believe In?
text: From the back seat of Steve Gates’s white Pontiac, Monique Robbins spotted Jasmine Coleman walking home from school alone. It was an icy December afternoon on Chicago’s South Side, and Jasmine’s only protection against the wind was a thin purple jacket. She looked cold. Gates pulled the car over to the curb, and Robbins hollered at Jasmine to get in.

headline: Restrictions on a ‘Rite of American Teendom’
text: In WHAT ways have state legislatures across the country restricted teenage driving in recent years?WHAT are the results of the studies that safety campaigners point to in order to justify these strict laws?

headline: Japan Holds 14 Chinese in Island Landing
text: TOKYO — The Japanese authorities arrested 14 Chinese citizens from a Hong Kong-based vessel on Wednesday after some of them staged a protest by landing on a Japanese-controlled island that is also claimed by China. The incident added to a recent flare-up in tensions between Japan and its Asian neighbors over history and territory.

headline: Pittsburgh Steelers, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: This past off-season gave us a smorgasbord of examples of why the Pittsburgh Steelers are one of the finest organizations in professional sports. There was Mike Tomlin getting his contract extended through 2016, continuing the organization’s unparalleled tradition of head coaching stability under the Rooney family. There was Kevin Colbert, the most underrated if not outright best general manager in pro football, playing hardball with the restricted free agent Mike Wallace, a burgeoning star receiver but not someone the organization is going to overpay to keep. There was the other burgeoning receiver, Antonio Brown, being signed to a new six-year contract before his value escalated further. There was a renowned receiver, Hall of Fame candidate Hines Ward, being ushered into the sunset with a hero’s farewell.

headline: Trickle-Down Fairy Dust
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: The Early Word: Influences
text: Today’s Times

headline: Lloyds Bank to Sell Private Equity Assets for $1.6 Billion
text: LONDON – The Lloyds Banking Group, the partly nationalized British bank, agreed on Wednesday to sell a number of its private equity investments to the British firm Coller Capital for around £1 billion, or $1.6 billion.

headline: Summer Styles | Gam On
text: A look at who’s staying cool and looking cooler this season.

headline: A Critic’s Case for Critics Who Are Actually Critical
text: In the spring of 1983, Esquire convened what it called a revenge symposium. The editors asked a group of well-known writers to “let go unbridled comments” on their harshest and least favorite critics. The results were spectacular.

headline: Buying Versus Renting, Owners Consider the Advantages
text: At a recent She Owns It business group meeting, the conversation focused on real estate. The business owners also touched on the related subject of working remotely, a topic we’ll explore further in coming posts.

headline: For Healthy Aging, a Late Act in the Footlights
text: What kind of old age will you have?

headline: Stone Links: Philosophical Fictions
text: The science-writing website io9 publishes an essay suggesting that science fiction — or as it is sometimes called, speculative fiction — is just an outgrowth of philosophy, in that the fantastical conceits of such fiction have functioned largely to test philosophical hypotheses. Many works of substantial philosophical content are equally well considered pieces of speculative fiction: Thomas More’s “Utopia,” Swift’s “Gulliver’s Travels,” and Shelley’s “Frankenstein.” The essay also manages to draw a line of influence from Plato’s Cave to the work of Philip K. Dick, and to the movie “The Matrix.”

headline: Carlyle Group Continues an Unusually Busy Summer
text: While summer has traditionally been a slow time for deal making, the Carlyle Group has been on a buying spree in recent weeks.

headline: Q&A: The Long Arm of Google on Chrome
text: Q.

headline: Germans Reopen Investigation on Facebook Privacy
text: BERLIN — Data protection officials in Germany reopened an investigation into Facebook’s facial recognition technology Wednesday, saying that the social networking giant was illegally compiling a huge database of members’ photos without their consent.

headline: Standard Chartered’s Shares Rally on Settlement
text: 8:32 a.m. | Updated

headline: Pilot Whales in the Apolima Straits
text: Scott Baker, associate director of the Marine Mammal Institute at Oregon State University, writes from Samoa, where he studies the formation of local communities among dolphins and their genetic isolation from one another.

headline: A Plea for Hunts Point: Invite Midsize Farmers
text: New York City officials are still negotiating the $350 million renovation of the city’s main produce distribution center at Hunts Point in the Bronx, which farmers in the New York region are hoping will make room for them.

headline: Is That New England Accent in Retreat?
text: Mitt Romney drew some criticism in March when he wrestled over the pronunciation of “Missouri.” But some residents of the state where he spends his vacations, according to a recent article in the journal American Speech, have become increasingly uncertain how to pronounce “New Hampshire.”

headline: Vain Glorious | Tom Ford’s Jardin Noir Perfumes
text: Tom Ford’s latest fragrance collection, Jardin Noir, features four new scents that subvert the savor of classic blooms (rose, lily, narcissus and hyacinth) into heady concoctions that seem, as Ford puts it, practically illicit. “When you showcase their darker and less innocent aspects,” he says, “flowers can become so thrilling and beautiful, they could almost ruin you. That was the sensation I was after.” If the sexy juice itself doesn’t ruin you, then its price might. A 250 milliliter bottle is $495.

headline: Opinion Report: Voting in Ohio
text: From the editorial page

headline: British Employment Defies Weak Economy
text: The British labor market has defied the country’s lingering recession, improving in the second quarter as businesses hired more workers before the Olympic Games, official data showed Wednesday.

headline: Europe Fights to Win More Chinese, BRIC Tourists
text: LONDON — Competition is heating up in Europe to attract more tourists from the BRIC countries — Brazil, Russia, India and China — whose economies are expanding while the Europeans are standing still.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Strategies for Hot Weather Exercise
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Australian Court Strikes Down Tobacco Challenge
text: SYDNEY — One of the world’s toughest cigarette labeling laws is set to take effect in Australia in December, after the country’s highest court ruled Wednesday against multinational tobacco companies that had sought to block the legislation.

headline: Daily Report: Germans Reopen Facebook Privacy Inquiry
text: German officials reopened an investigation into Facebook’s facial recognition technology Wednesday, contending the social network giant was illegally compiling a vast photo database of users without their consent, reports Kevin J. O’Brien for The New York Times from Berlin.

headline: Jack Dempsey vs. Rocky Graziano
text: Dear Diary: During the 1960s, my mother and I saw former boxing world heavyweight champion Jack Dempsey one summer evening standing outside of his famous restaurant formerly on Broadway between 49th and 50th Streets in Manhattan.

headline: The Checklist | Venus in Furs
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: On Democracy in Spain
text: MADRID — On Monday, July 30, 40 Spaniards ranging in age from their mid-20’s to early 70’s congregated in a dilapidated plaza in central Madrid. Those wizened by past experience brought folding chairs; others tore off cardboard slabs from a nearby recycling heap to fashion makeshift cushions. Newcomers stood or crouched.

headline: The Things They Stored
text: TEL AVIV — I got home Monday evening to find in my mailbox an official reminder: Did we have enough gas masks for the whole family? Getting one, or replacing an old one, is simple: the distribution center isn’t far; it’s at the building where the Boy Scouts’ meet around the corner, right near where my youngest boy goes to school.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Lo-Down: As the demographics of Manhattan’s Chinatown change, why shouldn’t its restaurants? Wilson Tang, the second-generation proprietor of Nam Wah Tea Parlor, discusses his own evolving ideas in an age that prizes “authenticity.” — Eric Asimov

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A New Chief at the Times Company and Farewells to H.G.B.
text: Reaching well outside the newspaper business, The New York Times Company announced that it had hired Mark Thompson, the departing director general of the BBC, as its next president and chief executive. Mr. Thompson has worked almost his entire career at the public broadcaster, making him an unusual choice. Robert Andrews of paidContent gives a British perspective on the hire, and Ken Doctor, the newspaper analyst, offers his take.

headline: In Some Parts of the City, a Common Police Practice
text: Across New York City, physical force is used by the police in many of the hundreds of thousands of stops they make each year.

headline: Those Corruption Protests Have Backfired in India
text: NEW DELHI — Since April last year, India has seen a wave of protests against politicians and political corruption. The latest demonstration, which ended on Tuesday, was led by the yoga master Baba Ramdev, whose alternative-medicine factory has cures for many ailments, although not corruption.

headline: Frustrations of Air Travel Push Passengers to Amtrak
text: WASHINGTON — Long a punch line for harried Northeast travelers, Amtrak has come to dominate commercial travel in the corridor connecting Washington, New York and Boston, and this summer its trains are packed.

headline: Pennsylvania Judge Upholds Voter ID Law
text: A Pennsylvania judge on Wednesday refused to grant an injunction on a new voter identification law that Democrats say could harm President Obama’s re-election chances by unfairly targeting minorities, college students and others in a key swing state.

headline: Big in Baku
text: The slim corridor that some Azeris call the Belt of Happiness starts at Baku’s Heydar Aliyev International airport. The new road into town is as black and shiny as the vast pools of oil that paid for it, as well as for everything else in Azerbaijan. And what oil doesn’t pay to fix, it pays to hide. Sand-colored concrete walls line the highway, but through their latticed arabesques you can just make out the woeful shacks behind them.

headline: Gay Male Comics Await the Spotlight
text: COULD James Adomian become the first man to break through as an openly gay stand-up star?

headline: Pneumothorax
text: A slide show depicting pneumothorax, the collection of air or gas in the space surrounding the lungs.

headline: Internet Piracy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Adoption, Destiny and Magical Thinking
text: I’m not a big believer in destiny. I’m squarely in the “stuff happens” camp. But the human tendency to feel that certain things were meant to be fascinates me. I’m impressed by our ability to extract a sense of purpose from the random events that make up our lives.

headline: Pockets of City See Higher Use of Force During Police Stops
text: The crowded neighborhoods of the West Bronx come alive at night. Residents, young and old, cluster around door stoops. Teenagers fill playground basketball courts. Police officers from the nearby 44th and 46th Precincts patrol the streets, from time to time stopping and frisking young men, mostly black and Latino. And when they do, statistics show, they use physical force far more often than the police do anywhere else in the city.

headline: Carpal Tunnel Repair
text: A slide show depicting surgery to correct the compression of the median nerve at the wrist.

headline: Alpha Fetoprotein
text: A slide show about alpha fetoprotein, or AFP.

headline: Amniocentesis
text: A slide show explaining amniocentesis.

headline: For Romney, a New Running Mate May Mean a New, Less Elliptical, Workout, Too
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Mitt Romney is a man of steady and immutable habits. He drinks Cherry Coke Zero. He eats peanut butter and honey sandwiches. And he works out on an elliptical machine.

headline: Never Mind Algebra. Is Literature Necessary?
text: In an opinion post in response to a recent New York Times essay, a city English teacher writes: "If algebra can be tossed by the wayside, why not Austen?"  And he laments, that is already happening. "Bit by bit, the body of English language instruction has been dismembered over the last 15 years or so."

headline: Business Day Live | August 15, 2012
text: With Standard Chartered settlement, a victory for a new regulator. | In Northeast, trains gain ground against airlines. | Importing Russia's top gun.

headline: Business Day Live: Hassles of Air Travel Push Passengers to Amtrak
text: With Standard Chartered settlement, a victory for a new regulator. | In Northeast, trains gain ground against airlines. | Importing Russia’s top gun.

headline: Checking Account Fees Rising, Analysis Finds
text: Feel as if you’re paying more for your checking account? You probably are.

headline: Getting a Jump on iPhone Upgraders
text: If you’re thinking about selling your iPhone so you can use the money to buy Apple’s new smartphone when it comes out, better act fast.

headline: A Different Approach to Coping With Drought
text: Water levels are low in reservoirs all over the parched West, but in many areas, the amount of water being used is no greater than the amount that evaporates, according to Moshe Alamaro, a scientist and inventor affiliated with M.I.T.

headline: Senate Democrats’ Strategy for Ryan Includes the Deficit
text: The Democrats’ war on Representative Paul D. Ryan has moved into the Upper Chamber, and it is extending beyond the battle over Medicare.

headline: Claressa Shields Shares Gold
text: Two months ago, Claressa Shields packed a strapless purple dress to wear in London if she became one of the first women boxers to win an Olympic medal. When the 17-year-old boxer from Flint, Mich. (who was included in our multimedia feature on America’s boxing women aiming for the Olympics this past winter), finally got to wear that dress, she had more than one historical achievement to celebrate: the first woman middleweight gold medalist, the youngest since 1924, the only American boxer to stand on top of the podium this year and the second-most-trending name on Yahoo! on the day of her victory.

headline: This Old Thing?
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Tablet Straining to Do It All
text: The hot news in Silicon Valley legal circles these days is Apple’s titanic lawsuit against Samsung. Apple maintains that Samsung pilfered some of its iPhone and iPad designs when creating the Samsung Galaxy series of phones and tablets.

headline: A Lament for a Supermarket, and Outrage Over Its Replacement
text: It was an unlovely place and its customers had many complaints: a chronic damp and musty smell, a poor selection unless one harbored a passion for Campbell’s soups, exorbitant prices, a fresh deli that could be anything but and bored workers with little interest in helping shoppers.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: My fiancé and I are planning a small wedding for family and close friends. It is important to us that the sanctity and beauty of the ceremony be respected. Several of our guests have babies and young children. We are happy to have them at our wedding under their parents’ supervision, but are concerned that this might lead to disruptions during the religious ceremony, which will be about 30 to 45 minutes.

headline: The Truth Has A Well-Known Demagogic Bias
text: The other day I picked up on something William Saletan wrote to illustrate the conventional wisdom that has let the essentially ridiculous Paul Ryan go so far. Today let me pick on William Galston – again not a household name, but a good representative of the Beltway gone bad.

headline: Leaning Toward the Light: Molly Ringwald Talks About Her New Novel
text: Molly Ringwald became a star for her roles in a beloved triumvirate of mid-’80s teenage movies: “Sixteen Candles,” “The Breakfast Club” and “Pretty in Pink.” Now 44, she continues to act and is also focused on a career as an author. In 2010, she published “Getting the Pretty Back.” She called that effort “a kind of entertaining, anecdotal style guide.” Her new book is “When It Happens to You,” a novel told in stories centered around Phillip and Greta, a couple whose marriage is foundering. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Ringwald discussed the appeal of flawed characters, advice she got from Bret Easton Ellis and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: A Battle Plan for Jet Lag
text: THERE are more so-called remedies for jet lag than there are time zones, from long-standing antidotes like No-Jet-Lag’s homeopathic tablets to new innovations like the Valkee Brain Stimulation Headset, which was tested earlier this year by Finnair and purports to alleviate jet lag by channeling bright light into the brain through the ear canal.

headline: Just Red Sox Being Red Sox
text: With everything that changes each season in baseball, it is nice to have a constant, a touchstone that reminds you what era one is in. To that end, the Red Sox are performing a public service, their dysfunction so consistent that it is almost comforting. Only the details change, from booing Nomar Garciaparra out of town to Manny being Manny to fried chicken and beer to whatever has popped out of Bobby Valentine’s mouth today.

headline: Wheelies: The 32-Pack Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Abby Elliott Not Returning to ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: Abby Elliott has joined the ranks of performers like Kristen Wiig and Andy Samberg who are leaving the cast of “Saturday Night Live.” Ms. Elliott, who joined “SNL” as a featured performer during its 2008-9 season, told the Web site Splitsider.com that she would not be returning to that long-running late-night comedy series. NBC declined to comment on Wednesday but a person with direct knowledge of plans at the show confirmed the report.

headline: A Rare Mother Goose, Indeed
text: The renowned children’s book editor Margaret McElderry died last year, but the imprint bearing her name carries on, as does the publisher’s “McElderry Book of...” series of anthologies. “The McElderry Book of Mother Goose,” the fourth volume (earlier collections were of Greek myths, Aesop’s fables and Grimms’ fairy tales) does much to continue her storied tradition — and give it a fresh little tweak, especially for those who’ve had enough of Little Jack Horner and his over-recited ilk.

headline: Ann Romney Refuses to Release More Tax Returns
text: In an interview scheduled to be broadcast Thursday evening on NBC’s “Rock Center,” Ann Romney, the wife of the Republican nominee, Mitt Romney, found herself facing some of the same questions that have dogged her husband’s campaign in recent weeks — namely, about the Romney family’s tax returns.

headline: Introducing Maggie Koerth-Baker
text: Readers of Boing Boing will know what I mean when I say that very few people can write about science like Maggie Koerth-Baker. She is the site’s longtime science editor and also the author of the excellent book Before the Lights Go Out: Conquering the Energy Crisis Before It Conquers Us. And starting this month, she’ll be contributing a regular column to the magazine that we’re calling Eureka. Her terrific first column is about the mind of a flip-flopper. Maggie will be writing frequently about the intersection of science and culture, about studies she finds to be especially revealing or provocative, about human behavior and technological innovation and natural phenomena. In short, she’ll be bringing us in closer, smarter, more exciting contact with the scientific world. We’re very happy to have her joining the magazine.

headline: Remember Iraq?
text: Since troops withdrew at the end of 2011, Iraq has receded from the American public consciousness. Just consider the U.S. presidential campaign where the economy – understandably – predominates. President Obama and Mitt Romney rarely even mention the country we invaded.

headline: Energy Security vs. Environment in Alaska
text: While the Marcellus Shale in New York and Pennsylvania and the Bakken Shale in North Dakota are trigger points in the world of fossil-fuel extraction these days, Alaska has been the lodestar for oil and gas development in the United States for the last half-century. And as befits a state dominated more by wild lands than humankind, it has been home to some of the fiercest political battles pitting energy interests against environmental concerns.

headline: The Get | Skagen Denmark and Hiromichi Konno Watch
text: It could be said that Hiromichi Konno has a thing for Danish design. Four years ago, he enjoyed a certain degree of acclaim when he created the futuristic-looking Rin chair for the venerable Danish furniture collective Fritz Hansen. More recently, Konno approached the watch company Skagen Denmark about a collaboration. “I was so impressed by their design philosophy,” Konno said, which he defines as “simple and beautiful.”

headline: Wall Street’s Race to the 48-Millisecond Trade
text: It took just 45 minutes this month for one of Wall Street’s top trading firms to lose $440 million, a loss that has focused attention on the potential problems associated with high-speed trading. Yet today’s technological challenges are not unlike those faced by traders in the 19th century, whose jobs were revolutionized by the advent of ticker machines.

headline: Religious Roots Tangle With the Groovy ’60s
text: Wearing a bushy beard and the absent-minded expression of a father preoccupied with work at the dinner table, Eric Anderson, who plays the Jewish singer Shlomo Carlebach in the bio-musical “Soul Doctor,” appears smaller than life. That changes, however, when he starts to sing.

headline: Reasonable Republicans?
text: Several commenters have asked that I provide examples of Republicans making reasonable economic arguments; some of them seem to be saying that I’m proving my bias if I don’t provide such examples.

headline: Forget Harvard; Real Economic Change Will Come From the Bottom
text: In Sunday’s magazine, Adam Davidson finds a reason to cheer for second-rate business schools. They may lack Nobel laureate professors and ivy-covered buildings, but they have managed to drive down the cost of a business degree. Some schools, like the University of California, Irvine, even offer online classes for free. ‘‘There are hundreds of millions of small farmers, shopkeepers and potential entrepreneurs,’’ Davidson writes, ‘‘for whom mass business-educational tools could be transformational in ways that make a handful of top schools seem utterly irrelevant.’’ According to Larry Cooperman, director of U.C. Irvine’s OpenCourseWare program, the transformation has already begun.

headline: Still Recovering From Knee Problems, Nadal Will Miss United States Open
text: Rafael Nadal withdrew from the United States Open on Wednesday, saying he was not ready to return to competition because of chronic knee problems that forced him out of the Olympics and two warm-up tournaments for the Open.

headline: Police Arrest Man, 54, in Robbery of a 9-Year-Old Boy
text: The police have arrested a 54-year-old man who they say violently mugged a 9-year-old Bronx boy for $19.

headline: Amtrak Dominates Northeast Corridor Travel
text: For harried travelers between the major cities of the Northeast, commercial travel increasingly means a trip to the train station, not the airport. Amtrak’s trains are packed this summer with passengers seeking to avoid fight delays and security lines and find space to work.

headline: How to Share the Revenue Could Be Stumbling Block in N.H.L. Negotiations
text: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said he was not certain whether he and league negotiators would have a response by Wednesday to the proposal made Tuesday by the Players’ Association.

headline: In Senate Races, Politics Are Local Again
text: We will soon be unveiling our forecast model for United States Senate races. But as a point of comparison and because there have been a number of important primaries for the Senate in recent weeks, I first wanted to give you my view of the contests.

headline: Introducing the Ocean Health Index
text: In a potential milestone for ocean management, a team of collaborators has produced the first Ocean Health Index, a tool for appraising the state of the world’s oceans. The index takes into account the major factors that influence the quality of regional marine ecosystems like fisheries, biodiversity, tourism and carbon storage and then assigns a score from zero to 100 for each place.

headline: A New Delano, This Time in Moscow
text: The Delano hotel is getting an outpost in Moscow, according to executives with the Morgans Hotel Group. The 160-room hotel, scheduled to open in 2015, will be run by Morgans and developed with the Capital Group.

headline: Equal (Voting) Consideration
text: As the board mentioned on the editorial page today, Ohio doesn’t treat all voters the same. Depending on where you live, your polling place may close promptly 5 p.m., or stay open in the evenings and on weekends. More specifically, if you live in a county likely to favor President Obama, you’ll have to get to the polls before the end of the traditional work day; if you live in a county likely to swing Republican, you can take your time.

headline: In Peugeot’s Troubles, a Test of Contradictory Campaign Promises for Hollande
text: SOCHAUX, France — Peugeot, one of France’s iconic companies, is in trouble, presenting President François Hollande with an early, telling crisis that is displaying the contradictions at the heart of his campaign promises to spur economic growth while shrinking the budget deficit with tax increases.

headline: Don’t Discourage Outside Shareholders
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is currently considering a rule-making petition that advocates tightening the rules governing how quickly shareholders must disclose when they hold 5 percent or more of a company’s shares.

headline: On Medicare, Obama Plays Offense
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa — With Mitt Romney on the attack over Medicare, President Obama entered the fight on Wednesday, catapulting the popular entitlements program to the top of the presidential campaign.

headline: Actress Writes to Putin to Demand Vegan Meals for Jailed Punk Protesters
text: Last Updated, 5:23 p.m. While the prosecution of three members of a Russian protest band called Pussy Riot has raised concerns about freedom of speech and the growing influence of the Orthodox Church in Russia, an American actress has identified another “urgent matter” about the case: Russian prisons do not serve vegan meals.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Valentino
text: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon. Today's pick: a romantic, lace and suede ankle bootie from Valentino Garavani.

headline: Owners Should Know What They’re Getting With Private Equity
text: Puneet Mehta, an Atlanta entrepreneur, remembers how eager he was to take the money. When investors courted him, he felt “razzle-dazzled,” enchanted by their promises to help him build the online marketing business he had founded in 2006.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Valentino Garavani
text: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon in honor of the store’s 111th anniversary. Today’s pick, No. 8 of 11: a romantic, lace and suede ankle bootie from Valentino Garavani. $1,195.

headline: Would You Take a Private Equity Investment?
text: In a small-business guide we’ve just published, Puneet Mehta talks about feeling “razzle-dazzled” when private equity investors approached him about buying into the online marketing business he had founded in 2006 in Atlanta.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 15
text: A view of the day in sports, including heroes’ welcomes for Olympians in Russia, Germany and Uganda, and a ceremony for the arrival of the Olympic flag in Rio de Janeiro, host of the 2016 Summer Games.

headline: Video: Fifth Graders in 1995 Predict How We’ll Use the Internet
text: “Hey, why should I be on the Internet?”

headline: 2013 Range Rover: A Flagship S.U.V. Takes Lessons From Its Sprightly Sibling
text: Land Rover introduced its 2013 Range Rover sport utility vehicle on Wednesday. Though the new flagship is unmistakably kin to the 2012 model, it borrows a measure of edginess from the smaller, sporty and successful Range Rover Evoque, which premiered to critical acclaim last year.

headline: Day 1 of New Dream for Illegal Immigrants
text: Advocates for immigrants drew attention to a program of the Obama administration that on Wednesday started accepting applications from young illegal immigrants seeking temporary legal status to live in the United States.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report:  ‘2 Households…’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festival’s close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.Follow me here: I was moved by seeing a man in the role of a young woman being kissed by a second guy, playing a teenage boy, who minutes earlier portrayed an old lady. And that wasn’t the only instance of unexpected emotion in “2 Households, 2 ________: Shakespeare’s R&J,” a pretty good show despite a fairly bad (and unprintable) title.

headline: For Cubs’ Volstad, Another Start, Another Loss
text: On the surface, it would seem logical to question the employment of a starting pitcher who has an 0-9 record and a 6.96 earned run average this season. Throw in a losing streak of 23 games, and one can start to question why the Cubs right-hander Chris Volstad is still in the rotation.

headline: Fringe Benefits | Highlights from the Edinburgh Festival
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Still Pulling for a Wildflower’s Survival
text: Eight years ago, a preservation battle raged on Staten Island over an inconspicuous plant called Torrey’s mountain mint. It was known to grow in fewer than 20 locations on the planet, and one of them was a site on the island’s southwest edge where a developer planned to build a shopping center called Bricktown Centre at Charleston.

headline: Treasury Appoints 2 to Ally Financial Board
text: Ally Financial, the former GMAC, said on Wednesday that Gerald Greenwald and Henry S. Miller had been elected to its board of directors.

headline: Veterinarian Surprises Florida’s Stearns in Republican Primary
text: A huge cash advantage and a shift to the ideological right were not enough to secure a primary victory for Representative Cliff Stearns, Republican of Florida, who lost his bid for a 13th term to a Tea Party-backed veterinarian who has never held public office.

headline: Biologists Track Biggest Florida Python – 17-Footer with 87 Eggs
text: [Aug. 18, 8:03 a.m. | Updated | See asterisks.]Here’s a quick update on the amazing story of the Burmese pythons that, brought to Florida as a result of the  laxly regulated trade in exotic reptiles, have been spreading and breeding in the state, with the Everglades National Park providing a particularly large buffet of wildlife for feeding. (Read the United States Geological Survey report Severe Declines in Everglades Mammals Linked to Pythons for more.)

headline: Digital Notes: 50,000 Are Owed Royalties, Agency Says
text: 4:02 p.m. | Updated SoundExchange, which collects royalties for digital streams and Internet radio, is looking for 50,000 artists and labels that are owed money.

headline: Pulp Friction
text: Joyce Carol Oates on violence, video games and sins of omission.

headline: What Stands on Two Legs, Isn’t Pink but Is Still a Flamingo?
text: Those in need of an adorable-baby-bird fix need look no farther than the Bronx Zoo, where a 3-day-old Caribbean flamingo emerged from under its mom and took its first steps last week at the zoo’s Aquatic Birds exhibit. The big moment was caught on video and released Wednesday by the zoo.

headline: TimesCast Tech | August 15, 2012
text: Game designers target the tablet market. | Keeping the grass green during a drought. | Customizing education by the hour.

headline: Ex-Officers Attack Obama Over Leaks on Bin Laden Raid
text: WASHINGTON — In a direct attack on one of President Obama’s political strengths, a group of former special operations and C.I.A. officers started a campaign on Tuesday night accusing Mr. Obama of recklessly leaking information about the raid that killed Osama bin Laden and other security matters to gain political advantage.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’ Sets April 4 Broadway Opening
text: “Kinky Boots,” one of the most anticipated musicals of the new Broadway season, with Cyndi Lauper making her debut as a songwriter for the stage, will begin performances on March 5, 2013, at the Al Hirschfeld Theater and open on April 4, the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Australia Restricts Company Logos on Cigarette Packs
text: Australia’s highest court upheld a law on Wednesday that prohibits tobacco companies from using their logos on cigarette packets, a decision that means smokers could see more of the graphic images associated with their habit: blistered, cancer-stricken mouths; children sick from secondhand smoke, and gangrenous limbs.

headline: At Ryan-Adelson Gathering, Budget Talk Trumps Israel
text: LAS VEGAS — At a private gathering with Representative Paul D. Ryan, Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire casino owner and Republican super-donor, offered no public remarks and, somewhat surprisingly, his pet cause of Israel was not part of the conversation, according to an attendee.

headline: Wells Fargo Offers E-Receipts to Branch Customers
text: Lots of retailers — the online kind and the brick-and-mortar version — have begun offering electronic receipts for purchases to help cut down on paper clutter in your wallet. So why shouldn’t banks get into the act, too?

headline: Long Island Man Is Charged With Insurance Fraud in Faked Drowning Case
text: A Long Island man suspected of faking his drowning to collect more than $400,000 in life insurance was arrested Wednesday and formally charged with insurance fraud, conspiracy and filing a false report.

headline: Romney on Regulation
text: Mitt Romney’s response to Joe Biden’s latest verbal fumble has been both totally predictable and totally baffling.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Mars on View, and Odes to Minecraft
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: ‘Now 43’ Compilation Tops Album Chart
text: After a nine-week run at No. 1, Carly Rae Jepsen’s song “Call Me Maybe” has finally been bumped from the top spot, by Flo Rida’s “Whistle.” But Ms. Jepsen’s song is now part of a different No. 1. It is the first track on the latest installment — Vol. 43 — of “Now That’s What I Call Music!” — the long-running pop compilation series, which opens atop Billboard’s album chart this week.

headline: Embracing the Right Fit
text: SO far, the Mitt Romney-Paul Ryan ticket has been given the approval rating typically reserved for a Hollywood bromance in the dead of August. Two thumbs up for the cute Republican dudes!

headline: Illegal Immigrants Line Up by Thousands for Deportation Deferrals
text: CHICAGO — Tens of thousands of young illegal immigrants waited excitedly in lines as long as a mile and thronged to information sessions across the country on Wednesday, the first day that a federal immigration agency began accepting applications for deportation deferrals that include permits to work legally.

headline: In Store | French Tips
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: 9/11 Museum Asks for Dismissal of Suit Over Cross
text: The National September 11 Memorial and Museum filed court papers this week seeking to dismiss a federal lawsuit brought by a group of atheists who oppose the museum’s decision to display the giant cross-shaped steel beam that became a site of daily prayer during the cleanup of ground zero.

headline: Inflation Deflation
text: The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated on Wednesday that prices rose at an annual pace of 1.4 percent over the 12 months ending in July, and even more slowly during July itself. The Federal Reserve likes an annual rate of 2 percent. So it’s time for more stimulus, right? QE33333333333!

headline: Bridgewater to Spend $750 Million on New Offices
text: There are hedge funds, and then there is Bridgewater Associates.

headline: Ratification of Union’s Deal With Caterpillar May Face Difficulties
text: Caterpillar and the International Association of Machinists said on Wednesday that they had reached a tentative six-year settlement that could end a 15-week strike at the company’s hydraulics parts plant in Joliet, Ill.

headline: On Our Radar: Wildfires in Washington State
text: Firefighters battle more than a dozen wildfires across the West, including a massive out-of-control blaze that has burned over 28,000 acres between two national forests in Washington State. [Reuters]

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: The Young Person’s Guide to the (Smartphone) Orchestra
text: When I was a toddler, my parents introduced me to music-making through a cheap plastic recorder. Later came a secondhand violin and the tireless efforts of my school’s choir teacher. It was all fun, even if I found it so hard to learn violin the “traditional” way. All I could produce for ages was a horrid squeaking.

headline: The Joys and Hazards of Self-Publishing on the Web
text: Not long ago, an aspiring book writer rejected by traditional publishing houses had only one alternative: vanity publishing. For $5,000 or $10,000, or sometimes much more, he could have his manuscript edited and published, provided that he agreed to buy many copies himself, often a few thousand or more. They typically ended up in the garage.

headline: A Man’s Humdrum Life Suddenly Turns Potent
text: Jonathan Tropper’s slick, manipulative new novel is about a lovable sad sack named Drew Silver. “You’ve got that kind of cuddly bad-boy thing going on, like you’re dangerous, but only a little bit, you know?” his daughter tells him.

headline: Missed Chance to Reject Voting Barriers
text: Judge Robert Simpson of the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania seems to assume that legislators have a high-minded public purpose for the laws they pass. That’s why, on Wednesday morning, he refused to grant an injunction to halt a Republican-backed voter ID law that could disenfranchise hundreds of thousands of poor and minority state residents in November.

headline: A Beach Body Built in Wisconsin
text: WHEN it comes to free celebrity endorsements, they don’t get much better than a presumptive vice-presidential candidate who swears by your product.

headline: Despite Alarm by U.S., Europe Lets Hezbollah Operate Openly
text: BERLIN — As American officials sound the alarm over what they call a resurgent threat from the Shiite militant group Hezbollah, thousands of its members and supporters operate with few restrictions in Europe, raising money that is funneled to the group’s leadership in Lebanon.

headline: Cisco Revenue and Profit Exceed Forecasts as Orders in Asia Stay Strong
text: Cisco Systems, the world’s largest maker of computer networking equipment, delivered quarterly results on Wednesday that slightly surpassed Wall Street’s expectations in a challenging environment for corporate technology spending.

headline: A Thorny Flower
