headline: Seeking a Reprieve
text: Thousands of young immigrants, in the country illegally, lined up to take part of a program that would allow deportations to be deferred for up to two years.

headline: Casino Plan Runs Into Opposition in Spain
text: MADRID — Two struggling Spanish cities, Madrid and Barcelona, have been eagerly courting the billionaire casino magnate Sheldon G. Adelson for months, each of them trying to become the site of his planned casino and leisure resort.

headline: Scene City: A Book Sale, Hamptons Style
text: The East Hampton Library holds its annual Authors Night benefit with a book sale and private dinners.

headline: ‘Carpe Aestatem': Seize Summer’s Last Days
text: Less than two weeks.

headline: State Regulators Widen Libor Investigation
text: State regulators are widening their investigation into interest rate manipulation, pursuing wrongdoing at seven of the world’s biggest banks.

headline: Anybody Have a Book?
text: ONCE you write a book, the work isn’t finished. You still have to get people to buy it.

headline: Another Trial Is Scheduled for Man Charged in 2008 Killing of Psychologist
text: A man accused of murdering a psychologist in her Upper East Side office in 2008 is set to face trial next year, after his lawyers said Wednesday that they would not challenge a finding that he was mentally fit. A 2010 attempt to try the man, David Tarloff, ended in a mistrial after he became psychotic during jury selection.

headline: New Big East Commissioner Can Talk Ambitions but Not Details
text: There was much that Mike Aresco couldn’t address Wednesday, when he was formally introduced as the Big East’s newest commissioner at the Manhattan New York Athletic Club. New to collegiate administration, he still looked as his contemporaries would, with shadows under his eyes, though his job has just begun.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Pakistan, India and South Africa.

headline: Van Persie Heads to Manchester United
text: Robin van Persie’s escape from Arsenal needs only a doctor’s approval before it becomes final.

headline: Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons Will Play Broadway
text: Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons will perform in a weeklong engagement at the Broadway Theater in October to celebrate the vocal group’s 50th anniversary, the producers announced on Wednesday. The show will run from Oct. 19 through 27.

headline: A Novel Asks Seattle to Laugh at Itself
text: SEATTLE — Maria Semple made an instant, jarring discovery when she moved with her boyfriend and daughter from Los Angeles to Seattle, a city whose Patagonia-clad inhabitants like to talk about bicycling, the environment and the eternally dull question (in her opinion) of whether it might rain.

headline: Fall Trends
text: No. 1: the decorated jacket. No. 2: the wrap. No. 3: the new suit.

headline: Syrian Conflict Imperils Historical Treasures
text: Preservationists and archaeologists are warning that fighting in Syria’s commercial capital, Aleppo — considered the world’s oldest continuously inhabited human settlement — threatens to damage irreparably the stunning architectural and cultural legacy left by 5,000 years of civilizations.

headline: Big Retailers Plan Effort for Mobile Purchases
text: Cash, credit or debit? You may one day have far more choices to make at the checkout counter. A group of big retailers, including 7-Eleven, Best Buy, CVS and Wal-Mart, said on Wednesday that they were forming a company that would offer a way for customers to pay for purchases with their smartphones, joining a wide array of businesses seeking a piece of this market.

headline: Broadway, Broadway, Here We Are! (Clap!)
text: POSTERS from infamous Broadway flops loom behind the young performers gathered for lunch recently at Joe Allen, the theater district restaurant. But for these exuberant actors, all making their Broadway debuts in “Bring It On: The Musical,” the brutal realities of the business couldn’t seem further away.

headline: Giving Their Regards
text: Five Broadway newbies are performing in “Bring It On: the Musical.”

headline: Dreaming of a Life as Vivid as Her Art
text: Inocente Izucar wants to join the circus someday and learn sign language. She paints her face every morning with colors and designs as bold as those on her sprawling canvases. She sometimes orders dessert before dinner because she emphatically believes “you can never go wrong with a root-beer float.”

headline: On Univision’s Nightly News, a Plea for Presidential Debate on Latino Issues
text: Univision will use its nightly news broadcast on Wednesday to plead with both presidential campaigns to accommodate an additional debate, on Univision, directed at the issues of concern to Latino viewers.

headline: Hip-Hop’s Loyal Mascot Now Cheers Himself On
text: 2 Chainz is 35, tall and gangly, all awkward angles. A working-class-minded interloper into a hip-hop era that has largely shelved self-presentations that are less than 110 percent polished, he juts out, tough to miss. His luxury restaurant is Benihana, not Philippe. His luxury brand is Polo, not Margiela. He rapped for more than a decade with little to no acclaim. He is nobody’s sex symbol.

headline: The Perplexity of Youths in a Group
text: The opening work of the Smuin Ballet’s triple bill at the Joyce Theater on Monday provides evidence of one of the most singular choreographic minds working in ballet today. Trey McIntyre’s “Oh, Inverted World” — set to songs by the Shins — is a pop ballet, reminiscent of some of the best pop ballets of Twyla Tharp. Its subject, though, is one that I don’t remember Ms. Tharp tackling: the perplexity of young individuals amid the group.

headline: Pianist Greets Beethoven Like an Old Friend in a Festival Debut
text: The Austrian pianist Rudolf Buchbinder has had a lifelong fascination with Beethoven, performing and recording the complete concertos and sonatas on several occasions. Beethoven “haunted me 24 hours, day and night, he often drove me half-crazy,” Mr. Buchbinder wrote about his experience of performing the sonata cycle in 1982.

headline: In Search of New Subjects to Spoof
text: One good thing about “Bullet in the Face,” a new series starting Thursday night on IFC, is the theme song, a jazzy, torchy spoof of a “Goldfinger”-era James Bond anthem. The chorus serves as a convenient plot summary:

headline: Russian Mayor at Center of Protests Resigns
text: MOSCOW — It was a conflict that made clear the impunity granted to public officials by Russia’s criminal justice system: The editor of a local newspaper was beaten nearly to death in 2008 after criticizing the mayor of a Moscow suburb, and the police barely feigned an investigation.

headline: Bridge Play at the Second World Mind Sports Games
text: LILLE, France — At the Second World Mind Sports Games here all three United States teams qualified for the round of 16, which started on Wednesday and will end on Thursday at 1:20 p.m. Eastern time. The results are at worldbridge.org.

headline: Tunisian Women March to Defend Equality
text: As Reuters reported, thousands of Tunisian women marched in the capital, Tunis, on Monday night to protest a provision in the new Islamist government’s draft constitution describing women as “complementary to men.” The 6,000 protesters pledged to defend the equality under the law they have enjoyed since Tunisia adopted its Code of Personal Status on Aug. 13, 1956.

headline: A Product With Devotees Tries to Widen Its Niche
text: THE Pelican brand of protective cases for electronics is well known, but only among users in fields like the oil industry, the military and aerospace. For years, the company’s primary form of marketing consisted of expos and trade publications.

headline: Johnson & Johnson to Remove Formaldehyde From Products
text: Johnson & Johnson, which makes a range of personal care products like baby shampoo, acne cream and antiwrinkle lotion, announced plans Wednesday to remove a host of potentially harmful chemicals, like formaldehyde, from its line of consumer products by the end of 2015, becoming the first major consumer products company to make such a widespread commitment.

headline: On Frogs, Fungi, Climate and the New News Process
text: On Monday, the University of South Florida press office put out a release to draw attention to an important new study finding amplified disease risk in frogs when exposure to a dangerous fungus coincides with increasingly varied temperatures. The headline was “Frogs Getting Sick from Climate Change.”

headline: Boundary: Keeping Cloud Software in Shape
text: With thousands of different software applications flying around the cloud of a data center’s computer servers and storage devices, things can get complex. There might be a business in explaining the story of their travels to overtaxed system managers.

headline: Eternally Under Construction
text: When John Archer finds an interesting piece of architectural salvage, he often builds a new wing around it.

headline: Scrap Mansion
text: DANVERS, Mass.

headline: The Cherished Remainders of a Luxe Life
text: IN her heyday as the bejeweled empress of New York philanthropy, Brooke Astor entertained presidents, first ladies and a potpourri of pooh-bahs and literati at her elegant 14-room duplex on Park Avenue. And when she died on Aug. 13, 2007, at Holly Hill, her estate in Westchester County, at 105, she left behind two households’ worth of cherished possessions, including Qing dynasty lacquer furniture, a jade-and-diamond Cartier clock and dozens of 19th-century dog portraits.

headline: Seeking an Edge, Then Falling Off the Cliff
text: The fastball left Matt Harrison’s hand at 93 miles per hour, headed for the inner half of the plate, belt high. This was the All-Star Game, last month in Kansas City, and any hitter might have done what Melky Cabrera did to that pitch: lash it on a line into the left-field bullpen for a home run.

headline: After Cabrera Is Suspended, Surprise and Sadness From the Yankees
text: The news that San Francisco Giants outfielder Melky Cabrera was suspended 50 games Wednesday for testing positive for testosterone was met with surprise and sadness in the Yankees’ clubhouse.

headline: Helen Gurley Brown, as Others Saw Her
text: YOU can debate for hours whether Helen Gurley Brown liberated women or held them back, with her salacious cover lines, big-haired scantily clad cover girls and relentless focus on improving sex lives (hers and his).

headline: Skinny-Dipping in the City
text: URBANITES: Consider the real estate luxuries that have consumed your thoughts, occupied your daydreams, perhaps even encroached upon your bank accounts, from the relatively modest (your own washer and dryer) to the truly extravagant (your own pool on the roof).

headline: In Yucatán, a Home for Two Travel Writers
text: A couple renovates a house in the Mexican state of Yucatán.

headline: In Mexico, a Dateline Beckons
text: TRAVEL writing, like any profession, has its advantages, the most obvious being the job itself: exploring faraway places on someone else’s dime. One drawback, though, is that travel writers are rarely able to immerse themselves in any one place.

headline: U.N. Panel Blames Syrian Army and Militia for Houla Massacre
text: An independent panel appointed by the United Nations to investigate rights abuses in Syria said Wednesday that the government’s armed forces and loyalist militias were responsible for the worst known atrocity in the conflict, a massacre of 108 villagers, nearly half of them women and children, in the western village of Houla on May 25.

headline: Chandeliers
text: Sara Story, an interior designer, searches for the right chandelier for each room’s temperament.

headline: Master of Suspense
text: WHEN Sara Story is looking for light fixtures, her feeling is, the bolder, the better.

headline: The King of Pants Hopes for a Second Reign
text: POOR pants. You never hear economists pegging a market forecast to their lengths, as they do with skirts, or magazines celebrating “It” pants, as they do with bags and shoes. In boom times, as in lean years, pants are just pants.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Would a fully equipped outdoor kitchen with appliances increase the resale value of my house?

headline: New York Times Magazine Plays New York Magazine in Softball, Everyone Gets Confused About Who’s On Which Team
text: Where we left off, on the fertile lowlands of Central Park’s public softball fields, our heroes from The New York Times Magazine were celebrating their first softball victory of the season (and maybe the last few years) against their archrival, The New Yorker. The score was around 9-1, some said. If only that were the only score of the summer we had to recall.

headline: Warning Issued on Codeine for Children
text: The Food and Drug Administration issued a warning on Wednesday after three children died from respiratory arrest caused by regular doses of codeine after surgery to treat sleep apnea. The agency cautioned parents and health workers to watch for symptoms of overdose, like unusual sleepiness, difficulty being aroused or awakened, confusion or noisy and difficult breathing.

headline: The Giants’ Top Pick Shows Grit and Speed
text: ALBANY — David Wilson jogged close to the sideline, his right hand gripping a ball. In that moment at Monday’s practice, Wilson could hear the fans just 10 feet away.

headline: Even Turtles Need a Nice Place to Call Home
text: Two years ago, the children’s-book author and illustrator Jan Brett and her husband, Joseph Hearne, a bassist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, installed a turtle pond on the grounds of their two-acre home in Norwell, Mass. It was inspired by her plan to write a book about an Eastern box turtle with wildflowers and ferns sprouting from its shell. In “Mossy,” due out next month (G. P. Putnam’s Sons; $17.99), the turtle spends some unhappy months on display at a natural-history museum until a penitent biologist restores it to its habitat.

headline: Ecuador to Let Assange Stay in Its Embassy
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The government of Ecuador is prepared to allow Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, to remain in its embassy in London indefinitely under a type of humanitarian protection, a government official said in Quito on Wednesday night. Mr. Assange has been holed up in the embassy for two months seeking asylum.

headline: No House Training Needed
text: Visitors to the New York International Gift Fair this weekend will be greeted by a menagerie at the MollaSpace booth — a buffalo, lamb, dog and horse, all prepared to support you. Designed by Owen Chuang and Cloud Lu of BiAugust, the Black Animal Chair collection is handmade in Taiwan, where the two are based.

headline: In Connecticut, a Convergence of Green Thumbs
text: From Aug. 24 to 26, gardeners may be inspired by earth-friendly techniques while exploring the art historian George Schoellkopf’s Hollister House Garden in Washington, Conn., at the symposium “Gardening Anew: Fresh Perspectives on the Garden.” Sponsored by Hollister House Garden and the Garden Conservancy, it will convene master landscape designers and plant gurus of the Northeast. Speakers will include Edwina von Gal, a designer whose clients include Richard Serra and Calvin Klein; William Cullina, executive director of Coastal Maine Botanical Gardens, a 250-acre expanse of organically grown native plants; and Eric T. Fleisher, director of horticulture for Battery Park City Parks Conservancy, who will discuss composting, soil biology and water conservation. Late-season plants from New England’s best nurseries will be sold, and there will be tours of seven area gardens, including Mr. Schoellkopf’s 25-acre masterpiece, developed over three decades.

headline: Counting Stanzas and Couplets Instead of Sheep
text: It’s not easy to read Kerry Larkin’s poetry without feeling the tug of the natural world. Truth be told, it’s not easy to read Ms. Larkin’s poetry, period. Sometimes the words are embroidered in white on white, and the messages are more like texture. Or in A Perfect Moon, above left, which mentions “pines that resemble construction paper cut outs against the almost black sky,” the lines are alternating bands of autumnal color.

headline: On Madison Avenue, a New Vibe
text: Conspicuous consumption has made a resounding return to Madison Avenue, at least on that mile of glistening shops stretching north of Barneys New York at East 60th Street. But it isn’t quite the same Madison Avenue as what was there before.

headline: Industrial Ingenuity (Just Add Water)
text: Roman & Williams, the design firm founded by Robin Standefer and Stephen Alesch, won fame for its scene-setting interiors for Manhattan’s trendy Ace and Standard Hotels, as well as the restaurants, bars and cafes within them. Now it’s moved on to product design, with bath fittings for Waterworks. The R. W. Atlas collection, which was inspired in part by a 1930s Leica camera and by an old microscope displayed in the designers’ offices, has a strong industrial sensibility; it would look at home in any vintage factory setting.

headline: Though Tone Is Familiar, Scott Has His Eye on a Different Result
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Jets linebacker Bart Scott spoke off the field Wednesday, and he still sounded like the player whose outspokenness helped him earn the nickname the Mad Backer.

headline: Sales at Baker, Ochre, Ligne Roset and Others
text: Baker furniture has introduced an Odds & Ends outlet Web site, updated weekly, with items up to 75 percent off (a Bill Sofield for Baker Cheval dining table, usually $10,124, is $2,531); (866) 222-3060, bakeroddsandends.com.

headline: California: Man Convicted of Murder in Five Deaths From 2003 Wildfire
text: Rickie Lee Fowler, 30, was convicted of murder on Wednesday in the deaths of five men caused by a fire he intentionally set in 2003 in Waterman Canyon in the foothills above San Bernardino. The wildfire burned 91,000 acres and 1,000 homes. Investigators said Mr. Fowler was high on methamphetamine and angry with a friend who had thrown him out of his home. Witnesses reported seeing Mr. Fowler and another man fling a lighted flare into dry brush, the authorities said. Prosecutors said they would seek the death penalty.

headline: Downtown Comes Uptown
text: EVER since the recession, Madison Avenue, a barometer of New York City’s retail health if ever there was one, has undergone what could be described as three stages of grief:

headline: In Albany, Hopes of Making New York State a Yogurt Empire
text: ALBANY — After two hours, the Yogurt Summit ran out of spoons.

headline: Professor Faces Firing for Joke Tied to Shootings
text: After turning down the lights in his classroom at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Prof. Gregory F. Sullivan began showing a documentary and prepared to step out for a moment.

headline: Maryland: Casino Bill Goes to Voters
text: Maryland will get another casino and expand table games statewide if voters approve a measure signed by Gov. Martin O’Malley on Wednesday. The legislation would allow for a casino to be built in Prince George’s County and permit table games in casinos. It also would enable the state’s casinos to stay open all day and lower taxes at some of them. Mr. O’Malley said it would create 2,300 jobs and generate $200 million for education.

headline: Stoudemire Putting New Spin on Career
text: Over a 16-month span that ended in May, Amar’e Stoudemire lost, in no particular order: his health, his brother, his head coach, his primacy in the Knicks’ universe, his scoring touch and, in the end, a little of his dignity.

headline: Mexico: Confessions Are Reported in the Killing of 5 Journalists
text: The Mexican authorities announced Wednesday that captured members of a criminal cell had confessed to the killing of five journalists in the state of Veracruz this year. According to the state attorney, the criminals, one of whom was detained last week carrying identification cards belonging to Irasema Becerra, a recently slain newspaper employee, admitted to a total of 36 crimes. Press freedom activists expressed dissatisfaction with the announcement, saying that it was unacceptable for the authorities to announce the resolution of these cases based on confessions rather than conducting full investigations. A 2012 report from Human Rights Watch attributed the country’s failing justice system in part to the “acceptance by some judges of confessions obtained through torture and other ill treatment.”

headline: Iran Group May Remain on U.S. Terror List
text: WASHINGTON — State Department officials are preparing for a possible decision by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton to redesignate an Iranian opposition group as a terrorist organization, in part because of the group’s resistance to abandoning its camp in Iraq, two American officials said Wednesday.

headline: Syrian Rebels Said to Be Holding Elite Fighters From Iran
text: WASHINGTON — American officials said Wednesday that they had obtained credible information that at least some of the 48 Iranians captured in Damascus this month by Syrian rebels were members of Iran’s elite Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, not the pilgrims described by the government in Tehran.

headline: U.S. Wins in Mexico for the First Time
text: The United States men’s soccer team ended a 75-year drought Wednesday night, defeating Mexico, 1-0, in a friendly for its first win on Mexican soil.

headline: The NBC Sports Network Hopes Ratings Will Rise
text: In past lives, it was called the Outdoor Life Channel, OLN and Versus. But by any name, the NBC Sports Network has been a blip in a universe dominated by ESPN.

headline: Hernandez Latest to Achieve Perfection, to Fans’ Delight
text: In what has become the year of the perfect game, Felix Hernandez of the Seattle Mariners added his name to the list Wednesday, marking the first time that three pitchers have pulled off the feat in the same season.

headline: Even in a Scrabble Match, ‘Cheat’ Is a 4-Letter Word
text: Bending the rules in sports and games may have just gotten its biggest global exposure at the Olympics, where we learned, among other things, that losing in badminton and soccer is an actual strategy (and one the International Olympic Committee officially frowns upon). But now cheating has moved into a more puzzling arena: competitive Scrabble.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 26
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: The Bias in Custom Prices
text: To the Editor:

headline: Having Kids Yet?
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Check-Cashing Stores
text: To the Editor:

headline: Can't Afford Foreign Aid, or Can't Afford to Cut It?
text: With so many Americans struggling, and with the federal budget in dire straits, aiding other nations may be profligate.

headline: The Case for Natural Gas Exports
text: NEW data released last month signaled a milestone for American energy: natural gas joined coal as the top source of electric power. Gas production has boomed on the back of abundant supplies. That has spurred debates over hydraulic fracturing, a method to extract gas from shale.

headline: A Chinese Murder Mystery, Far From Solved
text: LAST Thursday’s hastily orchestrated murder trial of Gu Kailai, the wife of the ousted Chinese Politburo member Bo Xilai, has raised several questions that cast serious doubt on the case.

headline: The View From Pyongyang
text: LIKE Havana, only more so, the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, is bereft of commercial billboards but covered with propaganda posters. In recent years, however, one company has been allowed to advertise its products: Pyonghwa Motors, a joint venture between the Rev. Sun Myung Moon’s South Korea-based Unification Church and North Korea’s state-run Ryonbong General Corporation. A few signs promoting the company’s Whistle sedan can be seen in Pyongyang and surrounding areas. Essentially a Hyundai, the Whistle is an increasingly common sight on Pyongyang streets, along with a growing number of BMW, Lexus, Mercedes, Nissan and other luxury and nonluxury vehicles, many privately owned.

headline: With Arena, Rapper Rewrites Celebrity Investors’ Playbook
text: When the developer Bruce Ratner set out to buy the New Jersey Nets and build an arena for them in Brooklyn, he recruited Jay-Z, the hip-hop superstar who grew up in public housing a couple of miles from the site, to join his group of investors.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Israeli Leaders Could Be Dissuaded From Striking Iran
text: JERUSALEM — A former Israeli national security adviser said Wednesday that the prime minister and the defense minister told him this week they had not yet decided to attack Iran’s nuclear facilities and could be dissuaded from a strike if President Obama approved stricter sanctions and publicly confirmed his willingness to use military force.

headline: Coalition Aims to Link School Group and Romney
text: Hoping that New Yorkers will think of “Romney” as a dirty word, a coalition of labor unions and liberal advocacy groups is beginning a campaign on Thursday to tie the presumptive Republican presidential nominee to defenders of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s education policies.

headline: Shooting at Family Research Council in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — A gunman trying to enter the downtown offices of a conservative policy organization on Wednesday morning shot and wounded a security guard before he was wrestled to the ground and arrested, a city police officer said.

headline: Romney the Unknowable
text: Ten days from now, some of the world’s best-paid magicians of image and narrative will unveil a reboot of a most unfathomable man, Willard Mitt Romney, a 2012 model with a shelf life of barely two months.

headline: Middle-Age Blues
text: Paul Ryan is everywhere! Nobody can talk about anything but the congressman from Wisconsin. We now know he is the intellectual, spiritual and moral center of the House of Representatives, who keeps his body fat below 8 percent and excels at a sport that involves sticking your hand inside a catfish, grabbing it by the tonsils and pulling it out of the water. Also, I believe he may have been the guy who ran the men’s relay race in the Olympics on a broken fibula.

headline: A Freebie Too Far
text: Most tennis fans can only dream about receiving the kind of thick, cream-colored invitation that State Senator Tony Avella of Queens got recently in the mail. The United States Tennis Association was pleased to invite him and a guest to view this year’s tennis championships, which begin Aug. 27. They could sit in the President’s Suite. They could pick “one session of your choice” during the first week. This is tennis at its best, viewed from the best seats in Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Risk Builds as Junk Bonds Boom
text: Money market funds pay next to nothing. Interest rates on United States Treasuries are dismal. The volatile stock market has been dead money for more than a decade.

headline: Pink Pants, Trotters and an Entourage
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Normally on the dark day here, Tom Durkin sleeps late and catches up on bills and errands. It’s the only day off for the voice of New York racing when the Saratoga meet is in session, and Durkin cherishes his alone time and silence.

headline: Muni Bonds Not as Safe as Thought
text: Municipal bonds, widely seen as one of the safest investments, actually default more often than most people realize, according to research issued Wednesday by economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: Egypt’s Islamist Leaders Accused of Stifling Media
text: CAIRO — Several recent moves by government authorities against Egyptian journalists have drawn sharp criticism from the news media and led to accusations that the country’s new Islamist president is willing to tolerate — if not employ — the same heavy-handed tactics used by former President Hosni Mubarak to stifle dissent.

headline: Judge Urges Apple and Samsung to Settle Their Patent Dispute
text: The judge presiding over an intellectual property dispute between Apple and Samsung Electronics said on Wednesday that the chief executives of the two companies should talk again before the jury begins its deliberations.

headline: The Women of Afghanistan
text: Afghanistan can be a hard and cruel land, especially for women and girls. Many fear they will be even more vulnerable to harsh tribal customs and the men who impose them after American troops withdraw by the end of 2014.

headline: Amid the Beauty of Mountains, Oil Rigs Arrive
text: The divisions within the Blackfeet tribe over oil represent two visions of the land where members have lived for centuries.

headline: Four Are Arrested in 2008 Robbery of an Armored-Car Guard, Including the Guard
text: When a man staged a brazen daylight robbery of an armored-car guard in Manhattan four years ago and made off with $330,000, the police immediately suspected an inside job.

headline: Tapping Into the Land, and Dividing Its People
text: BLACKFEET INDIAN RESERVATION, Mont. — The mountains along the eastern edge of Glacier National Park rise from the prairie like dinosaur teeth, their silvery ridges and teardrop fields of snow forming the doorway to one of America’s most pristine places.

headline: Keyed Up
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — In solving this Thursday puzzle from Ethan Cooper, I found that many of my hunches and first guesses just wouldn’t fit. It started at 1 Across with “Swiss —”, when I felt a compulsion to fill in “cheese,” particularly because it started with a “ch.” That would have been too many letters, though, and the right answer was the much healthier Swiss CHARD.

headline: No Criminal Case Is Likely in Loss at MF Global
text: A criminal investigation into the collapse of the brokerage firm MF Global and the disappearance of about $1 billion in customer money is now heading into its final stage without charges expected against any top executives.

headline: N.H.L. Commissioner Not Impressed With Union’s Proposal
text: Commissioner Gary Bettman on Wednesday effectively dismissed the N.H.L. Players’ Association proposal for a new collective bargaining agreement, saying that union and management remained far apart with one month to go before the current agreement expires.

headline: Pakistani Air Force Base With Nuclear Ties Is Attacked
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — Suspected Islamist militants attacked a major Pakistani Air Force base where some of the country’s nuclear weapons are thought to be stored in the early hours of Thursday, setting off an exchange of fire that lasted several hours.

headline: A Talk With Peter Hedges
text: Peter Hedges, the screenwriter and director of "The Odd Life of Timothy Green," discusses elements of his work.

headline: Volunteers Rescue Livestock From Raging Wildfire in Washington State
text: The Kittitas County Fairgrounds in central Washington State was being prepared for the arrival of hundreds of horses for the annual 4-H Horse Show this weekend when it suddenly became a crisis center for livestock caught in a wildfire that has consumed more than 28,000 acres since Monday.

headline: Dickey Gives Up Three Homers to Reds and Two Bracelets to Umpires
text: CINCINNATI — Baseball players attach significance to routine, find comfort in repetition. The Mets’ starters had their routines disrupted Wednesday — in more ways than one.

headline: Moments of Terror, Without Sound
text: William Saint Eloi, a deaf community leader in Leveque, Haiti, shares his memories of the earthquake of 2010.

headline: In Haiti, Uneven Revival From Earthquake Disaster
text: Hundreds of thousands remain without permanent housing in Haiti, two and a half years after an earthquake devastated the country.

headline: Show and Tell for Teachers, Inspired by Reality TV
text: Great teaching, it is sometimes said, is one of those things where you know it when you see it. Now, teachers in Washington will be able to see a lot more of it.

headline: ‘ESPNFC Press Pass’ Debuts
text: ESPN’s English-language global soccer show — “ESPNFC Press Pass” — debuted Wednesday in the United States and will be carried throughout the coming European season. The 30-minute show will be carried on the ESPNEWS channel six nights a week, Monday through Saturday at 2 a.m. Eastern (Sunday through Friday at 11 p.m. Pacific).

headline: Years After Haiti Quake, Safe Housing Is a Dream for Many
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Since the earthquake of Jan. 12, 2010, a scrappy 12-year-old boy named Givenson Fanfan has been sleeping on the rock-hard floor of a tent pitched in a fetid camp dominated by a 50-foot tower of trash. He dreams of a bed.

headline: Aug. 15: To Bounce, or Not to Bounce
text: Wednesday brought more data that measured Representative Paul D. Ryan’s impact on the horse race. There was a new set of polls in swing states from the firm Purple Strategies, and there was a weekly national tracking poll from YouGov.

headline: Fort Hood Shooting Trial Delayed Pending Ruling on Beard
text: HOUSTON — The Army psychiatrist accused of killing 13 people in a 2009 shooting rampage at the Fort Hood Army base in Killeen, Tex., won a temporary delay of his trial on Wednesday, after a military appeals court halted the proceedings to allow it time to rule on whether the judge in his case can order him to be forcibly shaved.

headline: Job Losses Persist for the Less-Educated
text: After suffering the largest share of job losses in the recession, Americans with no more than a high school education have continued to lose jobs during the sputtering recovery while better-educated people have gained millions of jobs, according to a Georgetown University study.

headline: Georgetown University Study on College Education and Employment
text: Americans with no more than a high school education have continued to lose jobs after the recession, while better-educated people have added millions of jobs.

headline: Soccer Enthusiasts Hope for a Stadium and a Pro Team in Queens
text: On many evenings in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, there are so many pickup soccer games being played on the worn fields that some matches spill over into the parking lots.

headline: Choice of Paul Ryan Shifts the Focus From Economy to Ideology
text: DES MOINES — Four years ago, John Brooks cast his ballot for Barack Obama, becoming one of the voters won over by his promise for changing Washington. This time, he had been undecided, but he said Mitt Romney made his decision easier by placing Representative Paul D. Ryan on the Republican ticket.

headline: Nellie Gray, Abortion Foe and Leader of Annual March, Dies at 88
text: Nellie Gray, a steadfast opponent of abortion who for almost 40 years led a yearly protest march in Washington that drew tens of thousands of supporters, and whose battle cry was “No exception! No compromise!,” was found dead on Monday at her home in Washington. She was 88.

headline: Pennsylvania Judge Keeps Voter ID Law Intact on Its Way to Higher Court
text: A Pennsylvania judge on Wednesday declined to block a new state law requiring specific kinds of photo identification to vote. Liberal groups, arguing that minorities and the poor would be disproportionately deprived of the ballot, said they would appeal to the State Supreme Court to stop the law before the November elections.

headline: Joan Roberts Dies at 95; Original ‘Oklahoma!’ Star
text: Joan Roberts, who created the role of the winsome “yeller”-haired heroine, Laurey, in the original Broadway production of “Oklahoma!,” died on Monday in Stamford, Conn. She was 95.

headline: Corrections: August 16, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Health Care Leads Campaign Dialogue in Midwest
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa — With Mitt Romney on the attack on Medicare, President Obama personally engaged in the fight on Wednesday as the popular public health program catapulted to the top of the presidential campaign agenda.

headline: Jews Awarded Damages in California Hotel Case
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — A jury here put the total price tag for what it held to be an anti-Semitic episode at the Hotel Shangri-La at about $1.6 million on Thursday. The award includes about $1.2 million in compensatory damages and more than $400,000 in punitive damages.

headline: Life, Interrupted: Putting a Positive Spin on Cancer
text: As a cancer patient, I think a lot about how we talk about illness — or more often, how we talk around it. Even the word “cancer” is ugly, scary, burdensome — a roadblock for a conversation before it even starts. Who wants to go there? Much of the time, I’d rather not bring it up if I don’t have to — and I’m the one with the disease!

headline: Word of the Day | cognizance
text: cognizance •\ˈkäg-nə-zən(t)s\• noun

headline: Homes for $1.5 Million
text: Properties in Massachusetts, Wyoming and Texas.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.5 Million
text: BARNSTABLE, MASS.

headline: In Gibraltar, a Restored 19th-Century Cottage
text: A three-bedroom Colonial cottage dating to 1803 is on the market in the British overseas territory of Gibraltar for $2.1 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Gibraltar
text: A HISTORIC COLONIAL HOME ON A LARGE LANDSCAPED LOT IN GIBRALTAR

headline: Garcia Is Latest Yankee to Thwart Texas
text: Freddy Garcia started Wednesday’s game facing the unenviable task of following perhaps the best Yankees pitching performance of the season, and he had to wait an additional 105 minutes before he could even attempt to outshine it.

headline: Sex Life of Teenagers Is Subject of Study
text: The popular notion that teenagers who are not ready for intercourse are experimenting with oral sex en masse is being challenged by new data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: How Bollywood’s Views on Pakistan Evolved
text: If one looks at India’s national trajectory through the lens of the Hindi film industry, in hundred years of its existence, there will be one major gap: India’s troubled relationship with Pakistan was conveniently ignored by the industry for decades.

headline: The Electoral Art of War
text: Attack your opponent’s strength: that has become the fundamental rule of modern politics.

headline: East Asia’s Sea Disputes: Scar Tissue from War Wounds
text: HONG KONG — It’s not easy keeping track of all the territorial disputes over rocky outcrops, barren mini-islands and submerged chunks of coral in East Asian waters. Each piece of land seems to have competing and passionate claims by any number of countries in the region, and each island group is called different names by the opposing claimants.

headline: News Quiz | August 16, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Does Marriage Still Define the Life of Indian Women?
text: “What does young India want? At the launch of his sixth book, on just this subject, the popular author Chetan Bhagat offered an inadvertently revealing comment: ‘Naukri aur chokri’ — jobs and girls,”  Nilanjana S. Roy wrote in The International Herald Tribune.

headline: Militants Attack Pakistani Air Force Base
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — An attack early Thursday on a major Pakistani air force base where some of the country’s nuclear weapons are thought to be stored set off a heavy gun battle in which eight attackers and one security official were killed.

headline: Indian Art Exhibition Makes a Rare Stop in China
text: “It is said that two thousand years ago, two priests brought the first Buddhist scriptures from India to China on the back of a pure white horse,” Clare Pennington wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 16, 2012
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the Q.&A. article “Returning to Her Trail of Tears.”

headline: Floundering Foes Help Indian Lawmakers
text: “There are times when the quality of the people who hate you is the most generous compliment you can receive,” Manu Joseph wrote in The International Herald Tribune. “The Indian National Congress, which heads the government in Delhi, is a beneficiary of its foes.”

headline: What’s In The Ryan Plan?
text: A number of commenters have asked for a summary of what’s actually in the Ryan plan. So this is a utility post.

headline: Artists Caught on a Camera’s Canvas
text: Sometimes art imitates life, sometimes life imitates art. But something special happens when art imitates art imitating life. In the 1920s, with some spillover before and after, The New York Times made a convention of photographing artists with both their works of art and the people (or pets) depicted in those works.

headline: Mitt Romney and Extreme Fiscal Policy
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: From Sportsman to Politician
text: Does the former cricket superstar have what it takes to lead an angry and disillusioned nation?

headline: Imran Khan Must Be Doing Something Right
text: On a cool evening in March, Imran Khan, followed by his dogs, walked around the extensive lawns of his estate, sniffling with an incipient cold. “My ex-wife, Jemima, designed the house — it is really paradise for me,” Khan said of the villa, which sprawls on a ridge overlooking Himalayan foothills and Pakistan’s capital, Islamabad. “My greatest regret is that she is not here to enjoy it,” he added, unexpectedly poignantly. We walked through the living room and then sat in his dimly lighted bedroom, the voices of servants echoing in the empty house, the mournful azans drifting up from multiple mosques in the city below.

headline: In Syria, the Demands of Life Conflict With Those of War
text: WHEN did the Syrian conflict begin?

headline: Rumors Lead People from Northeast to Flee Bangalore
text: Wild rumors of pending attacks led several thousand people to flee Bangalore on Wednesday night because of fears that violence in India’s northeastern region would somehow spread south.

headline: At Last, the Maybach Is Priceless
text: The word “Discontinued” appeared next to the five bottommost items on a price sheet issued recently by Mercedes-Benz USA for its 2013 vehicles. It was a jarring coda to the jumble of dollar signs, commas and digits — many of them stretching to six figures — that preceded it.

headline: Oakland Raiders, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: In professional sports, we’re always hearing about how “it’s a new era (!) in such-and-such-a-city.” Almost always, this is just a euphemistic way of saying that a team has been bad in recent years and is now hoping that a few personnel changes can fix things. But in the case of the 2012 Oakland Raiders, it really is a new era.

headline: The Early Word: Overwhelmed
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Ex-Aide to Cameron Appears in Court on Hacking Charges
text: LONDON — Andy Coulson, the former communications director for Prime Minister David Cameron and a onetime top editor in Rupert Murdoch’s British media outpost, appeared in court with six other people on Thursday to face charges in the long-running hacking scandal.

headline: Slump And Circumstance
text: The New Statesman had a good idea — it went to 20 British economists who signed a letter back in early 2010 calling for immediate austerity and asked them whether they still supported the Osborne policies now that Britain is in double-dip recession. Only one of those who replied said yes, while nine urged Osborne to reconsider his opposition to stimulus.

headline: When Looking for a Loan, You Can’t Fight Gravity
text: Getting a loan for your business is not a simple proposition. There are many types of loans, and many criteria that go into evaluating how much you can borrow and what you can expect to pay. There are thousands of lenders to pick from, and each one may have a slightly different proposition to suggest.

headline: How to Burn Dinner
text: Here is a simple, intense late-summer dinner you could cook on a pancake griddle set on the grate above a fire pit in someone’s backyard, as if performing a magic trick. The result is a plate of thick, luscious pork with a deep, burnished crust, redolent of garlic and rosemary, and a sunset of soft, smoky peaches nutty with brown butter. Those with powerful venting systems in their kitchens might try to cook the dish indoors, but the threat of the smoke alarm will loom. There is little poetry to that. For this recipe, endeavor to cook outside, under the sky.

headline: For Gamers, a Headset That Helps Pinpoint Opponents
text: Astro Gaming has long designed premium headsets for video game aficionados, and its latest, the A50 wireless headset, updates it for fans.

headline: Registering for Justice
text: Jason Goldberg and Christian Schoenherr are having their wedding Saturday evening at the acclaimed Manhattan restaurant Craft, where roughly 100 guests will dine on lobster, squab and hen-of-the-woods mushrooms, and the couple is registered at Sur La Table, for French cookware, German steak knives and such.

headline: Ecuador Grants Asylum to Assange, Defying Britain
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Ecuador forcefully rejected pressure from Britain and announced Thursday that it was granting political asylum to Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, who has been holed up for two months in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London trying to avoid extradition to Sweden.

headline: Q&A: Posting Flickr Picture Links to Twitter
text: Q.

headline: Did Yelp and TripAdvisor Push Google to Compete?
text: Google’s acquisition of Frommer’s travel guides this week offered a small glimpse into what it’s like for Web companies to live in Google’s world.

headline: Should Candidates Discuss Global Warming?
text: Ever since comprehensive legislation to reduce greenhouse gases died in Congress two years ago, my colleague John Broder noted here recently, climate change has been the issue that national politicians seem to avoid at all costs. Supporting renewable energy? Fine. Advocating energy independence? Great. Calling for action on global warming? Not so much.

headline: Nakedness in Dance, Taken to Extremes
text: HOW do you react to the look of a naked body onstage? Thirty-four years ago, as part of a friend’s bachelor party, I went to a London strip club with a group of seven other men. We were all in our early 20s; most of them were distinctly upper-crust; some qualified as what the English call chinless wonders and Hooray Henrys.

headline: Romney’s Message Moves Beyond Jobs
text: For most of the last year, Mitt Romney has stuck to one basic message: President Obama has botched the economy.

headline: Opinion Report: Freebies
text: From the editorial page

headline: Thursday Reading: Seizing the Last Days of Summer
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Seoul Judge Surprises Tycoon With Prison Term
text: SEOUL — A Seoul court on Thursday sentenced the head of the South Korean conglomerate Hanwha to four years in prison for embezzlement and made a rare decision to have the businessman dispatched directly to prison from the courtroom.

headline: Europeans Skeptical of Israeli War Talk
text: LONDON — The war talk in Israel, where authorities have been handing out gas masks in anticipation of a possible imminent conflict with Iran, has been met with a degree of skepticism in Europe.

headline: A Clerk With a Heart
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Four Rays Form Perfect Game Club
text: The saying goes that you should do one thing and do it better than anyone else. Unfortunately for the Tampa Bay Rays, what the team does best is suffer through perfect games.

headline: Daily Report: Cisco, a Tech Bellwether, Beats Forecasts
text: Cisco Systems, the world’s largest maker of computer networking equipment, delivered quarterly results on Wednesday that slightly surpassed Wall Street’s expectations, and investors are responding positively on Thursday.

headline: Does Your College Treat You Like a Child?
text: After a recent post on Jodhpur’s emergence as an education hub, India Ink received comments describing unreasonable restrictions on college campuses. We scoured the Internet and found many rules in college dormitories, known as hostels in India, that imposed curfews and bans on certain activities even though most of the students are adults. Moreover, the rules for women were often more restrictive. Here’s a selection:

headline: Great Dane
text: On a muggy May afternoon, the Danish actor Mads Mikkelsen stopped in Midtown Manhattan to meet me for a beer and a cheeseburger — a brief pause in the middle of a hectic bout of international zigzagging. He had just been in Bucharest and was en route to Cannes, where he would receive the best-actor award for his performance in Thomas Vinterberg’s “The Hunt,” in which he plays a kindergarten teacher menaced by small-town paranoia after he is accused of sexual abuse.

headline: Best Buy Founder Nudges Company’s Board to Consider Takeover
text: The founder of Best Buy, Richard M. Schulze, pressed his case on Thursday for a takeover of the electronics retailer, again trying to prod the company into considering his offer.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (1), Mexico (0)
text: Twenty years from now – 50 years from now – nobody will remember that the United States national team’s first victory over Mexico in Mexico was not a particularly well-played match.

headline: Andrew Upton to Become Sole Artistic Director of Sydney Theater Company
text: When Andrew Upton and Cate Blanchett, the husband-and-wife team that has served as the co-artistic directors of the Sydney Theater Company since 2008, complete their current and final term there, a familiar successor will be waiting in the wings: Mr. Upton will become the artistic director of that theater company, its chairman, David Gonski, said in a statement on Wednesday.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Asylum for Assange, and Jay-Z’s Stamp on the Nets
text: The WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange on Thursday was granted political asylum by Ecuador, whose embassy in London is currently shielding him. Outside the embassy, the scene has become more chaotic with scuffles between the police and supporters of Mr. Assange. Hanging over the Ecuadorean decision is the possibility that the British government could revoke the diplomatic immunity of the embassy and seize Mr. Assange to extradite him to Sweden, William Neuman and Maggy Ayala report, where he is wanted for questioning over allegations that he sexually assaulted two women. Ecuador’s foreign minister, Ricardo Patiño, didn’t take kindly to the suggestion that the British might move in: “We are not a British colony.” In his statement on Thursday, The Guardian reported, he said: “We trust the U.K. will offer the necessary guarantees so that both governments can act adequately and properly respect international rights and the right of asylum.”

headline: When Will We Address the Needs in High-Needs Schools?
text: In an opinion article, a college student who attended New York City schools draws attention to the city's many high-needs schools and their records of failure. "If we fail to attack mainstream economic issues now, then any attempts to improve existing school systems will collapse under a much greater problem: poverty. Empty wallets, empty stomachs and empty minds will persist."

headline: A Flawed Star and a Perfect Game
text: Baseball’s news came in such quick succession, and carrying such different messages, that it was as if Commissioner Bud Selig had picked up the red phone and dialed the baseball gods. The San Francisco Giants’ Melky Cabrera had just been suspended for 50 games for performance-enhancing drug use, dredging up all of baseball’s worst steroid era memories, and Selig needed something quick. How about a perfect game by Seattle’s Felix Hernandez, the gods offered back? Would that do?

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Fast Company: The Silicon Valley venture capital crowd seems to be getting all excited about lab-grown meat. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Asian Identity and the Global Economy
text: Last month I finished writing “Plutocrats,” a book on the rise of the global super-elite and the forces that created it, so I am somewhat obsessed with globalization, bankers and the like. That’s why those themes in a new indie movie, “Supercapitalist,” resonated most strongly for me.

headline: Velvet Revolution | Liya Kebede

text: A hotel guest was shot and killed inside his room at the Harlem Bed and Breakfast early Thursday, the police said.

headline: China Urges Japan to Release Protesters Caught on Disputed Island
text: TOKYO — China pressed Japan on Thursday to release 14 Chinese citizens arrested after some of them arrived on an island claimed by both countries, amid signs that Tokyo may soon deport them without pressing charges to avert a larger standoff.

headline: The Night the E.R. Staff Can Never Forget
text: AURORA, Colo. — More than three weeks have passed, but Daryl Johnson still begins his emergency room shift at the University of Colorado Hospital here with a sense of foreboding.

headline: Paul Ryan and the Art of the Possible
text: In my Campaign Stops column this week, I make the point that you have to look at Paul Ryan’s record over the last few years in the context of where his party stood after the 2008 election — moribund, deluded, and potentially self-destructive — and recognize 1) how much he’s done to move the Republicans in a more constructive direction and 2) that many of the problems with his famous/infamous House budgets reflect his party’s continuing deficiencies rather than his own. The absence of a replacement for Obamacare in the budget, for instance, doesn’t mean that Ryan hasn’t come out for such a replacement. (He has.) Likewise with the absence of Social Security reform and the implausible cuts to discretionary spending that this absence entails: Ryan’s original Roadmap deals with Social Security in a more serious and plausible way; he just hasn’t been able to get all of his House colleagues onside.

headline: Sales at Wal-Mart, Though Still Rising, Suggest Wary Shoppers
text: Consumers in the United States still seem to be holding their breath.

headline: Business Day Live | August 16, 2012
text: MF Global investigation could end without criminal charges. | Paul Ryan’s budget and the economy. | Jay-Z rewrites investor playbook with Nets arena in Brooklyn.

headline: Michael J. Fox May Return to TV
text: 11:13 a.m. | Updated Michael J. Fox, who starred on the sitcom “Spin City” in the 1990s but stepped aside in 2000 as the symptoms of his Parkinson’s disease worsened, may return to network television next year.

headline: Facebook Shares Hit New Low as a Lockup Period Ends
text: The Facebook slide on Wall Street continued on Friday, as the company’s shares reached new lows a day after early investors became eligible to sell their shares on the market. Shares closed down more than 4 percent, to $19.05, after reaching a low of $19.00 during the day — 50 percent lower than its original offering price of $38 in May.

headline: Another Change at News Corp. as TV Executive Steps Down
text: In the latest change at News Corporation before the company splits off its publishing businesses from its entertainment assets, David Haslingden, a long-time television executive who ran the Fox Networks Group is stepping down.

headline: On View | Architectones & Richard Neutra
text: The Paris-based artist Xavier Veilhan has created a site-specific installation that sparks a dialogue between the architecture and the history of Richard Neutra’s house.

headline: An Ode to Youth, Forever Fleeting
text: IN late May, a week after she graduated from Yale University, 22-year-old Marina Keegan headed to her family’s summer cottage on Cape Cod to begin revisions of “Independents,” a musical whose book she had written the summer before. The plan was for her to be joined there by the show’s director, lyricist and composer, but she never made it; the car in which she was riding crashed, killing her.

headline: What Does Your Fridge Door Say About Your Family?
text: Want to spend some time thinking about who your family is, and how the way you live reflects the way you really want to live, as opposed to the life that you’ve settled into, somehow, without much thought?

headline: On Our Radar: Appalachian Coal for India
text: The Booth Energy Group and the River Trading Company announce a $7 billion deal that could send nine million tons of coal a year to India from West Virginia and Kentucky. Such exports are rising as American demand for coal falls, as electric utilities burn more cheap natural gas. [The Associated Press]

headline: Finding George Orwell in Venezuela
text: MONTREAL — In 2005, Venezuela became an official Territory Free of Illiteracy. A massively funded government literacy drive achieved, in just over a year, what decades of neoliberal neglect had failed to deliver: a country where every single person knows how to read.

headline: Image of the Day: August 16
text: Kaliyattam, a traditional dance form, being performed in Chennai, Tamil Nadu.

headline: 11 Are Killed as U.S. Copter Goes Down in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Seven American soldiers and three Afghan soldiers and an interpreter were killed after daybreak on Thursday when their Black Hawk helicopter crashed in Kandahar Province in southern Afghanistan, the American-led military command here said.

headline: The Disunion of Myanmar
text: MAUNGDAW, Myanmar — At the sight of several Rohingyas collecting firewood and bringing cattle to pasture, the driver who was taking me to Maungdaw, a small town near Myanmar’s border with Bangladesh, screamed out that they should all be kicked out of the country or the recent bout of sectarian violence opposing them to the Rakhines would never end.

headline: How Much Can Patients Learn in a 15-Minute Doctor Visit?
text: Built more like a former professional basketball player than an elementary schoolteacher nearing retirement, the patient dropped a bagful of prescription medications on the table in the examining room and fell back into a chair. He couldn’t remember what most of them were for.

headline: Business Day Live: Jay-Z Rewrites Celebrity Investors’ Playbook
text: MF Global investigation could end without criminal charges. | Paul Ryan’s budget and the economy. | Jay-Z rewrites investor playbook with Nets arena in Brooklyn.

headline: At Monterey, Auctioning Duesenbergs and Packards for a Greater Good
text: A dozen classic cars will do more than find new owners this weekend at the Gooding & Company auction on the Monterey Peninsula. Their sale will help provide free medical care to children.

headline: Two Deputies Are Shot and Killed in a Louisiana Ambush
text: LAPLACE, La. — Two sheriff’s deputies were shot and killed early Thursday morning and two others were wounded in ambushes at a parking lot and a trailer park in this town about 25 miles up the Mississippi River from New Orleans.

headline: Marketer of Student Debit Cards Settles Charges of Improper Fees
text: Higher One, a big marketer of student debit cards, agreed to repay $11 million to 60,000 students to settle allegations that it had charged excessive fees to students who overdrew their accounts, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said.

headline: Justice Dept. Approves, With Changes, Verizon Wireless Spectrum Purchase
text: The United States Justice Department approved a deal struck by Verizon Wireless to purchase spectrum from the country’s largest cable operators, but officials also required that the agreement be altered to protect against higher prices for consumers.

headline: The Get | Smythson’s Currency Case
text: Back in the 1950s, Katherine Hepburn wouldn’t board a plane without her Smythson address book. In its pages, Hepburn logged meetings with friends like Laurence Olivier, Frank Sinatra and Vivien Leigh. On its cover, she’d stamped her initials K.H. and three places she frequented — London, California and New York — initiating a new way to personalize paper goods. (For memorabilia buffs, Hepburn’s book is currently on display in Smythson’s in-store museum at 4 West 57th Street.) Now, in honor of Hepburn’s brilliant idea, the London stationer is offering four-zipper currency cases embossed with Fashion Week’s four biggest cities — New York, London, Milan and Paris — and available with the option of monogramming, too. An update on the company’s original 1966 currency case, these new ones come in violet, olive and classic brown crocodile.

headline: The Cinematic Chase
text: With the release of the bike messenger chase film “Premium Rush,” a look back at movie chase scenes.

headline: Instagram Refreshes App by Including Photo Maps
text: Instagram may be waiting for its billion-dollar sale to Facebook to be finalized, but the company is not resting on its laurels. The company, working out of offices in San Francisco, continues to crank out updates to its popular photo-sharing application.

headline: In Fuel Cells, Some Hope for Urban Sanitation
text: As more and more people around the world flock to cities, urban areas in developing nations are struggling to keep up with the human influx and the waste that people produce. In 2010 roughly 2.5 billion people lacked basic sanitation, according to the World Health Organization.

headline: Who Owns That House?
text: There’s money to be made in Precita Park, but there are also neighbors to be lost.

headline: Feverishly Pursuing a Nondigital Chase
text: IT took a lot of nerve for the director David Koepp to include a chase under an elevated New York City train in “Premium Rush,” about a bike messenger’s frantic race to deliver a package from one end of Manhattan to the other.

headline: Update: Whither Eleanor’s Album?
text: A few weeks ago, we published a piece about a modest yet fascinating photo album that had found its way to the displays of the University of New Mexico Art Museum. “Random Shots Compiled for the Edification of Eleanor T. Wragg” read its first page — it was a Christmas gift from 1915, made up of 25 photos. Its pictures varied from quiet silhouettes and commonplace scenes to divers, airplanes and Gov. Jim Ferguson at the Cotton Palace Parade in Waco, Tex.

headline: 5 Critics Who Deserve a Statue
text: In Sunday’s Riff, Dwight Garner, a literary critic for The New York Times, makes the case for critics who are actually critical. “Critics take a beating, especially in popular culture,” Garner writes. “Jean Sibelius’s observation — ‘No statue has ever been erected to a critic’ — seems to be cited somewhere weekly. As well-known quotations go, this one strikes me as especially banal. It implies something disheartening about our culture. . . . That Brooklyn lacks an Alfred Kazin statue is almost enough to make a bookish type want to move to Oxford, England — or at least to Oxford, Miss.”

headline: Those Julia Child Treasures
text: We asked for your favorite Julia Child recipes — the recipes that, unlike her storied boeuf bourguignon, are part of everyday kitchen life — and lo and behold, you more than delivered. The following is a list, selected from over 200 comments, that highlight your most treasured Child standbys. They also demonstrate that the lessons she taught us about food and cooking continue to resonate. (See all the suggested recipes, and add to the list, here.)

headline: Ira Glass: By the Book
text: The host of “This American Life” and co-writer of the coming film “Sleepwalk With Me” would like to meet Edgar Allan Poe. “I don’t have a question, but dude just seems like he could use a hug.”

headline: What’s Your Favorite Movie Chase Scene?
text: For the coming film “Premium Rush,” about a bike messenger racing against time, a corrupt cop and a teeming city, David Koepp decided to include a chase under an elevated New York subway line even though he knew it would invite comparison with one of the greatest chase scenes of all time, the one in “The French Connection” with Gene Hackman in a car going after a bad guy in a train on the tracks overhead. As Mr. Koepp explained in this article about the difficulties of getting a pursuit right: “Shooting a chase scene in New York City, you’re standing on the shoulders of that giant. I almost didn’t do it, but I love the trestles.”

headline: A Song Tries to Go Beyond the ‘OMG’ Reaction to GMOs
text: [2:26 p.m. | Update | I’ll be adding various interesting “reviews” at the bottom of the post, starting with Stewart Brand, the author of “Whole Earth Discipline.”]

headline: Director Plans Pinter With a Twist, as Actresses Trade Off ‘Old Times’ Roles
text: Most actors have enough layers to explore with just one character in “Old Times,” an enigmatic 1971 play about identity and fractured memories by Harold Pinter, the Nobel Prize winner best known for psychological chillers like the “The Homecoming” and “The Caretaker.” But the theater director Ian Rickson has thrown down a challenge to leading ladies Kristin Scott Thomas and Lia Williams for an coming London revival of “Old Times” – they will alternate in the female roles of Kate and Anna, old friends who have not seen each other in 20 years.

headline: Lincoln’s Panama Plan
text: On Aug. 14 1862, Abraham Lincoln hosted a “Deputation of Free Negroes” at the White House, led by the Rev. Joseph Mitchell, commissioner of emigration for the Interior Department. It was the first time African Americans had been invited to the White House on a policy matter. The five men were there to discuss a scheme that even a contemporary described as a “simply absurd” piece of “charlatanism”: resettling emancipated slaves on a 10,000-acre parcel of land in present-day Panama.

headline: Wave of Attacks Kills Dozens in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — A wave of attacks across Iraq killed more than 100 people on Thursday, including dozens of women and children at an amusement park, security and medical officials said.

headline: At Camden Yards, Home Team Is Again a Draw for Fans
text: BALTIMORE — The Hampton Inn on Washington Boulevard here is just a pop fly from Camden Yards. There is even a couch shaped like a baseball glove at the entrance.

headline: Another Pop Group Tells Romney to Stop Using Its Song
text: Silversun Pickups have demanded that the Romney campaign stop using the band’s song “Panic Switch” at political rallies. It is the latest pop group to object to the use of a song at Republican events.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Compliance'
text: Craig Zobel, the writer and director of "Compliance," narrates a scene from his film.

headline: Romney Says ‘I’ve Paid at Least 13%’ in Taxes in Past Decade
text: 10:22 p.m. | Updated  The revised version of this post is available here.

headline: Few Voters Are Truly Up for Grabs, Research Suggests
text: WASHINGTON — Curtis Napier, a 52-year-old father of two in Lima, Ohio, belongs to a much-discussed group of Americans that is far smaller than is often realized: He is a true swing voter.

headline: Hot Dodgers Move Into First Place
text: There is a team rolling in Southern California right now, and it’s not the Angels or Padres. The Dodgers are playing winning ball, and have moved into sole possession of first place, for the first time since July 13, in the National League West.

headline: An App to Transport Ride-Sharing to the Road
text: Users of Ridejoy, the online ride-sharing service, can now take it on the road. The company released an iPhone app today to complement its Web site, which, like a motor version of CouchSurfing, matches travelers who need rides with drivers who have space in their cars.

headline: Videos of Top Teachers Explaining Their Craft
text: Teachers are human, after all, and they don’t like to be bored any more than the rest of us.

headline: Square Offers Flat-Rate Plan for Small Businesses
text: Not long after Square made waves by announcing a partnership with Starbucks, the company is offering a deal to companies at the smaller end of the spectrum.

headline: The Slightly Surprising Sex Lives of Teenagers
text: New numbers show fewer teenagers than you might expect report having oral sex before vaginal sex. The myth of teenagers experimenting with oral sex, and not really considering it “sex,” has been around for a while, but this new data, from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Survey of Family Growth and reported in The Times’s Health section, shows that teenagers themselves tell researchers something different.

headline: As Diplomatic Efforts Stall in Syria, U.N. Says It Will End Its Observer Mission
text: The United Nations Security Council decided on Thursday to terminate the United Nations observer mission in Syria, where the increasingly violent rebellion against President Bashar al-Assad’s government has left diplomatic peacemaking efforts paralyzed. But the Security Council agreed to keep a much smaller United Nations office in the country, holding out hope that a political solution was still possible.

headline: Tsunami Debris Strains Budgets and Patience
text: The steady increase in marine debris arriving on Pacific shorelines as a result of the March 2011 tsunami in Japan is starting to tax state budgets as well as deepen concerns over invasive species.

headline: Mary McCann Nabs Plum Role in ‘Harper Regan’
text: The coming Off Broadway premiere of “Harper Regan,” a critically acclaimed British play about family alienation and the limits of loyalty, will star Mary McCann as the title character, one of the richest female roles on tap in New York theater this fall.

headline: Seeking Real Diversity in New Schools
text: The CEO of the Success Academy Charter Schools explains why she is opening schools in more affluent and whiter neighborhoods in the city than where she started her charter school network. The answer is not for the fun of controversy and heated public hearings.

headline: Return of the Swift Boat
text: In March, Karl Rove wrote an Op-Ed for the Wall Street Journal in which he belittled the president’s decision to order the raid on Osama bin Laden. “Mr. Obama did what virtually any commander in chief would have done in the same situation,” Mr. Rove argued. “For this to be portrayed as the epic achievement of the first term tells you how bare the White House cupboards are.”

headline: HBO Orders Comedy Series ‘Family Tree’ From Christopher Guest
text: Has Christopher Guest finally found that rarest of packages to satisfy the implacable Mort Guffman? As Corky St. Clair might put it, a “beautifully wrapped, glossy, sweet-smelling show?” At the very least, Mr. Guest, a writer, director and star of comedies like “This Is Spinal Tap,” “Waiting for Guffman” and “A Mighty Wind,” has hit upon a project that will bring him back to series television.

headline: Garden of Notes by Author of ‘Animal Farm’
text: My favorite biographical detail about George Orwell might be that, when he died from tuberculosis in 1950 at the age of 46, his favorite fishing poles were standing in the corner of his London hospital room. He hoped he’d be using them again, and soon.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Givenchy
text: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon in honor of the store’s 111th anniversary. Today’s pick: an equestrian-inspired, leg-lengthening boot from Givenchy. $1,695.

headline: Ideas for English Language Learners | Recipes, Travel, Idioms and More
text: This summer we’ve started a new monthly feature on The Learning Network called “Ideas for E.L.L.’s.”

headline: Postcards in an Artist’s Journey
text: BRUNSWICK, Me. — Maine has loomed large in the work of numerous American painters, from Marsden Hartley, John Marin and Edward Hopper to Andrew Wyeth, Alex Katz and Lois Dodd. But William Wegman is probably the only Conceptual artist — if an erstwhile one — to have fallen hard for the state, as evidenced by “William Wegman: Hello Nature,” a beguiling exhibition at the Bowdoin College Museum of Art here.

headline: Keeping Score: A Solution to the Strasburg Puzzle
text: WASHINGTON — Stephen Strasburg is on his way to becoming the subject of the most debated absence in baseball since Sandy Koufax missed Game 1 of the 1965 World Series because of Yom Kippur.

text: A look at the day in sports, including Kobe Bryant drawing crowds in China and the ceremonial opening of the Little League World Series in Pennsylvania.

headline: The Soccer Chronicles: The Gold Standard
text: Heather O’Reilly, a midfielder on the United States women’s soccer team and a two-time gold medalist, will be writing regularly for the 2012 London Olympics blog. This is her sixth post.
