I began sorting through various cartons of peaches, making just enough noise to wake Pervez Khan, a fellow Pakistani who has been based in south London for more than a decade. As I tossed the fruit into a basket, Khan awoke and began apologizing. “It’s terrible of me to sleep on the job,” he said, “but it’s so hard to stay awake when you’re fasting.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Guilty Verdicts in Pussy Riot Case, and China’s Media Strategy
text: 10:59 a.m. | Updated Three members of the Russian feminist punk band Pussy Riot were found guilty on Friday over a stunt they staged in February against Vladimir V. Putin in the main Moscow Russian Orthodox cathedral, David Herszenhorn reports. The scene in hot, overcrowded courtroom with the three women behind bulletproof glass was being streamed live by Russia Today, fueling worldwide interest in the prosecution of the band members, who have received support from musicians around the world including Paul McCartney and Madonna. The judge sentenced each to a two-year prison sentence. The YouTube video of the incident is at nearly 450,000 views.

headline: Bike Share Delayed Until Spring, Mayor Says
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Friday that the city’s much-heralded bike-share program would not begin until next year, ending weeks of speculation about the program’s fate and dashing cyclists’ hopes of seeing the city’s newest public travel alternative this year.

headline: Obama Aide Says 5 Years of Romney Taxes Would Suffice
text: WASHINGTON — A day after Mitt Romney said that he paid at least 13 percent of his income in taxes each year, President Obama’s campaign manager on Friday said five years’ worth of Mr. Romney’s tax returns would satisfy Democrats.

headline: Two Americans Killed by Afghan Recruit
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two American Special Forces members were shot to death on Friday by a new Afghan local police recruit they were training at a small outpost in western Afghanistan.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Times: A struggling farm market in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, loses its green thumb: “Farmer Roy,” a New Jersey grower who made it his mission to bring fresh produce to the low-income neighborhood. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Times Co. Discloses Pay Package for Incoming C.E.O.
text: The New York Times Company is paying its new chief executive, Mark Thompson, an annual salary of $1 million and an immediate signing bonus valued at $3 million.

headline: In the Calm of Summer, Stocks Climb Gingerly
text: Stocks approached their highest levels of the year on Friday in the wake of some mildly encouraging economic data, closing out their sixth-straight positive week.

headline: For Its Shares to Rebound, Facebook Needs to Project More Magic
text: Want to better understand the crazy world of technology stocks? That requires having a grasp of something that can best be described as the curse of the ordinary.

headline: Facebook Shares Hit New Low as a Lockup Ends
text: 11:45 p.m. | Updated

headline: Making a Child Stop Her Distracting Dance
text: My husband and I attended an outdoor jazz concert at Lincoln Center. When the music began, a little girl (about 7) began doing an interpretive dance in the aisle, and didn’t stop. We could not look at the stage without seeing her. After a while, my husband politely asked the parents to restrain the girl. The mother carried her away, kicking and screaming. She wagged her finger at us, saying: “See what you’ve done.” Another man told us we had broken the girl’s heart and owed her an apology. Were we out of line?

headline: From the Finger Lakes, a Concentration of Good Wine Value
text: In my column this week, partly in response to a reader’s challenge, I suggest a dozen great values in American wines, all $20 and under. Some of you may be surprised at the selection, which includes four bottles from New York State.

headline: Helping a Child Adjust to Divorce
text: Last week, reader M. asked other readers, divorced parents and children of divorce, to weigh in on the monthly dinners she and her ex-husband have been having with their 4-year-old. M. and her spouse divorced last fall, when their daughter was 3, and instituted the dinners a few months later.

headline: Pok Pok Wing to Get a New Name and Dish: Phat Thai
text: The elephant on the plate, as far as Andy Ricker, the owner of the Pok Pok restaurants, is concerned, has always been the noodle dish called phat Thai, or pad Thai. It is about the most popular Thai dish among Americans, but Mr. Ricker has long made a point of not serving it. Until now.

headline: This Week’s Movies: August 17
text: In today’s episode, our critics offer their takes on three independent films: David Cronenberg’s “Cosmopolis,” Craig Zobel’s “Compliance” and the first live-action film from the French animators Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud, “Chicken With Plums.” Full reviews of all of this week’s films can be found here.

headline: A World of Trouble
text: Why do teenagers make such ideal protagonists? Maybe it’s because they’re doing just what novels do: struggling to make sense of a troubling and imperfect world. And at first, Jim, called Biscuit, and L. A. (Lee Ann), the teenage cousins at the heart of Tom Wright’s feisty first novel, are ­exactly what you hope they’ll be: funny, frank, mouthy and more than a touch off kilter. Both are forced to live with their grandmother because their mothers aren’t up to the task of child rearing. Their homes are haunted by alcoholism and violence, but Gram takes a simple, affectionate, responsibility for them — though it’s almost inevitable that certain questions, if not the answers, will push their ugly way to the surface sooner or later.

headline: Working 9 to 12
text: Robert Skidelsky is a historian best known for his definitive three-volume biography of John Maynard Keynes; his son Edward Skidelsky is a philosopher. They have collaborated on a book arguing that people in wealthy countries like Britain and the United States work too hard and by doing so miss out on the “good life” — an ethical concept of a life as “worthy of desire, not just one that is widely desired.”

headline: Silence, Exile and Cunning
text: If you walk in Dublin along Nassau Street and continue straight into South Leinster Street and then look up at the gable end of the red-brick building on the left, you can see the old sign that says “Finn’s Hotel.” The hotel is long gone, but an event that took place nearby in June 1904 gave an emotional context, a strange nourishing power, to James Joyce’s novel “Ulysses,” and the name of the hotel became one of the words he played with in the title of his novel “Finnegans Wake.”

headline: The Once and Future War
text: Revolutionary regimes, in the grip of a universalist faith, are often prepared to use violence to export their ideology. France did so after 1789, Russia after 1917 and Cuba after 1959. Only one revolutionary state currently poses a serious threat to world order: Iran. Like 18th-century France and 20th-century Russia, Iran has fused the expansionary impulse of an imperial power with an ideological attack on the status quo. But that only makes Iran harder to deal with, above all for the United States, the chief pillar of that status quo.

headline: The 8.5.12 Issue
text: WAY DOWN IN THE HOLE

headline: The Case Against Purple
text: In the late ’90s, you described the typical reader of Wallpaper, the first magazine you founded, as “a copywriter for a hot advertising firm in Stockholm or a grunge kid working in an indie record shop that suddenly got a film deal, there’s a degree of affluence all of a sudden.” Do those people even exist anymore?  Those people are still out there. They might have landed at different gigs. I’m constantly amazed by people who still get extraordinary tech deals for concepts and businesses which don’t have any hope of returning anything to their investors.

headline: I Was Jeff Koons’s Studio Serf
text: As a 21-year-old art student, I answered a help-wanted ad at the SoHo studio of Jeff Koons. During the interview, the studio manager set my slides on a light box and leaned over them with a loupe, inspecting each one like a jeweler with a tray of semiprecious stones. The head painter was consulted, a tall and taciturn man who eventually came over to shake my hand.

headline: Last Known Address
text: Shortly after renting a house, I found out from neighbors that the previous tenant died of an overdose. This didn’t create any major inconveniences, although early on we did find a few remnants (like police tape). But it did feel unsettling and slightly disturbing. Did our landlord have any ethical obligation to tell us what had happened before we signed the lease? WILLIAM, NEW YORK

headline: Who Made That Tube Top?
text: Elie Tahari arrived in New York in 1971 with less than $100 in his pocket. “I slept in the parks on the benches,” recalls the fashion designer. The son of Iranian refugees who emigrated to Israel and placed him for a time in an orphanage, Tahari hoped to make his fortune at 19 in the United States, “the land of the movies.”

headline: When the Network Effect Goes Into Reverse
text: With battered Facebook shares closing Friday at just over half their offering price in May, no one’s talking anymore about a social media “bubble.”

headline: Eats, Shoots and Leaves
text: On a recent summer afternoon, the photographer Todd Selby was standing in the kitchen of his minimalist apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, stirring shell pasta in a stock pot. He was making Olga’s Shell Soup, a bouillon-and-tomato-paste number concocted by his childhood nanny, a Mexican native who was named after a Swedish character in a telenovela. “This is my favorite soup in the world, but I’ve never met anyone who’s really that into it,” Selby said. “So I’m kind of curious what the reaction is going to be.”

headline: General Motors Recalls 9,400 Chevrolet and GMC Vans for Fire Hazard
text: General Motors recently informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that it would recall almost 9,400 of its 2003-4 Chevrolet Express and GMC Savana full-size vans because of a fire hazard.

headline: Family Says Mathieu Has Entered Rehab
text: The news that Louisiana State had dismissed one of its best players, defensive back Tyrann Mathieu, had the predictable ripple effect in schools lining up for permission to poach him for their teams. An L.S.U. spokesman said 20 schools had called, but that the school was only going to allow contact by schools Mathieu requested.

headline: Amazon Crowns ‘Hunger Games’ as Its Top Seller, Surpassing Harry Potter Series
text: Take that, Harry Potter.

headline: In Brooklyn, It’s All Nets
text: The Nets don’t officially step on the court in Brooklyn until the fall. But the team’s imprint is already evident, even ubiquitous, around the borough.

headline: Collateral Damage
text: London, 1940. Capt. Terence Stevenson of the Bomb Disposal Section arrives on the scene to defuse a delayed-­action bomb lodged in the rubble of a hospital. He reassures a boy lying only a few feet away, unable to be moved, that he’s just taking out the bomb’s tonsils “so he can’t talk.” Stevenson relays each step in his process through a microphone to his crew, positioned at a safe distance.

headline: Charles in Charge
text: Dare I call a 707-page biography a page turner? For once, the fake enthusiasm of blurb prose rings true. I did “finish the book in one sitting,” as another chestnut has it, though the sitting was a very long flight of 16 hours. And why? Because Jonathan Fenby, a former editor of The Observer of London and a prolific author, knows how to turn breadth and depth into enthrallment. ­Academic historians tend to shy away from the grand sweep, while journalists like to stick to the chatty and topical. Fenby has blended the best of both crafts — the historian’s gravitas, the journalist’s feel for drama — into a magnificent book that will rank alongside a classic like Jean Lacouture’s multi­volume biography of Charles de Gaulle.

headline: Business Day Live | August 17, 2012
text: August 17, 2012 - For the long-term jobless, a struggle to beat the odds. | James B. Stewart discusses Facebook and the backlash against social media stocks.

headline: California Dreams
text: David Hockney is often described as England’s most popular artist, but in his youth he dreamed of Los Angeles. He moved there in 1963, at age 26, unable to drive and believing he would get around the city by bus. This did not prevent him from traveling in his imagination to another California, one that bore little resemblance to the surfer-girl paradise enshrined by the Beach Boys. Instead of sand and the frothy ocean, Hockney painted quiet, slightly vacant-looking scenes of turquoise swimming pools in private backyards. They’re landscapes waiting for people to arrive, even when the people are already there.

headline: Disturbing the Peace
text: Thrillers not so thrilling lately? Serial killers too silly? Police detectives too sensitive? Wondering where all the tough guys went? I give you the Norwegian author Karin Fossum, whose new novel, THE CALLER (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $25), is one of the darkest, most disturbing crime stories you’re likely to read this year.

headline: The Other America
text: This book is a collaboration between Chris Hedges and Joe Sacco, showing us daily life in four centers of 21st-century American poverty. Hedges’ contribution — a combination of reportage and commentary — is in a long tradition of literary journalism. Sacco’s is the sort of graphic art popularized by Art Spiegelman in “Maus.” Both writers have decades of experience as correspondents in war zones, but in “Days of Destruction, Days of Revolt” they turn their attention to the bombed-out and collapsed areas of their own country.

headline: Under the Influence
text: Poetry changes nothing, W. H. Auden suggested. For once in his life he was wrong. Poetry changes ­everything, starting with the good behavior of anyone who reads a lot of it, as the poet-critic Maureen N. McLane discovers in her beguiling new book, “My ­Poets.” “I was good at school,” she writes. “The very things that made me good at school — a talent for aligning with authority, or for knowing what it wanted; a capacity for self-­estranging self-discipline; an ability to use anxiety as a fuel; an ­overidentification with established codes — were precisely the things that might render me not a writer, not a poet.”

headline: Back Forty to Serve Crabs on the Rockaway Boardwalk
text: Back Forty and Back Forty West, Peter Hoffman’s downtown restaurants, will be celebrating crabs with pop-ups in the Rockaways, in Queens, on Saturday, Aug. 18, and again on Aug. 25, on the boardwalk at 96th Street. The crabs will be hot and spicy starting around 2 p.m. and will be served as long as the supply lasts, perhaps until early evening. For $25 you will get a bucket of six steamed crabs, some potatoes and two ears of corn. There is a bar nearby. No reservations, or even shoes, for this!

headline: Image of the Day: August 17
text: A festival dedicated to Hindu snake goddess “Manasa” celebrated in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Here if You Need Me
text: There are two species of novelist: one writes as if the world is a known locale that requires dutiful reporting, the other as if the world has yet to be made. The former enjoys the complacency of the au courant and the lassitude of at-hand language, while the latter believes with Thoreau that “this world is but canvas to our imaginations,” that the only worthy assertion of imagination occurs by way of linguistic originality wed to intellect and emotional verity. You close “Don Quixote” and “Tristram Shandy,” “Middlemarch” and “Augie March,” and the cosmos takes on a coruscated import it rather lacked before, an “eternal and irrepressible freshness,” in Pound’s apt phrase. His definition of literature is among the best we have: “Language charged with meaning.” How charged was the last novel you read?

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: INTO THE DARKEST CORNER  By Elizabeth Haynes.  Harper/HarperCollins, $25.99.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THREE STRONG WOMEN,  by Marie NDiaye. Translated by John Fletcher. (Knopf, $25.95.) In loosely linked narratives, three women from Senegal struggle with fathers and husbands in France. This subtle, hypnotic novel won the Prix Goncourt in 2009.

headline: Paperback Row
text: BEGIN AGAIN: A Biography of John Cage,  by Kenneth Silverman. (Northwestern University, $24.95.) Cage (1912-92), the avant-garde composer whose most famous piece called for the performer not to make a sound, upended long-held conventions about experiencing art. Silverman presents a nuanced view of Cage, from his childhood in interwar Los Angeles and his creative awakening in Paris to his revolutionary work and his lifelong partnership with the choreographer Merce Cunningham.

headline: Inside the List
text: THERE’S SOMETHING ABOUT JULIA: Aug. 15 marked the centennial of Julia Child’s birth, and publishers are serving up biographies to satisfy every reading level and taste. There’s Julia Child for ailurophiles — “Julia’s Cats.” Julia Child for children — the picture book “Bon Appétit!” Julia Child for ailurophiles and children — “Minette’s Feast: The Delicious Story of Julia Child and Her Cat.” For everyone else, there’s “Dearie,” the biography by Bob Spitz, new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 6.

headline: To Be Continued
text: A lot of people curl their lips at the very idea of literary prequels and sequels, and it’s easy to see why. The road to damnation is paved with examples that suggest the form is practically unworkable. Some disappoint simply by having a distinctly second-best prose style — and so insult the author to whom they mean to show respect. Some by creating a pallid version of the original, strong characters. Some by unraveling the tension of the received plot. Some by the sheer silliness of their reinvention: “I, Sherlock Holmes.” “Little Women and Werewolves.” “Pride and Promiscuity.”

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Sets Standards for Data Collected From Black Boxes in Cars
text: Beginning next month, new cars equipped with so-called black boxes — instruments that record crash information — must meet certain criteria for categories of data captured, accuracy and crash survivability. But the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is still working on a rule that would require all new cars sold to contain the devices in the first place.

headline: New Hedge Funds Abound, Despite Tepid Industry Performance
text: It’s been a rough couple of years to be a hedge fund. Weak performance, enhanced regulation and an aggressive crackdown on insider trading have cast a harsh spotlight on the industry.

headline: In Church, Using the Bible as a Guide for Healthy Living
text: Inside Mt. Olivet Gospel Church in Corona, Queens, about a dozen older African-American women, some of them overweight, were perched in the pews reading intently. But they were not focused on the Bible. Instead, it was information on maintaining a healthy heart.

headline: College Players Criticize Changes in Rules
text: MASON, Ohio—Changes in the format of college tennis announced by the N.C.A.A. Wednesday have drawn a furious and seemingly one-sided response across social media, with players and coaches weighing in with their objections.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Martin Amis discusses his new novel, “Lionel Asbo”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Deborah Solomon talks about the artist David Hockney; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: The Value of the Network Effect
text: August 17, 2012 - After a dismal Facebook stock price drop, reporter Michael S. Schmidt and columnist James B. Stewart discuss the declining value of social media.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Baby Boomers
text: This week, A. O. Scott and David Carr discuss the continuing success of artists from the baby-boom generation and what sells when it comes to age.

headline: Fête Accompli | A Night at the Chateau
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Weekend Fare
text: The annual tradition of harvesting and eating crayfish is celebrated at Aquavit, 65 East 55th Street (between Madison and Park Avenues), in Midtown East. Peel-and-eat crayfish will be served through Friday and from Monday to Aug. 24, in half-pound servings, $32 at lunch and $42 at dinner, which includes a smorgasbord.

headline: Is Simple Demography Behind Weak Economy?
text: Economic growth in the United States has been disappointing for more than a decade now. Some of the reasons are complex and hotly debated, and will be the subject of a series of posts here starting next week. But one of the reasons is not mysterious at all. It simply reflects demographic changes.

headline: The Beasts and Beats of Belize
text: WE were hiking through the woods of the Cockscomb Basin Sanctuary and Jaguar Preserve in Belize, the more-than-150-square-mile verdant reserve that is a no-hunting haven for many species of this hemisphere’s wild cats — the puma, ocelot, jaguarundi, margay and jaguar. As we moved along well-tended trails, there were signs of activity — muddy paw prints by a riverbank, bits of jaguar scat — but we were unlikely to actually see any of these magnificent creatures.

headline: Where Mondrian Lingers on a Dutch Coast
text: “IF you stand beside the Bath Pavilion, and look to your right, you can still see this,” said Francisca van Vloten, her finger tracing the lines of the long, wooden wave breakers jutting into the North Sea in the print of Mondrian’s 1909 painting “Beach With Five Piers at Domburg.”

headline: Rachel Carson’s ‘Rugged Shore’ in Maine
text: WHEN Rachel Carson built a summer cottage on the Maine coast in 1953, she had not yet written “Silent Spring,” the work that arguably inspired the modern environmental movement. It was thanks to an earlier best seller, “The Sea Around Us,” that she was able to leave her government job and fulfill a longstanding dream.

headline: An Encore in Washington
text: Virginia Ali, the septuagenarian co-founder of Ben’s Chili Bowl, a late-night destination on the U Street strip in Washington, was in black-tie finery at the opening-night gala of the Howard Theater this spring.

headline: Restaurant Report: Pyongyang in Amsterdam
text: Pyongyang in Amsterdam bills itself as the “first North Korean restaurant in the Western world.” It is not. There are a scattering of restaurants around the world that are owned by North Korean expats or dissidents and serve regional dishes. These places, however, are relatively rare — and many don’t advertise their North Korean roots.

headline: Hotel Review: Ruschmeyer’s in Montauk, N.Y.
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Hiking Italy, Volcano to Volcano” (July 22), here’s another suggestion: Stay on Lipari, one of the Aeolian Islands, which offers a much greater variety of hotels and restaurants, and use it as a base for day trips to the islands of Stromboli and Vulcano. And if you decide to treat yourself to a dip in Vulcano’s thick sulfurous mud baths (it’s good for aching leg muscles), don’t wear your designer swimsuit. You’ll never get the smell out.MITCH CRASSONWhite Plains

headline: Calls Escalate for Presidential Debate Aimed at Minorities
text: The calls for an additional presidential debate moderated by (and aimed at) minorities escalated on Friday.

headline: A Separate Peace
text: Those interested in the history of abolition and racial equality would find few incidents in Lincoln’s presidency as dispiriting as the president’s Aug. 14, 1862, meeting with a delegation of five black men from Washington. It was dispiriting then as well: to the dismay of those hoping the Civil War would lead to full citizenship for African-Americans, Lincoln informed the delegation that “you and we are different races” and proposed that the five men be progenitors of a black colony the government would establish in Chiriquí, a region of what is now Panama.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Martin Amis Discusses ‘Lionel Asbo’
text: This week in the New York Times Book Review, Kathryn Harrison reviews “Lionel Asbo,” the latest novel by Martin Amis. The book’s title character is a London thug who wins the national lottery and becomes a tabloid darling. Ms. Harrison writes:

headline: Recovery in U.S., Though Lackluster, Trumps Europe’s
text: THE economic recovery from the 2007-9 recession has been a slow one in the United States, prompting much grumbling.

headline: There’s More Than One Way to Share a Bike
text: With the announcement on Friday that New York’s ambitious bike-sharing program, Citi Bike, will be delayed, New Yorkers will have to wait until spring 2013 to ride one of the bright blue bikes.

headline: When the Lender Buys Your Home Insurance, a Call Is in Order
text: FORCE-PLACED insurance isn’t high up on most people’s list of mortgage worries, not when so many people are in danger of losing their homes. But it’s been high up on mine ever since my wife and I had to battle our mortgage provider to remove flood insurance it had bought for us — and we didn’t need — for a condominium we owned in Florida.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Roger Vivier
text: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon. Today’s pick: Roger Vivier’s latest, a tri-colored pump.

headline: How America Can Slow Israel’s March to War
text: Washington

headline: Iran’s President Calls Israel ‘an Insult to Humankind’
text: Iran’s president fanned the flames of confrontation with Israel on Friday, calling the Israeli government “an insult to humankind” in a speech on the annual Iranian holiday that calls for the Palestinian reclamation of Jerusalem from Israel’s control.

headline: Rage Against the Machine Isn’t Returning Ryan’s Love
text: Representative Paul D. Ryan may love Rage Against the Machine, but the feeling isn’t mutual.

headline: The Week in Metro Pictures for Aug. 17
text: A look back at events from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: In Brazil, a Noisy, Tense Prosperity
text: BARKING dogs and a crying baby. Maids and housekeepers calling to each other through the air shaft of an apartment building. The echo of samba music on the radio and soccer matches on television. The faint murmur of the sea in the background, and in the foreground, the incessant clatter of construction: the pounding of hammers, the churning of cement mixers, the screeching of circular saws.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Roger Vivier
text: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon in honor of the store’s 111th anniversary. Today’s pick: Roger Vivier’s latest, a tri-colored pump with the brand’s signature buckle at the toe. $795.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Aug. 17
text: This week, A. O. Scott and David Carr discuss the success of artists from the baby-boom generation, like Meryl Streep and Bruce Springsteen, and what sells when it comes to age.

headline: Chumming Around With Great White Sharks
text: One of my Pace University communication students, Martin Totlandt, spent much of the summer in South Africa and filed this “Your Dot” dispatch about the controversy over the process of chumming — luring sharks with a fishy, bloody brew spooned overboard — something done both for science and for adventure tourism cage diving operations. The video above was shot by Totland of a shark encounter in June (the camera was on a pole). Here is his post:

headline: Green Card Lottery
text: I ENTERED the green card lottery in the fall of 2010. It was a surprisingly simple form, composed mostly of questions on contact information, but a box that read “Country Claimed” gave me pause. Most applicants write in wherever they were born, but for me it was a bit more complicated; I could not, in good faith, claim any country as my own.

headline: Conservative Elite in Capital Pay Heed to Ryan as Thinker
text: WASHINGTON — With the debate over the federal deficit roiling last year, David Smick, a financial market consultant, held a dinner for a bipartisan group of connected budget thinkers at his expansive home here.

headline: Baltimore Grand Prix Secures SRT as Presenting Sponsor
text: BALTIMORE — After sputtering dangerously, the Baltimore Grand Prix may be shifting out of first gear.

headline: As Jets Grab Spotlight, Giants Are Happy to Step Aside
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The prevailing hullabaloo at Giants training camp in Albany arose on Tuesday, relating to uncomfortable dorm room accommodations.

headline: A Lesson for Homeowners
text: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about force-placed insurance — insurance that a lender buys when it concludes that a homeowner does not have adequate hazard, flood or wind coverage. But the problem is that this insurance is almost always more expensive than the homeowner could buy in the open market. In addition, the coverage may be redundant or not needed at all. But homeowners have been reporting that they have a difficult time getting their lenders to remove the insurance.

headline: Casting in Colorado, Away From the Crowds
text: NORTHERN Colorado was still rubbing the previous night’s Independence Day parties from its eyes as I parked beside the rancher’s fence, pulled on waders and strung my fly rod. In the valley the drowsy river was a silver twist among green willows. The air smelled of wet sage, and black cattle stood like chess pieces in the distant fields. Beyond them the 12,000-foot peaks of the Mount Zirkel Wilderness had lined up for morning’s roll call, their summits lighted up like match tips.

headline: Share the Tale of Your Data Trail
text: This week I wrote about how improvements in technology and the capacity to store huge amounts of data cheaply now allow both the government and the private sector to collect and retain vast amounts of personal information. The laws and regulations that govern such collection, in the view of many experts, are outdated and inconsistent.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Talking About ‘The Underwater Welder’
text: “The Underwater Welder,” by Jeff Lemire, enters our graphic books paperback best-seller list at No. 6 this week. It’s about Jack Joseph, a man feeling pressure because of his deep sea welding gig and the fact that he’s going to become a father. The introduction to the book, by Damon Lindelof, one of the creators of “Lost,” compares it to “The Twilight Zone.” The book starts out innocently enough, seemingly a story about Jack, his pregnant wife, their life struggles and Jack’s relationship with his own father. Things get a bit eerie after Jack emerges from one of his dives to a changed world. Mr. Lemire’s characters, even when they’re happy, have a melancholy look to them. They create an almost instant rapport with the reader.

headline: For Chipper Jones, a Salute and Two Home Runs
text: It would be perfectly understandable if Chipper Jones slowed down a bit — he is 40 and in the final weeks of his major league career, which started in 1993 with the Braves.

headline: Living In | Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn
text: Gerritsen Beach, a neighborhood on Brooklyn’s southern shore, is prized by residents for its quiet and off-the-grid seclusion.

headline: The Art of Hiding in Plain Sight
text: GEORGE R. BROADHEAD, a retired newspaper executive and Marine Corps veteran, has lived in Beverly Hills and Manhattan Beach, Calif., and Greenwich, Conn., among many other places. The place he is choosing to spend his retirement, though, is the place where he grew up: Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn.

headline: Rerouted to Syria, Travelers Are Asked To Pass the Hat
text: PARIS — The anxieties of an unexpected landing in war-ravaged Syria were compounded for passengers on an Air France flight when they were asked by the crew if they couldn’t possibly, you know, come up with some cash to help out with the refueling.

headline: Real to the Touch
text: DENIS PIEL sat by a roadside in rural France, chatting on his cellphone. He was winding down from a hectic day that included a wearying drive and a flight punctuated by an infant’s squalls.

headline: Fees Dispute Prompts Blackout of WPIX by Cablevision
text: WPIX, the New York City affiliate of the CW network, is being blacked out in homes serviced by Cablevision, a major New York metropolitan area cable company.

headline: Planetary Poetry, Woven Into a Movie
text: WITH exotic imagery fit for the cover of National Geographic, the new film “Samsara” ranges across the globe: there are fantastical tiered temples in verdant Myanmar and glorious Japanese mohawks, the natural wonders of Namibian sand dunes and orderly production lines of modern agribusiness in China and Europe. The locations are unnamed, and a rich, varied score is heard instead of political or social commentary. One striking image flows into the next, loosely organized according to the cyclical Hindu notion of birth and destruction that gives the film its Sanskrit title.

headline: Business Day Live:  Long-Term Jobless Regroup to Fight the Odds
text: For the long-term jobless, a struggle to beat the odds. | James B. Stewart discusses Facebook and the backlash against social media stocks.

headline: Failure Is Important (and It Can Also Be Sort of Funny)
text: SEVERAL years ago, Mike Birbiglia was sitting in an office in Los Angeles when he heard what might be the most beautiful words that a president of a television network can say to a comedian: “You’re the next Seinfeld.”

headline: Before Adoption, 79 Lost Days
text: A new baby can bring much more than joy, responsibility and frustration. During one difficult bout with my son’s inconsolable tears, I took him for a walk. I strapped him to my chest in a nylon baby carrier, kissed Mommy good-bye and ventured into the cool evening. Together we walked. Well, I walked. He rode.

headline: Veteran Algerian Statesman to Succeed Annan as Special Syrian Envoy
text: Lakhdar Brahimi, a former Algerian foreign minister and widely respected statesman, was appointed Friday as the new special envoy to Syria from the United Nations and Arab League to replace Kofi Annan, who resigned in frustration two weeks ago over his inability to advance his plan to halt the Syrian conflict.

headline: Eye Intensity
text: ‘I don’t have a signature style,” says Mark Carrasquillo, the makeup artist who created the dramatic eyes on these pages. “But I like to think I can do many things, from full drag to ‘scrubbed clean,’ and somehow make it look like my hand.” He may be versatile, but one thing that carries through all his work is sex appeal. “I’ve been accused of making girls look oversexed,” he admits. The sultry makeup he did here has a tough-girl edge. “I wanted to play with the idea of youth, which for me means a bare face with one statement, like a drawn-on eyebrow or a matte black eye. No foundation, no blush — just lots of attitude.” While lipstick is optional (“I don’t believe in the rule that says you shouldn’t wear a strong eye with a strong lip — it’s a good-taste trap”), great skin is imperative. Carrasquillo’s trade secret? A special arnica oil-based luminizer he whips up in his East Village kitchen. “Every model I use it on asks me to make some for them,” he says. “I won’t reveal all the ingredients, but it’s healing and leaves skin with a beautiful, glowing finish.” Maquillage magic can only do so much, though, he adds. “A woman can have incredible skin, but if she’s not happy in it, all the makeup in the world won’t help. I’m so tired of seeing beautiful young girls with Botox, etc. I want to tell them to just simmer down and enjoy who they are.” More…

headline: Caterpillar Workers Ratify Deal They Dislike
text: Workers who had been striking at a Caterpillar hydraulic parts factory in Joliet, Ill., voted on Friday to ratify a proposed six-year contract that contained almost all of the concessions the company had demanded.

headline: A Champion of the Book Takes to the iPad
text: The author William H. Gass has written a 15,000-word essay called “Abstractions Arrive: Having Been There All the Time,” a collaboration with the noted photographer Michael Eastman, that can be read only on an iPad equipped with iBooks 2. It’s a surprising move by Mr. Gass, whose 1999 essay “A Defense of the Book” is cherished by devotees of the old-fashioned printed book who are distressed by the onrushing digital future. On our sister blog Bits, David Streitfeld recently spoke to Mr. Gass to learn more about the project.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $19.5 Million
text: In prime position on Fifth Avenue’s Museum Mile, a nine-room condominium that encompasses the entire ninth floor of 988 Fifth Avenue and offers stunning views of Central Park and the Metropolitan Museum of Art sold for $19.5 million, the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: On CCTV America, Some China Stories Recede From View
text: Although they come from opposite ends of the Chinese political spectrum, for two months this spring Bo Xilai, a Communist Party official who was dismissed from his post, and Chen Guangcheng, a blind, activist lawyer who fled house arrest in his village, shared one important trait: they were the most closely watched Chinese men in the world.

headline: In New Ads, Republicans Attack Over Medicare
text: Get ready for the debate over the 2010 health care law – its Medicare component especially – to be reignited on the airwaves.

headline: Relevant Links
text: A couple of links that didn’t make it into today’s column: How unequal, for example, is income in America? (A more difficult question is, Why do we say unequal but inequality?) You might check out the charts and figures here. There are a dozen charts right here that tell the story nicely. Be careful: it’s brain-wrenching material.

headline: A Glass All Empty
text: WHEN I picture my favorite moments with my husband over our 23 years together, someone is always holding a glass, or a bottle of wine, or a plastic cup — well, except for the last 11 years, since Rob stopped drinking.

headline: Report Faults Indian Government’s Handling of Coal Concessions
text: MUMBAI, India — The Indian government missed out on nearly $34 billion in royalties by selling private companies coal concessions at negotiated prices rather than auctioning them, according to an audit by a government agency released on Friday.

headline: Tomatoes Help With Summer Survival
text: ISN’T it lucky that just when it’s too hot to cook on the East Coast, tomatoes are at their sweetest, ripest and juiciest? Or at least it feels that way, like a serendipitous reward for suffering through a heat wave.

headline: Frida Clements and Tomo Nakayama
text: FRIDA CLEMENTS first fell for Tomo Nakayama’s music, and then for the man.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Adieu, Anna
text: On the Street: A hundred years from now, fashion historians will want to know about the astonishing style of Anna Piaggi, an Italian fashion editor who died in Milan on Aug. 7 at age 81.

headline: Buy a Print, Help Rwandans
text: Yutaka Sho, an assistant professor of architecture at Syracuse, has helped rebuild housing in Rwanda since she visited the genocide-ravaged country in 2008. She was a founder of GA Collaborative, a nonprofit group of design practitioners and educators, which assists in these efforts. But recently, she hit a fund-raising wall to continue the Rwanda work, so she appealed to Jungil Hong, a visual artist, whom she met when they were students at the Rhode Island School of Design. “Fund raising is just not fun,” said Ms. Sho. “We’re not very good at it. We hate to beg. But we can make art, so we wanted to combine those two things together.“

headline: A Riper Shade of Red
text: When I served the cold tomato soup from this week’s City Kitchen column to friends the other night, the response was positive. “Mmm, gazpacho, right? Delicious.” Well, yes and no.

headline: What Would You Do? Rent or Buy?
text: So you’ve just learned that the rent on your one-bedroom apartment in Chelsea is going up — again.

headline: Four Decisions

headline: Rent or Buy?
text: BLANCHING at their rent bills, more New Yorkers are being forced to confront that age-old question, should I rent, or does buying make more sense?

headline: In Andalusia, on the Trail of Inherited Memories
text: ARCOS DE LA FRONTERA, Spain — I still wonder how I ended up living in a former medieval bordello on the brink of a sandstone cliff on the southern frontier of Spain.

headline: Where the Beaked Whales Are
text: Scott Baker, associate director of the Marine Mammal Institute at Oregon State University, writes from Samoa, where he studies the formation of local communities among dolphins and their genetic isolation from one another.

headline: Debussy at 150: The Impressions Still Deceive
text: CLASSICAL music institutions are usually quick to seize on major anniversaries of a composer’s birth or death as a convenient programming hook. Get ready for the Wagner and Verdi bicentennial celebrations next year.

headline: Investment From China Places A123 Systems on the Defensive
text: As reported on Thursday by The Times, the financially troubled electric-vehicle battery maker A123 Systems reached a final agreement with the Wanxiang Group Corporation, a supplier of automotive parts and systems based in China, for an investment of up to $465 million.

headline: It’s Nearly Impossible to Stay Unknown
text: IF you believe the myth, Ariel Pink is home a lot.

headline: Widening U.N.C. Scandal Prompts Independent Review
text: For the past two years, North Carolina officials have liked to talk about getting past the scandal that landed it in N.C.A.A. hot water, embarrassing a university that likes to believe it is one of the few doing things “the right way.” The embers of the era of Butch Davis as the football coach showed that things had gone seriously off the rails, and now they have gotten only worse with the apparent leaking of Julius Peppers’s eye-opening transcript, which indicates the academic fraud stretches back a lot longer than the Davis era.

headline: Behind the Scenes at the Armory, an Immersion Course in History
text: The assignment was to make an eight-minute video “collage” that explained “King Lear” using images of modern celebrities. Whom to cast as Lear?

headline: Still Waiting for Rafa
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Between injuries, suspensions and international duty with Mexico, Rafael Marquez has played in only 38 games (a mere nine this season) since joining the Red Bulls from Barcelona in August 2010.

text: A look at the day in sports, including lonely fairway walks, blocking home plate and riding big waves in a surfing tournament in Tahiti.

headline: Former Chief of Peregrine Pleads Not Guilty to Fraud
text: The former chief executive of the failed brokerage firm Peregrine Financial Group, who last month wrote a note admitting that he had committed a long-ranging investment fraud, pleaded not guilty on Friday to lying to federal regulators.

headline: The Auto Insurance Case That Blew Up on the Internet
text: It isn’t often that automobile insurance becomes the subject of nationwide outrage. So when it does happen, it’s worth a peek inside all our policies to figure out how they actually work and what the insurance companies are up to behind the scenes.

headline: An Undercurrent of Darkness, Even at Disney
text: HOTSHOT TV animators used to knock on Disney Channel’s door very infrequently. For a generation of cartoonists raised on “The Simpsons,” Disney had a reputation as too worried about protecting its brand to have fun. The cool kids wanted to work elsewhere.

headline: Just Over Half of Eligible Teachers Receive Tenure
text: The Bloomberg administration's efforts to raise the bar for granting tenure status to teachers continued this year, with nearly half of the eligible teachers denied tenure. Many of them had the decision deferred for a year while others lost their jobs.

headline: For Selfish Seniors Only
text: Among the many falsehoods in the Romney campaign’s new Medicare ad is this remarkable line pitched to the elderly: “The money you paid in for guaranteed health care is going into a massive new government program that’s not for you.”

headline: Men’s Shorts Regain Fashion Status
text: There are notable figures in men’s fashion, who are chipping away at the pant-hem bias, and working to give short pants more respect.

headline: How Do You Want It to End?
text: Among the many things that Ellen Goodman has done — written a widely syndicated column, published books, won a Pulitzer Prize for commentary, given probably hundreds of talks on topics from friendship and feminism to bioethics — is this familiar job: She’s been a family caregiver.

headline: America and the Mini-Series, in Infancy
text: IN a late 1970s “Doonesbury” comic strip, the cartoonist Garry Trudeau imagined the NBC programming wizard Fred Silverman’s pitch for a docudrama about the Camp David accords — starring John Travolta and Suzanne Somers as Menachem Begin and Anwar Sadat.

headline: Shorts Have Men Showing a Little Leg
text: EARLIER this season on the MTV series “Savage U,” Dan Savage, the syndicated sex columnist, was asked if he wears shorts. His response was as immediate as it was dismissive: “No, no. I’m a grown-up.”

headline: About Your Underinsured Motorist Policy
text: In my Your Money column this weekend, I sought out more detail about the auto insurance case that lit up the Internet this week. It’s a complicated tale, involving Progressive Insurance and family members of Katie Fisher, who was killed in a car accident. They were trying to make a claim on her underinsured motorist policy, since there was an underinsured motorist at the wheel of the car that hit her.

headline: The TV Watch: Saudi Arabia

headline: Universal’s Paramount Hits
text: THE first thing you may notice about “Universal Rarities: Films of the 1930s,” a fine new box set from TCM’s limited edition Vault Collection, is that all four features it contains were actually produced and released by Paramount Pictures. “Million Dollar Legs” (1932), “Belle of the Nineties” (1934), “Artists and Models” (1937) and “Souls at Sea” (1937) are indeed Universal rarities in the sense that (a) they are rare and (b) they figure among the 700 or so pre-1950 Paramount sound films that through a series of acquisitions and mergers, ended up under the control of Universal’s television division.

headline: The TV Watch: Saudi Arabia

headline: Teenage Dream
text: In the 16 years since its introduction, the Porsche Boxster has steadily evolved into a great sports car. After its first full redesign, the two-seat convertible still shines.

headline: The Well Rounded Amber Heard
text: ‘She’s a punch-throwing, gun-shooting, crown-wearing, sash-bearing, beauty-pageant Barbie with a twist,” says the actress Amber Heard of her role in the Robert Rodriguez action film “Machete Kills,” due out next year. Similar words could be used to describe the 26-year-old actress, who at age 16 fled Catholic school in Austin, Tex., for a try at modeling in New York — but who still listens to the blues and is a crack shot with her .357 Magnum. Heard is also a Guess model, whose va-va-voom looks and progressive views on sexuality — she spoke out on behalf of the L.G.B.T. community at a 2010 Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation event — have earned her many a racy headline. Not that she’s noticed; Heard doesn’t read the gossips, anyway. (So don’t ask her about “Johnny Depp, Amber Heard Are ‘100 Percent Dating.’ ”) “If I had the time, I’d be reading my book or doing the crossword,” she says, referring to her one-week summer before filming “Paranoia,” a thriller with Liam Hemsworth. (Her most recent role was in the film adaptation of Hunter S. Thompson’s “The Rum Diary.”) In between movies, Heard, who has made trips to the Mexico border with Amnesty International, will work with the organization on a bilingual campaign to help raise awareness about current immigration policies. “It’ll be something we present both on a grass-roots level and a lobby level,” she says. Barbie goes to Washington? More…

headline: Panic Seizes India as a Region’s Strife Radiates
text: BRAJAKHAL, India — Like a fever, fear has spread across India this week, from big cities like Bangalore to smaller places like Mysore, a contagion fueling a message: Run. Head home. Flee. And that is what thousands of migrants from the country’s distant northeastern states are doing, jamming into train stations in an exodus challenging the Indian ideals of tolerance and diversity.

headline: Arkansas Police Release More Footage Related to Man’s Death
text: Witnesses in the Chavis Carter case in Arkansas said they heard a popping sound, then saw two police officers involved in his arrest approach the back seat of the patrol car where Mr. Carter had been placed in handcuffs and was later found with a fatal gunshot wound. That was according to new material released by the Jonesboro Police Department, which has said Mr. Carter apparently shot himself during the arrest last month.

headline: Marriage Is No Picnic? Begging to Differ
text: ONCE back from the honeymoon, newlyweds will still have romantic places to go.

headline: Congressional Leaders Issue Medicare Talking Points for August
text: With members of Congress back home for a five-week recess, leaders in both parties are working overtime to make sure that their respective messages on Medicare are being pounded in their Congressional districts. The case is particularly urgent now that Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin has been chosen as the number two on the Republican ticket.

headline: In India, Many Flee Fearing Violence
text: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh assured migrants that they were safe as thousands fled big cities, fearing a backlash from violence against Muslims in Assam.

headline: The Rolls-Royce That Built a Reputation
text: ON its way to the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance as a participant in the 1,500-mile Motoring Classic tour, the 1912 Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost owned by Charles Howard of Gloucestershire, England, was sidelined by an engine failure. That will not affect the Silver Ghost’s place in history, however. Some experts consider the Ghost the greatest Rolls of all.

headline: Can a Mom Get a Break?
text: SOMEHOW, my local manicure ladies always feel inclined to turn my $35 finger-and-toe sessions into a barrage of myriad personal questions. In halting English, they will pepper me with, “How old are you?” “Where you born?” “How much you make?” “What your husband do?”

headline: Porsche’s Baby Turns 16; Seeks a Bigger Allowance
text: PORSCHE doesn’t like to be rushed. But while it took the company’s lab-coated obsessives 16 years to fully redesign the Boxster, the two-seat convertible has steadily evolved into one of the world’s best sports cars.

headline: A Debutante Grows Up

But that would be as silly as worrying about being late to Templeton, the 15-acre estate in Old Westbury, N.Y., where she lives with a menagerie, a small staff, some Warhols and many boldface memories.

headline: Aug. 19 — 25
text: IN their uniformity and attire — “you’re all one size here” — the students at the Institute Benjamenta, a school for domestic servants, seem as much prisoners as pupils. Because this is a Quay Brothers movie, they also seem like automatons, something between men and machines. “Later in life,” Jakob (Mark Rylance) says, “we shall all be something very small and subordinate.” The Quays, masters of stop-motion animation, are the subjects of a gallery show at the Museum of Modern Art and a linked film series, which begins with what might seem like an anomaly in their canon, a live-action film, “INSTITUTE BENJAMENTA, OR THIS DREAM PEOPLE CALL HUMAN LIFE.”

headline: Svetlana Legetic, Washington Night Life Promoter, Moving to New York

headline: A Renaissance for a Space Age Relic
text: ON a recent evening, I struggled to hold a squat during what felt like a wildly electric earthquake. Forget the burn of the pose; my chief discomfort was the way my brain seemed to rattle, my ears buzzing.

headline: Editor’s Letter

It’s a timely and good question, one that deserves not to be brushed aside; and something I thought about as we reviewed the final pages for this issue, which is devoted to the fall women’s collections.

headline: Paul Ryan and the Auto Bailout
text: At an Ohio campaign stop on Thursday, Paul Ryan ventured into auto-bailout territory. He described a shuttered GM factory in his hometown of Janesville, Wis., and said “I remember President Obama visiting it when he was first running, saying he’ll keep that plant open. One more broken promise.” Later, in an interview with an ABC affiliate, he said the auto rescue “didn’t help Janesville. They shut our plant down.”

headline: United Nations Is Looking to Spur a Billion People to Act

headline: Getting Close and Personal With Imran Khan
text: For this week’s profile of Imran Khan, the Scottish photographer Finlay MacKay travelled to Pakistan to photograph the popular politician. MacKay, who has been a regular contributor to the magazine since 2006, is known for his highly choreographed portraits of celebrities and athletes (as his portraits of Javier Bardem, Nastia Liukin and Floyd Mayweather Jr. demonstrate).

headline: Tougher Crash Test Brings Lower Scores
text: NEW models typically receive the top rating — Good — in front offset crash tests conducted by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. So the institute raised eyebrows throughout the auto industry last week when it released results of a new type of frontal test in which only two of the 11 tested cars received the highest score.

headline: All-American Food With New-Age Touches

headline: Heineken Clinches Deal for Asia Pacific Breweries With $4.5 Billion Offer
text: Heineken claimed victory in its fight to gain control of Asia Pacific Breweries on Friday, announcing a sweetened deal to buy the rights to the beer maker held by Fraser & Neave for about $4.5 billion.

headline: Mining Golden Kernels From the Cob
text: I’m writing about corn in my column this week, with a recipe for a baked pancake that includes fresh kernels. In the video above, I give some tips on cutting the kernels off the cob, but I don’t go into the different methods of cooking corn. There is, of course, boiling (for a minute or two), broiling (slicked with olive oil, broil for a minute or two until browned in spots) and grilling, either in the husk or peeled.

headline: Adding Stevie Nicks and Paul Simon, Then Setting the Songbook to Shuffle

headline: A 20-Year Low in U.S. Carbon Emissions
text: Energy-related carbon dioxide emissions in the United States from January through March were the lowest of any recorded for the first quarter of the year since 1992, the federal Energy Information Administration reports.

headline: Changes in Egypt’s Top Military Command
text: On Aug. 12, President Mohamed Morsi purged Egypt’s top generals to reclaim the political power that the military had seized after the fall of Hosni Mubarak in 2011.

headline: With Defiance, Laughter and a New Single, Russian Riot Grrrls Go to Jail
text: As my colleague David Herszenhorn reports, three members of the all-female protest band Pussy Riot were sentenced to two-year prison terms on Friday by a judge who ruled that their impromptu performance of a song deriding Vladimir V. Putin in a Moscow cathedral last February was “motivated by religious hatred.”

headline: Second World Mind Sports Games in France
text: LILLE, France — At the Second World Mind Sports Games here, the United States open and senior teams qualified for the quarterfinals, which started on Friday and will end on Saturday at 1:20 p.m. Eastern time. The results are at worldbridge.org.

text: Canarsie, Brooklyn, 5:30 a.m. Thursday. A tip to the police: buckets of marijuana in a U.P.S. truck on Farragut Road and East 104th Street.

headline: Where Playwrights Take Center Stage
text: In the front window of the Drama Book Shop, on 40th Street in Midtown Manhattan, there is a sign that reads, “Playwright working,” with an arrow pointing down to just that. At 3:30 on a recent Friday afternoon, the featured writer was Hilary Bettis, one of 76 participants in Write Out Front, a three-week project continuing through Sept. 1.

headline: Liberty Media on the Cusp of Controlling Sirius XM
text: John C. Malone’s Liberty Media appeared to be close to victory on Friday in its continuing, and often sharp-elbowed, battle to take over Sirius XM Radio.

text: The fall women’s fashion issue of T stars Emma Watson, who after a decade of Harry Potter films is opening a new bag of tricks. Inside, meet Amber Heard, the model, activist and actress, and journey to Wellington, New Zealand, with the catwalker Miranda Kerr, who is photographed by her husband, Orlando Bloom, in the season’s white shirts and strappy flats. Scott. Want more? Then check out Lynn Yaeger’s report on the Paris Museum of Fashion, read Suzy Menkes musing on the return of the pantsuit or watch the model Liya Kebede lead a “Velvet Revolution.” See more from the issue >>

headline: Familiar Offerings Amid Ocher and Plum
text: IT’S been seven years since I last reviewed Rraci’s, and I can report that history pretty much repeats itself, but at a higher price. A charming back dining patio has been added, but inside, the pallor of age hangs over the restaurant. Ocher walls are almost hidden by a clutter of pretty mirrors reflecting the small spaces, window swags, wine bottles and dusty bouquets of silk flowers. The dim lighting, the dark wainscoting and a deep plum ceiling can feel cozy or claustrophobic, like being at the back of a cave. The menu, too, is dated, a near copy of that offered years ago. Dishes reflect the taste of those times — a preference for the rich and the heavy with less interest in the subtle and the seasonal. When is the last time anyone had calf’s liver as an appetizer?

headline: Court Overturns Law Expanding Taxi Service
text: A State Supreme Court justice on Friday rebuffed the Bloomberg administration’s plan to expand street hail service beyond Manhattan, signaling an uncertain future for livery taxis in the city and a victory for the yellow-cab industry, which has vigorously opposed the plan.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 17
text: Slide Show: A look back at the week’s events in New York City and the region.

headline: Horse Given Painkiller Breaks Down at New Mexico Racetrack
text: A horse that recently tested positive for a supercharged painkiller drawn from a type of South American frog broke down and was euthanized Thursday at a New Mexico racetrack after winning a trial heat for the coming All American Futurity, one of the world’s richest horse races.

headline: A College Lifts a Hurdle for Illegal Immigrants
text: DENVER — Monday is the first day of the school year for Metropolitan State University of Denver, a compact, urban campus in the heart of the city’s downtown.

headline: Unitarians Break With Tradition of Extended Time Off in Summer
text: “If you phone a Unitarian Church between the middle of June and Labor Day in September, the most you are apt to get is a recorded message,” Charles S. Slap said in his sermon at the First Unitarian Society of Schenectady, N.Y., on Sept. 8, 1985. “Our more orthodox friends never cease to be astounded by the contents of the message: ‘This church is closed for the summer. If you are one of those people who actually need a church during the summer, try the Presbyterians.’ ”

headline: When Bacon Beckons Far From Home

text: A hundred years from now, fashion historians will want to know about the astonishing style of Anna Piaggi, an Italian fashion editor who died in Milan on Aug. 7 at age 81.

headline: Woody Guthrie, Choreographer’s Muse
text: The performers who appear in the Downtown Dance Festival each year aren’t stellar. Many aren’t professional; quite a number aren’t adults. On the wrong day, too high a proportion of a mixed bill can be lackluster or foolish. The good programs, however, have often proved more than refreshing: they can be revelatory. As a permanent tourist in New York, I’m more than happy to sit in the open air near the southern tip of Manhattan. As a permanent student, I’m grateful when unfamiliar forms of dance teach me something new. One program this summer has shown me about important aspects of America I’d overlooked.

headline: Fine Arts
text: On Aug. 4, The Southampton Hospital held its annual benefit for more than 800 guests in a tent in the open fields adjacent to the hospital. A display of race cars fit the theme of the Grand Prix of Monaco.

headline: A Settler Leader, Worldly and Pragmatic

headline: Picasso’s Life Inspires Two Films
text: MADRID — Two events in Picasso’s life, a quarter of a century apart, are at the heart of new movies by two of Spain’s veteran directors.

headline: Arctic Drilling Will Begin This Year, Shell Official Says
text: HOUSTON — Despite embarrassing delays and trouble with its equipment, Shell remains confident that it will get final approval from regulators and be able to begin drilling for oil in Arctic waters off the Alaskan coast this summer, the oil company’s top Alaska executive said on Friday.

headline: What Parents Don’t Get About Camp
text: It’s been fun over this summer to read what parents think about summer camp. All those hopes for children’s gaining self-confidence or friends or independence! But let’s be honest, parents (or at least parents who weren’t campers themselves) don’t totally “get” the whole camp thing. And with campers coming home in droves, those parents are getting a full dose of the in-jokes, goofy rituals and the cherished memories that make up “camp.”

headline: A Mysterious Lady Wakes Up Dead
text: You know something is a bit strange when the hero goes home to his London flat and his comfy living-room armchairs are played by stagehands. And when the announced station stops for a train whizzing through the English countryside include Gosford Park, Downton Abbey and Brideshead Revisited. And when a news report describes a murder victim as a “well-dressed woman, about 35, with a knife in her back.”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,072 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Deutsche Bank’s Business With Sanctioned Nations Under Scrutiny
text: Federal and state prosecutors are investigating Deutsche Bank and several other global banks over accusations that they funneled billions of dollars through their American branches for Iran, Sudan and other sanctioned nations, according to law enforcement officials with knowledge of the cases.

headline: Recycling Plant Fire Unnerves a New York Town
text: After a fire burned through a recycling plant for electrical equipment two weeks ago in Columbia County, N.Y., the environmental tests that followed were alone cause for anxiety among residents.

headline: A Romance That Isn’t What It Seems
text: She is a mousy millinery assistant, consigned to the back room because she is not considered attractive enough to deal with customers. He is a small-time con man, looking for his next mark. He swiftly marries the women he woos, beds them (just to be polite), takes control of their bank accounts (this is 1910 London, after all, and young ladies need protecting) and runs for the hills.

headline: Obama Lags on Judicial Picks, Limiting His Mark on Courts
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is set to end his term with dozens fewer lower-court appointments than both Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush achieved in their first four years, and probably with less of a lasting ideological imprint on the judiciary than many liberals had hoped for and conservatives had feared.

text: First Floor TheaterLa MaMa ETC74A East Fourth Street, East Village(866) 468-7619Through Aug. 26

headline: Burglar Tells How He Got Into an East Village Apartment, Twice
text: The East Village apartment burglar, successful once, came back for more, and was caught in a trap and arrested. But a mystery lingered. How did he get in that apartment? Had he lived there before? No. And the building’s super said the lock was changed after the previous tenant left.

headline: Judge Bars Testimony by Expert in Frisk Suit
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has repeatedly said that the small number of guns found by police officers during stop-and-frisk encounters shows that the program is working as a deterrent, and not that the police are exercising poor judgment in deciding whom to stop, as critics have argued.

text: We need more Rachel Dratch in our lives.

text: MOSCOW — For a few brief moments Friday, a protester’s reaction to the news that three women in the punk band Pussy Riot were found guilty of hooliganism nearly caused an international incident.
