headline: Reviving the Memory of a Blues Pioneer
text: The blues singer known as Big Maybelle, who recorded hit singles and toured the country during the 1950s and 1960s, is largely forgotten today, except perhaps by blues aficionados. However, the powerful performance by Lillias White at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor makes a strong case that the blues belter’s obscurity is grievously undeserved.

headline: West Memphis Three, a Year Out of Prison, Navigate New Paths
text: ATLANTA — The list of things you learn about yourself when you get out of prison after 17 years is long: You’re allergic to shrimp, or you’re paralyzed by the choices in a grocery store or moved to tears by the softness of the night sky.

headline: For Williams Sisters, a Split in Cincinnati
text: MASON, Ohio — Serena Williams, the Olympic gold medalist and Wimbledon champion, lost her first match since May on Friday, falling to the German Angelique Kerber, 6-4, 6-4, in the quarterfinals at the Western & Southern Open in this suburb of Cincinnati.

headline: Many New York City Teachers Denied Tenure in Policy Shift
text: Nearly half of New York City teachers reaching the end of their probations were denied tenure this year, the Education Department said on Friday, marking the culmination of years of efforts toward Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s goal to end “tenure as we know it.”

headline: Watching the Olympics, Seeing Formula One
text: PARIS — I kept an eye on the Olympics, and since it is the summer break in Formula One, I tried to keep my mind off Formula One. But, inevitably, comparisons of the two spectacles kept entering my thoughts — especially since Formula One has for many years hyped itself as the world’s third most popular sporting spectacle, behind the Olympics and World Cup soccer.

headline: Ailing Yankees Give Teixeira Chance to Rest Injured Wrist
text: The Yankees look more brittle with each passing day. C. C. Sabathia, Andy Pettitte and Alex Rodriguez are on the disabled list, and now Mark Teixeira’s sore left wrist will most likely keep him sidelined for a couple of games.

headline: Merchants and Shoppers Sour on Daily Deal Sites
text: As their e-mail in-boxes filled with daily deal offers from Web sites like Groupon, Lea Pische and Edwin Hermawan, a pizzeria waitress and a former lawyer living on the Lower East Side, finally decided to buy one: a discounted Skillshare class on how to start a business.

headline: An Indecent Proposal and a Moral Dilemma
text: Isabella’s quandary in the Shakespeare play “Measure for Measure” is a little like Joan’s in the 2012 season of “Mad Men.” Should a woman sleep with a man she finds repellent if by doing so she serves a greater good? And how much greater does that good have to be? On “Mad Men,” it was a matter of crass commerce, an advertising agency getting its first big auto account. In “Measure for Measure,” it is a question of the woman’s saving her brother from execution. But this story being a product of Elizabethan England, when notions of immortal damnation were taken more personally, the playwright cannot let her fall into bed with just anybody. He cannot let her fall into bed at all.

headline: Ryan Tax Returns Show 20 Percent Rate in 2011
text: The Republican vice-presidential candidate Paul D. Ryan and his wife, Janna, paid 20 percent of their adjusted gross income in federal income taxes in 2011 and 15.9 percent in 2010, according to tax returns he released Friday.

headline: Obama’s Impact on the Federal Courts of Appeals
text: Vacancies on the district courts have increased during President Obama’s term, but he has restored some partisan balance to the appeals court bench.

headline: In England’s Premier League, Many Suitors for the Top Spot
text: It takes something special for England to forget about soccer — something as momentous as the greatest show on earth’s rolling into London for two weeks, in fact. But after a summer off, and a soaring Summer Olympics, the English Premier League is back to reclaim its title as the land’s greatest sporting spectacle.

headline: Thailand: 4 Die in Nightclub Fire in Phuket
text: Four people died and a dozen were injured Friday when a fire broke out at a nightclub on the Thai resort island of Phuket, the police said. The identities of the dead were not known late Friday, Maj. Gen. Chanasit Wattanawarangkul, the chief of police in Phuket, said by telephone. Phuket is about 510 miles south of Bangkok. General Chanasit said that the fire had occurred after power was cut and then restored during heavy rain in the early hours of Friday. A transformer “exploded,” he said, and the fire spread quickly into the building. Four French citizens were among the injured, one of whom suffered serious burns, Thai news reports said. The nightclub, the Tiger Discotheque, is in Patong, one of the island’s most popular tourist spots.

headline: The Minister of Death
text: From April 29 to May 30, 1862, some 300,000 men — including my great-great grandfather, Pvt. Edward Willis — converged at the tiny railroad depot of Corinth, in northern Mississippi, where they laid siege to the Confederate forces under Gen. P.G.T. Beauregard. The Union soldiers scarred the landscape with miles of earthen fortifications. But the trenches could not protect Edward and his fellow soldiers from what Thomas Macaulay called “the most terrible of all the ministers of death,” a predator that craved those close, confined spaces, where men’s blood, breath and spit mingled freely. Although they fought on opposite sides of the trenches, the Union and Confederate forces shared a common enemy: smallpox.

headline: Baseball, Faith and Doubt
text: It was impossible this week not to think about the incredible staying power of baseball.

headline: Push for More Cholera Inoculations
text: Pressure to adopt a cholera vaccine as part of the routine response to outbreaks mounted as two expert panels advised the World Health Organization to use it. On Thursday, experts meeting in Washington endorsed the use of the vaccine to control the continuing outbreak in Haiti and the Dominican Republic. Studies conducted by medical charities there showed that up to 90 percent of people who had received one dose of the vaccine returned for a second dose and were therefore protected. Separately, an expert panel advised the World Health Organization this year to seek enough money to create a global stockpile of two million doses for emergencies. On Friday, Sierra Leone declared its cholera outbreak a national humanitarian emergency; it has had almost 11,000 cases and 176 deaths since January. Cholera kills through rapid dehydration. The vaccine is for healthy people, but it could be used to surround outbreaks and keep them from spreading.

headline: Senator, Senator, Make Me a Match: For Staff, Schumer Is Cupid
text: Even by the standards of Capitol Hill, where ambitious and awkward young people are thrust together in cramped workplaces and crowded bars, the nuptial output of Senator Charles E. Schumer’s office stands out.

headline: ‘Sparkle’ Brightens Midday at the Multiplex
text: CULVER CITY, Calif. — It takes a lot to get an audience applauding during a movie at 2 o’clock on a hot afternoon. But “Sparkle” did the trick, at least three times, during a showing at the Pacific Theaters Stadium 12 here on Friday.

headline: Draft Horse That Bolted May End Up on Easy Street
text: Oreo, the runaway horse who dumped his carriage driver and two passengers near Columbus Circle on Thursday, may have bolted his way into an easier lifestyle.

headline: This Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: A strong Canadian dollar weighs on the auto industry as contract talks start, the Kalashnikov factory in Russia is humming thanks to American buyers, and Amtrak’s Acela train service is dominating travel in the Washington-New York-Boston corridor.

headline: Lottery Numbers
California: Young Immigrants Eligible for Driver’s Licenses
text: Young illegal immigrants who qualify for President Obama’s deportation deferral program will be eligible to obtain a driver’s license in California. Mr. Obama’s program, which began Wednesday, will grant work permits to immigrants who are 30 years or younger and meet program requirements. California law permits the Department of Motor Vehicles to issue driver’s licenses to individuals who present an “employment authorization document.” The young immigrants, “once they have been given deferred action, can apply for a driver’s license,” said Conrado Terrazas, a spokesman for Assemblyman Gil Cedillo, who has tried unsuccessfully to pass a law allowing licenses for illegal immigrants.

headline: Combating Blight With Beauty
text: To fight the scourge of graffiti in Atlanta, an international crew of female artists created murals — sprawling, brightly colored portraits and designs — in recession-hit neighborhoods.

headline: Putting a Good Face on Street Art, to Upgrade Atlanta
text: ATLANTA — Molly Rose Freeman gasped at the size of her wall: 180 feet long, 20 feet tall, a street artist’s dream.

headline: Ever Hear the One About ...
text: Tying up loose ends before vacation:

headline: Written in the Stars
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — If you solve crosswords on a regular basis, there’s some random knowledge that you just accumulate over time. Some of this information can serve as a refresher for things that are useful to know, like the periodic table of elements or world capitals. Then there are the other factoids, like zodiac signs or birthstones, that fall into a less serious category of miscellany but are just as commonly used. Crossword clues are really the great equalizer.

headline: Illinois Legislators Fail to Agree on Pension Package
text: CHICAGO — Illinois lawmakers, who gathered at the Capitol in Springfield for a special session on Friday, failed to reach agreement on a pension package aimed at addressing the state’s ballooning fiscal problems.

headline: At the Beach, Vulnerability and Confidence
text: Caitlin Teal Price stalks the strand from Coney Island to Brighton Beach, pausing over sunbathers to ask if she can snap a portrait.

headline: Behind Francisco’s Grin: Less Than Lovely Numbers
text: WASHINGTON — The return of closer Frank Francisco from the disabled list has not stabilized the Mets’ shaky bullpen.

headline: Ballpoint-Pen Springs and Other Fixes for Vintage Bugattis
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — In Sunday’s Automobiles section, I write about the Pebble Beach Motoring Classic, a 1,500-mile tour now in its eighth year as an official prelude to the concours d’élégance and collector-car auctions that take place on the Monterey Peninsula of California each August.

headline: Repair Costs Could Bring Down a Popular Pier
text: When it was created in the late 1990s, Hudson River Park seemed like a new genre of public space, a state-city hybrid built on and over the water, with continuing maintenance to be paid for by commercial development on a handful of piers.

headline: Long Lines and Big Dreams
text: The lines on Wednesday were huge, like the ribbon of humanity at Navy Pier in Chicago that snaked through halls and stairwells and along the pier and then stretched, amazingly, out to and under Lake Shore Drive. Young illegal immigrants by the tens of thousands formed similar lines in other cities across the country. They lined up outside churches and nonprofit agencies, holding paperwork and folders, to learn more about a new Obama administration policy that would protect them from deportation and give them permission to work.

headline: Elegant Newlyweds, Out With the Boss
text: Is there a local restaurant rule — Farmer’s Law? — that holds that the simpler and earthier the cuisine, the more sophisticated the clientele? That, at least, would seem to be the case at Rosemary’s, a two-month-old trattoria at the corner of Greenwich Avenue and 10th Street in the West Village. Rosemary’s not only has a rough-hewed Tuscan farmhouse look, with distressed wood and exposed beams; it also has a rooftop garden of herbs and vegetables (and soon, perhaps, a beehive and a chicken coop). The daily produce is transported from garden to kitchen in a retro-old-world manner: dropped in a basket and lowered with a block and tackle. In the dining room, one finds a discerning and affluent crowd, which one night last week included a newly wed Norwegian-Italian couple and the husband’s boss.

headline: Ryan, Appearing at Ease in First Week on Trail, Begins to Look Ahead
text: SPRINGFIELD, Va. — It is hard to imagine Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, sauntering into a hot-dog restaurant and having an elderly, white-haired woman shout, “Hey, kick some tail!”

headline: City Ends School Lunch Program That Used Professional Chefs
text: A well-regarded program that recruited professional chefs to help the New York City Department of Education provide fresher, healthier food in public schools is being discontinued because it does not meet new federal nutrition standards, the department said Friday.

headline: The Unsafe World of Investing
text: The JOBS Act — Jump-Start Our Business Start-Ups — is a bad law. Enacted in April, it ends longstanding investor protections, reduces market transparency and lowers accounting and auditing standards for companies that are planning to go public.

headline: One Retailer’s Experience With Groupon
text: An online T-shirt retailer offered his customers a Groupon deal last year of a $20 coupon good for $40 worth of merchandise. But few of those who bought the coupon spent much more than its $40 value.

headline: With Another Mets First, Santana Raises Concerns Instead of Spirits
text: WASHINGTON — Johan Santana began his year enveloped in a thick haze of uncertainty. He appears to be wading into that haze again.

headline: Congressional Fund-Raiser Charged With Immigration Fraud
text: A former rabbinical aide who may hold the fate of a United States representative in his hands has been arrested on immigration-fraud charges, federal authorities said on Friday.

headline: Defensive Back Is Latest Star to Stumble Amid All the Attention
text: Just last week, Tyrann Mathieu was the rare collegiate defensive back who had earned star status as an outspoken dervish of a player, one who demanded attention whenever he got near the ball. But Mathieu’s life has changed drastically, taking two sharp turns.

headline: Savoring the Illicit Thrill of a Glass of Something, Outside
text: Gibran K. Brown and Jaie Jordan sat on the stoop of their brownstone, looking out over Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, as they do most warm evenings. In the distance, dust settled on the soccer pitch as players scattered after a game. Except for a jingling dog collar, the huffing of a passing jogger and the chorus of cicadas, the cooling air was quiet.

headline: It’s How You Play the Game
text: Fans of honest gamesmanship should be inured by now to the spectacle of a home run hitter caught conniving with his private druggist to break the rules. The latest is Melky Cabrera, the most valuable player in last month’s All-Star Game who humbly attributed his success to the Lord. After drug testing, the San Francisco Giants outfielder was forced by league officials to admit this week that banned doses of testosterone also played no small role in his blazing bat speed.

headline: Mandatory Class for Airport Officers Accused of Profiling
text: Transportation Security Administration officers who are in a behavioral detection program designed to spot terrorists at airports have been ordered to undergo special training after officers in Boston were accused of racially profiling passengers.

headline: Jeter Hits Home Run, Savoring a Milestone
text: Shortly after the Yankees beat the Boston Red Sox, 6-4, at Yankee Stadium and Joe Girardi lauded the performances of several players, he slipped quietly into the clubhouse and placed the game’s lineup card on Derek Jeter’s chair in front of his locker.

headline: Online, Love Blooms and Decays
text: There will no doubt come a time, in the not-so-distant future, when scholars data-mine Facebook for a digital literature of love. Why not? All of love’s aspects can be found on Facebook: first-date photographs, swooning status updates, jealousy-stirring pokes, the not-quite-terminal “it’s complicated.” Here, meanwhile, are a few poems about Facebook’s role in romance found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

headline: Criticism Greets List of Debate Moderators
text: Complaining about the moderators of the presidential debates is a time-honored tradition of the election season. Usually, the complaints wait until the moderators have actually asked a question.

headline: Abortion Cases Against Clinic in Kansas Are Dropped by Prosecutors
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The first criminal prosecution of Planned Parenthood came to an abrupt end Friday when Kansas prosecutors dropped all charges against a local affiliate accused of failing to determine the viability of fetuses before abortions were performed.

headline: Dark Road to the White House
text: Shady money, voter suppression, shifting positions, murky details and widespread apathy.

headline: Welcome, New York Voters
text: Registering to vote in New York State is an unnecessarily cumbersome process, time-consuming and prone to error. Voters fill out forms at one of 129 motor vehicle offices around the state, which then have to be sorted and mailed to local boards of elections. Some names never make it to the lists of registered voters. Little wonder that New York ranks a dismal 48th in the nation in voter registration, trailed only by Texas and Mississippi.

headline: Political Page Turners
text: Let’s see if we can clear up a few things.

headline: Ryan Draws Crowds in First Week
text: Representative Paul Ryan completed his first week as the Republican vice-presidential candidate and whooshed overnight to the highest level of American celebrity with its perks and poison darts.

headline: A Wall Street Trader Becomes an Ironman
text: IT was just after 11:30 p.m. on Aug. 11 when Guy Adami heard the words that had floated through his daydreams for nearly a year — to say nothing of nearly every minute of the previous 16 hours:

headline: Reviewing the Porsche Boxster
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2013 Porsche Boxster, a slimmer, faster and more focused version of the sports car introduced by the German automaker 16 years ago.

headline: Harry Harrison, a Prolific Writer of Satiric Science Fiction, Dies at 87
text: “Incompetent, unlettered, unskilled writers sell to unexacting editors. All of this is going completely unnoticed by an incompetent readership.”

headline: Of Red Sox’ Many Problems, Injuries Have Hurt Most
text: There is a scene in the movie “Almost Famous” when the band first reads the article the young journalist has written about them for Rolling Stone. Jason Lee’s character is devastated by the portrayal.

headline: In a Horseplayer’s Heaven, It’s Bear’s Season
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — It requires a certain temperament for a horseplayer to endure the grind of the Saratoga meet day in, day out. He needs to be shrewd but good-humored, absorbed but resilient. A healthy bankroll helps, as does a strong, functioning liver.

headline: Parking Rules
text: On Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations in New York City will be suspended because of Id al-Fitr. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Premier League Preview
text: The Premier League season kicks off Saturday with seven games, including Robin van Persie-less Arsenal against Sunderland. Chelsea and Manchester City play their openers on Sunday, and Manchester United, now bolstered by van Persie, plays Everton on Monday. Graham Ruthven takes a look at what could be a crowded race for the top spot. Who do you think will end up lifting the trophy in May?

headline: The Butler Wears Flip-Flops
text: THE day was hardly under way, and Billy Mackay had already sweated through his blue shirt with “CABANA” written across the back.

headline: A Gaza Border Slams Shut, and With It, Chances for a Pilgrimage to Mecca
text: GAZA CITY — Every Ramadan for the past two decades, Mouin Mushtaha has made the pilgrimage to Mecca during the last 10 days of the Muslim holy month. This year, as Ramadan ticked away, he sat gloomily at the office of his tourism agency here, watching the festivities on television.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: North but No South

headline: Jailhouse Letter: Dear Judge, ‘The Staff Actually Discontinued My Fish Oil’
text: It is said that older people like to enumerate their various health woes, and apparently aging Yippies are no different.

headline: Meditation, and Cereal for Dinner
text: Robert Hammond, 42, founded Friends of the High Line in 1999 with Joshua David, helping transform the abandoned rail line in Chelsea into a linear park that draws millions of visitors a year. On Sundays, Mr. Hammond, who has lived in the West Village since 1994, spends time with his boyfriend, Justin Brennan, in the neighborhood, eating at local haunts and bicycling. While Mr. Hammond might take a prospective donor on a tour of the High Line, he usually chooses other parks for his own relaxation.

headline: A Suit Familiar and Remarkable
text: THE lawsuit traversed familiar ground: lesser-known songwriter sues established artist, claiming that her work was poached and turned into a hit song.

headline: The Night-Life Lawyer
text: THE New York bar, like all complex professional societies, has every sort of specialty you can think of: white-shoe litigators, Mafia defenders, crusading Legal Aiders, corporate crisis managers, City Hall fixers, real estate closers and lowly filers of slip-and-fall lawsuits. Sal Strazzullo’s specialty is that capricious class of person occupying the world of New York night life. In a decade as a lawyer, Mr. Strazzullo, 40, has earned a reputation for taking care of the boldface celebrities — and lesser lights of the pleasure-seeking set — who get themselves in trouble after dark.

headline: Corrections: August 18, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Watchmen’s Misdirected Gaze
text: “Person of Interest,” the CBS television drama developed as if to risk the collective cardiovascular failure of the New York Civil Liberties Union, delivers a vision of the city in which technological innovation, boundless private capital and an outlaw disposition collude to render a fantasia of sixth-sense policing. At the center sits an obsessive billionaire computer savant who deploys his own pattern-recognition software, advanced surveillance gadgetry and the acrobatics of a former spy to identify those about to perpetrate or fall prey to violence, and pre-empt their fate. Murder and malfeasance are nipped virtually at conception. Pass the cupcakes!

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Policy on Coal Concessions Cost Government Royalties, Audit Finds
text: The Indian government “missed out on nearly $34 billion in royalties by selling private companies coal concessions at negotiated prices rather than auctioning them,” according to an audit released on Friday, Vikas Bajaj wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Ryan: The First Decade
text: Continuing with my Ryan series, let’s look at what his budget (pdf) actually proposes (as opposed to vaguely promises) in its first decade.

headline: Reports on Government Contracts Deal Another Blow to Coalition
text: Summary of the findings released by India’s comptroller and auditor general on Friday.

headline: Echoes of Northeastern Violence Ripple Across Indian Cities
text: “Like a fever, fear has spread across India this week, from big cities like Bangalore to smaller places like Mysore, a contagion fueling a message: Run. Head home. Flee,” Jim Yardley wrote in The New York Times. “And that is what thousands of migrants from the country’s distant northeastern states are doing, jamming into train stations in an exodus challenging the Indian ideals of tolerance and diversity.

headline: The Weekend Word: Empty Benches
text: Today’s Times

headline: Kansas City Chiefs, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: Two years ago, everything was going great for the Kansas City Chiefs. They were a bright young team under a bright young coach, Todd Haley. They rode the league’s best rushing attack to a surprising A.F.C. West title. They had invested $28 million guaranteed in quarterback Matt Cassel, whom they felt was a good fit in Haley’s shotgun-based passing game. General Manager Scott Pioli was building this team the Patriot Way, stockpiling depth on both sides of the ball and retooling the classic 3-4 defense that former Patriots defensive coordinator Romeo Crennel was running. This was a team on the rise.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: In the Shopian district of southern Kashmir, people using the names Lashkar Al Qaida and Al Qaida Mujahideen  have been putting up posters threatening acid attacks on women who do not live in purdah or who carry cellphones, Kashmir Live  reported. The police said the perpetrators were not affiliated with any actual militant outfit and that two school dropouts were suspected, according to the newspaper.

headline: Leader Visits North Koreans at Border Post
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, has visited soldiers stationed near the two Koreas’ disputed sea border and bestowed official accolades on the artillery unit that shelled a South Korean island in 2010, killing four people, the North’s state-run news agency reported Saturday.

headline: Latin America Sees Hand of Colonialism in Assange Standoff
text: LONDON — Ecuador was this past weekend seeking support from its Latin American partners to confront what officials described as threats by Britain over Quito’s decision to grant asylum to Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder.

headline: Aug. 17: Does a Bullish Stock Market Predict a Faster Recovery?
text: There wasn’t much in the way of polling data on Friday. The national tracking polls were released — Mitt Romney and Paul D. Ryan got a comparatively poor number in the Rasmussen Reports tracking poll, which had President Obama pulling into a one-point lead after having trailed in that survey for much of the past few weeks. And there was a new national survey from the firm Angus Reid, which conducts online polls. It had Mr. Romney ahead by four points — up from a tie in its poll last month.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Manolo Blahnik Boot
text: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon in honor of the store’s 111th anniversary. Today’s pick (and the last in this series): a blinding ankle boot from Manolo Blahnik that’s covered in crystals and was designed exclusively for Bergdorf Goodman. $7,800.

headline: Premier League: And the Winner Is …
text: Let the games begin. No, not those Games. The games on the field and on the screen, TV and video. England’s Premier League and EA’s FIFA Soccer 13.

headline: Further Notes for the Sancerre-Inclined
text: PARIS — In his most recent Wines of The Times column, Eric Asimov tastes the so-called Sancerre satellites — appellations that produce white wine in a similar style to their better-known Loire Valley neighbor, from the same grape variety, sauvignon blanc. Indeed, wine from these appellations, which include Pouilly-Fumé, Menetou-Salon, Reuilly and Quincy, can be a good bet. Pouilly-Fumé sometimes matches or surpasses Sancerre in quality (and, unfortunately, in price) but all of the others are bargains.

headline: The Sun Hasn’t Set on the Drive-In
text: MONTCLAIR, Calif.

headline: Drive-In Theaters Offer a Bit of the Past, and Its Prices
text: A symbol of 1950s-era Southern California, the drive-in has shown resilience in today’s trying economy. Entry is cheap, the atmosphere is relaxed and, for some, the memories are unbeatable.

headline: At Second, at Least, Cubs Are a Force
text: When Skip, the manager in the movie “Bull Durham,” summed up baseball, he said: “This is a simple game. You throw the ball, you hit the ball, you catch the ball.” Unfortunately, at some point, the importance of catching the ball has become lost on some fans and sportswriters.

headline: For Russians, Corruption Is Just a Way of Life
text: Corruption in Russia is so pervasive that the whole society accepts the unacceptable as normal.

headline: Next to the Manager, but a Bit Ahead
text: With a profusion of pitching changes, pinch-hitting announcements and fielding realignments, a baseball game can slow interminably in the later innings. But to decision makers in the dugout — those who make strategic adjustments while looking ahead to the next pitch, the next batter, the next inning — it feels as if it is speeding up.

headline: Horses Fall Victim to Hard Times and Dry Times on the Range
text: AZTEC, N.M. — The land is parched, the fields are withering and thousands of the nation’s horses are being left to fend for themselves on the dried range, abandoned by people who can no longer afford to feed them.

headline: Raising the Ritalin Generation
text: I REMEMBER the moment my son’s teacher told us, “Just a little medication could really turn things around for Will.” We stared at her as if she were speaking Greek.

headline: Volstead Struggling with the Cubs
text: No player sums up the futility of the 2012 Chicago Cubs better than starter Chris Volstad. The Cubs acquired Volstad from the Miami Marlins in January for Carlos Zambrano, an expensive and volatile starter the team was eager to shed. But while Volstad may be quieter than Zambrano, his results have been discouraging.

headline: Blanking Out
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — The variety puzzle from Fred Piscop this week is a diagramless, so brace yourself for the sheer terror of seeing 289 white squares blankly staring at you. Warning: There is some assembly required. You have to figure out the puzzle’s geometry, and that is the hardest part. You have to determine which squares are to be filled in and which should be black squares. Adding to the difficulty is that you have to add the numbers to the grid.

headline: Good Stuff
text: WITH all the supply lists, school clothes and emergency contact sheets required before September begins, I can barely keep track of everything I have to buy, fill out or turn in. The new school year means that a bunch of new stuff will pour into our apartment — and I still haven’t figured out what to do with all the stuff from last year.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: The Legacy of the Baby Boom Generation
text: Readers debate whether the bashing of boomers as selfish and spoiled is justified.

headline: Why Waiting Is Torture
text: Editors' note: Waiting in line is a timeless form of torture. Here's a story from the archives that explains why.

headline: Flamboyant Crime Fighter Now May Face Chinese Justice Over Role in Scandal
text: CHONGQING, China — Wang Lijun reveled in his image as the consummate crime fighter. An ethnic Mongolian policeman with a fondness for expensive overcoats, he directed crackdowns on organized crime, performed autopsies, patented designs for police uniforms and was even named an honorary professor at the institute of a famous American forensic scientist. His earlier exploits inspired a television series. All that was missing was a mask and cape.

headline: Why Race Is Still a Problem for Mormons
text: Fairfax, Va.

headline: Bedoya Scores in Debut for New Club
text: The career of any professional soccer player will almost always have its peaks and valleys, but for Alejandro Bedoya, the last year has been a tumultuous ride beyond what most players have to endure.

headline: Crank It Up
text: Cooling degree days in some of the world’s largest urban areas.

headline: The Cost of Cool
text: THE blackouts that left hundreds of millions of Indians sweltering in the dark last month underscored the status of air-conditioning as one of the world’s most vexing environmental quandaries.

headline: Bobak Ferdowsi
text: Bobak Ferdowsi is a flight director for NASA’s Mars rover, Curiosity. Widely known as “Mohawk Guy,” he’s become an Internet sensation since Curiosity’s successful landing last week, prompting President Obama to joke that he’s considering getting a mohawk himself.

headline: The World Is Flat, Again
text: I’LL never forget my first globe. It was a basketball-size sphere with textured mountains and shining cerulean seas, but its crowning inner glory was a light bulb. Suspended in the darkness of my bedroom for most of the nights of my childhood, it served first as a night light unto my world. But night after night and year after year, it showed me the makings of things like nights and years and a permanently marvelous truth: We live on a sphere, turning in the light of a star.

headline: Be More Productive. Take Time Off.
text: Editors’ note: We’re resurfacing this story from the archives to show you that you should be taking more time off.

headline: Jeter Chips Away at Hits Record as Rose Watches
text: Derek Jeter stood on first base. His single in Seattle had pulled the rookie to 4,255 hits behind baseball’s career leader, Pete Rose. The ball was retrieved. He was 20 years old.

headline: Obama’s (Perceived) Transformation
text: EARLIER this month, Ann Coulter took to the airwaves of the Fox News network to denounce the dastardly machinations, large mendacity and mad villainy currently employed by the American president. Barack Obama was “a liar,” Coulter said, a “despicable campaigner” who once claimed the banner of “hope and change” but was now giving the American people “the ugliest campaign we’ve ever had.”

headline: Punting Less Can Be Rewarding, but Coaches Aren’t Risking Jobs on It
text: The punt seems to contradict football’s essence, as coaches voluntarily relinquish the ball even though they have at least one more chance to move it forward.

headline: As U.N. Monitors Leave Syria, More Bodies Are Found
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Nations sent its final group of observers out of Syria on Saturday as the war lumbered on, with activists reporting raids, airstrikes and shelling across the country, in Aleppo, Dara’a, Azaz and around Damascus, where opposition groups counted 40 bodies on the streets of a nearby suburb.

headline: For Russians, Corruption Is Just a Way of Life
text: CORRUPTION in Russia is so pervasive that the whole society accepts the unacceptable as normal, as the only way of survival, as the way things “just are.”

headline: Lawyers From Suits Against Big Tobacco Target Food Makers
text: Don Barrett, a Mississippi lawyer, took in hundreds of millions of dollars a decade ago after suing Big Tobacco and winning record settlements from R. J. Reynolds, Philip Morris and other cigarette makers. So did Walter Umphrey, Dewitt M. Lovelace and Stuart and Carol Nelkin.

text: Not actually home yet, but done with the more strenuous bits, and I will be in Monday’s paper.

headline: Los Angeles Puts a New Park at Its Heart
text: LOS ANGELES — Grand Park, one of the largest new parcels of open space in this sprawling city, is the focus of all sorts of grand visions. Designed for a major concert, a farmers’ market or a participatory dance recital, it opened late last month with much fanfare, meant to attract office workers, suburbanites from across the region, tourists and the urban dwellers who call downtown home.

headline: A Seeming Edge, Until the Winter Classic Nears
text: It appears about 90 percent certain that a lockout will postpone the start of the N.H.L. season, so the next question is how long that postponement will last. In this high-stakes game for hundreds of millions of dollars, who will blink first?

headline: Beware a Beautiful Calm
text: WASHINGTON

headline: As Woody Turns 100, We Protest Too Little
text: In October the Kennedy Center will throw a centennial party for Woody Guthrie, a star-studded concert with tickets topping out at $175. It will be America’s ultimate tribute to a beloved troubadour. “Through his unique music, words and style,” the Kennedy Center says, “Guthrie was able to bring attention and understanding to the critical issues of his day.”

headline: Truth and Lies About Medicare
text: Republican attacks on President Obama’s plans for Medicare are growing more heated and inaccurate by the day. Both Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan made statements last week implying that the Affordable Care Act would eviscerate Medicare when in fact the law should shore up the program’s finances.

headline: 2 Jets Quarterbacks and 2 Cheering Sections
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Midway through a Jets training camp practice last week, cornerback Antonio Cromartie picked off a pass thrown by quarterback Mark Sanchez. Cromartie soon encountered something he would never see in an actual game.

headline: Michigan’s G.O.P. Governor Defies Easy Labels
text: DETROIT — In this political age of ideological purity, Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan is an enigma.

headline: Asia’s Roiling Sea
text: The South China Sea, one of the world’s most important waterways, has been contested off and on for centuries. These days, with the sea bounded by some of Asia’s most vibrant economies — China, Vietnam, the Philippines, Taiwan and Malaysia — the competition has become a virtual free-for-all. Confrontations over territorial control are alarmingly frequent and could get out of hand, with dangerous consequences.

headline: Former Reliever Olson Tells Clubhouse Tales
text: During a rain delay at Yankee Stadium last week, Texas Rangers catcher Mike Napoli sent out an urgent bulletin from the visiting locker room. “This might be the funniest thing ever!” Napoli wrote on Twitter, going on to say that the Rangers were playing hide and seek in their enormous clubhouse, and that Michael Young always got caught.

headline: Youth Golf Thrives, but Not in High School
text: Will Thomson bounded onto the practice tee lugging a double-strapped golf bag. His round of 78 was complete, but Thomson was still brimming with energy. At 11, he was the youngest and smallest junior in the field at the International Junior Golf Tour’s Bridgestone Golf Tournament of Champions in late May in Orlando, Fla.

headline: Jim Hackett on Authentic Leadership
text: This interview with  James P. Hackett, the president and chief executive of Steelcase, the office furniture company based in Grand Rapids, Mich., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Romney Starts a Weekly Audiocast
text: With a drawn-out “Hellooo,” Mitt Romney begins his first weekly audio message – attacking President Obama’s Medicare plan and defending his own.

headline: Goldman, Still Playing in Bayou’s Mud
text: THE story of the Bayou Group, the hedge fund firm that collapsed in a whirl of lies and drugs, was always a little weird. But it just keeps getting weirder.

text: Nobody teed off in London, but in 2016 in Rio de Janeiro, golf will re-emerge as an Olympic sport.

text: MORTGAGE rates are very low, but some people who could qualify for cheap refinancing are procrastinating. That may be because shopping for a mortgage can make root canal surgery seem fun.

headline: To Obama, Republican Budget Plans Are ‘Snake Oil’

Ryan on Saturday, accusing the Republican ticket of seeking to cut trillions of dollars in taxes for the wealthy while raising taxes for the middle class and making deep cuts to programs that would benefit working Americans.

headline: Act Like a Writer
text: I think there is a natural curiosity that many people have when they hear about an actor writing fiction. While it’s not exactly comparable to proving a mathematical theorem (Danica McKellar, the girl from “The Wonder Years,” can boast about that feat), it does seem an unusual endeavor to some.

headline: Deluded Individualism
text: There is a curious passage early in Freud’s “Ego and the Id” where he remarks that the id behaves “as if” it were unconscious. The phrase is puzzling, but the meaning is clear: the id is the secret driver of our desires, the desires that animate our conscious life, but the ego does not recognize it as such. The ego — what we take to be our conscious, autonomous self — is ignorant to the agency of the id, and sees itself in the driver seat instead. Freud offers the following metaphor: the ego is like a man on horseback, struggling to contain the powerful beast beneath; to the extent that the ego succeeds in guiding this beast, it’s only by “transforming the id’s will into action as if it were its own.”

headline: ‘What Happened to Him?’
text: CHESAPEAKE, Va. — From the playgrounds of Richmond, Va., to the highest levels of international basketball, the exploits of Jonathan Hargett still resonate.

headline: Salmonella Outbreak in 20 States Kills 2 and Sickens 141
text: An outbreak of salmonella infections across 20 states has resulted in two deaths and sickened 141 people in recent weeks, state and federal authorities said.

headline: Landing in West Virginia, Dakich Checked the Exits
text: Soon after Dan Dakich took the basketball head coaching job at West Virginia in 2002, he sat down with a yellow legal pad and wrote a list of the issues facing the Mountaineers. It became so long and daunting that he decided it was too much. Eight days after he was hired, he walked away from what he said was a seven-year contract offer worth $3.5 million to return to his old job at Bowling Green, which pays $125,000 a year.

headline: In This Feast of Perfection, as Always, a Famine Lurks
text: Jim Palmer was preparing for a broadcast at Camden Yards last Wednesday when the scoreboard showed history unfolding in Seattle. Felix Hernandez, the Mariners’ ace, had reached the ninth inning of a perfect game, and Palmer, the Baltimore Orioles’ Hall of Fame right-hander, had to watch.

headline: Finding Dividends in Unusual Places
text: DIVIDEND seekers are in a bit of a quandary. As frightened investors have raced into defensive equities lately, traditional income-producing areas of the stock market have become fairly frothy.

headline: Both Campaigns Seize Role of Medicare Defender
text: THE VILLAGES, Fla. — After several days in which he mentioned only generalities on the campaign trail, Representative Paul D. Ryan sought on Saturday to play offense on Medicare, attacking in detail President Obama’s health care plan, seizing an issue that has the potential to be one of Mr. Ryan’s biggest liabilities in joining the Republican presidential ticket.

headline: Saturday on the Campaign Trail
text: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice presidential candidate, defended his plan to overhaul Medicare on Saturday in Florida. while President Obama campaigned in New Hampshire.

headline: Taliban Fighters Killed in Airstrike
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A coalition airstrike killed more than 20 Taliban insurgents after they had gathered to oversee a public execution in northeastern Afghanistan on Saturday, Afghan officials said.

headline: Remy Charlip, Dancer and Children’s Author, Dies at 83
text: Remy Charlip, a dancer, choreographer and founding member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company who dazzled avant-garde audiences for decades before finding an even larger audience writing and illustrating children’s books with titles like “Dress Up and Let’s Have a Party” and “Fortunately,” died on Tuesday in San Francisco. He was 83.

headline: Lining Up in Chicago, With Hopes of Gaining Legal Status
text: Young illegal immigrants discuss the impact of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program on their future.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 19
text: With Representative Paul D. Ryan joining the campaign trail this week, both campaigns have emissaries on the Sunday shows to weigh in on how the race is going — and where it will go from here.

headline: Passenger Is Shot in Livery Cab
text: A passenger in a livery cab was shot in the head early Saturday when a man held up the driver after the cab stopped at a traffic light in Brooklyn, according to the police.

headline: Mixed Signals in Darfur as Attacks Shadow Progress
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — It was a scene that seemed to belong to a different time, say, early 2004, when war was raging across Sudan’s vast desert region of Darfur. Hundreds of armed men — on horseback, camels, donkeys and in four-by-four trucks — some in street clothes, some in camouflage fatigues, swept into the Kassab displaced persons camp and began looting, burning, raping and shooting.

headline: NBC’s ‘Tonight Show’ Cuts Staff, and Jay Leno Takes a Pay Cut
text: The NBC network on Friday instituted budget cuts at “The Tonight Show,” a television mainstay that has played home to Jack Paar, Johnny Carson and now Jay Leno.

text: ST. CLOUD, Minn.

headline: Thank You for Sharing. But Why at the Office?
text: LATELY I’ve been hearing a lot about 20-somethings who are too eager to tell all at work. Whether they are recounting their drunken exploits or their external job searches, their tendency to provide too much information is leaving many managers scratching their heads.

headline: U.S. Says Iraqis Are Helping Iran to Skirt Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama announced last month that he was barring a Baghdad bank from any dealings with the American banking system, it was a rare acknowledgment of a delicate problem facing the administration in a country that American troops just left: for months, Iraq has been helping Iran skirt economic sanctions imposed on Tehran because of its nuclear program.

headline: Listen Closely
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Easier heard than seen, the big theme in this Sunday puzzle from Freddie Cheng relies on audible puns. By subbing out one phonetic sound for another in a number of common phrases, Mr. Cheng has created a way to cleverly transform a clue like “Ultranationalism” into an answer that sounds like the title of an Arnold Schwarzenegger Christmas movie. So keep your ears open.

headline: Scoring Complaints Grow After Six-Way Tie in Russia

headline: The Robot Factory Future
text: A new generation of adaptive vision-equipped robotics is set to change manufacturing around the world. At a lettuce factory in California, robots pack boxes alongside human employees.

headline: From an Illness, a Calling
text: MY father practiced law in our hometown, Maplewood, N.J., and my mother took care of our family of six children. I was the fifth child, probably destined to follow my father into the legal profession. But at 13, I found a lump on my neck. At first, the doctors thought it was mumps or maybe a tooth infection, but after a biopsy, Hodgkin’s disease was diagnosed.

headline: In Inelastic South Carolina, Change Is Unlikely
text: Today we continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Today’s stop: South Carolina, the Palmetto State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Prof. Robert Oldendick and Associate Prof. Mark Tompkins, both of the political science department at the University of South Carolina.

headline: Skilled Work, Without the Worker
text: DRACHTEN, the Netherlands — At the Philips Electronics factory on the coast of China, hundreds of workers use their hands and specialized tools to assemble electric shavers. That is the old way.

headline: Von Freeman, Fiery Tenor Saxophonist, Dies at 88
text: Von Freeman, who was considered one of the finest tenor saxophonists in jazz but attained wide fame only late in life, died on Aug. 11 in Chicago. He was 88.

headline: Phyllis Thaxter, Actress Who Played Superman’s Mother, Dies at 92
text: Phyllis Thaxter, an actress who got her start in Hollywood in a war movie during World War II, overcame polio while pregnant and then carved out a long acting career that led to her final film role, as Superman’s mother, died on Tuesday in Longwood, Fla. She was 92.

headline: Sabathia Says He Feels Good After Bullpen Session
text: C. C. Sabathia threw about 23 pitches in the bullpen Saturday and afterward had an unequivocal declaration about his next outing.

headline: For Romney, a Lucrative Weekend Raising Money
text: With President Obama campaigning in New Hampshire on Saturday and Representative Paul D. Ryan courting voters in Florida, which battleground state did Mitt Romney have on his weekend itinerary?

headline: Karl Fleming, Journalist Who Covered Civil Rights Era, Dies at 84

headline: Milton Bassin Dies at 88; Expanded York College

He was 88 and lived in Somers, N.Y.

headline: Saving the Prairie, and Planting Some New Ones
text: HOUSTON — Just south of here, past the oil refineries and wedged between two housing subdivisions, is one of the most endangered ecosystems on the planet — a coastal prairie.

headline: Jackson Bend in Accident
text: The multiple Grade I winner Jackson Bend was involved in a mishap Saturday morning on a training track at Saratoga Race Course in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., but he appeared to have sustained no serious injuries.

headline: ‘Double’ Turns the iPad Into a Telepresence Robot
text: In late 2010 I had the opportunity to be a robot for a few weeks with a telepresence robot called the Texai, made by Willow Garage. I zipped around The New York Times’s newsroom and attended meetings from completely different locations.

headline: Restaurant Manager Is Shot to Death in Queens
text: A gunman walked up behind the manager of a restaurant in Queens on Friday night and shot him fatally in the head, the police said.

headline: A Literary Hero, Keeping the Last Bookshop Alive
text: ARCHER CITY — On a recent Friday afternoon, the courthouse square in this tiny North Texas ranching community was packed with sleek Mercedes-Benzes and Lexuses that occupied spots usually left empty or taken by pickups. The drivers of these cars loaded boxes of books into trunks and back seats, and trucks hauling rig equipment slowed and stopped for people rushing across the street.

headline: Judge Raises New Questions About Facebook Advertising Tactic
text: A judge rejected Facebook’s settlement offer in response to a lawsuit that said the company violated California law by publicizing users’ “likes” of certain advertisers without paying them or giving them a way to opt out. Facebook’s advertising efforts face a new legal hurdle at a time when the social networking giant needs to increase revenue and convince investors of its long-term prospects.

headline: Djokovic, Humming Again, Will Meet Federer for a Title
text: MASON, Ohio — No medal was awarded, but Novak Djokovic earned a different sort of consolation Saturday with a hard-fought, 6-3, 6-2 victory against Juan Martín del Potro in the semifinals of the Western & Southern Open near Cincinnati.

headline: In Texas’ School District Financing, Factors are Hard to Compare
text: Canyon Independent School District did not set out to be one of the thriftiest in the state.

headline: Lester Offers Red Sox a Glimpse at What’s Been Missing
text: On July 22, Jon Lester allowed 11 runs in only four innings, hitting the low point in a career-worst season. Later, several Red Sox players were said to be angry with Manager Bobby Valentine for subjecting Lester to such humiliation, but Lester has never publicly complained about it. In fact, his only public reaction has been to put together some of his best starts of the season and show that maybe all is not lost for him and the Red Sox after all.

headline: Do Argentines Need Therapy? Pull Up a Couch
text: BUENOS AIRES — The cafe, just north of a leafy district affectionately nicknamed Villa Freud, was almost empty. Roberto Álvarez sipped his espresso, furrowed his brow and began ticking off the names of psychologists he had seen over the past decade. He stopped counting only when he noticed that he was running short of fingers.

headline: Sneaky Ways to Keep Conflicting Promises

headline: Lottery Numbers
Afghan Attacks on Allied Troops Prompt NATO to Shift Policy
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After months of military leaders’ attempts to tamp down worries over the killings of American and NATO troops by the Afghan forces serving beside them, Gen. John R. Allen, the top commander in Afghanistan, called an urgent meeting of his generals last Wednesday to address the escalating death toll.

headline: The Courtship Before Romney Elevated Ryan
text: It was supposed to be a 15-minute courtesy visit from a Republican with big presidential aspirations to a rising star in Congress with big ideas about how to address the nation’s fiscal problems.

headline: Support Grows in Germany for Vote on Giving Up Power to European Bloc
text: BERLIN — It has become the buzzword of the summer in Berlin: referendum. The foreign and finance ministers as well as opposition leaders have all come out in favor of allowing Germans to have a direct say in whether to give up more power to European Union institutions.

headline: Pinpointing Problem, Valentine Admits He’s Part of It
text: Bobby Valentine agreed with a lot of Red Sox fans and some of his own players before Saturday’s 4-1 victory against the Yankees: he hasn’t done a great job. In his first year as Boston’s manager, Valentine has been seen by some as a meddler who wanted to force change on a team full of established players.

headline: With Stellar Effort by Defense, Giants Expose Jets’ Flaws

headline: Mets Win Pitchers’ Duel With One Swing of Bat
text: WASHINGTON — Throughout the season, the Mets have bemoaned their relative lack of power, identifying it as a key reason they have had such a small margin for error each game.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: “Whatever be his politics, Ramdev knows how to work a crowd,” Revati Laul wrote in Tehelka magazine, as she described the scene at Delhi’s Ambedkar Stadium on the last day of the yoga teacher Baba Ramdev’s five-day public fast against graft and the governing Congress party. “Ramdev’s appeal is a strange mix of religiosity, television fame, rustic braggadocio and OBC aspiration,” she wrote, referring to the category of castes and communities known as “Other Backward Class.”

headline: Remixing Parental Objections Into Rap Lyrics
text: A few weeks ago, I was cruising down the freeway with my 14-year-old son, Nathaniel, and as always, he asked if he could listen to music. I said yes, and he slipped in a CD. Many times, when I am driving and he is listening to music, I tune out. But on this occasion, I was very tuned in — and horrified by what I heard.

headline: On a Bleak Holiday, Assad Makes a Display of Piety

headline: How to Investigate a Family Mystery
text: PARIS — Almost a year ago, while covering news on the Spanish island of Majorca, I entered a cramped notions shop named Angela that had been in the Aguiló family for centuries. One of the relatives led me upstairs to show an elaborate family tree with 560 names in tidy black and blue print that spanned 500 years.

headline: Preview: Red Bulls vs. Portland

headline: ‘The Expendables 2’ Proves Weaker Than the Original
text: Like their muscles, the box-office drawing power of Sylvester Stallone and his action-hero cohorts appears to be atrophying with age: “The Expendables 2,” with Mr. Stallone and a muscular ensemble, was the No. 1 movie in North America over the weekend. But its estimated $28.8 million in ticket sales was 21 percent lower than its series predecessor’s opening-weekend total, after accounting for inflation. Millennium Films spent about $90 million to make “The Expendables 2,” which was distributed by Lionsgate.

headline: Giuliani and Santorum Assail Biden for Virginia Speech

headline: In Apple’s Patent Case, Tech Shifts May Follow
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — This week, nine jurors are expected to hunker down in a federal courthouse here to decide a case that could change how the world’s smartphones and tablet computers look and work.

headline: Fortune Smiles on Toxic Terrain
text: “Money,” Martin Amis’s vibrantly dark 1985 novel, gave us a rollicking, repulsive picture of London and New York in the late 20th century, awash in cash, corruption, pornography, junk food, junk art, self-promotion and wretched excess of every imaginable variety. More than two and a half decades later that novel’s scabrous vision of a crude, rude world reeling from narcissism and acquisitiveness seems as potent as ever. Its hilariously awful hero, John Self, is an uncanny harbinger of the willful vulgarians who would gain even more ascendancies in the reality-show, greed-is-great era of the 21st century.

headline: William Windom, TV Everyman, Dies at 88

headline: Youthful Scores, Light and Dark, by Mozart and Schubert

headline: Indian Dance via Bollywood, by Way of Russia, Near Wall Street
text: In February, as I stood in line to collect my visa to go to India, the man next to me said: “You’re interested in Indian dance? But then you have to go to Bombay.” He was referring to dance in Bollywood movies.

headline: Commands Both Martial and Marital
text: STRATFORD, Ontario — One of the signal pleasures of attending the Stratford Shakespeare Festival here is the opportunity it affords to sample the breadth and depth of Shakespeare’s work in just a few days: a history play on Wednesday, a comedy on Thursday, a late romance on Friday. To survey Shakespeare’s plays in such proximity is sometimes to be reminded how unsatisfying — or at least how limiting — these traditional classifications can be.

headline: 2 Killed in Small-Plane Crash on Long Island

headline: Candidate’s Comments on Rape Draw Criticism
text: 9:59 p.m. | Updated A more recent version of this story is available here.

headline: Korean Pop’s Singular Mélange
text: NEWARK — They waited patiently, several thousand of them, outside the Prudential Center here on Friday night. They were mostly young, a combination of futuristic cool and slightly awkward. The more extravagantly attired were beyond mere extravagance: shiny clothes in bold contrasting prints, hair dyed in colors known to no rainbow.

headline: Sudanese Official Among 32 Killed in Plane Crash
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — An airplane carrying a Sudanese cabinet minister and 31 others crashed on Sunday in a mountainous region in the south, killing everyone on board, the state-run Sudan Radio reported.

headline: Auspicious Blessings
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — If today’s puzzle by Robert Cirillo were a food, it would be a fortune cookie: it’s light, easy to crack and contains an auspicious message. Sorry, no lucky numbers included, but the Powerball drawing is already over.

headline: Creative Hubris, as Ephemeral as Sea Foam
text: In the annals of things that have turned up on the shore in Rockaway Beach in Queens, haircuts and bowling are probably not unheard-of. But rarely are they as artistically minded as what Dustin Yellin prepared.

headline: Madonna Supports Russian Punk Band
text: Madonna has joined a group of celebrities protesting a two-year prison sentence in Moscow for three women from the Russian punk group Pussy Riot over a protest against President Vladimir V. Putin, according to Reuters. Madonna said in a statement that the sentence was “too harsh and in fact is inhumane.” “They’ve spent enough time in jail,” she said. “I call on all of Russia to let Pussy Riot go free.” On Friday a judge declared the members of the band guilty of hooliganism. At a recent concert in Moscow Madonna, above, wore a black ski mask and had the punk band’s name scrawled on her back, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Nicki Minaj Cancels Appearance
text: Nicki Minaj canceled her appearances at the V Festival in Britain because of damage to her vocal cords, The Associated Press reported. A representative for Ms. Minaj said that she had to back out of her shows on Saturday and Sunday because of “strained vocal cords.” She performed at a free concert last week in New York that also featured Drake, Lil Wayne and Foxy Brown.

headline: Bomb Wounds Iraqi Sunni Cleric Who Urged Cooperation With Shiites
text: BAGHDAD — An influential Sunni cleric was critically wounded and four of his bodyguards were killed when a bomb struck his convoy in western Baghdad on Sunday morning during one of the country’s most important holy days, according to Iraqi security officials.

headline: Museum to Hold Sachs Retrospective
text: The Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, will host “Looking for Love,” the first major New York retrospective of the independent filmmaker Ira Sachs, whose works have explored the lives of gay men. The program is to include a selection of shorts and all of Mr. Sach’s feature films, including “The Delta,” “Forty Shades of Blue” and “Married Life.” His latest film, “Keep the Lights On,” about a man and his drug-addicted boyfriend (with Thure Lindhardt, above left, and Zachary Booth), had its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival in January and opens theatrically on Sept. 7.

headline: From Gossip to Musical Theater
text: The celebrity blogger and gossip columnist Perez Hilton will make his New York theater debut next month when he joins the cast of the Off Broadway revue “Newsical the Musical: End of the World Edition,” a show that riffs on headlines. During his four-week engagement Mr. Hilton will perform a number written about him by Rick Crom, the show’s composer and lyricist. Mr. Hilton is to begin performances on Sept. 8 at the Kirk Theater in Clinton, with his opening night set for Sept. 17.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Theater Tickets on a Budget
text: Starting on Sept. 4 the Off Broadway Alliance will sponsor 20at20, a biannual event now in its sixth year, in which $20 cash-only tickets are made available for more than 30 Off Broadway plays and musicals starting 20 minutes before curtain. According to the alliance, a nonprofit group that supports Off Broadway theater, budget-conscious theatergoers with stamina and an empty Saturday calendar could spend $100 — less than one Broadway ticket — to see five shows: “Gazillion Bubble Show,” at 11 a.m.; “Avenue Q,” at 2:30 p.m.; “Sistas: The Musical,” at 4:30 p.m.; “Silence! The Musical,” at 8 p.m.; and “Fuerzabruta,” at 10.

headline: Bomber Kills 7 Officers in Russian Republic
text: MOSCOW — A suicide bomber killed seven police officers who were attending the funeral of a slain colleague on Sunday morning in Ingushetia, a predominantly Muslim republic in the North Caucasus where Russia has long struggled to suppress a separatist insurgency.

headline: Nascar Seeks to Woo Latinos With Fox Deportes Agreement
text: Nascar dads and Hispanics could be seen as being on opposite sides of the political fence, but that has not stopped Nascar from reaching an agreement with Fox Deportes, the Spanish-language cable sports channel, to broadcast 15 races starting in February.

headline: CME Is Said to Plan Derivative Exchange in Europe
text: The CME Group is planning to start a European derivatives exchange, in a significant expansion of the American market operator’s global footprint, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

headline: 2 Die in Libya as Car Bombs Strike Capital
text: CAIRO — At least two people were killed when car bombs exploded on Sunday outside security buildings in Libya’s capital, Tripoli. The blasts appeared to be the first deadly car bombings in Tripoli since the fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi nearly a year ago, and the latest in a string of violent episodes that have shaken several Libyan cities in recent weeks.

headline: Before the G.O.P. Convention, a Romney To-Do List
text: In a week, Republicans will gather in Tampa, Fla., where they will nominate Mitt Romney as their best hope to retake the White House from President Obama.

headline: Brent Grulke, a Builder of South by Southwest Fest, Dies at 51
text: Brent Grulke, who was instrumental in transforming South by Southwest, the annual music festival in Austin, Tex., from a regional event into a sprawling, sought-after and blissfully loud proving ground for musicians from around the world, died on Aug. 13 in Austin. He was 51.

headline: 50 Shades Widens Romance
text: Bookstores, authors and publishers are reaping the benefits of EL James’ increasingly popular erotic trilogy, “50 Shades of Grey.”

headline: 7 Weeks Into Connecticut Nursing Home Strike, the Accusations Fly
text: WESTPORT, Conn. — For the past 15 years, Paulette Clergy has washed, fed, dressed and joked with the nursing home residents at the Westport Health Care Center. The workers and residents, she said, often seemed like one big family.

headline: Retreat for Mind and Body Celebrates Its Past
text: The future of the Esalen Institute is under debate as the organization prepares for its 50th anniversary.

headline: Mets Wrap Up Rough Trip With a Disheartening Loss to the Nationals
text: WASHINGTON — The good news for the Mets is that the competition gets easier from here, at least for a spell.

headline: Journalists Dancing on the Edge of Truth
text: Before writing this column on recent incidents of plagiarism and fabrication, I spent time on the Web reading all known thought on the subject, making notes as I went. When I wrote it up, I used those notes to help create something I am now claiming as my own. Yes, I made phone calls to relevant experts and did historical research, but in the main — columnists are in part human aggregators — everything written here reflects something that came before it.
