headline: Do Prosecutors Have Too Much Power?
text: When one party decides whether to bring charges, what charges to bring and whether to offer a plea bargain, is the justice system lacking checks and balances?

headline: Of Age and Love
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Midst of a Drought, Keeping Traffic Moving on the Mississippi
text: ABOARD THE DREDGE POTTER, on the Mississippi River — This ship is making sure that the Big River, shrinking under one of the worst droughts in modern history, stays deep enough.

headline: Fabled Spiritual Retreat Debates Its Future
text: BIG SUR, Calif. — At twilight, not far from a cliff overlooking the Pacific Ocean, a Mayan shaman spoke of the return of Kukulkan to dozens of listeners sitting on the floor inside a yurt: As Venus, a planet of special significance to the ancient Mayans, passed directly between the Sun and Earth in June, the forces out there were heralding the return of Kukulkan, the snake deity, and the start of a new age of spiritual enlightenment in 2012.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Chicago Fed National Activity Index for July (Monday); existing home sales for July and Federal Open Market Committee minutes for August meeting (Wednesday); new home sales for July and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); durable goods orders for July (Friday).

headline: Testing What We Think We Know
text: Hanover, N.H.

headline: A Yankees Lifer in Nascar Land
text: CONCORD, N.C. — With 10 championships and 206 victories in 29 seasons of racing, Hendrick Motorsports is sometimes called the Yankees of Nascar. And now that Hendrick has a Yankees lifer on its staff, it would be hard to argue the point.

headline: It’s Not About Assange
text: ECUADOR’S decision to grant asylum to Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks wanted in Sweden for questioning over claims of rape and sexual molestation, has put the country in a political standoff with Britain, where he is holed up in the Ecuadorean Embassy.

headline: Don’t Fear All Islamists, Fear Salafis
text: Washington

headline: A Studio-Theater Venture Aims to Fill Gaps
text: LOS ANGELES — Studios make and release movies. Theater chains put them on screens.

headline: Akin Comments Could Swing Missouri Senate Race
text: In my review of Senate races last week, I classified Representative Todd Akin of Missouri, who won the Republican primary earlier this month, as a very slight favorite over the Democratic incumbent in the state, Claire McCaskill.

headline: After Failed Identity Change, Peanut Chews Reclaims Its Goldenberg’s Roots
text: NINE years ago the candy company Just Born purchased Goldenberg’s Peanut Chews, the Philadelphia candy bar introduced in 1917 as a World War I ration, with plans to transform what had been a popular regional treat into a national brand.

headline: On a Corner Plagued by Violence, Rallying to Say Enough Is Enough
text: Shortly before 11 p.m., as some community residents prepare for an anti-violence rally on a nearby corner, Anthony Caminero stood alone in the darkness of the playground across the street, pushing his 2-year-old son on a swing.

headline: Media Companies, Seeing Profit Slip, Push Into Education
text: LOS ANGELES — As another academic year starts, about 500,000 children across the country will find themselves learning subjects like middle school history or high school biology from a new line of digital textbooks. These manuals, branded Techbooks, come with all the Internet frills: video, virtual labs, downloadable content.

headline: The Trains’ Letters Are Correct. The Colors? Well ...
text: Subway riders in New York navigate by a combination of rote and conditioned reflexes — making the correct turns, choosing the right platform and (except on rare, embarrassing occasions) jumping on the right train without much thought.

headline: Student Contest Winner | A Staged Drowning
text: All summer long you’ve selected articles from the far corners of The Times for your comments, and this week was no different. Syria, Mars, the Olympics, Chick-fil-A, bird flu, sexual harassment, AIDS, military hazing, electrical blackouts — the topics you wrote about for this week’s contest were varied and unpredictable, and as usual, we had a hard time choosing our favorites.

headline: Five Ways to Plan for the School Year (While We’re on Vacation This Week)
text: We’re taking a break this week, both to get ready for the new school year and to indulge in summer pleasures while we still can. (Deep fried butter on a stick, anyone?) We hope you’re doing the same.

headline: In Picking Ryan, Romney Makes an All-In Move
text: The past five Republican vice-presidential candidates have all been quite conservative. But the four who preceded Representative Paul D. Ryan also had other strengths — and they were usually chosen in the hope of balancing out some perceived deficiency at the top of the ticket.

headline: An Unserious Man
text: Mitt Romney’s choice of Paul Ryan as his running mate led to a wave of pundit accolades. Now, declared writer after writer, we’re going to have a real debate about the nation’s fiscal future. This was predictable: never mind the Tea Party, Mr. Ryan’s true constituency is the commentariat, which years ago decided that he was the Honest, Serious Conservative, whose proposals deserve respect even if you don’t like him.

headline: To Survive, a Catholic School Retools for a Wealthier Market
text: Catholic schools have been bleeding enrollment and money for years, and many have been forced to close. But some, like St. Stephen of Hungary, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, have found a way to thrive — attracting a more affluent clientele by offering services and classes more commonly found in expensive private schools.

headline: Secrets Learned in Apple-Samsung Trial
text: When companies go to trial, as Apple and Samsung have learned, the public gets to hear corporate secrets. Among those revealed:

headline: Beachfront Beauty
text: Creative Time, the public arts organization, organized a sand castle building contest on Rockaway Beach, Queens.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Coming Next: Using an App as Prescribed
text: Before long, your doctor may be telling you to download two apps and call her in the morning.

headline: Merits of a Power Line From Quebec Are Debated
text: On paper, the proposal looks fairly straightforward: a 330-mile underground power line that would carry electricity generated by hydropower in Quebec, one of the cheapest power markets in North America, to New York City, one of the most expensive.

headline: Ramadan in Murfreesboro
text: Id al-Fitr — the end of Ramadan’s monthlong fasting and sacrifice — has turned out to be an especially joyous holiday for the Islamic American community of Murfreesboro, Tenn. Hundreds of worshipers were finally able to occupy their new suburban mosque this month, prevailing in their constitutional right after a two-year assault of bigotry, persistent court challenges, arson and a bomb threat at the construction site.

headline: What Happened to Homeowners Seeking Help
text: One of four homeowners who applied for mortgage modifications have received help.

headline: Condé Nast Invests in Digital Advertising Company Flite
text: Condé Nast, the high-end magazine publisher, will announce on Monday that it is joining the cloud.

headline: Get Antibiotics Off the Farm
text: Earlier this month, a federal magistrate judge in New York told the Food and Drug Administration to quit dillydallying on its three-decade effort to curb indiscriminate use of antibiotics in farm animals to spur their growth. He set a timetable for the agency to follow in withdrawing two important drugs — penicillin and two forms of tetracycline — from widespread use in animals. The trouble is, that timetable will give the F.D.A. five more years to complete the process.

headline: Judicial Elections and the Bottom Line
text: This year, 32 states will be holding contested elections or retention votes for judges on their highest courts. An ideological battle in Florida, an expensive and partisan one in North Carolina and others are providing uncomfortable lessons about why judges on the highest courts should be appointed rather than elected. Elections turn judges into politicians, and the need to raise money to finance ever more expensive campaigns makes the judiciary more vulnerable to improper influence by donors.

headline: In Dieppe, Remembering the Fallen
text: More than 2,000 people descended on Dieppe, France, on Sunday to commemorate one of the bloodiest days of World War II.

headline: A Day for Canada’s Fallen in a Lesser-Known Battle
text: DIEPPE, France — The beaches of Normandy, for most, evoke images of D-Day, the Allied invasion that set the path to victory over Germany.

headline: In Sliver of Old U.S.S.R., Hot Soccer Team Is Virtual State Secret
text: TIRASPOL, Moldova — It is a soccer club that few have heard of, from a corner of the former Soviet empire even fewer could easily locate: F.C. Sheriff Tiraspol, champions of Transnistria. The club was started by a former K.G.B. agent, and it plays in a place where smuggling is rampant and statues of Lenin still stand revered.

headline: Robo Redux
text: Each day in Civil Court in Brooklyn, Judge Noach Dear presides over as many as 100 credit card collection cases, a scene repeated day in and day out in courtrooms across the country.

headline: Cautious Moves on Foreclosures Haunting Obama
text: WASHINGTON — After inheriting the worst economic downturn since the Great Depression, President Obama poured vast amounts of money into efforts to stabilize the financial system, rescue the auto industry and revive the economy.

headline: Senate Candidate Provokes Ire With ‘Legitimate Rape’ Comment
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — In an effort to explain his stance on abortion, Representative Todd Akin, the Republican Senate nominee from Missouri, provoked ire across the political spectrum on Sunday by saying that in instances of what he called “legitimate rape,” women’s bodies somehow blocked an unwanted pregnancy.

headline: A Media Personality, Suffering a Blow to His Image, Ponders a Lesson
text: When Lynda and Stewart Resnick, the Beverly Hills entrepreneurs who founded POM Wonderful, wanted to host a dinner at their Aspen home in 2006 to talk about the Iraq war, they assembled a list of 22 A-list guests, including Queen Noor of Jordan, George Soros, the financier, and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California.

headline: Yankees Keep Teixeira on Bench to Rest Wrist
text: First baseman Mark Teixeira was held out of the Yankees’ lineup Sunday for a third straight game to rest a sore left wrist, raising concerns that a cortisone shot he received two weeks ago to reduce inflammation did not work.

headline: Minor League Player Closes In on Record for Steals in Season
text: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — Fewer than 200 fans turned out at Joe Davis Stadium, the home of the Southern League Huntsville Stars, on a stifling night earlier this month in this town in the Appalachian foothills, where the next generation of rocket engines are being designed at the nearby NASA Marshall Space Flight Center. Huntsville’s engineers were missing their chance to witness jet propulsion and escape velocity in person, in the guise of the visiting shortstop.

headline: The TV Watch Abroad
text: Alessandra Stanley, the chief television critic of The New York Times, is going abroad to watch foreign television this year.

headline: Ramadan TV Gently Pushes Saudi Boundaries
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Women are driving in Saudi Arabia.

headline: China Defers Death Penalty for Disgraced Official’s Wife
text: BEIJING — A Chinese court on Monday handed Gu Kailai, the wife of a disgraced Communist Party leader, a suspended death sentence for killing a British business associate who she reportedly feared was plotting to harm her son. In the Chinese legal system, such a sentence is tantamount to life in prison.

headline: Best Buy Names Hospitality Executive as New Chief
text: Aug. 20, 7:59 a.m. | Updated

headline: Simon P. Gourdine, Pioneer in Sports Management, Dies at 72
text: Simon P. Gourdine, who became the highest-ranking black executive in professional sports in the 1970s when he was named the N.B.A.’s deputy commissioner and who later served as executive director of the league’s players union, died Thursday in Englewood, N.J. He was 72.

headline: Veiled Anchors, Koranic Contests and Racy Romance
text: The disruptions of the Arab Spring shattered normal life in the Middle East — and make-believe. But television producers are resilient. Egyptian TV had dozens of new series during Ramadan. Syria’s output has been devastated by the conflict there, but the country still has several new dramas. Here are some regional offerings.

headline: Making the Final Miles Count the Most
text: VAIL, Colo. — Davis Phinney, the former Colorado cycling star, says Greg LeMond’s eight-second victory over Laurent Fignon in the 1989 Tour de France was the impetus for moving the individual time trial of this week’s USA Pro Challenge to the final day in Denver on Sunday.

headline: Yanks’ Insurance Policy Has a Premium Outing
text: The decision by Hiroki Kuroda to sign as a free agent with the Yankees, instead of the Boston Red Sox, was a minor postscript to the story lines for both teams this off-season. Kuroda, now 37, who had pitched five solid but unremarkable seasons for the Los Angeles Dodgers, was perceived as an insurance arm, a back-of-the-rotation commodity. Anything more might be asking too much.

headline: Charging Hard From the Comfort of a Quiet Corner
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — It’s more of a closet than an office — four walls that offer a place to shuffle through a stack of Day-Glo silks that are laid out like Jackson Pollock canvasses. There’s a replay machine to watch race videos and a place to lie and close her eyes.

text: West Lebanon, N.H.

headline: Simmering Chinese Anger at Japan Is Now on the Boil
text: HONG KONG — In angry mass protests and subdued smaller gatherings, Chinese citizens have taken to the streets to protest the landing by Japanese activists on some barren islands that are claimed by both countries.

headline: Sustainable Innovation: Reducing Fashion’s Carbon Footprint
text: The colorful world of fashion has its dark sides, not least of which is its potential impact on the environment.

text: The day in sports included baseball on the major league diamonds and the little league diamonds.

headline: Aetna Agrees to Buy Coventry in $5.7 Billion Deal

headline: Romney Statement on Abortion Contradicts Ryan’s Earlier Stance
text: A campaign statement that neither Mitt Romney nor Representative Paul D. Ryan opposes abortion in rape cases contradicts Mr. Ryan’s earlier position on the issue.

headline: Beckett Struggles Against Jeter and Suzuki
text: This late in the season, there is no gray area for Josh Beckett, no room for excuses. He either has a great start or a bad one.

headline: India Asks Pakistan to Investigate Panic Tied to Northeast
text: India’s top security official on Sunday “called on the Pakistani government to investigate Indian claims that ‘elements based in Pakistan’ had orchestrated a fear-mongering misinformation campaign that helped set off last week’s nationwide panic among migrants from India’s northeastern states,” Jim Yardley wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Tony Scott, Director Versed in Action, Dies at 68
text: LOS ANGELES — Tony Scott, the director of exuberant action films including “Top Gun” and “Unstoppable” and a prolific producer of television shows and commercials in partnership with his older brother, Ridley Scott, died on Sunday after jumping from the Vincent Thomas Bridge into the Los Angeles Harbor. He was 68.

headline: Private Schools Open Doors to Kids From Low-Income Families
text: “Like many 6-year-olds, Pankaj Disht clams up when speaking to a stranger,” Gayatri Rangachari Shah wrote in The International Herald Tribune. “But since switching to a private school, he has become more open and says he enjoys school and has many friends.”

headline: What Happens in Patna, Stays in Patna?
text: When the travel writer Trevor Fishlock went to my hometown of Patna, a journalist greeted him by saying, “Welcome to hell.” A few days later, that particular journalist, who had been zealous in his defense of the freedom of the press, was beaten unconscious.

headline: Generals Meet to Study Afghan Violence
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, arrived in Afghanistan on Monday for discussions on the progress of the war, including an intensified wave of insider attacks by Afghan forces on NATO service members, even as New Zealand became the latest coalition partner to announce an accelerated troop withdrawal.

headline: China Defers Death Penalty for Disgraced Official’s Wife
text: BEIJING — A Chinese court on Monday handed Gu Kailai, the wife of a disgraced Communist Party leader, a suspended death sentence for killing a British business associate who she reportedly feared was plotting to harm her son. In the Chinese legal system, such a sentence is tantamount to life in prison.

headline: Indians Celebrate Id al-Fitr
text: Muslims offering prayers at Delhi’s Jama Masjid on Monday.

headline: Photographing Violence Against Women, Even in Norway
text: Correction appended | There is a reason that we rarely see photo essays of serious social problems from Norway.

headline: Petkovic Hoping Setbacks Will End at U.S. Open
text: NEW HAVEN — Late on a Sunday morning in New Haven, Andrea Petkovic chats with her fellow German and good friend Anna-Lena Groenefeld. The two laugh, Groenefeld’s eyes glued to her phone. Petkovic is buried into a plush leather couch, the sweat gone from her practice session and a zip-up hoodie keeping her warm.

headline: The Early Word: Hindsight
text: Today’s Times

headline: San Diego Chargers, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: San Diego Chargers General Manager A.J. Smith said it best: “We have lost our respect in the league and our credibility in the league. We were an elite team. You miss one year in the playoffs? O.K. You miss two? You deserve everything that’s being said about you.”

headline: Writing Off Poor Children
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: In Tuscany, a Mad Celebrant of Olive Oil
text: VICCHIO, Italy — When the Renaissance started around here on Giotto’s palette, back around 1300, olives had been oiling the works of Mediterranean civilizations for millennia. They symbolized peace, and a pleasant lunch.

headline: Ex-Dictator’s Daughter Nominated for South Korean Presidency
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A former dictator’s daughter who cited Queen Elizabeth I of Britain as her role model became the first serious female contender for South Korea’s presidency on Monday when she was chosen as the governing party’s candidate for the election in December.

headline: For Giants, Debate Over a Dunking
text: The Giants made an unusual media splash over the weekend with a video that punter Steve Weatherford made available on his Twitter feed and that was widely circulated.

headline: Child’s Play
text: When I left you back in March, it was with the tale of my agoraphobic honeymoon meltdown in Hawaii in 2006, where I was last seen curled atop a starchy bedspread watching reruns while my husband paced to and fro, wondering whether to call a psychiatrist or a divorce lawyer. Readers e-mailed me to inquire after my health. Did I ever shut off the TV? Did my husband leave me once we hit the Lower 48? And how did “Roseanne” end again?

headline: This Week in Small Business: Reinventing the Toilet
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: On the Trail With The Caucus
text: As we head toward the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., next week, The Caucus will spend the first part of this week on the road, traveling with Mitt Romney, starting in New Hampshire on Monday.

headline: Sweaty Lessons in the ‘True’ Cost of Construction
text: When my wife, Julia, and I arrived in Moab, Utah, to start our four-month internship building a straw bale house, a party was raging in the backyard.

headline: Tip of the Week: Customizing iOS Notifications
text: Thanks to the Notifications settings, you can have an iPad, iPhone or iPod Touch get your attention when you have a calendar appointment, new e-mail messages or alerts from other apps. In iOS 5 and later, you can collect all the alerts from different apps in one place by dragging your finger down from the top of the screen to reveal the Notification Center screen.

headline: Merkel Facing a Frozen Conflict and Chilly Diplomacy
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has her hands full this week: Moldova, France and Greece. But what can she promise any of them?

headline: For the ‘21’ Club, a Potentially Significant Renovation
text: All summer long, workers have been toiling on a down-to-the-studs rebuilding of the private dining rooms of the venerable “21” Club.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Myanmar to Curb Censorship of Media
text: BANGKOK — The government of Myanmar said on Monday that it would no longer censor private publications, a move that journalists described as a major step toward media freedom in a country where military governments have tried for decades to control the flow of information.

headline: Monday Reading: A Battle Plan for Jet Lag
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: An Escape at the Nail Salon
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Barnes & Noble to Offer the Nook in Britain
text: Barnes & Noble, making a long-awaited international push, will sell its Nook e-readers and e-books in Britain for the first time beginning in October, the company said on Monday.

headline: Are Alternative Weeklies Toast?
text: Over the weekend, Rosie Gray, a former staffer at The Village Voice now at BuzzFeed, wrote that the men in charge of Village Voice Media had more or less the run the place into the ground. She pointed to staff layoffs on Friday at the newspaper, one more episode in a long stretch of downsizing at a publication that is part of a chain of weeklies.

headline: Daily Report: Apple-Samsung Decision Could Have Wide Impact
text: The Apple-Samsung patent trial is expected to wind down this week, and legal experts say a victory for either company could have broad implications for makers of smartphones and tablet computers, Nick Wingfield reports in Monday’s New York Times.

headline: Akin Comments Unlikely to Come Up at Romney-Ryan Event
text: GOFFSTOWN, N.H. — Mitt Romney’s campaign is expecting several thousand people to attend the town-hall-style meeting he’s holding with his running mate, Paul D. Ryan, here today.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Skirt Steak Files: Charlotte Druckman, whose book on women chefs, “Skirt Steak,” will be published in November, examines the lineup for the Grand Fooding festival next month in Brooklyn and runs some gender math: Of the 29 food industry participants in the dinners and other events taking place over five days, only two are women. Neither of those women is a chef. The festival is put together by Le Fooding, a French group that claims to offer a younger, fresher perspective on the restaurant scene. — Pete Wells

headline: After Antitrust Ruling, BAA to Sell a London Airport
text: LONDON – The British airport operator BAA agreed on Monday to sell Stansted Airport in London after the company decided not to challenge a court ruling on antitrust grounds.

headline: Kinder Morgan to Sell Assets to Tallgrass for $1.8 Billion
text: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners said on Monday that it had agreed to sell some pipeline and processing properties to Tallgrass Energy Partners for about $1.8 billion in cash, in the latest asset sale by the company in the wake of its takeover of the El Paso Corporation.

headline: Years After It Was Abolished, a City Board Lives On
text: The city’s Board of Estimate, an omnipotent body composed of the five borough presidents and three citywide elected officials, was gaveled to order for the last time on Aug. 27, 1990. But anybody who spends time delving into the city’s administrative code — there are people like this — knows that the board lives on in scores of references in the directory.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Restoring the Zakaria Brand, and Profiting in Textbooks
text: The multimedia career of Fareed Zakaria — CNN host, Time magazine and Washington Post columnist, public speaker — took a hit this month when he was found to have lifted entire passages from a New Yorker article for his Time magazine column. After a brief suspension, he will return to those outlets. But he tells Christine Haughney that he has been chastened by the experience: “Other things will have to go away. There’s got to be some stripping down.” To media critics, Mr. Zakaria is an example of how the personal brand now trumps the institutional brand, even of important outlets like Time and CNN. Still, even a widely successful personal brand can be overextended.

headline: How Instagram Could Have Cut a Better Deal
text: In hindsight, perhaps Instagram should have cut a different deal with Facebook.

headline: Leading Off: Get a Web Site for That!
text: On the heels of a report that an associate of the Giants’ Melky Cabrera tried to concoct a fake Web site so the outfielder could wiggle out of punishment for his positive test for performance-enhancing drugs, it is tempting to roll your eyes and toss him on the pile of sports’ most dismal cheaters. But he might really be on to something. Wouldn’t we all like to create a Web site to explain away a late car insurance payment or a forgotten anniversary. (Look, honey, cosmic-excuses.com says the Earth’s slowed rotation combined with global warming and the obesity epidemic means it’s really May 3. I’m not late!)

headline: The Battle Over 'Predator Teachers'

headline: A Low-Water Tour of the Mississippi River
text: ABOARD THE MOTOR VESSEL MISSISSIPPI, at Alton, Illinois — The big room was crowded on Friday with people who had gathered mainly to complain. It’s the annual low-water inspection tour, a summer ritual of the Mississippi River Commission, two weeks of travel and talk in which the panel that advises the Army Corps of Engineers on managing the mighty river and its tributaries speaks directly with the American people in their own towns, on their rivers. The tour was immortalized in a 1987 essay in The New Yorker by John McPhee titled “Atchafalaya.” That essay appeared in his wonderful 1990 book, “The Control of Nature.”

headline: Listing of a Brooklyn Home Ignites Blog Readers

They showed a leafy garden, a bright, open kitchen, the sleek retro finishes one might find in a Restoration Hardware catalog and a closet larger than many New York apartments. All those touches were drawn together with an asking price of $2.499 million.

headline: Sweet, Creamy Corn
text: The drought that much of the nation is experiencing this summer is expected to affect the price of milk and meat because of the feed corn that these commodities rely on. But interestingly, according to Bloomberg Businessweek, shoppers are not likely to see higher prices for corn on the cob because sweet corn is not as vulnerable to drought conditions. Corn on the cob that is sold in supermarkets is an irrigated crop, like other vegetables and fruits grown on large farms. However, smaller farms that sell their produce at farmers’ markets in drought-stricken areas are having a difficult time with their yields, so you may see a spike in prices there. The season for good, fresh sweet corn is such a short one that I will pay the price for it, just as I’ll spend money on heirloom tomatoes.

headline: Back from the U.S.S.R.
text: Twenty-one years ago, Russia’s future looked bleak. The country was still the U.S.S.R, and for a few years it seemed to be splitting apart at the seams even as it continued to resemble an unmovable monolith. The Soviet president, Mikhail Gorbachev, had relaxed censorship and lifted some restraints on private enterprise, unleashing a liberating force. But on Aug. 19, 1991, he was placed under house arrest, and a K.G.B.-led junta declared itself in charge. It seemed the Soviet flirtation with democracy was ending.

headline: First Look | The Freehand Miami Beach
text: When it opens in time for Art Basel Miami, the high-style hostel Freehand may be Miami Beach’s most unlikely scenester hideaway. And its developer, Andrew Zobler, the C.E.O. of Sydell Group (which owns the NoMad Hotel and brought the Ace Hotels to New York and Palm Springs), is betting that it’s a game changer in the hospitality business. He hired Roman & Williams, which designed the Ace New York, to create the interiors — colorful spaces, some with bunk beds, that look like a styled-out room at sleepaway camp. “Think seaside boathouse, lifeguard school, a homemade summer camp near the ocean,” says the designer Robin Standefer. Zobler, who traveled to hostels in the States and abroad and says he found that they “offered something lacking in many hotels — a culture where the guests were open to and often seeking out meaningful interactions with each other and where new friendships were being formed.” To that end, Freehand will have a vegetable garden, swimming pool, table tennis, bicycles and even art classes, as well as a restaurant and bar run by the folks behind local favorite Broken Shaker. And there will be towels, sheets, pillows and an amenity-stocked bathroom for every room — not always a given at hostels. As Standefer puts it, “it’s not a place with cheap beds to just crash in.” About 15 of the 60 rooms will be private (for one or two guests), while shared rooms will accommodate up to eight beds, with rates starting at about $50 for a bed in a shared room. Booking begins today.

headline: Close to Shore, Humpbacks Are Far From Safe

Finally he opens his jaw wide, takes a monstrous gulp and relaxes, breathing deeply at the water’s surface.

headline: A Concert for the Exiting Manhattan School of Music President
text: Robert Sirota is leaving as president of the Manhattan School of Music in October to devote all his time, according to the school, to composing. It so happens that his wife and two children are also professional musicians, so why not combine family and business in a concert farewell? Mr. Sirota’s wife, Victoria, an organist, and children, Jonah and Nadia – both violists – will join him for a performance of some of his chamber works on Sept. 13 at the school’s Borden Auditorium. Other musicians, including several of Manhattan’s staff members, will also take part. Two pieces will have their first performances: “Constellation,” for two violas, celeste and piano (that would be Mr. Sirota’s contribution) and “Twelve Days,” for six violas (as if there weren’t enough violas in Mr. Sirota’s life). Mr. Sirota has been president of Manhattan since 2005.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Paul Tough on How Obama’s Stance on Poverty Has Changed
text: Paul Tough, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover article on Roseland, a struggling section in Chicago where Barack Obama worked as a community organizer. Tough is the author of “Whatever It Takes: Geoffrey Canada’s Quest to Change Harlem and America.” His last article for the magazine was about schools focusing on students’ character as well as academic subjects like math or science. His new book, “How Children Succeed: Grit, Curiosity, and the Hidden Power of Character,” will come out on Sept. 4.

headline: Science Times Podcast
text: A man with an eye for sea creatures; a doctor’s journey to Antarctica; and surprising news about sleep.

headline: Tobacco: Uphill Battle for Antismoking Campaigns in Poor and Middle-Income Countries
text: Despite expensive antismoking campaigns, 41 percent of men in poor and middle-income countries still smoke and more young women are starting to, according to a major new survey of global tobacco use.

headline: Universal Golfage
text: American women achieved the right to vote in 1920. Swiss women had to wait another 51 years, until 1971. I was just a kid, and wasn’t really following the news. But I don’t think the  Swiss deserved praise for approving universal suffrage so late in the historical game.

headline: Phyllis Diller, 1917-2012
text: Ms. Diller, whose rapid-fire stand-up comedy helped open the door for two generations of funny women, died on Aug. 20 at 95.

headline: Emory University Acknowledges Incorrect Admissions Data
text: For more than a decade, Emory University has intentionally misreported the SAT and ACT scores of its enrolled students, the university acknowledged in a statement  on Friday after a three-month investigation:

headline: How to Make Summer Your Training Partner
text: Of course you know this summer has been just unbearably hot and humid in most of the country. Of course you are tired of hearing people whine about how hard it is to exercise in the heat.

headline: New Label Alert | Tanya Taylor
text: All week, T is introducing the lines to look out for this fall.

headline: A Planet ‘Just Right’ for Life? Perhaps, if It Exists
text: What ever happened to the Goldilocks planet?

headline: An Uncertain Planet
text: How many planets orbit Gliese 581?

headline: Examining the Ponzi Scheme Through the Mind of the Con Artist
text: Maybe “Ponzi scheme” should have its own spot in the Dewey Decimal System. Along with biographies of the schemers, a growing stack of scholarly references, legal tomes and articles aims to collect knowledge about this age-old crime.

headline: A Director Who Excelled in Excess
text: Tony Scott, who died on Sunday at 68, apparently from suicide, was one of the most influential film directors of the past 25 years, if also one of the most consistently and egregiously underloved by critics. One of the pop futurists of the contemporary blockbuster, he helped turn Tom Cruise into a megastar with the 1986 smash “Top Gun” and was instrumental in transforming Denzel Washington, over the course of five movies they made together — beginning with the locked-jaw masculinities of “Crimson Tide” (1995) and ending with the working-class heroics of “Unstoppable” (2010) — into a global brand. Mr. Scott made a lot of people rich and even more people happy with his enjoyably visceral work.

headline: TV Host and His Choice of Game Diminish Pleasure of the Hunt
text: Here is a conundrum. I would be delighted to have Randy Newberg come to my yard and shoot the deer, woodchucks and rabbits that eat everything in sight.

headline: Pineda Charged With Drunken Driving
text: Yankees pitcher Michael Pineda was arrested early Monday in Tampa, Fla., on a charge of driving under the influence of alcohol, a Tampa Police Department spokeswoman said.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Night of the Auk’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.I’m not sure how “Night of the Auk” went over when it opened on Broadway in 1956. But during its just-completed Fringe run it was turned into “Mystery Science Theater 3000,” and that seems just what it was born to be.

headline: The Making of a Thriller Writer
text: It was one of those arid summer days where you can see heat rippling from the pavement. Air-conditioning in the cranky Chevrolet up full blast. Kermit and the Muppets on the stereo singing about a rainbow.

headline: Myth About Rape and Pregnancy Is Not New
text: Last Updated, 12:22 a.m. Representative Todd Akin, the Republican Senate nominee from Missouri, gave new prominence to an old myth this past weekend when he downplayed the need for rape victims to have access to abortions. He claimed  that pregnancies from rape are “really rare,” because, “If it’s a legitimate rape, the female body has ways to try to shut that whole thing down.”

headline: For N.B.A. Owners, the Money’s on Romney
text: President Obama may have a better jump shot than his Republican rival for president, but N.B.A. owners seem more eager to offer Mitt Romney the bigger contract.

headline: New Parliament Is Convened in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Somalia convened a new federal Parliament on Monday, swearing in a new government to replace the internationally backed transitional federal government that has tried, with varying degrees of success, to assert control over the embattled country in recent years.

headline: A Whale, a Tag, a Mission
text: As I note in my article for Tuesday’s Times, humpback whales spend summer after summer just a stone’s throw from the coast of Massachusetts, yet scientists are still only beginning to learn fairly basic things about them. In our modern world of satellites and chips, it’s amazing how little we know about whales.

headline: Saint-Saëns’s English King Gets His Due
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — With relatively generous resources, lower overhead costs and experienced audiences, summer festivals can have an easier time than larger companies in presenting revelatory performances of operatic rarities.

headline: Endless Gray Zones for Thin Blue Line
text: Trolling the waters of international television, the online video purveyor Hulu has landed enough keepers — the British series “Rev.” and “Misfits,” the Israeli drama “Prisoners of War” — to make up for the clinkers, like “Little Mosque on the Prairie,” that should have been thrown back.

headline: Bending R&B Vocals
text: TREY SONGZ

headline: Being a Comic Nerd Is Right on the Money
text: LOS ANGELES — For a guy whose career is built around being a nerd, the comic Chris Hardwick does not fit the stereotype. He’s good-looking, has a girlfriend who is a model and an actress, and is not socially awkward.

headline: At the Met, No Blockbuster This Time Around
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art exhibition “Schiaparelli and Prada: Impossible Conversations” wrapped up on Sunday with a total attendance of 339,838.

headline: For Bags Like These, Even a Campaign Plane Must Wait
text: GOFFSTOWN, N.H. — There are not a lot of things that could persuade a presidential candidate’s plane to delay its takeoff and return to the airport.

headline: Soros Acquires Stake in Manchester United
text: Manchester United, the English soccer team, began its season on Monday with a 1-0 loss to Everton. But Manchester United, the newly public company, has received a big thumbs up from one of the world’s most famous investors.

headline: Dueling Earwigs Gain an Edge in Asymmetry
text: Conventional thinking is that in nature, symmetrical looks are highly valued. Even humans are known to look for symmetry in mates, as a quick measure of fitness.

headline: New U.N. Envoy to Syria Offends Both Sides
text: Lakhdar Brahimi, the veteran Algerian diplomat, may have started on the wrong foot in his newly appointed role as the special Syria peace envoy for the United Nations and the Arab League. And technically he has not even started the job yet.

headline: Cave Enthusiasts Find an 8-Legged Outlier
text: The Bigfoot of spiders has been discovered in the caves of southwestern Oregon.

headline: After an Olympic Bounce for ‘Today,’ ‘G.M.A.’ Bounces Right Back
text: For one day after the Summer Olympics ended, NBC’s “Today” show was the No. 1 morning show on television.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Smashing Screens and Competitive Copying
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: For Plus-Size Men
text: Men who fit into the size range offered by most brands have Mr. Porter, Valetmag.com and GQ to look to for style inspiration. But where can plus-sized fashion-focused gentlemen go? Chubstr.com, a Web site founded by Bruce Sturgell in 2011. Mr. Sturgell said he saw few fashion platforms that catered to a more plump crowd. So he started Chubstr, an online style guide for men whose appreciation for fashion is as large as their waist size.

headline: In Congress’s Paralysis, a Mightier Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court does not always have the last word. Sure, its interpretation of the Constitution is the one that counts, and only a constitutional amendment can change things after the justices have acted in a constitutional case.

headline: Account of ‘a Lynch’ in Jerusalem on Facebook
text: As my colleague Isabel Kershner reports, several Israeli teenagers who appeared in court on Monday following their arrest for beating a young Palestinian unconscious expressed little remorse for the attack after a hearing.

headline: NBC Will Broadcast New Michael J. Fox Show
text: 7:26 p.m. | Updated The NBC network has won the bidding war for a new sitcom starring Michael J. Fox, the actor famous for his roles on “Family Ties” and “Spin City” and for his public battle with Parkinson’s disease.

headline: New Frontiers of Extremism
text: Republicans are frantically trying to get Representative Todd Akin to drop out of the United States Senate race in Missouri after his remark about abortion and rape, but not because it was offensive and ignorant. They’re afraid he might lose and cost them a chance at a Senate majority next year. He would surely be replaced by a Republican who sounds more reasonable but holds similarly extreme views on abortion, immigration, gay rights and the role of government because those are the kinds of candidates the party nominates these days in state after state.

headline: Avid Golfer Rice Jumps a Barrier Again
text: WASHINGTON — Condoleezza Rice has lived a life of firsts: first black woman to be Secretary of State, first black woman to be national security adviser and the first African-American, first woman and youngest person to be provost of Stanford University.

headline: Handcuffed Man’s Death Ruled a Suicide
text: The death of a 21-year-old man found with a gunshot wound to the head while he was handcuffed in the back of a police car has been ruled a suicide, the Arkansas medical examiner said.

headline: House Member Is Rebuked After Nude Swim in Israel
text: WASHINGTON — They came to town promising something new and different, a fresh reprieve from the antics and proclivities of a “Washington” they disdained.

headline: WikiLeaks and Free Speech
text: WE have spent our careers as filmmakers making the case that the news media in the United States often fail to inform Americans about the uglier actions of our own government. We therefore have been deeply grateful for the accomplishments of WikiLeaks, and applaud Ecuador’s decision to grant diplomatic asylum to its founder, Julian Assange, who is now living in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London.

headline: Crude, Dirty and Dangerous
text: EVERY day more than one million barrels of oil flow to refineries in the United States from western Canada’s oil sands region. Producers hope to quadruple that amount in the next decade, arguing that oil from a friendly neighbor will deliver an extra degree of national security.

headline: Drought Clogs Traffic on a Shrunken Mississippi
text: Low water levels caused the Coast Guard to periodically close an 11-mile section of the Mississippi River to ships this month.

text: Amid the Occupy Wall Street and Tea Party movements, bus tours with illegal immigrants and nuns and jailed activists in Russia, what constitutes a successful protest?

text: To the Editor:

headline: Drive-Through Adventure Will End at Wildlife Park
text: For almost four decades, the animals of Six Flags Wild Safari have been a common denominator in countless family yarns. The time the monkey rode on top of the car. The giraffe that poked his head through the open window. The brown bear that posed for a picture with a baby hanging out the window beside it.

headline: Now Job Candidates Treat Travel Policy as a Negotiating Point
text: DID you know that one of the things that some job seekers are now negotiating is to what extent they will be exempt from strict corporate travel policies about what can and cannot be expensed on the road? I had no idea, but as soon as I heard, it made sense.

headline: Flying Through a Storm Cloud, and Into Another
text: BECAUSE of my job in hospitality, I’ve been traveling extensively for the past 40 years.

headline: Christian Girl’s Blasphemy Arrest Incites a Furor in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The arrest and imprisonment of a Christian girl accused of violating Pakistan’s blasphemy laws stoked a public furor on Monday, renewing international scrutiny of growing intolerance toward minorities in the country.

headline: Good Grade for Mayor; Regret Over His 3rd Term
text: New Yorkers are having second thoughts about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s third term.

headline: Rep. Todd Akin: The Statement and the Reaction
text: The sequence of events after Representative Todd Akin, Republican of Missouri, commented to a St. Louis television station on pregnancy as a result of rape.

headline: A Channel on the Web Devoted to Shoes, for Those Who Can’t Get Enough
text: FASHION brands spend a lot of money and time to place their products in movies, dramas and reality television. Nine West, the mass-market shoe store chain, has decided to cut out the middleman and produce its own media.

headline: Players Like Camp Restrictions; The Rules Are Growing on Coaches
text: When the Giants co-owner John Mara first told Coach Tom Coughlin last year that the new collective bargaining agreement mandated a day off for players in the first week of training camp, Coughlin was confused. Does that mean they cannot come to meetings, Coughlin asked Mara. No meetings, he was told. A full day off.

headline: Scott McKenzie, Singer Known for ‘San Francisco,’ Dies at 73
text: Scott McKenzie, who performed the 1967 ballad “San Francisco (Be Sure to Wear Flowers in Your Hair),” which became a defining hit for the counterculture generation and helped draw tens of thousands to the Haight-Ashbury district for the Summer of Love, died on Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 73.

headline: Aboard a Tug, All Is Quiet but the Churn of the Motor
text: The kayakers and the pleasure boaters were gone, and the harbor was quiet. Off Staten Island, the Ellen McAllister, a red tugboat no more than a hundred feet long, prepared to disturb the waters.

headline: With Rule Shift, Restroom Hunt May Get Tougher
text: They are gently lighted and spacious and lined with pristine tiles. They are as cramped as Port-O-Lets, splashed with graffiti and redolent with urine. They can be found behind sliding barnlike doors, down rickety staircases, through fry cooks’ kitchens or, just as often, not at all.

headline: Investors in Health Care Seem to Bet on Incumbent
text: Who is going to win the presidential election?

headline: Judge Dismisses Whistle-Blower Suit Against Infosys
text: A federal judge in Alabama on Monday dismissed a lawsuit by an American employee of Infosys, the giant Indian outsourcing company, who claimed he was harassed and sidelined after he reported what he believed was visa fraud by managers there.

headline: Facebook’s Ambition Collides With Harsh Market
text: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Inside Facebook’s headquarters, a red-and-white poster affixed to a wall asks bluntly: “What Could Go Wrong?”

headline: With New Chief, Best Buy Tries to Set Its Own Turnaround
text: Best Buy, the struggling electronics retailer aiming to turn around its fortunes, announced Monday that it had hired the chief executive of the hospitality company Carlson as its new leader — a move that is likely to be the first of several disclosures the company plans to make to reassure investors.

headline: Regulator Says Broker Audits Fail to Include Required Work
text: The many auditors who inspect the financial statements of brokerage firms appear to be cutting corners and not doing all the work they should do, a worrisome sign after the collapse of the Peregrine Financial Group, a leading commodities brokerage firm, where a fraud had gone undetected for many years.

headline: In World of Finance, One New Member Has Already Driven the Green
text: After years of working her way to the highest levels of Wall Street, Darla Moore was still thinking about a dilapidated building known as the bean market in her hometown, Lake City, S.C.

headline: New York City’s Taxi Plan
text: In a sweeping ruling last week, Justice Arthur Engoron of State Supreme Court in Manhattan nullified New York City’s important plan to increase taxi service in the outer boroughs and northern Manhattan. By doing so, he knocked a $635 million hole in the city’s $68.5 billion budget.

headline: Women at Augusta
text: What a year this has been for women breaking barriers. Daw Aung San Suu Kyi took a seat in Myanmar’s Parliament. Saudi Arabia, Brunei and Qatar let women compete on their Olympic teams for the first time. And now another bastion of male authority and rigorous devotion to antiquated laws has heeded the call of equality.

headline: The Enemy Within
text: It’s bad enough when American and coalition troops in Afghanistan meet death at the hands of the Taliban. Now they are increasingly vulnerable to members of the Afghan Army and police — the very forces they are training to secure the country’s future. At least 40 NATO troops have been killed by their Afghan counterparts this year, including 10 American service members in one horrendous two-week stretch.

headline: Panama Canal’s Growth Prompts U.S. Ports to Expand
text: BALTIMORE — The four cranes rise grandly over the port here, 14 stories high. Just off the boat from China and now being prepared for operations, the $40 million machines are part of this city’s gamble that when supersize container ships start coming through the expanded Panama Canal in 2015, Baltimore will be one of the few ports on the East Coast ready for their business.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In China, Gu Kailai’s Reprieve Reinforces Cynicism
text: BEIJING — When it comes to patriotic blockbusters, synchronized military parades and choreographed political cavalcades that fill the Great Hall of the People, the Chinese Communist Party knows how to put on a show.

headline: Guide for the Perplexed
text: Let’s say you’re generally a moderate voter. You look at the Romney-Ryan ticket and see that they are much more conservative than you. They don’t believe in tax increases ever. You think tax increases have to be a part of a budget deal. They want to slash social spending to the bone. You think that would be harsh on the vulnerable and bad for social cohesion.

headline: Aug. 20: When the Polling Gets Weird
text: Monday brought a Monmouth University poll showing President Obama ahead by one point in the national race — the same margin that he had in the last poll they conducted in June. Mitt Romney held onto a 2-point lead in the Gallup national tracking poll, and pulled ahead of Mr. Obama again by one point in the Rasmussen national tracker, which has fluctuated a bit recently but usually has a steady number like that.

headline: Obama Threatens Force Against Syria
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama warned Syria on Monday that it would face American military intervention if there were signs that its arsenal of unconventional weapons was being moved or prepared for use. It was Mr. Obama’s first direct threat of force against Syria, as he has resisted being drawn into the bloody 18-month rebellion.

headline: Health Experts Dismiss Assertions on Rape
text: Representative Todd Akin’s assertion that women who are victims of “legitimate rape” rarely get pregnant provoked outrage across the political spectrum, but the views he articulated are far from new in anti-abortion circles.

headline: The Lions of Tawhid
text: The Times’s C.J. Chivers travels with an antigovernment fighting group in and near Aleppo, where the war for Syria’s future has hardened all involved.

headline: Principle Over Politics
text: Omaha

headline: The Day Augusta Said Ike Was Out of Order
text: Custom and ritual have ruled Augusta National Golf Club for 80 years, and chief among those traditions has been an iron-willed chairman with almost complete authority, an obsessive desire for secrecy and eccentric determination to be different.

headline: Romney Gains Huge Cash Advantage Over Obama
text: Mitt Romney’s cash advantage over President Obama and the Democrats more than doubled in July, as intense Republican fund-raising and heavy spending by Mr. Obama and his allies left Mr. Romney and the Republican National Committee with $62 million more in the bank than the Democrats at the end of last month.

headline: Wise Choice, Judge Says, Now Forfeit $4.7 Million
text: Roberta Campbell balked at closing on an $18.75 million co-op apartment on the Upper East Side in 2009 after an inspection turned up what she felt were some grievous shortcomings: missing cooktop grates, shower enclosures and a microwave; unfinished floors; and a lack of heat, hot water, gas and air-conditioning.

headline: 8 Subway Inspectors Charged With Filing False Reports
text: Eight subway signal inspectors were charged on Monday with falsifying reports to make it appear they had performed inspections that prosecutors said they had never actually done.

headline: The Mets’ Only First-Place Hope
text: The Mets returned to Citi Field on Monday for seven games in a row against the two worst teams in the National League. It might have been an opportunity to dive into the playoff hunt, but the pennant race has passed the Mets by.

headline: With the Rebels in the Battle for Aleppo
text: A group of Syrian rebels seeks to destroy the government and its better-equipped forces by most any means. Their collective confidence that they will prevail both bonds them together and informs their sense that this is their time.

headline: Center of Gravity
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, hello there! Did everyone have a nice week? I know I did. Many thanks to Tom Gaffney for nimbly holding down the fort and feeding the emus while I was away. Tom did a great job and has a bright future in emu wrangling.

headline: Stoudemire Is Eager to Display New Moves
text: Amar’e Stoudemire arrived in New York on Monday with nothing but praise for the Hall of Fame center Hakeem Olajuwon after working with him for two weeks at Olajuwon’s ranch in Katy, Tex.

headline: Life With Syria’s Rebels in a Cold and Cunning War
text: TAL RIFAAT, Syria — Abdul Hakim Yasin, the commander of a Syrian antigovernment fighting group, lurched his pickup truck to a stop inside the captured residential compound he uses as his guerrilla base.

headline: Amid Plans to Limit Him, Santana Faces an M.R.I.
text: Johan Santana began June by throwing the Mets’ first no-hitter. Since then, Santana has struggled mightily, and now, nearing the end of August, the Mets have done their best to manage his injuries and his expectations, leaving open the possibility of shutting him down for the rest of the season.

headline: Politico Reporter Removed From Akin Coverage After Tweets
text: As Representative Todd Akin struggled to stay in his Senate race in Missouri for his comments about how pregnancy cannot happen in cases of “legitimate” rape, one journalist fought to stay in the race to cover him.

headline: New Yorkers’ Views of the Mayor and the Police
text: In a new poll by The New York Times, New Yorkers are divided about whether the stop-and-frisk practice is acceptable or excessive.

headline: Jets Squelch Preseason Panic After Ugly Loss
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets’ offensive coordinator, Tony Sparano, says he wants to see touchdowns and smiles. He expects both to come eventually.

headline: ABC News Stumbles in Report on Tony Scott’s Suicide
text: ABC News appears to have stumbled on flawed reporting for the second time in a month.

headline: Phil Moriarty, Coach of Swimmers and Divers at Yale and Olympics, Dies at 98
text: Phil Moriarty, one of the nation’s most successful swimming and diving coaches and a legend at Yale, died on Saturday in Mystic, Conn. He was 98.

headline: Taking Quake Relief Effort Into Their Own Hands
text: After Iran’s official relief organizations were accused of not doing enough for earthquake survivors, young Iranians spontaneously organized their own effort to gather money and goods.

headline: Young Iranians Step Up With Their Own Quake Relief
text: VARZAGHAN, Iran — As their caravan of private cars drove north along the Tehran-Tabriz highway, following the five trucks they had filled up with relief goods for the victims of the deadly double earthquake that struck northern Iran this month, a group of young Iranians — a mix of hipsters, off-road motor club members and children of affluent families — felt like rebels with a cause.

headline: No End to Housing Bust in ‘Carpet Capital of the World’
text: DALTON, Ga. — It’s lemonade time here in a town that calls itself the carpet capital of the world.

headline: CNN Host Makes Most of Akin’s No-Show
text: When Representative Todd Akin abruptly cancelled an interview with Piers Morgan on Monday night, Mr. Morgan trotted out an empty chair instead.

headline: Scared Straight — Into the Voting Booth
text: It strikes me as funny that we call our political organizations “parties.” For most of us, elections and political parties are the antithesis of fun. It’s no wonder that many young people avoid them. As colleges around the country welcome hordes of students, and politicians feebly attempt to spark interest in the fall election, we should ask why.

headline: Release of Prank Video Upsetting to Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The sign above the entrance to the Giants’ locker room reads “NY Giants Championship Culture,” indicating that members of the defending Super Bowl champions are expected to conduct themselves as professionals at all times.

headline: Dom Mintoff, Fiery Proponent of Maltese Independence, Dies at 96
text: Dom Mintoff, a fiery postwar socialist leader of Malta who closed NATO bases, evicted British interests, courted China and Libya and even banned The Times of London to chart an independent course for his tiny Mediterranean island nation, died on Monday. He was 96.

headline: Free Online Course Will Rely on Multiple Sites
text: A group of online-learning ventures is collaborating on a new kind of free class to be offered this fall, known as a mechanical MOOC (for “massive open online course”), that will teach a computer-programming language by patching together existing resources from open-learning sites.

headline: Cast of ‘Assassins’ Revival to Reunite for Roundabout Benefit
text: The original Broadway cast of the Stephen Sondheim-John Weidman musical “Assassins” is reuniting for a one-night-only benefit for the Roundabout Theater Company. Directed by Joe Mantello, the event will take place on Dec. 3 at Studio 54, where the Roundabout production, also directed by Mr. Mantello, opened in 2004.

headline: Gene Tests in Yeast Aid Work on Cancer
text: People have been searching for new medicines for thousands of years, and yet we have barely explored the universe of possibilities. Recently chemists at the University of Bern in Switzerland tried to estimate how many promising molecules have yet to be tested. In June they published their best guess: over a million billion billion billion billion billion billion. Blindly testing those molecules one at a time is not practical, and most of them will turn out to be useless anyway. So many scientists are looking for strategies they can use to zero in more quickly on promising candidates.

headline: Corrections: August 21, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Needs a Story
text: Inside Facebook’s headquarters, a red-and-white poster affixed to a wall asks bluntly: “What Could Go Wrong?” Somini Sengupta, of The New York Times, reports that below, in black ink, someone has scrawled in tiny letters: “Everything.”

headline: An Irishman Gives Back in Brooklyn
text: Rory McIlroy hunched over the putt Monday, his eyes determined and fixed on the hole in the middle of the putting green.

headline: Paul Supporters to Rally in Tampa
text: While political conventions these days have a reputation for being overly scripted, next week’s Republican gathering in Tampa, Fla., could have one unpredictable element: a legion of Ron Paul supporters turning out, some of whom will be on the convention floor.

headline: A Look Inside China’s ‘Club Fed’
text: HONG KONG — A Chinese court has suspended Gu Kailai’s death sentence for the cyanide murder of a British businessman. But Ms. Gu, the wife of the disgraced Communist Party boss Bo Xilai, is headed for a long stretch in the can, the clink, the hoosegow, the pen, the joint, the slammer, the Big House.

headline: Nice Line for Jeter, but Yankees Waste It
text: CHICAGO — It was a game of bloated numbers in which a dozen pitchers surrendered 25 hits and 12 walks, while 3 hours and 44 minutes passed between the first pitch to the last. But by the end, the most important number was the one that is shrinking before the Yankees eyes.

headline: Judge Dismisses Whistle-Blower Suit Against Infosys
text: A federal judge in Alabama on Monday dismissed a lawsuit by an American employee of Infosys, the Indian outsourcing company, who claimed “he was harassed and sidelined after he reported what he believed was visa fraud by managers there,” Julia Preston wrote in The New York Times.

headline: The “Imaginary Line” that Divides India and Bangladesh
text: Borders are significant barriers only in the minds of those who have never walked across one. Anyone who does that learns that in most places there is no crack in the earth where one country ends and another begins.

headline: Prime Time for Paul Ryan’s Guru (the One Who’s Not Ayn Rand)
text: As Paul Ryan and Mitt Romney take the stage in Tampa next week, the ghost of an Austrian economist will be hovering above them with an uneasy smile on his face. Ryan has repeatedly suggested that many of his economic ideas were inspired by the work of Friedrich von Hayek, an awkwardly shy (and largely ignored) economist and philosopher who died in 1992. A few years ago, it was probably possible to fit every living Hayekian in a conference room. Regardless of what happens in November, that will no longer be the case.

headline: Shaping Foreign Policy
text: While pundits agree that this presidential election will likely turn on economic issues, the candidates have been busy demonstrating that they are capable in foreign policy.

headline: In Bangalore, Classrooms Turn Into Makeshift Homes
text: A classroom on the third floor of the humanities block of St. Joseph’s College in Bangalore now serves as a makeshift dormitory. Mattresses have been rolled out atop benches laid side by side and on the professors’ wooden podium, surrounded by duffel bags packed for an indefinite stay. Since Thursday, five girls from India’s northeastern states have made this space their home.

headline: Rocket Fire Damages Plane Used by Joint Chiefs Chairman
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Insurgents hiding outside the heavily fortified Bagram Air Base fired a pair of rockets early Tuesday that damaged the parked C-17 transport plane used by Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, American and Afghan officials said.

headline: Exploring Mitt Romney’s Taxes and Tax Plan
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: The Woodward Dream Cruise Rediscovers Its Strut
text: ROYAL OAK, Mich. — As the 18th annual Woodward Dream Cruise got under way on Saturday morning, I drove south on Woodward Avenue accompanied by my wife, Marlene, and son, Erik, in our 1955 Chevrolet Bel Air. Our immediate goal was a breakfast of sliders at the venerable Hunter House in Birmingham, a nutritionally suspect Dream Cruise tradition for the Stenquist clan.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Keeper Possibilities
text: I’m far from alone in playing in multiple fantasy leagues. I like all formats: A.L./N.L.-only, keeper, redraft, mixed, head-to-head, roto, Scoresheet and Strat-O-Matic. I’ve succeeded in most formats, and failed in the same, with this year being no different. In at least two of my keeper leagues, I’m already looking toward 2013, speculating on potential closers and looking to acquire guys that could be undervalued in next year’s drafts. Here’s a look at a handful (with statistics through Sunday’s games unless noted):

text: In Today’s Times

headline: Meles Zenawi, Prime Minister of Ethiopia, Dies at 57
text: Meles Zenawi, Ethiopia’s repressive prime minister, who lifted his country from the ruins of civil war and transformed it into one of Africa’s fastest-growing economies and one of the United States government’s closest African allies, died on Monday, state television reported. He was 57.

headline: Concerns About Al Qaeda in Syria Underscore Questions About Rebels
text: What is Al Qaeda doing in Syria?

headline: Steve Gleason’s Story
text: A game is just a game, but every once in a while, it transcends that.

headline: Tampa Bay Bucs, 2012 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit, who is previewing all 32 teams, turns his attention to the N.F.C. South this week, starting with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

headline: It’s Not Too Soon to Think About Crowdfunding
text: I have taken a real interest in equity crowdfunding and its potential impact on social entrepreneurs. One reason: I would have loved to have been able to take advantage of it when I was doing my initial financing of TerraCycle.  Had crowdfunding existed then, I would have been able to raise money faster, on better terms, and from a wider range of investors — all good things when it comes to financing a small business.

headline: Globalization and the Income Slowdown
text: Derek Thompson of The Atlantic offers a thoughtful response to our list of 14 potential causes of the great American income slowdown:

headline: A Conversation With: Chef Vikas Khanna
text: With temperatures high and the air sticky in most of the United States and India right now, the thought of eating a rich Indian meal has little appeal. But the Michelin-starred chef Vikas Khanna says that it is possible to enjoy the flavorful food India is known for without feeling weighed down.

headline: Glencore Holds Firm on Price for Xstrata
text: LONDON — Ivan Glasenberg, chief executive of the commodities trading company Glencore International, on Tuesday played down speculation that the company would pay a higher price for its proposed $30 billion takeover of the mining company Xstrata.

headline: Indian and Western Colleges Set Up Joint Study Programs
text: “As colleges and universities worldwide wait for India’s lawmakers to approve a bill granting full access to the country’s vast education market,” Vir Singh wrote in The International Herald Tribune, “some institutions are reaching Indian students through twinning programs.”

headline: Europe’s Cities: Gentrification or Ghettoization?
text: LONDON — The widening gap between haves and have-nots in debt-saddled Europe has sharpened a debate over whether the accelerating gentrification of its major cities is leading to the ghettoization of their urban poor.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Baby Boomers Urged to Get Hepatitis C Test
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Cardiologist Issues Alert on St. Jude Heart Device
text: A cardiologist who studies the safety of heart devices said surgeons should stop using a component sold by St. Jude Medical until more is known about the long-term safety of the device.

headline: A Set of Headphones Clever, Cool and Costly
text: Bowers & Wilkins, known for high design and high fidelity, has introduced lightweight folding headphones with a strikingly functional look.

headline: Best Buy’s Tough Earnings May Lift Schulze’s Hopes a Little
text: Best Buy may have a tough time fending off a takeover.

text: Grist: The drought has a hashtag: farmers are using Twitter to talk to consumers, and each other, about the weather and their woes. #drought12 — Emily Weinstein

headline: New Label Alert | Confezioni Crosby
text: All week, T is introducing the lines to look out for this fall.

headline: Head of ABC’s ‘This Week’ Is Leaving to Join PepsiCo
text: 9:57 a.m. | Updated ABC News will cover this presidential campaign without one of its veteran journalists. Jon Banner, executive producer of George Stephanopoulos’s Sunday morning public affairs show “This Week,” will leave ABC News for a job at PepsiCo.

headline: Indian Dance via Bollywood, by Way of Russia, Near Wall Street
text: The weeklong Downtown Dance Festival closed Friday in downtown New York with its annual “Erasing Borders” program of Indian dance, Alastair Macaulay wrote in The New York Times. Despite the Indo-American label, the organizers included countries other than India and the United States, he wrote.

headline: Obama and Romney Discuss Role of Faith in Their Lives
text: Religion is enough of a political minefield that President Obama and Mitt Romney have declined interviews with reporters about their faith. But they agreed to write answers to nine questions about their personal faith and the role of faith in public life posed to them by Cathedral Age, the magazine of the Washington National Cathedral.

headline: Akin Asks for ‘Forgiveness’ in New Ad
text: As part of his effort to keep his place on the November ballot, Representative Todd Akin, Republican of Missouri, released an ad Tuesday in which he asks for viewers’ forgiveness for his comments on Sunday about rape.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Akin’s Evolving Media Strategy, and Student Autonomy
text: In trying to calm the anger swirling over his comments about “legitimate rape” and whether rape can lead to pregnancy, Representative Todd Akin, the Republican candidate for Senate from Missouri, scheduled a prime-time appearance on CNN on Monday, but ultimately didn’t show up. The host who was stood up by Mr. Akin, Piers Morgan, made the most of the nonappearance, Brian Stelter writes, telling the audience: “You’re looking live at the empty chair that Todd Akin was supposed to be sitting in for a live, prime-time exclusive interview.” The camera was fixed on the empty chair during the show, which appeared in an inset box.

headline: Former White House Cybersecurity Official Joins Start-Up
text: In January, Sameer Bhalotra left his position as President Obama’s senior director for cybersecurity without discussing his next move.

headline: Barnes & Noble Narrows Its Losses as ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’ Lifts Sales
text: 7:5o p.m. | Updated Add another happy beneficiary of the publishing powerhouse “Fifty Shades of Grey”: Barnes & Noble.

headline: Comedian Rob Delaney Will Release Online Standup Special
text: Rob Delaney may not yet have the name recognition of comedians like Louis C. K., Aziz Ansari or Jim Gaffigan. But with the help of his large and loyal Internet following, he is hoping he can take a page from his accomplished industry colleagues, and start creating material for and selling it directly online.

headline: Official’s Lawsuit Claims Discrimination Against Men at U.S. Immigration Agency
text: A discrimination and retaliation lawsuit has embroiled the upper reaches of the federal government’s immigration enforcement agency, contributing to a sense of turmoil in a bureaucracy that has been suffering major labor conflicts between senior officials and employees.

headline: Obama to Focus on Education in Campaign Swing Through Ohio and Nevada
text: President Obama set off Tuesday on a two-day campaign swing through Ohio and Nevada, with plans to continue etching sharp differences with his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney – this time on education policy.

headline: Fantasy Football: Wide Receiver Primer
text: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

text: Whether Facebook has lost credibility with Wall Street. | The remarkable transformation of Apple.

headline: Image of the Day: August 21
text: A flock of pigeons flying past a boy in Mumbai.

headline: A Chance to Walk, or Talk, With the Animals
text: Haven’t you always wanted to brush a goat? You can do it, maybe, this fall at the Central Park Zoo. The zoo announced Tuesday that registration is open for its fall and winter educational programming, which includes classes, internships and the like for children as young as 2, as well as teenagers and adults. More info is available on the zoo’s Web site.

headline: Three Ways to Figure Out What Stuff You Should Keep
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: At a Book Party, Witches and a Wiccan Prayer Circle
text: A book party Sunday night in Manhattan attracted so many witches in New York City that as one attendee, Rhea Rivera, put it, “I felt like all the brooms were just suddenly descending.”

headline: Price Wars Seen Hurting Solar Sector in China
text: GUANGZHOU, China — China’s solar panel manufacturers, who dominate global sales with a two-thirds market share, are confronting growing trade and financial problems, a Chinese industry official acknowledged Tuesday, shortly before one of the industry’s largest companies, Trina Solar, announced weak results for the second quarter.

headline: Site to Be Seen | Hello La Mode
text: Start-ups, by nature, are something of a gamble. But the French entrepreneurs Eric Gagnaire, Thierry Sebba and Mathieu Bidart based their business model on eliminating one big risk. Customers of their new luxury e-commerce marketplace, Hello La Mode, won’t have to worry about clicking to buy that Chanel bag or Hermès tie because these items, and all that sell on the site, will have to pass a rigorous check for authenticity and quality by the site’s team of fashion experts.

headline: Bicycle Lanes Draw Wide Support Among New Yorkers, Survey Finds
text: Bicycle lanes may be little more than painted stripes on concrete, but in New York City, they have become the stuff of lawsuits, neighborhood squabbles and tense debates over the proper role of government.

headline: Business Day Live: Facebook and Apple
text: The Times’s daily business show looks at whether Facebook has lost credibility with Wall Street and the remarkable transformation of Apple. The video is available at nytimes.com/bits.

headline: The Winning Record of Prosecutors on Insider Trading
text: The conviction of the hedge fund manager Douglas F. Whitman brings the record of the United States attorney’s office for the Southern District of New York to 8-0 in insider trading cases that have gone to trial since the wide-ranging investigation came to light in October 2009. By any measure, that is quite an accomplishment, as prosecutors, led by Preet Bharara, have squared off against some very talented white-collar defense lawyers.

headline: For This Man-Child, the Thrill of the Chase Has Yet to Grow Old
text: Dax Shepard, the writer, co-director and star of the silly, occasionally amusing car chase comedy “Hit & Run,” isn’t the first actor to be defined by a signature television role. Like James Gandolfini’s Tony Soprano, Crosby Braverman, the California man-child Mr. Shepard plays on “Parenthood,” (53 episodes and counting), is so indelible that, like it or not, everything else Mr. Shepard does registers as a pallid reflection.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times poll is based on telephone interviews with 1,026 adult residents from throughout New York City conducted Aug. 10 to 15. The interviews were in English or Spanish.

headline: Fleishman Hillard and GMR Marketing Acquire Content Company
text: 1:54 p.m. | Updated Fleishman Hillard, a public relations company, and GMR Marketing announced on Tuesday that they have acquired Amos Content Group to create a new joint venture called Freshwire.

headline: Bettman, Fehr and the Idea of an Industry Growth Fund
text: The N.H.L. Players’ Association’s enhanced revenue-sharing plan may wind up going nowhere with Commissioner Gary Bettman and the owners — or perhaps enough owners of struggling teams, seeing a lifeline that the league’s current revenue-sharing scheme does not provide, will demand that parts of the players’ plan be accepted.

headline: Politics Be Dammed
text: DELHI — Last week an unlikely new tourist destination opened in Gujarat, western India. Since Narendra Modi, the state’s chief minister, proclaimed in a blog post, “Fantastic visual treat awaits you as Narmada Dam overflows!” nearly 150,000 people have gathered to watch the accumulated water flow over the partially completed Sardar Sarovar Dam on the Narmada River.

headline: Rolling Out a Smaller Barrel Sooner
text: THE indispensable ingredient in great whiskey is time: years of aging and mellowing in casks. But in the world of craft whiskey, a growing number of distillers are unwilling to wait that long.

headline: Leading Off: Augusta National Inches Forward
text: There were few emphatic high-fives. Not all that many huzzahs. The reaction to Condoleezza Rice and Darla Moore becoming the first female members of Augusta National Golf Club, the host of the Masters, was more along the lines of: “Eh, that’s nice. Is Ryan Tannehill really starting the season opener for the Dolphins?” It was not exactly Nobel Prize territory.

headline: Antenna Company Raises $12 Million From Bill Gates and Lux Capital
text: Intellectual Ventures may be best known for its huge archive of patents and its willingness to pursue lawsuits in defense of those patents, but it’s also a part-time incubator to promising start-ups.

headline: American to the Rind
text: They’ve been doing back flips at Beecher’s, the Seattle-based cheese company that has a shop, restaurant and cheesemaking room in New York: one of their entries won the gold at the annual meeting of the American Cheese Society earlier this month. Flagsheep, an aged mix of sheep’s and cow’s milk that comes from Seattle in tall 16-pound clothbound cylinders, beat out 1,710 other cheeses at the event in Raleigh, N.C. It has a richly grassy aroma and flavor, and a firm texture that suggests Cheddar. And what has the folks at Beecher’s especially proud is that it was made with pasteurized milks. (Pasteurization kills some beneficial bacteria that could enhance aging and the quality of the cheese.) “It’s a testament to the cheesemaking that a pasteurized cheese could win,” said Elena Santogade, the company’s lead cheesemonger.

headline: Romance With Chinese Characteristics
text: BEIJING — Dating is hard at the best of times. In China the stakes are high from the outset: the expectation is that it should lead to marriage; never mind love for love’s sake.
