headline: More Dessert for Park Slope
text: Du Jour, a new Brooklyn bakery, offers a collection of well-made cookies, muffins, scones, cupcakes, cakes, brioches, croissants and desserts like butterscotch pudding. The simple but inviting brick-walled space is a largely do-it-yourself project by T. J. Obias; his wife, Vera Tong Obias; and their partner, Tae Kyung, who did most of the design and construction. The couple (shown) are both pastry chefs who have worked in a number of New York restaurants, including Dovetail, Morimoto, Café Gray and Buddakan. “But we never worked together,” Mr. Obias said.

headline: A Journey Home, in Search of Himself
text: A decade or so ago, when I was more physically fit, an editor at Outside magazine called to ask if I’d be interested in a job. I hemmed and hawed, as the phrase goes, before saying no thanks. “If only,” I said, “you were called Inside magazine.”

headline: Sicilian Almonds With a Hint of Noir
text: Fat, buttery Marcona almonds have become the stars of the nibble bowl. But serious cooks, and those with sophisticated taste buds that welcome bitterness, might consider distinctive almonds from Sicily. These are dry in texture, not oily, slightly wrinkled and dense with assertive flavor, the go-to nut when you want to leave no doubt that there are almonds in that cake or those cookies. The finest, from a company called Caffè Sicilia, come from the area around Noto, a Baroque hill town in the island’s southeastern corner. The almonds are protected by Slow Food. Avola, just north of Noto, is also known for its pointy bittersweet almonds. They are often coated with sugar, for the classic Jordan almonds, known as dragées in France and favored in Europe for weddings and christenings.

headline: Grammy Nominations Special Moves to Nashville
text: The televised concert to announce nominees for the Grammy Awards will be held in Nashville this year, in a nod to the power of country music within the music industry, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Tuesday.

headline: Drop the Pasta, Dad, and No One Gets Hurt
text: THEY sit there, five little pasta shells, nestled in a shallow bath of melted butter and Parmesan: the remains of dinner for my toddler son and daughter. I cannot help myself. I reach over, grab the pink plastic bowl and scoop a bite into my mouth. At that moment, I realize something has gone terribly wrong.

headline: New York Film Festival Adds ‘Paperboy’ to Schedule
text: The New York Film Festival has added “The Paperboy,” a new film directed by Lee Daniels, to its coming roster, and with it a gala tribute to its star Nicole Kidman, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Tuesday.

headline: My Coffee, My Clutter
text: Carl Richards’ recent column on throwing away unnecessary stuff got me thinking of what items I could get rid of to declutter my house. I got an easy answer while searching through a kitchen drawer for some dog biscuits — and finding instead a bag overflowing with empty Starbucks coffee sacks.

headline: How Has Your Child’s Diet Changed Your Own?
text: Matt Richtel writes this week about how fatherhood has led to his dietary woes. He gathers tips from bloggers and nutrition experts about the best ways to keep healthy while making meals that include the occasional hot dog or bowl of buttered pasta — foods that are not cholesterol-friendly, but are beloved by children.

headline: Andy Milice’s Second Chance
text: By the summer of 1862, the Union Army was wearing thin, worn down by death, disease and the need to occupy extensive tracts of rebel territory. To make things worse, the Army’s one-year enlistments were about to expire, sending thousands of men home.

headline: Stenciled Relief for Forward Operating Base Monotony
text: While cruising a main drag in southern Afghanistan one night in late May, I spied a silhouetted Eazy-E eyeballing me from one of the Jersey barriers lining the sidewalk. I tried not to stare at his ball cap, shades, and twin-crossed pistols. About 20 feet later, there he was peering from another wall, and again 20 feet after that. He was everywhere.

headline: G.O.P. Approves Strict Anti-abortion Language in Party Platform
text: 5:35 p.m. | Updated Even as the Republican establishment continued to call for Representative Todd Akin of Missouri to drop out of his Senate race because of his comments on rape and abortion, Republicans approved platform language on Tuesday calling for a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion with no explicit exceptions for cases of rape or incest.

headline: S.E.C. Pays Out First Whistle-Blower Reward
text: Federal securities regulators said on Tuesday that they had handed out the first reward under a new whistle-blower program, paying nearly $50,000 to a person who helped the agency shut down an investment fraud.

headline: Wheelies: The Smoke on the Water Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Iran Unveils More Defense Projects
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s president unveiled an upgraded short-range missile and several new defense projects on Tuesday, saying the Islamic Republic needed new weapons and navigation systems in order to defend itself against foreign threats.

headline: Jay Leno Snipes at Comcast Over ‘Tonight Show’ Cutbacks
text: On Friday, the NBC network, part of Comcast, imposed budget cuts at “The Tonight Show,” which included layoffs of between 20 and 25 staff members. The host, Jay Leno, took a pay cut, according to a person with direct knowledge of the cuts, in order to limit the number of layoffs. On Monday, Mr. Leno joined the long line of late-night hosts who use the monologue to take aim at the boss: “As you may have heard, our parent company has downsized ‘The Tonight Show.’ And we’ve consistently been No. 1 in the ratings. And if you know anything about our network, that kind of thing is frowned upon.”

headline: Ignoring Deadline to Quit, G.O.P. Senate Candidate Defies His Party Leaders
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Todd Akin on Tuesday ignored a deadline to abandon Missouri’s Senate race and vowed to remain the Republican nominee in defiance of his party’s leaders, including the presidential standard-bearer, Mitt Romney.

headline: ABC Sees a Contender in Jimmy Kimmel
text: In 2002, ABC pulled out every stop to lure David Letterman away from CBS, offering him the time period occupied by its news program “Nightline.” The network failed, and soon after inserted a new late-night host, Jimmy Kimmel, in the hour after “Nightline.”

headline: Restoring Trust in the Futures Market
text: James E. Oliff is a member of the board of FFastFill and of the CME Group, where he previously served as vice chairman. Neal L. Wolkoff was formerly the chairman and chief executive of the American Stock Exchange, chief operating officer of the New York Mercantile Exchange and chief executive of ELX Futures.

headline: The G.O.P. Platform
text: Every four years the two parties draft new platforms ahead of their presidential nominating conventions. These don’t necessarily indicate immediate legislative priorities, but they do indicate general direction. Since the 1980s, the Republican platform has been a test of how far the mainstream of the party is willing to move toward the right-wing fringe. Judging from the draft circulating this week, the answer is, pretty much all the way over.

headline: The Field Hockey Chronicles: Memories and Motivation
text: Michelle Kasold, a striker, has been a member of the United States field hockey team since 2006, and competed in her first Olympics in London. She has written regularly for the 2012 London Olympics blog. This is her fourth post.

headline: As Fighting Rages, Syria and Russia Reject U.S. Intervention Threat
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Army shellings and shootings raged in at least three insurgency hot spots across Syria on Tuesday, including what antigovernment activists described as the deadly bombardment of mourners in a Damascus suburb during funerals for victims of a newly discovered massacre.

headline: In Missouri’s Move to the Right, a Question of How Far
text: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here, a look at Missouri, the Show Me State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with David Robertson, a professor in the political science department at the University of Missouri-St. Louis, and Brian R. Calfano, an associate professor of political science at Missouri State University.

headline: Knocking Kids’ Socks Off | Hansel From Basel
text: The best thing about making accessories for children: “Not worrying about how the customer will integrate the pieces into her wardrobe,” says Hannah Byun, the Los Angeles-based designer of the stockings and sock line Hansel From Basel. “There’s nothing holding you back. It’s a free-for-all.” It’s true. A little girl could get away with mixing Byun’s mustache-print tights, or socks that resemble strawberries with leaves around the ankles — styles from her first collection for children, available this fall — with anything she owns and look cute, not cuckoo.

headline: A Resort Developer’s Himalayan Quest
text: The story of an American’s dream to build a luxury Himalayan ski resort shows the particular difficulties faced by foreign companies who want to do business in India.

headline: American Thwarted in Quest to Build a Ski Resort in India
text: MANALI, India — To John Sims, the Himalayas, with some of the finest mountain slopes in the world, seemed like the perfect place to build India’s first Western-style ski resort.

headline: Suzuki Recalls 102,000 Forenzas and Renos for Potential Headlight Failure
text: Suzuki is recalling almost 102,000 of its 2004-6 Forenza and 2005-6 Reno models because the headlights might fail. It is the second recall of those vehicles in the last five years for headlight problems.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: TimesCast Politics | August 21, 2012
text: A deadline for the Senate candidate Todd Akin in Missouri. | Convention preparations. | Mormonism and the campaign. | A lighter look at life on the campaign trail.

headline: Accord Sought in Germany Over Circumcision Issue
text: BERLIN — German officials have been meeting here with Israel’s chief Ashkenazi rabbi over the past two days as they seek a way to enshrine some sort of legal protection for Jews and Muslims who circumcise infant boys as a religious rite, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel’s Gain Is Felt as a Loss at ‘Nightline’
text: With Jimmy Kimmel moving to 11:35 p.m. in January, the famed ABC News program “Nightline” will be moving back a full hour to 12:35 a.m. It is a deeply disappointing outcome for many at the news division, which had fought hard to keep the pre-midnight time slot.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Benefits

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Arguing With Doctors
text: To the Editor:

headline: TimesCast Politics: All Eyes on Missouri
text: The Associated Press

headline: For Growth, Better Coordination Is Needed on Bank Regulation
text: Mohamed El-Erian is the chief executive of Pimco.

headline: Storm Heads Toward Florida as Convention Nears
text: After struggling to handle two political storms this week, Republicans may face a real one at their convention in Tampa, Fla., next week as hurricane season arrives.

headline: Blast on 2nd Ave. Subway Project Shatters Windows Above Ground
text: Updated, 9:15 p.m. | An intentional underground explosion on the Second Avenue subway project at 72nd Street propelled a thick column of debris and smoke into the air and shattered windows above ground on Tuesday.

headline: Early Antibiotic Use Linked to Childhood Obesity
text: Before you accept antibiotics for your infant, you may want to consider the results of a study published in the International Journal of Obesity showing a correlation between antibiotic exposure before 6 months and an increased body mass later in childhood, between 10 months and 3 years of age.

headline: Simplicity Is the Mother of Confection
text: MOST summer stone fruit — peaches, plums, nectarines, apricots — are candidates for a pretty tart. Fresh figs qualify, too. I cut the fruit into quarters or eighths, depending on their size, then crowd the wedges so that they stand at attention in tight concentric circles on a pastry shell. I dust the fruit with sugar and, as a typical recipe demands, I would dot the top with butter.

headline: Hawks Are Hardly Sunk Without Johnson
text: Joe Johnson is no longer an Atlanta Hawk.

headline: ‘The Office’ to Pack Up Its Files in 2013
text: It’s time to take a last nostalgic look at Jim, Pam and Dwight and their quotidian struggles and successes at the Scranton branch of the Dunder Mifflin paper company as they’ve been documented on “The Office.” When that NBC comedy begins its ninth season on Sept. 20, it will be the final one of the series, Greg Daniels, an executive producer, said on Tuesday.

headline: Saving India’s Tigers
text: India’s Supreme Court issued a ban on tourism inside the country’s game parks on June 24, and the government has been relocating hundreds of villagers to save the endangered wild tigers.

headline: Israel Asks Egypt to Remove Tanks From Sinai
text: JERUSALEM — Israel is “troubled” by the entry of Egyptian tanks into the northern Sinai Peninsula without coordination with Israel, a violation of the terms of the 33-year-old peace treaty between the two countries, and has asked Egypt to withdraw them, an Israeli government official said Tuesday.

headline: Obama Attacks Romney’s Proposals for College Financing
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio – President Obama, adding another verse to his litany of differences with Mitt Romney, promoted his record on education here Tuesday and assailed his Republican challenger for advising financially strapped young people who want to go to college to “shop around and borrow more money from your parents.”

headline: Anti-Putin Hackers Seize Moscow Court’s Web Site, Posting Calls to ‘Free Pussy Riot’
text: MOSCOW — Hackers briefly seized control Monday of the Web site of the Moscow district court that sentenced three members of the feminist protest band Pussy Riot to two years in a penal colony last week.

headline: Rationing Health Care More Fairly
text: Older adults are understandably anxious about the political sniping over the future financing of Medicare. That is precisely the intention of the presidential campaigns.

headline: 2,003 Deaths in Afghanistan
text: Chart showing deaths of identified United States service members directly involved in the war in Afghanistan.

headline: Face Time | Kay Panabaker
text: I met the Los Angeles-based actress Kay Panabaker on a quick visit to New York. We chatted about a lot of things, including her coming film, “Little Birds,” which opens Aug. 29 and also stars Juno Temple, Kate Bosworth and Leslie Mann. Panabaker’s character, Alison, is solid and levelheaded, much like the actress herself. Mature beyond her 22 years, this young lady knows who she is, what she stands for and which beauty products she can’t live without!

headline: Kinds Of Wrong
text: Looking at the comments on my Niall Ferguson takedown (see Ezra Klein, Matthew O’Brien, James Fallows, and Noah Smith for more), I found my memory jogged about a point I’ve been meaning to make about the nature of error in economics.

headline: Starter: Pork Slope
text: Introducing Starter, an occasional column that takes a look at restaurants as they are opening.

headline: In Toll of 2,000, New Portrait of Afghan War
text: His war was almost over. Or so Marina Buckley thought when her son Lance Cpl. Gregory T. Buckley Jr. told her that he would be returning from southern Afghanistan to his Marine Corps base in Hawaii in late August, three months early.

headline: Romney’s Attack on Clean Energy: True, With an Asterisk
text: 4:41 p.m. | Updated This week, Mitt Romney echoed an accusation made by various conservative bloggers against President Obama — that his administration has spent $90 billion on green energy.

headline: You Plan, I’ll Cook: Leaving the Menu to Others
text: AFTER her first daughter was born, Lindsey Swank Meili realized that something had to give, and that something was cooking dinner. Several nights a week, she ordered Chinese food or pizza. When she did cook, it was the same old stuff: meatloaf, chicken and lots of pasta.

headline: Winding Down the Elephant Season
text: Caitlin O’Connell-Rodwell, who teaches at the Stanford University School of Medicine, writes from Etosha National Park in Namibia, where she is studying elephant societies.

headline: A South African ‘Miss Julie’ Captivates Edinburgh Festival
text: EDINBURGH  — With 2,695 events in 279 locations to choose from, the process of deciding what to see here at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe can be a logistical nightmare. “I don’t want to miss anything really fantastic,” you think. Then:  “Can I possibly make it from Assembly on the Mount to Underbelly in Bristo Square in 15 minutes?” (Doubtful.) Planning anxiety kicks in.

headline: On the Radar: Arctic Sea Ice Melt
text: Next week, Arctic sea ice may melt to its smallest size since data collection began in 1979, according to the lead scientist at the National Snow and Ice Data Center. The summer of 2007 holds the record for sea ice melt, when the minimum area of the Arctic sea ice recorded was 39 percent smaller than the average minimum from 1979 to 2000. [Reuters]

headline: With X-1, McLaren Plays Custom Coachbuilder
text: The term “special operations” conjures images of furtive, masked figures in black, emerging like ninjas from stealthy vehicles to infiltrate a target. Those evocations are amply reflected by a one-of-a-kind supercar, the McLaren X-1, the first full product from the British marque’s Special Operations program.

headline: Court Blocks E.P.A. Rule on Cross-State Pollution
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Tuesday overturned a federal rule that laid out how much air pollution states would have to clean up to avoid incurring violations in downwind states.

headline: Syria Seen as Trying to Roil Lebanon
text: RAMA, Lebanon — As Syria’s civil war drags on, the recent arrest of a former Lebanese government minister allied with the Syrian leadership on charges that he planned a campaign of bombings and assassinations has led many in Lebanon to conclude that President Bashar al-Assad is trying to push this fragile country into a sectarian war.

headline: Calculating the Human Cost of the War in Afghanistan
text: Figuring out how many United States military personnel have died in the war in Afghanistan is not simple.

headline: Before Finding Fame, Countless Phone Calls, and One Audition
text: In the 1960s, Phyllis Diller’s New York was the New York of the performer on the way up. It was the New York of late-night comedy clubs, of grungy audition rooms, of “Broadway Danny Rose” types who claimed to have show-business connections — and were not afraid to pester producers for an audition.

headline: La Vara
text: Inside the new restaurant that offers up Spanish-style tapas in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: Sick on the Road? Try the Grocery Store
text: ADVENTUROUS travelers are often in a quandary: how do they pack lightly and still be prepared for the unexpected?

headline: A Valuable View of Trends in New U.S. Electric Power Sources
text: This is a valuable long-view chart from the Energy Information Administration showing how natural gas plants and wind turbines have been the dominant sources of new electricity generation capacity in the United States in recent years. Click here for more background from the Energy Department. There’s plenty of additional discussion of “the gas age” on Dot Earth. I found this via a Climate Progress post focused on new capacity built in the first half of this year.

headline: With Abortion in the Spotlight, a Challenge for Romney
text: 4:07 p.m. | Updated HOUSTON — The decision by Republican convention delegates to oppose abortion without explicit exceptions for rape and incest poses a tricky political challenge for Mitt Romney as he prepares to accept the presidential nomination in Tampa, Fla., next week.

headline: 1,200-Bed Halfway House in Newark Is Operating Illegally, Suit Says
text: New Jersey’s largest private halfway house has operated for over a decade without legal authority and should be shut down, a union representing corrections officers claims in a lawsuit.

headline: Surveillance, Civil Liberties and Inefficiency
text: After the Associated Press disclosed the N.Y.P.D.’s Muslim surveillance program, the Times board editorialized against it from a civil liberties perspective. It seemed the police were spying on Muslims—sending plainclothes officers to monitor Muslims at mosques, on college campuses, taking photographs of Muslim-owned businesses, listening to conversations—with no “reason to think anything wrong was going on.” The board acknowledged that “under a federal court decree, it is permissible to collect information from public sources” but argued that “going to public places apparently selected on the basis of religion” was “another matter.”

headline: UBS Hires Grafstein as Co-Head of M.&A. in the Americas
text: UBS has hired Laurence Grafstein, a veteran deal maker, as a co-head of mergers and acquisitions in the Americas, the Swiss bank announced Tuesday in an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook.

headline: Prosecutors File Arguments in Effort to Return Cambodian Statue
text: Federal prosecutors seeking to repatriate a 10th century statue to Cambodia filed court papers Monday accusing Sotheby’s of knowing the sculpture “was an important piece of cultural property that had been stolen” from a remote temple complex when the auction house put the massive sandstone artifact up for sale in March 2011.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘American Midget’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: As Ryan Campaigns, the Abortion Issue Intrudes
text: CARNEGIE, Pa. — While the furor continued over Representative Todd Akin’s remarks about rape, Paul D. Ryan did not mention his House colleague as he campaigned for the Republican presidential ticket here on Tuesday.

headline: In Sweden, My Dreams Will Find Me
text: “We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit.” — Aristotle

headline: New Ads Attack the Koch Brothers
text: As patrons of conservative groups, the billionaire Koch brothers have bankrolled plenty of negative ads, but now they are a direct target of one.

headline: Branching Out From Night Life
text: ON a humid Wednesday in June, an eclectic cross-section of the city’s cool kids descended upon a former Catholic school in NoLIta for a new shopping Web site.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Cell Towers vs. Police, and the History of @
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: The New York Times’s Public Opinion Poll
text: A new poll asked New Yorkers about the mayor’s performance, bike lanes, the soda ban and other questions about quality of life in the city.

headline: Gary M. Rosenberg
text: Mr. Rosenberg, 62, is the founding partner of Rosenberg & Estis, a law firm based in New York that represents real estate developers. The firm has a longstanding relationship with the Durst Organization and has worked on the developer’s projects at Four Times Square and One Bryant Park. It is currently involved in the leasing of One World Trade Center.

headline: A Reunion of Flavors From Spain
text: APPEARANCES count in food, but great cooking is sometimes hard to spot at first glance. When they arrive at the table, there is nothing prepossessing about the fried artichokes served at La Vara, a four-month-old Spanish restaurant in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. I took one look and thought, O.K., fried artichokes. I know what these are all about.

headline: As Republicans Meet, Biden Will Campaign in Tampa
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. plans to crash the other party’s party. When Republicans gather in Tampa, Fla., next week to nominate Mitt Romney and Paul D. Ryan, Mr. Biden intends to be there as well, to campaign for the Democrats.

headline: Two Lives, Intoxicated by Theater
text: STRATFORD, Ontario — Much of the glory and a lot of the money in show business find their way to actors — or at least stars. But two refreshing solo shows at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival this season reorient our perceptions of where much of the magic really comes from, at least in the theater.

headline: Internet Analysts Question India’s Efforts to Stem Panic
text: MUMBAI, India — The Indian government’s efforts to stem a weeklong panic among some ethnic minorities has again put it at odds with Internet companies like Google, Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Gentle Giant Seeks the Strength to Body Check His Mother
text: The bodybuilder Kim Kold doesn’t loom over the world of “Teddy Bear,” a low-key Danish drama about saying hello to love and goodbye to dear old, horrible Mom, he towers. As Dennis, the movie’s emphatically noncuddly title character, Mr. Kold has a diffident manner that appears at odds with his outrageous physical size and his character’s expert exhibitionism. A hulking contradiction tucked under a stratum of ropy muscle, his Dennis is at once massive and passive, as big as a house and shy as a mouse. He needs to roar.

headline: Rising Rents Create a Demand for Manhattan Walk-Up Buildings
text: The Benchmark Real Estate Group acquired the 22-unit walk-up building at 156 Sullivan Street in SoHo for just over $6 million last year. It is now in contract to sell the rental building for $12.5 million.

headline: Fog and Faces: Day and Night in the Punjab
text: In “Alms for a Blind Horse” the writer and director Gurvinder Singh cares more about the weathered faces of villagers and the morning fog that settles over their town and fields than he does about storytelling. His method is a slow, careful formalism — so slow and so careful that his film can feel airless and overly aestheticized.

headline: A $650 Million Expansion of Port Newark Spurs Interest in Its Environs
text: In Newark’s Ironbound district, a developer broke ground last month on a $50 million warehouse without a committed tenant — a bold move and a sign of how much faith there is in the potential for growth in the state’s industrial sector and specifically in its ports.

headline: Doctor Group Is Treating Syrian Rebels and Civilians
text: PARIS — Working in a converted villa in a town in the Syrian north, an international team of doctors and nurses has been quietly treating Syrian opposition fighters and civilians for the past two months, Doctors Without Borders announced in Paris on Tuesday.

headline: Gilt Adds New Twists to Mobile App
text: Gilt Groupe, the New York company known for its time-sensitive sales of designer clothing, is releasing a major upgrade for its iPhone app on Wednesday. It introduces a complete redesign as well as the ability to search automatically for apparel that matches the clothing you own.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Lebanon, Pakistan, Nepal and Ecuador.

headline: Guitar Strings: The Art of the Package
text: In a former life, before joining The New York Times in 2007, I managed the Guitar Shop in Washington — a famously cramped, 90-year-old vintage-instrument store. Founded in 1922 by Sophocles Papas, a Greek immigrant who became a friend, publisher and musical envoy to the renowned classical guitarist Andres Segovia, the Guitar Shop kept an inventory of almost 2,000 stringed instruments, some of which dated back to the 1700s. By the time I left for New York, we were the last remaining music store in downtown Washington.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 21
text: Photo Replay: Aug. 21

headline: Talking Death, and Promises, With a Preschooler
text: I recently had an unplanned death talk with my 4½-year-old daughter that left me wondering if my explanation of mortality should have stopped at worms and dogs, at least until she gets a little bit older.

headline: Canadians Ask Why Design of $100 Bill Replaced Asian Woman With White One
text: OTTAWA — When the Bank of Canada switched to plastic-based banknotes, it ran the proposed designs past eight focus groups, hoping to avoid controversy or embarrassment.

headline: Elevator Music Meets Classical: Concerts in a Lobby
text: What’s wrong with this picture? New York City’s major institutions have done little to commemorate the 150th anniversary of Debussy’s birth, but Arts Brookfield — the performance presentation arm of Brookfield Office Properties, a real estate concern that operates large office buildings in New York and across North America — is filling the gap with Debussy 150, a free four-concert series in the lobby of 1 Liberty Plaza in Lower Manhattan.

headline: IAC Is Said to Make Offer for Times’s About.com
text: The New York Times Company has found there is more interest than it may have expected in its ailing About Group, a business unit that includes the informational Web site About.com.

headline: Ryan Takes to Pennsylvania to Push Medicare Message
text: WEST CHESTER, Pa. — Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin customized from his menu of attacks on President Obama to fit a full day of campaigning in Pennsylvania on Tuesday, putting state-specific numbers on his assertion that current Medicare beneficiaries will suffer benefit cuts under the 2010 health care law.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘This Too Shall Suck’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Parkinson’s in Check, Fox to Star in Sitcom
text: After Michael J. Fox learned he had Parkinson’s disease, but before he publicly disclosed his diagnosis in 1998, he worried that his career as a comedic actor would be ruined if viewers knew that he was, as he put it in his memoir, “battling an incurable neurological disease.”

headline: A Northern (or Maybe Bronx?) Cheer for the South’s Independence
text: Chuck Thompson is a travel writer who has worked on assignment in more than 50 countries. Real countries. The kinds that have recognizable borders and appear on maps.

headline: What the G.O.P. Platform Represents
text: Over the years, the major parties’ election-year platforms have been regarded as Kabuki theater scripts for convention week. The presidential candidates blithely ignored them or openly dismissed the most extreme planks with a knowing wink as merely a gesture to pacify the noisiest activists in the party.

headline: The Big Problem With Small Plates
text: This week I review La Vara, a new restaurant in Brooklyn with a menu that explores the contribution that Jews and Muslims made to Spain’s cuisine. Have you been? If you have, I’d love to know what you thought. I admired a great deal of the dishes that the owners and co-chefs, Alex Raij and Eder Montero, have put on their menu (those artichokes! That tuna salad! Those red shrimp, served with their heads!).

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Fantasy Artists’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.James Ryan Caldwell knows how to write. All he needs now is to learn when to quit. At 90 minutes, his expertly acted comedy-drama “Fantasy Artists” is rather good. But you can’t help thinking that at 75 minutes it would be even better.

headline: Icahn Withdraws Offer to Take Refining Company Private
text: Carl C. Icahn, who owns 82 percent of CVR Energy, said on Tuesday that he was dropping an offer to take the Texas refiner private, citing changing market conditions.

headline: The Caucus Click: Signs of Youth
text: Students painted signs to be used at next week’s Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Profits in G.M.A.C. Bailout to Benefit Financiers, Not U.S.
text: Among the companies that were bailed out by the federal government during the financial crisis, perhaps the most intractable is proving to be the company formerly known as the General Motors Acceptance Corporation. It’s a case study in how bailouts can linger and profits, when they do come, flow not to the government but to the Warren E. Buffetts of the world.

headline: Why Apple Might be Better Off Losing Its Patent Lawsuit
text: Could it be in Apple’s self-interest to lose its bitter court battle with Samsung?

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,084 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: U.S. Companies Worry About Effect of Russia Joining W.T.O.
text: MOSCOW — After two decades of negotiations, Russia will finally join the World Trade Organization on Wednesday. The lower trade barriers that come along with membership will open up new opportunities for foreign companies to do business in Russia.

headline: United States Grants Broad Sanctions Exemption for Iran Quake Aid
text: The United States cleared the way on Tuesday for American charities to expedite relief to the victims of the double earthquake that struck Iran more than two weeks ago, issuing the charities a temporary but broad exemption to the regimen of economic sanctions imposed on that country over its disputed nuclear energy program.

headline: Anti-Islam Ads Remixed in San Francisco and New York
text: As my colleague Benjamin Weiser reported last month, a federal judge in Manhattan ruled that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had violated the First Amendment rights of a pro-Israel group by refusing to run an ad that refers to Arabs as “savage” on 318 city buses.

headline: Recalling the Real ‘Dog Day Afternoon,’ 40 Years On
text: The woman’s body stiffened with each passing second as she sat anxiously in the back row of a 14-person limousine. Suddenly, a man sitting near her was fatally shot — killed by an F.B.I. agent, the culmination of nearly 14 hours of one of the more gripping criminal episodes in recent New York City history.

headline: Ethiopian Leader’s Death Highlights Gap Between U.S. Interests and Ideals
text: LIBREVILLE, Gabon — There was probably no leader on the African continent who exemplified the conflict between the American government’s interests and its highest ideals better than Prime Minister Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia.

headline: Dell Makes Moves to Survive in Cloud-Centric World
text: Despite headwinds in its core business, Dell is trying hard to move into the new world of corporate computing.

headline: TimesCast Politics | Eyes on Missouri
text: A deadline for the Senate candidate Todd Akin.

headline: New Yorkers and Bike Lanes
text: When asked simply whether bike lanes were a good idea or a bad idea, 66 percent of New Yorkers said they were a good idea, according to a new poll by The New York Times.

headline: Paul and Republican Party Officials Reach Deal on Delegates
text: The presidential campaign of the libertarian Republican Ron Paul has reached agreement with party leaders on delegate disputes, clearing the way for a harmonious convention to nominate Mitt Romney next week in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Brain Tumor Treatment for Baseball Union Leader
text: Michael Weiner, the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, announced Tuesday that he had begun treatment for a brain tumor. Weiner, who plans to continue working, is expected to be treated for at least a month.

headline: Beneath a Humdrum Exterior, Talk of Mysterious Inner Depths
text: PARIS — The French have never been passionate about François Hollande, their new president. A professional politician, never a government minister, he has been engaged in the machinations of the Socialist Party for most of his career. He was elected, narrowly, on a platform of change, but in large part because he was not Nicolas Sarkozy. And now the bland Mr. Hollande faces a daunting economic landscape and a euro crisis, and the French wonder if he, or anyone, can really make much difference.

headline: Giving Little Virginia Something to Sing About
text: FOR decades, Macy’s has been on Broadway, literally. Soon, the department store will be there figuratively, too, as it develops a musical for schools around the country.

headline: Recovery for the Speedy Nicks Is Deliberately Slow
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Hakeem Nicks snared a pass in the left flat from Eli Manning during Tuesday’s practice and looked as if he wanted to simply run all day.

headline: Celebrate the Farmer!
text: I was at a farm dinner in Maine the other night, a long table of 60 people eating corn, chicken, salad, a spectacular herb sorbet and other goodies. When one of the hosts arose to ask someone to describe the first course on the table – huge marrow bones from the farm’s cattle– she introduced not the chef but the farmers. Similarly, at a fund-raiser on Cape Cod a week or so earlier, the talk was all about the provenance of the produce and meat rather than the cooking technique. The most popular guy was the oyster grower.

headline: After Afghanistan, a New Great Game
text: SINCE 9/11, America’s priority in Central Asia has been to defeat the Taliban in Afghanistan. But as the United States and NATO pull out, there is a new danger: that the West could become entangled in regional rivalries, local strongman politics and competition with Russia and China.

headline: Comparing the Candidates on Medicare
text: How the provisions in the president’s health care law differ from the plans of Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan.

headline: Setback for Rogue Immigration Laws
text: A federal appeals court in Atlanta on Monday properly blocked several provisions of immigration laws in Alabama and Georgia, saying they violated constitutional rights and undermined federal law. The rulings were huge setbacks for the repellent idea that states can bypass federal authority over immigration and create their own schemes to harass and expel undocumented residents.

headline: Smart Cars Get a Connection Test in Michigan
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Federal regulators on Tuesday announced a yearlong “smart car” project to determine whether wireless communication between vehicles can improve safety on the nation’s highways.

headline: Living the Abstinent Lifestyle in New York
text: Trinity Laurel moved to Manhattan at 21 to pursue a modeling career. Raised in a Christian home, Laurel was a virgin when she reached the city, and says she has “remained pure” while living here since.

headline: Samuel H. Lindenbaum, ‘Dean’ of New York Zoning Lawyers, Dies at 77
text: Samuel H. Lindenbaum, who was widely considered New York City’s top zoning lawyer and who was credited with doing as much as any of the powerful developers among his clients to shape the modern skyline of Manhattan, died on Friday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 77.

headline: Disney World on the Hudson
text: WHEN the first segment of the High Line, the now-famous park built atop an old elevated railway on the West Side of Manhattan, opened in 2009, I experienced a moment of excitement. I had often wondered what it would be like to climb that graffiti-marked trestle with its wild urban meadow. Of course, I’d seen the architectural renderings and knew not to expect a wilderness. Still, the idea was enticing: a public park above the hubbub, a contemplative space where nature softens the city’s abrasiveness.

headline: Prosecutorial Abuse
text: Federal law allows federal courts to award attorneys’ fees and other expenses to criminal defendants who prove gross misconduct on the part of federal prosecutors. The law — a 1997 amendment sponsored by Representative Henry Hyde, a Republican — is a valuable deterrent to prosecutorial abuse, providing compensation in cases where a court finds the government’s position to be “vexatious, frivolous or in bad faith.”

headline: Uncertain Future for the Gray Wolf
text: The recovery of the gray wolf in the Rocky Mountain West is one of the Endangered Species Act’s great success stories. Hunted nearly to extinction, wolves were reintroduced to the region in the 1990s and have since staged a remarkable comeback, thanks to federal protections. But whether this story has a happy ending will depend on the federal government’s willingness to monitor, and revise if necessary, wolf management plans it has agreed to in Idaho and Montana and is about to strike with Wyoming.

headline: Pettitte Talks About Return, His and Clemens’s
text: CHICAGO — After a light catch with C.C. Sabathia in the outfield Tuesday afternoon, Andy Pettitte returned to the clubhouse and was asked, among other things, about his old friend and teammate Roger Clemens’s plans to pitch in a minor league game this week.

headline: Risks of Syrian Intervention Limit Options for U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — Despite President Obama’s warning to Syria not to use its arsenal of chemical weapons or allow them to fall into the hands of extremists, the administration’s options for intervening remain limited by what its officials have described as a simple calculus: It would make the conflict even worse.

headline: Patients Would Pay More if Romney Restores Medicare Savings, Analysts Say
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney’s promise to restore $716 billion that he says President Obama “robbed” from Medicare has some health care experts puzzled, and not just because his running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan, included the same savings in his House budgets.

headline: Criminal Prosecutions at a Low Rate in the Bronx, a Report Finds
text: Prosecutors have declined to pursue criminal cases far more often in the Bronx than in other parts of the city, according to a news report published Tuesday examining state judicial data.

headline: A Peacock Wanders Queens, Undeterred and Unclaimed
text: Escaped peafowl tend to enrapture even the most blasé of New Yorkers.

headline: We Need a ‘Conservative’ Party
text: There has been lots of talk that Paul Ryan’s nomination ensures that we’ll now have a “real” debate about the role of government. That’s actually funny. The bar for this campaign is so low that we celebrate the fact that it might include a serious debate about one of the four great issues of the day, though even that is not clear yet. And even if Ryan’s entry does spark a meaningful debate about one of the great issues facing America — the nexus of debt, taxes and entitlements — there is little sign that we’ll seriously debate our other three major challenges: how to generate growth and upgrade the skills of every American in an age when the merger of globalization and the information technology revolution means every good job requires more education; how to meet our energy and climate challenges; and how to create an immigration policy that will treat those who are here illegally humanely, while opening America to the world’s most talented immigrants, whom we need to remain the world’s most innovative economy.

headline: A Promise Unfulfilled at an Art Deco Bathhouse in the Rockaways
text: With its octagonal brick towers rising above the beach, the sprawling bathhouse at Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaways has, since opening in 1932, served as a monument to Art Deco design, grand public works and populist fun. Lately, however, it has become a symbol of something else: public frustration.

headline: Dispute Over Islands Reflects Japanese Fear of China’s Rise
text: ISHIGAKI, Japan — When the flotilla of 21 fishing boats arrived at an island chain at the center of a growing territorial dispute with China, the captains warned the dozens of activists and politicians aboard not to attempt a landing.

headline: Skinny-Dipping in Israel Casts Unwanted Spotlight on Congressional Travel
text: WASHINGTON — The trip was much like any of the hundreds hosted in recent years by a nonprofit offshoot of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a powerful Washington lobby, and the purpose was much the same: to solidify the support of American lawmakers for Israel at a time of Middle East tumult.

headline: Trespassing to Plant Flowers, and a Flag
text: The gardeners entered the empty lot, pushing in the bottom of a metal gate on the Lower East Side, ducking under it and dragging their tools behind them.

headline: Akin Controversy Stirs Up Abortion Issue in Campaign
text: WASHINGTON — As an orator, Representative Todd Akin of Missouri may stand out for his clumsiness. But as a legislator, Mr. Akin has a record on abortion that is largely indistinguishable from those of most of his Republican House colleagues, who have viewed restricting abortion rights as one of their top priorities.

headline: Tennis Referee, in New York for U.S. Open, Arrested in Murder Case
text: The police arrested a professional tennis referee at a Manhattan hotel on Tuesday on a charge of murder in the death of her husband in April. The referee, Lois Ann Goodman, nicknamed Lolo, was in New York to work the United States Open.

headline: Social Media Propels a Song of Summer
text: YouTube versions of Carly Rae Jepsen’s cheerfully flirty song, “Call Me Maybe,” helped turn it into the song of summer.

headline: Poker Is More a Game of Skill Than of Chance, a Judge Rules
text: The game was Texas Hold ’Em. About $300 bought a place at the table in the back room of a warehouse on Staten Island, where waitresses floated around with food and drinks and the play lasted until breakfast.

headline: Progress Is Cited on New Reactor in North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — While the region’s attention has remained focused on whether the new North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, can consolidate his power, his country has been making significant progress in the construction of a new reactor widely seen as a cover for making more fuel for nuclear weapons, analysts say, citing satellite imagery of the building site.

headline: Secretive Police Unit Sought to Map Terrorist Havens in City, Official Testifies
text: Despite being dispatched to hundreds of places across New York City where would-be terrorists might congregate, an eight-member Police Department unit that eavesdropped on countless conversations has not generated a lead or an investigation in at least six years, a police chief testified in a deposition unsealed Monday.

headline: Just Think No
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Should the Fed Risk Inflation to Spur Growth?
text: The specter of runaway inflation has haunted many economists since the 1970s. But is this fear keeping the economy stagnant?

headline: The New Rise of a Summer Hit: Tweet It Maybe
text: For decades, the song of the summer would emerge each year following a pattern as predictable as the beach tides.

headline: Deciding Whether to Medicate a Child
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
Summit Meeting in Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: Using Voter ID Laws to Protect Our Democracy
text: To the Editor:

headline: All Yours
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — You know how everyone has at least one thing that makes their brain shut down? It might be a certain subject they studied in school (trigonometry), or the way an appliance manual is written (all of them). There is always at least one thing we encounter in life that is so complex to us that our poor brain cells just give up and put out a sign that says “Closed for Lunch.”

headline: On Trail, Obama Attacks Romney on Student Aid
text: RENO, Nev. — President Obama, adding another chapter to his litany of differences with Mitt Romney, took to the road on Tuesday to promote his record on education and assail his Republican challenger for advising financially struggling college hopefuls to “shop around and borrow more money from your parents.”

headline: A Politician Whose Faith Is Central to His Persistence
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Throughout his political career, Representative Todd Akin’s agenda has been driven by a belief that his mission came from God.

headline: Chilean Ex-Officers Charged in 1985 Kidnapping of U.S. Hiker
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — A judge ordered the arrest on Tuesday of eight retired police and military officers in connection with the kidnapping and disappearance of Boris Weisfeiler, an American university professor who disappeared while hiking in Chile in 1985.

headline: Warren Ties Brown to G.O.P.’s Agenda on Women’s Issues
text: BOSTON – Elizabeth Warren seized on the weekend comments of Missouri Representative Todd Akin on Tuesday, seeking to link his statement about “legitimate rape” to the Republican Party’s broader agenda on women’s issues – and thus, to her opponent in the Massachusetts Senate race, the incumbent Republican Senator Scott P. Brown.

headline: The New High-Tech Dating Technology? Meet in a Bar
text: Online dating services have long promised to help people find a mate by using statistical science to predict personal chemistry. But some of the biggest services are now adding a retro twist.

headline: A Crime That Transfixed the City
text: Revisiting a widely publicized bank robbery attempt in Brooklyn on Aug. 22, 1972, that inspired the film “Dog Day Afternoon.”

headline: Offline Dating
text: Online daters go for a brand new dating tactic ... sort of. At a MeetMoi.com event, singles try to meet their match at the Greenwood Park bar in Brooklyn.

headline: As Decision Nears on Gas Drilling, Ad War Heats Up in New York State
text: ALBANY — As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration finishes up new regulations on where and how to allow hydraulic fracturing in New York State, groups on both sides of the issue are turning to the airwaves in a late-inning effort to press their cases.

headline: Former G.O.P. Hero Plays Down Label
text: BOSTON — When Mitt Romney ran for governor of Massachusetts a decade ago, he said that the “R” after his name stood for “Reform.”

headline: When Precedent Dictates Prudence
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Questions Surround Man’s Death in Patrol Car
text: On a dark suburban street in Jonesboro, Ark., last month, the police arrested a young man named Chavis Carter. They searched him, handcuffed him and put him in the back of a patrol car.

headline: Mets Follow the Nationals’ Cue on Limiting Innings of Pitcher
text: With the Mets toddling toward the end of the season, their postseason hopes all but extinguished, how far they should push various pitchers has become a central question.

headline: Appeals Court Draws Boundaries on Alabama’s Immigration Law
text: When Alabama’s immigration law was passed in the spring of 2011, it was the boldest test yet of the doctrine of self-deportation. If the state put up legal obstacles to nearly every aspect of illegal immigrants’ lives, as a chief sponsor of the law put it at the time, it would “make their lives difficult and they will deport themselves.”

headline: Corrections: August 22, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 21
text: Flipping boats and diving plays highlighted Tuesday’s events.

headline: A Place for Passionate Tennis Players
text: New York, a city of subcultures, has a gem on Manhattan’s West Side. Bordered by 94th and 96th Streets, between the Onassis Reservoir and the West Drive of one of the world’s most famous public spaces, sits the Central Park Tennis Center.

headline: With East Race Tightening, Nova’s Struggles Raise Concerns
text: CHICAGO — Even as their lead in the American League East has shriveled in the last few weeks, the outward calm of the Yankees has never seemed shaken. But late Tuesday night, after another poor outing by Ivan Nova, Manager Joe Girardi acknowledged that Nova’s problems had now endured for a significant period of time. But he bristled at questions about how much longer the Yankees could stick with Nova, their struggling right-hander.

headline: Are Unlimited Data Plans Dead? T-Mobile USA Says No
text: Just when cellphone customers were beginning to think “all you can eat” data plans were a relic of the past, T-Mobile USA on Wednesday said that next month it will begin offering a plan that does not put any limits on the use of data for things like browsing the Web, watching videos or streaming music.

headline: Riding the Wave of Surfer Fitness
text: To the casual spectator, surfing seems to involve primarily balance, grace, nervy insouciance and a certain laid-back, ineffable oneness with the powers of the deep. But a series of newly published studies of the actual physical demands of surfing reveal that other, sometimes surprising aspects of fitness may be as important to surfing success as the ability to judge and remain upright on a swell.

headline: Web Sites Accused of Collecting Data on Children
text: A coalition of nearly 20 children’s advocacy, health and public interest groups plans to file complaints with the Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday, asserting that some online marketing to children by McDonald’s and four other well-known companies violates a federal law protecting children’s privacy.

headline: St. John’s Senior Leads Met Open
text: Pat Wilson, a St. John’s senior from Andover, N.J., shot a seven-under-par 65 to take a one-stroke lead after one round of the Met Open Championship at Plainfield Country Club in Edison, N.J. Three holes in one were made, all on the second hole.

headline: A Special Subculture in Central Park
text: The Central Park Tennis Center attracts a plethora of regulars, many of whom arrive at its doors an hour before its 6:30 a.m. opening time to claim their court.

headline: Has Obama Made the Job Situation Worse?
text: “Without a doubt President Obama inherited a difficult situation. Here’s the problem. He made it worse,” Paul Ryan, the Republican vice presidential candidate,  has been saying in his stump speech.

headline: Friendship as Priceless as the National Pastime
text: CHICAGO — A welcome breeze blew in from Lake Michigan as the two older women, one white and one African-American, sat in the garden of their South Side retirement home and joked and reminisced about five decades of friendship knit tight by the game of baseball.

headline: The Making of a ‘Quality Suit’ in Kolkata’s Bustling New Market
text: The first time I met Ajit Singh, I offended him.

headline: Are Drone Strikes Worth the Costs?
text: HONG KONG — American drones have launched five airstrikes in the past five days in the tribal areas between Pakistan and Afghanistan. The latest attack — carried out Tuesday in North Waziristan by a pair of American drones — killed five suspected militants. The incident was barely mentioned in the U.S. media.

headline: Internet Analysts Question India’s Efforts to Stem Panic
text: “The Indian government’s efforts to stem a weeklong panic among some ethnic minorities has again put it at odds with Internet companies like Google, Facebook and Twitter,” Vikas Bajaj  wrote in The New York Times.

headline: American Thwarted in Quest to Build a Ski Resort in India
text: “To John Sims, the Himalayas, with some of the finest mountain slopes in the world, seemed like the perfect place to build India’s first Western-style ski resort,” Vikas Bajaj wrote in The New York Times.

headline: In the Lap of Himalayas, Luxury Ski Resorts Are a Distant Dream
text: Manali, a hill station in the Kullu Valley of Himachal Pradesh state, has long been seen as a potential hub for skiing in India. Witness the efforts of a group of foreign investors who have been trying to build the Himalayan Ski Village there for nearly a decade.

headline: From Bible-Belt Pastor to Atheist Leader
text: Late one night in early May 2011, a preacher named Jerry DeWitt was lying in bed in DeRidder, La., when his phone rang. He picked it up and heard an anguished, familiar voice. It was Natosha Davis, a friend and parishioner in a church where DeWitt had preached for more than five years. Her brother had been in a bad motorcycle accident, she said, and he might not survive.

headline: What’s a Monkey to Do in Tampa?
text: The monkey appeared behind a Bennigan’s. The Bennigan’s was one in a row of free-standing, fast-casual joints in Clearwater, Fla., just outside Tampa, that also includes a Panda Express and a Chipotle. At one end, a Perkins Family Restaurant flies a preposterously large Stars and Stripes in its front yard, as if it were a federal building or an aircraft carrier.

headline: Street Fighting in Aleppo
text: Goran Tomasevic, a staff photographer for Reuters, photographed the fighting in Aleppo, Syria, from Aug. 1 to 17. While he was there, his dramatic images ran on the front pages of newspapers throughout the world. Mr. Tomasevic, 43, has been covering armed conflicts since 1991. On Tuesday, James Estrin interviewed him via e-mail. The exchange has been edited.

headline: Managing the Ocean for Humans and Whales
text: As I wrote this week in a story about the humpback whales that summer off New England, one of the main reasons researchers want to learn about the humpbacks is so that the whales can be better protected from human activities like fishing and boating.

headline: The Early Word: Renegade
text: Today’s Times

headline: Carolina Panthers, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: On paper, the 2012 Carolina Panthers are a classic sleeper team. You may have heard about how at least five new teams have reached the N.F.L. postseason every year since 1996, meaning teams that didn’t make the playoffs the previous season. Generally, at least one of those teams had a bad-but-not-awful record – like, say, 6-10 – the year before.

headline: The Mameco-Ardun Saga Reaches a Fitting Climax at Pebble Beach
text: 8:22 a.m. | Updated

headline: Is Deficit Spending the Answer?
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: The Census Zombie Eats Another Brain
text: Back in 2010 all the usual suspects were going on about how there had been a huge increase in federal employment under Obama. This was funny, for two reasons: it was all about temporary hiring for the Census, and the meme continued to be part of what everyone on the right knew, just knew, to be true long after the Census blip was over and federal employment was back below its level when Obama took office.

headline: Conciliatory Notes in Germany on Easing Greece's Burden
text: BERLIN — Bild, Germany’s most-read newspaper, has accused Greece of “making our euro kaput” and only a few days ago referred to the country as “a bottomless pit.”

headline: How the Toilet Paper Entrepreneur Branded Himself Too Well
text: When Mike Michalowicz published a book in 2008, he was looking for a name that would stick. He chose: “The Toilet Paper Entrepreneur.”

headline: An Attack on Grameen Bank, and the Cause of Women
text: This month, the Grameen Bank, the organization that won the Nobel Peace Prize for extending small loans to impoverished village women, has come under renewed attack from the government of Bangladesh. Last year, I reported that the government was attempting to forcibly remove the bank’s founder, Muhammad Yunus, from his position as managing director on the pretense that Yunus, then 70, was beyond the official retirement age. The government prevailed.

headline: How I Got That Shot: Justin Novak
text: What started as a lark for three pro photographer buddies, ended up as some heroic images, and a lesson on how a little lighting can turn daytime shots on-the-fly into powerful images.

headline: A Parade of Spinning Dolphins
text: Scott Baker, associate director of the Marine Mammal Institute at Oregon State University, writes from Samoa, where he studies the formation of local communities among dolphins and their genetic isolation from one another.

headline: Euro Zone Talks Revive Specter of Greek Exit
text: LONDON — Have Greece’s euro zone partners resigned themselves to seeing Europe’s most distressed economy pull out of the single currency?

headline: Q&A: Turning Off an Annoying Safari Alert
text: Q.

headline: Understanding Medicare “Cuts”
text: Jackie Calmes has a very good piece about those Medicare “cuts” Romney promises to repeal. As she emphasizes, all of these involve reductions in payments to insurance companies and health providers, rather than reductions in patient benefits. So what are we talking about?

headline: Occupy Video
text: A pretty good video compilation related to the Occupy Handbook, featuring some people you may know:

headline: Pussy Riot Was Carefully Calibrated for Protest
text: DEPENDING on your taste, punk died in 1979, or maybe 1994, or whenever studded leather cuffs became a must-have mall-girl accessory. Now, suddenly, punk has been resurrected, stitched together anew in the form of the well-accessorized Russian women who call themselves Pussy Riot.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Profits in G.M.A.C. Bailout to Benefit Financiers, Not U.S.  |  Among the companies that were bailed out by the federal government during the financial crisis, perhaps the most intractable is proving to be the company formerly known as the General Motors Acceptance Corporation. It is a case study in how bailouts can linger and profits, when they do come, flow not to the government but to the Warren E. Buffetts of the world, the Deal Professor writes.

headline: Aug. 21: Romney Showing Improved Results in Swing State Polls
text: We can get pretty detail-oriented in our analysis of the polls here at FiveThirtyEight. But sometimes there is also value in applying a simpler approach.

headline: Opinion Report: Wyoming Wolves
text: From the editorial page

headline: Japanese Leader Meets With Antinuclear Protesters
text: TOKYO — For the first time since antinuclear rallies began months ago outside Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda’s office, a dozen protesters were allowed inside on Wednesday for a half-hour meeting that the fledgling movement hailed as a victory. The meeting comes at a time of growing antinuclear sentiment in Japan, and with elections expected this year.

headline: A Botched Robbery That Went Hollywood
text: Temperatures were in the 90s on the afternoon of Aug. 22, 1972, when a young mop-haired gunman emerged from a Chase Manhattan Bank in Gravesend, Brooklyn, wearing a sweaty V-neck undershirt.

headline: Wednesday Reading: When Your Child’s Diet Changes Yours
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Peanuts, Popcorn and Dermatology at Yankee Stadium
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Is Facebook Straying From the ‘Hacker Way’?
text: Has Facebook lost its hacker way?

headline: Summer Styles | Lacy Ladies
text: A look at who’s staying cool and looking cooler this season.

headline: YouTube Will Now Let Mobile Users Choose Whether to Watch Ads
text: People often visit Web sites on their mobile phones as much or more than they do on computers. But that leaves Web companies with a challenge: how to make money on phones, where there is less space for advertisements and people have less patience for them?

headline: Daily Report: Online Dating Services Go Retro
text: Online dating services have long promised to help people find a mate by using statistical science to predict personal chemistry. But some of the biggest services are now adding a retro twist, Jenna Wortham reports in Wednesday’s New York Times.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Washington Post: A new analysis by the Natural Resources Defense Council says that Americans throw away up to 40 percent of their food each year, with the average family of four ends up tossing out up to $2,275 worth. — Emily Weinstein

headline: Akin Defies Calls to Step Down in TV Interviews
text: 10:27 a.m. | Updated  Representative Todd Akin on Wednesday morning took his case for staying in Missouri’s Senate race to the mainstream media he has blamed for his travails, telling both ABC’s “Good Morning America” and NBC’s “Today” show that his decision to defy his party’s leadership and conservative cognoscenti was a stand for the Republican voters of the Show Me State.

headline: In Vietnam, Growing Fears of an Economic Meltdown
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — Construction crews got as far as the first floor of what was to be Saigon Residence, a high-end apartment building in the center of Ho Chi Minh City. All that remains today of the abandoned project are piles of moldy bricks, rusting steel rods and a small team of security guards who have transformed the cement foundation into a parking lot for motorcycles.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Kimmel, Fox and ‘Call Me Maybe’ Make Waves
text: This year’s ubiquitous summer hit, “Call Me Maybe” by Carly Jepsen, signals a bigger change than just the weather for the media business, writes Ben Sisario. Even last year, the big hits were all produced by old-style music companies pushing for radio play but this year songs like “Call Me Maybe” and Gotye’s “Somebody That I Used to Know” got their initial push through social media before ending up on Top 40 radio.

headline: Language and China’s ‘Practical Creativity’
text: Every language presents challenges — English pronunciation can be idiosyncratic and Russian grammar is fairly complex, for example — but non-alphabetic writing systems like Chinese pose special challenges.

headline: Health Care REIT to Buy Sunrise Senior Living
text: Health Care REIT Inc. agreed on Wednesday to buy Sunrise Senior Living for $844.6 million in cash, in a deal aimed at creating one of the biggest owners of nursing homes in the United States, Canada and Britain.

headline: The New Citigroup Isn’t Your Father’s Citicorp
text: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroup‘s chief executive, has entered the debate over splitting up big banks. But did he overstate one of his key points?

headline: Citic Capital Sells Stake to Qatar Fund
text: The Chinese asset management firm Citic Capital Holdings is taking on a new shareholder by agreeing to sell a 22 percent stake to a unit of Qatar’s sovereign wealth fund.

headline: Syrian Forces Are Said to Expand Deadly ‘Hit and Run’ Efforts in Damascus
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Gunfire and shelling rocked Damascus, Syria, and its suburbs on Wednesday as opponents of President Bashar al-Assad reported a widening campaign by the military to sow fear and death in neighborhoods where the rebels are strong and the government is too weak to assert full control.

headline: A Public Bathroom, Transformed Into a Gem by the Beach
text: Inside Public Comfort Station 2 on the boardwalk in Brighton Beach, even the trash receptacles are clothed, their utilitarian metal covered in burgundy fabric. The sinks have pink skirts, too, while the mirrors wear garlands of silk flowers, the soap bottles dispense fruit-scented hand cleanser and plastic ferns stand in the corner.

headline: Searching Through the Ashes of an Exploded Life
text: In “Infinite Jest” David Foster Wallace  described  clinical depression as “the Great White Shark of pain,” “a level of psychic pain wholly incompatible with human life as we know it,” a “nausea of the cells and soul,” a sort of “double bind in which any/all of the alternatives we associate with human agency — sitting or standing, doing or resting, speaking or keeping silent, living or dying — are not just unpleasant but literally horrible,” a radical loneliness in which “everything is part of the problem, and there is no solution.”

headline: Supreme Court Castigates Government for Poor Tiger Conservation Efforts
text: The Supreme Court of India on Wednesday extended the temporary ban on tourism in the core areas of the country’s tiger parks by another week, as it criticized the government for its inaction in protecting the endangered animal.

headline: Art Lessons
text: As public schools across the country shutter their arts programs in favor of grueling test prep instruction, children’s picture books are helping make up for the loss. Two sweet new books, “Mousterpiece” and “Sky Color,” continue what seems to have become a kind of crusade to teach children the value of artistic self-expression.

headline: Cholera Epidemic Envelops Coastal Slums in West Africa
text: DAKAR, Senegal — A fierce cholera epidemic is spreading through the coastal slums of West Africa, killing hundreds and sickening many more in one of the worst regional outbreaks in years, health experts said.

headline: Business Day Live | August 22, 2012
text: The challenges that await Best Buy's new chief executive. | High-tech dating goes retro. | How social media is changing the music industry's hit making process.

headline: Business Day Live: The New High-Tech Dating Technique? Meet in a Bar
text: The challenges that await Best Buy’s new chief executive. | Online dating services go retro. | How the music industry’s hit-making process is changing.

headline: Budget Impasse Invites Recession Risk, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Congressional Budget Office said Wednesday that the economic recovery would continue “at a modest pace” for the rest of the year, but that if Congress took no action to stave off tax increases and automatic budget cuts scheduled for Jan. 1, the economy could fall into a recession.

headline: New Label Alert | Julia Jentzsch
text: All week, T is introducing the lines to look out for this fall.

headline: France: Floor Plans for Government Offices Stolen
text: A USB memory stick and discs containing the floor plans for the Élysée Palace, the Interior Ministry, the Paris police headquarters and several large companies were in a bag stolen from a car near a Parisian train station on Sunday, the Interior Ministry confirmed Tuesday. The plans, which were not encrypted, did not contain information about who occupied various rooms and were not classified, the ministry said in a statement. “The information they contain does not imperil the security of the sites concerned,” the statement said.

headline: One on One: Ernest Cline, Author of ‘Ready Player One’
text: “Ready Player One,” written by the 40-year-old Ernest Cline, is a science fiction novel set in 2044. It takes place on a grimy version of Earth where people prefer to live in a virtual reality video game rather than in real life. The book follows the story of Wade Watts, who is on an epic quest to solve a multilevel puzzle that involves playing 1980s video games and trivia. Here is an edited interview with Mr. Cline.

headline: The Other Wild Monkeys of Florida
text: The odd thing I found about traveling to Florida to write a story in Sunday’s magazine about a monkey on the loose is how many times someone asks you which monkey on the loose, exactly, you’re asking after.

headline: Image of the Day: August 22
text: A two-day nationwide strike called by a group of Indian bank employee unions against reform proposals.

headline: The Wild Macaques of Silver River
text: Troops of monkeys running free in Florida.

headline: With Clemens, You Can’t Make This Stuff Up
text: There are some sports stories you just couldn’t make up if you tried. For today’s example, Roger Clemens comes out of retirement at 50 to pitch for an independent minor league team and also take some hacks in an over-50 men’s softball league. Now, were the Atlantic League the kind of league that installs beer kegs at each base and requires someone with actual athletic talent to pitch with a small child perched on his shoulders, heads across the country might not be lolling with such fatigue. But no, the Sugar Land Skeeters (we couldn’t make that up either) are apparently enough of an actual organization to have an official team backdrop — with the team’s and its sponsor’s name, no less — for Clemens’s news conference Wednesday. Oh, and the Astros consider this serious enough to send a scout to contemplate a possible major league return.

headline: The Don Quixote of the Spanish Crisis
text: Bearded and blustery, with a kaffiyeh draped around his neck, Juan Manuel Sánchez Gordillo cuts a rakish profile. For the last 33 years he has been the mayor of the small Andalusian town of Marinaleda, a Communist enclave in southern Spain.

headline: Margaret Dunning, Queen for a Weekend at Pebble Beach
text: The Margaret Dunning Road Show made a pit stop at the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance last weekend, where the 102-year-old showed her cherished 1930 Packard.

headline: Biography of Gore Vidal Coming in 2015
text: The life of Gore Vidal, the prolific and pugnacious man of letters who died in July, will be unfurled in a new biography written by Jay Parini, the novelist and scholar, and published by Doubleday.

headline: Briton Who Fought for Assisted Suicide Is Dead
text: LONDON — A 58-year-old British man suffering from so-called locked-in syndrome died Wednesday, six days after a panel of High Court judges rejected his request for help in ending his life. His death is certain to galvanize the already contentious debate about assisted suicide in Britain.

headline: A Quick End to TARP Means a Smaller Payoff for Taxpayers
text: Quietly, the Treasury Department is engaged in another bailout of the banks. This time, it’s America’s small banks that are the lucky duckies.

headline: Overlooked and Underfoot: Sidewalk Cleaning in New York City
text: They say that gum stays in the stomach for seven years, but how long does a discarded piece remain on the sidewalk?

headline: A Virginia Baker Is in the Spotlight at a Ryan Rally
text: ROANOKE, Va. — Joe the Plumber, meet Chris the Baker.

headline: Possession Paralysis Revisited
text: Possession paralysis, it turns out, is real.

headline: The Legs Take Their Turn
text: MARCY STEIN, 46, a former competitive power lifter who lives on the Upper East Side and manages large construction projects for a consulting company, keeps an eye on the shape of her legs. “When you’re power lifting, your legs are amazing, but they’re big and muscular,” she said.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘The Art of Painting’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.If “The Art of Painting” were a real art history lecture, it would be a sophomore’s dream. The instructor (Mark Chrisler) is cute, and he makes the lives of long-dead white European men entertaining.

headline: Death of a Strongman
text: NAIROBI — After two months of mysterious absence, Meles Zenawi, Ethiopia’s prime minister, is finally accounted for: He’s dead.

headline: The Rhinos Have Arrived
text: O.K., it’s August. But the arrival of two 4,000-pound adolescent southern white rhinos — brothers, no less — at the Bronx Zoo would be news any day. The surprisingly nimble-footed pair (see video above or here) were a gift from The Wilds, a conservation park in Cumberland, Ohio, where they were born three and a half years ago.

headline: Phyllis Diller and Her Comic Craft
text: Early in her career Phyllis Diller, who died on Monday at 95, made fun of her legs and her figure. Later she took aim at her wrinkles and plastic surgery. “I’ve had so many things done to my body,” she began a joke, “that when I die, God won’t know me.”

headline: Ask Your Local G.O.P. Candidate About ‘Legitimate’ Rape
text: A reporter for the Pittsburgh TV station KDKA asked Paul Ryan the other day what he thought of Rep. Todd Akin’s pronouncement that victims of “legitimate rape” can magically “shut down” pregnancy and so do not need the right to an abortion.

headline: 60% in City Oppose Bloomberg’s Soda Ban, Poll Finds
text: The big-soda ban is losing some of its fizz.

headline: Donations by Media Companies Tilt Heavily to Obama
text: Wall Street may lean Republican this presidential election cycle, but the New York media world is staunchly Democratic.

headline: Scene City: South Central in East Hampton
text: “End of Watch” holds a private screening in the Hamptons.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times poll is based on telephone interviews with 1,026 adult residents from throughout New York City conducted Aug. 10 to 15. The interviews were in English or Spanish.

headline: Talk of Small Plates on Twitter
text: Pete Wells’s blog post about the problems of sharing a meal made up of small plates sparked an exchange on Twitter with the writers Michele Humes and Francis Lam, the chef David Chang, the Bloomberg restaurant critic Ryan Sutton and others. about Chinese cuisine and American habits, the distinction between a family-style meal and the current small plates rage, and the advantage in serving small plates for the restaurant. Here are excerpts from the conversation. To be sure we see your tweet on the subject, cc @nytdining.

headline: A Big Party for a Not-So-Big Film
text: IN the new movie “End of Watch,” Jake Gyllenhaal plays a cop in South Central Los Angeles, working the neighborhood patrol and battling some seriously scary thugs from a Mexican drug cartel.

headline: No Charges for Officer Accused by Judge
text: After a three-month investigation, the Queens district attorney has decided not to bring criminal charges against a police officer who was accused of assaulting a State Supreme Court justice on the street in what the judge contended was an unprovoked attack, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Limited Convention Broadcasts Shut Out Ann Romney
text: At 10:30 on Monday night, Ann Romney is scheduled to take the stage at the Republican National Convention, in Act 1 of her husband’s four-day introduction to the nation. But tens of millions of people will not be able to watch.

headline: U.S. Oil and Mining Companies Must Disclose Payments to Foreign Governments
text: HOUSTON — Despite stiff industry lobbying against it, the Securities and Exchange Commission voted 2 to 1 on Wednesday to require American oil and mining companies to disclose taxes and other fees they pay to foreign governments. The disclosures are aimed at curbing corruption, which is common in some major oil-producing nations.

headline: Kenya Clashes Leave Dozens Dead
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — As many as 52 people, most of them women and children, were killed Wednesday in a coastal area of Kenya in attacks involving two rival communities, officials said.

headline: In Texas, Don’t Even Mention Abortion
text: The Republican-controlled State Legislature in Texas and Gov. Rick Perry are perfectly willing to endanger the general health and welfare of low-income women to further their agenda of eroding abortion rights. And, now, a federal appeals court has given them a green light to do that, at least temporarily.

headline: Book Will Describe Raid That Killed Bin Laden
text: A detailed first-person account of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, written by a member of the Navy SEALs who participated in the mission and was present at Bin Laden’s death, will be released next month, the publisher said on Wednesday.

headline: David Champion, Director of Automotive Testing for Consumer Reports, Joins Nissan
text: To fill the newly created position of adviser for competitive assessment and quality, Nissan North America has hired David Champion, formerly the senior director of Consumer Reports’ auto test center. The appointment takes effect on Sept. 10, Nissan noted in a media release on Wednesday.
