headline: Father’s Age Is Linked to Risk of Autism and Schizophrenia
text: Older men are more likely than young ones to father a child who develops autism or schizophrenia, because of random mutations that become more numerous with advancing paternal age, scientists reported on Wednesday, in the first study to quantify the effect as it builds each year. The age of mothers had no bearing on the risk for these disorders, the study found.

headline: Ryan Pressed to Explain Position on Rape and Abortion
text: Representative Paul D. Ryan sought to distance himself from Todd Akin, his House colleague, on Wednesday by condemning his comments about rape, even while deflecting questions about the meaning of “forcible rape.”

headline: The Get | Chloé’s Boots
text: A fall boot is like a winter coat — so critical it can easily turn into a must-have of mythic proportions. Thankfully, Chloé’s Clare Waight Keller has designed three similar and pretty-close-to-perfect boot styles — the toe shape is the same on all; the heel size and height varies from pair to pair — that help make the best-ever boot something one cannot only attain but wear everyday. Available in three seasonally-appropriate colors — mustard-yellow, brick-red and rich burgundy (very important this season, take note) — the glossed-leather gives the shoes’ equestrian silhouettes a polished feel. The only hard part now? Picking which one to wear.

headline: U.N. Visit Will Set Back a Push to Isolate Iran
text: Efforts led by the United States and Israel to isolate Iran suffered a setback on Wednesday when the United Nations announced that Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, would join officials from 120 countries in Tehran next week for a summit meeting that Iran has trumpeted as a vindication of its defiance and enduring importance in world affairs.

headline: Struggling to Recover From a Cyberattack
text: IN 2006, Peter Justen, a serial entrepreneur, founded MyBizHomepage, an online service that connected to companies’ QuickBooks accounting software to help business owners monitor their financial metrics. When the site went live in 2008, it attracted significant media attention. It was free to use and the company planned to make money through advertising, a recipe that appealed to Mr. Justen’s investors, who valued the company at $100 million based on the vast potential they perceived.

headline: Die Koelner Bierhalle
text: IN the spirit of barbarian tribes, beer gardens with no-frills décor and heavyweight glassware have invaded New York’s bar scene. The latest is Die Koelner Bierhalle, which opened in early August in Park Slope, a few blocks from the Barclays Center.

headline: Video: Primary Day in Connecticut
text: The Lieberman-Lamont race remains tight as the polls close in Connecticut. (Producer: Matthew Orr)

headline: A New Addition to Police Lingo: ‘Easy, Peasy, Lemon Squeezy’
text: There are all sorts of things police officers are known to say when they arrest someone. “Freeze,” or “Police — don’t move!”

headline: University of Texas Compounds Conflict Question in Review of Gas Report
text: As I wrote recently, the University of Texas, Austin, appropriately initiated an independent review of the report from its Energy Institute on gas drilling using hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, methods. The review was ordered after the Public Accountability Initiative, a nonprofit research group, pointed out previously undisclosed financial ties between a leader of the report, Charles Groat, and a drilling company.

headline: A Murder Sentence Underlines South African Inequality
text: JOHANNESBURG — When a leading white supremacist was found bludgeoned to death in his bed on his farm outside Johannesburg in April 2010, the Rainbow Nation shuddered.

headline: Stone Links: Paul Ryan, Pussy Riot and Philosophy
text: Over the past week, “philosophy” made the headlines of stories from opposite ends of the political spectrum.

headline: Whose Ryan Is It Anyway?
text: Gail Collins: David, welcome back! You missed so much while you were on vacation. Tim Pawlenty is the Republican vice-presidential nominee, and Michele Bachmann is going to make the keynote speech at the convention, and Donald Trump will be leading the invocation.

headline: Most New Long-Term Care Claims Are Filed by Women
text: While deciding to purchase long-term care insurance is a complex decision, it is one that women, in particular, may want to spend some time considering. Nearly two-thirds of new claims under long-term care policies in 2011 were made by women, according to the latest data from an industry group.

headline: Akin Remarks Push Gender Issues to Center Stage
text: Just days before Mitt Romney formally assumes the leadership of his party, he and his Republican colleagues are once again confronting the party’s long-standing difficulty attracting the support of women — a demographic reality that could cost Mr. Romney the White House.

headline: In Google’s Inner Circle, a Falling Number of Women
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — At Google, data is king. Now the company is using data to figure out if it can anoint a few queens.

headline: The Kitchen Announces Its Fall Season
text: Yoga mats, Beethoven, stories from life in America and Mary Shelley’s “Frankenstein” all serve as fodder for offerings this season at The Kitchen performance and exhibition space, which released highlights of its program, which runs from Sept. 7 – Dec. 22.

headline: Reinventing Instant Film in an Age of Instant Imagery
text: In the world of photography, innovation has a shelf life. By 2008, some 60 years after Edwin Land’s invention of the Polaroid camera, analog photography had been usurped by the power of the digital age. The shuttering of instant film production left a community of Polaroid enthusiasts and professional photographers with uncertain futures: Would instant film ever be produced again? Could Polaroid be resurrected?

headline: Big City Book Club: Discussing Nora Ephron
text: 9:30 p.m. | Updated  That’s a wrap! The live portion of our conversation is now concluded. But please still weigh in in the comments section below with any and all thoughts on Nora Ephron and her work. I’ll be checking in throughout the week. And stay tuned: we’ll announce our next book club selection soon.

headline: Older Fathers Linked to Risk of Autism and Schizophrenia
text: A new study provides some of the first solid scientific evidence for a true increase in autism. In the Science section, Benedict Carey describes the research: “Older men are more likely than young ones to father a child who develops autism or schizophrenia, because of random mutations that become more numerous with advancing paternal age, scientists reported on Wednesday. The age of mothers had no bearing on the risk for these disorders.” Read more.

headline: Please Don’t Eat the Cheese Curls
text: In the Dining Section, Matt Richtel writes about the ways having children has changed his diet — and not for the better. For him, it’s the main meals. He snatches the French fries and finishes the last bites of pasta.

headline: Another Player Receives 50-Game Ban
text: For the second time in a week, Major League Baseball has suspended a prominent major leaguer for testing positive for an excessive level of testosterone, a clear indication that illegal performance enhancers continue to exist as a stubborn element of the sport despite intensified efforts to eliminate their use.

headline: Genome Detectives Solve a Hospital’s Deadly Outbreak
text: The ambulance sped up to the red brick federal research hospital on June 13, 2011, and paramedics rushed a gravely ill 43-year-old woman straight to intensive care. She had a rare lung disease and was gasping for breath. And, just hours before, the hospital learned she had been infected with a deadly strain of bacteria resistant to nearly all antibiotics.

headline: David Henry Hwang Wins $200,000 Prize for Playwriting
text: The $200,000 Steinberg award for playwriting, the most generous prize in theater, has been presented to Tony Award winner David Henry Hwang for 32 years of provocative satires and dramas (“Chinglish,” “M. Butterfly”) that brought more Asian and Asian-American characters to Broadway and other stages, the Harold and Mimi Steinberg Charitable Trust announced on Wednesday.

headline: Missouri Republicans Weigh In on Akin
text: Missouri residents who are active in the Republican Party are divided over Representative Todd Akin’s decision to continue his campaign for the United States Senate, even as a chorus of party leaders urged him to throw in the towel.

headline: Many at Fed Ready to Act if Necessary
text: WASHINGTON — Many Federal Reserve officials at their most recent policy meeting pushed for further actions to support the economy if the recovery failed to strengthen over the summer, an official account released on Wednesday showed.

headline: Thomas Jefferson, ‘Founding Foodie’
text: Thomas Jefferson’s take on agriculture sounds remarkably like the 1800s version of Wendell Berry, with a little bit of Alice Waters thrown in.

headline: Japanese Journalist’s Final Report From Syria Is Released After Her Death
text: Two days after a Japanese journalist, Mika Yamamoto, was shot and killed in the Syrian city of Aleppo, her news agency released some of the footage she recorded in her final hours.

headline: Worst Year for West Nile Is Expected, Officials Say
text: The nation is heading toward the worst outbreak of West Nile disease in the 13 years that the virus has been on this continent, federal health authorities said Wednesday.

headline: TimesCast Tech | August 22, 2012
text: Fixing a pothole with an app. | Online dating goes retro. | Presidential campaign apps raise concerns over privacy.

headline: Romania’s Meat Market
text: Come transfer time, professional soccer players are paraded and sold like meat at a butcher shop, their movement among various clubs becoming a public affair chronicled in news media transmissions across the globe.

headline: Action Plans on CO2 that Go Beyond ‘Woe is Me, Shame on You’
text: I recently received a note from Tim Whitley, the founder and head of the nonprofit group Carbon Offsets to Alleviate Poverty, which I think merits posting as a “Your Dot” contribution because it takes a step beyond the “woe is me, shame on you” rhetoric that has long been favored by people seeking to cut greenhouse gas emissions. Here’s Whitley’s piece, with a postscript from me:

headline: In Ultra-Secretive Case, One Veil May Be Lifted
text: The case of John Doe and Richard Roe may be about to take a small step toward transparency.

headline: Postal Service Stuck With Glut of ‘Simpsons’ Stamps
text: 4:42 p.m. | Updated Perhaps recalling the heady days when Bart Simpson T-shirts sold in the millions and a song like “Do the Bartman” had the power to become a cultural touchstone, the UnitedStates Postal Service produced 1 billion stamps featuring characters from “The Simpsons” in 2009 to commemorate the show’s 20th year on Fox.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Cerebral Ballzy
text: Having Cerebral Ballzy play at Santos Party House is like putting a tiger in a paper cage. Ballzy, one of New York’s loudest, most raucous fire starters, comes with a thick crowd — one of elbow-throwing, neck-snapping, mosh-pit-shoving ruffians that doesn’t exactly jibe with Santos’s thorough, and intimidating, fleet of security guards. At a recent performance, a prominently displayed sign forbade moshing, leaving the audience somewhat castrated in its enthusiasm, but it was clear that on any other night, the scene would be pure chaos. The singer Honor Titus — channeling a mixture of Jimi Hendrix, Tony Hawk and a punk prince — was apparently singing about getting black-out drunk, refusing to be told what to do and being a native New Yorker, but you’d have to be reading a karaoke screen to know that. For the raucous among you, Cerebral Ballzy will perform at the Afro Punk festival in Brooklyn this weekend.

headline: Can This Company Recover From a Cyberattack?
text: A case study we’ve just published explains the challenges faced by Peter Justen, chief executive of MyBizHomepage, a Middleburg, Va., provider of business accounting software. The business was shut down by a wave of cyber attacks that apparently came from a disgruntled former employee.

headline: A Manic Collection of Orderly Designs
text: As a design student with an inexplicable desire for accumulating all kinds of objects, I was filled with joy upon discovering Amass, the blog of James Phillips Williams, a former art director at Bergdorf Goodman. A successful graphic designer, Williams lives and works in New York with his wife, Allison Muench, where they run their own design studio, MW, whose clients have included the department store Takashimaya. I recently e-mailed Williams to find out more about his acquisitive nature and the blog.

headline: Taylor Swift Song Sets a Record for Digital Sales
text: This week on the music charts, Taylor Swift’s new song set a digital sales record, and the debut album by the rapper 2 Chainz opens at No. 1.

headline: The Dance Between Belize and Its Bondholders
text: This is the dynamic at work in the negotiations between Belize and its bondholders. Really it’s the dynamic in most sovereign debt restructurings.

headline: A Web Site That Aims to Help Manage Student Loans
text: I don’t have student loans anymore (thank goodness). But I do recall that managing them was a challenge. How many loans did I have? How much was I paying in total? When would they all be paid off? Who is Sallie Mae, and why did I borrow so much money from her?

headline: U.S. Road to Brazil Detours to Outer Space
text: The revolution will not be televised … and neither will United States men’s national team away games in regional World Cup qualifying — unless you are among a small universe of TV viewers who have access to Al-Jazeera Sports Media Network’s beIN Sport channel.

headline: TimesCast Tech: Offline Dating
text: Fixing a pothole with an app, online dating goes retro and presidential campaign apps raise concerns over privacy. The video is available at nytimes.com/bits

headline: Scouting Report
text: LIMITED EDITION:

headline: Steel Plate Above Subway Blast Site ‘Opened Up Like a Trapdoor’
text: A 1,800-pound steel plate that was secured along only one side “opened up like a trapdoor” and sent rocks and other debris flying through the air when explosives were set beneath it this week at the Second Avenue subway excavation site, a transit spokesman said Wednesday.

headline: Romney Returns to His Mainstay: The Economy
text: BETTENDORF, Iowa — With the unwanted distractions of Representative Todd Akin’s “legitimate rape” comments still swirling in the background on Wednesday, Mitt Romney returned to his political mainstay during a campaign stop at LeClaire Manufacturing here — hitting President Obama over the economy.

headline: In a Little-Known WWII Battle, a Father’s Experience Becomes a Daughter’s Journey
text: DIEPPE, France — Going to the 70th anniversary commemoration of the Dieppe raid in Normandy this past weekend was part of a journey I began when I was very small. It gathered steam in college, when I first saw footage at the Canadian War Museum in Ottawa that was shot at Dieppe by the Germans. I stood in a gallery watching it, looking for my father, Francis Stanley Parker, a private in the Black Watch Regiment of Canada, in the columns marching past the camera — an American in the sea of Canadian captives.

headline: Work at Slaughterhouse Is Halted After Graphic Undercover Videos
text: Federal authorities have shut down a California slaughterhouse for investigation after an animal protection charity secretly filmed cows being electrically shocked, shot in the head, suffocated and undergoing other abuses.

headline: Traffic Agent Arrested but Not Charged in Alleged Rape
text: The police arrested a New York City traffic enforcement agent on Tuesday night after a woman claimed he had raped her. But a spokesman for the Bronx district attorney said Wednesday that the agent had not been charged and that prosecution of the case had been deferred because of insufficient evidence.

headline: Existential Questions
text: To the Editor:

headline: To Sketch, to Draw, to Create, With No Pencil in Sight
text: I used to have a habit of carrying around a red Moleskine notebook and, while sipping a beer or a coffee, I’d make little sketches. My drawings were just curiosities, sometimes of the scene or of an interesting person. They were more for fun, to let my creative juices flow, than an attempt at serious art. Often I’d have to borrow a pen from the bar or cafe because carrying a pencil in a jeans pocket wasn’t ideal.

headline: Buying Their Way to Twitter Fame
text: AS a comedian, Dan Nainan was blessed with fans, millions of YouTube views and, once, an audience with President Obama. But one thing was missing.

headline: ‘Too High to Fail’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Weak Sales and a Large Write-Down Give H.P. a Loss
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The pressure is building for Meg Whitman to make a miracle happen.

headline: Help to Promote Canada From a Director’s Chair
text: Canada, the country where the directors James Cameron, David Cronenberg and Paul Haggis were born, is tapping its creative and civic-minded public to promote tourism.

headline: Two Vestiges of Vaudeville
text: As the Broadway musical in-jokes and double and triple entendres snowballed into a comic avalanche at Tuesday’s opening-night performance of “The Prince and the Show Boy” at 54 Below, I was reminded once again that vaudeville never died. The Prince of the title is Faith Prince and the Show Boy is Jason Graae, who, although hardly a boy, conveys the brashness of a mouthy hyperactive teenager. Both are vaudevillians to the bone.

headline: HTML5, Apps and JavaScript Video
text: Here are the videos from last week’s TimesOpen event on HTML5, Apps and JavaScript:

headline: Ex-Giant Michael Strahan Is Seen as Favorite to Join Kelly Ripa on ‘Live’
text: Is the the former New York Giants great Michael Strahan about to play a new position on television?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Syria, India, Mars and North Carolina.

headline: The Dinner Table Debate
text: An excerpt from debate on gay marriage between Brian Brown and Dan Savage, held after dinner at Mr. Savage’s home.

headline: Behind the Due Diligence Dispute at Best Buy
text: The squabble between Best Buy and its founder, Richard M. Schulze, appears, for the moment, to center on one basic matter: the terms of opening the electronics retailer’s books for due diligence.

headline: Diana Nyad’s Neverending Swim
text: Diana Nyad is in her early 60s and all she has wanted to do for the last 35 years is swim the 103 miles that separate Havana from Key West, Fla. She tried and failed three times, starting at age 28, before she jumped into the water on Saturday night to begin her latest attempt. Last December, Elizabeth Weil profiled Nyad in the magazine, capturing her obsessive determination to successfully cross the Straits of Florida, despite the pleading from some of those closest to her that she let this mania go.

headline: For Prince Harry, Vegas Exploits Didn’t Stay There
text: LONDON — A year that has featured a triumphant Olympic Games and Queen Elizabeth II’s diamond jubilee struck an unwelcome bump on Wednesday for the royal family with the publication of photographs showing the queen’s sometimes wayward grandson, Prince Harry, naked and cavorting with a naked woman, or women, during a strip billiards game in a Las Vegas hotel room.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘The Particulars’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Melodies, Immersive and Vibrant
text: There are many reasons to like Lincoln Center’s Mostly Mozart Festival. But one of the best is its subtle yet crucial transformation of the chronically woeful Avery Fisher Hall, the home base of the festival’s orchestra, which played a program of Bach, Mendelssohn and Mozart on Tuesday evening, led by Andrew Manze, making his festival debut.

headline: Obama Promotes His Education Credentials, Putting Down Romney’s
text: LAS VEGAS – It’s back-to-school time, and President Obama has been all but handing out three-ring binders and pencil sharpeners this week, as he promotes his education credentials and slams those of his challenger, Mitt Romney.

headline: In India, Preserving a Fading Tradition
text: Two friends have started a record label to preserve the music of the Manganiyars, whose songs have no written record.

headline: House Subcommittee Wades Into the Universal-EMI Deal
text: The Universal Music Group’s proposed $1.9 billion takeover of EMI Music, already under close scrutiny by regulators in the United States and Europe, is facing additional pressure from a subcommittee in the House of Representatives.

headline: Preserving the Passion of India’s Roots Music
text: RANERI, India — In this tiny village almost 400 miles southwest of New Delhi, where women wash dishes in the sand to conserve water, and electricity is scarce, Lakha Khan sat on the floor of a stone hut, legs crossed and white turban in place. There he coaxed a bright, high-pitched, dizzyingly fast melody from his violinlike sarangi.

headline: Waltzing a Famous Page Out of John Cage’s Book
text: Most performers who have been inclined to commemorate John Cage’s centenary this season have done so by performing Cage’s music. Kevin James, a trombonist and composer, decided instead to write a work using some of the same principles that animate Cage’s music, including randomness, humor and a mingling of music as it is traditionally understood and unalloyed noise. He presented the piece at the DiMenna Center on Tuesday evening, both as a tribute to Cage and as a way to introduce his new group, the [kaj] Ensemble, which clearly hopes to challenge counter)induction both as a new-music band and over its idiosyncratic orthography.

headline: Defined by Words, Not by a Disease
text: TWENTY years ago this month, Mary Fisher took the stage of the Republican National Convention at the Houston Astrodome and delivered a 13-minute prime-time speech that was seen by many as a sharp rebuke of her party’s negligence in the face of the growing AIDS epidemic.

headline: Placing Blame for Middle-Class Doldrums
text: 6:06 p.m. | Updated to correct description of the group answering a question.

headline: It’s You, She Says, and at a Discount
text: ON a hot afternoon this summer, the air-conditioning was going full blast at the Loehmann’s store in Chelsea. Carly Zell, the store’s personal shopper, was welcoming a steady stream of visitors to her third-floor office with coos of “honey” and “darling.”

headline: A Spin Around Montpelier, Vt.
text: Home to about 8,000 people, Montpelier is one of America’s smallest state capitals.

headline: 36 Hours in Montpelier, Vt.
text: TUCKED away in a tangle of wilderness and clinging to the edges of the Winooski and North Branch Rivers, Montpelier, Vt., with a population of about 8,000, is one of the smallest state capitals in the country, but it is also among the most forward-thinking. It’s the capital of the first state to formally abolish slavery in 1777, and the first to allow civil unions for gay couples.

headline: Weight-Loss Surgery May Prevent Diabetes
text: For people who are extremely overweight and likely to develop diabetes, surgery may be the best form of prevention.

headline: Second World Mind Sports Games in France
text: LILLE, France — At the Second World Mind Sports Games here the United States senior team (Richie Schwartz, Lew Finkel, Neil Chambers, John Schermer, Steve Landen and Sam Lev; I was its nonplaying captain) failed in its bid to win the world title. In the 96-board final on Tuesday and Wednesday against Hungary (Mikos Dumbovich, Mihaly Kovacs, Peter Magyar and Geza Szappanos, with its nonplaying captain, Gyorgy Barany), the United States lost by 247 international match points to 166. France came in third.

headline: Artifacts | A David Among Goliaths
text: When the art world reconvenes in Chelsea this fall, it will find the usual bounty of big-name artists — and a leap into gigantism among some of their dealers. Sean Kelly, David Zwirner, Hauser & Wirth, Friedrich Petzel and Andrea Rosen are either multiplying their locations or tripling in size, or both. But one Chelsea stalwart is expanding his business by going small. And Taiwanese.

headline: The Second Avenue Blasts, Above and Below Ground
text: The words have become a decades-long refrain: Work has been suspended on the Second Avenue subway line. The latest cause? An intentional underground explosion at 72nd Street, during which “something went awry and an explosion was felt at street level,” Adam Lisberg, a Metropolitan Transportation Authority spokesman, told The Times.

headline: Ian Falconer: By the Book
text: The author and illustrator, most recently, of “Olivia and the Fairy Princesses” says good children’s books don’t underestimate the reader. “Children will figure things out.”

headline: Pop Stars Join Growing Effort to Aid the Poor
text: If there is such a thing as a prodigy in the world of philanthropy, Hugh Evans fits the bill. At 14, after visiting a Manila slum with the Christian humanitarian group World Vision, he returned to his middle-class home outside Melbourne, Australia, and announced to his mother he wanted to dedicate his life to ending extreme poverty. She laughed.

headline: New York’s City Council Adds Climate Change Panels
text: The exodus of City Hall aides has already begun as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s term approaches its end next year, but climate change isn’t going anywhere. So in an attempt to continue Mr. Bloomberg’s environmental focus long after he’s gone, the City Council passed legislation on Wednesday that would make two panels advising the city on the threats of global warming a permanent fixture of government.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hackers Gain Ground, and Backpacking Tech

headline: If Summer Goes, Why Won’t the Guests?
text: MEGAN MURPHY SCHWAB, a marketing executive in suburban New Jersey, was seven months pregnant with her second child when a friend asked if another friend, who had just arrived in New York, might spend a night at her home to escape the summer heat. Ms. Schwab had met the woman, who seemed nice enough, so she and her husband, Jeff, an accountant, agreed to put her up.

text: After months of anticipation, Facebook is now closer to completing its takeover of Instagram, the popular photo-sharing application.

headline: Beware the Fiscal Cliff
text: There’s an easy way to cut the deficit nearly in half, the Congressional Budget Office said today: just do nothing when the various elements of the “fiscal cliff” click into place on New Year’s Day. Taxes will go up, spending will go down, and the deficit will be cut from $1.1 trillion this year to $641 billion in 2013.

His books include “A Sea in Flames: The Deepwater Horizon Oil Blowout,” and “The View From Lazy Point; A Natural Year in an Unnatural World,” which won the  2012 Orion Award. His series “Saving the Ocean” will be premiering this fall on PBS television.

headline: Bringing the Ocean With Her
text: WHEN Marie DiManno got married in 1973, her new husband, Jerry DiManno, told her, “You have to love the beach.”

headline: Afghanistan, Contradicting NATO, Blames Foreign Spies for Insider Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even as the Afghan government said on Wednesday that it would take new measures to counter a wave of deadly insider killings of Western troops by Afghan security forces, President Hamid Karzai’s office asserted for the first time that foreign spy agencies were behind most of the attacks, putting it directly at odds with NATO’s assessment of the crisis.

headline: Exotics

headline: Spanier’s Lawyers Attack Freeh Findings
text: Lawyers for the former Penn State president Graham B. Spanier issued a searing rebuttal Wednesday to findings by the former F.B.I. director Louis J. Freeh that Spanier and other top university officials had helped conceal allegations of child abuse involving the former assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky.

headline: Exotics
text: RYAN KORBAN is a 28-year-old self-taught interior designer with a full-size taxidermy zebra in his living room, custom shagreen-covered chairs in his dining room and a vintage goat-parchment armoire.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. The carpeting on our stairs is worn. Should we replace it before selling our home? And if so, with what?

headline: Hunt Continues for Escaped Peacock in Queens
text: As of late Wednesday afternoon, the captivating, if elusive, peacock flying around Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, had still not been apprehended.

headline: Images From Wyeth’s World, Paint Splatters and All
text: James Welling’s interest in Andrew Wyeth dates from his teenage years, when he took a drawing class at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, where some of the artist’s work was displayed. Flash forward four decades. Mr. Welling, 61, is a professor in the Art Department at U.C.L.A. (he will be a visiting professor at Princeton starting next month). During his prolific career, he has painted, sculptured and worked in video. At one point, he was John Baldessari’s teaching assistant.

headline: Hamptons Havens Open for a Day
text: Do hedge fund managers’ hedges grow any greener? Two of the impeccably tended Edens on view this weekend for charity may offer a clue. On Saturday, the Guild Hall of East Hampton will present its seventh annual lecture and garden tour, the Garden as Art, offering access to five private gardens.

headline: A Classic Bookcase Comes to America
text: The late Danish architect Mogens Koch, one of the lesser-known heroes of Scandinavian design, is perhaps best remembered for the shelving system he created in 1928 for his own home in Copenhagen. The system soon caught the interest of Rud. Rasmussen, a local company. Rasmussen put it into production in 1932 and has been making it ever since. Last year, Carl Hansen, another Danish manufacturer, acquired Rasmussen and is giving Mr. Koch’s design its American debut. The Shelving System (it features an extensive range of modular elements, including a CD/DVD unit) is exceptionally flexible. The sections for the basic six-piece unit can be installed horizontally or vertically, allowing lots of options. Made of solid oak with dovetail and rabbet joints to provide strength and stability, the basic unit measures about 30 by 30 by 10.6 inches and is $1,650. Information: (212) 242-6736 or carlhansen.com.

headline: Help Paige Rense Noland Clear Her Closets
text: As the former editor of Architectural Digest, Paige Rense Noland spent 35 years influencing taste. On Saturday, at 11 a.m., Eastern time, many of the objects she collected during that time will go up for sale at the online retailer One Kings Lane.

headline: The City That Always Twinkles
text: Like so many other New Yorkers, David Weeks is a bit of a voyeur. His latest product, the Lonely City USB hub, is the result of “walking down the street late at night, looking up at a building and seeing that one window lit up,” he said. “Maybe it’s a lamp, maybe it’s the glow of a TV.” The hub illuminates when plugged into an outlet, regardless of whether a device is charging (there’s room for four to charge at any given time). The buildings are based on a Google map view of 16th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, a block Mr. Weeks said he has frequented over the years, whether on the way to teaching at Parsons or shopping at Paul Smith. “Google maps shows the ghosted buildings at a 45-degree angle — we looked at that block, broke it into several parts and then elaborated on it,” he said. The Windows- and Mac-compatible hub is $25 on Mr. Weeks’s retail site, tweekstudio.com.

headline: Sales at Home Remedy, Modani, West Elm and Others
text: Some items from Jonathan Adler, Aid to Artisans, Kahler and others are up to 75 percent off at Home Remedy, through Sept. 3 (an Aid to Artisans throw, originally $80, is $56); (800) 363-0405, homeremedynyc.com.

headline: In the City, ‘T’ Stands for Taxi
text: What’s next? “T Driver,” starring Robert De Niro?

text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is looking for ideas.

headline: Nova, With Soreness in Shoulder, Will Probably Miss Next Start
text: CHICAGO — With the Yankees on the verge of being forced to make a decision about whom to drop from the starting rotation, they might not have to make that call after Ivan Nova came up with soreness on the outside of his right shoulder.

headline: Fans Worry After Pakistan Twitter Star Goes Off Line
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — “Where r u MAJOR ?? What happened 2 u ?? I hope u r safe from mad dog jihadis.”

headline: A Wife Recalls Her Estranged Husband’s 1972 Failed Bank Robbery
text: On Aug. 22, 1972, Carmen Wojtowicz was at Rockaway Beach getting some sun with her two children when she heard a news bulletin on her portable radio about “an admitted homosexual” robbing a bank.

headline: Sculpture City
text: A look at public art displays in New York City.

headline: At Edinburgh Fringe, Topical Playwriting Is Seriously Up to the Minute
text: EDINBURGH — Political theater aims to be topical, but a recent presentation here by Theater Uncut had a sense of immediacy that was notable even by that standard.

headline: A Petition to the White House: Give Up the Beer Recipe
text: Most Americans won’t ever drink a beer at the White House, but some beer enthusiasts are hoping they’ll soon be able to have a pint that tastes like its brew.

headline: After Trip of 352 Million Miles, Cheers for 23 Feet on Mars
text: It was a modest test drive: moving forward 15 feet, turning in place 120 degrees, then backing up about 8 feet. The entire trip took about 16 minutes, with most of the time spent stopped as cameras took photographs of the progress.

headline: In Fashion, Are Trends Passé?
text: Here are some style directions from some of the fashion industry’s influential coterie of tastemakers.

headline: Exploring Africa’s Big, Wild Rhino Country
text: How many times in life does anyone get to see an entirely different world, which makes one question all the old familiar things? Rick Bass, an environmental writer based in Montana, poses this question to readers in his new book, “The Black Rhinos of Namibia,” a conservation and adventure story set in the mean expanses of southwest Africa’s Namib Desert.

headline: Racial Comment by Republican Official in Ohio Rekindles Battle Over Early Voting
text: CLEVELAND — A battle over early voting hours in Ohio is flaring again after a top adviser to Gov. John Kasich, a Republican, this week made remarks that Democrats cast as racist, and the Republican secretary of state suspended two local election officials who voted to extend balloting hours in one county.

headline: Regulator Fines Bank for Analysts’ Violations

headline: Changes to Money Market Funds Stall

headline: In Nevada, Voting for ‘None’ Is No Longer an Option

headline: Beauty Spots
text: EAU DE PHONE Serge Lutens, who has done photography and art direction, and is now a celebrated perfumer, is selling his elegant cloche perfume bottles in the United States for the first time, starting this month ($280 to $300 each). The Barneys New York flagship on Madison Avenue is his exclusive retailer; the store also has a telephone number, (212) 833-2425, for those who’d like to call in for their cloche, which contains a choice of 30 signature fragrances, some of them also available for the first time in this country, like Iris Silver Mist and La Myrrhe.

headline: Despite #NBCFail, NBC and Twitter Say Partnership Was Success
text: If you followed the griping by Twitter users  about NBC’s handling of the Olympic Games, you might think the NBC-Twitter Olympics partnership was an epic disaster. NBC’s decision to time-delay most events prompted angry kvetching on Twitter and quickly popularized the hashtag #NBCFail.

headline: Hoping to Get Lucky Again in the Travers
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The pills rattled in the jar announcing that the post-position draw for the Travers Stakes was under way. On the edge of the paddock, the trainer Gary Contessa tried to explain why he had entered a horse named Speightscity that looked as if he had no chance to win the 143rd running of the Midsummer Derby on Saturday.

headline: Aug. 22: Keeping Score on a Busy Polling Day

headline: A Lemon Grower Emphasizes Uses for Citrus Outside the Kitchen
text: AMERICANS on average consume only three pounds of fresh lemons annually — the equivalent of about a dozen medium lemons — compared with the 6.2 pounds Europeans consume, according to data from the Agriculture Department.

headline: Panel Wants Former Judge in Syracuse Kept Off Bench
text: A former family court judge in Syracuse should be barred from returning to the bench, the State Commission on Judicial Conduct ruled Wednesday, after an investigation into an act of sexual misconduct 40 years ago with his niece, 13 years before he became a jurist.

headline: Signs of Revival, Slight but Sure, for Home Sales

headline: Romney Energy Plan Would Expand Oil Drilling on U.S. Land and Offshore
text: HOUSTON — Mitt Romney plans to unveil an energy plan Thursday morning in Hobbs, N.M., that would allow states more control over the development of energy resources on federal lands within their borders, as well as aggressively expand offshore oil and gas drilling — including along the coasts of Virginia and the Carolinas — as part of a broader effort to reach energy independence.

headline: Dolan to Give Benediction at Gathering of the G.O.P.

headline: In Defense of Big Banks

headline: Developments in Iran and Sinai Deepen Israel’s Worries About Egypt

headline: A Deeper Search for Secrets on Mars
text: Astronauts won’t be landing on Mars anytime soon, but, in recent weeks, NASA has made great strides toward exploring the planet more thoroughly than ever before with automated laboratories dropped on the surface. It is a welcome development given increasingly tight budgets for robotic explorations of the solar system.

headline: Snub to City by Lil Wayne Outrages an Official

headline: The Program

headline: The Program
text: It took me a few days to work up the nerve to phone William Binney. As someone already a “target” of the United States government, I found it difficult not to worry about the chain of unintended consequences I might unleash by calling Mr. Binney, a 32-year veteran of the National Security Agency turned whistle-blower. He picked up. I nervously explained I was a documentary filmmaker and wanted to speak to him. To my surprise he replied: “I’m tired of my government harassing me and violating the Constitution. Yes, I’ll talk to you.”

headline: Citigroup Assails Nasdaq Over Flawed Facebook I.P.O.

headline: Ties to Obama Aided in Access for Big Utility

headline: Nina Bawden, Author of ‘Carrie’s War,’ Dies at 87

headline: Preschool Special Education Trade Group Calls for More State Audits and Penalties

headline: Give Small Political Donors a Voice

Howard Berman has raised $3.5 million, while his opponent, Brad Sherman, raised $2.7 million. For both candidates, only 1 percent of their money came from donations under $200.

headline: Another Rebuff for Cleaner Air
text: What’s a federal agency to do? Twice in the last eight years, the Environmental Protection Agency has issued carefully vetted rules aimed at reducing air pollution that crosses state lines — the smog-forming nitrogen oxide pollutants and health-threatening sulfur dioxide that drift eastward from Midwestern power plants. And, in both cases, the agency has been shot down by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

headline: Silicon Valley Techies Fight to Save a Popular but Illegal Haven
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Hacker Dojo is equal parts shared office, lecture hall and after-hours salon for a variety of tinkerers, software coders and entrepreneurs who intend to reinvent the future. The idea for Pinterest was cooked up here. The makers of Pebble watches used the space as their West Coast headquarters. Today, however, it is threatened with extinction. City officials in Mountain View have ordered Hacker Dojo to comply with city regulations for offices or move out.

headline: Matthew Ianniello, the Mafia Boss Known as ‘Matty the Horse,’ Dies at 92
text: Matthew Ianniello, the low-key reputed Genovese crime boss known as “Matty the Horse,” who was convicted of rigging construction bids, skimming union dues and wringing protection money from bar owners, pornography peddlers and topless dancers during a half-century career that, among other highlights, helped transform Times Square into the dingy world capital of peep shows in the 1960s and ’70s, died on Aug. 15 at his home in Old Westbury, on Long Island. He was 92.

headline: Tiny Hawaiian Island Will See if New Owner Tilts at Windmills
text: LANAI CITY, Hawaii — Lanai should be the very picture of tropical tranquillity, the kind of Pacific island where Gilligan set ground. Just 3,135 people live on its 141 square miles. There are no traffic lights, movie theaters or bakeries. There is just one gas station and three main roads. It is ringed with vast and empty beaches, accessible only by four-wheel drive. A visitor can roam its hills for hours without encountering another living being.

headline: William P. Thurston, Theoretical Mathematician, Dies at 65

headline: Healing the Knee, and Then the Psyche
text: Jamal Lewis’s right knee might have been injured, but his foot was fine, and he used it to mash the gas pedal in his car. It was Oct. 4, 1998. He drove along Interstate 40 in Tennessee. First east. Then back west again, crying and agonizing all the way. The day before, Lewis, then a sophomore running back for the University of Tennessee, had torn his lateral collateral ligament in a game against Auburn, an injury that abruptly ended a promising season.

headline: Romney Strategists Say They’ll Stay the Course Amid Focus on Abortion
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney’s campaign advisers have concluded that they do not need any major adjustments in strategy to respond to the new focus on abortion and reproductive rights caused by Representative Todd Akin, betting that their candidate’s economic message will still resonate with female voters after the controversy over Mr. Akin’s remarks about “legitimate rape” subsides.

headline: Mets Add to Woes, Despite Solid Start by Harvey
text: The Mets wasted another strong start from the rookie Matt Harvey, failing to overtake the lowly Colorado Rockies during a 5-2 loss Wednesday night at Citi Field.

headline: Georgia: 2 Waffle House Plotters Are Sentenced
text: Two of the four men who federal officials said plotted terrorist activities from a booth at a North Georgia Waffle House were sentenced to five years in prison on Wednesday for conspiring to obtain an unregistered explosive device and silencer. Defense lawyers had argued that the men were egged on by an informant and that recordings of their plot showed nothing more than old men bragging. Prosecutors said the men were members of a loose-knit militia group that had scouted federal buildings in Atlanta to attack and had planned to kill people. Judge Richard W. Story of Federal District Court said that while people have the right to talk about what they want, “when they start buying bombs and silencers, I’m sorry, we have crossed the line.” Lawyers for the men, Frederick Thomas, 73, and Dan Roberts, 68, said the sentence was part of a plea deal that includes 100 hours of community service. The other men charged, Ray Adams and Samuel Crump, both in their 60s, plan to go to trial. They are charged with conspiracy and attempting to make the poison ricin from castor beans.

headline: With Heat Turned Up, Yankees Sit Down, One by One

headline: Life, Interrupted: Six Ways to Cope With Cancer
text: People are always giving advice to cancer patients. Whether it is nutritional advice or doctor recommendations or tips on how to quell the nausea that accompanies chemotherapy, just as soon as people hear you are sick they usually want to find a way to help. Most of the advice is welcome and encouraging, though in some cases you’re just not in the mood to hear what someone has learned because you’re too busy treading water.

headline: Simon Says Don’t Use Flashcards
text: Parents who want to stimulate their children’s brain development often focus on things like early reading, flashcards and language tapes. But a growing body of research suggests that playing certain kinds of childhood games may be the best way to increase a child’s ability to do well in school. Variations on games like Freeze Tag and Simon Says require relatively high levels of executive function, testing a child’s ability to pay attention, remember rules and exhibit self-control — qualities that also predict academic success.

On Aug.15, rumors of possible violence led several thousand people from India’s northeastern region to flee Bangalore. The exodus continued over the next few days as thousands flocked to train stations in Bangalore, Chennai and Pune, while Indian leaders attempted to restore calm.

headline: New Orleans Saints, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: No one really knows whether the New Orleans Saints can overcome the distractions and fallout of the bounties scandal. Their situation – Coach Sean Payton suspended for the year, the interim head coach Joe Vitt suspended for the first six games, General Manager Mickey Loomis suspended for the first eight – is unprecedented in the N.F.L. Until Wednesday, it was still unknown who, exactly, would be in charge for the first month and a half of the season while Vitt was away.  (The Saints chose offensive line coach Aaron Kromer.)

headline: Shuck and Awe
text: I don’t need to tell you that there are alternatives to eating corn straight from the cob: you’ve probably adored creamed corn for most of your life. (Possibly you’ve never made it from scratch, and if that’s the case, throw some kernels in a pan with some butter, and after a little while, add some cream along with seasoning. Heat. Eat.) But it’s equally probable that you haven’t done much else with corn kernels taken off the cob. This isn’t a revolutionary process (it’s as old as corn), nor is it difficult: Stand shucked corn upright in a bowl and use a paring knife to cut down along the kernels, as close to the cob as you can. Really dig that knife in — you want everything you can get from the cob. Corn kernels are a revelation, assuming, of course, that the corn is good to begin with. And right now, it should be (and it should be just fine raw, as it is in the first three of these ideas). So before corn costs $6 an ear next year, go for it.

headline: Venus and Serena Against the World
text: There’s video that exists of Venus and Serena Williams playing tennis when they were kids — 8 and 7, respectively — in the late ’80s, on unshaded but otherwise decent-looking public courts in California. This is not one of the clips you’ve maybe seen, taken from various news segments, but an earlier, stranger video, made by their father and longtime coach, Richard Williams, as a kind of audition tape for the tennis-instructional guru Vic Braden, ostensibly requesting an invitation to Braden’s camp, although the real reason for it, you can’t help feel in watching, simply was to let Braden know that greatness had arrived in the world. Richard’s face in the film as he presents the girls to Braden seems, as it does so often, on the brink of laughter. This was in Compton, the low-income, gang-afflicted hub city outside Los Angeles, an area made infamous by many a rap song. Although they enjoyed about as stable an upbringing as you could have in Compton back then, its problems were no mere abstraction: they supposedly knew to lie down on the court when gunshots rang out in the park. And there’s a story that Richard, when asked what he would do if his daughters ever won a Grand Slam, said he would go back and try to help the Crips who sometimes looked out for the girls during their practice sessions. “Venus Williams Is Straight Outta Compton!” read an early promotional poster their father made, to post on telephone poles. He billed the two as celebrities before they were even famous. That was how you did it. Not fake it till you make it. You decided what you were. First you had the belief, and then you had the training. “Belief and training,” Venus told me a couple of weeks ago when I met with her in Cincinnati, where she and Serena were playing in a tournament just days after returning from the Olympics. “That was unconquerable.”
