text: Scenes from the 1977 U.S. Open.

headline: Queens Was Burning, Too
text: On a Sunday night midway through the 1977 U.S. Open, nearly 7,000 people gathered in the stadium at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, for a third-round match between the ninth-seeded Eddie Dibbs and an 18-year-old named John McEnroe, who was making his debut at the tournament that year. Two months earlier, McEnroe surprised the tennis world by reaching the semifinals of Wimbledon as a qualifier. His feathery touch dazzled the British fans while his combustive behavior led the British tabloids to nickname him Superbrat. Now McEnroe, who grew up in nearby Douglaston, looked poised to make a deep run at the Open. First, though, he had to get past Dibbs, a short, speedy player known as Fast Eddie.

headline: Tokyo Stock Exchange Completes Tender Offer for Osaka Rival
text: TOKYO — The Tokyo Stock Exchange said on Thursday that it had completed a $1.1 billion public tender offer for its smaller rival, the Osaka Securities Exchange, moving closer to a merger that could bolster Japan’s standing as an Asian financial hub.

headline: New Scenes Filmed in L.A. Said to Replace Theater Shoot-Up in ‘Gangster Squad’
text: LOS ANGELES — In the heat of another too-hot afternoon, this city’s Chinatown — the real one, not the myth explored in the movie with that name — was littered on Wednesday with the repercussions from last month’s theater shootings in Aurora, Colo.

headline: Ban Ki-moon’s Tehran Trip: Damned if He Does …
text: LONDON — The role of Secretary General of the United Nations must sometimes seem like the ultimate no-win job.

headline: South Korea Returns Letter on Islets From Japanese Leader
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A letter from the Japanese prime minister to the South Korean president was refused by both governments on Thursday, as the countries’ latest quarrel over a set of disputed islets spawned a curious spat over diplomatic protocol.

headline: Now, the Next Stage
text: JAKE GYLLENHAAL made a deal with himself 10 years ago: For every three movies he made, he would perform in a play.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Opinion Report: Mega Donations
text: From the editorial page

headline: A Dozen Recipes for Corn Off the Cob
text: For most of these recipes, use 4 to 6 ears of corn, which should work out to between 3 and 4 cups of kernels, depending on the size of the ears.

headline: Clinton Appeals to Voters in New Obama Ad
text: 11:02 p.m. | Updated A more recent version of this post appears here.

headline: Which Way Is the River?
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Thursday Reading: Father’s Age Linked to Risk of Autism and Schizophrenia
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Daily Report: At the Top of Google, Fewer Women
text: Senior women at Google are losing ground, reports Claire Cain Miller in The New York Times. Since Larry Page became chief executive and reorganized Google last year, women have been pushed out of his inner circle and passed over for promotions. They include Marissa Mayer, who left last month to run Yahoo after being sidelined at Google.

headline: A Tale of Two Territories
text: PORTREE, Scotland — Earlier this month, ahead of the Edinburgh International Book Festival, my wife Penny and I decided to go hiking on the Isle of Skye. We were staying outside Portree, the main town on the island, at the foot of Loch Sligachan. From the window of our room we could see the Black Cuillin Mountains, their towering summits silhouetted against the sky as if drawn by a mighty hand.

headline: Saving Serious Ryan
text: There has, of course, been some pushback against my column pointing out that the Very Serious Paul Ryan is not, in fact, serious at all. Some of this pushback takes the form of assertions that he must be serious, because the Congressional Budget Office scored his plan and found that it led to lower debt.

headline: Stupid Animal Trick: Flying Sheep and Deer Among Hawaii’s Islands
text: Audrey McAvoy, an Associated Press reporter in Hawaii, has filed a fascinating piece chronicling one of the human activities that have created the global mashup of animals and plants that is ecology in the Anthropocene. Here’s a snippet (as you read, keep in mind that islands are particularly vulnerable to serious environmental disruption from introduced species):

headline: Francisco d’Anconia on Money
text: Dave Weigel made a great catch the other day: he notes that Paul Ryan has said that his views on monetary policy are based on Francisco d’Anconia’s speech in Atlas Shrugged.

headline: Celebrities Join to Oppose Upstate Gas Drilling
text: More than 140 artists and celebrities, including Lady Gaga and Paul McCartney, have signed on to a coalition to try to persuade Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to ban the use of hydraulic fracturing — also known as hydrofracking or fracking — to extract natural gas in parts of New York State.

headline: Madonna Alters Concert Video That Had Angered French Political Party
text: Madonna appears to have conceded in a war of words (and pictures) with France’s National Front political party, and has toned down an image shown in her concerts that once depicted Marine Le Pen, the president of that far-right party, with a swastika on her head.

headline: Pragmatism as a Guiding Political Trait
text: NEW YORK — After to speaking this week to Glenn Hubbard, a top Romney advisor and the dean of the Columbia Business School, I decided to focus my column on the big economic choice that Americans face in this election. But Mr. Hubbard also had some interesting things to say about Mr. Romney as a person and as a politician.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Insatiable Critic: A highly personal and heartbreaking celebration of the life of the photographer Steven Richter, Gael Greene’s partner and dining companion of 27 years, who recently died at the age of 74. Titled “Farewell Steven: Letting Go,” its last sentence reads: “Not yet ready to be alone.” – Glenn Collins

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Politics Bores the Networks, and Harry Tempts British Papers
text: Confident that the presidential election this year lacks the drama of 2008, ABC, CBS and NBC are cutting back coverage of the conventions, Jeremy W. Peters reports. This means, among other things, that the first night of the four-night Republican National Convention will be skipped entirely by the networks, including a speech by Ann Romney, Mitt Romney’s wife. The other three nights will get an hour each. (The Democratic convention is only three nights long, but NBC will offer two of its three hours of coverage on the final night so it can carry an N.F.L. football game earlier in the week.)

headline: Power Failures in Venezuela
text: Venezuelans are used to the routine. A computer-generated Venezuelan flag flutters on the screen, followed by a ponderous announcement: “This is a broadcast from the Ministry of People’s Power for Communication and Information of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela and by the national network of radio and television.” Forget about that baseball game. This is a cadena, or chain, meaning it’s a chained broadcast and every single channel has to show it. (And every radio station, too!)

headline: In France, All Eyes on P.$.G.
text: PARIS — These days it seems any discussion about Paris Saint-Germain begins with a look at the money the club has spent since Qatar Sports Investment bought the team.

headline: Full-Time Work Means Better Health for Mothers
text: “This is not about advice for women,” the University of Akron sociologist Adrianne M. Frech said of her latest research, which showed that women who work steadily full-time after the birth of their first child report better physical health than women who don’t.

headline: Australia Increases Refugee Quota in Broad Immigration Reform
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Julia Gillard on Thursday ordered an immediate increase in the number of refugees that her country accepts yearly, part of an immigration reform package aimed at encouraging migrants to use official channels for asylum rather than long and dangerous boat journeys.

headline: New Label Alert | Nellie Partow
text: All week, T is introducing the lines to look out for this fall.

headline: Eye Candy or Eyesore?
text: Public art makes me think of what the Conceptualist Douglas Huebler once said: “The world is full of objects, more or less interesting; I do not wish to add any more.” That may be a funny thing for an artist to say, but if you live in a place as densely packed with objects of all kinds as New York City, you may appreciate its wisdom. Nevertheless, for better or worse, temporary public art displays pop up all over the city during the warm seasons in hopes of adding beauty and zest to the urban fabric.

headline: Who Counts as Middle Class?
text: As I’ve written before, Americans don’t have a great sense of where they fall in the income distribution, or even what the income distribution actually looks like. Now, in a new report, the Pew Research Center has given us an update on the types of Americans most likely to call themselves middle class, and the answer doesn’t necessarily have a lot to do whether respondents earn close to the median income.

headline: Monk Competition Announces Semifinalists
text: Twelve semifinalists have been selected for the 25th Annual Thelonious Monk International Jazz Competition, to be held on Sept. 22 and 23 in Washington. Presented by the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz, the competition is widely regarded as the most prestigious of its kind, with the winner receiving a $25,000 music scholarship and a recording contract with the Concord Music Group.

headline: An Innocent in the Ivy League
text: The conservative movement loves an innocent. Better yet if he has attended an Ivy League college and witnessed the debauchery of the elites firsthand. For this particular position, Nathan Harden, the author of “Sex and God at Yale,” possesses impeccable credentials. He was home-schooled, was already married when he got to college and had worshiped the institution so blindly that he was bound to be disappointed.

headline: Academic Battleground
text: When generals prepare to “fight the last war,” as the saying goes, they’re bound to be surprised by new enemies deploying new tactics over new terrain. On the evidence of Bruce Bawer’s fighting-mad book, “The Victims’ Revolution: The Rise of Identity Studies and the Closing of the Liberal Mind,” this rule holds true for the academic culture wars as well.

headline: A Short Film Set in Trinidad
text: “Doubles With Slight Pepper,” a short film by Ian Harnarine, is about a bittersweet reconciliation between a father who returns to Trinidad and his son, who sells the island’s staple food, doubles.

headline: A World at Your Fingertips
text: If there’s one advantage the app revolution has brought to the book world, it’s that often unwieldy tomes like atlases can be transformed into vivid, dynamic programs that bring the world outside traditional books to life — through animation, music, photos, videos and more. That they do so while weighing less than a cinder block is a nice perk, too.

headline: School of Hard Knocks
text: Most readers of The New York Times probably subscribe to what Paul Tough calls “the cognitive hypothesis”: the belief “that success today depends primarily on cognitive skills — the kind of intelligence that gets measured on I.Q. tests, including the abilities to recognize letters and words, to calculate, to detect patterns — and that the best way to develop these skills is to practice them as much as possible, beginning as early as possible.” In his new book, “How Children Succeed,” Tough sets out to replace this assumption with what might be called the character hypothesis: the notion that noncognitive skills, like persistence, self-control, curiosity, conscientiousness, grit and self-confidence, are more crucial than sheer brainpower to achieving success.

headline: Grown-Up Angst
text: Even when she was MOLLY RINGWALD, Molly Ringwald wasn’t content just being Molly Ringwald. In 1988 the teen idol reteamed with her “Pretty in Pink” co-star Andrew McCarthy for “Fresh Horses,” a talky drama about a tough, sullen Kentucky country girl who catches the eye of an engaged engineering student. For moviegoers who went in expecting the plucky high schooler she played in the earlier movie, or “Sixteen Candles,” “Fresh Horses” was a real downer. The group of much more popular friends to whom I recommended it abandoned me halfway through for “Ernest Saves Christmas” and never hung out with me again. I loved it, though — in part because you could see how hard Ringwald was working to be not just a teen-movie star but an actress. That she couldn’t yet pull it off made “Fresh Horses” poignant, and no less enjoyable — and as fans of the ABC Family series “The Secret Life of the American Teenager” know, in the end she has become an actress, and not a bad one at all.

headline: Buccaneers and Bullion
text: Alas for the unintended cruelty of a book-reviewing aunt! On the long ride to catch the sunset from the dunes above Lake Michigan, I handed my restless 7-year-old nephew a book from my beach bag: Robert Louis Stevenson’s “Treasure Island.” Instantly and intently, he began reading aloud, propelled by the excitement of discovery. Later, back at the cottage, he asked, “Can I have my book now?” Guiltily, I told him he’d have to wait: I needed it for a story I was writing about “Treasure Island” and its new sequel, “Silver,” by the British poet Andrew Motion. I felt like a blackhearted mutineer.

headline: Seeking a New York Audience for a Film Rooted in Trinidad
text: Ian Harnarine was studying physics at the University of Illinois in Chicago and preparing himself for a life in academia when he realized that he had lost his passion for science.

headline: Built to Last
text: Fifty years ago this fall, undergraduates were assigned their first Norton Anthology, often the only required text for a college freshman’s survey of English literature. Here, M. H. Abrams, the founding general editor, and Stephen Greenblatt, the current general editor, discuss the history of the anthology, the challenges facing English literature survey courses and the enduring question, Why study literature?

headline: Save the Date
text: Admit it. You’ve fantasized about time travel. You’ve wondered what it would be like to visit your own past and slap some sense into your younger self. Perhaps you’ve imagined having dinner with Leonardo, or sitting in the emperor’s box in the Roman Colosseum.

headline: Drawn Out
text: Why do we draw and write? Toddlers, protean in their creativity, exuberantly deploy any drawing implement within reach. “Only on paper!” I used to admonish nervously, reliving the maternal wrath I once incurred after “decorating” my childhood bedroom wall with wild-style wax crayons.

headline: Mutant Chronicles
text: The middle school years conspire to make all boys feel like mutants. This is a circumstance two middle-grade books acknowledge in a fashion that is mercifully more creepy-crawly than touchy-feely.

headline: Bookshelf: First Day
text: IT’S TIME FOR PRESCHOOL!  By Esmé Raji Codell.Illustrated by Sue Ramá.  40 pp. Greenwillow Books/HarperCollins Publishers. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: An App for Cartoon Multitasking
text: You know how your children act when they are overstimulated? Well, here’s an app that pretty much guarantees that behavior.

headline: Identity Crises
text: Individualism. Embracing differences. Following your dream. Being free to be you and me. These are among the great themes of American children’s literature. They’re among the great themes of American adult literature too — of America, period. Figures as diverse as Ron Paul and Barack Obama, Ayn Rand and Mark Twain, John Ford and Wes Anderson would, I think, agree. Each in his or her own special way!

headline: Bodies and Soul
text: As surely as a gardener plants flowers or a mason lays stone, a writer puts obstacles in the path of love. Your families hate each other. Your cultures clash. One of you is rich and one of you is poor, or one of you is naïf and one of you is whore. Maybe there’s a prickly vampirism issue, maybe a pesky time-travel quirk. It’s always something.

headline: Bookshelf: Numbers
text: ONE TWO THAT’S MY SHOE!  Written and illustrated by Alison Murray.  32 pp. Disney-Hyperion Books. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6)

headline: Spellbound
text: Teenagers typically turn to fantasy as a means of escaping the rigors and disappointments of adolescence, and many authors specialize in creating universes entirely separate from our own. But in “The Girl With Borrowed Wings,” a frankly spellbinding love story, Rinsai Rossetti shows the power of fantasy when it coincides with, rather than opposes, what may be a grim reality.

headline: One Man’s Tale of Two Koreas, Changed Allegiances, Torture and Fear
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The bizarre twists of fate and intrigue that have shadowed Kim Young-hwan, once one of South Korea’s best-known student activists, read like the plot of a Bond movie.

headline: Tell Me
text: Native American lore tells of animals so entranced by powerful tales they forget to gather winter provisions, a myth that makes vivid our innate hunger for storytelling. But sometimes what most satisfies our need for stories is telling the tale ourselves.

headline: Can You Keep a Secret?
text: Unlike her Newbery Medal-­winning novel, “When You Reach Me,” in which time travel is the subtext to all the interwoven story lines, Rebecca Stead’s new book, “Liar & Spy,” is firmly grounded in the here and now. What the two do share is a mood of shimmery unrest. Part coming­-of-age tale, part mystery, “Liar & Spy” takes place in contemporary Brooklyn and revolves around a seventh-grade loner and misfit named Georges. Cast out of his own home after his father loses his job and the family sells their house to make ends meet — and cast off by his best friend in favor of the popular clique — Georges finds himself living in a new apartment building with a cast of eccentric neighbors. These include the similarly aged and oddly named Safer, the building’s resident dog walker as well as a budding spy; Safer’s candy-obsessed younger sister, Candy; and their bird-watching older brother, Pigeon.

headline: Hanging on Every Word
text: It may be telling that “The Fantastic Flying Books of Mr. Morris Lessmore,” a kind of totem to the unmatched joys of reading, appeared in two different screen adaptations before making the transition into print. Winning an Oscar earlier this year for best animated short after appearing, last summer, as a lauded animated app, William Joyce’s story of a natty Southern loner was a feat of digital imagination, a dazzlingly polished animation and a wordless tribute to a fading literary age. Now, realized at last as a children’s book, his tale gains elegance but loses depth. The print-edition “Morris Lessmore” is a stylishly paced, vividly illustrated parable for young readers, yet it somehow lacks the dreamy creativity of its animated precursors. Ultimately, Joyce’s book tells us something we may already suspect: that storytelling these days has a broader canvas than the hallowed space within the ­library doors.

headline: Life Backstage
text: The parenting-book world is flooded with jeremiads about how tween culture breeds sociopaths and prostitots, ergo we should unplug the Internet. But this is a narrative belied by the thriving field of age-appropriate books epitomized by the nice-girls-finish-first graphic novels of Raina Telgemeier, poetic illustrator of middle-school life.

headline: Aftermath
text: Shortly after the 2002 release of “Big Mouth & Ugly Girl,” her first novel for young adults, Joyce Carol Oates noted in an interview that young adult fiction is “just stripped-down adult fiction with more dialogue and less description. In adult fiction you do things with language — for example, you might repeat certain adjectives for an atmospheric effect. In young adult fiction, that isn’t done, and the chapters tend to be shorter.”

headline: Bookshelf: Funny Folk Tales
text: GOLDILOCKS AND THE THREE DINOSAURS  Written and illustrated by Mo Willems.  40 pp. Balzer & Bray/HarperCollins Publishers. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 7)

headline: Fear and Self-Loathing
text: When you’re a teenager, especially if you’re a girl, it’s deceptively easy to wreak havoc, if unintentionally, on your body. The pressure to appear flawless and to fit in without ever breaking a sweat requires putting your best poker face forward while shoving the messiness of adolescence under the bed. Skipping meals? Why not? Sticking two fingers down your throat after too many carbs? Easy as pie. Becoming a little fast and loose with alcohol and drugs, or negotiating a quick slice of the knife across your inner thigh? It happens all the time.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: LIONEL ASBO: State of England,  by Martin Amis. (Knopf, $25.95.) The Dickensian theme of Amis’s novel is the corrupting influence of money, as his antihero, a career criminal with a vestigial conscience, wins the lottery and is baffled by legitimate wealth.

headline: Paperback Row
text: ROCK THE CASBAH: Rage and Rebellion Across the Islamic World,  by Robin Wright. (Simon & Schuster, $17.) Wright, a veteran foreign correspondent and the author of “Dreams and Shadows: The Future of the Middle East” (2008), examines the causes and repercussions of revolts against autocratic rule in countries like Tunisia, Egypt, Libya and Yemen. Traveling across the region, she profiles poets, playwrights, feminists, TV imams and others working toward a “counter-jihad” to reclaim Islam from militants who crave perpetual holy war.

headline: In the Shadow of War
text: A convention of novels aimed at children in the middle-grade years holds that whatever problem a girl confronts, her parents will not be the ones to help. This often makes sense both psychologically and narratively. These are the years when children begin to differentiate themselves from their parents and learn to fight their own battles. And really, how exciting would a story be in which our heroine, say, is ganged up on by other girls, but then tells her mother, who steps in, does all the right things, and every­thing’s fine?

headline: Universal Struggles
text: Businesses are quick to lump together tweens and teenagers into one big marketing opportunity, but when it comes to books, younger readers are very different from their young adult counterparts. How do you define that shifting period of transitions between the ages of 8 and 10, or 7 and 10, when children read at very different rates, with different aptitudes and for different reasons?

headline: Batman’s New Perch Above Gotham: Your iPad
text: From the shadows, Batman swoops down and lands on your iPad to fight a gang of thugs. But fear not! He’ll throw a lot of punches, but he won’t scratch your screen.

headline: Up Front
text: This week, Hanna Rosin reviews Nathan Harden’s “Sex and God at Yale,” an investigation into oversexualized college life — and its dangers to young women. A senior editor at The Atlantic and Slate, Rosin conducted her own campus research for her forthcoming book, “The End of Men” — although she came to markedly different conclusions. She maintains that the “hookup culture” Harden decries might be “integral” to women’s success in college. Why? Casual relationships “won’t derail future life plans.”

headline: Fantasy Football: Running Back Primer
text: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy. Jason also blogs at blackfifty9razor.com.

headline: Bookshelf: First Day
text: New picture books about heading off to school.

headline: Republican Immigration Platform Backs ‘Self-Deportation’
text: Republicans have adopted a party platform on immigration that would require employers nationwide to verify workers’ legal status and deny federal financing to universities that allow illegal immigrant students to enroll at lower in-state tuition rates.

headline: Undeterred by Drug Testing in Baseball
text: At first glance, the news that pitcher Bartolo Colon has tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs is about as surprising as the Cookie Monster testing positive for chocolate chips. He is 39, having resurrected his injury-plagued career with help from a fishy-sounding stem cell procedure last year and despite a physique that makes it clear his performance-enhancing drugs are hidden in double cheeseburgers.

headline: Bookshelf: Numbers
text: New picture books offer creative approaches to counting.

headline: Bookshelf: Funny Folk Tales
text: Variations on Goldilocks, the Three Little Pigs and more.

headline: State Agency Web Sites May Work Business Hours
text: In this day and age, when routine chores like paying bills and ordering groceries can be done online at anytime, day or night, some New York State agencies have Web sites that have yet to join the 24/7 world.

headline: Half of Homeowners Under 40 Are Still Underwater
text: The country’s underwater homes are slowly resurfacing as the housing market improves. But younger borrowers are still more likely to be submerged, a new report from real estate site Zillow.com finds.

headline: Image of the Day: August 23
text: A procession marking the end of the Sindhi fasting festival of Jhulelal Chaliha in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.

headline: The Lowdown | Michael David Quattlebaum Jr. and Mykki Blanco
text: Hip-hop and homosexuality have been thrust into the same uncomfortably small room, most recently on the occasion of Frank Ocean’s much-discussed coming out and the stream of controversial shows of support or slander that followed. But the community is poised to have to swallow a much bigger bite of acceptance with the virtually unprecedented marriage of rap and cross-dressing embodied by the artist known as Mykki Blanco.

headline: Business Day Live | August 23, 2012
text: For the housing market, the beginning of a recovery. | Fed officials push for action to support the economy. | A derailed effort to change money market funds.

headline: Business Day Live: Signs of Revival, Slight but Sure, for Home Sales
text: For the housing market, the beginning of a recovery. | Fed officials push for action to support the economy. | A derailed effort to change money market funds.

headline: With Multimedia Show, Ford Looks to Give Fusion an Edge
text: Ford brought its redesigned Fusion sedan to meet some artists and artisans Tuesday night at Eyebeam in Chelsea. A multimedia exhibition, called “Wall to Wall: The Fusion Collective,” filled the event space with mirrors and fog, pulsating lights and towering speakers.

headline: Despite Good Intentions, a Fresco in Spain Is Ruined
text: MADRID — A case of suspected vandalism in a church in a northeastern village in Spain has turned out to be probably the worst art restoration project of all time.

headline: Key Democratic State Parties Have Financial Edge
text: While President Obama and Mitt Romney crisscross the nation raising money for their campaigns, in the battleground states Republican and Democratic organizations have been laying the groundwork for voter organization and turnout for the November election. Much of the money for those efforts comes from the national party organizations — the Democratic and Republican National Committees, plus several Congressional party arms — that has been sent to the states from Washington.

headline: JPMorgan’s Former Leader Makes a Case for Big Banks
text: More than a decade ago, William B. Harrison Jr. and Sanford I. Weill pioneered the model of the financial behemoth from their perches atop JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup. But today, the two Wall Street veterans hardly see eye to eye.

headline: Sonia Gandhi Ranked Sixth Most Powerful Woman in the World
text: Sonia Gandhi, the Congress party president and chairwoman of the coalition government running the country, is India’s most powerful woman and the sixth most powerful woman in the world, according to Forbes magazine.

headline: Polls Highlight Senate Races in Swing States
text: Democratic incumbents have an edge over their challengers in the Florida and Ohio Senate races, while in Wisconsin, fresh from winning the Republican primary, former Gov. Tommy Thompson has a six-point advantage over Representative Tammy Baldwin.

headline: Drawbacks to Banking Accounts for Seniors
text: Caveat check writer.

headline: Walking the Walk, Cane in Hand
text: THE sight of an actor lost in thought, murmuring lines en route to an audition, is hardly uncommon in a city’s theater district. But passengers on an Amtrak train from Philadelphia to New York one morning two years ago may have noticed something far rarer: a performer prepping a bit of silent-film high jinks.

headline: China Confronts Mounting Piles of Unsold Goods
text: GUANGZHOU, China — After three decades of torrid growth, China is encountering an unfamiliar problem with its newly struggling economy: a huge buildup of unsold goods that is cluttering shop floors, clogging car dealerships and filling factory warehouses.

headline: Lennon’s Killer Denied Parole a 7th Time
text: Mark David Chapman has been denied parole, for the seventh time, in the murder ofJohn Lennon, the New York State corrections department said Thursday.

headline: California Dreams, Iranian Décor
text: In 1978, my mother packed two maroon, leatherette suitcases, and she, my father and I boarded a plane for the United States. Just about everyone who could leave Iran had done so already; friends and relatives had been selling off their houses for months. But “revolution” and “exile” were not words my family applied to our circumstances. We left our apartment on Pahlavi Avenue completely intact. The two suitcases suggested, if not a vacation, at most a temporary absence.

headline: General Notes Taliban Coercion in Some Attacks on Troops
text: WASHINGTON — The senior commander in Afghanistan made new allowances on Thursday that Taliban influence could play a large role in attacks by Afghan security forces on Americans, saying that up to one-quarter of the killings could be caused by Taliban infiltration or coercion. But he reiterated that most of such insider attacks have still been attributed to personal grievances and animosities.

headline: Indian Government Casts a Wide, Puzzling Net Over Internet
text: Earlier this week, the Indian government acknowledged that it had asked internet service providers to block about 250 web pages in an effort to contain ethnic tensions between Muslims and people from the northeast.

headline: Rowling to Make U.S Appearance to Promote Her First Novel for Adults
text: J.K. Rowling is coming to America to promote her first novel for adults, “The Casual Vacancy,” her publisher has announced. Ms. Rowling will appear at one public event, an onstage interview at Jazz at Lincoln Center with the author Ann Patchett on Oct. 16. She will also take questions from the audience and sign copies of her book for audience members. Tickets go on sale Sept. 10, starting at $37, a price that includes a copy of the book.

headline: Levon Helm Tribute Is Planned for October
text: John Mayer, Gregg Allman, Joe Walsh and other prominent musicians plan to hold a large benefit concert to raise money for Levon Helm’s estate on Oct. 3 at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., Mr. Helm’s family announced.

headline: Lincoln’s Letter to the Editor
text: On Aug. 19, 1862 Horace Greeley, the editor of The New York Tribune, published a long “open letter” to President Lincoln in his newspaper. Titled “The Prayer for Twenty Millions,” the letter demanded that Lincoln immediately move to end slavery, not only in the Confederacy, but also in the loyal slave states – Delaware, Maryland, Kentucky, and Missouri, as well as in those parts of Tennessee under control of the United States. The letter was noteworthy as a bold, widely read attack on the president by a major figure in his own party. Even more noteworthy, though, was Lincoln’s response.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Dogs’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Based on Donations, N.H.L.’s American Owners Prefer Republican Candidates
text: N.H.L. owners are very wealthy and engaged in battle with a union, so it would not be surprising to find that when it comes to American electoral politics, they lean strongly Republican.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Preventing Abortions…With Lethal Force
text: Via Talking Points Memo

headline: Even if Akin Wanted to Quit Race, It Would Be Difficult
text: Despite the firestorm over his comments about rape and pregnancy, Representative Todd Akin says he has no plans to drop out as the Republican Senate nominee in Missouri.

headline: What the Sound and Fury Over Best Buy May Signify
text: The squabbling between Best Buy and its founder and principal stockholder, Richard M. Schulze, appears about as mature as sibling teenagers fighting over the only car.

headline: F.T.C. Settles With Marketers of Ab Circle Pro
text: There are few easy ways to lose weight quickly, but that has not stopped some marketers from making claims to the contrary, especially for products pitched on late-night infomercials.

headline: Facebook Speeds Up iPhone and iPad Apps
text: Facebook on Thursday released major upgrades to its iPhone and iPad apps. Those who have suffered from the sluggishness of the current apps can breathe a collective sigh of relief: these new versions are much faster.

headline: Pairs Well With Peanuts? Wine Tasting on Delta
text: In-flight food has gotten regular upgrades — this spring alone British Airways prepared a menu with the chef Simon Hulstone, and ANA enlisted the French pastry chef Pierre Hermé. Now, Delta has turned its attention to oenophiles, who know that a chewy wine doesn’t mean you’ll need a toothpick after a glass.

headline: Vain Glorious | Braid, Not Frayed!
text: Braids have been around forever, of course, but they are morphing from a Nordic, tight style into chic, messier plaits, thanks to modern-day heroines like Jennifer Lawrence (as Katniss Everdeen in “The Hunger Games”) and Emilia Clarke, who plays the warrior princess Daenerys Targaryen on “Game of Thrones.”

headline: Facebook Reorients Itself for a Small-Screen World
text: MENLO PARK, Calif. — At Facebook’s headquarters here, mobile devices are everywhere. The first thing visitors do is sign in on iPads at the front desk. Employees at the campus coffee shop use iPads as cash registers. Instead of sending e-mails, Facebook employees prefer to use the company’s messaging system, which pops up new messages on both mobile devices and PCs.

headline: Sony Pictures the Latest Studio to Make Broadway Push
text: Sony Pictures Entertainment has signed a five-year deal with the Broadway producer Scott Sanders (“Evita,” “The Color Purple”) to mount stage versions of the studio’s films, with their first project being a musical adaptation of the 1982 Dustin Hoffman comedy “Tootsie.” The deal, which was announced on Thursday, represents the latest move by several Hollywood film studios to capitalize on theatergoers’ appetite – particularly tourists visiting New York – for musicals based on movies or books; most Broadway musicals these days are adaptations, like the top-grossing shows “Wicked” and “The Lion King” and new hits like the Tony Award winner “Once” and the Disney musical “Newsies.”

headline: Author of Book on Bin Laden Raid Is Identified
text: The anonymous Navy SEAL member who has written a book about the raid that killed Osama bin Laden remained anonymous for less than 24 hours.

headline: Report Finds Americans Wasteful of Food
text: Forty percent of the food Americans have available to them goes uneaten, according to a report released this week by the Natural Resources Defense Council. Most of this nutrient-rich uneaten food ends up rotting in landfills.

headline: China Forces Ethnic Kachin Refugees Back to a Conflict Zone in Myanmar’s North
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — The authorities in southwestern China are forcibly evicting thousands of encamped ethnic Kachin refugees who fled a renewed civil war in neighboring Myanmar, pushing them back into the conflict zone in Kachin State in northern Myanmar, according to foreign human rights researchers, political analysts and two people in Kachin State.

headline: Bulgaria Plots Return to Olympic Prominence
text: PLOVDIV, Bulgaria — Svetla Otzetova, a grande dame of Bulgarian rowing, wore a perfectly pressed blouse, and her brow somehow managed to stay dry despite the stifling heat.

headline: Far, Maybe Too Far, Into the Yukon
text: WE watched the pot closely, feeding the fire beneath it with whatever damp, gnarled sticks we could scavenge from the tree-starved tundra around us — but still it didn’t boil.

headline: Self-Deportation
text: The Republican platform drafting committee has adopted the “self-deportation” immigration “solution” that Mitt Romney embraced during the primaries. This is the idea that it is not only possible to force 11 million undocumented immigrants to leave the country by making them miserable, but also desirable–presumably because Americans are itching to get back to farm labor, domestic and restaurant work, small-scale entrepreneurship and other backbreaking, minimal-wage jobs that illegal immigrants have stolen from them.

headline: They’re Not Making Any More (Well, Almost)
text: Two facts stand out from Thursday’s report on new home sales in July.

headline: Jets Demote Often-Criticized Lineman
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — As a boy in his bedroom in Davenport, Iowa, before going to sleep every night, Austin Howard prayed over and over that he would become a starter in the N.F.L.

headline: For “Lawless” Car Wrangler, a Potent Fidelity to the Ford V-8
text: My father grew up during the Depression in a mountain valley in North Carolina. The only person in the valley who owned a car in those days, he was fond of saying, was the moonshiner’s wife. The moonshiner himself was in prison, leaving his wife to quite literally run the business from a battered Model T Ford.

headline: South African Panel Named to Investigate Mine Shooting
text: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa’s president appointed a panel of judges on Thursday to investigate the events that led up to the police shooting that killed 34 miners on strike at a platinum mine last week.

headline: Big Income Losses for Those Near Retirement
text: 7:24 p.m. | Updated with additional details.

headline: Craig Zadan and Neil Meron to Produce Academy Awards Show
text: LOS ANGELES — The next Oscar show has found its producers, and they are a very musical pair. Craig Zadan and Neil Meron, whose films include the musicals “Chicago” and “Hairspray,” have agreed to produce the 85th Academy Awards ceremony, set for Feb. 24, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Thursday. Along with their credits as film producers, Mr. Zadan and Mr. Meron have worked in television, where their series include “Drop Dead Diva” and “Smash,” and on Broadway, where they were producers of the revived “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying” and “Promises, Promises.” The recruiting of Mr. Zadan and Mr. Meron was the first major step by Hawk Koch, who was elected president of the Academy earlier this month.

headline: ‘The Exonerated’ to Be Revived at the Culture Project
text: “The Exonerated,” a critically acclaimed play about wrongfully convicted survivors of death row, which had star-filled casts for its Off Broadway run from 2002 to 2004, will return for a seven-week run starting Sept. 15 at the Culture Project, its artistic director announced on Thursday. The production will once again feature a rotating cast of stars – including Stockard Channing, Brian Dennehy and Brooke Shields – who will read accounts by former death row inmates.

headline: Family Tree of Languages Has Roots in Anatolia, Biologists Say
text: Biologists using tools developed for drawing evolutionary family trees say that they have solved a longstanding problem in archaeology: the origin of the Indo-European family of languages.

headline: TimesCast Politics | August 23, 2012
text: A new poll on Paul Ryan's impact on the race. | Reaction to Todd Akin's comments. | The perks awaiting delegates in Tampa.

headline: Bank of America Adds 4 Directors
text: Bank of America on Thursday appointed four new directors to its board in anticipation of several current board members stepping down after they reach retirement age.

headline: Staten Island Gets Lift With Talk of a Mall and a Ferris Wheel
text: They come by the thousands, crowding onto the Staten Island Ferry with their cameras, eager for the ferry’s perfect views of New York Harbor, where the Statue of Liberty and Lower Manhattan gleam. But once on Staten Island, few make it out of the terminal, where a deck attached to the terminal offers a sweeping view of a parking lot caked with goose droppings, the small ballpark of the minor-league Staten Island Yankees and beyond, another parking lot.

headline: Bad Grades Are Rising for Auditors
text: Are audits getting worse? Or are the inspectors getting pickier?

headline: UBS Also Urges S.E.C. to Reject Nasdaq’s Proposal
text: The big banks are pointing their pitchforks toward Nasdaq.

text: Eric Thayer for The New York Times

headline: Digital Notes: Spotify Revenue Grew Fast in 2011, but Losses Mounted, Too
text: Everything about the streaming-music service Spotify is growing rapidly: the number of people who listen, the number of apps that work on its platform, the amount of money it takes in and  the amount of money it loses.

headline: Sisters on Set
text: Behind the scenes of a cover shoot with Venus and Serena Williams.

headline: Romney Unveils Plan for Energy Independence
text: 9:11 p.m. | Updated A more recent version of this post can be found here.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Hanafuda Denki’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: New York Fed Sells Off Last A.I.G.-Related Holdings
text: 8:31 p.m. | Updated The government is one step closer to shedding its burden from the financial crisis.

headline: Edible Selby | The Big Morel Cookout With Connie Green
text: In this sequel to The Selby’s last film, which follows the mushroom huntress Connie Green and the chef Sean O’Toole on a search for edible fungus in California’s high Sierras, Green gathers her friends — “the tribal members of this mushroom hunting cult,” she calls them — for a four-course morel-focused meal. Joining her and O’Toole at the outside table: Chef Hiro Sone of Terra Restaurant in Napa, Calif., who prepares a tartine of foie gras-stuffed morels in a crayfish sauce; the pastry chef and restaurateur Lissa Doumani, also of Terra, and Ame in San Francisco, who makes morels stuffed with lamb kibbe; the Kitchen Door‘s chef, Todd Humphries, who serves morels stuffed with bratwurst; and Chef Staffan Terje of Perbacco and Barbacco, cooking porcinis and peaches. Click here to see more of what’s on the menu.

headline: Nobody Cares About the Deficit
text: Dave Weigel makes a good point: there’s a huge inconsistency between the way Republicans are responding to the new CBO report on the fiscal cliff and everything they’ve been saying for the past two years.

headline: Federer-Murray Looms, but Earlier
text: Before the United States Open draw on Thursday, Brad Gilbert, a coach and commentator, asked the same question as everyone else in tennis. The “big, $64,000 question,” he called it — five words that would produce an answer crucial to this tournament.

headline: Whole Wheat Tomato and Ricotta Tart
text: These American wheat beers in the hefeweizen style are bright refreshers designed to sip and enjoy on their own on a summer day, or to pour alongside food that is anything but serious. Beer and grilled hot dogs? Burgers? Pizza? Without question. The last time we trained our palates on this category of suds I devised a pizza paved with ripe tomatoes, Vidalia onions and Stilton. On this revisit I took a longer detour on the way to beer and pizza, making a tomato and ricotta tart for a warm-weather lunch, an early evening bite or a first course at dinner. The whole-wheat pastry pays homage to the beers.

headline: Forget Coffee, I’ll Have This Brew
text: IN the heat of a waning summer, when half the world seems to have taken off on vacation, a late-morning glass of wheat beer can be another sort of pleasurable departure. In Bavaria, home of the hefeweizen style of wheat beer, such refreshment is an essential component of the brotzeit, or second breakfast.

headline: Tracing the Origins of Indo-European Languages
text: A study suggests that the Indo-European family of languages originated in Anatolia, or modern-day Turkey.

headline: Let There Be Light, in Three Dimensions
text: Despite C. P. Snow’s 1959 plaint about the gap between science and the humanities, there isn’t any — on one level at least. Artists happily take up whatever new technology falls into their hands. The mystery is why some inventions gain traction and others, like holograms, are met with a flurry of excitement, used for a short time and then abandoned.

headline: Qatar Fund Raises Stake in Xstrata
text: The battle lines are hardening in the fight over control for the mining company Xstrata.

headline: Giants Still Awaiting Development of Stronger Running Game
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Time after time, the Giants looked to establish the run Saturday in their preseason game against the Jets, only to have their backs repelled with as much force as they used to hit the line of scrimmage.

headline: No Breaks for a Rider in a Hurry
text: Pushing pedal to the mettle and its breezily thin, goofy story to the breaking point, “Premium Rush” provides just about all the late summer air-conditioned relief you could hope for. It’s buoyant dumb-fun, a ticking-clock thriller about a New York bicycle messenger who has to get from here to there without being taken out. Stuffed with zingers and zippy stunts, it comes with pretty young things of all hues and hair types — few prettier than its lead, Joseph Gordon-Levitt — and start-to-finish clever special effects, none more clever or special than Michael Shannon. If you want to see a political undertow in its urban band of multicultural renegades, there’s that for the taking too.

headline: Edible Selby | The Big Morel Cookout
text: Connie Green, a mushroom huntress, gathers her friends for a four-course morel-focused meal.

headline: Inside the List
text: THE LADY VANISHES: Forget having it all. If recent novels are any indication, women really fantasize about walking away from it all. In Gillian Flynn’s “Gone Girl” — at No. 1 in its 11th week on the hardcover fiction list — a young wife disappears from her home on the morning of her fifth anniversary. Paula Bomer’s “Nine Months,” published on Aug. 21, features a pregnant painter who abandons her family and takes off on a debauched cross-country trip. And new on the extended hardcover fiction list at No. 18 is Maria Semple’s “Where’d You Go, Bernadette,” in which a renowned, reclusive and very cranky architect vanishes, leaving her 15-year-old daughter to piece together the clues.

headline: China Producing More Than It Sells
text: China has a a glut of capacity.

headline: At Lambstock 2012, Fire, Bourbon and Fat Back
text: What do you get when you blend a Southern revival and an episode of “Top Chef” with a pinch of summer camp and prison break, all dry rubbed and left to cook on the spit?

headline: Private Equity Firms Stimulate Earnings and Deals in Post-Revolution Egypt
text: DUBAI — After Abraaj Capital bought a stake in AlBorg Laboratories in May 2008, the Dubai-based private equity firm braced for a rough ride. Over the next four years, AlBorg, an Egyptian medical testing company, weathered the global financial crisis, the economic downturn and the revolutions that swept the Mideast.

headline: The Widespread Problem of Doctor Burnout
text: The patient, a powerfully built middle-aged restaurant worker, had awakened one morning with a tight pain in his shoulders that traveled down his right arm. At work, he could barely shrug his shoulders or turn his head. “My fingers were so weak,” he recalled, “that I couldn’t even get a good grip around a glass of water.”

headline: Sampling a Filipino Specialty They’ll Be Competing to Gulp Down
text: Balut, a perennial contender on any Westerner’s list of extreme foods, is consumed in the Philippines as naturally as hamburgers are here. It’s a fertilized duck egg, a Franken-snack complete with partially developed bones, veins and eyes.

headline: Baiting the Anti-U.N. Crowd
text: I have always been a supporter of the United Nations. Despite its shortcomings, it has proven its worth again and again, from its role in the creation of Israel, to keeping the peace in countless global hotspots, to intervening in humanitarian crises.

headline: German Raid Cracks Down on Neo-Nazis
text: BERLIN — The authorities in Germany banned three known neo-Nazi groups and raided dozens of members’ homes and meeting places in the western state of North Rhine-Westphalia on Thursday, in an effort to break up an aggressive network of far-right extremists.

headline: News Corp.’s Chief Digital Officer to Step Down as Company Prepares to Split
text: News Corporation’s chief digital officer, Jonathan Miller, will step down, the company announced on Thursday, in the latest example of an executive departing since News Corporation said it would split the publishing business from the rest of the company.

headline: Four-Legged Reason to Keep It Together
text: WHEN I met the dog, he was sitting in a cage to my left as I entered a local animal shelter near the running path I frequent in downtown Austin, Texas. I had no intention to adopt a dog. I only stopped for a drink of cold water.

headline: New York Marathoners Are Left Holding Their Bags
text: New York City Marathon organizers came under intense criticism from runners Thursday after announcing that the event would veer from common raceday practices and no longer transport runners’ clothing and other belongings to the finish line of the marathon in Central Park.

headline: Ryan Blames Obama for Looming Defense Cuts
text: 5:51 p.m. | Updated FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. — Campaigning a few miles from Fort Bragg, where patriotism runs deep and the local economy depends on military spending, Representative Paul D. Ryan pinned responsibility for a looming chop to the defense budget on President Obama.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 23
text: A view of the day in sports, including the gymnast Gabby Douglas throwing out the ceremonial first pitch at Citi Field and a Diamond League track and field event in Lausanne, Switzerland.

headline: Waiter, Where’s the Fly in My Soup?
text: When restaurant servers ask me how everything is, I give honest answers: “This lobster roll is delicious, but sort of skimpy for $38.” Or “I didn’t realize the chocolate sauce would be a mere trickle on the side of my plate.” This drives my wife crazy, but I don’t feel like smiling and saying everything is great when the dish has been misrepresented or I’m being taken advantage of. What do you think?

headline: Whimsy Teased From Molten Beginnings
text: Some of the art in “Jean-Michel Othoniel: My Way,” a whimsical but cloying midcareer survey at the Brooklyn Museum, can strike you as the sculptural equivalent of haute couture. A bed framed by Murano glass beads is accompanied by veils of tulle, each one hand embroidered with gold thread in a workshop established by Louis XIV. Elsewhere, 4,200 yellow blown-glass bricks, shaped by artisans from Firozabad, India, form a shimmering rectangular solid.

headline: In Norway, a New Model for Justice
text: Oslo

headline: ‘Soul Doctor,’ Musical About Singing Rabbi, Eyes Next Stage
text: The producers of the recent Off Broadway musical “Soul Doctor,” about the life and singing career of Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach, are in talks to move the show either to Broadway’s Circle in the Square Theater or to Off Broadway’s New World Stages, according to the lead producer of the show, Jeremy Chess. He said he is now seeking to expand his pool of investors to remount the show as he awaits word from Paul Libin of Circle in the Square while pursuing separate negotiations with executives at New World Stages.

headline: In a Tiny Nook, an Array of Treats
text: FIRST you must find it, somewhere in the depths of the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side, past the cheesemonger, the Latin grocer and the baklava shop. Ni Japanese Delicacies, which opened last September, is not a restaurant, just a cluttered stall (a nook, really) without tables or chairs. At a short counter along the back wall, the owner and chef, Atsushi Numata, labors alone over a cutting board wedged against an induction burner. Pots and scissors dangle. Unlidded Tupperware and jars of condiments inch toward the edge.

headline: Sarah Wong’s Portraits of Dutch Transgendered Children
text: Several years before Lindsay Morris photographed the gender-fluid children featured in our recent cover story, the Dutch photographer Sarah Wong was documenting children in her country who said they felt they were born in the wrong body.

headline: G.M. Readies a Retooling of Lordstown Plant for Next Chevy Cruze
text: On Thursday, General Motors announced that it would spend $220 million equipping plants in Lordstown and Parma, Ohio, to build the next generation of the Chevrolet Cruze. The automaker said the redesigned compact car would offer revised exterior and interior styling, along with improved fuel economy, but provided no further details.

headline: The Leisure Class Bears Its Burden
text: “Neighboring Sounds,” Kleber Mendonça Filho’s revelatory debut feature, takes place mostly on a wealthy block in the northeastern Brazilian city of Recife. Identical, gleaming white high-rises — some with fancy names like Vivaldi, Westminster and Camille Claudel — dominate the skyline, obscuring the nearby ocean and also the urban poverty that has been central to Brazil’s social and cinematic identity for decades.

headline: Worth Its Weight | Mannin’s New Insignia Collection
text: With gold prices continuing to rise, jewelers are looking for new ways to execute their designs without compromising quality. Suzanne Donnegan is among them. “There was really a void in the market for affordable bespoke jewelry,” says Donnegan, who, four years ago, introduced the minimalistic fine jewelry line Mannin. It features 18-karat solid gold monogrammable pendants, rings and cuff links — exquisite but very expensive expressions of quiet luxury. (Jennifer Aniston, Jessica Biel and Halle Berry are customers.) Enter Donnegan’s new Insignia collection: necklaces, rings, bracelets, earrings, cuff links and money clips, in all-silver and silver with 22-karat gold overlay for a sheen and weight that mimics, uncannily, their 18-karat solid gold counterparts. “New luxury should be about both high quality and accessibility,” Donnegan says. In other words, same dash, less cash. “The Insignia shopper is interested in collecting jewelry. She appreciates understated design details and loves owning pieces that reflect her personal identity.”

headline: Restrained Chronicler of Tumultuous Times
text: The Indian photographer Homai Vyarawalla, who died in January at 98, spoke many times, with undiminished regret, of two opportunities missed.

headline: University Credit Unions Can Be Good Choice for Student Banking
text: Students heading to college generally prefer a bank that’s convenient to campus and doesn’t charge a lot of fees. A new report from the Web site Nerdwallet.com suggests that university credit unions, when available, are often a better deal for students than big banks.

headline: Hackers Lay Claim to Saudi Aramco Cyberattack
text: Unknown computer hackers claim they forced the world’s largest oil company, Saudi Aramco, to quarantine its oil production systems from infected PCs inside the company last week. They threatened to attack the company again this Saturday.

headline: Q. and A. on West Nile Virus
text: The outbreak of West Nile virus this year has spread to nearly every state and is shaping up to be the largest one on record since the first human cases were reported in the United States in 1999.

headline: Glenn Hubbard, Blogger
text: R. Glenn Hubbard, the dean of the Columbia Business School and a top economic adviser to Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign, has joined the economics blogosphere.

headline: Left in Hands of Mets, Sparkling Debut Is Lost
text: The fact that the Mets have directed much of their attention toward next season complicated the question of how a game like Thursday’s should be comprehended.

headline: Deal Will Allow One-Tap Purchases Through Facebook
text: Bango, a British company that few will have heard of on this side of the Atlantic, wants to help Facebook make money on mobile devices — not by showing advertisements, but by making it easy to buy things when you log into Facebook on your phone.

headline: By the Sea, by the Sea, Rivalries and Conflicts
text: Guillaume Canet’s “Little White Lies” delivers a two-and-a-half-hour scolding to so-called “bobos,” the term in France for affluent people who embrace a fusion of bourgeois and bohemian values. Although the word “bobo” has been used by David Brooks, a columnist for The New York Times, to describe “members of the new information elite,” in France it refers to overgrown Parisian yuppies in their 30s and 40s, like the group of bickering friends in “Little White Lies” who take a communal vacation every summer in Cap Ferrat.

headline: Drought Disrupts Everyday Tasks In Rural Midwest
text: WILDWOOD, Mo. — The wells supplying people’s homes are running dry here at the heart of the nation’s drought, which the government announced on Thursday has spread to 63.2 percent of the country, centered in the parched earth of the southern Midwest.

headline: Verizon Wins Approval for Huge Spectrum Purchase
text: Verizon Wireless on Thursday won unanimous Federal Communications Commission approval to move forward with its $3.9 billion purchase of airwaves from the country’s largest cable providers.

headline: Ex-Cuomo Aide Attacks Press Coverage as Scandal-Focused
text: ALBANY — A former top aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday criticized news coverage of Albany, saying it had become too focused on scandal.

headline: Vidal’s Own Wit to Celebrate Him
text: TWO of Gore Vidal’s favorite pastimes were having sex and appearing on television, and at a memorial service on Thursday, Mr. Vidal — the novelist, essayist, screenwriter and all-around man of letters who died in July at the age of 86 — got to do the second at least. He was shown in several clips from a PBS documentary being his usual acerbic, witty and elegant self: taking America to task for needless wars, a bloated military-industrial complex and political hypocrisy.

headline: Around the World With ‘Samsara’
text: Images from “Samsara,” with audio commentary from the director Ron Fricke and the producer Mark Magidson.

headline: Broken Hearts and Breaking News
text: The most recent episode of “The Newsroom” opened with a let’s-put-on-a-show moment — literally — as the idealistic producer of the fictional cable-news program at the heart of the series rallied her troops. Hoping to exploit the chaos of a power blackout to regain control of the newscast, she delivered a stem winder, beginning with, “A miracle happens — we become a team again,” and as it built you couldn’t help thinking: Here he goes again.

headline: Beyond the Luster of Mahogany
text: Mahogany for 18th-century furniture was harvested under appalling conditions across the Caribbean. Slaves branded with owners’ monograms lived in thatched huts and scouted for trees. They had to drag and roll felled mahogany trunks to riverfronts and then float the logs, which were chained together, to ships waiting in bays full of sharks and coral reefs.

headline: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Aug. 24-30
text: Classical

headline: Beauty, Tender and Fleeting, Amid History’s Ire

headline: The Dual Powers of Woman, in Muted Force or Frenzied Abandon
text: The choreographer Mark Morris has staged nothing more tragic than his 1989 version of Henry Purcell’s hourlong opera “Dido and Aeneas,” and nothing more fixated on the nexus of love, sex, destruction and death. For many people it is the greatest work Mr. Morris has ever made. What matters more, though, is that Mr. Morris has created a dazzling interpretation of Purcell’s superlative work. The more closely you follow it, the more packed its movement is with meanings; even though I have seen the work a number of times over the years, it keeps surprising me.

headline: Mog, an Online Music Service, Sells Its Ad Network for $10 Million
text: Last month, half of the digital music company Mog was sold to Beats Electronics, the company behind the popular Beats by Dr. Dre headphones. Now the other half, an advertising network for music Web sites, has been sold as well.

headline: Dance Listings for Aug. 24-30
text: Dance

headline: Eurofile | Loving Ljubljana
text: Long before I’d actually visited one, I thought I knew what the ideal European town should look like. On snowy school-vacation afternoons in Westchester, N.Y., my grandmother would pull down from the shelves a beautifully illustrated German or English storybook she’d grown up with and suggest we get “cozy.” (This meant hot chocolate for my brother and me and a tumbler of sherry with rattling ice cubes for her.) In these Victorian volumes, there was always a castle on a mountain in the middle of the city, which would be cut in half by a swan-dotted river, and ham- or mustard-colored houses. Cobbled streets led to squares with four-spout stone fountains. Off-duty soldiers would be flirting with buxom barmaids, clergymen would be patting children on their heads (and not elsewhere), and housewives would be pinning hand-scrubbed sheets to lines run between old lilac bushes.

headline: Financing Student Housing
text: AS college students prepare for fall classes, some of their parents or grandparents will be studying up on the real estate markets near campus.

headline: Reggae in Coney Island, and Celtic Roots
text: The Miser is away this week, so he’s left it to us to scrounge up a couple of free and fabulous things to do this weekend. Bonus: They both have great beats that you can dance to.

headline: Dry Land
text: Mark Neis, a Kansas farmer, is struggling to maintain his crops during the worst American drought in half a century.

headline: Kodak to Sell Legacy Film Units as Part of Bankruptcy Plan
text: The Eastman Kodak Company outlined a plan on Thursday to sell its legacy film units and focus on commercial printing services, as part of its plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection.

headline: Taking Dance to the Air
text: AFTER dancing on land and in the water, I was naturally ready for the next element. So I tried it in the air, which turned out to be no easy feat. It called on all the strength I could muster to stay aloft and keep gravity in check.

text: The New York Times critics on "Premium Rush," "Neighboring Sounds" and "Sleepwalk With Me."

headline: Where Chocolate Lovers Can Play Willy Wonka
text: AS the mother of an energetic and curious 4-year-old daughter, I’m constantly searching for activities to fill our weekends that go beyond the usual Central Park visit or Staten Island Ferry ride. While the plans I make might entertain my daughter, Meenakshi, they tend to leave me counting the minutes until we’re done. After all, I’m usually sitting on the side and watching as she takes a cooking class or another turn on a kiddie ride.
