text: ALBANY — Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, one of the last powerful Democratic Party bosses in New York City, was abruptly stripped of his committee chairmanship and censured Friday after he was accused of sexually harassing two women who worked in his district office this summer.

headline: Charlotte Vignon and Joseph Godla
text: ON Aug. 1, an eclectic mix of New York and Los Angeles museum folk, Parisian friends and Western artists gathered at the Rainbow Ranch near Big Sky, Mont., to watch Charlotte Vignon, 37, an associate curator of decorative arts at the Frick Collection in Manhattan, and Joseph Godla, 56, the chief conservator there, exchange vows.

headline: At the U.S. Open and Beyond, a Radio Announcer’s Internet Odyssey
text: Tennis fans will not see Ken Thomas at the 2012 United States Open. A tanned, gray-haired man wearing a headset and microphone and sitting on a scaffold platform above Court 13, Thomas has been a sideshow of his own during qualifying rounds at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Color Me Better
text: At No. 2 on the hardcover list this week is Volume 1 of the color edition of “Scott Pilgrim,” by Bryan Lee O’Malley. The original softcover version of the series was a regular presence on our sales chart in 2010 as fans counted down the days until the release of the film version starring Michael Cera. (The movie criminally underperformed at the box office.) In August of that year, the six volumes were in the top seven of the paperback list.

headline: Scandinavia on $125 a Day
text: IT was my first full day in Oslo and I thought that I had found a rare bargain: a six-pack of Carlsberg beer for under $5 (or 27.40 Norwegian kroner) at the Kiwi Minipris supermarket! Even for a mass-produced pilsner, it was a surprising deal for Norway, where just about everything costs more than you’d expect. And by more, I don’t mean by increments of 10 or 15 percent, but by multiples of two or three or four.

headline: Herding Sheep in Basque Country (Idaho)
text: SHEEP, you may be surprised to learn, are not as dumb as they look. Some people might even describe them as shrewdly calculating, remarkably crafty animals with fierce independent streaks. Given the slightest opening, for example, they will quit a herd, striking out in small, enterprising bands for the high-desert plains — ungulate fugitives in a promised land of sagebrush and cactus — sometimes never to be seen again.

headline: Should Twins Be in the Same Classroom?
text: This week, H. asks (via my Facebook page): Is it better to split up twins in school? This parent feels like the research is split; some experts suggest children will do better in separate classrooms, others the opposite.

headline: In Idaho, Two Basque Stories
text: While Boise is home to thousands of people of Basque descent, there are very few Basques left on the state’s sheep ranges.

headline: On College Move-In Day, Resist the U-Haul
text: THIS week, my neighbor Lisa, who owns a smallish Honda, asked if she could borrow our minivan to help move her daughter to college in New York City, about 40 minutes away.

headline: Mitt Romney Plays the Birther Card
text: Politicians sometimes think they can get away with saying something profoundly offensive or just plain stupid by acting like it was a joke. It never works, just like it didn’t work today when Mr. Romney shamelessly played the birther card in what seems like an increasingly desperate campaign against President Obama.

headline: Coming of Age, From Script to Screen
text: MARSHFIELD, Mass.

headline: In Kentucky, Fried Chicken History
text: WHEN making his rounds as a traveling salesman for a Chicago printing company, Duncan Hines would occasionally pull off the Dixie Highway in Corbin, Ky., and eat at Sanders Cafe. In the 1939 edition of “Adventures in Good Eating,” his pioneering restaurant guide, he recommended the cafe and its adjoining motor court as “very good place to stop en route to Cumberland Falls and the Great Smokies,” highlighting its “sizzling steaks, fried chicken, country ham, hot biscuits.”

headline: Richard Linklater on America’s Ignored Monuments
text: RICHARD LINKLATER, 52, director of such films as “Bernie,” “School of Rock” and “Dazed and Confused,” is allergic to guidebooks.

headline: Shooting in Midtown Manhattan
text: New York City officials say a laid-off women’s accessories designer fatally shot a former co-worker outside the Empire State Building, then was killed by police in a shootout that wounded nine bystanders.

headline: Uncovering the Secrets of Fukuoka
text: THE crowd at Akatan, a narrow, standing bar in the southern Japanese city of Fukuoka, thickened as each glass of sake and shochu was poured. By midnight, strangers had swept my husband, Dave, and me — the only Western faces in the smoky bar — into alcohol-fueled conversations that, with the language barrier, often devolved into comical pantomime. Every time we explained that we were visiting Fukuoka as tourists, the same question arose: “But why?”

headline: Invitation to Cardinal Shows G.O.P.’s Catholic Push
text: Some benedictions bestow a bigger blessing than others, and Mitt Romney hit the jackpot by signing up Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the president of the Conference of Catholic Bishops, to deliver the closing prayer at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., next week.

headline: Hotel Review: Shore Hotel in Santa Monica, Calif.
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Reactions at Scene of Midtown Shooting
text: Witnesses and people passing by the Empire State Building right after the shooting share impressions and concerns.

headline: Sleepwalk to Work
text: IT took a while for Athanasios Biros to solve the mystery of his noisy upstairs neighbor. Mr. Biros, 35, who works for a bank, at first suspected a bartender with odd working hours lived above his studio in Greenwich Village. Then he heard a pounding noise at 7 in the morning. “I just snapped,” he said. He knocked on the door, and met his neighbors, an Eastern European family with a child. The mother promised to stop the child from crisscrossing the paper-thin floors.

headline: Near Yale, a District Blooms
text: New Haven’s Ninth Square has seen a surge in galleries, boutiques and creative energy.

headline: In Private Equity, Seeking to Profit From Small-Time Deals
text: PRIVATE equity investing is getting a lot of attention this presidential season. Now that Mitt Romney, whose fortune came from his private equity work at Bain Capital, is set to accept the Republican presidential nomination next week in Tampa, Fla., the industry will certainly spend the fall in the spotlight.

headline: Creativity Sprouts on a St. Petersburg Island
text: SHELTERED by a wall covered in colorful murals that depicted a horror-fairy tale with a happy ending, a Russian friend and I sat back in lawn chairs and sipped cappuccinos. To our left was a still pool once used for submarine testing. Behind it stood large, shuttered, morbidly charming brick warehouses. “It’s amazing!” said my friend as he pointed at the row of buildings across the canal, in the midst of St. Petersburg. “All those years, you couldn’t come in here. Now it’s open, and you have a completely new view of the city.”

headline: Miniseries Treatment in Works for ‘Wolf Hall’ and ‘Bring Up the Bodies’
text: A six-hour adaptation of two of Hilary Mantel’s novels, “Wolf Hall” and its sequel, “Bring Up the Bodies,” will come to television in late 2013, BBC Two has announced. “Wolf Hall,” a historical novel set during the reign of King Henry VIII, won the Man Booker Prize for Fiction in 2009. Peter Straughan, who wrote the screenplay for the 2011 movie version of “Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy,” will adapt the Mantel novels for television.

headline: The 6 Worst Moments of My Raiders Fandom
text: In Sunday’s Riff, Steve Almond writes about the agony suffered and insight gained from remaining loyal to a terrible sports team. Painful as it was to recall, he agreed to dredge up his six worst moments of being a Raiders fan.

headline: Letter From Assembly Speaker Silver Censuring Assemblyman Lopez
text: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver censuring Assemblyman Vito Lopez of Brooklyn dated August 24, 2012.

headline: Your Experience With Small-Time Private Equity Investments
text: In this weekend’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan chronicles the experience of private equity investors with less money and expertise than the Mitt Romneys of the world. An increasing number are getting in the game, frustrated with low returns in other investment arenas.

headline: How to Know if You Have Enough Auto Insurance
text: There’s nothing like a good scare to send us all scurrying to our auto insurance policy to see what our coverage is. This month, those of us who have followed the story of Progressive Insurance and the Fisher family got one.

headline: Making Bold First Impressions at the Piano
text: IN the spring of 1970 Rudolf Serkin announced that he would play the 32 Beethoven piano sonatas in a series of eight recitals at Carnegie Hall during the 1970-71 season to commemorate the 200th anniversary of Beethoven’s birth. Then nearly 67, Serkin was a pre-eminent Beethoven interpreter. Yet he had never played a complete Beethoven sonata cycle.

headline: Big Ticket |  Sold for $21 Million
text: A penthouse with sophisticated steamed-beech-dominated interiors by Charles Gwathmey and sweeping views of Central Park from its perch at the Verona, an Upper East Side co-op designed by William E. Mowbray in 1908, sold under the radar for $21 million, the biggest sale of the week according to city records.

headline: Aug. 26 — Sept. 1
text: THE novelist Ian Fleming was not pleased when he learned that his greatest creation, James Bond, was played by Sean Connery in “Dr. No,” the first in the film series. “I’m looking for Cmdr. James Bond,” he said, “not an overgrown stuntman.” Moviegoers disagreed, and Fleming later came to his senses. Now, in honor of the franchise’s 50th anniversary, the complete Connery Bonds (including “Never Say Never Again,” from 1983), will be screened in IFC’s aptly named program JAMES BOND NO. 1: SEAN CONNERY’S 007, starting Friday (with an all-day, seven-film Bond-a-thon next Sunday.)

headline: Business Day Live: Drought Disrupts Everyday Tasks in Rural Midwest
text: For farmers, drought becomes a way of life. | Americans near retirement suffer big income losses. | James B. Stewart discusses Mitt Romney’s foreign tax credit.

headline: Auto Insurance, Scaredy-Cats and the Rollers of the Dice
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I try to lay out the facts and odds that lay behind the question of whether any of us have enough auto insurance. Some people look at the long odds of a bad wreck and buy the minimum amount that their state requires. Others buy as much as they can, figuring that it’s better to be safe than to be sorry.

headline: In Euro Crisis, Fingers Can Point in All Directions
text: FRANKFURT — The debate about how to distribute the cost of preserving the euro often centers on a fundamental question that is unspoken but implicit: Who caused this crisis anyway?

headline: Counter Intuitive | Chez Aline in Paris
text: It was happenstance that the young chef Delphine Zampetti came to open the tiny Parisian eatery Chez Aline. Last May, Zampetti, who has worked at Café Caché and Le Verre Volé, was walking down Rue de la Roquette in the 11th Arrondissement when she noticed a butcher shop with a charmingly retro vibe. The next week, she passed the shop again, only this time there was a “for sale” sign in the window. It was “une petite idée, just like that,” she muses. And then she went for it.

headline: Will Emissions Disclosure Mean Investor Pressure on Polluters?
text: A new financial tool developed by the investment firm South Pole Carbon, in partnership with the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, provides greenhouse gas emissions profiles of more than 40,000 publicly listed companies. This index is aimed at encouraging greater disclosure from companies while, hopefully, also pushing investors to build more responsible portfolios.

headline: ‘Quadrophenia,’ Still a Flash Point for the Mods
text: MANY years after filming the climax to the 1979 film “Quadrophenia” in Brighton, England, the director Franc Roddam found himself back there for a screening. Though the town had long been famous as a beachfront resort, Mr. Roddam’s film adaptation of the Who’s rock opera has drawn fans there as well, particularly for its depiction of a 1964 gathering of the futurist Mods, which ended in a clash with their sworn enemies, the backward-gazing, leather-clad Rockers. New Mods continue to travel there for scooter rallies and “weekenders.”

headline: A Lightning Rod in More Ways Than One
text: Oversize in almost every way, the Empire State Building has been the scene of several awful dramas in its 81 years — as well as a singular cinematic one — all magnified by the tower’s status as one of the most recognizable symbols of New York City.

headline: You Say True Life, I Say Scripted
text: HOW, exactly, does one write reality?

headline: An Affair to Remember, and Put on Screen
text: THE relationship depicted in “Keep the Lights On” isn’t one that most people would want to revisit. The film, based on part of the director Ira Sachs’s life, immerses viewers in the love and protracted dysfunction involving Erik, a needy documentary filmmaker, and Paul, a charming yet drug-addicted lawyer in publishing.

headline: GOP Intellectual Decline, Monetary Edition
text: There was a time, not long ago, when Republicans — whatever you might think of their other ideas — were part of the mainstream consensus on monetary policy. Here’s the Economic Report of the President from 2004 (pdf), presumably written by Greg Mankiw:

headline: ‘What’s the Matter With Kids Today?’
text: ‘Bye Bye Birdie’ and ‘High Time’

headline: Fresh Beans in the Salad Push Cans to the Side
text: ONE of the pleasures of cooking this time of year is the casual simplicity of the menus. Lots of room-temperature dishes, cool wine and no fussing.

headline: A National Champion Trucker, With a Record Nearly as Spotless as His Trophy
text: Over the 2.1 million miles Don Logan has driven a commercial truck, he has been involved in only one road accident; a drunken driver collided with his rig in 1996.

headline: Niallism
text: I’m not even reading the back and forth at this point — it’s too embarrassing — but if you’re interested, Matt O’Brien sums it up.

headline: Regulatory SWAT Team May Have to Move Slowly on Money Funds
text: A SWAT team of top regulators was formed after the financial crisis to swoop in and stamp out big risks lurking in the financial system. Should the mutual fund industry fear this team as it tries to protect one of its biggest products from further reform?

headline: The Week in Pictures, August 24
text: A look back at the week’s events in New York City and the region.

headline: Where Aerobic Fortitude Is a Big Plus
text: THE Harlem River curves by Kingsbridge, a middle-class neighborhood of 47,000 folded into a valley in the northwestern Bronx. There’s also a busy highway, the six-lane Major Deegan Expressway, that slices through the area. And mature trees shade many sidewalks — as along Tibbett Avenue, which is named for a brook buried long ago.

headline: Debunking the Hunter-Gatherer Workout
text: DARWIN isn’t required reading for public health officials, but he should be. One reason that heart disease, diabetes and obesity have reached epidemic levels in the developed world is that our modern way of life is radically different from the hunter-gatherer environments in which our bodies evolved. But which modern changes are causing the most harm?

headline: The Cadillac Your Livery Driver Has Been Dreaming Of
text: IT will be the black car waiting to pick you up at the airport. It’s the Cadillac upon which hearses and limousines will be based. When Hertz runs out of midsize cars, it is the luxury sedan into which you’ll upgrade.

headline: Three’s a Crowd: The Bench Seat Is Benched
text: FULL-SIZE American sedans are an endangered species, and the front bench seat is fading away with them.

headline: Owner of Shangri-La Hotel Tries to Make Amends With Jewish Groups
text: LOS ANGELES — Tehmina Adaya, owner of the Hotel Shangri-La in the beach town of Santa Monica, Calif., announced on Friday some measures meant to repair her standing among Jews in the wake of a jury decision last week that found she had violated the civil rights of members of a Jewish group she tried to evict from her hotel in 2010.

headline: Appreciation for Vintage Cars, in Two Senses
text: Monterey, Calif.

headline: Celebrating the Classics, Confirming Their Value
text: Pebble Beach, Calif.

headline: Buy High, Sell Higher
text: The Monterey auctions set a record of $262 million in sales this year, easily surpassing 2011’s total of $198 million. Here is a look at some noteworthy models that were offered for sale.

headline: Shocking, Not Shocking, and Mildly Amusing Links
text: Shocking (not): Monsanto joins the club and dishes out $4.2 million to fight Prop 37, California’s GMO-labeling initiative. And an Argentine study found that an ingredient in Round Up can cause birth defects.

headline: Fresh Beans in the Salad Push Cans to the Side
text: In this week’s City Kitchen column, local beans become a delicious salad in a fresh version of the all-too-often canned and bland three-bean salad.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Syria, Iraq, New York and Egypt.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Nathan Harden on ‘Sex and God at Yale’
text: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Hanna Rosin reviews “Sex and God at Yale,” in which Nathan Harden details the debauchery hiding in plain sight in the Ivy League. Ms. Rosin writes that his account is revealing, but:

headline: Luxury Workhorse
text: The unpretentious 2013 Cadillac XTS may not be flashy, but the brand’s venerable customer base will feel right at home inside, front seat or back.

headline: Gestation Crate Denial in New Jersey
text: Check out this op-ed on NJ.com by Princeton professor Peter Singer and the Humane Society’s Paul Shapiro calling for the New Jersey legislature to pass a bill that would improve the lives of pigs in confinement, a bill similar to one passed in nine other states. Here’s a reply from the head of New Jersey’s Farm Bureau; no comment needed:

headline: Chic in Review | A Close Encounter of the Calvin Klein Kind
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Week in Culture in Pictures, Aug. 24
text: A Korean pop band performed in Newark, Jake Gyllenhaal is making his New York stage debut, and artists built sand castles on Rockaway Beach.

headline: The Stranded Unemployed
text: On Thursday I wrote about how incomes have declined sharply in the last few years, particularly for people approaching retirement age. A new report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics sheds some light on why: People who lost work, especially if they’re older, often aren’t finding re-employment; even when they do find new work, they’re taking major pay cuts.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Aug. 24
text: More Photographs

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Salamander Starts Over’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Moscow Court Finds Kasparov Not Guilty of Illegal Protest During Pussy Riot Trial
text: MOSCOW – A judge here ruled on Friday that the former chess champion Garry Kasparov was not guilty of participating in an unsanctioned political demonstration outside the courthouse where three women in the punk band Pussy Riot were convicted of hooliganism last week and sentenced to two years in prison.

headline: Ukrainian Dance Camp in the Catskills
text: Each summer for about three decades, children of Ukrainian descent have converged on a wooded retreat in the Catskills.

headline: Ukrainian Folk Dance
text: Clips from the documentary “Folk,”directed and produced by Roxy Topotowych.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 24
text: A view of the day in sports included soccer in France and Germany, cycling in Portugal and sailing in Cape Town.

headline: Going Their Own Ways
text: THE other day I got hung up on a new sandbar, the words “luxury-branded accommodations,” a term that sadly does not apply to mortuaries (not yet) but rather to hotel rooms splashed with a peer company’s status symbols. A classic twofer, but clearly intended for gullible people.

headline: Reactions to Verizon’s Deal With the Cable Companies
text: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday approved a deal that allows Verizon Wireless to purchase a huge swath of spectrum, the radio waves that carry wireless communications, from the country’s largest cable providers.

headline: Week in Review: A Defeat for Schapiro
text: In an effort to curb money market funds, a Plan B is considered. | The New York Fed sold the last of its A.I.G. bailout bonds. | Jesse Eisinger uncovered a TARP move that isn’t helping taxpayers. | And Andrew Ross Sorkin said investors in health care were betting on President Obama. A look back on our reporting of the last week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Swedes Win in Open Teams at World Mind Games
text: LILLE, France — The Open Teams at the Second World Mind Sports Games here this week was a triumph for Sweden, represented by Krister Ahlesved, Jonas Petersson, Peter Bertheau, Per-Ola Cullin, Fredrik Nystrom and Johan Upmark, with its nonplaying captain, Mats Axdorph.

headline: Crowdfunding Merger Points to Ambitions in Latin America
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The crowdfunding site Ideame has acquired the Brazilian company Movere in a deal that may prompt more consolidation in this sector in Latin America.

headline: Last of the Summer Sweet Corn
text: The summer sweet corn season is brief but memorable, and as Martha Rose Shulman explains, sweet corn can be used to create a number of delicious dishes. She writes:

headline: Steve Van Buren, 91, Dies; Hall of Fame Halfback
text: Steve Van Buren, the Honduras-born son of an American fruit inspector who took up the unfamiliar game of football in high school and went on to stardom with the Philadelphia Eagles, becoming a Hall of Fame running back and, many said, one of the greatest to play the game, died on Thursday in Lancaster, Pa. He was 91.

headline: Alzheimer’s Drug Misses Goal, but Offers Hint of Potential
text: An Alzheimer’s drug being tested by Eli Lilly failed in its main goal of halting progress of the disease, the company said Friday, but there were some signs it could slow cognitive decline in patients with mild cases.

headline: Resort Towns Face a Last Picture Show
text: OCEAN CITY, N.J. — There are nicer and newer movie theaters than the Strand 5 on the boardwalk here on the Jersey Shore. The sound is uneven, and the auditoriums haven’t been renovated in decades.

headline: Out of Frame
text: Small movie theaters are struggling to survive the conversion to digital projection.

headline: Reviewing the Cadillac XTS
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman reviews the 2013 Cadillac XTS, which replaces the DTS full-size sedan as the “most Cadillac-like of all the current Cadillacs.”

headline: Pandora and Spotify Rake In the Money and Then Send It Off in Royalties
text: If you have read anything about digital music recently, you have probably encountered two names over and over: Spotify and Pandora. Both offer an abundance of free listening on easy-to-use interfaces, and music fans have embraced them. At least 33 million people have tried Spotify, more than 150 million have registered for Pandora.

headline: Jury Awards $1 Billion to Apple in Samsung Patent Case
text: Apple won a decisive victory on Friday in a lawsuit against Samsung, a verdict that will give Apple ammunition in a far-flung patent war with its global competitors in the smartphone business.

headline: Dad Hasn’t Just Been Sitting Around
text: Along with being the father to Maude and her sister, Iris, 9, Judd Apatow has parented, mentored or gently nudged many a Hollywood project into being. Here are some of his proudest achievements.

headline: The Caucus Click: Ready for Their Entrance
text: Janice Overton, a volunteer in Tampa, Fla., helped deliver giant tubes of balloons on Friday for temporary storage before the Republican National Convention.

headline: She’s 14, Going on 140 Characters
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Two-and-Twenty Tax Dodges
text: For Mitt Romney, probably the only thing worse than having to lay bare his financial life is for someone else to lay it all out. Which is, of course, exactly what Gawker did on Thursday, when the gossip Web site published confidential documents from Bain Capital, the private equity firm where Mr. Romney made his multi-millions – and from which he still takes a share of the profits.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hacking Your Head, and Twitter ‘Sin’
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A SoHo Condo, a Clinton studio co-op and a Fort Greene co-op.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A four-bedroom Mediterranean home in Yonkers and a three-bedroom town house in Sea Bright, N.J.

headline: Chef’s Redemption Tells of a Softening North Korea
text: TOKYO — For years, the Japanese sushi chef who spent over a decade working for the Kim family in North Korea lived in dread of a knock on the door by an agent sent to kill him for returning to Japan and writing a tell-all book exposing the rulers’ extravagant lifestyle.

headline: A Maelstrom of Horror in a Desert House
text: Property maintenance can be a pain, especially when a ghost appears to be the resident super. Just ask Kelly (Ashley Greene of “Twilight”) and Ben (Sebastian Stan of “Gossip Girl”), the leads in “The Apparition.” Recent college grads minding an investment home owned by Kelly’s parents, they just want to spruce up the place, a spacious desert residence, but objects simply won’t stay put.

headline: From Farm to Table, but Hardly Rustic
text: WHEN I hear the words “farm to table,” I picture an old white clapboard inn, with gardens all around. Ursino, an ambitious farm-to-table restaurant on the campus of Kean University in Union, is in a hulking glass and metal building that fronts Morris Avenue.

headline: To Trip the Volynska Polka, Respectfully in the Catskills
text: KERHONKSON, N.Y. — Each summer for about three decades, children of Ukrainian descent have converged on a wooded retreat here in the Catskills, the girls donning embroidered blouses, and the boys puffy Cossack pants, to learn the folk dances of their ancestors.

headline: A Kitchen Geared to a Locavore’s Tastes
text: FRANK LEPRI is known to Hartford-area diners from his years as chef at the late and lamented downtown bistro Pastis; when it closed, he and his wife, Debbie, opened an excellent trattoria called Da Lepri in Ellington, later adding a burger bar nearby. And last spring they opened a steak-and-seafood emporium in the 275-year-old Tolland farmhouse where the restaurant Zest had been.

headline: Will Tom Stoppard Side With Graham Greene on the Last Book of ‘Parade’s End’?
text: Contributing to the One-Page Magazine is a fun and sometimes challenging exercise in compression and economy. For every 70 words I work into a column, there are often hundreds more I could have written on a subject. That’s never been more true than it is for Sunday’s edition, which focuses on the most exciting TV news in recent memory: Benedict Cumberbatch, best known as the lead in BBC’s “Sherlock,” stars in Tom Stoppard’s adaptation of Ford Madox Ford’s “Parade’s End.” The joint BBC and HBO production was directed by Susanna White and is positioned as the smart Edwardian-era alternative to “Downton Abbey,” a show Cumberbatch has ridiculed far and wide. Most notoriously, he denounced its cheap sentiment in an interview with Reader’s Digest and called the second season “atrocious,” preceded by an adverb that cannot be written here.

headline: The Artwork of Jeffrey Johnson
text: Jeffrey T. Johnson, the designer who killed a former colleague near the Empire State Building on Friday, had a YouTube channel dedicated to showcasing the illustrations on his Web site, St. Jolly’s Art, most of which depict cars, motorcycles, women and combinations thereof.

headline: Bust of Civil War General Stirs Anger in Alabama
text: In Selma, Ala., a battle over what to do with a bronze bust of a contradictory and controversial Civil War general has lasted far longer than the war itself.

headline: Ann Romney’s Convention Speech Is Moved to Tuesday
text: Republicans are moving Ann Romney’s convention speech to Tuesday night after failing to persuade any of the broadcast networks to televise any of the convention speeches on Monday.

headline: What Not to Take to Tampa
text: Leave your tomatoes at home, if you plan on going to the Republican National Convention. The current list of items banned around the convention zone in Tampa varies from weapons to vegetation to puppet-making materials.

headline: Having Fun With Tapas in a Flashy Room
text: TO get a bead on NoMa Social, the young hot spot in the newly refurbished Radisson Hotel, in New Rochelle, you might want to start with a special appetizer called Farm Egg in Purgatory. A little bit ironic, and deliriously good, the dish involves a poached egg floating in a fiery, basil-laden tomato brodetto, with brittle grilled toast as a means of getting at it. If you’re foolish enough to pass it around, you may never see it again.

headline: A Colorful Change for Jambox
text: While many have been wowed by the sound of Jawbone’s Jambox portable speaker, some may have been less impressed with the monochromatic look of its blue, silver, black or red cases.

headline: Republicans’ Weather Watch
text: Bad weather at an outdoor wedding, a graduation, a picnic or a pep rally is mostly just bad luck. Bad weather at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla. next week may be unlucky in more ways than one.

headline: Friday Night Music: Fairport Convention
text: OK, I thought of trying to make it topical — in which case, given what passes for Romney humor, it should have been “Born in the USA”. But never mind. For whatever reason, lately I’ve been listening to old folk-rock — and it doesn’t get better than this:

headline: Wineries’ Golden Haul
text: Long Island producers won the top prizes in six of 30 classes of wine in the New York Wine and Food Classic this month.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 24
text: Subjects include the illicit tradition of stoop drinking, New Yorkers’ opinions on police stop-and-frisk practices, and the New York town of Ilion as it braces for a possible future without a Remington Arms factory.

headline: Men, Who Needs Them?
text: Boise, Idaho

headline: New Mexican Fare, and an Old Barbecue
text: CHICHIMECAS is a Mexican restaurant with a difference. Its two-story, cream-colored brick building, situated beside the railroad tracks in Farmingdale, was previously the home of Estelle’s Contemporary BBQ. When Chichimecas opened in late May, its owners kept the smoker, resulting in a menu of barbecue alongside the Mexican classics.

headline: The Clock Ticks for Men as Well
text: LET the baton of blame pass to the next runner.

headline: Gun Used by Shooter Is Known for Its Deadly Power
text: The pistol used by a disgruntled designer to kill a former co-worker outside the Empire State Building on Friday is among the more lethal handguns on the American firearms market.

headline: Apple Beats Samsung: First Reactions
text: 8:35 p.m. | Updated  Adding comment from Samsung Electronics.

headline: Gambia’s Leader Declares Plans for Mass Executions
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The eccentric president of Gambia has warned that he will carry out a mass execution of prisoners by mid-September, a threat local journalists and opposition officials said must be taken seriously given his unpredictability and long record of human rights abuses.

headline: How Hate Gets Counted
text: DO American Sikhs count?

text: Lance Armstrong dropped his fight against doping charges Thursday, which means he will be stripped of his seven Tour de France titles. But his loyal sponsors are not stripping him of their support.

headline: Al Gore, The End Of the Line
text: At 64, even after accumulating more than $100 million in wealth, Mr. Gore races like a man making up for lost time: blog posts to write, business deals to close, a global climate to save

headline: Supposedly No Threat, Astros Send Mets to Sixth Straight Loss
text: The Mets lost to the Astros, the worst team in the major leagues, by 3-1 on Friday night at Citi Field, dropping 12 games under .500, a low for them this season.

headline: Decision by 2 Officers to Open Fire in Busy Midtown Leaves Bystanders Wounded
text: As the two officers confronted a gunman in front of the Empire State Building on a busy Friday morning, they had to make a snap decision: Do they open fire in the middle of Midtown?

text: A man fatally shot his former co-worker and was then shot and killed by the police in gunfire that injured nine other people outside the Empire State Building.

headline: This Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Unsold goods are piling up in China, housing in the United States is starting to recover slightly, and Germany reaffirmed its commitment to keeping Greece in the euro zone.

headline: Bloomberg Backs ‘Responsible’ Extraction of Gas and Pays to Help Set Up Rules
text: After giving away a chunk of his personal fortune to the cause of eliminating coal-fired power plants, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is opening his checkbook in support of “responsible” extraction of natural gas by hydraulic fracturing.

headline: The Caucus Click: Flipping for Paul
text: A young visitor goes for a spin at the Paul Festival, an informal, alternate convention held at the Florida State Fairgrounds in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Pressure Increases on Yankees and Girardi After Sweep by White Sox
text: CLEVELAND — When Joe Girardi yelled at a heckling fan Wednesday night after a loss in Chicago, it appeared that the stress of a three-game losing streak and a tightening pennant race were unsettling him. The loss reduced the Yankees’ lead in the American League East to three games — a margin that was cut a-half game further before Friday night’s game against the Cleveland Indians — and Girardi was not happy.

headline: 2 U.S. Employees Wounded in Ambush on Mexican Road
text: MEXICO CITY — The circumstances were all too typical in a drug war in which roadside ambushes involving armored sport utility vehicles are a staple. But in an ambush on Friday, the vehicle belonged to the United States Embassy, the wounded were two American employees and the assailants included federal police officers.

headline: Woods Stays in Chase, Wincing All the Way
text: FARMINGDALE, N.Y. — The hardest part of Tiger Woods’s round at the Barclays on Friday was not getting his ball in the cup, it was picking it out of it. He woke up with a kink in his lower back from sleeping on a hotel mattress that was too soft, and as he warmed up on the range at Bethpage State Park, his back grew stiffer.

headline: Amid a Renovation, Rethinking the Neuberger
text: PURCHASE, N.Y.

headline: Cash Moves by HSBC in Inquiry
text: Prosecutors investigating the movement of money by global banks suspect HSBC of laundering money for Mexican drug cartels and moving cash for Saudi Arabian banks with ties to terrorists, according to federal authorities with direct knowledge of the investigations.

headline: ‘We Won,’ Lindgren Says, After a Loss
text: Here at The New York Times Magazine, we believe in accuracy. We hire writers who know how to relay the truth to our readers. We have a team of researchers who double-check their facts. We make corrections when we get things wrong. But sometimes, the truth gets murky. Last night was one of those times.

headline: No More Bluffing
text: Chicago

headline: Tropical Storm Isaac Lashes Haiti, Still Crippled by Earthquake
text: MEXICO CITY — Tropical Storm Isaac unleashed heavy rain over Haiti on Friday, raising the threat of floods and mudslides that could worsen the misery of a nation where hundreds of thousands still remain homeless from the 2010 earthquake.

headline: Arms and the Duck
text: We had a shooting near the Empire State Building. An aggrieved ex-employee of an apparel company killed his former co-worker, and was himself killed by police. Except for the famous-landmark location, it was not actually a very big story. Remember the mass shooting at the lumberyard in North Carolina earlier this year, or the one last October at the California cement plant? No? Neither does anybody else except the grieving families.

headline: Once Again, Landmark Is Backdrop to Violence
text: On movie screens it has been besieged by aliens, tidal waves and an overgrown ape. But on Friday morning the horror at the Empire State Building was all too real.

headline: At the Carnival, Love and Looming Clouds
text: Looked at objectively, the hero of “Carousel” isn’t very good hero material. Proud, vain and not just a little bit dumb, the carnival barker Billy Bigelow also possesses a violent streak and a hot temper.

headline: College Football Preview: Five Teams to Watch
text: OHIO The last time the Bobcats won more games than any other Football Bowl Subdivision program in the state was 1962. That streak should end in 2012. Beyond the talent, experience and coaching, the Bobcats have a schedule that could not be more favorable. Ohio is simply a better team than every opponent on its schedule — and that includes Penn State, which hosts the Bobcats in the season opener.

headline: Dump It on the States
text: On Thursday, Mitt Romney unveiled the latest in a series of bad ideas for taking government duties out of Washington and hiding them in the back rooms of state capitols. Mostly, Mr. Romney wants to allow states to quietly smother social programs the federal government has run for decades. In the case of his new energy policy, he wants to give states power to bypass Washington’s caution in burrowing for oil, gas and coal on federal lands.

headline: Long Before Carnage, an Office Grudge Festered
text: The two men at the center of a fatal shooting outside the Empire State Building on Friday had brushed shoulders for years — often literally, two large egos stuffed into a small office — and yet could hardly have been less alike.

headline: After Gay Son’s Suicide, Mother Finds Blame in Herself and in Her Church
text: RIDGEWOOD, N.J. — When Tyler Clementi told his parents he was gay, two days before he left for Rutgers University in the fall of 2010, he said he had known since middle school.

headline: President Morsi and His Critics
text: There was another street demonstration in Cairo on Friday. This time, instead of inveighing against former President Hosni Mubarak, or his generals, people were protesting against Egypt’s first freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi. It was one more sign that citizens in the new Egypt are determined to make their voices heard — and a sign, too, that Mr. Morsi and his party, the Muslim Brotherhood, are having a hard time hearing those voices.

headline: Aruba Shares Gain on Strong Quarter
text: Aruba Networks, a maker of components for mobile devices, surged 14 percent, to $19.36, after reporting quarterly sales and profit that exceeded analysts’ estimates. Revenue in the period, which ended July 31 and was the fourth quarter of Aruba’s fiscal year, rose 22 percent, to $139.2 million, and profit excluding some items was 18 cents a share, topping a company projection of 16 to 17 cents.

headline: For Judgeships in New York City
text: With Congressional primaries decided in a separate election in June and just a few state legislative races on the ballot, New York City’s primary elections on Sept. 13 are expected to draw few voters. Holding the primaries on a Thursday instead of the customary Tuesday does not help.

headline: Syrian Forces Strike Again in Suburbs of Damascus
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian troops continued to pound the suburbs of Damascus on Friday, as fighting raged in Aleppo and as rebels in the eastern city of Deir al-Zour reported seizing an armory that had been contested for days.

headline: Trial to Begin for 16 Members of Amish Group Charged in Beard-Cutting Attacks
text: Sixteen members of an Amish splinter group accused of terrorizing the Amish of eastern Ohio in bizarre beard-cutting attacks are scheduled to go on trial Monday in federal court in Cleveland.

headline: Romney, in His Home State, Raises Birth Certificate Issue
text: COMMERCE, Mich. — Mitt Romney, who has denounced the nasty personal tone of the presidential campaign, seemed to make a joke about President Obama’s birth certificate while speaking to voters here on Friday, reinjecting the issue of the president’s birthplace into the campaign.

headline: Murdoch Paper Defies a Warning and Exposes Prince Harry
text: LONDON — It took 72 hours, but one of Britain’s normally scandal-hungry tabloids finally broke ranks on Friday, defying a warning from palace officials and publishing two photographs of Prince Harry cavorting naked during a game of strip billiards in his Las Vegas hotel suite.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Al Gore Through the Years
text: A look at Mr. Gore’s life from his run for presidency to his current work with global warming.

headline: A New Guide to the Republican Herd
text: A look at the major blocs of the Republican Party going into the 2012 election.

headline: Starving the Future
text: America is in trouble.

headline: Diplomacy With Iran Still Is Viable, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration insisted Friday that “there is time and space” for a diplomatic solution to the Iranian nuclear crisis, despite new evidence, to be released next week by international nuclear inspectors, that Iran is bolstering its ability to produce a type of uranium that can be converted relatively quickly to bomb fuel.

headline: Missouri Lawmaker Tries to Shift Focus From Comments on Rape
text: CHESTERFIELD, Mo. — Representative Todd Akin held a public event on Friday afternoon for the first time since the broadcast of his controversial comments about rape victims, and attempted to turn the focus of his Senate race in Missouri back on the issue that had once made victory seem a sure thing: Senator Claire McCaskill.

headline: Point of No Return
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Note to readers under the age of 25 (Don’t hide, I can see you out there): You will be able to get a toehold in this puzzle. Give it a whirl, even though it’s a Saturday. It’s the long entries that, when filled in, give you the start you need to tell all your friends that you finished a Saturday New York Times puzzle.

headline: G.O.P. Convention Will Include Video Tribute to Paul
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney’s campaign on Friday extended an olive branch to the small army of Ron Paul delegates who will arrive in Tampa, Fla., next week even as Mr. Romney’s lawyers sought to prevent a similar show of political force at future conventions.

headline: Corrections: August 25, 2012
text: NEW YORK

headline: France: Remarks Cost Designer Award
text: President François Hollande of France has stripped John Galliano, the fashion designer convicted last year of making anti-Semitic remarks, of the Légion d’Honneur that he was awarded in 2009. Mr. Galliano, 51, who was made a chevalier of the Légion d’Honneur by former President Nicolas Sarkozy, was involved in two drunken episodes in a small Paris bar and restaurant. His anti-Semitic remarks, some of them caught on an amateur video, led to his conviction last year on charges of “public insults based on origin, religious affiliation, race or ethnicity.” In February 2011, Mr. Galliano harangued a museum curator about being Jewish and uttered racial insults at her friend, who is of South Asian origin. The court also saw a video of Mr. Galliano, the previous November, declaring his love for Adolf Hitler. Mr. Hollande, elected in May, has been outspoken in condemning anti-Semitism and crimes against Jews committed by the French police under Nazi occupation.

headline: A Slump Can’t Get in the Way
text: The Yankees, on the verge of being swept in Chicago for the first time in 21 years and in desperate need of a stabilizing victory, were trailing in the top of the seventh inning Wednesday night. There was a runner on first base representing the tying run, and Russell Martin was at the plate trying not to think about his agonizing offensive season, the worst of his career.

headline: Jerry Grant, Racecar Driver Who Broke Speed Barrier, Dies at 77
text: Jerry Grant, who was the first driver to go faster than 200 miles per hour in an Indy-style racecar but who may be best remembered for his heartbreaking defeats, memorably in the 1972 Indianapolis 500,  died on Aug. 12 in Orange, Calif. He was 77.

headline: Daryl Hine, Poet, Editor and Translator, Dies at 76
text: Daryl Hine, an admired poet who adhered to classical themes, complicated formal structures and intricate rhyming patterns to explore themes of philosophy, history and his own sexuality, died on Monday in Evanston, Ill. He was 76.

headline: Will Men Really Worry About Their Biological Clocks?
text: The most striking thing to me about the online reaction to the recent study concluding that, in a fraction of cases, increased mutations found in the sperm of older men meant they were more likely than their younger counterparts to father children with autism or schizophrenia was the reaction that wasn’t. The reaction, that is, from the world of fathers who blog and write about their children and their children’s autism.

headline: Putin Shows Some Openness to New Missile Reductions
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin said Friday that Russia would be willing to negotiate new reductions in nuclear arms with the United States but that Washington must first change its plans for a missile defense system in Europe strongly opposed by the Kremlin.

headline: Mets Plumb the Depths of Division and Devotion
text: The Mets entered Friday night’s game against the Houston Astros with a number of questions.

headline: In Horse Town, Daily Doubles Give Way to Nightly Buzz
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The man who called himself Joe smiled as he spoke of Newsdad, the horse that almost was.

headline: Sharing Fire With Pollock
text: Jackson Pollock is best known for the paintings he made from 1947 to 1951 in which he poured and dripped enamel paint onto large, unprimed canvases tacked to the floor of his studio, which at that time happened to be in Springs, N.Y., a hamlet in the town of East Hampton. These are the works that broke the ice for other painters of his generation, as Willem de Kooning put it, and that turned Pollock into a legend: “Jack the Dripper,” according to a 1956 Life magazine article, whose approach signaled the end of easel painting for many younger artists.

headline: Biden Postpones Campaign Visit to Tampa
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has postponed an in-your-face visit to Tampa scheduled for Monday, his office said Friday night.

headline: A Scary Smack in the Helmet, but Sighs of Relief for Jeter and Sabathia
text: CLEVELAND — The Yankees faced their most critical test of the season Friday night. They had been swept in Chicago, and their division lead slashed to two and a half games. So the thought of C. C. Sabathia being unable to respond after a bout of inflammation in his left elbow was frightening for them to contemplate.

headline: Orgy Photos Give More Than a Peek Into Chinese Officials’ Sex Lives
text: BEIJING — There are some things that are well known about the sex lives of China’s most lascivious male officials.

headline: Finding Humanity in a Disturbing Mind
text: The scene looks harmless enough at first. Odd but harmless. A young woman and an older man are standing on a forested hill talking about baseball. He has binoculars and is watching a game from afar. Soon we learn why he isn’t at the game and why he so badly wants to be. Gradually and gracefully, his story unfolds in Gino DiIorio’s “Release Point,” having its world premiere with the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch.

headline: Romney in Crisis: Two Dark Spots in Fortunate Life
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney was, uncharacteristically, terrified.

headline: Learning to Play Tennis Late in Life
text: There is seldom an hour I spend alone with Kirill when I don’t come to feel worn and inadequate.

headline: A Ghost Town on 20 Acres in Brooklyn
text: The developer Douglas C. Steiner recently reached an agreement with the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation to convert an abandoned Civil War-era hospital complex into a media and technology hub.

headline: Garcia Will Skip the Deutsche Bank Championship
text: FARMINGDALE, N.Y. — After winning last week in Greensboro and holding a share of the lead at the Barclays at the halfway point, Sergio Garcia realized it is possible to play too well for one’s own good.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York

text: Vanderbilt

headline: Dock Master
text: Catherine Kendrick, 78, known as Kay, has covered the Yonkers waterfront as a volunteer lifeguard for 60 years, and she is still there.

headline: For Boston, a Swap of Problems for Potential
text: In 2007, when the Boston Red Sox won their second championship in four years, they seemed to be the model franchise. They were rich and savvy, with a pipeline of homegrown talent and the guts and brains to act boldly and wisely when they needed to make a move.

headline: A Lifetime of Guarding Lives
text: ON Wednesday afternoon, a young woman walked to the end of the city pier in Yonkers, just north of the New York City limits, and stared longingly out at the Hudson River.

headline: Colorado Suspect Spoke of Plans, Prosecutors Say
text: DENVER — James E. Holmes, the former graduate student charged with murdering 12 people in a shooting spree inside a Colorado movie theater last month, told a classmate months earlier that he wanted to kill people, prosecutors said in court filings on Friday.

headline: A Verdict That Alters an Industry
text: The federal court jury’s decision Friday in a smartphone patent lawsuit between Apple and Samsung is expected to alter the dynamics of the highly competitive mobile phone industry.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,086 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Litigation, Rockefeller and the Yankees
text: “Music,” the composer Ira B. Arnstein once said, “is a language in sound like Latin or French. I’ll prove it.” He tried. But the perennial plaintiff, who argued in lawsuit after lawsuit that more popular composers had plagiarized his music, never won a case.

headline: Hertz Said to Be Close to Buying Dollar Thrifty
text: Hertz Global Holdings is near a deal to acquire the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group for nearly $2.5 billion, according to a person briefed on the transaction, ending a fierce and protracted merger battle among the nation’s largest car rental companies.

headline: As Tough as His Task
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Every morning, Bill and Colleen O’Brien know their older son, 10-year-old Jack, will have a seizure when he wakes up. It could last 30 seconds or go on for 30 minutes, necessitating an ambulance trip to the hospital. There may be more seizures during the day, depending on disparate factors like weather patterns and Jack’s growth spurts. And when they happen, the O’Briens can do little except to turn their son on his side and wait for the seizure to end.

headline: Tennis, of Course, and Ladybugs
text: Patrick McEnroe, 46, ESPN’s affably enlightening tennis commentator, will host and call matches at the United States Open, which starts Monday at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens. He also works at the site year-round, as the general manager of player development for the United States Tennis Association. Mr. McEnroe retired from professional tennis in 1998, though he and his older brother John won the over-45 legends doubles tournament at the French Open this year. He and his wife, the actress-singer  Melissa Errico, live in SoHo with their three daughters, Victoria, 6, and the twins Diana and Juliette, 3 ½. Sundays are family time, either in the city or at the house they rent in Sag Harbor, N.Y., in summer.

headline: Wilson Shines for Giants’ Offense, but Amukamara Sustains Ankle Injury
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — With 12 days until the regular-season opener, the Giants entered their third preseason game with significant expectations for two young players. David Wilson, the first-round pick, is pushing to become a critical part of the running game, and Prince Amukamara, the first-round draft pick in 2011, had been trying to fit in as a de facto starting cornerback.

headline: Local Stop: Sutton Place
text: The quiet neighborhood of Sutton Place runs along the East River from 53rd to 59th Street.

headline: Parks, Privacy and River Views
text: Sutton Place is both a grand old residential avenue (originally known as “Avenue A”), running alongside the East River from 53rd to 59th Street, and a serviceable neighborhood extending west to Second Avenue. At the river’s edge, the cross streets end in little vest-pocket parks with wide views of boats navigating the river’s treacherous currents, of Roosevelt Island’s Southpoint Park and of the monumental Queensboro and Williamsburg Bridges. Like many of its residents, Sutton Place is sedate and well maintained. Once here, people and businesses tend to stay put. “Whenever people talk about assisted living, I say, ‘No way, I’d rather live in Sutton Place!’ ” said Vera Mayer, who moved there from Riverdale, in the Bronx, 38 years ago. “There’s the privacy of Sutton Place, and then you walk over one block and you have everything you need.”

headline: Knicks’ Anthony Optimistic After Olympics
text: This off-season has been a success for Carmelo Anthony. He won his second Olympic gold medal for the United States in London, where he averaged 16.3 points and set a single-game American Olympic scoring record with 37 points against Nigeria.

headline: Seeking Brooklyn’s Lost Mass Grave
text: NOTHING is visible at the intersection of Third Avenue and Eighth Street in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn to indicate that anything extraordinary is there. The artisanal-pie place on one corner and the auto body shops across the way suggest it is merely another spot in the city where grit is giving way to gentrification. But if a small group of history enthusiasts are right, this particular corner of Kings County is hallowed ground.

headline: Calling All Refugee Kids
text: The Refugee Youth Summer Academy in Manhattan helps immigrant children and their families find their footing in the United States.

headline: At Colorado Race, Mixed Reaction on Armstrong
text: BRECKENRIDGE, Colo. — Cycling fans who gathered for the start of Friday’s Stage 5 of the USA Pro Challenge did not allow the Lance Armstrong scandal to diminish their enthusiasm for a sport riddled for years by doping controversy. But some were deeply worried for young competitive riders facing tough choices.

headline: Newest Young Immigrants Get a Head Start on School
text: The Refugee Youth Summer Academy program helps dozens of recently arrived children, many from families of refugees, prepare to enter the school system.

headline: India’s Paralyzed Parliament
text: These days, the Indian legislators have settled into a routine: At 11 a.m., members of the upper and lower houses gather at the Parliament House. Immediately, the opposition members walk to the well of the house, shouting, “Nahi chalegi, nahi chalegi” (“will not function, will not function”) and “Manmohan Singh gaddi choro!” (“Manmohan Singh, leave the chair”). The helpless speaker repeatedly tells the members, “Kripya baith jaieye” (“Please sit down”), but no one listens. After few minutes, the session is adjourned.

headline: In New York, With 6 Weeks to Adapt to America
text: TWENTY-FOUR days after he arrived in the United States, Mamadou Fadja Diallo, 13, showed up for summer school in Manhattan looking wary and confused. The building itself was disorienting: big and imposing, with polished floors, nothing like his school back home in Guinea. He was surrounded by students from all over the world. He could not understand a word anyone was saying.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: A mob set fire to a police vehicle and beat up three police officers in Srinagar after prayers on Monday during the Muslim celebration of Id al-Fitr, Kashmir Live  reported.

headline: Blunting Ideology With Biography
text: Unless you’ve subjected yourself to an Internet blackout to better commune with the natural pleasures of summer, chances are you’ve heard something about Mindy Meyer, the 22-year-old New York State Senate contestant, who, when asked about Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in an interview, said she was “not familiar with him in particular, like his issues, and you know, everything about him.” A Brooklynite who would appear to find her intellectual stimulation in caricatures of celebrity vapidity, she has sought the endorsement of Kim Kardashian.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Wages in Bangladesh Far Below India
text: India’s neighbor Bangladesh has become the second-largest apparel exporter in the world, after China, Jim Yardley  reports, but labor unrest is growing as workers demand higher wages.

headline: Remembering Steve Van Buren,  Hall of Famer for Eagles
text: Steve Van Buren led the Philadelphia Eagles to three straight Eastern Division titles and their first two N.F.L. championships, in 1948 and 1949. He retired as the leading rusher in league history. Van Buren died on Thursday in Lancaster, Pa., of pneumonia. He was 91. A few thoughts:

headline: The Weekend Word: Crisis Management
text: Today’s Times• A 1968 car crash in France and the 1998 diagnosis of Ann Romney’s multiple sclerosis were dark moments in what has otherwise seemed a charmed existence for Mitt Romney, Sheryl Gay Stolberg writes. Both offer clues into the Republican nominee’s character and the way he reacts to challenges.

headline: Working Out With the Women of Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG—Hong Kong is muggy and mountainous, but that isn’t slowing down the city’s senior citizens.

headline: Las Vegas and the Prince Harry Effect
text: LONDON — As British newspapers continued to harrumph about Prince Harry’s naked antics in Las Vegas, the scandal surrounding the third-in-line to the throne appeared to have done little to chill their readers’ enthusiasm for visiting Sin City.

headline: The End of the Line
text: AL GORE lives alone now, in a 10,000-square-foot colonial in Nashville, where magnolia trees shade the house and geothermal wells, buried beneath the driveway, cool and heat its 20 rooms.

headline: Pakistani Militant Leader Dies in Airstrike, NATO Says
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — NATO forces said on Saturday that they had killed a senior Pakistani Taliban commander in an airstrike in Afghanistan, highlighting the increasingly complicated nature of the fight against Islamist militants along the border between Afghanistan and Pakistan.

headline: At Least 39 Killed in Blast at Refinery in Venezuela
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — At least 39 people were killed on Saturday and dozens more were injured in a giant explosion that set off a raging fire at Venezuela’s largest oil refinery, according to officials who rushed to the scene on the Paraguaná Peninsula.

headline: Eight Fantasy Football Sleepers in 2012
text: The term sleeper in fantasy football has changed over the last decade. Years ago, you could find great value with a rookie running back that no one knew about. Now, that player is going in the eighth round and every fantasy owner in your league knows his 40-yard dash time, vertical leap, college yards-per-carry and mother’s maiden name.

headline: Inflation Lessons
text: One of the themes I’ve hit on many times is the fact that the crisis and slump have been a testing ground for economic doctrines. People came into this mess with very different views about how the economy works, and the crisis in effect provided natural experiments that tested those views.

headline: College Football Preview: Overlooked, but They Shouldn’t Be
text: STAR LOTULELEI, UTAH, DTLotulelei, a senior, demands double teams, collapses the pocket, clogs running lanes and tears up game plans.

headline: Union Leader Works On Despite Brain Tumor
text: The player representatives for every major league team were summoned to a conference call with the union’s executive director, Michael Weiner, at 1 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday. The players did not know the subject but had no reason to suspect anything unusual. Weiner wasted no time in telling them the news: the day before, he had begun treatment for a brain tumor.

headline: Games Are Over; Battle Goes On
text: The Olympic sprinter Sanya Richards-Ross was at BET’s Midtown studios last Wednesday for an appearance on the hip-hop show “106 & Park.” Before stepping in front of the raucous studio audience, she put on her makeup with expert precision and helped a hair stylist fashion her characteristic “S. R. R. braid.” Later she joked with the rapper Bow Wow about his stealing the two gold medals she won at the recent London Games.

headline: Romney Compares Protesters to a Greek Chorus
text: POWELL, Ohio — Mitt Romney had a message for the protesters who greeted him and Representative Paul D. Ryan, along with 5,000 supporters, here on Saturday morning: “This is kind of like the Greek chorus in the background,” he said, in a reference to President Obama’s speech four years ago at the Democratic convention in Denver, which he delivered in front of large Greek columns.

headline: The Rangers’ Renaissance Man
text: The death last week of the Rangers star Don Raleigh at 86 severed another of the last links to a long-vanished world of hockey where the ice was brown, chicken-wire fencing guarded the ends of the rink and a skinny player who developed a taste for opera could make it in the N.H.L.

headline: Storm Adds to Misery in Haiti’s Homeless Camps
text: MEXICO CITY — Tropical Storm Isaac whirled across Haiti on Saturday, delivering strong winds and rain that caused flooding, mudslides and at least a few deaths, according to preliminary reports, but not the kind of widespread destruction feared in the earthquake-battered nation.

headline: Jets’ Pouha Says He Will Be Ready
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Sione Pouha thought he knew pretty much everything there was to know about what it felt like to butt heads with offensive linemen. Pouha is a 325-pound nose tackle entering his eighth year with the Jets, and knocking helmets is just a part of the job.

headline: Variety: A Fair Acrostic

headline: French Leader Hails Greeks for ‘Painful Efforts’ in Crisis

headline: Ragtag Revolts in Parts of Afghanistan Repel Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In small mountain villages on Taliban turf in eastern Afghanistan, Pashtun tribesmen took up arms to fight the insurgents this summer, fed up with their heavy-handed tactics of closing schools and threatening families whose sons had joined the Afghan Army.

headline: Another Alternative Inflation Measure
text: A correspondent alerted me to an interesting alternative measure of inflation beyond the Billion Price Index. Those who claim that inflation is vastly understated often appeal to the authority of Shadowstats, a site that purports to provide true measures of many economic variables.

headline: No Crime, No Punishment
text: When the Justice Department recently closed its criminal investigation of Goldman Sachs, it became all but certain that no major American banks or their top executives would ever face criminal charges for their role in the financial crisis.

text: The smartphone in your hand is a marvel of innovation, packing sophisticated computing and communications technologies into a sleek digital device.

headline: A Glitch in Health Care Reform
text: Confusing language in the health care reform law has raised the possibility that millions of Americans living on modest incomes may be unable to afford their employers’ family policies and yet fail to qualify for government subsidies to buy their own insurance. This is a bizarre development that undercuts the basic goal of health care reform — to expand the number of insured people and make their coverage affordable.

headline: The Outbreak of West Nile Disease
text: The nation is in the midst of an outbreak of West Nile disease that could become the worst ever recorded since the virus was first detected in New York in 1999. The number of cases has risen sharply in recent weeks.

headline: How Mr. Romney Would Force-Feed the Pentagon
text: Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan are portraying themselves as lionhearted budget-cutters, ready to slice out profligate spending in all sorts of government programs and services and lead America to lower taxes and lower deficits. Many experts say their numbers don’t add up, even if they were to impose all the cuts they want.

headline: How Long Do You Want to Live?
text: SINCE 1900, the life expectancy of Americans has jumped to just shy of 80 from 47 years. This surge comes mostly from improved hygiene and nutrition, but also from new discoveries and interventions: everything from antibiotics and heart bypass surgery to cancer drugs that target and neutralize the impact of specific genetic mutations.

headline: Leave Me Alone!
text: I watched Super Bowl XLVI in February by myself, the same way I watch most televised N.F.L. games. Sad? Hardly. Solo watching is a habit I adopted in high school. Although my friends and family were not overtly obnoxious, I often found them disruptive.

headline: Big Chem, Big Harm?
text: NEW research is demonstrating that some common chemicals all around us may be even more harmful than previously thought. It seems that they may damage us in ways that are transmitted generation after generation, imperiling not only us but also our descendants.

headline: U.S. Cup Qualifier: The View From Traffic in Brazil

headline: 30 Seconds With Anthony Davis: Unique Twist to Hoops Trifecta

After leading Kentucky to the N.C.A.A. championship in April, Davis, a 6-foot-10 power forward, was chosen in June by the New Orleans Hornets as the first pick of the N.B.A. draft. This month, Davis helped the United States men’s basketball team win the gold medal at the London Olympics.

text: Randy Moody is the co-chairman of Republicans for Planned Parenthood, which was founded in 1995 to give Republicans who favor abortion rights a voice. Despite his long-shot lobbying efforts and the continuing furor over Representative Todd Akin’s remarks about abortion and rape, the G.O.P. Platform Committee last week adopted a strict anti-abortion position with no exceptions for rape, incest or to save the life of the mother.

headline: Dozens of Bodies Are Found in Town Outside Damascus
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Dozens of bodies, possibly more than 200, were found Saturday in a town outside Damascus, raising the specter of a massacre by Syrian troops as bad as any atrocity committed since the Syrian uprising began nearly 18 months ago.

headline: The Democrats’ Abortion Moment

headline: An Immune Disorder at the Root of Autism
text: IN recent years, scientists have made extraordinary advances in understanding the causes of autism, now estimated to afflict 1 in 88 children. But remarkably little of this understanding has percolated into popular awareness, which often remains fixated on vaccines.

headline: Chinese Deny Forcing Refugees to Myanmar
text: The Chinese Foreign Ministry has denied human rights advocates’ reports that China is forcing ethnic Kachin refugees to return to a war zone in Myanmar, saying that the people are going home of their own accord.

headline: What Would Jesus Do? Skinny-Dip
text: KEVIN YODER, a congressman from Kansas, apologized last week for swimming nude in the Sea of Galilee last summer during a trip with his wife and other members of Congress, who apparently were clothed. Actually, he apologized for “any embarrassment I have caused for my colleagues and constituents.”

headline: Out of a Job, but Not Missing a Beat
text: Scott Radinsky pitched for four major league teams from 1990 to 2001. A left-handed reliever who appeared in 557 games, Radinsky compiled a 42-25 record, a 3.44 earned run average and 52 saves. In 2004, he began working his way up the coaching ranks for the Cleveland Indians, serving as a pitching coach for four of their minor league teams. In 2010, he became the Indians’ bullpen coach, and this year, he was put in charge of the pitchers. But six days after a reporter interviewed him in Cleveland, Radinsky was home in California, without a job and pondering his next move. And he was being Radinsky, which means being engagingly different, as this two-week account demonstrates.

headline: Shifting Conference Alignments
text: Nearly a quarter of the 124 programs in the Football Bowl Subdivision will change their conference affiliation between 2011-13. A look at the 2012 and 2013 changes.

headline: Lee’s Losing Battle on the Mound
text: Last Tuesday, in the seventh inning against Cincinnati at Citizens Bank Park, Cliff Lee of the Philadelphia Phillies walked Todd Frazier. It is the only walk Lee has issued in four starts this month, compared with 32 strikeouts. Alas, he has no victories in August.

headline: The Antisocial Contract
text: WHEN the Republican Party meets in Tampa, Fla., this week, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey will deliver the keynote address. He promises “hard truths.” Twenty years ago, the Democrat-turned-Republican Phil Gramm had that job. Warning to Governor Christie: no one remembers anything Mr. Gramm said. What we do remember from the 1992 convention in Houston is the jeremiad delivered by Patrick J. Buchanan, the former speechwriter for Richard M. Nixon who won nearly a quarter of Republican primary votes that year. With his invocation of a “cultural war” for the “soul of America,” Mr. Buchanan brought down the house.

headline: Drugs, Sweat and Fear
text: In the fall of 2007, I attended my first yoga class. For more than four years — ever since graduation had dumped me into adulthood — I’d been leveled by anxiety. My days were plagued with worry. Was I living correctly? What if I died? What if, like in that Twilight Zone episode, the rest of the world died and I lived? Innocuous things I said to people haunted me hours later— Was that dumb? Mean? Wildly inappropriate?—until I’d squirm with shame. Unable to sleep at night, I gobbled Tylenol PM, rationalizing that it was over-the-counter, as if “over-the-counter” meant “nutritious.

headline: Radical Islamic Attacks in a Moderate Region Unnerve the Kremlin

headline: The Sun Belt, Eclipsed

It was more than just a source of votes. The Sun Belt infused the Republican Party with a frontier spirit: the optimistic, free-ranging embrace of individualism and the disdain for big government and regulation.

headline: By Adding Pieces, Braves Are Hoping to Complete Puzzle

headline: Kuroda’s One Year Is Enough to Wonder About Next One
text: CLEVELAND — Although Hiroki Kuroda lost the game, he provided exactly the kind of performance that persuaded ed the Yankees to sign him last winter. He allowed three runs in eight innings; on a normal night, that equals a victory for a Yankees pitcher.

headline: Despite Democrats’ Warnings, Private Medicare Plans Find Success

headline: Red Sox’ Deal Catches Yanks by Surprise

Whenever a team makes a significant move that has wide-ranging implications in the division, it always captures the attention of its rivals, and no team is measured against the Yankees more than the Red Sox, and vice versa.

headline: Stonewall’s Bounty
text: It was the most grueling of the forced marches for which Gen. Stonewall Jackson was justly famous — 56 miles in 36 hours across the rolling Virginia Piedmont. To move faster, at the beginning his men were ordered to “unsling knapsacks.” They were going to live off the land. But the land didn’t offer much to sustain 23,000 Confederates. On the second day, remembered a South Carolina soldier, Berry Benson, “My only food…was a handful of parched corn and three or four small sour green apples.”

headline: Into the Laboratory for the Secrets of Spin
text: SCHILLER PARK, Ill. — Perhaps nowhere is tennis’s evolution more visible than at the All England Club, which hosted Wimbledon and the Olympics this summer. The clues were found on the manicured lawns of Centre Court, where by the end of each tournament, scorching rallies had browned the grass at the baselines, a far cry from the hourglass pattern of wear and tear seen during the serve-and-volley heyday.

headline: Down to Earth, But Heroic Nonetheless
text: HONG KONG — The word isn’t often used in a serious or confident way anymore — hero — but it’s certainly being invoked, and appropriately so, in the obituaries about Neil Armstrong.

headline: Returning Champs Remember Their Returns
text: Samantha Stosur did not play a single match in Arthur Ashe Stadium during the 2011 United States Open until the final, when she stunningly and resoundingly defeated heavily-favored Serena Williams, 6-2, 6-3, to win her first Grand Slam singles crown.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Editions
text: In a well-researched piece in the Economic and Political Weekly, Jyoti Punwani analyzes the run-up to the Aug. 11 rally at Azad Maidan in Mumbai and the fallout from the violence that occurred. There were clear signs of upcoming trouble, which the Mumbai police should have noticed, she argues, including a weeklong promotion of the rally that involved the circulation of graphic video clips taken from the Internet and widespread discussion in the Urdu press. The Mumbai police suffer from a chronic lack of intelligence about the city’s Muslim community, she argues, caused by its lack of knowledge of Urdu, lack of Muslim recruits and biased attitude.

headline: Crackdown Toll Seen as Syrians Bury Hundreds
text: DARAYA, Syria — Mass burials in this Damascus suburb on Sunday showed the carnage of the past few days in gruesome detail: scores of bodies lined up on top of one another in long, thin graves moist with mud.

headline: Reader Comments on my Big Chem Column
text: My Sunday column is about chemicals that are all around us and appear to be even more dangerous than previously thought. I’ve written before about these endocrine disruptors, so called because they wreak havoc with the body’s endocrine system governing hormones. Now new research indicates that their effects may be passed down from generation to generation in humans. Using doses of the chemical BPA similar to what humans encounter, the study shows that exposure to the chemical in pregnant mice can affect the sociability of their children and their children’s children. This should be devastating for Big Chem, which has so far been able to block any meaningful national curbs on endocrine disruptors. This obviously isn’t regular fodder for op-ed columns, but it seems an issue of public health and public policy that deserves more attention. I’d welcome your comments on what should be done.
