headline: In Dollar Thrifty Deal, Hertz Bets Big on Certainty of Closing
text: It took Hertz Global Holdings two years to reach an agreement to buy the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group.

headline: New York Film Festival Adds ‘Heaven’s Gate’ to Masterworks Lineup
text: Set aside 219 minutes of your life and get ready to stake out a position on one of the more controversial works of contemporary cinema: “Heaven’s Gate” is coming to the New York Film Festival. That 1980 Michael Cimino western — which, depending on your perspective, is either an underrated epic that was misunderstood in its day or the overwrought behemoth that brought down an entire motion-picture studio (or possibly both); but definitely features Kris Kristofferson on roller skates — will be presented as part of the festival’s Masterworks lineup, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Monday.

headline: Health Care Flaws (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Medical Imaging’s Gains (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Genes and Memory (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: After Deadly Sweep Through Haiti, Tropical Storm Isaac Heads for Gulf Coast
text: Tropical Storm Isaac churned toward the central Gulf Coast of the United States on Monday after a weekend of flooding in southern Florida and destruction in Haiti, where at least 19 people died, according to The Associated Press, from the effects of its violent winds and torrential rains. Another five died in the Dominican Republic, The A.P. said.

headline: Stigma of H.I.V. Is a Barrier to Prenatal Care
text: Fear of being stigmatized as an AIDS patient is still a major barrier to good medical care for pregnant young women in many countries, a new study and a literature review have found.

headline: The End of the Offline World as We Know It?
text: On Sunday, I wrote a column about re-learning to live in the moment — something that has become a challenge given that I am constantly tuning into the lives of my friends and the people I know though my smartphone and various social networks.

headline: To Keep Inventor’s Flame Bright, Fans Return to His Workshop
text: Nikola Tesla electrified the world with alternating current, then slipped into obscurity, dying penniless in 1943 on the 33rd floor of the New Yorker Hotel in Manhattan. But though his fame was eclipsed by other inventors, he was never forgotten: A hardy band of enthusiasts has long sought to give this eccentric genius his due.

headline: TimesCast Politics | August 27, 2 P.M.
text: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi discusses the weather's impact on the convention. | Rallies and protests outside. | David Firestone of The Times's editorial board on Paul Ryan's social policies.

headline: Arctic Sea Ice Hits New and Early Summer Low for Satellite Era
text: 11:44 p.m. | Updates from several scientists below |The planet is warming and the Arctic is warming the most, as long foreseen by scientists in a climate system pushed out of balance through the rapid buildup of heat-trapping greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. One result is greater loss of Arctic sea ice in the annual summer warmup.

headline: ‘Best Man,’ ‘One Man, Two Guvnors’ Turn a Profit
text: Only a fraction of Broadway musicals ever turn a profit, and even rarer are plays that end up making money for their investors. But in the last week, two did: The producers of the “Gore Vidal’s The Best Man” announced on Monday that they had recouped their $3.25 million capitalization costs, a few days after producers of the comedy “One Man, Two Guvnors” said they had recouped their investment of $3.25 million as well.

headline: People Watching | Steve Roden
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Woman, 29, Found Fatally Injured on Lower East Side
text: Updated, 10:51 p.m. |  A 29-year-old woman was found fatally injured and bleeding from her neck in a stairwell on the Lower East Side on Monday, the police said.

headline: Street Style: Afro-Punk Music Festival
text: The eighth annual Afro-Punk Festival took place at Commodore Barry Park in Brooklyn.

headline: What Children Really Need for ‘Back to School’
text: Looking over summer homework assignments, last-minute shopping for clothes and supplies, and checking classroom placements — these are among the things parents do in the final weeks before their children start school.

headline: Schumer Urges Repairs to the Capitol Dome
text: 6:46 p.m. | Updated Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, citing years of inclement weather, sent a letter to Speaker John A. Boehner on Monday about the “severe disrepair” plaguing the Capitol dome.

headline: Van Cliburn Has Advanced Bone Cancer
text: The pianist Van Cliburn, who famously triumphed at the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow in 1958, has “advanced bone cancer,” a spokeswoman said on Monday.

headline: Boehner Sees G.O.P. Victory, but Not Necessarily a Mandate on Medicare
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The House speaker, John A. Boehner, on Monday cautiously predicted victory for Republicans up and down the ticket in November, but he avoided saying that a Republican victory would mean a mandate for the sweeping changes to Medicare that Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan have proposed.

headline: Scourge of the Lionfish, Part 2: Counterattack
text: Carl Safina is founder of Blue Ocean Institute at Stony Brook University and a MacArthur Fellow. His books include “A Sea in Flames: The Deepwater Horizon Oil Blowout,” and “The View From Lazy Point; A Natural Year in an Unnatural World,” which won the  2012 Orion Award. His series “Saving the Ocean” will be premiering this fall on PBS television.

headline: New Warren Ad Keeps Focus on Women’s Issues
text: BOSTON — A new television ad released by Elizabeth Warren on Monday aimed to keep Massachusetts voters’ attention on women’s issues after Ms. Warren and her Republican opponent, Senator Scott P. Brown, pounced on the comments about rape made by Representative Todd Akin of Missouri.

headline: Happy Days, of All Kinds, for a Town in Ulster
text: ENNISKILLEN, Northern Ireland — “Happy Days!” said the waiter as he neatly deposited plates of the “Beckett Special Antipasti” (chicken and foie gras terrine, a curried soup with mussels, smoked haddock fish cake) at our table. As this phrase is the title of Samuel Beckett’s 1961 play, and also of a new Beckett festival in this small town, he might well have been joking. But he wasn’t. “Happy days,” as it turns out, is a commonly used salutation in these parts.

headline: Afro-Punk Festival in Brooklyn
text: The festival returned last weekend to Commodore Barry Park in Fort Greene with 32 bands and disc jockeys.

headline: A Punk Fest, Defiant and Undefinable
text: Slamming together categories — and, when appropriate, bodies — is the ever-expanding mission of the annual Afro-Punk Festival, which returned last weekend to Commodore Barry Park in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

headline: The Storm, Again
text: Tropical Storm Isaac is more than just a logistical inconvenience for Republicans gathered in Tampa: it is a powerful reminder both of Republican incompetence in handling Hurricane Katrina seven years ago, and the party’s no-less-disastrous plans to further cut emergency-related spending.

headline: As Convention Opens, Debt Clock Ticks
text: As Republicans gather in Tampa, Fla., for their convention, party leaders want to drive home a message to voters: The federal debt is hurtling toward $16 trillion, and it is President Obama’s fault.

headline: Should the President Deliver a Marine Citation in Person?
text: In his Op-Ed column today, Roger Cohen quoted a letter from John Kael Weston to President Obama.  Mr. Weston, who served for the State Department in the city of Fallujah in Iraq and in Afghanistan’s Helmand Province, suggested that Mr. Obama appear in person at Camp Lejeune, in North Carolina, next month to present the Presidential Unit Citation to soldiers who fought under the Marine Expeditionary Brigade-Afghanistan from May 29, 2009, to April 12, 2010.

headline: As Genes Learn Tricks, Animal Lifestyles Evolve
text: Early one evening a few years ago, I took a short hike with my wife, Jamie, in the Cockscomb Basin Wildlife Sanctuary in Belize. The large, lush reserve is known for its healthy population of jaguars, so, following closely behind our guide, we kept our eyes peeled for the elusive cats. We saw a few tracks and some claw marks on trees, but elected to leave the jungle before nightfall.

headline: Many Bone Tests for Some, and Too Few for Others
text: Though Riva Schwartz, who manages a law office in Garden City, N.Y., has never broken a bone, she began receiving bone-density scans almost 10 years ago, when she turned 50. Eventually she was given a diagnosis of osteoporosis and started treatment. But every bone-building medication she took had side effects.

headline: Aspirin May Aid Cancer Recovery
text: Men treated for prostate cancer who took aspirin regularly for other medical conditions were less likely to die of their cancer than patients who weren’t taking aspirin, according to a new study published on Tuesday in The Journal of Clinical Oncology.

headline: Fuel Factory Explodes, Then Comedy Ensues
text: The country’s insatiable appetite for energy powers Dan O’Neil’s “Victor Frange Presents Gas,” a diffuse and fitfully insightful eco-comedy from the Incubator Arts Project. With one roaring engine.

headline: Dented Souls, on the Road to Redemption
text: “Before I became Mr. Mom,” says Ben Benjamin Jr., the unlucky hero of “The Revised Fundamentals of Caregiving,” Jonathan Evison’s third and most stealthily powerful novel, “I had decent options. O.K., options.” Ben had a work history of painting parade floats and stacking scones in a bakery, then switched gears to become a doting father and husband. He gave his all to domesticity. He had no idea how evanescent his ordinary life would be.

headline: Times Talks: Looking Back on 'Lost'
text: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof, executive producers, discuss the finale of the ABC series.

headline: Times Talks: Looking Back on 'Lost'
text: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof, executive producers, discuss the "sideways" timeline of the final season.

headline: Times Talks: Looking Back on 'Lost'
text: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof, executive producers, talk about why the answers to questions on "Lost" simply lead to more questions.

headline: Docking and Dining on Jamaica Bay
text: Here are spots on the bay side that remain little known except to the locals and boaters who ply Jamaica Bay and make a ritual of stopping by.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Smartphone Satellites and Inheriting E-Books and iTunes
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Boss Vetoes Your Upgrade. (It’s the Seat Next to Him.)
text: I’VE been flying all of my life. When you start a business, it’s great to have to fly because that means your business is growing. But the process is infuriating. As a former counterterrorism agent in Britain, I can’t argue against safety. And at my company, Tough Mudder, we take safety very seriously. But there just needs to be a more efficient manner to conduct security at the airports.

headline: AMC Ad Uses Snarky Blog Post to Mock Dish Network
text: 5:47 p.m. | Updated Does the snarkiness of a blog post translate for a mainstream, general audience? A cable company is hoping to find out.

headline: Music From Yeasayer, Tamia, Lionel Loueke and Divine Fits
text: YEASAYER

headline: Obama Gets Briefing on Tropical Storm
text: President Obama received a briefing on Monday afternoon about Tropical Storm Isaac as it approached hurricane force, but aides say no decision has been made to cancel his campaign trip on Tuesday to two swing states, Iowa and Colorado.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, North Korea, Maryland and Ethiopia.

headline: City to City, on the Cheap
text: The intercity bus business has expanded rapidly since companies like BoltBus and Megabus took to the highways, promising fares as low as a dollar between cities like Boston and New York.

headline: Multiple Clips of Syrian Helicopter Crash
text: As my colleague Steven Erlanger reports, Syrian rebels claimed responsibility for shooting down a government helicopter during fighting in the eastern suburbs of Damascus on Monday.

headline: American Roots Music, Earnestly Embraced Onstage
text: Normally it works like this: A band comes to town, does a soundcheck on its stage for the night, maybe grabs a quick meal of debatable quality, plays a show, then squeezes in some carousing before it is time for its car or van or bus to depart for the next carnival.

headline: Portman to Reprise Obama Role for Romney Debate Preparation
text: TAMPA, Fla. – It’s time for Senator Rob Portman to dust off those old Obama audiobooks again. He has been tapped to reprise his role of playing President Obama to help Mitt Romney prepare for his debates.

headline: A Cynical Portrait of Two Political Bases
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Romney campaign isn’t going to admit that its outrageous welfare ad, falsely accusing President Obama of gutting the welfare-to-work requirement, is a nakedly racial appeal to white working-class voters. (Tom Edsall’s expert dissection this morning makes that clear.)

headline: New Book in Battle Over East vs. West
text: In 1988 Pankaj Mishra was a recent university graduate in the northern Indian city of Benares with big literary ambitions he had little idea how to fulfill. But when he heard that a local library was going to be auctioning back issues of The New York Review of Books as waste paper, he knew exactly what to do.

headline: Far From Wall Street and Silicon Valley, a Focus on Family Ties
text: MILWAUKEE — When the hedge fund manager David Einhorn was just another investment analyst in the mid-1990s, his family gave him $500,000 to get his fund, Greenlight Capital, off the ground. Now that he is a billionaire after a career of doing battle with large corporations, he has returned the favor.

headline: Protests Muted as Convention Gears Up
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The storm that caused Republican officials to cancel the bulk of the first day of their convention is also dampening the protests, as fewer demonstrators than were expected turned out for the first day of rallies.

headline: Top American Junior Will Turn Pro After U.S. Open
text: Mitchell Krueger of Aledo, Tex., has decided to skip college and turn professional after the United States Open junior tournament, which begins next weekend.

headline: Photo Released for Suspect in 13-Year-Old’s Killing
text: Three days after a 13-year-old boy was killed in Brownsville, Brooklyn, the police released a photo on Monday of a 17-year-old who they say they believe is the gunman.

headline: Willard C. Butcher, Former Chief of Chase Manhattan, Dies at 85
text: Willard C. Butcher, the former chairman and chief executive of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, who led the bank during a period of international growth in the 1980s, died on Saturday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 85.

headline: U.S. Military Disciplines 9 Over Video and Koran Burning
text: WASHINGTON — American military authorities disciplined nine service members on Monday for two episodes this year — the burning of Korans and the posting of a video showing Marines urinating on dead insurgents — that prompted nationwide outrage in Afghanistan. The punishments did not include criminal charges or jail time, and they fell short of what President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan had demanded.

headline: Assembly Paid $103,000 in Harassment Case
text: ALBANY — Sheldon Silver, the New York State Assembly speaker, authorized a secret payment of $103,080 to settle sexual harassment claims against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez this year, according to records released by the Assembly on Monday night.

headline: Connecting the Dots After Cyberattack on Saudi Aramco
text: Publicly released details of a cyberattack on Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil producer, appear to confirm reports that critical data on three-quarters of the company’s PCs was replaced with the image of a burning American flag.

headline: Where Pirates Can Dock and Dine in New York
text: ON a recent Sunday, as a guitar player did his best Tom Petty imitation, a pirate politely enjoyed brunch on the deck of the Wharf Bar and Restaurant, overlooking Jamaica Bay. In a knit cap with rhinestone skull and crossbones, a jacket with golden epaulets and a scruffy and ashen beard, he hoisted his Budweiser in a toast: “To the captain!”

headline: Founders of Diaspora, Intended as the Anti-Facebook, Move On
text: Two summers ago, a quartet of students at New York University started an ambitious project called Diaspora that was intended to be an open alternative to Facebook, one that would give its users greater control over their data and personal information. They created a project on Kickstarter with the modest goal of raising $10,000, enough capital to support themselves for the time it would take to develop the software. The project caught fire around the Web, and the group ended up raising $200,000.

headline: Expect Fewer Seats, Even for Overseas Flights
text: WHERE are we going?

headline: Somalia: Troops Seize Port From the Shabab
text: Somali and African Union troops seized the port of Marka, Somalia, on Monday from the Shabab as part of a campaign to secure Somalia, which is trying to establish its first effective national government since 1991. African Union officials said its fighters met little resistance in the battle for Marka, which is about 68 miles south of Mogadishu. The Shabab earned income from taxes and port fees in Marka, according to a United Nations report.

headline: China: 2 Tibetan Teenagers Set Themselves on Fire
text: Two Tibetan teenagers set themselves on fire and burned to death on Monday in an anti-Chinese political protest in a restive Tibetan-populated area of western China’s Sichuan Province, the rights group Free Tibet reported. At least 50 people have set themselves on fire since March 2011. The latest victims were identified as Lobsang Kalsang, an 18-year-old monk, and Damchoek, 17, a former monk. Free Tibet, which has networks of contacts in Tibetan-populated areas of China, said the teenagers staged their protest outside the Kirti monastery in the town of Ngaba, known in Chinese as Aba, a center of anti-Chinese sentiment.

headline: City Revives a Lunch Program That Takes Chefs Into Schools
text: Reversing course, city education officials said on Monday that a well-regarded culinary organization that recruits professional chefs to prepare school lunches could continue doing so when the new year begins next week.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Once-a-Day Pill for H.I.V.
text: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new once-a-day H.I.V. treatment from Gilead Sciences that contains four different drugs in one pill.

headline: In Mexico, Rehearsing to Inject Drama Into the Courtroom
text: MEXICO CITY — The witness’s testimony was beginning to show cracks. He grew visibly tense, his knuckles turning white as he gripped the table harder.

headline: Morsi’s Syria Plan Suggests Regional Approach to Foreign Affairs
text: Did President Obama watch Egypt swing from pivotal ally to potential opponent? Versions of that question have hovered around the presidential campaign from the early Republican primary debates through Mitt Romney’s comments on his recent trip to Israel about the Islamist electoral victories in the wake of the Arab spring.

headline: Timescast: Day 1 of the Republican Convention
text: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

headline: The Man in the Moon
text: Norfolk, Va.

headline: Destroying Precious Land for Gas
text: ON the northern tip of Delaware County, N.Y., where the Catskill Mountains curl up into little kitten hills, and Ouleout Creek slithers north into the Susquehanna River, there is a farm my parents bought before I was born. My earliest memories there are of skipping stones with my father and drinking unpasteurized milk. There are bald eagles and majestic pines, honeybees and raspberries. My mother even planted a ring of white birch trees around the property for protection.

headline: Romney to Arrive in Tampa on Tuesday
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Republican National Convention will be welcoming its newest — and most high-profile — guest on Tuesday: Mitt Romney himself.

headline: Newspapers Fighting Deal on Postage for Ad Fliers
text: WASHINGTON — Having confronted significant declines in advertising revenue, the newspaper industry was dealt another blow last week when the Postal Regulatory Commission approved a plan granting potentially deep discounts to one of the nation’s largest direct marketers.

headline: Deal Helps a Bank Catch Up in Capital
text: One of the nation’s bigger regional banks, M&T Bank, has had a hectic few days of deal-making.

headline: News Outlets Stay Alert but in Place
text: TAMPA, Fla. — As a huge storm churned toward New Orleans, the country’s major television news divisions found themselves torn between covering two rapidly unfolding stories almost 700 miles apart.

headline: At 15, Ko Shows Confidence and Game
text: At home in Palm Beach on Sunday, the Hall of Fame golfer JoAnne Carner was trying to watch one force of nature, but another, Tropical Storm Isaac, dumped so much rain on South Florida that Carner kept losing the satellite picture on her television.

headline: Keynoter Christie Is a Skilled Speaker and Tea Party Pleaser
text: You could set a watch to the cadence of the town hall-style meetings that have helped make Chris Christie a Republican favorite in his 2 ½ years as the governor of New Jersey.

headline: Romney Campaign and Activists Reach Compromise on Delegate Rule
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney’s campaign has reached a compromise with conservative activists in the Republican Party who had been angered by efforts to change rules for delegate selection leading up to the 2016 election.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,087 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: For Putin, Report Says, State Perks Pile High
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin is rumored to be among the world’s wealthiest men, with an oil-fed fortune worth tens of billions of dollars. He denies that, vehemently, but a report to be published Tuesday suggests that the dispute may be beside the point.

headline: Gangs’ Truce Buys El Salvador a Tenuous Peace
text: SAN SALVADOR — They had faced off many times before, on the streets, with guns in their hands. But when top leaders of two of the hemisphere’s most violent street gangs sat across from one another in the stifling air of a maximum security prison here this year, the encounter had a very different aim: peace.

headline: In a Post-9/11 City, a Person’s Language Can Be a Cause for Police Suspicion
text: Earlier this summer, Thomas P. Galati, commanding officer of the New York Police Department’s elite intelligence division, sat for an unusual legal interrogation, during which he talked of his keen interest in Urdu-speaking New Yorkers.

headline: Stealing Coverage From the Republicans
text: On Sunday August 26th, a number of fringe groups staged actions to take attention away from the Republican National Convention.

headline: Composer’s Unknown Political Oeuvre
text: Lin-Manuel Miranda has had a busy few years since his musical “In the Heights,” a hip-hop-infused celebration of the grit and dreams of Latino immigrants in Washington Heights, became a hit on Broadway and won a shelf full of Tony Awards.

headline: Obama, D’Souza and Anti-Colonialism
text: I’ve never before had the experience of seeing a movie based on the ideas of a friend who is also the film’s producer, writer, co-director and on-camera star. The friend is Dinesh D’Souza and the movie is “2016: Obama’s America.” It’s a bit less than 90 minutes long and for the most part it follows the path of D’Souza’s 2010 book “The Roots of Obama’s Rage.”

headline: Samsung Case Puts Apple Closer to Google Fight
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Steven P. Jobs minced no words when talking about Android, Google’s mobile operating system, which he saw as too similar to the iPhone’s. He told his biographer, Walter Isaacson, that Android was “a stolen product” and said, “I’m willing to go thermonuclear war on this.”

headline: Where the Clothes Are as Eclectic as the Music
text: Music flowed through the streets outside Commodore Barry Park in Brooklyn last weekend, luring more than 30,000 concertgoers (according to festival organizers) inside the park for the eighth annual Afro-Punk Festival. The diverse musical lineup, which included Erykah Badu, who is known for her sultry soul sound, and Das Racist, the New York hip-hop group, reflected the crowd that gathered.

headline: In Tampa: Charles Blow & David Firestone
text: The Op-Ed columnist Charles M. Blow asks David Firestone about his editorial on Paul Ryan’s radicalism and the political calculations of the Romney campaign.

headline: Huggability and Helium
text: TAMPA, Fla.

headline: The Real Romney
text: The purpose of the Republican convention is to introduce America to the real Mitt Romney. Fortunately, I have spent hours researching this subject. I can provide you with the definitive biography and a unique look into the Byronic soul of the Republican nominee:

headline: Museum Showcases Ichiro’s Baseball Career
text: TOYOYAMA, Japan — Proud parents often keep mementos from their children’s sports exploits. Nobuyuki and Yoshie Suzuki went several steps further.

headline: Palin Spends First Day of Republican Convention in Arizona
text: GILBERT, Ariz. — Sarah Palin spent the first day of the Republican National Convention serving baked beans and sliders at a barbecue joint here, in a last-minute campaign stop for Kirk Adams, a former state legislator who is vying for the Republican nomination in Arizona’s Fifth Congressional District race.

headline: After Empire State Building Shooting, a Gunman’s Mother Asks Why
text: From the moment she learned that her son had coldly and calculatingly shot and killed a former co-worker in Midtown, the mother of Jeffrey T. Johnson has replayed every reel of his life from birth to boyhood and beyond, searching her memory for something that might help explain why.

headline: Active in Cloud, Amazon Reshapes Computing
text: SEATTLE — Within a few years, Amazon.com’s creative destruction of both traditional book publishing and retailing may be footnotes to the company’s larger and more secretive goal: giving anyone on the planet access to an almost unimaginable amount of computing power.

headline: After Attacks, Israeli Schools Confront Hate
text: JERUSALEM — Tamer Jbarah, a 17-year-old Palestinian student who speaks accentless Hebrew after years in a bilingual school that is about half Jewish, said he was not at all surprised when a mob of Jewish teenagers beat an Arab teenager unconscious this month while hundreds watched and did nothing to help.

headline: The Yellow Test
text: I went to see Carrie a week after her accident. Her shoulder had been broken, the bone shattered, and 24 stitches were needed to sew the cuts on her face. Her arm was in a sling. Her feet were propped on a pillow. A bottle of Vicodin was on a table within easy reach.

headline: Upstate Judge Is Censured for Accidentally Firing Gun in Chambers
text: On second thought, Judge Vincent A. Sgueglia admitted to state judicial officials, the landmark courthouse in Owego, N.Y., was probably not the best place to repair a revolver with a faulty firing mechanism.

headline: Latest Scandals From Albany
text: It is time for Vito Lopez to resign after 28 years as a New York state assemblyman. On Friday, Speaker Sheldon Silver censured him after the Assembly’s bipartisan ethics committee found that Mr. Lopez had sexually harassed and groped two female employees. Mr. Lopez, who says the accusations are “unfair and untrue,” was stripped of his powerful position as Housing Committee chairman. A fixture on the political landscape since 1984, Mr. Lopez is also the Democratic Party boss in Brooklyn.

headline: Business and Political Experiences Pull Romney 2 Ways on Economy
text: WASHINGTON — When Mitt Romney declared during his unsuccessful campaign for the Senate in 1994 that the federal minimum wage should rise with inflation, a break with Republican doctrine, both Democrats and Republicans accused him of pandering to Massachusetts voters.

headline: After Replacing Coach, Li Finds Quick Success
text: After losing in the first round at the London Olympics, an event especially important at home in China, Li Na decided it was time for a change.

headline: Video From Tampa: Paul Ryan’s Extremism
text: In Tampa, Op-Ed columnist Charles Blow talks to David Firestone about Paul Ryan’s socially conservative policies and his impact on Mitt Romney’s electoral prospects.

headline: Yankees Bring Back a Bat They Hope Can Help
text: The Yankees acquired outfielder Steve Pearce from the Houston Astros on Monday, completing a circuitous route for the 29-year-old journeyman who has switched teams numerous times this season.

headline: Military Spending on Biofuels Draws Fire
text: When the Navy put a Pacific fleet through maneuvers on a $12 million cocktail of biofuels this summer, it proved that warships could actually operate on diesel from algae or chicken fat.

headline: New York Rabbi’s Prayer Will Open G.O.P. Convention
text: The Republican Party does not often mention New York City as the place it turns to for religious guidance. But this year, New Yorkers will give both the opening and the closing prayers at the Republican National Convention, in a quirk of timing that nevertheless highlights the increased importance the party is placing on appealing to Jewish and Catholic voters.

headline: With Referees Out, N.F.L. Stars Throw Flag on Novice Fill-Ins
text: In one National Football League preseason game, the referee announced a penalty with his back to the television camera. In another, an official twice referred to a team from Atlanta as Arizona. That referee, whose previous experience included a stint in the Lingerie Football League, also mixed up which team had won the coin toss.

headline: Lottery Numbers
‘Warning: Smoking Can Kill You’
text: Tobacco use is the leading preventable cause of death in the United States. Around 400,000 people die each year from smoking, which cuts lives short on average about 13 years. And that does not include the 50,000 who die from exposure to secondhand smoke or the 8.6 million whose illnesses are caused by smoking.

headline: 2 Courts Cite a Vague Rule in Rejecting State Laws
text: For years, opponents of a payroll tax to help finance the Metropolitan Transportation Authority argued that it unfairly made people in the suburbs underwrite a service that mostly benefited people in New York City.

headline: Iran’s Nuclear Quest
text: Iran appears to have installed a few hundred more centrifuges at its deep underground site known as Fordow, thus enhancing its ability to produce uranium enriched to 20 percent, a purity that can be converted relatively quickly to bomb-grade fuel.

headline: Aftermath of the Amuay Refinery Explosion
text: A deadly explosion at Venezuela’s largest oil refinery over the weekend has killed at least 41 people, leaving the neighboring town of Punto Fijo to cope with the destruction.

headline: Venezuelan Government Criticized in Deadly Refinery Blast
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — A deadly explosion at Venezuela’s largest oil refinery over the weekend has unleashed a barrage of criticism at the government’s management of the state-run oil company, Petróleos de Venezuela. Even as President Hugo Chávez has turned the oil company into the financial engine of his socialist revolution, critics say it has neglected essential activities like maintenance, safety and the development of new sources of production.

headline: All the Discomforts of Home
text: Deep in the second act of “Heartless,” the murky new play by Sam Shepard, a luminous lunacy lights up the stage. It is generated by Lois Smith and Jenny Bacon, playing a mother and daughter who thus far haven’t had much to say to each other and wouldn’t even appear to have much in common, aside from that inconvenient matter of being related. But just listen to them now.

headline: Path of a Pop-Up
text: Administrivial Acrostic Update Alert! As some of you commented on the 8/26/12 Acrostic blog post about Garrison Keillor, there was a minor goof in one of the clues. I asked Will Shortz about it, and here is his response: “Amazingly, there were two “Hunchback” movies — one in 1996, the other in 1997. Salma Hayek was in the 1997 one, so the clue should have referenced that date.” The date in the puzzle has now been updated.

headline: A Salvadoran Cease-Fire Holds, for Now
text: A jailhouse truce between two of Latin America’s most violent street gangs appears to have held for five months, leading to a steep drop in homicides. But there are questions over its durability.

headline: Texas: Appeals Court Declines to Rule on Forced Shaving of Defendant
text: The highest military appeals court ruled on Monday that it was premature for them to decide whether Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist accused in a shooting rampage at an Army base in Texas in 2009, could have his beard forcibly shaved before the start of his trial. Major Hasan told his lawyers that he began growing a beard because of his Muslim faith. But the judge overseeing his pretrial hearings at Fort Hood said that Major Hasan was disrupting the proceedings and violating Army regulations, and that he would be forcibly shaved if he did not do so voluntarily. Major Hasan’s lawyers appealed, but on Monday the United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces said that since the judge had not issued a definitive order for a forcible shaving, it was too early for them to decide. The court said that if such an order were issued, Major Hasan could appeal to a lower Army appeals court. But the court appeared to agree with Major Hasan’s lawyers on elements of the case, asking the judge to address, if an order for shaving was given, why a forcible shaving was the “least restrictive means” of intruding on his religious liberties. With the court’s stay on the proceedings lifted, neither a hearing date nor a trial date had yet been scheduled.

headline: Party Down, Favela Style
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A Colt AR-15 rifle was aimed at my gut, an FMK-3 sub-machine gun a little lower. The men holding the weapons were barely that, and they shared a bottle of cheirinho da loló, passing the cheap chloroform-ether mix back and forth, sniffing it for a glossy high. This was a baile funk, Rio de Janeiro’s illegal block party of music, guns and narcotics — one of those all-night festas that exist in myth for those who cannot gain access to them or are too fearful to attend.

headline: The Euro Crisis Is Back From Vacation
text: In June, it seemed as if any day might bring about the collapse of the Greek economy and with it, the entire euro zone and its decade-old currency. Then in July and August, it seemed as if everyone was on vacation. Now they’re back — finance officials and political leaders have been flying all over Europe to meet with one another — and along with them the crisis that has been raging for the last two years. Here is a guide to the new season’s most intriguing (and terrifying) story lines.

headline: Hunting for Debris and Answers in Alaska
text: Throughout months of measuring trees, I carried the hope of finding a glass float on the outer coast of Southeast Alaska. Green and blue and made of hand-blown glass, they are remnants of the deep sea fishing industry, used long before plastic and other materials kept nets afloat. Most that remain today originated in Japan. Since I last wrote for the Green Blog, we’ve visited 24 sites in dead, dying and stressed yellow cedar forests in the West Chichagof-Yakobi Wilderness over the course of a three-week expedition.

This picturesque corner of Appalachia has now provided a bonanza for dialect coaches and their charges, who set the hills alive with a symphony of dropped consonants and attenuated vowels almost as violent as the gunfire that periodically erupts.

headline: Finding Something Worthy in Every Find

If the price is right (it usually is), I buy them and take them home.

headline: Is Ron Paul Winning the Future?
text: With no actual convention to cover here in Tampa these last two days, the press has gravitated toward what you might call para-convention events: Newt Gingrich’s week-long “Newt University” tutorial in conservative ideas, for instance, and Ron Paul’s “We Are the Future” rally for his army of supporters, held Sunday at the University of South Florida. About Gingrich, at this point, there is little of interest to be said, but the boasting title of Paul’s rally has at least some claim to be the truth, given how well the libertarian congressman performed with younger voters in the primary season. Writing for the American Conservative, Jim Antle makes a plausible case that Paul has moved the Republican Party in his direction, and might move it further still: From the party-wide enthusiasm for critiques of the Federal Reserve to the reappearance of “bona-fide noninterventionists” in Republican House contests to the emergence of Kentucky Senator Rand Paul as a more mainstream advocate for his father’s ideas, Antle writes, “the rapid progress” of Paulism “in a short period of time is undeniable.”

headline: Obama Courts the Votes of a Less-Engaged Youth

headline: Following Up on a Restaurant’s Unconventional Strategy
text: A year ago, we told you about a dilemma facing Red Iguana, a family-owned Mexican restaurant in Salt Lake City. Its owners, Lucy Cardenas and Bill Coker, were facing a two-pronged problem with their first location. First, a happy problem: their restaurant had gotten so popular after appearing on the Food Network’s “Diners, Drive-ins and Dives” that customers regularly had to wait an hour to be seated. At the same time, the city was about to build a light rail line down the middle of the restaurant’s street, a project that had the potential to force the business to close for several weeks.

Yet I am the kind of practical woman who could hear his fear and chalk it up to predeployment jitters.

headline: The Get | Valentino’s Noir Capsule Flats
text: The designers Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pierpaolo Piccioli have done it again, this time by giving Valentino’s beloved studded accessories a tough new look for their Noir Capsule, which stars materials like python, crocodile and patent leather in all-black with gothic ruthenium spikes (instead of the usual rocker-y silver ones). A favorite from the group and a must-have for fall is this strappy patent-leather flat ($895). The black on black is such a striking contrast to the pretty-lady shape. Lookin’ sharp!

headline: An Artisanal Food Court in TriBeCa
text: When he set out to open a market, Kyle Wittels, an interior designer, knew his limitations. “I wasn’t a retailer,” he said. “I knew I had to get professionals.” So that’s just what he did. All Good Things is a no-frills, floor-through affair in the heart of TriBeCa with counters for different artisanal vendors, like a food court for provisioning. He has lured Orwasher’s for bread, Blue Marble Ice Cream and Nunu Chocolates from Brooklyn, Dickson’s Farmstand Meats from Chelsea Market, Blue Bottle Coffee, the florist Polux Fleuriste and, from Sag Harbor, Cavaniola’s cheeses, condiments and cured meats. The chef Ryan Tate, formerly at Savoy, will run the produce and seafood stands. Mr. Tate will also be the chef for the intimate downstairs restaurant, Le Restaurant, to open in mid-October with a $70 to $80 prix fixe menu with no choices that will change every day.

headline: Hurricane Isaac is a Rainmaker for a Parched Heartland
text: [Sept. 2, 4:32 p.m. | Update | Heavy rains from the storm formerly known as Isaac have indeed been welcomed in a broad stretch of the drought-stricken Midwest, Jack Healy reports in The Times.]

headline: Aperitifs From Oregon Vineyards
text: The business of making spirits in America is constantly finding new niches. The latest are aperitif concoctions, like vermouth, that are inspired by venerable European models. Imbue, a fledgling Oregon company owned by three entrepreneurs, all of whom have worked in wineries, breweries or restaurants, has introduced a vermouth it rightly calls bittersweet. Instead of the austere herbaceousness of a classic French dry vermouth, it has a mellower flavor, without being sweet. Though the company says it was designed to go with new American gins, it seems better suited for what is called a perfect manhattan, which is made with half sweet, half dry vermouth. It’s also elegant on its own, over ice. An aperitif wine called Petal and Thorn is pale rose, fragrant with orange blossom and mimosa up front, but grips with a bitter finish. Serve it on the rocks as you might Lillet. Both products are made from Oregon pinot gris wines that are distilled and blended with eau de vie and botanicals.

headline: More Like an Impostor Than an Innocent Abroad
text: In his new stunt documentary, “The Ambassador,” the Danish journalist and filmmaker Mads Brugger impersonates a European adventurer seeking his fortune in Africa. This character, named Mads Cortzen, might have been dreamed up by Joseph Conrad in collaboration with Sacha Baron Cohen. A slender, dapper fellow with a ginger beard and an ironical manner, Cortzen motors around Liberia and the Central African Republic in a flag-festooned Volvo, handing out bribes and secretly recording his meetings with government ministers, diamond mine owners and shady passport brokers.

headline: Stone Links: Consider the Octopus
text: Scientific American discusses the claim of a group of prominent researchers on consciousness recently convening at Cambridge: a neocortex is not a precondition of conscious experience. In fact, these researchers believe there are good reasons to suppose that the neural substrates of experiential states, and of emotive states as well, are present in creatures with brains structured very differently from our own. Most interestingly, even some invertebrates—specifically, octopuses—appear to show signs of being conscious. “That does not necessarily mean that you could have a distraught octopus or an elated cuttlefish on your hands,” Katherine Harmon writes. But it does mean we need to think of consciousness as being spread across a wide range of species, and being realizable by a number of different neurological structures.

headline: An Art Show for Pussy Riot
text: The Russian performance artists and punk activists known as Pussy Riot, three of whom were sentenced to prison in Moscow this month, continue to garner international support, most recently from the art world. On Sept. 10, the group will be the subject of a pop-up exhibition and fund-raiser at Lombard-Freid Projects, a Chelsea gallery. The event is to be organized by Victoria Dushkina, a curator from Moscow, and Amnesty International, which has supported the cause of Pussy Riot for months.

headline: About Black and White and a Great City’s Blight
text: In the classic Motown song “Dancing in the Street,” Martha and the Vandellas sang, “Can’t forget the Motor City.” That’s easy enough to say when the topic is music: the MC5, the White Stripes, Bob Seger, Diana Ross, Smokey Robinson and countless other influential musicians have their roots there. But when it comes to literature, forgetting Detroit can be regrettably easy to do. The city may be one of our great, if crumbling, metropolises, yet contemporary fiction set there is sparse.  Dean Bakopoulos and Charles Baxter have written memorably about Detroit’s suburbs and nearby Ann Arbor. But fiction about present-day Detroit itself? Not so much lately; it’s almost as if novels themselves had had to flee the post-1960s urban blight.

headline: Live Updates From the Republican National Convention

headline: The Ron Paul Revolt
text: TAMPA, Fla.–It was a far cry from the hijinx at the 1980 convention, when Ted Kennedy tried to wrangle delegates, along with the Democratic nomination, away from President Jimmy Carter–but Ron Paul’s supporters did wage a small-scale revolt in Tampa today.

headline: Delegates Show State Pride in Fashion Choices
text: The tradition of wacky individualistic outfits at party conventions is a long one, so consider the effort it must take to enforce a delegation dress code.

headline: Republican Party Platforms, Then and Now
text: Comparing passages from the 1980 Republican party platform to the party’s platform in 2012.

headline: Times Reporter Shared Maureen Dowd Column With C.I.A. Before Publication
text: A New York Times reporter provided a copy of a column written by the columnist Maureen Dowd to an official with the Central Intelligence Agency before it was published, a spokeswoman for the newspaper has confirmed.

headline: National Retailers Discover a Brooklyn Mall
text: The Fulton Street Mall in Downtown Brooklyn has been changing rapidly in recent years, as national retail chains flock to the mall, a shopping strip that once housed local sneaker stores and jewelry repair shops.

headline: Weapons of the Syrian Rebels
text: Using unconventional means to acquire weapons, Syria’s rebels have managed to besiege the government, seize territory and drive the conventionally equipped Syrian armed forces back in certain areas of the countryside.

headline: Before Lifting DNA, Meticulous Protocol
text: It is a small bit of trickery masquerading as generosity: A suspect is offered a cigarette or a soft drink in a police interrogation room.

headline: Companies Court 181 Million Viewers for N.F.L. Season
text: LIKE children anticipating the arrival of Santa Claus, the marketers of Madison Avenue have circled next Wednesday on their calendars to herald the arrival of the 2012-13 National Football League season.

headline: How the Republicans Built It
text: It was a day late, but the Republicans’ parade of truth-twisting, distortions and plain falsehoods arrived on the podium of their national convention on Tuesday. Following in the footsteps of Mitt Romney’s campaign, rarely have so many convention speeches been based on such shaky foundations.

headline: A Season of Tweaks and Ailments
text: First baseman Mark Teixeira said he expected his left calf strain to keep him out of the lineup for at least a week, but with rosters expanding on Saturday, the Yankees are not expected to put him on the disabled list.

headline: On Our Radar: Green Tuesday at the White House
text: On Tuesday it was environmental news day for the Obama administration.

headline: Robert Kotlowitz, a Shaper of Channel 13, Dies at 87
text: Robert Kotlowitz, a novelist and editor who reluctantly became a public television executive in 1971 and went on to help shape a lineup of homegrown and imported shows — including “The MacNeil/Lehrer Report,” “Live at the Met,” “Dance in America” and “Brideshead Revisited” — that represent a high-water mark in American television, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Sharp Cuts in Dental Coverage for Adults on Medicaid
text: BOSTON — Banned from tightening Medicaid eligibility in recent years, many states have instead slashed optional benefits for millions of poor adults in the program. Teeth have suffered disproportionately.

headline: Discussing Ann Romney
text: Rick Berke and Carolyn Ryan discuss Ann Romney at the Republican National Convention.

headline: Floor Fights and Ron Paul
text: Jim Rutenberg reports on demonstrations by Ron Paul supporters on the floor of the 2012 Republican National Convention.

headline: A Fatal Slip on the Stairs Cuts Short a Life at 29
text: Just months ago, she was studying the translucent flesh of squid bought at a fish market, in the hope of replicating their gleam in the giant, handcrafted model she was making for a special exhibit on bioluminescence at the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: When Chief Executives Share Company News on Facebook
text: RealNetworks, an online media pioneer that is trying to turn itself around, told employees on Tuesday that it would lay off 14 percent of them, or about 160 people over the next seven months, starting with 80 right away. Instead of trying to keep his e-mail to the staff a secret, though, Rob Glaser, the founder of RealNetworks and its interim chief executive, cut and pasted it onto his Facebook page.

headline: Victims’ Sons in Tough Fight for Redress After China Rail Crash
text: SHANGHAI — Henry Cao has stark memories of the moment the high-speed train he was riding rear-ended another last summer in the eastern city of Wenzhou: the pleasantly hypnotic rocking that gave way to a jolt he likened to an earthquake, followed by blackness and the sensation of falling as the car plummeted 100 feet off a viaduct.

headline: In French Baseball League, the Feel Is More Minor Than Major
text: ROUEN, France — The best baseball in France was played on a recent Sunday afternoon in Rouen, on a spartan diamond beyond the soccer field at a municipal sports complex. Rouen’s team, the Huskies, swept a doubleheader against the Templiers of Sénart, outside Paris, on a cool, drizzly day when, at most, 35 spectators huddled under umbrellas on metal-and-plywood bleachers behind home plate.

headline: At 70, Perkins Returns to Coach at Junior College
text: ELLISVILLE, Miss. — Ray Perkins held two of the most high-profile jobs a football coach can occupy. From 1979 to 1982, he was the coach for the Giants, and in 1983, he was chosen to succeed Bear Bryant at Alabama.

headline: Malcolm W. Browne, Pulitzer-Prize Winning Reporter, Dies at 81
text: Malcolm W. Browne, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter whose four-decade career included covering the Vietnam War — and taking one of the most memorable photos of the conflict — and a lively second act as a science writer who explained chemical weapons and described the rise of synthetic body parts, died on Monday in Hanover, N.H. He was 81.

headline: Battling Themselves and Zombies
text: Like an animal warfare episode of “Wild Kingdom” but with less character motivation, “The Day” cycles through bursts of horrific violence only to end much as it begins: static, hollow and vague. An unspecified event a decade earlier — Luke Passmore’s barely-there screenplay is no help here — has left all of society more or less like “The Hunger Games.”

headline: How the Media Adapt When News Is Scarce
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Strange things are happening inside the media workspaces at the Republican National Convention.

headline: Shift in Connecticut Senate Race as Democrat Is Put on the Defensive
text: NEW HAVEN — Representative Christopher S. Murphy has been at once the other guy — the largely unknown subject of attack ads by his Republican rival, Linda E. McMahon — and the Democratic nominee who was presumed to be the heavy favorite in the Senate race to replace Joseph I. Lieberman.

headline: F.A.A. to Review Rules on Use of Electronic Devices
text: Air travelers carrying smartphones, digital tablets and other electronic devices have long complained about having to turn off their gadgets until reaching an altitude of 10,000 feet.

headline: Libya Officials Seem Helpless as Sufi Shrines Are Vandalized
text: CAIRO — Libya’s interior minister retracted his two-day-old resignation announcement on Tuesday amid a growing uproar over the destruction of Sufi shrines and sacred sites, punctuated by a United Nations plea for an end to such “brutal attacks.”

headline: School Abuse Case May Proceed, Judge Says
text: A top-tier Brooklyn private school cannot automatically use New York State’s statute of limitations to prevent a case involving sexual abuse allegations against a former football coach from proceeding, a judge ruled Tuesday, because of the possibility that the school may have engaged in a scheme to cover up decades of abuse.

headline: A Banker Bets on Organic Farming
text: It’s unlikely that large-scale changes in the so-called food system will happen without movement on the part of big investors. Sadly, most of these — like the corporations they support — take short-term, profit-maximizing views. (This, along with enthusiastic dabblers, is the basic reason we have bubbles.) But there are unconventional exceptions. Jeremy Grantham, the chief investment strategist for the unfortunately named G.M.O. (it stands for Grantham, Mayo, Van Otterloo & Co. LLC, and he is a company co-founder), is one of those.

headline: New York State Is Investigating Energy Drink Makers
text: The New York attorney general has subpoenaed three large makers of so-called energy drinks as part of an investigation into whether the companies are misleading consumers about how much caffeine the drinks contain and the health risks they could pose.

headline: Mining for Stories
text: Cape Town

headline: Nalbandian Withdraws From Open
text: David Nalbandian withdrew from the United States Open on Tuesday, the day before he was set to play his fellow Argentine Juan Martín Del Potro in the first round. He had been recovering from a rib injury.

headline: Platform’s Sharp Turn to Right Has Conservatives Cheering
text: One party platform stated that Hispanics and others should not “be barred from education or employment opportunities because English is not their first language.” It highlighted the need for “dependable and affordable” mass transit in cities, noting that “mass transportation offers the prospect for significant energy conservation.” And it prefaced its plank on abortion by saying that “we recognize differing views on this question among Americans in general — and in our own party.”

headline: Taking Flight From Misery, Only to Court Peril
text: Lily and Alison are best friends, unhappy teenagers coming of age on the photogenically desolate shores of California’s storied Salton Sea. That salty, accidentally man-made body of water, with its shoals of calcified fish and bird bones under a relentless desert sun, supplies both a bleak atmosphere and some convenient metaphors for “Little Birds,” Elgin James’s Sundance-incubated debut feature, which follows Lily and Alison on a journey from boredom to danger.

headline: Best Friends, Doubles Partners and, Unhappily, Opponents
text: Vania King waited patiently for her friend before they were escorted out to Court 11 on Tuesday at the United States Open.

headline: $3.5 Million Settlement in Mortgage Bias Case
text: A mortgage company has agreed to pay more than $3.5 million to settle allegations by federal prosecutors that it charged higher interest rates and fees on mortgages to nonwhite borrowers than to whites with similar financial backgrounds, federal officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Federal Court Finds Texas Voting Maps Discriminatory
text: HOUSTON — A federal court in Washington ruled on Tuesday that political maps drawn by the Republican-controlled Legislature in Texas discriminated against minority voters, a decision that black and Hispanic groups claimed as a victory and the state attorney general vowed to appeal to the Supreme Court.

headline: Selective Memory in Tampa
text: The Republican speakers at the first night of the party’s convention in Tampa kept shouting that “it is time” or “about time” or “past time” that the United States had a president who appreciates small businesses, or hates red tape, or wants to get rid of regulations, or wants to cut taxes.

headline: For Half the Field, the Opener Is the Closer
text: One by one they limped off courts at the United States Open, heads bowed, eyes downcast, shoulders slumped. They answered questions in small, interview rooms with concrete walls, away from the stadiums and big crowds.

headline: Humanizing Mitt Romney
text: Carolyn Ryan and Scott Helman from The Boston Globe talk about how the Republican National Convention will act as a platform to make Mitt Romney more likable to the electorate.

headline: The Last Journey
text: The sons of two victims of China’s first high-speed-train crash prepare to bring their parents’ bodies home to New York. The family is locked in compensation talks with Chinese authorities.

headline: For One Night, Mets Shift Directions With Phillies
text: PHILADELPHIA — The once-heated rivalry between the Mets and the Philadelphia Phillies has been reduced to a race for a consolation prize in their division: third place.

headline: Lovelyloveville, Where Pillows Get Presents
text: Silliness runs rampant for the Oogieloves and their young friends on screen and in the movie theater audience.

headline: Americans Shot in Mexico Were C.I.A. Operatives Aiding in Drug War
text: MEXICO CITY — The two Americans who were wounded when gunmen fired on an American Embassy vehicle last week were Central Intelligence Agency employees sent as part of a multiagency effort to bolster Mexican efforts to fight drug traffickers, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Morsi’s Wrong Turn
text: I find it very disturbing that one of the first trips by Egypt’s newly elected president, Mohamed Morsi, will be to attend the Nonaligned Movement’s summit meeting in Tehran this week. Excuse me, President Morsi, but there is only one reason the Iranian regime wants to hold the meeting in Tehran and have heads of state like you attend, and that is to signal to Iran’s people that the world approves of their country’s clerical leadership and therefore they should never, ever, ever again think about launching a democracy movement — the exact same kind of democracy movement that brought you, Mr. Morsi, to power in Egypt.

headline: For Two Brothers, a Painful Odyssey
text: Two Chinese-American brothers went to China to recover the bodies of their parents, who were killed in a high-speed rail crash in Wenzhou in July 2011. The parents, who were janitors at La Guardia Airport, were the only United States citizens killed in the crash.

headline: Couture and Kitsch at the Convention
text: A number of state delegations are making their collective fashion statements at the Republican National Convention.

headline: Render Harmless
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — We really have to watch that Tony Orbach carefully. If we don’t keep our eyes on him, he is liable to pull some sneaky sleight-of-hand on us. In fact, he’s done it today, by swapping the letters “L” and “A” in his theme entries.

headline: The Secret Weapon: All of Us
text: The Republican National Convention opened by smacking President Obama with the theme “We Built it.”

headline: Jets Say Dropped Passes by Rookie Are Not a Concern Yet
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — No Jets receiver has caught more passes in the preseason than the rookie Stephen Hill, the tall and speedy second-round draft choice from Georgia Tech. But Hill does not seem to be asked a lot these days about any of those receptions.

headline: More Than a Dozen Die in 2 Attacks in a Russian Republic
text: MOSCOW — Seven people died in a suicide bombing, including a respected Muslim cleric, and a border guard shot to death seven of his fellow soldiers before being killed on Tuesday in separate attacks in the Republic of Dagestan in the North Caucasus, where Russia has long battled violent Islamic separatists.

headline: How to Weather a Hurricane
text: HURRICANE Isaac, which made landfall in Louisiana last night, has not only disrupted the Republican National Convention but also brought back painful memories of Hurricane Katrina, which devastated the Gulf Coast seven years ago this week.

headline: New Urgency on Airport Plan for Britain’s Cameron
text: LONDON — The idea has been kicking around for nearly 70 years, and now it is Prime Minister David Cameron’s turn to confront it: whether to support the building of a new hub airport on the Thames estuary east of London or to shelve it again, even as projections for future air traffic show London’s existing airports seizing up under the strains within 20 years.

headline: New Code Aims to Ease Suspensions of Students
text: New York City public-school students can no longer be suspended for one-time, low-level infractions, and the youngest pupils can be suspended only for 5 days for midlevel offenses, down from 10, according to new disciplinary rules posted by the Education Department this week.

headline: Police Officers Out in Force in Tampa
text: Thousands of officers are policing the protests at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Court Orders City Tax Increase for Pennsylvania Capital
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — Residents of this debt-laden state capital are facing a court-ordered income tax increase of one percentage point as part of an effort to repair the city’s perilous finances.

headline: Yankees Rely on Small Ball, Not Long Ball
text: When the lineup card was tacked onto the doorway to the Yankees’ clubhouse, Steve Pearce was getting fitted for a belt. His Houston Astros-issue equipment bag had not even arrived yet.

headline: A Refugee Disaster in the Making
text: The bloodshed in Syria, which is getting worse by the day, has created an enormous refugee problem. An estimated 200,000 Syrian refugees have crossed the borders of Turkey, Jordan, Iraq and Lebanon, including more than 80,000 in Turkey alone. The United Nations refugee agency, to which the United States is the biggest donor, could soon be overmatched without more significant efforts from other nations.

headline: In Keynote Speech, Christie Asks Country to Face Hard Truths
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Chris Christie, the sharp-tongued governor of New Jersey, on Tuesday extolled Mitt Romney as an exceptional leader willing to speak hard truths to a nation weary of President Obama‘s policies and ready to make a much-needed change.

headline: Can Hezbollah Survive the Fall of Assad?
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon

headline: U.N. Leader to Tell Iran of Criticisms, an Aide Says
text: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, expects to discuss the disputed Iranian nuclear program, the Syria conflict and the need to provide “greater space” for Iranian political freedoms when he talks with Iran’s leaders during a visit to Tehran this week for the Nonaligned Movement meeting, his spokesman said Tuesday.

headline: Nomination Secure, Romney Pitch Starts
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney, a former governor of Massachusetts who has aspired to reach the White House since his father first sought the office four decades ago, was nominated by the Republican Party here on Tuesday as its choice to become the 45th president of the United States.

headline: New Man on Campus, Armed
text: For more than 30 years, the University of Colorado has enforced a sensible policy banning guns from its campuses. The ban worked well until March, when the State Supreme Court agreed with a student’s complaint that it violated a state law allowing citizens with “concealed-carry” permits to carry guns in public places.

headline: Smoothing the Path From Foreign Lips to American Ears
text: ATHENS, Ohio — For hundreds of grown men and women here, work can mean sticking fingers into models of the human mouth, or trying to talk while peering at their tongues in mirrors or while hopping up and down stairs.

headline: An Uncontrollable Outbreak
text: The menace posed by germs resistant to powerful antibiotics was all too apparent when a deadly, drug-resistant form of pneumonia bacteria struck the Clinical Center of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., last year. It infected 17 patients and killed 6 of them.

headline: Village’s Tribute Reignites a Debate About Italy’s Fascist Past
text: AFFILE, Italy — This village in the rolling hills east of Rome is known for its fresh air, olive oil and wine — and its residual appreciation of Benito Mussolini, whose image adorns some wine bottles on prominent display in local bars.

headline: Stephens Pulls Early Upset; Wozniacki Is Out
text: Before her match with Francesca Schiavone of Italy, before her upset victory and before she displayed her bright smile to the crowd at Louis Armstrong Stadium, Sloane Stephens saw herself on posters.

headline: California Sheriffs Oppose Bill on Illegal Immigrants
text: LOS ANGELES — Some California sheriffs are pushing back against a proposed state law that would bar law enforcement officers from detaining illegal immigrants for deportation if they have not been charged with serious or violent crimes.

headline: David Lederman, Pioneer of Artificial Heart, Dies at 68
text: David M. Lederman, who led the team of scientists that developed the first fully implantable artificial heart — which, although it had limited success, prompted further advances in the treatment of late-stage heart disease — died on Aug. 15 at his home in Marblehead, Mass. He was 68.

headline: Corrections: August 29, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: U.S. Open: Day 2
text: Andy Roddick, Novak Djokovic, Ana Ivanovic and Venus and Serena Williams coast through the first round of play.

headline: Families of Aurora Shooting Victims Ask Relief Fund to Speed Assistance
text: AURORA, Colo. — Clasping hands, their voices thick with grief, the families of some of the victims of last month’s deadly movie theater rampage spoke out on Tuesday, saying they had received scant financial assistance from a relief fund set up to aid them and little explanation as to why.

headline: How New Orleans’s New Defenses May Be Tested
text: New Orleans is expected to get 9 to 10 inches of rainfall in 24 hours. This map shows the rainfall forecast and expected storm surge.

headline: Rick Santorum's R.N.C. Speech
text: Former United States Senator Rick Santorum speaks at the 2012 Republican National Convention.

headline: Lies, Damn Lies and G.O.P. Video
text: TAMPA, Fla.

headline: France Opens Homicide Inquiry in Arafat’s Death
text: A French court will open a homicide investigation into the 2004 death of the former Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, left, French news media reported Tuesday. Mr. Arafat’s widow, Suha, petitioned French authorities to investigate last month after findings by a Swiss laboratory suggested that Mr. Arafat may have been exposed to polonium 210, the same radioactive isotope used to poison a dissident Russian former spy in London in 2006. Mr. Arafat died in a French military hospital on Nov. 11, 2004, after an infection that was never identified, according to medical records. There have long been suggestions, however unspecific, that he may have been the victim of foul play. The Palestinian Authority, which has agreed to exhume the body for analysis, welcomed the French decision, Saeb Erekat, an aide to the Palestinian Authority president Mahmoud Abbas, told Agence France-Presse.

headline: Love, Not Politics?
text: If the purpose of the Republican National Convention was to convince Americans that someone named Romney has a soul, a heart and a rich character, then it succeeded tonight. Only the Romney’s name is Ann, not Mitt.

headline: Paul Supporters’ Protest Signals Deeper Division
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney’s tightly choreographed nomination here was disrupted on Tuesday when a contingent of Ron Paul delegates from several states protested what they said were new rules by the Republican leadership to squelch their movement’s rise within the party.

headline: In Speech, Ann Romney Plays to the Heart
text: Ann Romney introduced her husband Tuesday night to the nation and to the Republican Party that had nominated him as president with a rousing speech that exhorted Americans, “You can trust Mitt.”

headline: George L. Gunther, Connecticut Legislator, Dies at 92
text: George L. Gunther, an iconoclastic Republican state senator from Connecticut who spent 40 years in office, making him the state’s longest-serving member of the General Assembly, died on Sunday in Branford, Conn. He was 92 and lived in Stratford.

headline: Surprise Journey Ends Early for Israeli Underdog
text: Kiryat Shmona is a hardened little city on Israel’s border with Lebanon, a town of 23,000 that has been repeatedly subjected to violence during the decades of Arab-Israeli confrontations. But over the past year, it became known for something else — as the home of an upstart soccer team that somehow captured the championship of Israel’s top league and then just kept going.

headline: Lawyers Say Amish Acted Out of Compassion
text: CLEVELAND — Seeking to counter federal hate crime charges, defense lawyers for 16 Amish men and women on trial here said Tuesday that their clients had cut the beards and hair of perceived enemies out of compassion — trying, with admittedly misguided methods, to help them repent and see the true Amish way.

headline: Aug. 28: A Moment of Polling Clarity
text: At FiveThirtyEight, we’re usually consumed by how much the polls disagree with one another, and where the race stands once you filter through all that noise. But every now and then, the pollsters make our job easy.

headline: Rare Illness Has Killed 2 Lodgers at Yosemite
text: LOS ANGELES — With its bears, slippery rock walls and waterfalls, Yosemite National Park, where at least 18 people died last year, is known as a particularly dangerous patch of America the beautiful.

headline: Two Who Were No. 1 Want More Than Memories
text: Four years after they were the top two seeds in the 2008 United States Open, the Serbs Ana Ivanovic and Jelena Jankovic found themselves farther from the spotlight on Tuesday in Flushing Meadows.

headline: National Security to Star for a Night  at Democratic National Convention
text: WASHINGTON—The Obama camp, eager to showcase what officials view as the president’s sterling record on foreign policy (and Mitt Romney’s lack of experience on global issues), is designating a special night at the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte next week as national security night.

headline: Finding Your Ideal Running Form
text: Can people become better, more efficient runners on their own, merely by running?

headline: Word of the Day | discretion
text: discretion •\dis-ˈkre-shən\• noun

headline: García-López Savors an Upset
text: Guillermo García-López looked on his way to pulling off one of the biggest comebacks and upsets so far at the 2012 United States Open, reeling off the third and fourth sets and leading No. 10 Juan Monaco, 5-3, in the fifth at a boisterous Grandstand court.

headline: A Better Life Eternally Eluded the Boy From ‘The Corner’
text: BALTIMORE — In good times, DeAndre McCullough inspired nearly everyone he touched. He was a small-time drug dealer made good, a recovering addict who had a fledgling career counseling troubled teenagers. He played bit roles on HBO in “The Wire” and in “The Corner,” which chronicled his life in the drug trade at the age of 15.

headline: Fast Rise Built With Discipline
text: WASHINGTON — In the early 1990s, Tortilla Coast, a popular Capitol Hill watering hole, was staffed by ambitious young men and women flinging Tex-Mex and margaritas at patrons whose jobs in the nearby House and Senate office buildings they not so secretly coveted.

headline: At the Republican Convention, the Words Being Used
text: A look at how often speakers at the Republican National Convention have used different words, based on an analysis of transcripts from the Federal News Service.

headline: ESPN Extends M.L.B. Deal, Doubling What It Pays Yearly
text: ESPN flexed its financial muscles again Tuesday, extending its Major League Baseball rights for $5.6 billion from 2014 to 2021. At an average of $700 million annually, ESPN is doubling what it is now paying.

headline: Cellar Dweller in Japan Adds Pizazz, Not Victories
text: YOKOHAMA, Japan — It is fair to say that offering discounted tickets to men who come to the ballpark dressed in drag is an unconventional approach to filling seats. The same can be said of teams that offer fans a refund if they are unhappy with the game, even when the home team wins.

headline: Smoothing the Path From Foreign Lips to American Ears
text: Foreign graduate students at Ohio University “are spending up to two hours a day learning how to speak so that their American colleagues and students will understand them,” Richard Perez-Pena wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Stepping Out of a Husband’s Shadow, and Perhaps Overshadowing Him
text: She may be too good.

headline: China Slams Romney for ‘Pugnacious’ Policies
text: HONG KONG — The Republican Party was still battening down its hatches against Tropical Storm Isaac when Hurricane China began to lash Mitt Romney and the party’s proposed policies on Asia.

headline: A Hotel Is Romney Central (Cart Coming Through!)
text: An oversize golf cart zipped out of the porticoed driveway of the Marriott Waterside Hotel, spilling over with Romneys: Tagg, Ben, Craig and Craig’s wife, Mary. They playfully threatened to mow down passing journalists, laughing as they headed to a party in Ybor City.

headline: Quayle Loses House Primary in Redrawn Arizona District
text: PHOENIX — United States Representative Ben Quayle lost his bid for a second term in office on Tuesday, defeated by another first-term incumbent, Representative David Schweikert, in a nasty, costly and very competitive Republican primary in a newly drawn congressional district.

text: Ann Romney speaks about her husband, presidential candidate Mitt Romney, at the 2012 Republican National Convention.

text: A day-by-day recap of the conventions in Tampa, Fla., and Charlotte, N.C.

headline: News Quiz | August 29, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Digital Music Option Thrives, Though Quietly
text: The digital music company Spotify, which uses free song streams to lure people to paid subscriptions, has earned the music industry’s approval by making money from listeners who might otherwise use their computers to download songs illegally.

headline: Key Speeches From the Republican National Convention
text: An interactive look at the most talked-about speeches from the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla.

headline: The Case for Noblesse Oblige
text: One useful way to think about Mormon culture is to envision an outpost of old-fashioned Yankees dropped down in the Mountain West. The early Mormons were Anglo-Saxon Northeasterners who wended their way west, WASPs who dropped the Protestantism and added polygamy but otherwise kept many of the habits of their New York and New England forebears: a communitarian spirit and a flinty work ethic, and an attitude toward their own success that mixed self-effacement and noblesse oblige.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 29, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article “How Well You Sleep May Hinge on Race.”

headline: Cairo, City of Fights
text: CAIRO — In the best of times the hotel touts and papyrus vendors of Talaat Harb Square are persistent and sly. They sidle up to tourists with a smile and chitchat, until they’ve bonded just enough to pitch a souvenir or a tour of the Pyramids. By then the tourist can’t walk away without being rude.

headline: Death Sentence Upheld for Kasab
text: The Indian Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld the death sentence of Ajmal Kasab, the sole surviving gunman from the attacks that killed 166 people in Mumbai in November 2008.

headline: Tig Notaro Has Cancer. Go Ahead, Laugh.
text: Last month, you went onstage at Largo in Los Angeles and did a very unusual set. You told the audience how four months ago you contracted a life-threatening infection. Days after your release from the hospital, your mother died after a freak fall in her house. Shortly after that, you were given a diagnosis of Stage 2 breast cancer. You opened your set saying, “Thank you, I have cancer, thank you.” The crowd laughed. Did they know?  I don’t think a lot did, no. People were laughing, and I remember being onstage thinking, We’re all standing on this bridge and only I know that it’s about to collapse. And it did.

headline: Feel the Loathing on the Campaign Trail
text: Sometime early last May, I began to have this goofy notion, which turned into a daydream and eventually became a recurring fantasy. It went like this: One morning, I would wake up to the news that the previous evening, with no advance warning to the media, Mitt and Ann Romney stopped by the White House at the invitation of Barack and Michelle Obama. No one was certain what happened while they were there or what they talked about or how it came together, though eventually some details would trickle out. The couples told funny stories from the campaign trail and shared pictures of their families. Mitt drank lemonade, and Michelle led a moonlit tour of her garden. Everyone ate hot dogs loaded with toppings, which inspired a cable christening of the “Sauerkraut Summit.”

headline: Rethinking the Family Portrait
text: For most children, household rules are fairly simple. Love your family, take care of your things.

headline: Hurricane Isaac Reaches the Gulf Coast

headline: Tennessee Titans, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: What are we to make of the Tennessee Titans? Midway through August, they announced that 24-year-old Jake Locker would be their starting quarterback in Week 1. Locker will be playing in a more open, advanced system than what offensive coordinator Chris Palmer was able to run last season, and he’ll be throwing to first-round rookie receiver Kendall Wright. These seem like the makings of a team in rebuilding mode – or at least of a team looking to begin a new chapter.

headline: A Pop Queen Flaunts Her Toned Maturity
text: PHILADELPHIA — A ritual, a blood bath, slacklining, a partial striptease, drummers in midair, traditional Basque harmonies, a psychedelic train ride — they’re all part of Madonna’s “MDNA” tour, which started its North American itinerary with an arena concert here at the Wells Fargo Center on Tuesday night. It comes to Yankee Stadium next Thursday and Sept. 8.

headline: It’s Not Clear What Valet Offers, But It Wants $200 for It

headline: Taliban Kill at Least 8 Pakistani Soldiers in Ambush
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Taliban fighters armed with rifles and rocket launchers killed at least eight Pakistani soldiers during an ambush early on Wednesday in South Waziristan, near the Afghan border, military officials and Taliban commanders said.

headline: New Claim Rekindles Olof Palme Murder Mystery
text: LONDON — In a bizarre postscript to the death of Eva Rausing, the American-born billionaire who died in London of a suspected drug overdose in May, she is said to have left behind information that could help solve a 26-year-old murder mystery.
